verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:1
verses.text: The Letters of St.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:2
verses.text: Jerome.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:3
verses.text: Letter I.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:4
verses.text: To Innocent.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:6
verses.text: You have frequently asked me, dearest Innocent, not to pass over in silence the marvellous event which has happened in our own day.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:7
verses.text: I have declined the task from modesty and, as I now feel, with justice, believing myself to be incapable of it, at once because human language is inadequate to the divine praise, and because inactivity, acting like rust upon the intellect, has dried up any little power of expression that I have ever had.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:8
verses.text: You in reply urge that in the things of God we must look not at the work which we are able to accomplish, but at the spirit in which it is undertaken, and that he can never be at a loss for words who has believed on the Word.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:10
verses.text: What, then, must I do? The task is beyond me, and yet I dare not decline it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:11
verses.text: I am a mere unskilled passenger, and I find myself placed in charge of a freighted ship.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:12
verses.text: I have not so much as handled a rowboat on a lake, and now I have to trust myself to the noise and turmoil of the Euxine.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:13
verses.text: I see the shores sinking beneath the horizon, "sky and sea on every side"; darkness lowers over the water, the clouds are black as night, the waves only are white with foam.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:14
verses.text: You urge me to hoist the swelling sails, to loosen the sheets, and to take the helm.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:15
verses.text: At last I obey your commands, and as charity can do all things, I will trust in the Holy Ghost to guide my course, and I shall console myself, whatever the event.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:16
verses.text: For, if our ship is wafted by the surf into the wished-for haven, I shall be content to be told that the pilotage was poor.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:17
verses.text: But, if through my unpolished diction we run aground amid the rough cross-currents of language, you may blame my lack of power, but you will at least recognize my good intentions.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:19
verses.text: To begin, then: Vercellae is a Ligurian town, situated not far from the base of the Alps, once important, but now sparsely peopled and fallen into decay.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:20
verses.text: When the consular was holding his visitation there, a poor woman and her paramour were brought before him—the charge of adultery had been fastened upon them by the husband—and were both consigned to the penal horrors of a prison.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:21
verses.text: Shortly after an attempt was made to elicit the truth by torture, and when the blood-stained hook smote the young man's livid flesh and tore furrows in his side, the unhappy wretch sought to avoid prolonged pain by a speedy death.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:22
verses.text: Falsely accusing his own passions, he involved another in the charge; and it appeared that he was of all men the most miserable, and that his execution was just inasmuch as he had left to an innocent woman no means of self-defence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:23
verses.text: But the woman, stronger in virtue if weaker in sex, though her frame was stretched upon the rack, and though her hands, stained with the filth of the prison, were tied behind her, looked up to heaven with her eyes, which alone the torturer had been unable to bind, and while the tears rolled down her face, said: "Thou art witness, Lord Jesus, to whom nothing is hid, who triest the reins and the heart.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:24
verses.text: Thou art witness that it is not to save my life that I deny this charge.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:25
verses.text: I refuse to lie because to lie is sin.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:26
verses.text: And as for you, unhappy man, if you are bent on hastening your death, why must you destroy not one innocent person, but two? I also, myself, desire to die.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:27
verses.text: I desire to put off this hated body, but not as an adulteress.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:28
verses.text: I offer my neck; I welcome the shining sword without fear; yet I will take my innocence with me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:29
verses.text: He does not die who is slain while purposing so to live".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:31
verses.text: The consular, who had been feasting his eyes upon the bloody spectacle, now, like a wild beast, which after once tasting blood always thirsts for it, ordered the torture to be doubled, and cruelly gnashing his teeth, threatened the executioner with like punishment if he failed to extort from the weaker sex a confession which a man's strength had not been able to keep back.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:33
verses.text: Send help, Lord Jesus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:34
verses.text: For this one creature of Thine every species of torture is devised.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:35
verses.text: She is bound by the hair to a stake, her whole body is fixed more firmly than ever on the rack; fire is brought and applied to her feet; her sides quiver beneath the executioner's probe; even her breasts do not escape.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:36
verses.text: Still the woman remains unshaken; and, triumphing in spirit over the pain of the body, enjoys the happiness of a good conscience, round which the tortures rage in vain.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:37
verses.text: The cruel judge rises, overcome with passion.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:38
verses.text: She still prays to God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:39
verses.text: Her limbs are wrenched from their sockets; she only turns her eyes to heaven.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:40
verses.text: Another confesses what is thought their common guilt.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:41
verses.text: She, for the confessor's sake, denies the confession, and, in peril of her own life, clears one who is in peril of his.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:43
verses.text: Meantime she has but one thing to say: "Beat me, burn me, tear me, if you will; I have not done it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:44
verses.text: If you will not believe my words, a day will come when this charge shall be carefully sifted.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:45
verses.text: I have One who will judge me".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:46
verses.text: Wearied out at last, the torturer sighed in response to her groans; nor could he find a spot on which to inflict a fresh wound.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:47
verses.text: His cruelty overcome, he shuddered to see the body he had torn.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:48
verses.text: Immediately the consular cried, in a fit of passion, "Why does it surprise you, bystanders, that a woman prefers torture to death? It takes two people, most assuredly, to commit adultery; and I think it more credible that a guilty woman should deny a sin than that an innocent young man should confess one".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:50
verses.text: Like sentence, accordingly, was passed on both, and the condemned pair were dragged to execution.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:51
verses.text: The entire people poured out to see the sight; indeed, so closely were the gates thronged by the out-rushing crowd, that you might have fancied the city itself to be migrating.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:52
verses.text: At the very first stroke of the sword the head of the hapless youth was cut off, and the headless trunk rolled over in its blood.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:53
verses.text: Then came the woman's turn.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:54
verses.text: She knelt down upon the ground, and the shining sword was lifted over her quivering neck.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:55
verses.text: But though the headsman summoned all his strength into his bared arm, the moment it touched her flesh the fatal blade stopped short, and, lightly glancing over the skin, merely grazed it sufficiently to draw blood.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:56
verses.text: The striker saw, with terror, his hand unnerved, and, amazed at his defeated skill and at his drooping sword, he whirled it aloft for another stroke.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:57
verses.text: Again the blade fell forceless on the woman, sinking harmlessly on her neck, as though the steel feared to touch her.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:58
verses.text: The enraged and panting officer, who had thrown open his cloak at the neck to give his full strength to the blow, shook to the ground the brooch which clasped the edges of his mantle, and not noticing this, began to poise his sword for a fresh stroke.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:59
verses.text: "See," cried the woman, "a jewel has fallen from your shoulder.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:60
verses.text: Pick up what you have earned by hard toil, that you may not lose it".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:62
verses.text: What, I ask, is the secret of such confidence as this? Death draws near, but it has no terrors for her.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:63
verses.text: When smitten she exults, and the executioner turns pale.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:64
verses.text: Her eyes see the brooch, they fail to see the sword.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:65
verses.text: And, as if intrepidity in the presence of death were not enough, she confers a favor upon her cruel foe.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:66
verses.text: And now the mysterious Power of the Trinity rendered even a third blow vain.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:67
verses.text: The terrified soldier, no longer trusting the blade, proceeded to apply the point to her throat, in the idea that though it might not cut, the pressure of his hand might plunge it into her flesh.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:68
verses.text: Marvel unheard of through all the ages! The sword bent back to the hilt, and in its defeat looked to its master, as if confessing its inability to slay.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:70
verses.text: Let me call to my aid the example of the three children, who, amid the cool, encircling fire, sang hymns, instead of weeping, and around whose turbans and holy hair the flames played harmlessly.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:71
verses.text: Let me recall, too, the story of the blessed Daniel, in whose presence, though he was their natural prey, the lions crouched, with fawning tails and frightened mouths.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:72
verses.text: Let Susannah also rise in the nobility of her faith before the thoughts of all; who, after she had been condemned by an unjust sentence, was saved through a youth inspired by the Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:73
verses.text: In both cases the Lord's mercy was alike shewn; for while Susannah was set free by the judge, so as not to die by the sword, this woman, though condemned by the judge, was acquitted by the sword.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:75
verses.text: Now at length the populace rise in arms to defend the woman.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:76
verses.text: Men and women of every age join in driving away the executioner, shouting round him in a surging crowd.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:77
verses.text: Hardly a man dares trust his own eyes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:78
verses.text: The disquieting news reaches the city close at hand, and the entire force of constables is mustered.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:79
verses.text: The officer who is responsible for the execution of criminals bursts from among his men, and  Staining his hoary hair with soiling dust,  exclaims: "What! citizens, do you mean to seek my life? Do you intend to make me a substitute for her? However much your minds are set on mercy, and however much you wish to save a condemned woman, yet assuredly I—I who am innocent—ought not to perish".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:80
verses.text: His tearful appeal tells upon the crowd, they are all benumbed by the influence of sorrow, and an extraordinary change of feeling is manifested.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:81
verses.text: Before it had seemed a duty to plead for the woman's life, now it seemed a duty to allow her to be executed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:83
verses.text: Accordingly a new sword is fetched, a new headsman appointed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:84
verses.text: The victim takes her place, once more strengthened only with the favor of Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:85
verses.text: The first blow makes her quiver, beneath the second she sways to and fro, by the third she falls wounded to the ground.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:86
verses.text: Oh, majesty of the divine power highly to be extolled! She who previously had received four strokes without injury, now, a few moments later, seems to die that an innocent man may not perish in her stead.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:88
verses.text: Those of the clergy whose duty it is to wrap the blood-stained corpse in a winding-sheet, dig out the earth and, heaping together stones, form the customary tomb.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:89
verses.text: The sunset comes on quickly, and by God's mercy the night of nature arrives more swiftly than is its wont.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:90
verses.text: Suddenly the woman's bosom heaves, her eyes seek the light, her body is quickened into new life.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:91
verses.text: A moment after she sighs, she looks round, she gets up and speaks.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:92
verses.text: At last she is able to cry: "The Lord is on my side; I will not fear.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:93
verses.text: What can man do unto me?"  13.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:94
verses.text: Meantime an aged woman, supported out of the funds of the church, gave back her spirit to heaven from which it came.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:95
verses.text: It seemed as if the course of events had been thus purposely ordered, for her body took the place of the other beneath the mound.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:96
verses.text: In the gray dawn the devil comes on the scene in the form of a constable, asks for the corpse of her who had been slain, and desires to have her grave pointed out to him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:97
verses.text: Surprised that she could have died, he fancies her to be still alive.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:98
verses.text: The clergy show him the fresh turf, and meet his demands by pointing to the earth lately heaped up, taunting him with such words as these: "Yes, of course, tear up the bones which have been buried! Declare war anew against the tomb, and if even that does not satisfy you, pluck her limb from limb for birds and beasts to mangle! Mere dying is too good for one whom it took seven strokes to kill".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:100
verses.text: Before such opprobrious words the executioner retires in confusion, while the woman is secretly revived at home.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:101
verses.text: Then, lest the frequency of the doctor's visits to the church might give occasion for suspicion, they cut her hair short and send her in the company of some virgins to a sequestered country house.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:102
verses.text: There she changes her dress for that of a man, and scars form over her wounds.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:103
verses.text: Yet even after the great miracles worked on her behalf, the laws still rage against her.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:104
verses.text: So true is it that, where there is most law, there, there is also most injustice.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:106
verses.text: But now see whither the progress of my story has brought me; we come upon the name of our friend Evagrius.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:107
verses.text: So great have his exertions been in the cause of Christ that, were I to suppose it possible adequately to describe them, I should only show my own folly; and were I minded deliberately to pass them by, I still could not prevent my voice from breaking out into cries of joy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:108
verses.text: Who can fittingly praise the vigilance which enabled him to bury, if I may so say, before his death Auxentius of Milan, that curse brooding over the church? Or who can sufficiently extol the discretion with which he rescued the Roman bishop from the toils of the net in which he was fairly entangled, and showed him the means at once of overcoming his opponents and of sparing them in their discomfiture? But  Such topics I must leave to other bards,  Shut out by envious straits of time and space.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:109
verses.text: I am satisfied now to record the conclusion of my tale.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:110
verses.text: Evagrius seeks a special audience of the Emperor; importunes him with his entreaties, wins his favor by his services, and finally gains his cause through his earnestness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 1:111
verses.text: The Emperor restored to liberty the woman whom God had restored to life.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 2:1
verses.text: Letter II.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 2:2
verses.text: To Theodosius and the Rest of the Anchorites.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 2:3
verses.text: Written from Antioch, 374 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 2:4
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 2:5
verses.text: , while Jerome was still in doubt as to his future course.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 2:6
verses.text: Theodosius appears to have been the head of the solitaries in the Syrian Desert.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 2:7
verses.text: How I long to be a member of your company, and with uplifting of all my powers to embrace your admirable community! Though, indeed, these poor eyes are not worthy to look upon it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 2:8
verses.text: Oh! that I could behold the desert, lovelier to me than any city! Oh! that I could see those lonely spots made into a paradise by the saints that throng them! But since my sins prevent me from thrusting into your blessed company a head laden with every transgression, I adjure you (and I know that you can do it) by your prayers to deliver me from the darkness of this world.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 2:9
verses.text: I spoke of this when I was with you, and now in writing to you I repeat anew the same request; for all the energy of my mind is devoted to this one object.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 2:10
verses.text: It rests with you to give effect to my resolve.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 2:11
verses.text: I have the will but not the power; this last can only come in answer to your prayers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 2:12
verses.text: For my part, I am like a sick sheep astray from the flock.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 2:13
verses.text: Unless the good Shepherd shall place me on his shoulders and carry me back to the fold, my steps will totter, and in the very effort of rising I shall find my feet give way.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 2:14
verses.text: I am the prodigal son who although I have squandered all the portion entrusted to me by my father, have not yet bowed the knee in submission to him; not yet have I commenced to put away from me the allurements of my former excesses.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 2:15
verses.text: And because it is only a little while since I have begun not so much to abandon my vices as to desire to abandon them, the devil now ensnares me in new toils, he puts new stumbling-blocks in my path, he encompasses me on every side.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 2:16
verses.text: The seas around, and all around the main.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 2:17
verses.text: I find myself in mid-ocean, unwilling to retreat and unable to advance.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 2:18
verses.text: It only remains that your prayers should win for me the gale of the Holy Spirit to waft me to the haven upon the desired shore.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:1
verses.text: Letter III.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:2
verses.text: To Rufinus the Monk.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:3
verses.text: Written from Antioch, 374 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:4
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:5
verses.text: , to Rufinus in Egypt.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:6
verses.text: Jerome narrates his travels and the events which have taken place since his arrival in Syria, particularly the deaths of Innocent and Hylas (§3).

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:7
verses.text: He also describes the life of Bonosus, who was now a hermit on an island in the Adriatic (§4).

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:8
verses.text: The main object of the letter is to induce Rufinus to come to Syria.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:10
verses.text: That God gives more than we ask Him for, and that He often grants us things which "eye hath not seen nor ear heard, neither have they entered into the heart of man," I knew indeed before from the mystic declaration of the sacred volumes; but now, dearest Rufinus, I have had proof of it in my own case.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:11
verses.text: For I who fancied it too bold a wish to be allowed by an exchange of letters to counterfeit to myself your presence in the flesh, hear that you are penetrating the remotest parts of Egypt, visiting the monks and going round God's family upon earth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:12
verses.text: Oh, if only the Lord Jesus Christ would suddenly transport me to you as Philip was transported to the eunuch, and Habakkuk to Daniel, with what a close embrace would I clasp your neck, how fondly would I press kisses upon that mouth which has so often joined with me of old in error or in wisdom.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:13
verses.text: But as I am unworthy (not that you should so come to me but) that I should so come to you, and because my poor body, weak even when well, has been shattered by frequent illnesses; I send this letter to meet you instead of coming myself, in the hope that it may bring you hither to me caught in the meshes of love's net.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:15
verses.text: My first joy at such unexpected good tidings was due to our brother, Heliodorus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:16
verses.text: I desired to be sure of it, but did not dare to feel sure, especially as he told me that he had only heard it from some one else, and as the strangeness of the news impaired the credit of the story.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:17
verses.text: Once more my wishes hovered in uncertainty and my mind wavered, till an Alexandrian monk who had some time previously been sent over by the dutiful zeal of the people to the Egyptian confessors (in will already martyrs), impelled me by his presence to believe the tidings.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:18
verses.text: Even then, I must admit I still hesitated.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:19
verses.text: For on the one hand he knew nothing either of your name or country: yet on the other what he said seemed likely to be true, agreeing as it did with the hint which had already reached me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:20
verses.text: At last the truth broke upon me in all its fulness, for a constant stream of persons passing through brought the report: "Rufinus is at Nitria, and has reached the abode of the blessed Macarius".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:21
verses.text: At this point I cast away all that restrained my belief, and then first really grieved to find myself ill.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:22
verses.text: Had it not been that my wasted and enfeebled frame fettered my movements, neither the summer heat nor the dangerous voyage should have had power to retard the rapid steps of affection.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:23
verses.text: Believe me, brother, I look forward to seeing you more than the storm-tossed mariner looks for his haven, more than the thirsty fields long for the showers, more than the anxious mother sitting on the curving shore expects her son.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:25
verses.text: After that sudden whirlwind dragged me from your side, severing with its impious wrench the bonds of affection in which we were knit together,  The dark blue raincloud lowered o'er my head:  On all sides were the seas, on all the sky.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:26
verses.text: I wandered about, uncertain where to go.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:27
verses.text: Thrace, Pontus, Bithynia, the whole of Galatia and Cappadocia, Cilicia also with its burning heat, one after another shattered my energies.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:28
verses.text: At last Syria presented itself to me as a most secure harbor to a shipwrecked man.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:29
verses.text: Here, after undergoing every possible kind of sickness, I lost one of my two eyes; for Innocent, the half of my soul, was taken away from me by a sudden attack of fever.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:30
verses.text: The one eye which I now enjoy, and which is all in all to me, is our Evagrius, upon whom I with my constant infirmities have come as an additional burden.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:31
verses.text: We had with us also Hylas, the servant of the holy Melanium, who by his stainless conduct had wiped out the taint of his previous servitude.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:32
verses.text: His death opened afresh the wound which had not yet healed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:33
verses.text: But as the apostle's words forbid us to mourn for those who sleep, and as my excess of grief has been tempered by the joyful news that has since come to me, I recount this last, that, if you have not heard it, you may learn it; and that, if you know it already, you may rejoice over it with me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:35
verses.text: Bonosus, your friend, or, to speak more truly, mine as well as yours, is now climbing the ladder foreshown in Jacob's dream.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:36
verses.text: He is bearing his cross, neither taking thought for the morrow nor looking back at what he has left.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:37
verses.text: He is sowing in tears that he may reap in joy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:38
verses.text: As Moses in a type so he in reality is lifting up the serpent in the wilderness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:39
verses.text: This is a true story, and it may well put to shame the lying marvels described by Greek and Roman pens.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:40
verses.text: For here you have a youth educated with us in the refining accomplishments of the world, with abundance of wealth, and in rank inferior to none of his associates; yet he forsakes his mother, his sisters, and his dearly loved brother, and settles like a new tiller of Eden on a dangerous island, with the sea roaring round its reefs; while its rough crags, bare rocks, and desolate aspect make it more terrible still.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:41
verses.text: No peasant or monk is to be found there.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:42
verses.text: Even the little Onesimus you know of, in whose kisses he used to rejoice as in those of a brother, in this tremendous solitude no longer remains at his side.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:43
verses.text: Alone upon the island—or rather not alone, for Christ is with him—he sees the glory of God, which even the apostles saw not save in the desert.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:44
verses.text: He beholds, it is true, no embattled towns, but he has enrolled his name in the new city.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:45
verses.text: Garments of sackcloth disfigure his limbs, yet so clad he will be the sooner caught up to meet Christ in the clouds.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:46
verses.text: No watercourse pleasant to the view supplies his wants, but from the Lord's side he drinks the water of life.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:47
verses.text: Place all this before your eyes, dear friend, and with all the faculties of your mind picture to yourself the scene.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:48
verses.text: When you realize the effort of the fighter then you will be able to praise his victory.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:49
verses.text: Round the entire island roars the frenzied sea, while the beetling crags along its winding shores resound as the billows beat against them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:50
verses.text: No grass makes the ground green; there are no shady copses and no fertile fields.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:51
verses.text: Precipitous cliffs surround his dreadful abode as if it were a prison.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:52
verses.text: But he, careless, fearless, and armed from head to foot with the apostle's armor, now listens to God by reading the Scriptures, now speaks to God as he prays to the Lord; and it may be that, while he lingers in the island, he sees some vision such as that once seen by John.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:54
verses.text: What snares, think you, is the devil now weaving? What stratagems is he preparing? Perchance, mindful of his old trick, he will try to tempt Bonosus with hunger.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:55
verses.text: But he has been answered already: "Man shall not live by bread alone".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:56
verses.text: Perchance he will lay before him wealth and fame.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:57
verses.text: But it shall be said to him: "They that desire to be rich fall into a trap and temptations," and "For me all glorying is in Christ".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:58
verses.text: He will come, it may be, when the limbs are weary with fasting, and rack them with the pangs of disease; but the cry of the apostle will repel him: "When I am weak, then am I strong," and "My strength is made perfect in weakness".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:59
verses.text: He will hold out threats of death; but the reply will be: "I desire to depart and to be with Christ".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:60
verses.text: He will brandish his fiery darts, but they will be received on the shield of faith.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:61
verses.text: In a word, Satan will assail him, but Christ will defend.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:62
verses.text: Thanks be to Thee, Lord Jesus, that in Thy day I have one able to pray to Thee for me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:63
verses.text: To Thee all hearts are open, Thou searchest the secrets of the heart, Thou seest the prophet shut up in the fish's belly in the midst of the sea.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:64
verses.text: Thou knowest then how he and I grew up together from tender infancy to vigorous manhood, how we were fostered in the bosoms of the same nurses, and carried in the arms of the same bearers; and how after studying together at Rome we lodged in the same house and shared the same food by the half savage banks of the Rhine.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:65
verses.text: Thou knowest, too, that it was I who first began to seek to serve Thee.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:66
verses.text: Remember, I beseech Thee, that this warrior of Thine was once a raw recruit with me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:67
verses.text: I have before me the declaration of Thy majesty: "Whosoever shall teach and not do shall be called least in the kingdom of heaven".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:68
verses.text: May he enjoy the crown of virtue, and in return for his daily martyrdoms may he follow the Lamb robed in white raiment! For "in my Father's house are many mansions," and "one star differeth from another star in glory".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:69
verses.text: Give me strength to raise my head to a level with the saints' heels! I willed, but he performed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:70
verses.text: Do Thou therefore pardon me that I failed to keep my resolve, and reward him with the guerdon of his deserts.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:71
verses.text: I may perhaps have been tedious, and have said more than the short compass of a letter usually allows; but this, I find, is always the case with me when I have to say anything in praise of our dear Bonosus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:73
verses.text: However, to return to the point from which I set out, I beseech you do not let me pass wholly out of sight and out of mind.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:74
verses.text: A friend is long sought, hardly found, and with difficulty kept.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:75
verses.text: Let those who will, allow gold to dazzle them and be borne along in splendor, their very baggage glittering with gold and silver.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:76
verses.text: Love is not to be purchased, and affection has no price.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:77
verses.text: The friendship which can cease has never been real.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 3:78
verses.text: Farewell in Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 4:1
verses.text: Letter IV.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 4:2
verses.text: To Florentius.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 4:3
verses.text: Sent to Florentius along with the preceding letter, which Jerome requests him to deliver to Rufinus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 4:4
verses.text: This Florentius was a rich Italian who had retired to Jerusalem to pursue the monastic life.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 4:5
verses.text: Jerome subsequently speaks of him as "a distinguished monk so pitiful to the needy that he was generally known as the father of the poor".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 4:6
verses.text: (Chron.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 4:7
verses.text: ad a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 4:8
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 4:11
verses.text: How much your name and sanctity are on the lips of the most different peoples you may gather from the fact that I commence to love you before I know you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 4:12
verses.text: For as, according to the apostle, "Some men's sins are evident going before unto judgment," so contrariwise the report of your charity is so widespread that it is considered not so much praiseworthy to love you as criminal to refuse to do so.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 4:13
verses.text: I pass over the countless instances in which you have supported Christ, fed, clothed, and visited Him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 4:14
verses.text: The aid you rendered to our brother Heliodorus in his need may well loose the utterance of the dumb.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 4:15
verses.text: With what gratitude, with what commendation, does he speak of the kindness with which you smoothed a pilgrim's path.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 4:16
verses.text: I am, it is true, the most sluggish of men, consumed by an unendurable sickness; yet keen affection and desire have winged my feet, and I have come forward to salute and embrace you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 4:17
verses.text: I wish you every good thing, and pray that the Lord may establish our nascent friendship.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 4:19
verses.text: Our brother, Rufinus, is said to have come from Egypt to Jerusalem with the devout lady, Melanium.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 4:20
verses.text: He is inseparably bound to me in brotherly love; and I beg you to oblige me by delivering to him the annexed letter.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 4:21
verses.text: You must not, however, judge of me by the virtues that you find in him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 4:22
verses.text: For in him you will see the clearest tokens of holiness, whilst I am but dust and vile dirt, and even now, while still living, nothing but ashes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 4:23
verses.text: It is enough for me if my weak eyes can bear the brightness of his excellence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 4:24
verses.text: He has but now washed himself and is clean, yea, is made white as snow; whilst I, stained with every sin, wait day and night with trembling to pay the uttermost farthing.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 4:25
verses.text: But since "the Lord looseth the prisoners," and resteth upon him who is of a contrite spirit, and that trembleth at His words, perchance he may say even to me who lie in the grave of sin: "Jerome, come forth".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 4:26
verses.text: The reverend presbyter, Evagrius, warmly salutes you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 4:27
verses.text: We both with united respect salute the brother, Martinianus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 4:28
verses.text: I desire much to see him, but I am impeded by the chain of sickness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 4:29
verses.text: Farewell in Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 5:1
verses.text: Letter V.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 5:2
verses.text: To Florentius.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 5:3
verses.text: Written a few months after the preceding (about the end of 374 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 5:4
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 5:5
verses.text: ) from the Syrian Desert.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 5:6
verses.text: After dilating on his friendship for Florentius, and making a passing allusion to Rufinus, Jerome mentions certain books, copies of which he desires to be sent to him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 5:7
verses.text: He also speaks of a runaway slave about whom Florentius had written to him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 5:9
verses.text: Your letter, dear friend, finds me dwelling in that quarter of the desert which is nearest to Syria and the Saracens.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 5:10
verses.text: And the reading of it rekindles in my mind so keen a desire to set out for Jerusalem that I am almost ready to violate my monastic vow in order to gratify my affection.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 5:11
verses.text: Wishing to do the best I can, as I cannot come in person I send you a letter instead; and thus, though absent in the body, I come to you in love and in spirit.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 5:12
verses.text: For my earnest prayer is that our infant friendship, firmly cemented as it is in Christ, may never be rent asunder by time or distance.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 5:13
verses.text: We ought rather to strengthen the bond by an interchange of letters.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 5:14
verses.text: Let these pass between us, meet each other on the way, and converse with us.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 5:15
verses.text: Affection will not lose much if it keeps up an intercourse of this kind.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 5:17
verses.text: You write that our brother, Rufinus, has not yet come to you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 5:18
verses.text: Even if he does come it will do little to satisfy my longing, for I shall not now be able to see him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 5:19
verses.text: He is too far away to come hither, and the conditions of the lonely life that I have adopted forbid me to go to him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 5:20
verses.text: For I am no longer free to follow my own wishes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 5:21
verses.text: I entreat you, therefore, to ask him to allow you to have the commentaries of the reverend Rhetitius, bishop of Augustodunum, copied, in which he has so eloquently explained the Song of Songs.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 5:22
verses.text: A countryman of the aforesaid brother Rufinus, the old man Paul, writes that Rufinus has his copy of Tertullian, and urgently requests that this may be returned.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 5:23
verses.text: Next I have to ask you to get written on paper by a copyist certain books which the subjoined list will show you that I do not possess.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 5:24
verses.text: I beg also that you will send me the explanation of the Psalms of David, and the copious work on Synods of the reverend Hilary, which I copied for him at Trêves with my own hand.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 5:25
verses.text: Such books, you know, must be the food of the Christian soul if it is to meditate in the law of the Lord day and night.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 5:26
verses.text: Others you welcome beneath your roof, you cherish and comfort, you help out of your own purse; but so far as I am concerned, you have given me everything when once you have granted my request.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 5:27
verses.text: And since, through the Lord's bounty, I am rich in volumes of the sacred library, you may command me in turn.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 5:28
verses.text: I will send you what you please; and do not suppose that an order from you will give me trouble.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 5:29
verses.text: I have pupils devoted to the art of copying.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 5:30
verses.text: Nor do I merely promise a favor because I am asking one.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 5:31
verses.text: Our brother, Heliodorus, tells me that there are many parts of the Scriptures which you seek and cannot find.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 5:32
verses.text: But even if you have them all, affection is sure to assert its rights and to seek for itself more than it already has.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 5:34
verses.text: As regards the present master of your slave—of whom you have done me the honor to write—I have no doubt but that he is his kidnapper.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 5:35
verses.text: While I was still at Antioch the presbyter, Evagrius, often reproved him in my presence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 5:36
verses.text: To whom he made this answer: "I have nothing to fear".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 5:37
verses.text: He declares that his master has dismissed him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 5:38
verses.text: If you both want him, he is here; send him whither you will.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 5:39
verses.text: I think I am not wrong in refusing to allow a runaway to stray farther.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 5:40
verses.text: Here in the wilderness I cannot myself execute your orders; and therefore I have asked my dear friend Evagrius to push the affair vigorously, both for your sake and for mine.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 5:41
verses.text: I desire your welfare in Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 6:1
verses.text: Letter VI.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 6:2
verses.text: To Julian, a Deacon of Antioch.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 6:3
verses.text: This letter, written in 374 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 6:4
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 6:5
verses.text: , is chiefly interesting for its mention of Jerome's sister.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 6:6
verses.text: It would seem that she had fallen into sin and had been restored to a life of virtue by the deacon, Julian.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 6:7
verses.text: Jerome speaks of her again in the next letter (§4).

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 6:8
verses.text: It is an old saying, "Liars are disbelieved even when they speak the truth".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 6:9
verses.text: And from the way in which you reproach me for not having written, I perceive that this has been my lot with you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 6:10
verses.text: Shall I say, "I wrote often, but the bearers of my letters were negligent"? You will reply, "Your excuse is the old one of all who fail to write".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 6:11
verses.text: Shall I say, "I could not find any one to take my letters"? You will say that numbers of persons have gone from my part of the world to yours.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 6:12
verses.text: Shall I contend that I have actually given them letters? They not having delivered them, will deny that they have received them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 6:13
verses.text: Moreover, so great a distance separates us that it will be hard to come at the truth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 6:14
verses.text: What shall I do then? Though really not to blame, I ask your forgiveness, for I think it better to fall back and make overtures for peace than to keep my ground and offer battle.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 6:15
verses.text: The truth is that constant sickness of body and vexation of mind have so weakened me that with death so close at hand I have not been as collected as usual.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 6:16
verses.text: And lest you should account this plea a false one, now that I have stated my case, I shall, like a pleader, call witnesses to prove it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 6:17
verses.text: Our reverend brother, Heliodorus, has been here; but in spite of his wish to dwell in the desert with me, he has been frightened away by my crimes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 6:18
verses.text: But my present wordiness will atone for my past remissness; for, as Horace says in his satire:  All singers have one fault among their friends:  They never sing when asked, unasked they never cease.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 6:19
verses.text: Henceforth I shall overwhelm you with such bundles of letters that you will take the opposite line and beg me not to write.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 6:20
verses.text: I rejoice that my sister—to you a daughter in Christ—remains steadfast in her purpose, a piece of news which I owe in the first instance to you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 6:21
verses.text: For here where I now am I am ignorant not only as to what goes on in my native land, but even as to its continued existence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 6:22
verses.text: Even though the Iberian viper shall rend me with his baneful fangs, I will not fear men's judgment, seeing that I shall have God to judge me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 6:23
verses.text: As one puts it:  Shatter the world to fragments if you will:  'Twill fall upon a head which knows not fear.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 6:24
verses.text: Bear in mind, then, I pray you, the apostle's precept that we should make our work abiding; prepare for yourself a reward from the Lord in my sister's salvation; and by frequent letters increase my joy in that glory in Christ which we share together.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:1
verses.text: Letter VII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:2
verses.text: To Chromatius, Jovinus, and Eusebius.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:3
verses.text: This letter (written like the preceding in 374 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:4
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:5
verses.text: ) is addressed by Jerome to three of his former companions in the religious life.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:6
verses.text: It commends Bonosus (§3), asks guidance for the writer's sister (§4), and attacks the conduct of Lupicinus, Bishop of Stridon (§5).

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:8
verses.text: Those whom mutual affection has joined together, a written page ought not to sunder.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:9
verses.text: I must not, therefore, distribute my words some to one and some to another.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:10
verses.text: For so strong is the love that binds you together that affection unites all three of you in a bond no less close than that which naturally connects two of your number.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:11
verses.text: Indeed, if the conditions of writing would only admit of it, I should amalgamate your names and express them under a single symbol.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:12
verses.text: The very letter which I have received from you challenges me in each of you to see all three, and in all three to recognize each.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:13
verses.text: When the reverend Evagrius transmitted it to me in the corner of the desert which stretches between the Syrians and the Saracens, my joy was intense.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:14
verses.text: It wholly surpassed the rejoicings felt at Rome when the defeat of Cannae was retrieved, and Marcellus at Nola cut to pieces the forces of Hannibal.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:15
verses.text: Evagrius frequently comes to see me, and cherishes me in Christ as his own bowels.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:16
verses.text: Yet as he is separated from me by a long distance, his departure has generally left me as much regret as his arrival has brought me joy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:18
verses.text: I converse with your letter, I embrace it, it talks to me; it alone of those here speaks Latin.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:19
verses.text: For hereabout you must either learn a barbarous jargon or else hold your tongue.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:20
verses.text: As often as the lines—traced in a well-known hand—bring back to me the faces which I hold so dear, either I am no longer here, or else you are here with me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:21
verses.text: If you will credit the sincerity of affection, I seem to see you all as I write this.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:22
verses.text: Now at the outset I should like to ask you one petulant question.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:23
verses.text: Why is it that, when we are separated by so great an interval of land and sea, you have sent me so short a letter? Is it that I have deserved no better treatment, not having first written to you? I cannot believe that paper can have failed you while Egypt continues to supply its wares.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:24
verses.text: Even if a Ptolemy had closed the seas, King Attalus would still have sent you parchments from Pergamum, and so by his skins you could have made up for the want of paper.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:25
verses.text: The very name parchment is derived from a historical incident of the kind which occurred generations ago.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:26
verses.text: What then? Am I to suppose the messenger to have been in haste? No matter how long a letter may be, it can be written in the course of a night.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:27
verses.text: Or had you some business to attend to which prevented you from writing? No claim is prior to that of affection.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:28
verses.text: Two suppositions remain, either that you felt disinclined to write or else that I did not deserve a letter.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:29
verses.text: Of the two I prefer to charge you with sloth than to condemn myself as undeserving.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:30
verses.text: For it is easier to mend neglect than to quicken love.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:32
verses.text: You tell me that Bonosus, like a true son of the Fish, has taken to the water.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:33
verses.text: As for me who am still foul with my old stains, like the basilisk and the scorpion I haunt the dry places.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:34
verses.text: Bonosus has his heel already on the serpent's head, whilst I am still as food to the same serpent which by divine appointment devours the earth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:35
verses.text: He can scale already that ladder of which the psalms of degrees are a type; whilst I, still weeping on its first step, hardly know whether I shall ever be able to say: "I will lift up mine eyes unto the hills, from whence cometh my help".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:36
verses.text: Amid the threatening billows of the world he is sitting in the safe shelter of his island, that is, of the church's pale, and it may be that even now, like John, he is being called to eat God's book; whilst I, still lying in the sepulchre of my sins and bound with the chains of my iniquities, wait for the Lord's command in the Gospel: "Jerome, come forth".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:37
verses.text: But Bonosus has done more than this.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:38
verses.text: Like the prophet he has carried his girdle across the Euphrates (for all the devil's strength is in the loins), and has hidden it there in a hole of the rock.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:39
verses.text: Then, afterwards finding it rent, he has sung: "O Lord, thou hast possessed my reins.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:40
verses.text: Thou hast broken my bonds in sunder.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:41
verses.text: I will offer to thee the sacrifice of thanksgiving".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:42
verses.text: But as for me, Nebuchadnezzar has brought me in chains to Babylon, to the babel that is of a distracted mind.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:43
verses.text: There he has laid upon me the yoke of captivity; there inserting in my nostrils a ring of iron, he has commanded me to sing one of the songs of Zion.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:44
verses.text: To whom I have said, "The Lord looseth the prisoners; the Lord openeth the eyes of the blind".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:45
verses.text: To complete my contrast in a single sentence, whilst I pray for mercy Bonosus looks for a crown.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:47
verses.text: My sister's conversion is the fruit of the efforts of the saintly Julian.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:48
verses.text: He has planted, it is for you to water, and the Lord will give the increase.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:49
verses.text: Jesus Christ has given her to me to console me for the wound which the devil has inflicted on her.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:50
verses.text: He has restored her from death to life.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:51
verses.text: But in the words of the pagan poet, for her  There is no safety that I do not fear.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:52
verses.text: You know yourselves how slippery is the path of youth—a path on which I have myself fallen, and which you are now traversing not without fear.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:53
verses.text: She, as she enters upon it, must have the advice and the encouragement of all, she must be aided by frequent letters from you, my reverend brothers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:54
verses.text: And—for "charity endureth all things,"—I beg you to get from Pope Valerian a letter to confirm her resolution.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:55
verses.text: A girl's courage, as you know, is strengthened when she realizes that persons in high place are interested in her.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:57
verses.text: The fact is that my native land is a prey to barbarism, that in it men's only God is their belly, that they live only for the present, and that the richer a man is the holier he is held to be.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:58
verses.text: Moreover, to use a well-worn proverb, the dish has a cover worthy of it; for Lupicinus is their priest.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:59
verses.text: Like lips like lettuce, as the saying goes—the only one, as Lucilius tells us, at which Crassus ever laughed—the reference being to a donkey eating thistles.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:60
verses.text: What I mean is that an unstable pilot steers a leaking ship, and that the blind is leading the blind straight to the pit.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:61
verses.text: The ruler is like the ruled.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:63
verses.text: I salute your mother and mine with the respect which, as you know, I feel towards her.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:64
verses.text: Associated with you as she is in a holy life, she has the start of you, her holy children, in that she is your mother.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:65
verses.text: Her womb may thus be truly called golden.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:66
verses.text: With her I salute your sisters, who ought all to be welcomed wherever they go, for they have triumphed over their sex and the world, and await the Bridegroom's coming, their lamps replenished with oil.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:67
verses.text: O happy the house which is a home of a widowed Anna, of virgins that are prophetesses, and of twin Samuels bred in the Temple! Fortunate the roof which shelters the martyr-mother of the Maccabees, with her sons around her, each and all wearing the martyr's crown! For although you confess Christ every day by keeping His commandments, yet to this private glory you have added the public one of an open confession; for it was through you that the poison of the Arian heresy was formerly banished from your city.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:68
verses.text: You are surprised perhaps at my thus making a fresh beginning quite at the close of my letter.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:69
verses.text: But what am I to do? I cannot refuse expression to my feelings.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:70
verses.text: The brief limits of a letter compel me to be silent; my affection for you urges me to speak.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 7:71
verses.text: I write in haste, my language is confused and ill-arranged; but love knows nothing of order.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 8:1
verses.text: Letter VIII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 8:2
verses.text: To Niceas, Sub-Deacon of Aquileia.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 8:3
verses.text: Niceas, the sub-deacon, had accompanied Jerome to the East but had now returned home.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 8:4
verses.text: In after-years he became bishop of Aquileia in succession to Chromatius.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 8:5
verses.text: The date of the letter is 374 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 8:6
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 8:7
verses.text: The comic poet Turpilius says of the exchange of letters that it alone makes the absent present.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 8:8
verses.text: The remark, though occurring in a work of fiction, is not untrue.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 8:9
verses.text: For what more real presence—if I may so speak—can there be between absent friends than speaking to those whom they love in letters, and in letters hearing their reply? Even those Italian savages, the Cascans of Ennius, who—as Cicero tells us in his books on rhetoric—hunted their food like beasts of prey, were wont, before paper and parchment came into use, to exchange letters written on tablets of wood roughly planed, or on strips of bark torn from the trees.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 8:10
verses.text: For this reason men called letter-carriers tablet-bearers, and letter-writers bark-users, because they used the bark of trees.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 8:11
verses.text: How much more then are we, who live in a civilized age, bound not to omit a social duty performed by men who lived in a state of gross savagery, and were in some respects entirely ignorant of the refinements of life.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 8:12
verses.text: The saintly Chromatius, look you, and the reverend Eusebius, brothers as much by compatibility of disposition as by the ties of nature, have challenged me to diligence by the letters which they have showered upon me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 8:13
verses.text: You, however, who have but just left me, have not merely unknit our new-made friendship; you have torn it asunder—a process which Laelius, in Cicero's treatise, wisely forbids.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 8:14
verses.text: Can it be that the East is so hateful to you that you dread the thought of even your letters coming hither? Wake up, wake up, arouse yourself from sleep, give to affection at least one sheet of paper.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 8:15
verses.text: Amid the pleasures of life at home sometimes heave a sigh over the journeys which we have made together.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 8:16
verses.text: If you love me, write in answer to my prayer.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 8:17
verses.text: If you are angry with me, though angry still write.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 8:18
verses.text: I find my longing soul much comforted when I receive a letter from a friend, even though that friend be out of temper with me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 9:1
verses.text: Letter IX.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 9:2
verses.text: To Chrysogonus, a Monk of Aquileia.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 9:3
verses.text: A bantering letter to an indifferent correspondent.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 9:4
verses.text: Of the same date as the preceding.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 9:5
verses.text: Heliodorus, who is so dear to us both, and who loves you with an affection no less deep than my own, may have given you a faithful account of my feelings towards you; how your name is always on my lips, and how in every conversation which I have with him I begin by recalling my pleasant intercourse with you, and go on to marvel at your lowliness, to extol your virtue, and to proclaim your holy love.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 9:6
verses.text: Lynxes, they say, when they look behind them, forget what they have just seen, and lose all thought of what their eyes have ceased to behold.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 9:7
verses.text: And so it seems to be with you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 9:8
verses.text: For so entirely have you forgotten our joint attachment that you have not merely blurred but erased the writing of that epistle which, as the apostle tells us, is written in the hearts of Christians.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 9:9
verses.text: The creatures that I have mentioned lurk on branches of leafy trees and pounce on fleet roes or frightened stags.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 9:10
verses.text: In vain their victims fly, for they carry their tormentors with them, and these rend their flesh as they run.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 9:11
verses.text: Lynxes, however, only hunt when an empty belly makes their mouths dry.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 9:12
verses.text: When they have satisfied their thirst for blood, and have filled their stomachs with food, satiety induces forgetfulness, and they bestow no thought on future prey till hunger recalls them to a sense of their need.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 9:13
verses.text: Now in your case it cannot be that you have already had enough of me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 9:14
verses.text: Why then do you bring to a premature close a friendship which is but just begun? Why do you let slip what you have hardly as yet fully grasped? But as such remissness as yours is never at a loss for an excuse, you will perhaps declare that you had nothing to write.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 9:15
verses.text: Had this been so, you should still have written to inform me of the fact.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 10:1
verses.text: Letter X.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 10:2
verses.text: To Paul, an Old Man of Concordia.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 10:3
verses.text: Jerome writes to Paul of Concordia, a centenarian (§2), and the owner of a good theological library (§3), to lend him some commentaries.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 10:4
verses.text: In return he sends him his life (newly written) of Paul the hermit.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 10:5
verses.text: The date of the letter is 374 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 10:6
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 10:8
verses.text: The shortness of man's life is the punishment for man's sin; and the fact that even on the very threshold of the light death constantly overtakes the new-born child proves that the times are continually sinking into deeper depravity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 10:9
verses.text: For when the first tiller of paradise had been entangled by the serpent in his snaky coils, and had been forced in consequence to migrate earthwards, although his deathless state was changed for a mortal one, yet the sentence of man's curse was put off for nine hundred years, or even more, a period so long that it may be called a second immortality.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 10:10
verses.text: Afterwards sin gradually grew more and more virulent, till the ungodliness of the giants brought in its train the shipwreck of the whole world.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 10:11
verses.text: Then when the world had been cleansed by the baptism—if I may so call it—of the deluge, human life was contracted to a short span.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 10:12
verses.text: Yet even this we have almost altogether wasted, so continually do our iniquities fight against the divine purposes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 10:13
verses.text: For how few there are, either who go beyond their hundredth year, or who, going beyond it, do not regret that they have done so; according to that which the Scripture witnesses in the book of Psalms: "the days of our years are threescore years and ten; and if by reason of strength they be fourscore years, yet is their strength labor and sorrow".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 10:15
verses.text: Why, say you, these opening reflections so remote and so far fetched that one might use against them the Horatian witticism:  Back to the eggs which Leda laid for Zeus,  The bard is fain to trace the war of Troy?  Simply that I may describe in fitting terms your great age and hoary head as white as Christ's.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 10:16
verses.text: For see, the hundredth circling year is already passing over you, and yet, always keeping the commandments of the Lord, amid the circumstances of your present life you think over the blessedness of that which is to come.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 10:17
verses.text: Your eyes are bright and keen, your steps steady, your hearing good, your teeth are white, your voice musical, your flesh firm and full of sap; your ruddy cheeks belie your white hairs, your strength is not that of your age.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 10:18
verses.text: Advancing years have not, as we too often see them do, impaired the tenacity of your memory; the coldness of your blood has not blunted an intellect at once warm and wary.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 10:19
verses.text: Your face is not wrinkled nor your brow furrowed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 10:20
verses.text: Lastly, no tremors palsy your hand or cause it to travel in crooked pathways over the wax on which you write.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 10:21
verses.text: The Lord shows us in you the bloom of the resurrection that is to be ours; so that whereas in others who die by inches whilst yet living, we recognize the results of sin, in your case we ascribe it to righteousness that you still simulate youth at an age to which it is foreign.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 10:22
verses.text: And although we see the like haleness of body in many even of those who are sinners, in their case it is a grant of the devil to lead them into sin, whilst in yours it is a gift of God to make you rejoice.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 10:24
verses.text: Tully in his brilliant speech on behalf of Flaccus describes the learning of the Greeks as "innate frivolity and accomplished vanity".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 10:25
verses.text: Certainly their ablest literary men used to receive money for pronouncing eulogies upon their kings or princes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 10:26
verses.text: Following their example, I set a price upon my praise.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 10:27
verses.text: Nor must you suppose my demand a small one.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 10:28
verses.text: You are asked to give me the pearl of the Gospel, "the words of the Lord," "pure words, even as the silver which from the earth is tried, and purified seven times in the fire," I mean the commentaries of Fortunatian and—for its account of the persecutors—the History of Aurelius Victor, and with these the Letters of Novatian; so that, learning the poison set forth by this schismatic, we may the more gladly drink of the antidote supplied by the holy martyr Cyprian.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 10:29
verses.text: In the mean time I have sent to you, that is to say, to Paul the aged, a Paul that is older still.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 10:30
verses.text: I have taken great pains to bring my language down to the level of the simpler sort.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 10:31
verses.text: But, somehow or other, though you fill it with water, the jar retains the odor which it acquired when first used.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 10:32
verses.text: If my little gift should please you, I have others also in store which (if the Holy Spirit shall breathe favorably), shall sail across the sea to you with all kinds of eastern merchandise.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 11:1
verses.text: Letter XI.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 11:2
verses.text: To the Virgins of aemona.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 11:3
verses.text: aemona was a Roman colony not far from Stridon, Jerome's birthplace.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 11:4
verses.text: The virgins to whom the note is addressed had omitted to answer his letters, and he now writes to upbraid them for their remissness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 11:5
verses.text: The date of the letter is 374 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 11:6
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 11:7
verses.text: This scanty sheet of paper shows in what a wilderness I live, and because of it I have to say much in few words.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 11:8
verses.text: For, desirous though I am to speak to you more fully, this miserable scrap compels me to leave much unsaid.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 11:9
verses.text: Still ingenuity makes up for lack of means, and by writing small I can say a great deal.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 11:10
verses.text: Observe, I beseech you, how I love you, even in the midst of my difficulties, since even the want of materials does not stop me from writing to you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 11:11
verses.text: Pardon, I beseech you, an aggrieved man: if I speak in tears and in anger it is because I have been injured.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 11:12
verses.text: For in return for my regular letters you have not sent me a single syllable.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 11:13
verses.text: Light, I know, has no communion with darkness, and God's handmaidens no fellowship with a sinner, yet a harlot was allowed to wash the Lord's feet with her tears, and dogs are permitted to eat of their masters' crumbs.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 11:14
verses.text: It was the Saviour's mission to call sinners and not the righteous; for, as He said Himself, "they that be whole need not a physician".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 11:15
verses.text: He wills the repentance of a sinner rather than his death, and carries home the poor stray sheep on His own shoulders.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 11:16
verses.text: So, too, when the prodigal son returns, his father receives him with joy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 11:17
verses.text: Nay more, the apostle says: "Judge nothing before the time".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 11:18
verses.text: For "who art thou that judgest another man's servant? To his own master he standeth or falleth".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 11:19
verses.text: And "let him that standeth take heed lest he fall".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 11:20
verses.text: "Bear ye one another's burdens".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 11:21
verses.text: Dear sisters, man's envy judges in one way, Christ in another; and the whisper of a corner is not the same as the sentence of His tribunal.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 11:22
verses.text: Many ways seem right to men which are afterwards found to be wrong.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 11:23
verses.text: And a treasure is often stowed in earthen vessels.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 11:24
verses.text: Peter thrice denied his Lord, yet his bitter tears restored him to his place.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 11:25
verses.text: "To whom much is forgiven, the same loveth much".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 11:26
verses.text: No word is said of the flock as a whole, yet the angels joy in heaven over the safety of one sick ewe.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 11:27
verses.text: And if any one demurs to this reasoning, the Lord Himself has said: "Friend, is thine eye evil because I am good?".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 12:1
verses.text: Letter XII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 12:2
verses.text: To Antony, Monk.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 12:3
verses.text: The subject of this letter is similar to that of the preceding.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 12:4
verses.text: Of Antony nothing is known except that some mss.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 12:5
verses.text: describe him as "of aemona".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 12:6
verses.text: The date of the letter is 374 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 12:7
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 12:8
verses.text: While the disciples were disputing concerning precedence our Lord, the teacher of humility, took a little child and said: "Except ye be converted and become as little children ye cannot enter the kingdom of heaven".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 12:9
verses.text: And lest He should seem to preach more than he practised, He fulfilled His own precept in His life.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 12:10
verses.text: For He washed His disciples' feet, he received the traitor with a kiss, He conversed with the woman of Samaria, He spoke of the kingdom of heaven with Mary at His feet, and when He rose again from the dead He showed Himself first to some poor women.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 12:11
verses.text: Pride is opposed to humility, and through it Satan lost his eminence as an archangel.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 12:12
verses.text: The Jewish people perished in their pride, for while they claimed the chief seats and salutations in the market place, they were superseded by the Gentiles, who had before been counted as "a drop of a bucket".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 12:13
verses.text: Two poor fishermen, Peter and James, were sent to confute the sophists and the wise men of the world.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 12:14
verses.text: As the Scripture says: "God resisteth the proud and giveth grace to the humble".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 12:15
verses.text: Think, brother, what a sin it must be which has God for its opponent.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 12:16
verses.text: In the Gospel the Pharisee is rejected because of his pride, and the publican is accepted because of his humility.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 12:17
verses.text: Now, unless I am mistaken, I have already sent you ten letters, affectionate and earnest, whilst you have not deigned to give me even a single line.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 12:18
verses.text: The Lord speaks to His servants, but you, my brother servant, refuse to speak to me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 12:19
verses.text: Believe me, if reserve did not check my pen, I could show my annoyance in such invective that you would have to reply—even though it might be in anger.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 12:20
verses.text: But since anger is human, and a Christian must not act injuriously, I fall back once more on entreaty, and beg you to love one who loves you, and to write to him as a servant should to his fellow-servant.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 12:21
verses.text: Farewell in the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 13:1
verses.text: Letter XIII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 13:2
verses.text: To Castorina, His Maternal Aunt.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 13:3
verses.text: An interesting letter, as throwing some light on Jerome's family relations.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 13:4
verses.text: Castorina, his maternal aunt, had, for some reason, become estranged from him, and he now writes to her to effect a reconciliation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 13:5
verses.text: Whether he succeeded in doing so, we do not know.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 13:6
verses.text: The date of the letter is 374 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 13:7
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 13:8
verses.text: The apostle and evangelist John rightly says, in his first epistle, that "whosoever hateth his brother is a murderer".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 13:9
verses.text: For, since murder often springs from hate, the hater, even though he has not yet slain his victim, is at heart a murderer.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 13:10
verses.text: Why, you ask, do I begin in this style? Simply that you and I may both lay aside past ill feeling and cleanse our hearts to be a habitation for God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 13:11
verses.text: "Be ye angry," David says, "and sin not," or, as the apostle more fully expresses it, "let not the sun go down upon your wrath".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 13:12
verses.text: What then shall we do in the day of judgment, upon whose wrath the sun has gone down not one day but many years? The Lord says in the Gospel: "If thou bring thy gift to the altar, and there rememberest that thy brother hath aught against thee; leave there thy gift before the altar, and go thy way; first be reconciled to thy brother, and then come and offer thy gift".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 13:13
verses.text: Woe to me, wretch that I am; woe, I had almost said, to you also.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 13:14
verses.text: This long time past we have either offered no gift at the altar or have offered it whilst cherishing anger "without a cause".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 13:15
verses.text: How have we been able in our daily prayers to say "Forgive us our debts as we forgive our debtors," whilst our feelings have been at variance with our words, and our petition inconsistent with our conduct? Therefore I renew the prayer which I made a year ago in a previous letter, that the Lord's legacy of peace may be indeed ours, and that my desires and your feelings may find favor in His sight.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 13:16
verses.text: Soon we shall stand before His judgment seat to receive the reward of harmony restored or to pay the penalty for harmony broken.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 13:17
verses.text: In case you shall prove unwilling—I hope that it may not be so—to accept my advances, I for my part shall be free.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 13:18
verses.text: For this letter, when it is read, will insure my acquittal.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:1
verses.text: Letter XIV.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:2
verses.text: To Heliodorus, Monk.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:3
verses.text: Heliodorus, originally a soldier, but now a presbyter of the Church, had accompanied Jerome to the East, but, not feeling called to the solitary life of the desert, had returned to Aquileia.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:4
verses.text: Here he resumed his clerical duties, and in course of time was raised to the episcopate as bishop of Altinum.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:5
verses.text: The letter was written in the first bitterness of separation and reproaches Heliodorus for having gone back from the perfect way of the ascetic life.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:6
verses.text: The description given of this is highly colored and seems to have produced a great impression in the West.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:7
verses.text: Fabiola was so much enchanted by it that she learned the letter by heart.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:8
verses.text: The date is 373 or 374 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:9
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:11
verses.text: So conscious are you of the affection which exists between us that you cannot but recognize the love and passion with which I strove to prolong our common sojourn in the desert.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:12
verses.text: This very letter—blotted, as you see, with tears—gives evidence of the lamentation and weeping with which I accompanied your departure.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:13
verses.text: With the pretty ways of a child you then softened your refusal by soothing words, and I, being off my guard, knew not what to do.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:14
