verses.text: Was I to hold my peace? I could not conceal my eagerness by a show of indifference.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:15
verses.text: Or was I to entreat you yet more earnestly? You would have refused to listen, for your love was not like mine.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:16
verses.text: Despised affection has taken the one course open to it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:17
verses.text: Unable to keep you when present, it goes in search of you when absent.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:18
verses.text: You asked me yourself, when you were going away, to invite you to the desert when I took up my quarters there, and I for my part promised to do so.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:19
verses.text: Accordingly I invite you now; come, and come quickly.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:20
verses.text: Do not call to mind old ties; the desert is for those who have left all.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:21
verses.text: Nor let the hardships of our former travels deter you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:22
verses.text: You believe in Christ, believe also in His words: "Seek ye first the kingdom of God and all these things shall be added unto you".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:23
verses.text: Take neither scrip nor staff.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:24
verses.text: He is rich enough who is poor—with Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:26
verses.text: But what is this, and why do I foolishly importune you again? Away with entreaties, an end to coaxing words.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:27
verses.text: Offended love does well to be angry.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:28
verses.text: You have spurned my petition; perhaps you will listen to my remonstrance.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:29
verses.text: What keeps you, effeminate soldier, in your father's house? Where are your ramparts and trenches? When have you spent a winter in the field? Lo, the trumpet sounds from heaven! Lo, the Leader comes with clouds! He is armed to subdue the world, and out of His mouth proceeds a two-edged sword to mow down all that encounters it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:30
verses.text: But as for you, what will you do? Pass straight from your chamber to the battle-field, and from the cool shade into the burning sun? Nay, a body used to a tunic cannot endure a buckler; a head that has worn a cap refuses a helmet; a hand made tender by disuse is galled by a sword-hilt.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:31
verses.text: Hear the proclamation of your King: "He that is not with me is against me, and he that gathereth not with me scattereth".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:32
verses.text: Remember the day on which you enlisted, when, buried with Christ in baptism, you swore fealty to Him, declaring that for His sake you would spare neither father nor mother.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:33
verses.text: Lo, the enemy is striving to slay Christ in your breast.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:34
verses.text: Lo, the ranks of the foe sigh over that bounty which you received when you entered His service.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:35
verses.text: Should your little nephew hang on your neck, pay no regard to him; should your mother with ashes on her hair and garments rent show you the breasts at which she nursed you, heed her not; should your father prostrate himself on the threshold, trample him under foot and go your way.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:36
verses.text: With dry eyes fly to the standard of the cross.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:37
verses.text: In such cases cruelty is the only true affection.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:39
verses.text: Hereafter there shall come—yes, there shall come—a day when you will return a victor to your true country, and will walk through the heavenly Jerusalem crowned with the crown of valor.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:40
verses.text: Then will you receive the citizenship thereof with Paul.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:41
verses.text: Then will you seek the like privilege for your parents.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:42
verses.text: Then will you intercede for me who have urged you forward on the path of victory.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:43
verses.text: I am not ignorant of the fetters which you may plead as hindrances.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:44
verses.text: My breast is not of iron nor my heart of stone.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:45
verses.text: I was not born of flint or suckled by a tigress.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:46
verses.text: I have passed through troubles like yours myself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:47
verses.text: Now it is a widowed sister who throws her caressing arms around you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:48
verses.text: Now it is the slaves, your foster-brothers, who cry, "To what master are you leaving us?" Now it is a nurse bowed with age, and a body-servant loved only less than a father, who exclaim: "Only wait till we die and follow us to our graves".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:49
verses.text: Perhaps, too, an aged mother, with sunken bosom and furrowed brow, recalling the lullaby with which she once soothed you, adds her entreaties to theirs.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:50
verses.text: The learned may call you, if they please,  The sole support and pillar of your house.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:51
verses.text: The love of God and the fear of hell will easily break such bonds.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:52
verses.text: Scripture, you will argue, bids us obey our parents.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:53
verses.text: Yes, but whoso loves them more than Christ loses his own soul.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:54
verses.text: The enemy takes sword in hand to slay me, and shall I think of a mother's tears? Or shall I desert the service of Christ for the sake of a father to whom, if I am Christ's servant, I owe no rites of burial, albeit if I am Christ's true servant I owe these to all? Peter with his cowardly advice was an offence to the Lord on the eve of His passion; and to the brethren who strove to restrain him from going up to Jerusalem, Paul's one answer was: "What mean ye to weep and to break my heart? For I am ready not to be bound only, but also to die at Jerusalem for the name of the Lord Jesus".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:55
verses.text: The battering-ram of natural affection which so often shatters faith must recoil powerless from the wall of the Gospel.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:56
verses.text: "My mother and my brethren are these whosoever do the will of my Father which is in heaven".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:57
verses.text: If they believe in Christ let them bid me God-speed, for I go to fight in His name.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:58
verses.text: And if they do not believe, "let the dead bury their dead".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:60
verses.text: But all this, you argue, only touches the case of martyrs.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:61
verses.text: Ah! my brother, you are mistaken, you are mistaken, if you suppose that there is ever a time when the Christian does not suffer persecution.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:62
verses.text: Then are you most hardly beset when you know not that you are beset at all.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:63
verses.text: "Our adversary as a roaring lion walketh about seeking whom he may devour," and do you think of peace? "He sitteth in the lurking-places of the villages: in the secret places doth he murder the innocent; his eyes are privily set against the poor.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:64
verses.text: He lieth in wait secretly as a lion in his den; he lieth in wait to catch the poor;" and do you slumber under a shady tree, so as to fall an easy prey? On one side self-indulgence presses me hard; on another covetousness strives to make an inroad; my belly wishes to be a God to me, in place of Christ, and lust would fain drive away the Holy Spirit that dwells in me and defile His temple.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:65
verses.text: I am pursued, I say, by an enemy  Whose name is Legion and his wiles untold;  and, hapless wretch that I am, how shall I hold myself a victor when I am being led away a captive?  5.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:66
verses.text: My dear brother, weigh well the various forms of transgression, and think not that the sins which I have mentioned are less flagrant than that of idolatry.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:67
verses.text: Nay, hear the apostle's view of the matter.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:68
verses.text: "For this ye know," he writes, "that no whore-monger or unclean person, nor covetous man, who is an idolater, hath any inheritance in the kingdom of Christ and of God".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:69
verses.text: In a general way all that is of the devil savors of enmity to God, and what is of the devil is idolatry, since all idols are subject to him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:70
verses.text: Yet Paul elsewhere lays down the law in express and unmistakable terms, saying: "Mortify your members, which are upon the earth, laying aside fornication, uncleanness, evil concupiscence and covetousness, which are idolatry, for which things' sake the wrath of God cometh".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:71
verses.text: Idolatry is not confined to casting incense upon an altar with finger and thumb, or to pouring libations of wine out of a cup into a bowl.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:72
verses.text: Covetousness is idolatry, or else the selling of the Lord for thirty pieces of silver was a righteous act.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:73
verses.text: Lust involves profanation, or else men may defile with common harlots those members of Christ which should be "a living sacrifice acceptable to God".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:74
verses.text: Fraud is idolatry, or else they are worthy of imitation who, in the Acts of the Apostles, sold their inheritance, and because they kept back part of the price, perished by an instant doom.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:75
verses.text: Consider well, my brother; nothing is yours to keep.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:76
verses.text: "Whosoever he be of you," the Lord says, "that forsaketh not all that he hath, he cannot be my disciple".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:77
verses.text: Why are you such a half-hearted Christian?  6.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:78
verses.text: See how Peter left his net; see how the publican rose from the receipt of custom.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:79
verses.text: In a moment he became an apostle.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:80
verses.text: "The Son of man hath not where to lay his head," and do you plan wide porticos and spacious halls? If you look to inherit the good things of the world you can no longer be a joint-heir with Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:81
verses.text: You are called a monk, and has the name no meaning? What brings you, a solitary, into the throng of men? The advice that I give is that of no inexperienced mariner who has never lost either ship or cargo, and has never known a gale.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:82
verses.text: Lately shipwrecked as I have been myself, my warnings to other voyagers spring from my own fears.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:83
verses.text: On one side, like Charybdis, self-indulgence sucks into its vortex the soul's salvation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:84
verses.text: On the other, like Scylla, lust, with a smile on her girl's face, lures it on to wreck its chastity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:85
verses.text: The coast is savage, and the devil with a crew of pirates carries irons to fetter his captives.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:86
verses.text: Be not credulous, be not over-confident.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:87
verses.text: The sea may be as smooth and smiling as a pond, its quiet surface may be scarcely ruffled by a breath of air, yet sometimes its waves are as high as mountains.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:88
verses.text: There is danger in its depths, the foe is lurking there.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:89
verses.text: Ease your sheets, spread your sails, fasten the cross as an ensign on your prow.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:90
verses.text: The calm that you speak of is itself a tempest.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:91
verses.text: "Why so?" you will perhaps argue; "are not all my fellow-townsmen Christians?" Your case, I reply, is not that of others.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:92
verses.text: Listen to the words of the Lord: "If thou wilt be perfect go and sell that thou hast, and give to the poor, and come and follow me".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:93
verses.text: You have already promised to be perfect.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:94
verses.text: For when you forsook the army and made yourself an eunuch for the kingdom of heaven's sake, you did so that you might follow the perfect life.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:95
verses.text: Now the perfect servant of Christ has nothing beside Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:96
verses.text: Or if he have anything beside Christ he is not perfect.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:97
verses.text: And if he be not perfect when he has promised God to be so, his profession is a lie.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:98
verses.text: But "the mouth that lieth slayeth the soul".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:99
verses.text: To conclude, then, if you are perfect you will not set your heart on your father's goods; and if you are not perfect you have deceived the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:100
verses.text: The Gospel thunders forth its divine warning: "Ye cannot serve two masters," and does any one dare to make Christ a liar by serving at once both God and Mammon? Repeatedly does He proclaim, "If any one will come after me let him deny himself and take up his cross and follow me".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:101
verses.text: If I load myself with gold can I think that I am following Christ? Surely not.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:102
verses.text: "He that saith he abideth in Him ought himself also so to walk even as He walked".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:104
verses.text: I know you will rejoin that you possess nothing.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:105
verses.text: Why, then, if you are so well prepared for battle, do you not take the field? Perhaps you think that you can wage war in your own country, although the Lord could do no signs in His? Why not? you ask.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:106
verses.text: Take the answer which comes to you with his authority: "No prophet is accepted in his own country".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:107
verses.text: But, you will say, I do not seek honor; the approval of my conscience is enough for me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:108
verses.text: Neither did the Lord seek it; for when the multitudes would have made Him a king he fled from them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:109
verses.text: But where there is no honor there is contempt; and where there is contempt there is frequent rudeness; and where there is rudeness there is vexation; and where there is vexation there is no rest; and where there is no rest the mind is apt to be diverted from its purpose.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:110
verses.text: Again, where, through restlessness, earnestness loses any of its force, it is lessened by what it loses, and that which is lessened cannot be called perfect.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:111
verses.text: The upshot of all which is that a monk cannot be perfect in his own country.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:112
verses.text: Now, not to aim at perfection is itself a sin.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:114
verses.text: Driven from this line of defence you will appeal to the example of the clergy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:115
verses.text: These, you will say, remain in their cities, and yet they are surely above criticism.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:116
verses.text: Far be it from me to censure the successors of the apostles, who with holy words consecrate the body of Christ, and who make us Christians.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:117
verses.text: Having the keys of the kingdom of heaven, they judge men to some extent before the day of judgment, and guard the chastity of the bride of Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:118
verses.text: But, as I have before hinted, the case of monks is different from that of the clergy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:119
verses.text: The clergy feed Christ's sheep; I as a monk am fed by them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:120
verses.text: They live of the altar: I, if I bring no gift to it, have the axe laid to my root as to that of a barren tree.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:121
verses.text: Nor can I plead poverty as an excuse, for the Lord in the gospel has praised an aged widow for casting into the treasury the last two coins that she had.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:122
verses.text: I may not sit in the presence of a presbyter; he, if I sin, may deliver me to Satan, "for the destruction of the flesh that the spirit may be saved".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:123
verses.text: Under the old law he who disobeyed the priests was put outside the camp and stoned by the people, or else he was beheaded and expiated his contempt with his blood.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:124
verses.text: But now the disobedient person is cut down with the spiritual sword, or he is expelled from the church and torn to pieces by ravening demons.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:125
verses.text: Should the entreaties of your brethren induce you to take orders, I shall rejoice that you are lifted up, and fear lest you may be cast down.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:126
verses.text: You will say: "If a man desire the office of a bishop, he desireth a good work".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:127
verses.text: I know that; but you should add what follows: such an one "must be blameless, the husband of one wife, vigilant, sober, chaste, of good behavior, given to hospitality, apt to teach, not given to wine, no striker but patient".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:128
verses.text: After fully explaining the qualifications of a bishop the apostle speaks of ministers of the third degree with equal care.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:129
verses.text: "Likewise must the deacons be grave," he writes, "not double-tongued, not given to much wine, not greedy of filthy lucre, holding the mystery of the faith in a pure conscience.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:130
verses.text: And let these also first be proved; then, let them minister, being found blameless".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:131
verses.text: Woe to the man who goes in to the supper without a wedding garment.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:132
verses.text: Nothing remains for him but the stern question, "Friend, how camest thou in hither?" And when he is speechless the order will be given, "Bind him hand and foot, and take him away, and cast him into outer darkness; there shall be weeping and gnashing of teeth".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:133
verses.text: Woe to him who, when he has received a talent, has bound it in a napkin; and, whilst others make profits, only preserves what he has received.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:134
verses.text: His angry lord shall rebuke him in a moment.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:135
verses.text: "Thou wicked servant," he will say, "wherefore gavest thou not my money into the bank that at my coming I might have required mine own with usury?" That is to say, you should have laid before the altar what you were not able to bear.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:136
verses.text: For whilst you, a slothful trader, keep a penny in your hands, you occupy the place of another who might double the money.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:137
verses.text: Wherefore, as he who ministers well purchases to himself a good degree, so he who approaches the cup of the Lord unworthily shall be guilty of the body and blood of the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:139
verses.text: Not all bishops are bishops indeed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:140
verses.text: You consider Peter; mark Judas as well.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:141
verses.text: You notice Stephen; look also on Nicolas, sentenced in the Apocalypse by the Lord's own lips, whose shameful imaginations gave rise to the heresy of the Nicolaitans.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:142
verses.text: "Let a man examine himself and so let him come".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:143
verses.text: For it is not ecclesiastical rank that makes a man a Christian.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:144
verses.text: The centurion Cornelius was still a heathen when he was cleansed by the gift of the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:145
verses.text: Daniel was but a child when he judged the elders.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:146
verses.text: Amos was stripping mulberry bushes when, in a moment, he was made a prophet.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:147
verses.text: David was only a shepherd when he was chosen to be king.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:148
verses.text: And the least of His disciples was the one whom Jesus loved the most.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:149
verses.text: My brother, sit down in the lower room, that when one less honorable comes you may be bidden to go up higher.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:150
verses.text: Upon whom does the Lord rest but upon him that is lowly and of a contrite spirit, and that trembleth at His word? To whom God has committed much, of him He will ask the more.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:151
verses.text: "Mighty men shall be mightily tormented".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:152
verses.text: No man need pride himself in the day of judgment on merely physical chastity, for then shall men give account for every idle word, and the reviling of a brother shall be counted as the sin of murder.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:153
verses.text: Paul and Peter now reign with Christ, and it is not easy to take the place of the one or to hold the office of the other.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:154
verses.text: There may come an angel to rend the veil of your temple, and to remove your candlestick out of its place.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:155
verses.text: If you intend to build the tower, first count the cost.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:156
verses.text: Salt that has lost its savor is good for nothing but to be cast out and to be trodden under foot of swine.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:157
verses.text: If a monk fall, a priest shall intercede for him; but who shall intercede for a fallen priest?  10.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:158
verses.text: At last my discourse is clear of the reefs: at last this frail bark has passed from the breakers into deep water.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:159
verses.text: I may now spread my sails to the breeze; and, as I leave the rocks of controversy astern, my epilogue will be like the joyful shout of mariners.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:160
verses.text: O desert, bright with the flowers of Christ! O solitude whence come the stones of which, in the Apocalypse, the city of the great king is built! O wilderness, gladdened with God's especial presence! What keeps you in the world, my brother, you who are above the world? How long shall gloomy roofs oppress you? How long shall smoky cities immure you? Believe me, I have more light than you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:161
verses.text: Sweet it is to lay aside the weight of the body and to soar into the pure bright ether.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:162
verses.text: Do you dread poverty? Christ calls the poor blessed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:163
verses.text: Does toil frighten you? No athlete is crowned but in the sweat of his brow.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:164
verses.text: Are you anxious as regards food? Faith fears no famine.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:165
verses.text: Do you dread the bare ground for limbs wasted with fasting? The Lord lies there beside you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:166
verses.text: Do you recoil from an unwashed head and uncombed hair? Christ is your true head.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:167
verses.text: Does the boundless solitude of the desert terrify you? In the spirit you may walk always in paradise.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:168
verses.text: Do but turn your thoughts thither and you will be no more in the desert.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:169
verses.text: Is your skin rough and scaly because you no longer bathe? He that is once washed in Christ needeth not to wash again.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:170
verses.text: To all your objections the apostle gives this one brief answer: "The sufferings of this present time are not worthy to be compared with the glory" which shall come after them, "which shall be revealed in us".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:171
verses.text: You are too greedy of enjoyment, my brother, if you wish to rejoice with the world here, and to reign with Christ hereafter.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:173
verses.text: It shall come, it shall come, that day when this corruptible shall put on incorruption, and this mortal shall put on immortality.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:174
verses.text: Then shall that servant be blessed whom the Lord shall find watching.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:175
verses.text: Then at the sound of the trumpet the earth and its peoples shall tremble, but you shall rejoice.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:176
verses.text: The world shall howl at the Lord who comes to judge it, and the tribes of the earth shall smite the breast.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:177
verses.text: Once mighty kings shall tremble in their nakedness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:178
verses.text: Venus shall be exposed, and her son too.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:179
verses.text: Jupiter with his fiery bolts will be brought to trial; and Plato, with his disciples, will be but a fool.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:180
verses.text: Aristotle's arguments shall be of no avail.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:181
verses.text: You may seem a poor man and country bred, but then you shall exult and laugh, and say: Behold my crucified Lord, behold my judge.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:182
verses.text: This is He who was once an infant wrapped in swaddling clothes and crying in a manger.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:183
verses.text: This is He whose parents were a workingman and a working-woman.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:184
verses.text: This is He, who, carried into Egypt in His mother's bosom, though He was God, fled before the face of man.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:185
verses.text: This is He who was clothed in a scarlet robe and crowned with thorns.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:186
verses.text: This is He who was called a sorcerer and a man with a devil and a Samaritan.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:187
verses.text: Jew, behold the hands which you nailed to the cross.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:188
verses.text: Roman, behold the side which you pierced with the spear.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:189
verses.text: See both of you whether it was this body that the disciples stole secretly and by night.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:190
verses.text: For this you profess to believe.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 14:191
verses.text: My brother, it is affection which has urged me to speak thus; that you who now find the Christian life so hard may have your reward in that day.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:1
verses.text: Letter XV.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:2
verses.text: To Pope Damasus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:3
verses.text: This letter, written in 376 or 377 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:4
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:5
verses.text: , illustrates Jerome's attitude towards the see of Rome at this time held by Damasus, afterwards his warm friend and admirer.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:6
verses.text: Referring to Rome as the scene of his own baptism and as a church where the true faith has remained unimpaired (§1), and laying down the strict doctrine of salvation only within the pale of the church (§2), Jerome asks "the successor of the fisherman" two questions, viz.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:7
verses.text: : (1) who is the true bishop of the three claimants of the see of Antioch, and (2) which is the correct terminology, to speak of three "hypostases" in the Godhead, or of one? On the latter question he expresses fully his own opinion.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:9
verses.text: Since the East, shattered as it is by the long-standing feuds, subsisting between its peoples, is bit by bit tearing into shreds the seamless vest of the Lord, "woven from the top throughout," since the foxes are destroying the vineyard of Christ, and since among the broken cisterns that hold no water it is hard to discover "the sealed fountain" and "the garden inclosed," I think it my duty to consult the chair of Peter, and to turn to a church whose faith has been praised by Paul.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:10
verses.text: I appeal for spiritual food to the church whence I have received the garb of Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:11
verses.text: The wide space of sea and land that lies between us cannot deter me from searching for "the pearl of great price".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:12
verses.text: "Wheresoever the body is, there will the eagles be gathered together".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:13
verses.text: Evil children have squandered their patrimony; you alone keep your heritage intact.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:14
verses.text: The fruitful soil of Rome, when it receives the pure seed of the Lord, bears fruit an hundredfold; but here the seed corn is choked in the furrows and nothing grows but darnel or oats.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:15
verses.text: In the West the Sun of righteousness is even now rising; in the East, Lucifer, who fell from heaven, has once more set his throne above the stars.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:16
verses.text: "Ye are the light of the world," "ye are the salt of the earth," ye are "vessels of gold and of silver".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:17
verses.text: Here are vessels of wood or of earth, which wait for the rod of iron, and eternal fire.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:19
verses.text: Yet, though your greatness terrifies me, your kindness attracts me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:20
verses.text: From the priest I demand the safe-keeping of the victim, from the shepherd the protection due to the sheep.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:21
verses.text: Away with all that is overweening; let the state of Roman majesty withdraw.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:22
verses.text: My words are spoken to the successor of the fisherman, to the disciple of the cross.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:23
verses.text: As I follow no leader save Christ, so I communicate with none but your blessedness, that is with the chair of Peter.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:24
verses.text: For this, I know, is the rock on which the church is built! This is the house where alone the paschal lamb can be rightly eaten.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:25
verses.text: This is the ark of Noah, and he who is not found in it shall perish when the flood prevails.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:26
verses.text: But since by reason of my sins I have betaken myself to this desert which lies between Syria and the uncivilized waste, I cannot, owing to the great distance between us, always ask of your sanctity the holy thing of the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:27
verses.text: Consequently I here follow the Egyptian confessors who share your faith, and anchor my frail craft under the shadow of their great argosies.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:28
verses.text: I know nothing of Vitalis; I reject Meletius; I have nothing to do with Paulinus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:29
verses.text: He that gathers not with you scatters; he that is not of Christ is of Antichrist.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:31
verses.text: Just now, I am sorry to say, those Arians, the Campenses, are trying to extort from me, a Roman Christian, their unheard-of formula of three hypostases.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:32
verses.text: And this, too, after the definition of Nicaea and the decree of Alexandria, in which the West has joined.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:33
verses.text: Where, I should like to know, are the apostles of these doctrines? Where is their Paul, their new doctor of the Gentiles? I ask them what three hypostases are supposed to mean.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:34
verses.text: They reply three persons subsisting.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:35
verses.text: I rejoin that this is my belief.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:36
verses.text: They are not satisfied with the meaning, they demand the term.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:37
verses.text: Surely some secret venom lurks in the words.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:38
verses.text: "If any man refuse," I cry, "to acknowledge three hypostases in the sense of three things hypostatized, that is three persons subsisting, let him be anathema".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:39
verses.text: Yet, because I do not learn their words, I am counted a heretic.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:40
verses.text: "But, if any one, understanding by hypostasis essence, deny that in the three persons there is one hypostasis, he has no part in Christ".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:41
verses.text: Because this is my confession I, like you, am branded with the stigma of Sabellianism.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:43
verses.text: If you think fit enact a decree; and then I shall not hesitate to speak of three hypostases.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:44
verses.text: Order a new creed to supersede the Nicene; and then, whether we are Arians or orthodox, one confession will do for us all.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:45
verses.text: In the whole range of secular learning hypostasis never means anything but essence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:46
verses.text: And can any one, I ask, be so profane as to speak of three essences or substances in the Godhead? There is one nature of God and one only; and this, and this alone, truly is.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:47
verses.text: For absolute being is derived from no other source but is all its own.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:48
verses.text: All things besides, that is all things created, although they appear to be, are not.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:49
verses.text: For there was a time when they were not, and that which once was not may again cease to be.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:50
verses.text: God alone who is eternal, that is to say, who has no beginning, really deserves to be called an essence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:51
verses.text: Therefore also He says to Moses from the bush, "I am that I am," and Moses says of Him, "I am hath sent me".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:52
verses.text: As the angels, the sky, the earth, the seas, all existed at the time, it must have been as the absolute being that God claimed for himself that name of essence, which apparently was common to all.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:53
verses.text: But because His nature alone is perfect, and because in the three persons there subsists but one Godhead, which truly is and is one nature; whosoever in the name of religion declares that there are in the Godhead three elements, three hypostases, that is, or essences, is striving really to predicate three natures of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:54
verses.text: And if this is true, why are we severed by walls from Arius, when in dishonesty we are one with him? Let Ursicinus be made the colleague of your blessedness; let Auxentius be associated with Ambrose.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:55
verses.text: But may the faith of Rome never come to such a pass! May the devout hearts of your people never be infected with such unholy doctrines! Let us be satisfied to speak of one substance and of three subsisting persons—perfect, equal, coeternal.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:56
verses.text: Let us keep to one hypostasis, if such be your pleasure, and say nothing of three.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:57
verses.text: It is a bad sign when those who mean the same thing use different words.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:58
verses.text: Let us be satisfied with the form of creed which we have hitherto used.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:59
verses.text: Or, if you think it right that I should speak of three hypostases, explaining what I mean by them, I am ready to submit.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:60
verses.text: But, believe me, there is poison hidden under their honey; the angel of Satan has transformed himself into an angel of light.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:61
verses.text: They give a plausible explanation of the term hypostasis; yet when I profess to hold it in the same sense they count me a heretic.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:62
verses.text: Why are they so tenacious of a word? Why do they shelter themselves under ambiguous language? If their belief corresponds to their explanation of it, I do not condemn them for keeping it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:63
verses.text: On the other hand, if my belief corresponds to their expressed opinions, they should allow me to set forth their meaning in my own words.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:65
verses.text: I implore your blessedness, therefore, by the crucified Saviour of the world, and by the consubstantial trinity, to authorize me by letter either to use or to refuse this formula of three hypostases.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:66
verses.text: And lest the obscurity of my present abode may baffle the bearers of your letter, I pray you to address it to Evagrius, the presbyter, with whom you are well acquainted.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:67
verses.text: I beg you also to signify with whom I am to communicate at Antioch.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 15:68
verses.text: Not, I hope, with the Campenses; for they—with their allies the heretics of Tarsus—only desire communion with you to preach with greater authority their traditional doctrine of three hypostases.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 16:1
verses.text: Letter XVI.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 16:2
verses.text: To Pope Damasus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 16:3
verses.text: This letter, written a few months after the preceding, is another appeal to Damasus to solve the writer's doubts.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 16:4
verses.text: Jerome once more refers to his baptism at Rome, and declares that his one answer to the factions at Antioch is, "He who clings to the chair of Peter is accepted by me".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 16:5
verses.text: Written from the desert in the year 377 or 378.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 16:7
verses.text: By her importunity the widow in the gospel at last gained a hearing, and by the same means one friend induced another to give him bread at midnight, when his door was shut and his servants were in bed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 16:8
verses.text: The publican's prayers overcame God, although God is invincible.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 16:9
verses.text: Nineveh was saved by its tears from the impending ruin caused by its sin.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 16:10
verses.text: To what end, you ask, these far-fetched references? To this end, I make answer; that you in your greatness should look upon me in my littleness; that you, the rich shepherd, should not despise me, the ailing sheep.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 16:11
verses.text: Christ Himself brought the robber from the cross to paradise, and, to show that repentance is never too late, He turned a murderer's death into a martyrdom.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 16:12
verses.text: Gladly does Christ embrace the prodigal son when he returns to Him; and, leaving the ninety and nine, the good shepherd carries home on His shoulders the one poor sheep that is left.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 16:13
verses.text: From a persecutor Paul becomes a preacher.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 16:14
verses.text: His bodily eyes are blinded to clear the eyes of his soul, and he who once haled Christ's servants in chains before the council of the Jews, lives afterwards to glory in the bonds of Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 16:16
verses.text: As I have already written to you, I, who have received Christ's garb in Rome, am now detained in the waste that borders Syria.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 16:17
verses.text: No sentence of banishment, however, has been passed upon me; the punishment which I am undergoing is self-inflicted.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 16:18
verses.text: But, as the heathen poet says:  They change not mind but sky who cross the sea.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 16:19
verses.text: The untiring foe follows me closely, and the assaults that I suffer in the desert are severer than ever.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 16:20
verses.text: For the Arian frenzy raves, and the powers of the world support it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 16:21
verses.text: The church is rent into three factions, and each of these is eager to seize me for its own.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 16:22
verses.text: The influence of the monks is of long standing, and it is directed against me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 16:23
verses.text: I meantime keep crying: "He who clings to the chair of Peter is accepted by me".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 16:24
verses.text: Meletius, Vitalis, and Paulinus all profess to cleave to you, and I could believe the assertion if it were made by one of them only.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 16:25
verses.text: As it is, either two of them or else all three are guilty of falsehood.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 16:26
verses.text: Therefore I implore your blessedness, by our Lord's cross and passion, those necessary glories of our faith, as you hold an apostolic office, to give an apostolic decision.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 16:27
verses.text: Only tell me by letter with whom I am to communicate in Syria, and I will pray for you that you may sit in judgment enthroned with the twelve; that when you grow old, like Peter, you may be girded not by yourself but by another, and that, like Paul, you may be made a citizen of the heavenly kingdom.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 16:28
verses.text: Do not despise a soul for which Christ died.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 17:1
verses.text: Letter XVII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 17:2
verses.text: To the Presbyter Marcus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 17:3
verses.text: In this letter, addressed to one who seems to have had some pre-eminence among the monks of the Chalcidian desert, Jerome complains of the hard treatment meted out to him because of his refusal to take any part in the great theological dispute then raging in Syria.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 17:4
verses.text: He protests his own orthodoxy, and begs permission to remain where he is until the return of spring, when he will retire from "the inhospitable desert".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 17:5
verses.text: Written in a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 17:6
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 17:9
verses.text: I had made up my mind to use the words of the psalmist: "While the wicked was before me I was dumb with silence; I was humbled, and I held my peace even from good" and "I, as a deaf man, heard not; and I was as a dumb man that openeth not his mouth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 17:10
verses.text: Thus I was as a man that heareth not".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 17:11
verses.text: But charity overcomes all things, and my regard for you defeats my determination.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 17:12
verses.text: I am, indeed, less careful to retaliate upon my assailants than to comply with your request.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 17:13
verses.text: For among Christians, as one has said, not he who endures an outrage is unhappy, but he who commits it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 17:15
verses.text: And first, before I speak to you of my belief (which you know full well), I am forced to cry out against the inhumanity of this country.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 17:16
verses.text: A hackneyed quotation best expresses my meaning:  What savages are these who will not grant  A rest to strangers, even on their sands!  They threaten war and drive us from their coasts.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 17:17
verses.text: I take this from a Gentile poet that one who disregards the peace of Christ may at least learn its meaning from a heathen.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 17:18
verses.text: I am called a heretic, although I preach the consubstantial trinity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 17:19
verses.text: I am accused of the Sabellian impiety although I proclaim with unwearied voice that in the Godhead there are three distinct, real, whole, and perfect persons.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 17:20
verses.text: The Arians do right to accuse me, but the orthodox forfeit their orthodoxy when they assail a faith like mine.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 17:21
verses.text: They may, if they like, condemn me as a heretic; but if they do they must also condemn Egypt and the West, Damasus and Peter.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 17:22
verses.text: Why do they fasten the guilt on one and leave his companions uncensured? If there is but little water in the stream, it is the fault, not of the channel, but of the source.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 17:23
verses.text: I blush to say it, but from the caves which serve us for cells we monks of the desert condemn the world.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 17:24
verses.text: Rolling in sack-cloth and ashes, we pass sentence on bishops.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 17:25
verses.text: What use is the robe of a penitent if it covers the pride of a king? Chains, squalor, and long hair are by right tokens of sorrow, and not ensigns of royalty.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 17:26
verses.text: I merely ask leave to remain silent.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 17:27
verses.text: Why do they torment a man who does not deserve their ill-will? I am a heretic, you say.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 17:28
verses.text: What is it to you if I am? Stay quiet, and all is said.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 17:29
verses.text: You are afraid, I suppose, that, with my fluent knowledge of Syriac and Greek, I shall make a tour of the churches, lead the people into error, and form a schism! I have robbed no man of anything; neither have I taken what I have not earned.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 17:30
verses.text: With my own hand daily and in the sweat of my brow I labor for my food, knowing that it is written by the apostle: "If any will not work, neither shall he eat".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 17:32
verses.text: Reverend and holy father, Jesus is my witness with what groans and tears I have written all this.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 17:33
verses.text: "I have kept silence, saith the Lord, but shall I always keep silence? Surely not".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 17:34
verses.text: I cannot have so much as a corner of the desert.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 17:35
verses.text: Every day I am asked for my confession of faith; as though when I was regenerated in baptism I had made none.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 17:36
verses.text: I accept their formulas, but they are still dissatisfied.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 17:37
verses.text: I sign my name to them, but they still refuse to believe me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 17:38
verses.text: One thing only will content them, that I should leave the country.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 17:39
verses.text: I am on the point of departure.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 17:40
verses.text: They have already torn away from me my dear brothers, who are a part of my very life.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 17:41
verses.text: They are, as you see, anxious to depart—nay, they are actually departing; it is preferable, they say, to live among wild beasts rather than with Christians such as these.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 17:42
verses.text: I myself, too, would be at this moment a fugitive were I not withheld by physical infirmity and by the severity of the winter.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 17:43
verses.text: I ask to be allowed the shelter of the desert for a few months till spring returns; or if this seems too long a delay, I am ready to depart now.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 17:44
verses.text: "The earth is the Lord's and the fulness thereof".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 17:45
verses.text: Let them climb up to heaven alone; for them alone Christ died; they possess all things and glory in all.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 17:46
verses.text: Be it so.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 17:47
verses.text: "But God forbid that I should glory save in the cross of our Lord Jesus Christ, by whom the world is crucified unto me and I unto the world".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 17:49
verses.text: As regards the questions which you have thought fit to put to me concerning the faith, I have given to the reverend Cyril a written confession which sufficiently answers them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 17:50
verses.text: He who does not so believe has no part in Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 17:51
verses.text: My faith is attested both by your ears and by those of your blessed brother, Zenobius, to whom, as well as to yourself, we all of us here send our best greeting.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 18:1
verses.text: Letter XVIII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 18:2
verses.text: To Pope Damasus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 18:3
verses.text: This (written from Constantinople in a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 18:4
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 18:5
verses.text: 381) is the earliest of Jerome's expository letters.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 18:6
verses.text: In it he explains at length the vision recorded in the sixth chapter of Isaiah, and enlarges upon its mystical meaning.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 18:7
verses.text: "Some of my predecessors," he writes, "make 'the Lord sitting upon a throne' God the Father, and suppose the seraphim to represent the Son and the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 18:8
verses.text: I do not agree with them, for John expressly tells us that it was Christ and not the Father whom the prophet saw".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 18:9
verses.text: And again, "The word seraphim means either 'glow' or 'beginning of speech,' and the two seraphim thus stand for the Old and New Testaments.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 18:10
verses.text: 'Did not our heart burn within us,' said the disciples, 'while he opened to us the Scriptures?' Moreover, the Old Testament is written in Hebrew, and this unquestionably was man's original language".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 18:11
verses.text: Jerome then speaks of the unity of the sacred books.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 18:12
verses.text: "Whatever," he asserts, "we read in the Old Testament we find also in the Gospel; and what we read in the Gospel is deduced from the Old Testament.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 18:13
verses.text: There is no discord between them, no disagreement.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 18:14
verses.text: In both Testaments the Trinity is preached".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 18:15
verses.text: The letter is noticeable for the evidence it affords of the thoroughness of Jerome's studies.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 18:16
verses.text: Not only does he cite the several Greek versions of Isaiah in support of his argument, but he also reverts to the Hebrew original.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 18:17
verses.text: So far as the West was concerned he may be said to have discovered this anew.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 18:18
verses.text: Even educated men like Augustine had ceased to look beyond the LXX.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 18:19
verses.text: , and were more or less aghast at the boldness with which Jerome rejected its time-honored but inaccurate renderings.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 18:20
verses.text: The letter also shows that independence of judgment which always marked Jerome's work.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 18:21
verses.text: At the time when he wrote it he was much under the sway of Origen.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 18:22
verses.text: But great as was his admiration for the master, he was not afraid to discard his exegesis when, as in the case of the seraphim, he believed it to be erroneous.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 19:1
verses.text: Letter XIX.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 19:2
verses.text: From Pope Damasus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 19:3
verses.text: A letter from Damasus to Jerome, in which he asks for an explanation of the word "Hosanna" (a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 19:4
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 20:1
verses.text: Letter XX.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 20:2
verses.text: To Pope Damasus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 20:3
verses.text: Jerome's reply to the foregoing.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 20:4
verses.text: Exposing the error of Hilary of Poitiers, who supposed the expression to signify "redemption of the house of David," he goes on to show that in the gospels it is a quotation from Psa.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 20:5
verses.text: cxviii.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 20:6
verses.text: 25 and that its true meaning is "save now" (so A.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 20:7
verses.text: V.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 20:9
verses.text: "Let us," he writes, "leave the streamlets of conjecture and return to the fountain-head.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 20:10
verses.text: It is from the Hebrew writings that the truth is to be drawn".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 20:11
verses.text: Written at Rome a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 20:12

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 21:1
verses.text: Letter XXI.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 21:2
verses.text: To Damasus  In this letter Jerome, at the request of Damasus, gives a minutely detailed explanation of the parable of the prodigal son.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:1
verses.text: Letter XXII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:2
verses.text: To Eustochium.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:3
verses.text: Perhaps the most famous of all the letters.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:4
verses.text: In it Jerome lays down at great length (1) the motives which ought to actuate those who devote themselves to a life of virginity, and (2) the rules by which they ought to regulate their daily conduct.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:5
verses.text: The letter contains a vivid picture of Roman society as it then was—the luxury, profligacy, and hypocrisy prevalent among both men and women, besides some graphic autobiographical details (§§7, 30), and concludes with a full account of the three kinds of monasticism then practised in Egypt (§§34–36).

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:6
verses.text: Thirty years later Jerome wrote a similar letter to Demetrias (CXXX.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:7
verses.text: ), with which this ought to be compared.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:8
verses.text: Written at Rome 384 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:9
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:11
verses.text: "Hear, O daughter, and consider, and incline thine ear; forget also thine own people and thy father's house, and the king shall desire thy beauty".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:12
verses.text: In this forty-fourth psalm God speaks to the human soul that, following the example of Abraham, it should go out from its own land and from its kindred, and should leave the Chaldeans, that is the demons, and should dwell in the country of the living, for which elsewhere the prophet sighs: "I think to see the good things of the Lord in the land of the living".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:13
verses.text: But it is not enough for you to go out from your own land unless you forget your people and your father's house; unless you scorn the flesh and cling to the bridegroom in a close embrace.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:14
verses.text: "Look not behind thee," he says, "neither stay thou in all the plain; escape to the mountain lest thou be consumed".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:15
verses.text: He who has grasped the plough must not look behind him or return home from the field, or having Christ's garment, descend from the roof to fetch other raiment.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:16
verses.text: Truly a marvellous thing, a father charges his daughter not to remember her father.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:17
verses.text: "Ye are of your father the devil, and the lusts of your father it is your will to do".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:18
verses.text: So it was said to the Jews.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:19
verses.text: And in another place, "He that committeth sin is of the devil".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:20
verses.text: Born, in the first instance, of such parentage we are naturally black, and even when we have repented, so long as we have not scaled the heights of virtue, we may still say: "I am black but comely, O ye daughters of Jerusalem".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:21
verses.text: But you will say to me, "I have left the home of my childhood; I have forgotten my father, I am born anew in Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:22
verses.text: What reward do I receive for this?" The context shows—"The king shall desire thy beauty".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:23
verses.text: This, then, is the great mystery.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:24
verses.text: "For this cause shall a man leave his father and his mother and shall be joined unto his wife, and they two shall be" not as is there said, "of one flesh," but "of one spirit".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:25
verses.text: Your bridegroom is not haughty or disdainful; He has "married an Ethiopian woman".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:26
verses.text: When once you desire the wisdom of the true Solomon and come to Him, He will avow all His knowledge to you; He will lead you into His chamber with His royal hand; He will miraculously change your complexion so that it shall be said of you, "Who is this that goeth up and hath been made white?"  2.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:27
verses.text: I write to you thus, Lady Eustochium (I am bound to call my Lord's bride "lady"), to show you by my opening words that my object is not to praise the virginity which you follow, and of which you have proved the value, or yet to recount the drawbacks of marriage, such as pregnancy, the crying of infants, the torture caused by a rival, the cares of household management, and all those fancied blessings which death at last cuts short.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:28
verses.text: Not that married women are as such outside the pale; they have their own place, the marriage that is honorable and the bed undefiled.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:29
verses.text: My purpose is to show you that you are fleeing from Sodom and should take warning by Lot's wife.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:30
verses.text: There is no flattery, I can tell you, in these pages.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:31
verses.text: A flatterer's words are fair, but for all that he is an enemy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:32
verses.text: You need expect no rhetorical flourishes setting you among the angels, and while they extol virginity as blessed, putting the world at your feet.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:34
verses.text: I would have you draw from your monastic vow not pride but fear.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:35
verses.text: You walk laden with gold; you must keep out of the robber's way.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:36
verses.text: To us men this life is a race-course: we contend here, we are crowned elsewhere.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:37
verses.text: No man can lay aside fear while serpents and scorpions beset his path.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:38
verses.text: The Lord says: "My sword hath drunk its fill in heaven," and do you expect to find peace on the earth? No, the earth yields only thorns and thistles, and its dust is food for the serpent.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:39
verses.text: "For our wrestling is not against flesh and blood, but against the principalities, against the powers, against the world-rulers of this darkness, against the spiritual hosts of wickedness in the heavenly places".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:40
verses.text: We are hemmed in by hosts of foes, our enemies are upon every side.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:41
verses.text: The weak flesh will soon be ashes: one against many, it fights against tremendous odds.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:42
verses.text: Not till it has been dissolved, not till the Prince of this world has come and found no sin therein, not till then may you safely listen to the prophet's words: "Thou shalt not be afraid for the terror by night nor for the arrow that flieth by day; nor for the trouble which haunteth thee in darkness; nor for the demon and his attacks at noonday.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:43
verses.text: A thousand shall fall at thy side and ten thousand at thy right hand; but it shall not come nigh thee".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:44
verses.text: When the hosts of the enemy distress you, when your frame is fevered and your passions roused, when you say in your heart, "What shall I do?" Elisha's words shall give you your answer, "Fear not, for they that be with us are more than they that be with them".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:45
verses.text: He shall pray, "Lord, open the eyes of thine handmaid that she may see".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:46
verses.text: And then when your eyes have been opened you shall see a fiery chariot like Elijah's waiting to carry you to heaven, and shall joyfully sing: "Our soul is escaped as a bird out of the snare of the fowlers: the snare is broken and we are escaped".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:48
verses.text: So long as we are held down by this frail body, so long as we have our treasure in earthen vessels; so long as the flesh lusteth against the spirit and the spirit against the flesh, there can be no sure victory.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:49
verses.text: "Our adversary the devil goeth about as a roaring lion seeking whom he may devour".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:50
verses.text: "Thou makest darkness," David says, "and it is night: wherein all the beasts of the forest do creep forth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:51
verses.text: The young lions roar after their prey and seek their meat from God".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:52
verses.text: The devil looks not for unbelievers, for those who are without, whose flesh the Assyrian king roasted in the furnace.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:53
verses.text: It is the church of Christ that he "makes haste to spoil".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:54
verses.text: According to Habakkuk, "His food is of the choicest".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:55
verses.text: A Job is the victim of his machinations, and after devouring Judas he seeks power to sift the [other] apostles.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:56
verses.text: The Saviour came not to send peace upon the earth but a sword.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:57
verses.text: Lucifer fell, Lucifer who used to rise at dawn; and he who was bred up in a paradise of delight had the well-earned sentence passed upon him, "Though thou exalt thyself as the eagle, and though thou set thy nest among the stars, thence will I bring thee down, saith the Lord".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:58
verses.text: For he had said in his heart, "I will exalt my throne above the stars of God," and "I will be like the Most High".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:59
verses.text: Wherefore God says every day to the angels, as they descend the ladder that Jacob saw in his dream, "I have said ye are Gods and all of you are children of the Most High.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:60
verses.text: But ye shall die like men and fall like one of the princes".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:61
verses.text: The devil fell first, and since "God standeth in the congregation of the Gods and judgeth among the Gods," the apostle writes to those who are ceasing to be Gods—"Whereas there is among you envying and strife, are ye not carnal and walk as men?"  5.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:62
verses.text: If, then, the apostle, who was a chosen vessel separated unto the gospel of Christ, by reason of the pricks of the flesh and the allurements of vice keeps under his body and brings it into subjection, lest when he has preached to others he may himself be a castaway; and yet, for all that, sees another law in his members warring against the law of his mind, and bringing him into captivity to the law of sin; if after nakedness, fasting, hunger, imprisonment, scourging and other torments, he turns back to himself and cries "Oh, wretched man that I am, who shall deliver me from the body of this death?" do you fancy that you ought to lay aside apprehension? See to it that God say not some day of you: "The virgin of Israel is fallen and there is none to raise her up".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:63
verses.text: I will say it boldly, though God can do all things He cannot raise up a virgin when once she has fallen.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:64
verses.text: He may indeed relieve one who is defiled from the penalty of her sin, but He will not give her a crown.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:65
verses.text: Let us fear lest in us also the prophecy be fulfilled, "Good virgins shall faint".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:66
verses.text: Notice that it is good virgins who are spoken of, for there are bad ones as well.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:67
verses.text: "Whosoever looketh on a woman," the Lord says, "to lust after her hath committed adultery with her already in his heart".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:68
verses.text: So that virginity may be lost even by a thought.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:69
verses.text: Such are evil virgins, virgins in the flesh, not in the spirit; foolish virgins, who, having no oil, are shut out by the Bridegroom.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:71
verses.text: But if even real virgins, when they have other failings, are not saved by their physical virginity, what shall become of those who have prostituted the members of Christ, and have changed the temple of the Holy Ghost into a brothel? Straightway shall they hear the words: "Come down and sit in the dust, O virgin daughter of Babylon, sit on the ground; there is no throne, O daughter of the Chaldaeans: for thou shalt no more be called tender and delicate.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:72
verses.text: Take the millstone and grind meal; uncover thy locks, make bare the legs, pass over the rivers; thy nakedness shall be uncovered, yea, thy shame shall be seen".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:73
verses.text: And shall she come to this after the bridal-chamber of God the Son, after the kisses of Him who is to her both kinsman and spouse? Yes, she of whom the prophetic utterance once sang, "Upon thy right hand did stand the queen in a vesture of gold wrought about with divers colours," shall be made naked, and her skirts shall be discovered upon her face.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:74
verses.text: She shall sit by the waters of loneliness, her pitcher laid aside; and shall open her feet to every one that passeth by, and shall be polluted to the crown of her head.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:75
verses.text: Better had it been for her to have submitted to the yoke of marriage, to have walked in level places, than thus, aspiring to loftier heights, to fall into the deep of hell.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:76
verses.text: I pray you, let not Zion the faithful city become a harlot: let it not be that where the Trinity has been entertained, there demons shall dance and owls make their nests, and jackals build.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:77
verses.text: Let us not loose the belt that binds the breast.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:78
verses.text: When lust tickles the sense and the soft fire of sensual pleasure sheds over us its pleasing glow, let us immediately break forth and cry: "The Lord is on my side: I will not fear what the flesh can do unto me".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:79
verses.text: When the inner man shows signs for a time of wavering between vice and virtue, say: "Why art thou cast down, O my soul, and why art thou disquieted within me? Hope thou in God, for I shall yet praise Him who is the health of my countenance and my God".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:80
verses.text: You must never let suggestions of evil grow on you, or a babel of disorder win strength in your breast.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:81
verses.text: Slay the enemy while he is small; and, that you may not have a crop of tares, nip the evil in the bud.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:82
verses.text: Bear in mind the warning words of the Psalmist: "Hapless daughter of Babylon, happy shall he be that rewardeth thee as thou hast served us.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:83
verses.text: Happy shall he be that taketh and dasheth thy little ones against the stones".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:84
verses.text: Because natural heat inevitably kindles in a man sensual passion, he is praised and accounted happy who, when foul suggestions arise in his mind, gives them no quarter, but dashes them instantly against the rock.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:85
verses.text: "Now the Rock is Christ".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:87
verses.text: How often, when I was living in the desert, in the vast solitude which gives to hermits a savage dwelling-place, parched by a burning sun, how often did I fancy myself among the pleasures of Rome! I used to sit alone because I was filled with bitterness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:88
verses.text: Sackcloth disfigured my unshapely limbs and my skin from long neglect had become as black as an Ethiopian's.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:89
verses.text: Tears and groans were every day my portion; and if drowsiness chanced to overcome my struggles against it, my bare bones, which hardly held together, clashed against the ground.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:90
verses.text: Of my food and drink I say nothing: for, even in sickness, the solitaries have nothing but cold water, and to eat one's food cooked is looked upon as self-indulgence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:91
verses.text: Now, although in my fear of hell I had consigned myself to this prison, where I had no companions but scorpions and wild beasts, I often found myself amid bevies of girls.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:92
verses.text: My face was pale and my frame chilled with fasting; yet my mind was burning with desire, and the fires of lust kept bubbling up before me when my flesh was as good as dead.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:93
verses.text: Helpless, I cast myself at the feet of Jesus, I watered them with my tears, I wiped them with my hair: and then I subdued my rebellious body with weeks of abstinence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:94
verses.text: I do not blush to avow my abject misery; rather I lament that I am not now what once I was.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:95
verses.text: I remember how I often cried aloud all night till the break of day and ceased not from beating my breast till tranquillity returned at the chiding of the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:96
verses.text: I used to dread my very cell as though it knew my thoughts; and, stern and angry with myself, I used to make my way alone into the desert.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:97
verses.text: Wherever I saw hollow valleys, craggy mountains, steep cliffs, there I made my oratory, there the house of correction for my unhappy flesh.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:98
verses.text: There, also—the Lord Himself is my witness—when I had shed copious tears and had strained my eyes towards heaven, I sometimes felt myself among angelic hosts, and for joy and gladness sang: "because of the savour of thy good ointments we will run after thee".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:100
verses.text: Now, if such are the temptations of men who, since their bodies are emaciated with fasting, have only evil thoughts to fear, how must it fare with a girl whose surroundings are those of luxury and ease? Surely, to use the apostle's words, "She is dead while she liveth".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:101
verses.text: Therefore, if experience gives me a right to advise, or clothes my words with credit, I would begin by urging you and warning you as Christ's spouse to avoid wine as you would avoid poison.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:102
verses.text: For wine is the first weapon used by demons against the young.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:103
verses.text: Greed does not shake, nor pride puff up, nor ambition infatuate so much as this.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:104
verses.text: Other vices we easily escape, but this enemy is shut up within us, and wherever we go we carry him with us.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:105
verses.text: Wine and youth between them kindle the fire of sensual pleasure.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:106
verses.text: Why do we throw oil on the flame—why do we add fresh fuel to a miserable body which is already ablaze.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:107
verses.text: Paul, it is true, says to Timothy "drink no longer water, but use a little wine for thy stomach's sake, and for thine often infirmities".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:108
verses.text: But notice the reasons for which the permission is given, to cure an aching stomach and a frequent infirmity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:109
verses.text: And lest we should indulge ourselves too much on the score of our ailments, he commands that but little shall be taken; advising rather as a physician than as an apostle (though, indeed, an apostle is a spiritual physician).

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:110
verses.text: He evidently feared that Timothy might succumb to weakness, and might prove unequal to the constant moving to and fro involved in preaching the Gospel.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:111
verses.text: Besides, he remembered that he had spoken of "wine wherein is excess," and had said, "it is good neither to eat flesh nor to drink wine".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:112
verses.text: Noah drank wine and became intoxicated; but living as he did in the rude age after the flood, when the vine was first planted, perhaps he did not know its power of inebriation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:113
verses.text: And to let you see the hidden meaning of Scripture in all its fulness (for the word of God is a pearl and may be pierced on every side) after his drunkenness came the uncovering of his body; self-indulgence culminated in lust.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:114
verses.text: First the belly is crammed; then the other members are roused.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:115
verses.text: Similarly, at a later period, "The people sat down to eat and to drink and rose up to play".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:116
verses.text: Lot also, God's friend, whom He saved upon the mountain, who was the only one found righteous out of so many thousands, was intoxicated by his daughters.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:117
verses.text: And, although they may have acted as they did more from a desire of offspring than from love of sinful pleasure—for the human race seemed in danger of extinction—yet they were well aware that the righteous man would not abet their design unless intoxicated.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:118
verses.text: In fact he did not know what he was doing, and his sin was not wilful.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:119
verses.text: Still his error was a grave one, for it made him the father of Moab and Ammon, Israel's enemies, of whom it is said: "Even to the fourteenth generation they shall not enter into the congregation of the Lord forever".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:121
verses.text: When Elijah, in his flight from Jezebel, lay weary and desolate beneath the oak, there came an angel who raised him up and said, "Arise and eat".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:122
verses.text: And he looked, and behold there was a cake and a cruse of water at his head.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:123
verses.text: Had God willed it, might He not have sent His prophet spiced wines and dainty dishes and flesh basted into tenderness? When Elisha invited the sons of the prophets to dinner, he only gave them field-herbs to eat; and when all cried out with one voice: "There is death in the pot," the man of God did not storm at the cooks (for he was not used to very sumptuous fare), but caused meal to be brought, and casting it in, sweetened the bitter mess with spiritual strength as Moses had once sweetened the waters of Mara.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:124
verses.text: Again, when men were sent to arrest the prophet, and were smitten with physical and mental blindness, that he might bring them without their own knowledge to Samaria, notice the food with which Elisha ordered them to be refreshed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:125
verses.text: "Set bread and water," he said, "before them, that they may eat and drink and go to their master".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:126
verses.text: And Daniel, who might have had rich food from the king's table, preferred the mower's breakfast, brought to him by Habakkuk, which must have been but country fare.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:127
verses.text: He was called "a man of desires," because he would not eat the bread of desire or drink the wine of concupiscence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:129
verses.text: There are, in the Scriptures, countless divine answers condemning gluttony and approving simple food.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:130
verses.text: But as fasting is not my present theme and an adequate discussion of it would require a treatise to itself, these few observations must suffice of the many which the subject suggests.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:131
verses.text: By them you will understand why the first man, obeying his belly and not God, was cast down from paradise into this vale of tears; and why Satan used hunger to tempt the Lord Himself in the wilderness; and why the apostle cries: "Meats for the belly and the belly for meats, but God shall destroy both it and them;" and why he speaks of the self-indulgent as men "whose God is their belly".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:132
verses.text: For men invariably worship what they like best.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:133
verses.text: Care must be taken, therefore, that abstinence may bring back to Paradise those whom satiety once drove out.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:135
verses.text: You will tell me, perhaps, that, high-born as you are, reared in luxury and used to lie softly, you cannot do without wine and dainties, and would find a stricter rule of life unendurable.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:136
verses.text: If so, I can only say: "Live, then, by your own rule, since God's rule is too hard for you".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:137
