verses.text: Not that the Creator and Lord of all takes pleasure in a rumbling and empty stomach, or in fevered lungs; but that these are indispensable as means to the preservation of chastity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:138
verses.text: Job was dear to God, perfect and upright before Him; yet hear what he says of the devil: "His strength is in the loins, and his force is in the navel".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:139
verses.text: The terms are chosen for decency's sake, but the reproductive organs of the two sexes are meant.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:140
verses.text: Thus, the descendant of David, who, according to the promise is to sit upon his throne, is said to come from his loins.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:141
verses.text: And the seventy-five souls descended from Jacob who entered Egypt are said to come out of his thigh.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:142
verses.text: So, also, when his thigh shrank after the Lord had wrestled with him, he ceased to beget children.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:143
verses.text: The Israelites, again, are told to celebrate the passover with loins girded and mortified.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:144
verses.text: God says to Job: "Gird up thy loins as a man".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:145
verses.text: John wears a leathern girdle.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:146
verses.text: The apostles must gird their loins to carry the lamps of the Gospel.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:147
verses.text: When Ezekiel tells us how Jerusalem is found in the plain of wandering, covered with blood, he uses the words: "Thy navel has not been cut".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:148
verses.text: In his assaults on men, therefore, the devil's strength is in the loins; in his attacks on women his force is in the navel.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:150
verses.text: Do you wish for proof of my assertions? Take examples.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:151
verses.text: Sampson was braver than a lion and tougher than a rock; alone and unprotected he pursued a thousand armed men; and yet, in Delilah's embrace, his resolution melted away.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:152
verses.text: David was a man after God's own heart, and his lips had often sung of the Holy One, the future Christ; and yet as he walked upon his housetop he was fascinated by Bathsheba's nudity, and added murder to adultery.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:153
verses.text: Notice here how, even in his own house, a man cannot use his eyes without danger.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:154
verses.text: Then repenting, he says to the Lord: "Against thee, thee only, have I sinned and done this evil in Thy sight".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:155
verses.text: Being a king he feared no one else.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:156
verses.text: So, too, with Solomon.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:157
verses.text: Wisdom used him to sing her praise, and he treated of all plants "from the cedar tree that is in Lebanon even unto the hyssop that springeth out of the wall;" and yet he went back from God because he was a lover of women.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:158
verses.text: And, as if to show that near relationship is no safeguard, Amnon burned with illicit passion for his sister Tamar.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:160
verses.text: I cannot bring myself to speak of the many virgins who daily fall and are lost to the bosom of the church, their mother: stars over which the proud foe sets up his throne, and rocks hollowed by the serpent that he may dwell in their fissures.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:161
verses.text: You may see many women widows before wedded, who try to conceal their miserable fall by a lying garb.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:162
verses.text: Unless they are betrayed by swelling wombs or by the crying of their infants, they walk abroad with tripping feet and heads in the air.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:163
verses.text: Some go so far as to take potions, that they may insure barrenness, and thus murder human beings almost before their conception.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:164
verses.text: Some, when they find themselves with child through their sin, use drugs to procure abortion, and when (as often happens) they die with their offspring, they enter the lower world laden with the guilt not only of adultery against Christ but also of suicide and child murder.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:165
verses.text: Yet it is these who say: "'Unto the pure all things are pure;' my conscience is sufficient guide for me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:166
verses.text: A pure heart is what God looks for.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:167
verses.text: Why should I abstain from meats which God has created to be received with thanksgiving?" And when they wish to appear agreeable and entertaining they first drench themselves with wine, and then joining the grossest profanity to intoxication, they say "Far be it from me to abstain from the blood of Christ".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:168
verses.text: And when they see another pale or sad they call her "wretch" or "manichaean;" quite logically, indeed, for on their principles fasting involves heresy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:169
verses.text: When they go out they do their best to attract notice, and with nods and winks encourage troops of young fellows to follow them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:170
verses.text: Of each and all of these the prophet's words are true: "Thou hast a whore's forehead; thou refusest to be ashamed".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:171
verses.text: Their robes have but a narrow purple stripe, it is true; and their head-dress is somewhat loose, so as to leave the hair free.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:172
verses.text: From their shoulders flutters the lilac mantle which they call "ma-forte;" they have their feet in cheap slippers and their arms tucked up tight-fitting sleeves.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:173
verses.text: Add to these marks of their profession an easy gait, and you have all the virginity that they possess.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:174
verses.text: Such may have eulogizers of their own, and may fetch a higher price in the market of perdition, merely because they are called virgins.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:175
verses.text: But to such virgins as these I prefer to be displeasing.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:177
verses.text: I blush to speak of it, it is so shocking; yet though sad, it is true.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:178
verses.text: How comes this plague of the agapetae to be in the church? Whence come these unwedded wives, these novel concubines, these harlots, so I will call them, though they cling to a single partner? One house holds them and one chamber.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:179
verses.text: They often occupy the same bed, and yet they call us suspicious if we fancy anything amiss.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:180
verses.text: A brother leaves his virgin sister; a virgin, slighting her unmarried brother, seeks a brother in a stranger.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:181
verses.text: Both alike profess to have but one object, to find spiritual consolation from those not of their kin; but their real aim is to indulge in sexual intercourse.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:182
verses.text: It is on such that Solomon in the book of proverbs heaps his scorn.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:183
verses.text: "Can a man take fire in his bosom," he says, "and his clothes not be burned? Can one go upon hot coals and his feet not be burned?"  15.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:184
verses.text: We cast out, then, and banish from our sight those who only wish to seem and not to be virgins.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:185
verses.text: Henceforward I may bring all my speech to bear upon you who, as it is your lot to be the first virgin of noble birth in Rome, have to labor the more diligently not to lose good things to come, as well as those that are present.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:186
verses.text: You have at least learned from a case in your own family the troubles of wedded life and the uncertainties of marriage.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:187
verses.text: Your sister, Blaesilla, before you in age but behind you in declining the vow of virginity, has become a widow but seven months after she has taken a husband.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:188
verses.text: Hapless plight of us mortals who know not what is before us! She has lost, at once, the crown of virginity and the pleasures of wedlock.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:189
verses.text: And, although, as a widow, the second degree of chastity is hers, still can you not imagine the continual crosses which she has to bear, daily seeing in her sister what she has lost herself; and, while she finds it hard to go without the pleasures of wedlock, having a less reward for her present continence? Still she, too, may take heart and rejoice.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:190
verses.text: The fruit which is an hundredfold and that which is sixtyfold both spring from one seed, and that seed is chastity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:192
verses.text: Do not court the company of married ladies or visit the houses of the high-born.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:193
verses.text: Do not look too often on the life which you despised to become a virgin.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:194
verses.text: Women of the world, you know, plume themselves because their husbands are on the bench or in other high positions.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:195
verses.text: And the wife of the emperor always has an eager throng of visitors at her door.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:196
verses.text: Why do you, then, wrong your husband? Why do you, God's bride, hasten to visit the wife of a mere man? Learn in this respect a holy pride; know that you are better than they.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:197
verses.text: And not only must you avoid intercourse with those who are puffed up by their husbands' honors, who are hedged in with troops of eunuchs, and who wear robes inwrought with threads of gold.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:198
verses.text: You must also shun those who are widows from necessity and not from choice.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:199
verses.text: Not that they ought to have desired the death of their husbands; but that they have not welcomed the opportunity of continence when it has come.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:200
verses.text: As it is, they only change their garb; their old self-seeking remains unchanged.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:201
verses.text: To see them in their capacious litters, with red cloaks and plump bodies, a row of eunuchs walking in front of them, you would fancy them not to have lost husbands but to be seeking them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:202
verses.text: Their houses are filled with flatterers and with guests.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:203
verses.text: The very clergy, who ought to inspire them with respect by their teaching and authority, kiss these ladies on the forehead, and putting forth their hands (so that, if you knew no better, you might suppose them in the act of blessing), take wages for their visits.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:204
verses.text: They, meanwhile, seeing that priests cannot do without them, are lifted up into pride; and as, having had experience of both, they prefer the license of widowhood to the restraints of marriage, they call themselves chaste livers and nuns.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:205
verses.text: After an immoderate supper they retire to rest to dream of the apostles.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:207
verses.text: Let your companions be women pale and thin with fasting, and approved by their years and conduct; such as daily sing in their hearts: "Tell me where thou feedest thy flock, where thou makest it to rest at noon," and say, with true earnestness, "I have a desire to depart and to be with Christ".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:208
verses.text: Be subject to your parents, imitating the example of your spouse.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:209
verses.text: Rarely go abroad, and if you wish to seek the aid of the martyrs seek it in your own chamber.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:210
verses.text: For you will never need a pretext for going out if you always go out when there is need.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:211
verses.text: Take food in moderation, and never overload your stomach.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:212
verses.text: For many women, while temperate as regards wine, are intemperate in the use of food.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:213
verses.text: When you rise at night to pray, let your breath be that of an empty and not that of an overfull stomach.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:214
verses.text: Read often, learn all that you can.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:215
verses.text: Let sleep overcome you, the roll still in your hands; when your head falls, let it be on the sacred page.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:216
verses.text: Let your fasts be of daily occurrence and your refreshment such as avoids satiety.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:217
verses.text: It is idle to carry an empty stomach if, in two or three days' time, the fast is to be made up for by repletion.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:218
verses.text: When cloyed the mind immediately grows sluggish, and when the ground is watered it puts forth the thorns of lust.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:219
verses.text: If ever you feel the outward man sighing for the flower of youth, and if, as you lie on your couch after a meal, you are excited by the alluring train of sensual desires; then seize the shield of faith, for it alone can quench the fiery darts of the devil.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:220
verses.text: "They are all adulterers," says the prophet; "they have made ready their heart like an oven".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:221
verses.text: But do you keep close to the footsteps of Christ, and, intent upon His words, say: "Did not our heart burn within us by the way while Jesus opened to us the Scriptures?" and again: "Thy word is tried to the uttermost, and thy servant loveth it".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:222
verses.text: It is hard for the human soul to avoid loving something, and our mind must of necessity give way to affection of one kind or another.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:223
verses.text: The love of the flesh is overcome by the love of the spirit.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:224
verses.text: Desire is quenched by desire.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:225
verses.text: What is taken from the one increases the other.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:226
verses.text: Therefore, as you lie on your couch, say again and again: "By night have I sought Him whom my soul loveth".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:227
verses.text: "Mortify, therefore," says the apostle, "your members which are upon the earth".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:228
verses.text: Because he himself did so, he could afterwards say with confidence: "I live, yet not I, but Christ, liveth in me".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:229
verses.text: He who mortifies his members, and feels that he is walking in a vain show, is not afraid to say: "I am become like a bottle in the frost.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:230
verses.text: Whatever there was in me of the moisture of lust has been dried out of me".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:231
verses.text: And again: "My knees are weak through fasting; I forget to eat my bread.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:232
verses.text: By reason of the voice of my groaning my bones cleave to my skin".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:234
verses.text: Be like the grasshopper and make night musical.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:235
verses.text: Nightly wash your bed and water your couch with your tears.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:236
verses.text: Watch and be like the sparrow alone upon the housetop.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:237
verses.text: Sing with the spirit, but sing with the understanding also.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:238
verses.text: And let your song be that of the psalmist: "Bless the Lord, O my soul; and forget not all his benefits; who forgiveth all thine iniquities; who healeth all thy diseases; who redeemeth thy life from destruction".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:239
verses.text: Can we, any of us, honestly make his words our own: "I have eaten ashes like bread and mingled my drink with weeping?" Yet, should we not weep and groan when the serpent invites us, as he invited our first parents, to eat forbidden fruit, and when after expelling us from the paradise of virginity he desires to clothe us with mantles of skins such as that which Elijah, on his return to paradise, left behind him on earth? Say to yourself: "What have I to do with the pleasures of sense that so soon come to an end? What have I to do with the song of the sirens so sweet and so fatal to those who hear it?" I would not have you subject to that sentence whereby condemnation has been passed upon mankind.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:240
verses.text: When God says to Eve, "In pain and in sorrow thou shalt bring forth children," say to yourself, "That is a law for a married woman, not for me".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:241
verses.text: And when He continues, "Thy desire shall be to thy husband," say again: "Let her desire be to her husband who has not Christ for her spouse".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:242
verses.text: And when, last of all, He says, "Thou shalt surely die," once more, say, "Marriage indeed must end in death; but the life on which I have resolved is independent of sex.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:243
verses.text: Let those who are wives keep the place and the time that properly belong to them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:244
verses.text: For me, virginity is consecrated in the persons of Mary and of Christ".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:246
verses.text: Some one may say, "Do you dare detract from wedlock, which is a state blessed by God?" I do not detract from wedlock when I set virginity before it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:247
verses.text: No one compares a bad thing with a good.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:248
verses.text: Wedded women may congratulate themselves that they come next to virgins.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:249
verses.text: "Be fruitful," God says, "and multiply, and replenish the earth".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:250
verses.text: He who desires to replenish the earth may increase and multiply if he will.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:251
verses.text: But the train to which you belong is not on earth, but in heaven.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:252
verses.text: The command to increase and multiply first finds fulfilment after the expulsion from paradise, after the nakedness and the fig-leaves which speak of sexual passion.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:253
verses.text: Let them marry and be given in marriage who eat their bread in the sweat of their brow; whose land brings forth to them thorns and thistles, and whose crops are choked with briars.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:254
verses.text: My seed produces fruit a hundredfold.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:255
verses.text: "All men cannot receive God's saying, but they to whom it is given".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:256
verses.text: Some people may be eunuchs from necessity; I am one of free will.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:257
verses.text: "There is a time to embrace and a time to refrain from embracing.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:258
verses.text: There is a time to cast away stones, and a time to gather stones together".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:259
verses.text: Now that out of the hard stones of the Gentiles God has raised up children unto Abraham, they begin to be "holy stones rolling upon the earth".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:260
verses.text: They pass through the whirlwinds of the world, and roll on in God's chariot on rapid wheels.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:261
verses.text: Let those stitch coats to themselves who have lost the coat woven from the top throughout; who delight in the cries of infants which, as soon as they see the light, lament that they are born.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:262
verses.text: In paradise Eve was a virgin, and it was only after the coats of skins that she began her married life.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:263
verses.text: Now paradise is your home too.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:264
verses.text: Keep therefore your birthright and say: "Return unto thy rest, O my soul".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:265
verses.text: To show that virginity is natural while wedlock only follows guilt, what is born of wedlock is virgin flesh, and it gives back in fruit what in root it has lost.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:266
verses.text: "There shall come forth a rod out of the stem of Jesse, and a flower shall grow out of his roots".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:267
verses.text: The rod is the mother of the Lord—simple, pure, unsullied; drawing no germ of life from without but fruitful in singleness like God Himself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:268
verses.text: The flower of the rod is Christ, who says of Himself: "I am the rose of Sharon and the lily of the valleys".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:269
verses.text: In another place He is foretold to be "a stone cut out of the mountain without hands," a figure by which the prophet signifies that He is to be born a virgin of a virgin.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:270
verses.text: For the hands are here a figure of wedlock as in the passage: "His left hand is under my head and his right hand doth embrace me".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:271
verses.text: It agrees, also, with this interpretation that the unclean animals are led into Noah's ark in pairs, while of the clean an uneven number is taken.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:272
verses.text: Similarly, when Moses and Joshua were bidden to remove their shoes because the ground on which they stood was holy, the command had a mystical meaning.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:273
verses.text: So, too, when the disciples were appointed to preach the gospel they were told to take with them neither shoe nor shoe-latchet; and when the soldiers came to cast lots for the garments of Jesus they found no boots that they could take away.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:274
verses.text: For the Lord could not Himself possess what He had forbidden to His servants.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:276
verses.text: I praise wedlock, I praise marriage, but it is because they give me virgins.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:277
verses.text: I gather the rose from the thorns, the gold from the earth, the pearl from the shell.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:278
verses.text: "Doth the plowman plow all day to sow?" Shall he not also enjoy the fruit of his labor? Wedlock is the more honored, the more what is born of it is loved.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:279
verses.text: Why, mother, do you grudge your daughter her virginity? She has been reared on your milk, she has come from your womb, she has grown up in your bosom.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:280
verses.text: Your watchful affection has kept her a virgin.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:281
verses.text: Are you angry with her because she chooses to be a king's wife and not a soldier's? She has conferred on you a high privilege; you are now the mother-in-law of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:282
verses.text: "Concerning virgins," says the apostle, "I have no commandment of the Lord".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:283
verses.text: Why was this? Because his own virginity was due, not to a command, but to his free choice.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:284
verses.text: For they are not to be heard who feign him to have had a wife; for, when he is discussing continence and commending perpetual chastity, he uses the words, "I would that all men were even as I myself".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:285
verses.text: And farther on, "I say, therefore, to the unmarried and widows, it is good for them if they abide even as I".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:286
verses.text: And in another place, "have we not power to lead about wives even as the rest of the apostles?" Why then has he no commandment from the Lord concerning virginity? Because what is freely offered is worth more than what is extorted by force, and to command virginity would have been to abrogate wedlock.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:287
verses.text: It would have been a hard enactment to compel opposition to nature and to extort from men the angelic life; and not only so, it would have been to condemn what is a divine ordinance.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:289
verses.text: The old law had a different ideal of blessedness, for therein it is said: "Blessed is he who hath seed in Zion and a family in Jerusalem:" and "Cursed is the barren who beareth not:" and "Thy children shall be like olive-plants round about thy table".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:290
verses.text: Riches too are promised to the faithful and we are told that "there was not one feeble person among their tribes".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:291
verses.text: But now even to eunuchs it is said, "Say not, behold I am a dry tree," for instead of sons and daughters you have a place forever in heaven.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:292
verses.text: Now the poor are blessed, now Lazarus is set before Dives in his purple.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:293
verses.text: Now he who is weak is counted strong.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:294
verses.text: But in those days the world was still unpeopled: accordingly, to pass over instances of childlessness meant only to serve as types, those only were considered happy who could boast of children.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:295
verses.text: It was for this reason that Abraham in his old age married Keturah; that Leah hired Jacob with her son's mandrakes, and that fair Rachel—a type of the church—complained of the closing of her womb.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:296
verses.text: But gradually the crop grew up and then the reaper was sent forth with his sickle.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:297
verses.text: Elijah lived a virgin life, so also did Elisha and many of the sons of the prophets.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:298
verses.text: To Jeremiah the command came: "Thou shalt not take thee a wife".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:299
verses.text: He had been sanctified in his mother's womb, and now he was forbidden to take a wife because the captivity was near.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:300
verses.text: The apostle gives the same counsel in different words.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:301
verses.text: "I think, therefore, that this is good by reason of the present distress, namely that it is good for a man to be as he is".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:302
verses.text: What is this distress which does away with the joys of wedlock? The apostle tells us, in a later verse: "The time is short: it remaineth that those who have wives be as though they had none".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:303
verses.text: Nebuchadnezzar is hard at hand.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:304
verses.text: The lion is bestirring himself from his lair.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:305
verses.text: What good will marriage be to me if it is to end in slavery to the haughtiest of kings? What good will little ones be to me if their lot is to be that which the prophet sadly describes: "The tongue of the sucking child cleaveth to the roof of his mouth for thirst; the young children ask for bread and no man breaketh it unto them"? In those days, as I have said, the virtue of continence was found only in men: Eve still continued to travail with children.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:306
verses.text: But now that a virgin has conceived in the womb and has borne to us a child of which the prophet says that "Government shall be upon his shoulder, and his name shall be called the mighty God, the everlasting Father," now the chain of the curse is broken.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:307
verses.text: Death came through Eve, but life has come through Mary.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:308
verses.text: And thus the gift of virginity has been bestowed most richly upon women, seeing that it has had its beginning from a woman.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:309
verses.text: As soon as the Son of God set foot upon the earth, He formed for Himself a new household there; that, as He was adored by angels in heaven, angels might serve Him also on earth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:310
verses.text: Then chaste Judith once more cut off the head of Holofernes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:311
verses.text: Then Haman—whose name means iniquity—was once more burned in fire of his own kindling.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:312
verses.text: Then James and John forsook father and net and ship and followed the Saviour: neither kinship nor the world's ties, nor the care of their home could hold them back.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:313
verses.text: Then were the words heard: "Whosoever will come after me, let him deny himself and take up his cross and follow me".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:314
verses.text: For no soldier goes with a wife to battle.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:315
verses.text: Even when a disciple would have buried his father, the Lord forbade him, and said: "Foxes have holes and the birds of the air have nests, but the Son of Man hath not where to lay His head".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:316
verses.text: So you must not complain if you have but scanty house-room.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:317
verses.text: In the same strain, the apostle writes: "He that is unmarried careth for the things that belong to the Lord, how he may please the Lord: but he that is married careth for the things that are of the world how he may please his wife.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:318
verses.text: There is difference also between a wife and a virgin.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:319
verses.text: The unmarried woman careth for the things of the Lord that she may be holy both in body and in spirit.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:320
verses.text: But she that is married careth for the things of the world how she may please her husband".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:322
verses.text: How great inconveniences are involved in wedlock and how many anxieties encompass it I have, I think, described shortly in my treatise—published against Helvidius—on the perpetual virginity of the blessed Mary.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:323
verses.text: It would be tedious to go over the same ground now; and any one who pleases may draw from that fountain.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:324
verses.text: But lest I should seem wholly to have passed over the matter, I will just say now that the apostle bids us pray without ceasing, and that he who in the married state renders his wife her due cannot so pray.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:325
verses.text: Either we pray always and are virgins, or we cease to pray that we may fulfil the claims of marriage.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:326
verses.text: Still he says: "If a virgin marry she hath not sinned.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:327
verses.text: Nevertheless such shall have trouble in the flesh".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:328
verses.text: At the outset I promised that I should say little or nothing of the embarrassments of wedlock, and now I give you notice to the same effect.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:329
verses.text: If you want to know from how many vexations a virgin is free and by how many a wife is fettered you should read Tertullian "to a philosophic friend," and his other treatises on virginity, the blessed Cyprian's noble volume, the writings of Pope Damasus in prose and verse, and the treatises recently written for his sister by our own Ambrose.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:330
verses.text: In these he has poured forth his soul with such a flood of eloquence that he has sought out, set forth, and put in order all that bears on the praise of virgins.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:332
verses.text: We must proceed by a different path, for our purpose is not the praise of virginity but its preservation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:333
verses.text: To know that it is a good thing is not enough: when we have chosen it we must guard it with jealous care.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:334
verses.text: The first only requires judgment, and we share it with many; the second calls for toil, and few compete with us in it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:335
verses.text: "He that shall endure unto the end," the Lord says, "the same shall be saved," and "many are called but few are chosen".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:336
verses.text: Therefore I conjure you before God and Jesus Christ and His elect angels to guard that which you have received, not readily exposing to the public gaze the vessels of the Lord's temple (which only the priests are by right allowed to see), that no profane person may look upon God's sanctuary.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:337
verses.text: Uzzah, when he touched the ark which it was not lawful to touch, was struck down suddenly by death.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:338
verses.text: And assuredly no gold or silver vessel was ever so dear to God as is the temple of a virgin's body.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:339
verses.text: The shadow went before, but now the reality is come.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:340
verses.text: You indeed may speak in all simplicity, and from motives of amiability may treat with courtesy the veriest strangers, but unchaste eyes see nothing aright.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:341
verses.text: They fail to appreciate the beauty of the soul, and only value that of the body.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:342
verses.text: Hezekiah showed God's treasure to the Assyrians, who ought never to have seen what they were sure to covet.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:343
verses.text: The consequence was that Judaea was torn by continual wars, and that the very first things carried away to Babylon were these vessels of the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:344
verses.text: We find Belshazzar at his feast and among his concubines (vice always glories in defiling what is noble) drinking out of these sacred cups.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:346
verses.text: Never incline your ear to words of mischief.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:347
verses.text: For men often say an improper word to make trial of a virgin's steadfastness, to see if she hears it with pleasure, and if she is ready to unbend at every silly jest.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:348
verses.text: Such persons applaud whatever you affirm and deny whatever you deny; they speak of you as not only holy but accomplished, and say that in you there is no guile.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:349
verses.text: "Behold," say they, "a true hand-maid of Christ; behold entire singleness of heart.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:350
verses.text: How different from that rough, unsightly, countrified fright, who most likely never married because she could never find a husband".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:351
verses.text: Our natural weakness induces us readily to listen to such flatterers; but, though we may blush and reply that such praise is more than our due, the soul within us rejoices to hear itself praised.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:352
verses.text: Like the ark of the covenant Christ's spouse should be overlaid with gold within and without; she should be the guardian of the law of the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:353
verses.text: Just as the ark contained nothing but the tables of the covenant, so in you there should be no thought of anything that is outside.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:354
verses.text: For it pleases the Lord to sit in your mind as He once sat on the mercy-seat and the cherubims.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:355
verses.text: As He sent His disciples to loose Him the foal of an ass that he might ride on it, so He sends them to release you from the cares of the world, that leaving the bricks and straw of Egypt, you may follow Him, the true Moses, through the wilderness and may enter the land of promise.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:356
verses.text: Let no one dare to forbid you, neither mother nor sister nor kinswoman nor brother: "The Lord hath need of you".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:357
verses.text: Should they seek to hinder you, let them fear the scourges that fell on Pharaoh, who, because he would not let God's people go that they might serve Him, suffered the plagues described in Scripture.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:358
verses.text: Jesus entering into the temple cast out those things which belonged not to the temple.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:359
verses.text: For God is jealous and will not allow the father's house to be made a den of robbers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:360
verses.text: Where money is counted, where doves are sold, where simplicity is stifled where, that is, a virgin's breast glows with cares of this world; straightway the veil of the temple is rent, the bridegroom rises in anger, he says: "Your house is left unto you desolate".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:361
verses.text: Read the gospel and see how Mary sitting at the feet of the Lord is set before the zealous Martha.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:362
verses.text: In her anxiety to be hospitable Martha was preparing a meal for the Lord and His disciples; yet Jesus said to her: "Martha, Martha, thou art careful and troubled about many things.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:363
verses.text: But few things are needful or one.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:364
verses.text: And Mary hath chosen that good part which shall not be taken away from her".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:365
verses.text: Be then like Mary; prefer the food of the soul to that of the body.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:366
verses.text: Leave it to your sisters to run to and fro and to seek how they may fitly welcome Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:367
verses.text: But do you, having once for all cast away the burden of the world, sit at the Lord's feet and say: "I have found him whom my soul loveth; I will hold him, I will not let him go".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:368
verses.text: And He will answer: "My dove, my undefiled is but one; she is the only one of her mother, she is the choice one of her that bare her".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:369
verses.text: Now the mother of whom this is said is the heavenly Jerusalem.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:371
verses.text: Ever let the privacy of your chamber guard you; ever let the Bridegroom sport with you within.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:372
verses.text: Do you pray? You speak to the Bridegroom.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:373
verses.text: Do you read? He speaks to you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:374
verses.text: When sleep overtakes you He will come behind and put His hand through the hole of the door, and your heart shall be moved for Him; and you will awake and rise up and say: "I am sick of love".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:375
verses.text: Then He will reply: "A garden inclosed is my sister, my spouse; a spring shut up, a fountain sealed".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:376
verses.text: Go not from home nor visit the daughters of a strange land, though you have patriarchs for brothers and Israel for a father.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:377
verses.text: Dinah went out and was seduced.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:378
verses.text: Do not seek the Bridegroom in the streets; do not go round the corners of the city.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:379
verses.text: For though you may say: "I will rise now and go about the city: in the streets and in the broad ways I will seek Him whom my soul loveth," and though you may ask the watchmen: "Saw ye Him whom my soul loveth?" no one will deign to answer you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:380
verses.text: The Bridegroom cannot be found in the streets: "Strait and narrow is the way which leadeth unto life".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:381
verses.text: So the Song goes on: "I sought him but I could not find him: I called him but he gave me no answer".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:382
verses.text: And would that failure to find Him were all.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:383
verses.text: You will be wounded and stripped, you will lament and say: "The watchmen that went about the city found me: they smote me, they wounded me, they took away my veil from me".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:384
verses.text: Now if one who could say: "I sleep but my heart waketh," and "A bundle of myrrh is my well beloved unto me; he shall lie all night betwixt my breasts"; if one who could speak thus suffered so much because she went abroad, what shall become of us who are but young girls; of us who, when the bride goes in with the Bridegroom, still remain without? Jesus is jealous.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:385
verses.text: He does not choose that your face should be seen of others.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:386
verses.text: You may excuse yourself and say: "I have drawn close my veil, I have covered my face and I have sought Thee there and have said: 'Tell me, O Thou whom my soul loveth, where Thou feedest Thy flock, where Thou makest it to rest at noon.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:387
verses.text: For why should I be as one that is veiled beside the flocks of Thy companions?'" Yet in spite of your excuses He will be wroth, He will swell with anger and say: "If thou know not thyself, O thou fairest among women, go thy way forth by the footsteps of the flock and feed thy goats beside the shepherd's tents".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:388
verses.text: You may be fair, and of all faces yours may be the dearest to the Bridegroom; yet, unless you know yourself, and keep your heart with all diligence, unless also you avoid the eyes of the young men, you will be turned out of My bride-chamber to feed the goats, which shall be set on the left hand.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:390
verses.text: These things being so, my Eustochium, daughter, lady, fellow-servant, sister—these names refer the first to your age, the second to your rank, the third to your religious vocation, the last to the place which you hold in my affection—hear the words of Isaiah: "Come, my people, enter thou into thy chambers, and shut thy doors about thee: hide thyself as it were for a little moment, until the indignation" of the Lord "be overpast".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:391
verses.text: Let foolish virgins stray abroad, but for your part stay at home with the Bridegroom; for if you shut your door, and, according to the precept of the Gospel, pray to your Father in secret, He will come and knock, saying: "Behold, I stand at the door and knock; if any man…open the door, I will come in to him, and will sup with him, and he with me".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:392
verses.text: Then straightway you will eagerly reply: "It is the voice of my beloved that knocketh, saying, Open to me, my sister, my love, my dove, my undefiled".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:393
verses.text: It is impossible that you should refuse, and say: "I have put off my coat; how shall I put it on? I have washed my feet; how shall I defile them?" Arise forthwith and open.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:394
verses.text: Otherwise while you linger He may pass on and you may have mournfully to say: "I opened to my beloved, but my beloved was gone".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:395
verses.text: Why need the doors of your heart be closed to the Bridegroom? Let them be open to Christ but closed to the devil according to the saying: "If the spirit of him who hath power rise up against thee, leave not thy place".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:396
verses.text: Daniel, in that upper story to which he withdrew when he could no longer continue below, had his windows open toward Jerusalem.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:397
verses.text: Do you too keep your windows open, but only on the side where light may enter and whence you may see the eye of the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:398
verses.text: Open not those other windows of which the prophet says: "Death is come up into our windows".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:400
verses.text: You must also be careful to avoid the snare of a passion for vainglory.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:401
verses.text: "How," Jesus says, "can ye believe which receive glory one from another?" What an evil that must be the victim of which cannot believe! Let us rather say: "Thou art my glorying," and "He that glorieth, let him glory in the Lord," and "If I yet pleased men I should not be the servant of Christ," and "Far be it from me to glory save in the cross of our Lord Jesus Christ, through whom the world hath been crucified unto me and I unto the world;" and once more: "In God we boast all the day long; my soul shall make her boast in the Lord".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:402
verses.text: When you do alms, let God alone see you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:403
verses.text: When you fast, be of a cheerful countenance.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:404
verses.text: Let your dress be neither too neat nor too slovenly; neither let it be so remarkable as to draw the attention of passers-by, and to make men point their fingers at you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:405
verses.text: Is a brother dead? Has the body of a sister to be carried to its burial? Take care lest in too often performing such offices you die yourself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:406
verses.text: Do not wish to seem very devout nor more humble than need be, lest you seek glory by shunning it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:407
verses.text: For many, who screen from all men's sight their poverty, charity, and fasting, desire to excite admiration by their very disdain of it, and strangely seek for praise while they profess to keep out of its way.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:408
verses.text: From the other disturbing influences which make men rejoice, despond, hope, and fear I find many free; but this is a defect which few are without, and he is best whose character, like a fair skin, is disfigured by the fewest blemishes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:409
verses.text: I do not think it necessary to warn you against boasting of your riches, or against priding yourself on your birth, or against setting yourself up as superior to others.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:410
verses.text: I know your humility; I know that you can say with sincerity: "Lord, my heart is not haughty nor mine eyes lofty;" I know that in your breast as in that of your mother the pride through which the devil fell has no place.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:411
verses.text: It would be time wasted to write to you about it; for there is no greater folly than to teach a pupil what he knows already.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:412
verses.text: But now that you have despised the boastfulness of the world, do not let the fact inspire you with new boastfulness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:413
verses.text: Harbor not the secret thought that having ceased to court attention in garments of gold you may begin to do so in mean attire.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:414
verses.text: And when you come into a room full of brothers and sisters, do not sit in too low a place or plead that you are unworthy of a footstool.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:415
verses.text: Do not deliberately lower your voice as though worn out with fasting; nor, leaning on the shoulder of another, mimic the tottering gait of one who is faint.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:416
verses.text: Some women, it is true, disfigure their faces, that they may appear unto men to fast.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:417
verses.text: As soon as they catch sight of any one they groan, they look down; they cover up their faces, all but one eye, which they keep free to see with.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:418
verses.text: Their dress is sombre, their girdles are of sackcloth, their hands and feet are dirty; only their stomachs—which cannot be seen—are hot with food.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:419
verses.text: Of these the psalm is sung daily: "The Lord will scatter the bones of them that please themselves".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:420
verses.text: Others change their garb and assume the mien of men, being ashamed of being what they were born to be—women.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:421
verses.text: They cut off their hair and are not ashamed to look like eunuchs.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:422
verses.text: Some clothe themselves in goat's hair, and, putting on hoods, think to become children again by making themselves look like so many owls.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:424
verses.text: But I will not speak only of women.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:425
verses.text: Avoid men, also, when you see them loaded with chains and wearing their hair long like women, contrary to the apostle's precept, not to speak of beards like those of goats, black cloaks, and bare feet braving the cold.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:426
verses.text: All these things are tokens of the devil.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:427
verses.text: Such an one Rome groaned over some time back in Antimus; and Sophronius is a still more recent instance.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:428
verses.text: Such persons, when they have once gained admission to the houses of the high-born, and have deceived "silly women laden with sins, ever learning and never able to come to the knowledge of the truth," feign a sad mien and pretend to make long fasts while at night they feast in secret.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:429
verses.text: Shame forbids me to say more, for my language might appear more like invective than admonition.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:430
verses.text: There are others—I speak of those of my own order—who seek the presbyterate and the diaconate simply that they may be able to see women with less restraint.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:431
verses.text: Such men think of nothing but their dress; they use perfumes freely, and see that there are no creases in their leather shoes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:432
verses.text: Their curling hair shows traces of the tongs; their fingers glisten with rings; they walk on tiptoe across a damp road, not to splash their feet.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:433
verses.text: When you see men acting in this way, think of them rather as bridegrooms than as clergymen.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:434
verses.text: Certain persons have devoted the whole of their energies and life to the single object of knowing the names, houses, and characters of married ladies.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:435
verses.text: I will here briefly describe the head of the profession, that from the master's likeness you may recognize the disciples.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:436
verses.text: He rises and goes forth with the sun; he has the order of his visits duly arranged; he takes the shortest road; and, troublesome old man that he is, forces his way almost into the bedchambers of ladies yet asleep.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:437
verses.text: If he sees a pillow that takes his fancy or an elegant table-cover—or indeed any article of household furniture—he praises it, looks admiringly at it, takes it into his hand, and, complaining that he has nothing of the kind, begs or rather extorts it from the owner.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:438
verses.text: All the women, in fact, fear to cross the news-carrier of the town.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:439
verses.text: Chastity and fasting are alike distasteful to him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:440
verses.text: What he likes is a savory breakfast—say off a plump young crane such as is commonly called a cheeper.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:441
verses.text: In speech he is rude and forward, and is always ready to bandy reproaches.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:442
verses.text: Wherever you turn he is the first man that you see before you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:443
verses.text: Whatever news is noised abroad he is either the originator of the rumor or its magnifier.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:444
verses.text: He changes his horses every hour; and they are so sleek and spirited that you would take him for a brother of the Thracian king.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:446
verses.text: Many are the stratagems which the wily enemy employs against us.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:447
verses.text: "The serpent," we are told, "was more subtile than any beast of the field which the Lord God had made".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:448
verses.text: And the apostle says: "We are not ignorant of his devices".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:449
verses.text: Neither an affected shabbiness nor a stylish smartness becomes a Christian.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:450
verses.text: If there is anything of which you are ignorant, if you have any doubt about Scripture, ask one whose life commends him, whose age puts him above suspicion, whose reputation does not belie him; one who may be able to say: "I have espoused you to one husband that I may present you as a chaste virgin to Christ".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:451
verses.text: Or if there should be none such able to explain, it is better to avoid danger at the price of ignorance than to court it for the sake of learning.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:452
verses.text: Remember that you walk in the midst of snares, and that many veteran virgins, of a chastity never called in question, have, on the very threshold of death, let their crowns fall from their hands.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:453
verses.text: If any of your handmaids share your vocation, do not lift up yourself against them or pride yourself because you are their mistress.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:454
verses.text: You have all chosen one Bridegroom; you all sing the same psalms; together you receive the Body of Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:455
verses.text: Why then should your thoughts be different? You must try to win others, and that you may attract the more readily you must treat the virgins in your train with the greatest respect.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:456
verses.text: If you find one of them weak in the faith, be attentive to her, comfort her, caress her, and make her chastity your treasure.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:457
verses.text: But if a girl pretends to have a vocation simply because she desires to escape from service, read aloud to her the words of the apostle: "It is better to marry than to burn".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:458
verses.text: Idle persons and busybodies, whether virgins or widows; such as go from house to house calling on married women and displaying an unblushing effrontery greater than that of a stage parasite, cast from you as you would the plague.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:459
verses.text: For "evil communications corrupt good manners," and women like these care for nothing but their lowest appetites.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:460
verses.text: They will often urge you, saying, "My dear creature, make the best of your advantages, and live while life is yours," and "Surely you are not laying up money for your children".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:461
verses.text: Given to wine and wantonness, they instill all manner of mischief into people's minds, and induce even the most austere to indulge in enervating pleasures.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:462
verses.text: And "when they have begun to wax wanton against Christ they will marry, having condemnation because they have rejected their first faith".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:463
verses.text: Do not seek to appear over-eloquent, nor trifle with verse, nor make yourself gay with lyric songs.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:464
verses.text: And do not, out of affectation, follow the sickly taste of married ladies who, now pressing their teeth together, now keeping their lips wide apart, speak with a lisp, and purposely clip their words, because they fancy that to pronounce them naturally is a mark of country breeding.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:465
verses.text: Accordingly they find pleasure in what I may call an adultery of the tongue.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:466
verses.text: For "what communion hath light with darkness? And what concord hath Christ with Belial?" How can Horace go with the psalter, Virgil with the gospels, Cicero with the apostle? Is not a brother made to stumble if he sees you sitting at meat in an idol's temple? Although "unto the pure all things are pure," and "nothing is to be refused if it be received with thanksgiving," still we ought not to drink the cup of Christ, and, at the same time, the cup of devils.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:467
verses.text: Let me relate to you the story of my own miserable experience.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:469
verses.text: Many years ago, when for the kingdom of heaven's sake I had cut myself off from home, parents, sister, relations, and—harder still—from the dainty food to which I had been accustomed; and when I was on my way to Jerusalem to wage my warfare, I still could not bring myself to forego the library which I had formed for myself at Rome with great care and toil.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:470
verses.text: And so, miserable man that I was, I would fast only that I might afterwards read Cicero.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:471
verses.text: After many nights spent in vigil, after floods of tears called from my inmost heart, after the recollection of my past sins, I would once more take up Plautus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:472
verses.text: And when at times I returned to my right mind, and began to read the prophets, their style seemed rude and repellent.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:473
verses.text: I failed to see the light with my blinded eyes; but I attributed the fault not to them, but to the sun.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:474
verses.text: While the old serpent was thus making me his plaything, about the middle of Lent a deep-seated fever fell upon my weakened body, and while it destroyed my rest completely—the story seems hardly credible—it so wasted my unhappy frame that scarcely anything was left of me but skin and bone.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:475
verses.text: Meantime preparations for my funeral went on; my body grew gradually colder, and the warmth of life lingered only in my throbbing breast.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:476
verses.text: Suddenly I was caught up in the spirit and dragged before the judgment seat of the Judge; and here the light was so bright, and those who stood around were so radiant, that I cast myself upon the ground and did not dare to look up.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:477
verses.text: Asked who and what I was I replied: "I am a Christian".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:478
verses.text: But He who presided said: "Thou liest, thou art a follower of Cicero and not of Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:479
verses.text: For 'where thy treasure is, there will thy heart be also.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:480
verses.text: '" Instantly I became dumb, and amid the strokes of the lash—for He had ordered me to be scourged—I was tortured more severely still by the fire of conscience, considering with myself that verse, "In the grave who shall give thee thanks?" Yet for all that I began to cry and to bewail myself, saying: "Have mercy upon me, O Lord: have mercy upon me".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:481
verses.text: Amid the sound of the scourges this cry still made itself heard.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:482
verses.text: At last the bystanders, falling down before the knees of Him who presided, prayed that He would have pity on my youth, and that He would give me space to repent of my error.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:483
verses.text: He might still, they urged, inflict torture on me, should I ever again read the works of the Gentiles.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:484
verses.text: Under the stress of that awful moment I should have been ready to make even still larger promises than these.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:485
verses.text: Accordingly I made oath and called upon His name, saying: "Lord, if ever again I possess worldly books, or if ever again I read such, I have denied Thee".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:486
verses.text: Dismissed, then, on taking this oath, I returned to the upper world, and, to the surprise of all, I opened upon them eyes so drenched with tears that my distress served to convince even the incredulous.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:487
verses.text: And that this was no sleep nor idle dream, such as those by which we are often mocked, I call to witness the tribunal before which I lay, and the terrible judgment which I feared.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:488
verses.text: May it never, hereafter, be my lot to fall under such an inquisition! I profess that my shoulders were black and blue, that I felt the bruises long after I awoke from my sleep, and that thenceforth I read the books of God with a zeal greater than I had previously given to the books of men.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:490
verses.text: You must also avoid the sin of covetousness, and this not merely by refusing to seize upon what belongs to others, for that is punished by the laws of the state, but also by not keeping your own property, which has now become no longer yours.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:491
verses.text: "If have not been faithful," the Lord says, "in that which is another man's, who shall give you that which is your own?" "That which is another man's" is a quantity of gold or of silver, while "that which is our own" is the spiritual heritage of which it is elsewhere said: "The ransom of a man's life is his riches".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:492
verses.text: "No man can serve two masters, for either he will hate the one and love the other; or else he will hold to the one and despise the other.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:493
verses.text: Ye cannot serve God and Mammon".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:494
verses.text: Riches, that is; for in the heathen tongue of the Syrians riches are called mammon.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:495
verses.text: The "thorns" which choke our faith are the taking thought for our life.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:496
verses.text: Care for the things which the Gentiles seek after is the root of covetousness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:497
verses.text: But you will say: "I am a girl delicately reared, and I cannot labor with my hands.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:498
verses.text: Suppose that I live to old age and then fall sick, who will take pity on me?" Hear Jesus speaking to the apostles: "Take no thought what ye shall eat; nor yet for your body what ye shall put on.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:499
verses.text: Is not the life more than meat, and the body than raiment? Behold the fowls of the air: for they sow not, neither do they reap nor gather into barns; yet your heavenly Father feedeth them".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:500
verses.text: Should clothing fail you, set the lilies before your eyes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:501
verses.text: Should hunger seize you, think of the words in which the poor and hungry are blessed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:502
verses.text: Should pain afflict you, read "Therefore I take pleasure in infirmities," and "There was given to me a thorn in the flesh, the messenger of Satan to buffet me, lest I should be exalted above measure".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:503
verses.text: Rejoice in all God's judgments; for does not the psalmist say: "The daughters of Judah rejoiced because of thy judgments, O Lord"? Let the words be ever on your lips: "Naked came I out of my mother's womb, and naked shall I return thither;" and "We brought nothing into this world, and it is certain we can carry nothing out".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:505
verses.text: To-day you may see women cramming their wardrobes with dresses, changing their gowns from day to day, and for all that unable to vanquish the moths.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:506
verses.text: Now and then one more scrupulous wears out a single dress; yet, while she appears in rags, her boxes are full.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:507
verses.text: Parchments are dyed purple, gold is melted into lettering, manuscripts are decked with jewels, while Christ lies at the door naked and dying.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:508
verses.text: When they hold out a hand to the needy they sound a trumpet; when they invite to a love-feast they engage a crier.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:509
verses.text: I lately saw the noblest lady in Rome—I suppress her name, for I am no satirist—with a band of eunuchs before her in the basilica of the blessed Peter.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:510
verses.text: She was giving money to the poor, a coin apiece; and this with her own hand, that she might be accounted more religious.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:511
verses.text: Hereupon a by no means uncommon incident occurred.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:512
verses.text: An old woman, "full of years and rags," ran forward to get a second coin, but when her turn came she received not a penny but a blow hard enough to draw blood from her guilty veins.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:513
verses.text: "The love of money is the root of all evil," and the apostle speaks of covetousness as being idolatry.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:514
verses.text: "Seek ye first the kingdom of God and all these things shall be added unto you".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:515
verses.text: The Lord will never allow a righteous soul to perish of hunger.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:516
verses.text: "I have been young," the psalmist says, "and now am old, yet have I not seen the righteous forsaken nor his seed begging bread".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:517
verses.text: Elijah is fed by ministering ravens.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:518
verses.text: The widow of Zarephath, who with her sons expected to die the same night, went without food herself that she might feed the prophet.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:519
verses.text: He who had come to be fed then turned feeder, for, by a miracle, he filled the empty barrel.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:520
verses.text: The apostle Peter says: "Silver and gold have I none, but such as I have give I thee.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:521
verses.text: In the name of Jesus Christ rise up and walk".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:522
verses.text: But now many, while they do not say it in words, by their deeds declare: "Faith and pity have I none; but such as I have, silver and gold, these I will not give thee".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:523
verses.text: "Having food and raiment let us be therewith content".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:524
verses.text: Hear the prayer of Jacob: "If God will be with me and will keep me in this way that I go, and will give me bread to eat and raiment to put on, then shall the Lord be my God".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:525
verses.text: He prayed only for things necessary; yet, twenty years afterwards, he returned to the land of Canaan rich in substance and richer still in children.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:526
verses.text: Numberless are the instances in Scripture which teach men to "Beware of covetousness".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:528
verses.text: As I have been led to touch to the subject—it shall have a treatise to itself if Christ permit—I will relate what took place not very many years ago at Nitria.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:529
verses.text: A brother, more thrifty than covetous, and ignorant that the Lord had been sold for thirty pieces of silver, left behind him at his death a hundred pieces of money which he had earned by weaving linen.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:530
verses.text: As there were about five thousand monks in the neighborhood, living in as many separate cells, a council was held as to what should be done.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:531
verses.text: Some said that the coins should be distributed among the poor; others that they should be given to the church, while others were for sending them back to the relatives of the deceased.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:532
verses.text: However, Macarius, Pambo, Isidore and the rest of those called fathers, speaking by the Spirit, decided that they should be interred with their owner, with the words: "Thy money perish with thee".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:533
verses.text: Nor was this too harsh a decision; for so great fear has fallen upon all throughout Egypt, that it is now a crime to leave after one a single shilling.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:535
verses.text: As I have mentioned the monks, and know that you like to hear about holy things, lend an ear to me for a few moments.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:536
verses.text: There are in Egypt three classes of monks.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:537
verses.text: First, there are the coenobites, called in their Gentile language Sauses, or, as we should say, men living in a community.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:538
verses.text: Secondly, there are the anchorites, who live in the desert, each man by himself, and are so called because they have withdrawn from human society.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:539
verses.text: Thirdly, there is the class called Remoboth, a very inferior and little regarded type, peculiar to my own province, or, at least, originating there.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:540
verses.text: These live together in twos and threes, but seldom in larger numbers, and are bound by no rule; but do exactly as they choose.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:541
verses.text: A portion of their earnings they contribute to a common fund, out of which food is provided for all.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:542
verses.text: In most cases they reside in cities and strongholds; and, as though it were their workmanship which is holy, and not their life, all that they sell is extremely dear.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:543
verses.text: They often quarrel because they are unwilling, while supplying their own food, to be subordinate to others.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:544
verses.text: It is true that they compete with each other in fasting; they make what should be a private concern an occasion for a triumph.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:545
verses.text: In everything they study effect: their sleeves are loose, their boots bulge, their garb is of the coarsest.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:546
verses.text: They are always sighing, or visiting virgins, or sneering at the clergy; yet when a holiday comes, they make themselves sick—they eat so much.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:548
verses.text: Having then rid ourselves of these as of so many plagues, let us come to that more numerous class who live together, and who are, as we have said, called Coenobites.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:549
verses.text: Among these the first principle of union is to obey superiors and to do whatever they command.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:550
verses.text: They are divided into bodies of ten and of a hundred, so that each tenth man has authority over nine others, while the hundredth has ten of these officers under him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:551
verses.text: They live apart from each other, in separate cells.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:552
verses.text: According to their rule, no monk may visit another before the ninth hour; except the deans above mentioned, whose office is to comfort, with soothing words, those whose thoughts disquiet them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:553
verses.text: After the ninth hour they meet together to sing psalms and read the Scriptures according to usage.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:554
verses.text: Then when the prayers have ended and all have sat down, one called the father stands up among them and begins to expound the portion of the day.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:555
verses.text: While he is speaking the silence is profound; no man ventures to look at his neighbor or to clear his throat.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:556
verses.text: The speaker's praise is in the weeping of his hearers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:557
verses.text: Silent tears roll down their cheeks, but not a sob escapes from their lips.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:558
verses.text: Yet when he begins to speak of Christ's kingdom, and of future bliss, and of the glory which is to come, every one may be noticed saying to himself, with a gentle sigh and uplifted eyes: "Oh, that I had wings like a dove! For then would I fly away and be at rest".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:559
verses.text: After this the meeting breaks up and each company of ten goes with its father to its own table.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:560
verses.text: This they take in turns to serve each for a week at a time.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:561
verses.text: No noise is made over the food; no one talks while eating.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:562
verses.text: Bread, pulse and greens form their fare, and the only seasoning that they use is salt.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:563
verses.text: Wine is given only to the old, who with the children often have a special meal prepared for them to repair the ravages of age and to save the young from premature decay.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:564
verses.text: When the meal is over they all rise together, and, after singing a hymn, return to their dwellings.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:565
verses.text: There each one talks till evening with his comrade thus: "Have you noticed so-and-so? What grace he has! How silent he is! How soberly he walks!" If any one is weak they comfort him; or if he is fervent in love to God, they encourage him to fresh earnestness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:566
verses.text: And because at night, besides the public prayers, each man keeps vigil in his own chamber, they go round all the cells one by one, and putting their ears to the doors, carefully ascertain what their occupants are doing.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:567
verses.text: If they find a monk slothful, they do not scold him; but, dissembling what they know, they visit him more frequently, and at first exhort rather than compel him to pray more.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:568
verses.text: Each day has its allotted task, and this being given in to the dean, is by him brought to the steward.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:569
verses.text: This latter, once a month, gives a scrupulous account to their common father.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:570
verses.text: He also tastes the dishes when they are cooked, and, as no one is allowed to say, "I am without a tunic or a cloak or a couch of rushes," he so arranges that no one need ask for or go without what he wants.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:571
verses.text: In case a monk falls ill, he is moved to a more spacious chamber, and there so attentively nursed by the old men, that he misses neither the luxury of cities nor a mother's kindness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:572
verses.text: Every Lord's day they spend their whole time in prayer and reading; indeed, when they have finished their tasks, these are their usual occupations.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:573
verses.text: Every day they learn by heart a portion of Scripture.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:574
verses.text: They keep the same fasts all the year round, but in Lent they are allowed to live more strictly.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:575
verses.text: After Whitsuntide they exchange their evening meal for a midday one; both to satisfy the tradition of the church and to avoid overloading their stomachs with a double supply of food.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:576
verses.text: A similar description is given of the Essenes by Philo, Plato's imitator; also by Josephus, the Greek Livy, in his narrative of the Jewish captivity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:578
verses.text: As my present subject is virgins, I have said rather too much about monks.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:579
verses.text: I will pass on, therefore, to the third class, called anchorites, who go from the monasteries into the deserts, with nothing but bread and salt.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:580
verses.text: Paul introduced this way of life; Antony made it famous, and—to go farther back still—John the Baptist set the first example of it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:581
verses.text: The prophet Jeremiah describes one such in the words: "It is good for a man that he bear the yoke in his youth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:582
verses.text: He sitteth alone and keepeth silence, because he hath borne it upon him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:583
verses.text: He giveth his cheek to him that smiteth him, he is filled full with reproach.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:584
verses.text: For the Lord will not cast off forever".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:585
verses.text: The struggle of the anchorites and their life—in the flesh, yet not of the flesh—I will, if you wish, explain to you at some other time.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:586
verses.text: I must now return to the subject of covetousness, which I left to speak of the monks.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:587
verses.text: With them before your eyes you will despise, not only gold and silver in general, but earth itself and heaven.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:588
verses.text: United to Christ, you will sing, "The Lord is my portion".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:590
verses.text: Farther, although the apostle bids us to "pray without ceasing," and although to the saints their very sleep is a supplication, we ought to have fixed hours of prayer, that if we are detained by work, the time may remind us of our duty.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:591
verses.text: Prayers, as every one knows, ought to be said at the third, sixth and ninth hours, at dawn and at evening.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:592
verses.text: No meal should be begun without prayer, and before leaving table thanks should be returned to the Creator.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:593
verses.text: We should rise two or three times in the night, and go over the parts of Scripture which we know by heart.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:594
verses.text: When we leave the roof which shelters us, prayer should be our armor; and when we return from the street we should pray before we sit down, and not give the frail body rest until the soul is fed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:595
verses.text: In every act we do, in every step we take, let our hand trace the Lord's cross.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:596
verses.text: Speak against nobody, and do not slander your mother's son.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:597
