verses.text: "Who art thou that judgest the servant of another? To his own lord he standeth or falleth; yea, he shall be made to stand, for the Lord hath power to make him stand".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:598
verses.text: If you have fasted two or three days, do not think yourself better than others who do not fast.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:599
verses.text: You fast and are angry; another eats and wears a smiling face.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:600
verses.text: You work off your irritation and hunger in quarrels.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:601
verses.text: He uses food in moderation and gives God thanks.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:602
verses.text: Daily Isaiah cries: "Is it such a fast that I have chosen, saith the Lord?" and again: "In the day of your fast ye find your own pleasure, and oppress all your laborers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:603
verses.text: Behold ye fast for strife and contention, and to smite with the fist of wickedness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:604
verses.text: How fast ye unto me?" What kind of fast can his be whose wrath is such that not only does the night go down upon it, but that even the moon's changes leave it unchanged?  38.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:605
verses.text: Look to yourself and glory in your own success and not in others' failure.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:606
verses.text: Some women care for the flesh and reckon up their income and daily expenditure: such are no fit models for you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:607
verses.text: Judas was a traitor, but the eleven apostles did not waver.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:608
verses.text: Phygellus and Alexander made shipwreck; but the rest continued to run the race of faith.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:609
verses.text: Say not: "So-and-so enjoys her own property, she is honored of men, her brothers and sisters come to see her.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:610
verses.text: Has she then ceased to be a virgin?" In the first place, it is doubtful if she is a virgin.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:611
verses.text: For "the Lord seeth not as man seeth; for man looketh upon the outward appearance, but the Lord looketh on the heart".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:612
verses.text: Again, she may be a virgin in body and not in spirit.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:613
verses.text: According to the apostle, a true virgin is "holy both in body and in spirit".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:614
verses.text: Lastly, let her glory in her own way.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:615
verses.text: Let her override Paul's opinion and live in the enjoyment of her good things.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:616
verses.text: But you and I must follow better examples.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:617
verses.text: Set before you the blessed Mary, whose surpassing purity made her meet to be the mother of the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:618
verses.text: When the angel Gabriel came down to her, in the form of a man, and said: "Hail, thou that art highly favored; the Lord is with thee," she was terror-stricken and unable to reply, for she had never been saluted by a man before.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:619
verses.text: But, on learning who he was, she spoke, and one who had been afraid of a man conversed fearlessly with an angel.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:620
verses.text: Now you, too, may be the Lord's mother.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:621
verses.text: "Take thee a great roll and write in it with a man's pen Maher-shalal-hash-baz".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:622
verses.text: And when you have gone to the prophetess, and have conceived in the womb, and have brought forth a son, say: "Lord, we have been with child by thy fear, we have been in pain, we have brought forth the spirit of thy salvation, which we have wrought upon the earth".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:623
verses.text: Then shall your Son reply: "Behold my mother and my brethren".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:624
verses.text: And He whose name you have so recently inscribed upon the table of your heart, and have written with a pen upon its renewed surface—He, after He has recovered the spoil from the enemy, and has spoiled principalities and powers, nailing them to His cross—having been miraculously conceived, grows up to manhood; and, as He becomes older, regards you no longer as His mother, but as His bride.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:625
verses.text: To be as the martyrs, or as the apostles, or as Christ, involves a hard struggle, but brings with it a great reward.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:626
verses.text: All such efforts are only of use when they are made within the church's pale; we must celebrate the passover in the one house, we must enter the ark with Noah, we must take refuge from the fall of Jericho with the justified harlot, Rahab.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:627
verses.text: Such virgins as there are said to be among the heretics and among the followers of the infamous Manes must be considered, not virgins, but prostitutes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:628
verses.text: For if—as they allege—the devil is the author of the body, how can they honor that which is fashioned by their foe? No; it is because they know that the name virgin brings glory with it, that they go about as wolves in sheep's clothing.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:629
verses.text: As antichrist pretends to be Christ, such virgins assume an honorable name, that they may the better cloak a discreditable life.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:630
verses.text: Rejoice, my sister; rejoice, my daughter; rejoice, my virgin; for you have resolved to be, in reality, that which others insincerely feign.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:632
verses.text: The things that I have here set forth will seem hard to her who loves not Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:633
verses.text: But one who has come to regard all the splendor of the world as off-scourings, and to hold all things under the sun as vain, that he may win Christ; one who has died with his Lord and risen again, and has crucified the flesh with its affections and lusts; he will boldly cry out: "Who shall separate us from the love of Christ? Shall tribulation, or distress, or persecution, or famine, or nakedness, or peril, or sword?" and again: "I am persuaded that neither death nor life, nor angels, nor principalities nor powers, nor things present, nor things to come, nor height, nor depth, nor any other creature shall be able to separate us from the love of God which is in Christ Jesus, our Lord".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:634
verses.text: For our salvation the Son of God is made the Son of Man.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:635
verses.text: Nine months He awaits His birth in the womb, undergoes the most revolting conditions, and comes forth covered with blood, to be swathed in rags and covered with caresses.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:636
verses.text: He who shuts up the world in His fist is contained in the narrow limits of a manger.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:637
verses.text: I say nothing of the thirty years during which he lives in obscurity, satisfied with the poverty of his parents.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:638
verses.text: When He is scourged He holds His peace; when He is crucified, He prays for His crucifiers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:639
verses.text: "What shall I render unto the Lord for all His benefits towards me? I will take the cup of salvation and call upon the name of the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:640
verses.text: Precious in the sight of the Lord is the death of His saints".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:641
verses.text: The only fitting return that we can make to Him is to give blood for blood; and, as we are redeemed by the blood of Christ, gladly to lay down our lives for our Redeemer.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:642
verses.text: What saint has ever won his crown without first contending for it? Righteous Abel is murdered.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:643
verses.text: Abraham is in danger of losing his wife.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:644
verses.text: And, as I must not enlarge my book unduly, seek for yourself: you will find that all holy men have suffered adversity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:645
verses.text: Solomon alone lived in luxury and perhaps it was for this reason that he fell.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:646
verses.text: For "whom the Lord loveth, He chasteneth, and scourgeth every son whom He receiveth".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:647
verses.text: Which is best—for a short time to do battle, to carry stakes for the palisades, to bear arms, to faint under heavy bucklers, that ever afterwards we may rejoice as victors? or to become slaves forever, just because we cannot endure for a single hour?  40.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:648
verses.text: Love finds nothing hard; no task is difficult to the eager.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:649
verses.text: Think of all that Jacob bore for Rachel, the wife who had been promised to him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:650
verses.text: "Jacob," the Scripture says, "served seven years for Rachel.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:651
verses.text: And they seemed unto him but a few days for the love he had to her".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:652
verses.text: Afterwards he himself tells us what he had to undergo.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:653
verses.text: "In the day the drought consumed me and the frost by night".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:654
verses.text: So we must love Christ and always seek His embraces.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:655
verses.text: Then everything difficult will seem easy; all things long we shall account short; and smitten with His arrows, we shall say every moment: "Woe is me that I have prolonged my pilgrimage".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:656
verses.text: For "the sufferings of this present time are not worthy to be compared with the glory which shall be revealed in us".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:657
verses.text: For "tribulation worketh patience, and patience experience, and experience hope; and hope maketh not ashamed".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:658
verses.text: When your lot seems hard to bear read Paul's second epistle to the Corinthians: "In labors more abundant; in stripes above measure; in prisons more frequent; in deaths oft.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:659
verses.text: Of the Jews five times received I forty stripes save one; thrice was I beaten with rods; once was I stoned; thrice I suffered shipwreck; a night and a day I have been in the deep; in journeyings often, in perils of waters, in perils of robbers, in perils by mine own countrymen, in perils by the heathen, in perils in the city, in perils in the wilderness, in perils in the sea, in perils among false brethren, in weariness and painfulness, in watchings often, in hunger and thirst, in fastings often, in cold and nakedness".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:660
verses.text: Which of us can claim the veriest fraction of the virtues here enumerated? Yet it was these which afterwards made him bold to say: "I have finished my course, I have kept the faith.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:661
verses.text: Henceforth there is laid up for me a crown of righteousness which the Lord, the righteous Judge, shall give me at that day".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:662
verses.text: But we, if our food is less appetizing than usual, get sullen, and fancy that we do God a favor by drinking watered wine.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:663
verses.text: And if the water brought to us is a trifle too warm, we break the cup and overturn the table and scourge the servant in fault until blood comes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:664
verses.text: "The kingdom of heaven suffereth violence and the violent take it by force".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:665
verses.text: Still, unless you use force you will never seize the kingdom of heaven.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:666
verses.text: Unless you knock importunately you will never receive the sacramental bread.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:667
verses.text: Is it not truly violence, think you, when the flesh desires to be as God and ascends to the place whence angels have fallen to judge angels?  41.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:668
verses.text: Emerge, I pray you, for a while from your prison-house, and paint before your eyes the reward of your present toil, a reward which "eye hath not seen, nor ear heard, neither hath it entered into the heart of man".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:669
verses.text: What will be the glory of that day when Mary, the mother of the Lord, shall come to meet you, accompanied by her virgin choirs! When, the Red Sea past and Pharaoh drowned with his host, Miriam, Aaron's sister, her timbrel in her hand, shall chant to the answering women: "Sing ye unto the Lord, for he hath triumphed gloriously; the horse and his rider hath he thrown into the sea".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:670
verses.text: Then shall Thecla fly with joy to embrace you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:671
verses.text: Then shall your Spouse himself come forward and say: "Rise up, my love, my fair one, and come away, for lo! the winter is past, the rain is over and gone".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:672
verses.text: Then shall the angels say with wonder: "Who is she that looketh forth as the morning, fair as the moon, clear as the sun?" "The daughters shall see you and bless you; yea, the queens shall proclaim and the concubines shall praise you".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:673
verses.text: And, after these, yet another company of chaste women will meet you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:674
verses.text: Sarah will come with the wedded; Anna, the daughter of Phanuel, with the widows.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:675
verses.text: In the one band you will find your natural mother and in the other your spiritual.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:676
verses.text: The one will rejoice in having borne, the other will exult in having taught you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:677
verses.text: Then truly will the Lord ride upon his ass, and thus enter the heavenly Jerusalem.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:678
verses.text: Then the little ones (of whom, in Isaiah, the Saviour says: "Behold, I and the children whom the Lord hath given me") shall lift up palms of victory and shall sing with one voice: "Hosanna in the highest, blessed is he that cometh in the name of the Lord, hosanna in the highest".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:679
verses.text: Then shall the "hundred and forty and four thousand" hold their harps before the throne and before the elders and shall sing the new song.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:680
verses.text: And no man shall have power to learn that song save those for whom it is appointed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:681
verses.text: "These are they which were not defiled with women; for they are virgins.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:682
verses.text: These are they which follow the Lamb whithersoever he goeth".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:683
verses.text: As often as this life's idle show tries to charm you; as often as you see in the world some vain pomp, transport yourself in mind to Paradise, essay to be now what you will be hereafter, and you will hear your Spouse say: "Set me as a sunshade in thine heart and as a seal upon thine arm".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 22:684
verses.text: And then, strengthened in body as well as in mind, you, too, will cry aloud and say: "Many waters cannot quench love, neither can the floods drown it".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 23:1
verses.text: Letter XXIII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 23:2
verses.text: To Marcella.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 23:3
verses.text: Jerome writes to Marcella to console her for the loss of a friend who, like herself, was the head of a religious society at Rome.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 23:4
verses.text: The news of Lea's death had first reached Marcella when she was engaged with Jerome in the study of the 73d psalm.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 23:5
verses.text: Later in the day he writes this letter in which, after extolling Lea, he contrasts her end with that of the consul-elect, Vettius Agorius Praetextatus, a man of great ability and integrity, whom he declares to be now "in Tartarus".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 23:6
verses.text: Written at Rome in 384 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 23:7
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 23:9
verses.text: To-day, about the third hour, just as I was beginning to read with you the seventy-second psalm—the first, that is, of the third book—and to explain that its title belonged partly to the second book and partly to the third—the previous book, I mean, concluding with the words "the prayers of David the son of Jesse are ended," and the next commencing with the words "a psalm of Asaph"—and just as I had come on the passage in which the righteous man declares: "If I say, I will speak thus; behold I should offend against the generation of thy children," a verse which is differently rendered in our Latin version:—suddenly the news came that our most saintly friend Lea had departed from the body.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 23:10
verses.text: As was only natural, you turned deadly pale; for there are few persons, if any, who do not burst into tears when the earthen vessel breaks.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 23:11
verses.text: But if you wept it was not from doubt as to her future lot, but only because you had not rendered to her the last sad offices which are due to the dead.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 23:12
verses.text: Finally, as we were still conversing together, a second message informed us that her remains had been already conveyed to Ostia.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 23:14
verses.text: You may ask what is the use of repeating all this.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 23:15
verses.text: I will reply in the apostle's words, "much every way".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 23:16
verses.text: First, it shows that all must hail with joy the release of a soul which has trampled Satan under foot, and won for itself, at last, a crown of tranquillity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 23:17
verses.text: Secondly, it gives me an opportunity of briefly describing her life.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 23:18
verses.text: Thirdly, it enables me to assure you that the consul-elect, that detractor of his age, is now in Tartarus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 23:19
verses.text: Who can sufficiently eulogize our dear Lea's mode of living? So complete was her conversion to the Lord that, becoming the head of a monastery, she showed herself a true mother to the virgins in it, wore coarse sackcloth instead of soft raiment, passed sleepless nights in prayer, and instructed her companions even more by example than by precept.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 23:20
verses.text: So great was her humility that she, who had once been the mistress of many, was accounted the servant of all; and certainly, the less she was reckoned an earthly mistress the more she became a servant of Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 23:21
verses.text: She was careless of her dress, neglected her hair, and ate only the coarsest food.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 23:22
verses.text: Still, in all that she did, she avoided ostentation that she might not have her reward in this world.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 23:24
verses.text: Now, therefore, in return for her short toil, Lea enjoys everlasting felicity; she is welcomed into the choirs of the angels; she is comforted in Abraham's bosom.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 23:25
verses.text: And, as once the beggar Lazarus saw the rich man, for all his purple, lying in torment, so does Lea see the consul, not now in his triumphal robe but clothed in mourning, and asking for a drop of water from her little finger.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 23:26
verses.text: How great a change have we here! A few days ago the highest dignitaries of the city walked before him as he ascended the ramparts of the capitol like a general celebrating a triumph; the Roman people leapt up to welcome and applaud him, and at the news of his death the whole city was moved.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 23:27
verses.text: Now he is desolate and naked, a prisoner in the foulest darkness, and not, as his unhappy wife falsely asserts, set in the royal abode of the milky way.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 23:28
verses.text: On the other hand Lea, who was always shut up in her one closet, who seemed poor and of little worth, and whose life was accounted madness, now follows Christ and sings, "Like as we have heard, so have we seen in the city of our God".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 23:30
verses.text: And now for the moral of all this, which, with tears and groans, I conjure you to remember.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 23:31
verses.text: While we run the way of this world, we must not clothe ourselves with two coats, that is, with a twofold faith, or burthen ourselves with leathern shoes, that is, with dead works; we must not allow scrips filled with money to weigh us down, or lean upon the staff of worldly power.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 23:32
verses.text: We must not seek to possess both Christ and the world.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 23:33
verses.text: No; things eternal must take the place of things transitory; and since, physically speaking, we daily anticipate death, if we wish for immortality we must realize that we are but mortal.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 24:1
verses.text: Letter XXIV.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 24:2
verses.text: To Marcella.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 24:3
verses.text: Concerning the virgin Asella.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 24:4
verses.text: Dedicated to God before her birth, Marcella's sister had been made a church-virgin at the age of ten.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 24:5
verses.text: From that time she had lived a life of the severest asceticism, first as a member and then as the head of Marcella's community upon the Aventine.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 24:6
verses.text: Jerome, who subsequently wrote her a letter (XLV) on his departure from Rome, now holds her up as a model to be admired and imitated.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 24:7
verses.text: Written at Rome a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 24:8
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 24:11
verses.text: Let no one blame my letters for the eulogies and censures which are contained in them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 24:12
verses.text: To arraign sinners is to admonish those in like case, and to praise the virtuous is to quicken the zeal of those who wish to do right.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 24:13
verses.text: The day before yesterday I spoke to you concerning Lea of blessed memory, and I had hardly done so, when I was pricked in my conscience.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 24:14
verses.text: It would be wrong for me, I thought, to ignore a virgin after speaking of one who, as a widow, held a lower place.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 24:15
verses.text: Accordingly, in my present letter, I mean to give you a brief sketch of the life of our dear Asella.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 24:16
verses.text: Please do not read it to her; for she is sure to be displeased with eulogies of which she is herself the object.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 24:17
verses.text: Show it rather to the young girls of your acquaintance, that they may guide themselves by her example, and may take her behavior as the pattern of a perfect life.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 24:19
verses.text: I pass over the facts that, before her birth, she was blessed while still in her mother's womb, and that, virgin-like, she was delivered to her father in a dream in a bowl of shining glass brighter than a mirror.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 24:20
verses.text: And I say nothing of her consecration to the blessed life of virginity, a ceremony which took place when she was hardly more than ten years old, a mere babe still wrapped in swaddling clothes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 24:21
verses.text: For all that comes before works should be counted of grace; although, doubtless, God foreknew the future when He sanctified Jeremiah as yet unborn, when He made John to leap in his mother's womb, and when, before the foundation of the world, He set apart Paul to preach the gospel of His son.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 24:23
verses.text: I come now to the life which after her twelfth year she, by her own exertion, chose, laid hold of, held fast to, entered upon, and fulfilled.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 24:24
verses.text: Shut up in her narrow cell she roamed through paradise.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 24:25
verses.text: Fasting was her recreation and hunger her refreshment.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 24:26
verses.text: If she took food it was not from love of eating, but because of bodily exhaustion; and the bread and salt and cold water to which she restricted herself sharpened her appetite more than they appeased it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 24:27
verses.text: But I have almost forgotten to mention that of which I should have spoken first.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 24:28
verses.text: When her resolution was still fresh she took her gold necklace made in the lamprey pattern (so called because bars of metal are linked together so as to form a flexible chain), and sold it without her parents' knowledge.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 24:29
verses.text: Then putting on a dark dress such as her mother had never been willing that she should wear, she concluded her pious enterprise by consecrating herself forthwith to the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 24:30
verses.text: She thus showed her relatives that they need hope to wring no farther concessions from one who, by her very dress, had condemned the world.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 24:32
verses.text: To go on with my story, her ways were quiet and she lived in great privacy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 24:33
verses.text: In fact, she rarely went abroad or spoke to a man.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 24:34
verses.text: More wonderful still, much as she loved her virgin sister, she did not care to see her.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 24:35
verses.text: She worked with her own hands, for she knew that it was written: "If any will not work neither shall he eat".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 24:36
verses.text: To the Bridegroom she spoke constantly in prayer and psalmody.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 24:37
verses.text: She hurried to the martyrs' shrines unnoticed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 24:38
verses.text: Such visits gave her pleasure, and the more so because she was never recognized.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 24:39
verses.text: All the year round she observed a continual fast, remaining without food for two or three days at a time; but when Lent came she hoisted—if I may so speak—every stitch of canvas and fasted well-nigh from week's end to week's end with "a cheerful countenance".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 24:40
verses.text: What would perhaps be incredible, were it not that "with God all things are possible," is that she lived this life until her fiftieth year without weakening her digestion or bringing on herself the pain of colic.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 24:41
verses.text: Lying on the dry ground did not affect her limbs, and the rough sackcloth that she wore failed to make her skin either foul or rough.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 24:42
verses.text: With a sound body and a still sounder soul she sought all her delight in solitude, and found for herself a monkish hermitage in the centre of busy Rome.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 24:44
verses.text: You are better acquainted with all this than I am, and the few details that I have given I have learned from you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 24:45
verses.text: So intimate are you with Asella that you have seen, with your own eyes, her holy knees hardened like those of a camel from the frequency of her prayers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 24:46
verses.text: I merely set forth what I can glean from you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 24:47
verses.text: She is alike pleasant in her serious moods and serious in her pleasant ones: her manner, while winning, is always grave, and while grave is always winning.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 24:48
verses.text: Her pale face indicates continence but does not betoken ostentation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 24:49
verses.text: Her speech is silent and her silence is speech.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 24:50
verses.text: Her pace is neither too fast nor too slow.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 24:51
verses.text: Her demeanor is always the same.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 24:52
verses.text: She disregards refinement and is careless about her dress.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 24:53
verses.text: When she does attend to it it is without attending.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 24:54
verses.text: So entirely consistent has her life been that here in Rome, the centre of vain shows, wanton license, and idle pleasure, where to be humble is to be held spiritless, the good praise her conduct and the bad do not venture to impugn it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 24:55
verses.text: Let widows and virgins imitate her, let wedded wives make much of her, let sinful women fear her, and let bishops look up to her.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 27:2
verses.text: To Marcella.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 27:3
verses.text: In this letter Jerome defends himself against the charge of having altered the text of Scripture, and shows that he has merely brought the Latin Version of the N.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 27:4
verses.text: T.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 27:5
verses.text: into agreement with the Greek original.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 27:6
verses.text: Written at Rome 384 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 27:7
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 27:9
verses.text: After I had written my former letter, containing a few remarks on some Hebrew words, a report suddenly reached me that certain contemptible creatures were deliberately assailing me with the charge that I had endeavored to correct passages in the gospels, against the authority of the ancients and the opinion of the whole world.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 27:10
verses.text: Now, though I might—as far as strict right goes—treat these persons with contempt (it is idle to play the lyre for an ass), yet, lest they should follow their usual habit and reproach me with superciliousness, let them take my answer as follows: I am not so dull-wilted nor so coarsely ignorant (qualities which they take for holiness, calling themselves the disciples of fishermen as if men were made holy by knowing nothing)—I am not, I repeat, so ignorant as to suppose that any of the Lord's words is either in need of correction or is not divinely inspired; but the Latin manuscripts of the Scriptures are proved to be faulty by the variations which all of them exhibit, and my object has been to restore them to the form of the Greek original, from which my detractors do not deny that they have been translated.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 27:11
verses.text: If they dislike water drawn from the clear spring, let them drink of the muddy streamlet, and when they come to read the Scriptures, let them lay aside the keen eye which they turn on woods frequented by game-birds and waters abounding in shellfish.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 27:12
verses.text: Easily satisfied in this instance alone, let them, if they will, regard the words of Christ as rude sayings, albeit that over these so many great intellects have labored for so many ages rather to divine than to expound the meaning of each single word.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 27:13
verses.text: Let them charge the great apostle with want of literary skill, although it is said of him that much learning made him mad.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 27:15
verses.text: I know that as you read these words you will knit your brows, and fear that my freedom of speech is sowing the seeds of fresh quarrels; and that, if you could, you would gladly put your finger on my mouth to prevent me from even speaking of things which others do not blush to do.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 27:16
verses.text: But, I ask you, wherein have I used too great license? Have I ever embellished my dinner plates with engravings of idols? Have I ever, at a Christian banquet, set before the eyes of virgins the polluting spectacle of Satyrs embracing bacchanals? or have I ever assailed any one in too bitter terms? Have I ever complained of beggars turned millionaires? Have I ever censured heirs for the funerals which they have given to their benefactors? The one thing that I have unfortunately said has been that virgins ought to live more in the company of women than of men, and by this I have made the whole city look scandalized and caused every one to point at me the finger of scorn.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 27:17
verses.text: "They that hate me without a cause are more than the hairs of mine head," and I am become "a proverb to them".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 27:18
verses.text: Do you suppose after this that I will now say anything rash?  3.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 27:19
verses.text: But "when I set the wheel rolling I began to form a wine flagon; how comes it that a waterpot is the result?" Lest Horace laugh at me I come back to my two-legged asses, and din into their ears, not the music of the lute, but the blare of the trumpet.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 27:20
verses.text: They may say if they will, "rejoicing in hope; serving the time," but we will say "rejoicing in hope; serving the Lord".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 27:21
verses.text: They may see fit to receive an accusation against a presbyter unconditionally; but we will say in the words of Scripture, "Against an elder receive not an accusation, but before two or three witnesses.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 27:22
verses.text: Them that sin rebuke before all".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 27:23
verses.text: They may choose to read, "It is a man's saying, and worthy of all acceptation;" we are content to err with the Greeks, that is to say with the apostle himself, who spoke Greek.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 27:24
verses.text: Our version, therefore, is, it is "a faithful saying, and worthy of all acceptation".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 27:25
verses.text: Lastly, let them take as much pleasure as they please in their Gallican "geldings;" we will be satisfied with the simple "ass" of Zechariah, loosed from its halter and made ready for the Saviour's service, which received the Lord on its back, and so fulfilled Isaiah's prediction: "Blessed is he that soweth beside all waters, where the ox and the ass tread under foot".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 28:2

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 28:4

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 28:5

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 28:6
verses.text: "Some," he writes, "make it a 'change of metre,' others 'a pause for breath,' others 'the beginning of a new subject.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 28:7
verses.text: ' According to yet others it has something to do with rhythm or marks a burst of instrumental music".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 28:8
verses.text: Jerome himself inclines to follow Aquila and Origen, who make the word mean "forever," and suggests that it betokens completion, like the "explicit" or "feliciter" in contemporary Latin mss.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 30:9
verses.text: After explaining the mystical meaning of the alphabet, Jerome goes on thus: "What honey is sweeter than to know the wisdom of God? others, if they will, may possess riches, drink from a jewelled cup, shine in silks, and try in vain to exhaust their wealth in the most varied pleasures.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 30:10
verses.text: Our riches are to meditate in the law of the Lord day and night, to knock at the closed door, to receive the 'three loaves' of the Trinity, and, when the Lord goes before us, to walk upon the water of the world".

verses.text: Letter XXXI.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 31:2

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 31:3
verses.text: Jerome writes to thank Eustochium for some presents sent to him by her on the festival of St.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 31:4
verses.text: Peter.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 31:5
verses.text: He also moralizes on the mystical meaning of the articles sent.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 31:6
verses.text: The letter should be compared with Letter XLIV.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 31:7
verses.text: , of which the theme is similar.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 31:8
verses.text: Written at Rome in 384 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 31:9
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 31:10
verses.text: (on St.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 31:11
verses.text: Peter's Day).

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 31:13
verses.text: Doves, bracelets, and a letter are outwardly but small gifts to receive from a virgin, but the action which has prompted them enhances their value.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 31:14
verses.text: And since honey may not be offered in sacrifice to God, you have shown skill in taking off their overmuch sweetness and making them pungent—if I may so say—with a dash of pepper.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 31:15
verses.text: For nothing that is simply pleasurable or merely sweet can please God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 31:16
verses.text: Everything must have in it a sharp seasoning of truth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 31:17
verses.text: Christ's passover must be eaten with bitter herbs.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 31:19
verses.text: It is true that a festival such as the birthday of Saint Peter should be seasoned with more gladness than usual; still our merriment must not forget the limit set by Scripture, and we must not stray too far from the boundary of our wrestling-ground.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 31:20
verses.text: Your presents, indeed, remind me of the sacred volume, for in it Ezekiel decks Jerusalem with bracelets, Baruch receives letters from Jeremiah, and the Holy Spirit descends in the form of a dove at the baptism of Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 31:21
verses.text: But to give you, too, a sprinkling of pepper and to remind you of my former letter, I send you to-day this three-fold warning.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 31:22
verses.text: Cease not to adorn yourself with good works—the true bracelets of a Christian woman.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 31:23
verses.text: Rend not the letter written on your heart as the profane king cut with his penknife that delivered to him by Baruch.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 31:24
verses.text: Let not Hosea say to you as to Ephraim, "Thou art like a silly dove".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 31:25
verses.text: My words are too harsh, you will say, and hardly suitable to a festival like the present.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 31:26
verses.text: If so, you have provoked me to it by the nature of your own gifts.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 31:27
verses.text: So long as you put bitter with sweet, you must expect the same from me, sharp words that is, as well as praise.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 31:29
verses.text: However, I do not wish to make light of your gifts, least of all the basket of fine cherries, blushing with such a virgin modesty that I can fancy them freshly gathered by Lucullus himself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 31:30
verses.text: For it was he who first introduced the fruit at Rome after his conquest of Pontus and Armenia; and the cherry tree is so called because he brought it from Cerasus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 31:31
verses.text: Now as the Scriptures do not mention cherries, but do speak of a basket of figs, I will use these instead to point my moral.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 31:32
verses.text: May you be made of fruits such as those which grow before God's temple and of which He says, "Behold they are good, very good".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 31:33
verses.text: The Saviour likes nothing that is half and half, and, while he welcomes the hot and does not shun the cold, he tells us in the Apocalypse that he will spew the lukewarm out of his mouth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 31:34
verses.text: Wherefore we must be careful to celebrate our holy day not so much with abundance of food as with exultation of spirit.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 31:35
verses.text: For it is altogether unreasonable to wish to honor a martyr by excess who himself, as you know, pleased God by fasting.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 31:36
verses.text: When you take food always recollect that eating should be followed by reading, and also by prayer.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 31:37
verses.text: And if, by taking this course, you displease some, repeat to yourself the words of the Apostle: "If I yet pleased men I should not be the servant of Christ".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 32:3

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 32:4

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 32:7
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 32:9
verses.text: There are two reasons for the shortness of this letter, one that its bearer is impatient to start, and the other that I am too busy to waste time on trifles.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 32:10
verses.text: You ask what business can be so urgent as to stop me from a chat on paper.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 32:11
verses.text: Let me tell you, then, that for some time past I have been comparing Aquila's version of the Old Testament with the scrolls of the Hebrew, to see if from hatred to Christ the synagogue has changed the text; and—to speak frankly to a friend—I have found several variations which confirm our faith.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 32:12
verses.text: After having exactly revised the prophets, Solomon, the psalter, and the books of Kings, I am now engaged on Exodus (called by the Jews, from its opening words, Eleh shemôth), and when I have finished this I shall go on to Leviticus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 32:13
verses.text: Now you see why I can let no claim for a letter withdraw me from my work.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 32:14
verses.text: However, as I do not wish my friend Currentius to run altogether in vain, I have tacked on to this little talk two letters which I am sending to your sister Paula, and to her dear child Eustochium.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 32:15
verses.text: Read these, and if you find them instructive or pleasant, take what I have said to them as meant for you also.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 32:17
verses.text: I hope that Albina, your mother and mine, is well.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 32:18
verses.text: In bodily health, I mean, for I doubt not of her spiritual welfare.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 32:19
verses.text: Pray salute her for me, and cherish her with double affection, both as a Christian and as a mother.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 33:13
verses.text: Antiquity marvels at Marcus Terentius Varro, because of the countless books which he wrote for Latin readers; and Greek writers are extravagant in their praise of their man of brass, because he has written more works than one of us could so much as copy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 33:14
verses.text: But since Latin ears would find a list of Greek writings tiresome, I shall confine myself to the Latin Varro.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 33:15
verses.text: I shall try to show that we of to-day are sleeping the sleep of Epimenides, and devoting to the amassing of riches the energy which our predecessors gave to sound, if secular, learning.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 33:17
verses.text: Varro's writings include forty-five books of antiquities, four concerning the life of the Roman people.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 33:19
verses.text: But why, you ask me, have I thus mentioned Varro and the man of brass? Simply to bring to your notice our Christian man of brass, or, rather, man of adamant—Origen, I mean—whose zeal for the study of Scripture has fairly earned for him this latter name.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 33:20
verses.text: Would you learn what monuments of his genius he has left us? The following list exhibits them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 33:21
verses.text: His writings comprise thirteen books on Genesis, two books of Mystical Homilies, notes on Exodus, notes on Leviticus, also single books, four books on First Principles, two books on the Resurrection, two dialogues on the same subject.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 33:23
verses.text: So, you see, the labors of this one man have surpassed those of all previous writers, Greek and Latin.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 33:24
verses.text: Who has ever managed to read all that he has written? Yet what reward have his exertions brought him? He stands condemned by his bishop, Demetrius, only the bishops of Palestine, Arabia, Phenicia, and Achaia dissenting.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 33:25
verses.text: Imperial Rome consents to his condemnation, and even convenes a senate to censure him, not—as the rabid hounds who now pursue him cry—because of the novelty or heterodoxy of his doctrines, but because men could not tolerate the incomparable eloquence and knowledge which, when once he opened his lips, made others seem dumb.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 33:27
verses.text: I have written the above quickly and incautiously, by the light of a poor lantern.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 33:28
verses.text: You will see why, if you think of those who to-day represent Epicurus and Aristippus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 36:18

verses.text: Letter XXXVII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 37:2
verses.text: To Marcella.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 37:3
verses.text: Marcella had asked Jerome to lend her a copy of a commentary by Rhetitius, bishop of Augustodunum (Autun), on the Song of Songs.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 37:4
verses.text: He now refuses to do so on the ground that the work abounds with errors, of which the two following are samples: (1) Rhetitius identifies Tharshish with Tarsus, and (2) he supposes that Uphaz (in the phrase "gold of Uphaz") is the same as Cephas.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:1
verses.text: Letter XXXVIII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:2
verses.text: To Marcella.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:3
verses.text: Blaesilla, the daughter of Paula and sister of Eustochium, had lost her husband seven months after her marriage.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:4
verses.text: A dangerous illness had then led to her conversion, and she was now famous throughout Rome for the length to which she carried her austerities.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:5
verses.text: Many censured her for what they deemed her fanaticism, and Jerome, as her spiritual adviser, came in for some of the blame.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:6
verses.text: In the present letter he defends her conduct, and declares that persons who cavil at lives like hers have no claim to be considered Christians.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:7
verses.text: Written at Rome in 385 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:8
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:10
verses.text: When Abraham is tempted to slay his son the trial only serves to strengthen his faith.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:11
verses.text: When Joseph is sold into Egypt, his sojourn there enables him to support his father and his brothers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:12
verses.text: When Hezekiah is panic-stricken at the near approach of death, his tears and prayers obtain for him a respite of fifteen years.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:13
verses.text: If the faith of the apostle, Peter, is shaken by his Lord's passion, it is that, weeping bitterly, he may hear the soothing words: "Feed my sheep".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:14
verses.text: If Paul, that ravening wolf, that little Benjamin, is blinded in a trance, it is that he may receive his sight, and may be led, by the sudden horror of surrounding darkness, to call Him Lord Whom before he persecuted as man.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:16
verses.text: So is it now, my dear Marcella, with our beloved Blaesilla.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:17
verses.text: The burning fever from which we have seen her suffering unceasingly for nearly thirty days has been sent to teach her to renounce her over-great attention to that body which the worms must shortly devour.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:18
verses.text: The Lord Jesus has come to her in her sickness, and has taken her by the hand, and behold, she arises and ministers unto Him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:19
verses.text: Formerly her life savored somewhat of carelessness; and, fast bound in the bands of wealth, she lay as one dead in the tomb of the world.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:20
verses.text: But Jesus was moved with indignation, and was troubled in spirit, and cried aloud and said, Blaesilla, come forth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:21
verses.text: She, at His call, has arisen and has come forth, and sits at meat with the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:22
verses.text: The Jews, if they will, may threaten her in their wrath; they may seek to slay her, because Christ has raised her up.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:23
verses.text: It is enough that the apostles give God the glory.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:24
verses.text: Blaesilla knows that her life is due to Him who has given it back to her.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:25
verses.text: She knows that now she can clasp the feet of Him whom but a little while ago she dreaded as her judge.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:26
verses.text: Then life had all but forsaken her body, and the approach of death made her gasp and shiver.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:27
verses.text: What succour did she obtain in that hour from her kinsfolk? What comfort was there in their words lighter than smoke? She owes no debt to you, ye unkindly kindred, now that she is dead to the world and alive unto Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:28
verses.text: The Christian must rejoice that it is so, and he that is vexed must admit that he has no claim to be called a Christian.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:30
verses.text: A widow who is "loosed from the law of her husband" has, for her one duty, to continue a widow.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:31
verses.text: But, you will say, a sombre dress vexes the world.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:32
verses.text: In that case, John the Baptist would vex it, too; and yet, among those that are born of women, there has not been a greater than he.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:33
verses.text: He was called an angel; he baptized the Lord Himself, and yet he was clothed in raiment of camel's hair, and girded with a leathern girdle.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:34
verses.text: Is the world displeased because a widow's food is coarse? Nothing can be coarser than locusts, and yet these were the food of John.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:35
verses.text: The women who ought to scandalize Christians are those who paint their eyes and lips with rouge and cosmetics; whose chalked faces, unnaturally white, are like those of idols; upon whose cheeks every chance tear leaves a furrow; who fail to realize that years make them old; who heap their heads with hair not their own; who smooth their faces, and rub out the wrinkles of age; and who, in the presence of their grandsons, behave like trembling school-girls.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:36
verses.text: A Christian woman should blush to do violence to nature, or to stimulate desire by bestowing care upon the flesh.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:37
verses.text: "They that are in the flesh," the apostle tells us, "cannot please God".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:39
verses.text: In days gone by our dear widow was extremely fastidious in her dress, and spent whole days before her mirror to correct its deficiencies.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:40
verses.text: Now she boldly says: "We all with unveiled face, beholding as in a glass the glory of the Lord, are changed into the same image, from glory to glory, even as by the spirit of the Lord".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:41
verses.text: In those days maids arranged her hair, and her head, which had done no harm, was forced into a waving head-dress.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:42
verses.text: Now she leaves her hair alone, and her only head-dress is a veil.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:43
verses.text: In those days the softest feather-bed seemed hard to her, and she could scarcely find rest on a pile of mattresses.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:44
verses.text: Now she rises eager for prayer, her shrill voice cries Alleluia before every other, she is the first to praise her Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:45
verses.text: She kneels upon the bare ground, and with frequent tears cleanses a face once defiled with white lead.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:46
verses.text: After prayer comes the singing of psalms, and it is only when her neck aches and her knees totter, and her eyes begin to close with weariness, that she gives them leave reluctantly to rest.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:47
verses.text: As her dress is dark, lying on the ground does not soil it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:48
verses.text: Cheap shoes permit her to give to the poor the price of gilded ones.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:49
verses.text: No gold and jewels adorn her girdle; it is made of wool, plain and scrupulously clean.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:50
verses.text: It is intended to keep her clothes right, and not to cut her waist in two.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:51
verses.text: Therefore, if the scorpion looks askance upon her purpose, and with alluring words tempts her once more to eat of the forbidden tree, she must crush him beneath her feet with a curse, and say, as he lies dying in his allotted dust: "Get thee behind me, Satan".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:52
verses.text: Satan means adversary, and one who dislikes Christ's commandments, is more than Christ's adversary; he is anti-christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:54
verses.text: But what, I ask you, have we ever done that men should be offended at us? Have we ever imitated the apostles? We are told of the first disciples that they forsook their boat and their nets, and even their aged father.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:55
verses.text: The publican stood up from the receipt of custom and followed the Saviour once for all.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:56
verses.text: And when a disciple wished to return home, that he might take leave of his kinsfolk, the Master's voice refused consent.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:57
verses.text: A son was even forbidden to bury his father, as if to show that it is sometimes a religious duty to be undutiful for the Lord's sake.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:58
verses.text: With us it is different.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:59
verses.text: We are held to be monks if we refuse to dress in silk.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:60
verses.text: We are called sour and severe if we keep sober and refrain from excessive laughter.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:61
verses.text: The mob salutes us as Greeks and impostors if our tunics are fresh and clean.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:62
verses.text: They may deal in still severer witticisms if they please; they may parade every fat paunch they can lay hold of, to turn us into ridicule.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 38:63
verses.text: Our Blaesilla will laugh at their efforts, and will bear with patience the taunts of all such croaking frogs, for she will remember that men called her Lord, Beelzebub.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:1
verses.text: Letter XXXIX.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:2
verses.text: To Paula.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:3
verses.text: Blaesilla died within three months of her conversion, and Jerome now writes to Paula to offer her his sympathy and, if possible, to moderate her grief.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:4
verses.text: He asks her to remember that Blaesilla is now in paradise, and so far to control herself as to prevent enemies of the faith from cavilling at her conduct.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:5
verses.text: Then he concludes with the prophecy (since more than fulfilled) that in his writings Blaesilla's name shall never die.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:6
verses.text: Written at Rome in 389 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:7
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:9
verses.text: "Oh that my head were waters and mine eyes a fountain of tears: that I might weep," not as Jeremiah says, "For the slain of my people," nor as Jesus, for the miserable fate of Jerusalem, but for holiness, mercy, innocence, chastity, and all the virtues, for all are gone now that Blaesilla is dead.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:10
verses.text: For her sake I do not grieve, but for myself I must; my loss is too great to be borne with resignation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:11
verses.text: Who can recall with dry eyes the glowing faith which induced a girl of twenty to raise the standard of the Cross, and to mourn the loss of her virginity more than the death of her husband? Who can recall without a sigh the earnestness of her prayers, the brilliancy of her conversation, the tenacity of her memory, and the quickness of her intellect? Had you heard her speak Greek you would have deemed her ignorant of Latin; yet when she used the tongue of Rome her words were free from a foreign accent.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:12
verses.text: She even rivalled the great Origen in those acquirements which won for him the admiration of Greece.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:13
verses.text: For in a few months, or rather days, she so completely mastered the difficulties of Hebrew as to emulate her mother's zeal in learning and singing the psalms.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:14
verses.text: Her attire was plain, but this plainness was not, as it often is, a mark of pride.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:15
verses.text: Indeed, her self-abasement was so perfect that she dressed no better than her maids, and was only distinguished from them by the greater ease of her walk.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:16
verses.text: Her steps tottered with weakness, her face was pale and quivering, her slender neck scarcely upheld her head.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:17
verses.text: Still she always had in her hand a prophet or a gospel.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:18
verses.text: As I think of her my eyes fill with tears, sobs impede my voice, and such is my emotion that my tongue cleaves to the roof of my mouth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:19
verses.text: As she lay there dying, her poor frame parched with burning fever, and her relatives gathered round her bed, her last words were: "Pray to the Lord Jesus, that He may pardon me, because what I would have done I have not been able to do".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:20
verses.text: Be at peace, dear Blaesilla, in full assurance that your garments are always white.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:21
verses.text: For yours is the purity of an everlasting virginity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:22
verses.text: I feel confident that my words are true: conversion can never be too late.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:23
verses.text: The words to the dying robber are a pledge of this: "Verily I say unto thee, today shalt thou be with me in paradise".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:24
verses.text: When at last her spirit was delivered from the burden of the flesh, and had returned to Him who gave it; when, too, after her long pilgrimage, she had ascended up into her ancient heritage, her obsequies were celebrated with customary splendor.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:25
verses.text: People of rank headed the procession, a pall made of cloth of gold covered her bier.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:26
verses.text: But I seemed to hear a voice from heaven, saying: "I do not recognize these trappings; such is not the garb I used to wear; this magnificence is strange to me".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:28
verses.text: But what is this? I wish to check a mother's weeping, and I groan myself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:29
verses.text: I make no secret of my feelings; this entire letter is written in tears.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:30
verses.text: Even Jesus wept for Lazarus because He loved him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:31
verses.text: But he is a poor comforter who is overcome by his own sighs, and from whose afflicted heart tears are wrung as well as words.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:32
verses.text: Dear Paula, my agony is as great as yours.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:33
verses.text: Jesus knows it, whom Blaesilla now follows; the holy angels know it, whose company she now enjoys.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:34
verses.text: I was her father in the spirit, her foster-father in affection.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:35
verses.text: Sometimes I say: "Let the day perish wherein I was born," and again, "Woe is me, my mother, that thou hast borne me a man of strife and a man of contention to the whole earth".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:36
verses.text: I cry: "Righteous art thou, O Lord…yet let me talk with thee of thy judgments.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:37
verses.text: Wherefore doth the way of the wicked prosper?" and "as for me, my feet were almost gone, my steps had well-nigh slipped.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:38
verses.text: For I was envious at the foolish when I saw the prosperity of the wicked, and I said: How doth God know? and is there knowledge in the most high? Behold these are the ungodly who prosper in the world; they increase in riches".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:39
verses.text: But again I recall other words, "If I say I will speak thus, behold I should offend against the generation of thy children".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:40
verses.text: Do not great waves of doubt surge up over my soul as over yours? How comes it, I ask, that godless men live to old age in the enjoyment of this world's riches? How comes it that untutored youth and innocent childhood are cut down while still in the bud? Why is it that children three years old or two, and even unweaned infants, are possessed with devils, covered with leprosy, and eaten up with jaundice, while godless men and profane, adulterers and murderers, have health and strength to blaspheme God? Are we not told that the unrighteousness of the father does not fall upon the son, and that "the soul that sinneth it shall die?" Or if the old doctrine holds good that the sins of the fathers must be visited upon the children, an old man's countless sins cannot fairly be avenged upon a harmless infant.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:41
verses.text: And I have said: "Verily, I have cleansed my heart in vain, and washed my hands in innocency.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:42
verses.text: For all the day long have I been plagued".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:43
verses.text: Yet when I have thought of these things, like the prophet I have learned to say: "When I thought to know this, it was too painful for me; until I went into the sanctuary of God; then understood I their end".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:44
verses.text: Truly the judgments of the Lord are a great deep.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:45
verses.text: "O the depth of the riches both of the wisdom and knowledge of God! How unsearchable are His judgments, and His ways past finding out!" God is good, and all that He does must be good also.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:46
verses.text: Does He decree that I must lose my husband? I mourn my loss, but because it is His will I bear it with resignation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:47
verses.text: Is an only son snatched from me? The blow is hard, yet it can be borne, for He who has taken away is He who gave.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:48
verses.text: If I become blind a friend's reading will console me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:49
verses.text: If I become deaf I shall escape from sinful words, and my thoughts shall be of God alone.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:50
verses.text: And if, besides such trials as these, poverty, cold, sickness, and nakedness oppress me, I shall wait for death, and regard them as passing evils, soon to give way to a better issue.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:51
verses.text: Let us reflect on the words of the sapiential psalm: "Righteous art thou, O Lord, and upright are thy judgments".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:52
verses.text: Only he can speak thus who in all his troubles magnifies the Lord, and, putting down his sufferings to his sins, thanks God for his clemency.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:53
verses.text: The daughters of Judah, we are told, rejoiced, because of all the judgments of the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:54
verses.text: Therefore, since Judah means confession, and since every believing soul confesses its faith, he who claims to believe in Christ must rejoice in all Christ's judgments.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:55
verses.text: Am I in health? I thank my Creator.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:56
verses.text: Am I sick? In this case, too, I praise God's will.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:57
verses.text: For "when I am weak, then am I strong;" and the strength of the spirit is made perfect in the weakness of the flesh.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:58
verses.text: Even an apostle must bear what he dislikes, that ailment for the removal of which he besought the Lord thrice.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:59
verses.text: God's reply was: "My grace is sufficient for thee; for my strength is made perfect in weakness".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:60
verses.text: Lest he should be unduly elated by his revelations, a reminder of his human weakness was given to him, just as in the triumphal car of the victorious general there was always a slave to whisper constantly, amid the cheerings of the multitude, "Remember that thou art but man".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:62
verses.text: But why should that be hard to bear which we must one day ourselves endure? And why do we grieve for the dead? We are not born to live forever.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:63
verses.text: Abraham, Moses, and Isaiah, Peter, James, and John, Paul, the "chosen vessel," and even the Son of God Himself have all died; and are we vexed when a soul leaves its earthly tenement? Perhaps he is taken away, "lest that wickedness should alter his understanding…for his soul pleased the Lord: therefore hasted he to take him away from the people"—lest in life's long journey he should lose his way in some trackless maze.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:64
verses.text: We should indeed mourn for the dead, but only for him whom Gehenna receives, whom Tartarus devours, and for whose punishment the eternal fire burns.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:65
verses.text: But we who, in departing, are accompanied by an escort of angels, and met by Christ Himself, should rather grieve that we have to tarry yet longer in this tabernacle of death.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:66
verses.text: For "whilst we are at home in the body, we are absent from the Lord".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:67
verses.text: Our one longing should be that expressed by the psalmist: "Woe is me that my pilgrimage is prolonged, that I have dwelt with them that dwell in Kedar, that my soul hath made a far pilgrimage".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:68
verses.text: Kedar means darkness, and darkness stands for this present world (for, we are told, "the light shineth in darkness; and the darkness comprehendeth it not").

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:69
verses.text: Therefore we should congratulate our dear Blaesilla that she has passed from darkness to light, and has in the first flush of her dawning faith received the crown of her completed work.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:70
verses.text: Had she been cut off (as I pray that none may be) while her thoughts were full of worldly desires and passing pleasures, then mourning would indeed have been her due, and no tears shed for her would have been too many.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:71
verses.text: As it is, by the mercy of Christ she, four months ago, renewed her baptism in her vow of widowhood, and for the rest of her days spurned the world, and thought only of the religious life.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:72
verses.text: Have you no fear, then, lest the Saviour may say to you: "Are you angry, Paula, that your daughter has become my daughter? Are you vexed at my decree, and do you, with rebellious tears, grudge me the possession of Blaesilla? You ought to know what my purpose is both for you and for yours.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:73
verses.text: You deny yourself food, not to fast but to gratify your grief; and such abstinence is displeasing to me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:74
verses.text: Such fasts are my enemies.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:75
verses.text: I receive no soul which forsakes the body against my will.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:76
verses.text: A foolish philosophy may boast of martyrs of this kind; it may boast of a Zeno a Cleombrotus, or a Cato.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:77
verses.text: My spirit rests only upon him "that is poor and of a contrite spirit, and that trembleth at my word.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:78
verses.text: Is this the meaning of your vow to me that you would lead a religious life? Is it for this that you dress yourself differently from other matrons, and array yourself in the garb of a nun? Mourning is for those who wear silk dresses.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:79
verses.text: In the midst of your tears the call will come, and you, too, must die; yet you flee from me as from a cruel judge, and fancy that you can avoid falling into my hands.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:80
verses.text: Jonah, that headstrong prophet, once fled from me, yet in the depths of the sea he was still mine.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:81
verses.text: If you really believed your daughter to be alive, you would not grieve that she had passed to a better world.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:82
verses.text: This is the commandment that I have given you through my apostle, that you sorrow not for them that sleep, even as the Gentiles, which have no hope.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:83
verses.text: Blush, for you are put to shame by the example of a heathen.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:84
verses.text: The devil's handmaid is better than mine.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:85
verses.text: For, while she imagines that her unbelieving husband has been translated to heaven, you either do not or will not believe that your daughter is at rest with me".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:87
verses.text: Why should I not mourn, you say? Jacob put on sackcloth for Joseph, and when all his family gathered round him, refused to be comforted.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:88
verses.text: "I will go down," he said, "into the grave unto my son mourning".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:89
verses.text: David also mourned for Absalom, covering his face, and crying: "O my son, Absalom…my son, Absalom! Would God I had died for thee, O Absalom, my son!" Moses, too, and Aaron, and the rest of the saints were mourned for with a solemn mourning.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:90
verses.text: The answer to your reasoning is simple.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:91
verses.text: Jacob, it is true, mourned for Joseph, whom he fancied slain, and thought to meet only in the grave (his words were: "I will go down into the grave unto my son mourning"), but he only did so because Christ had not yet broken open the door of paradise, nor quenched with his blood the flaming sword and the whirling of the guardian cherubim.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:92
verses.text: (Hence in the story of Dives and Lazarus, Abraham and the beggar, though really in a place of refreshment, are described as being in hell.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:93
verses.text: ) And David, who, after interceding in vain for the life of his infant child, refused to weep for it, knowing that it had not sinned, did well to weep for a son who had been a parricide—in will, if not in deed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:94
verses.text: And when we read that, for Moses and Aaron, lamentation was made after ancient custom, this ought not to surprise us, for even in the Acts of the Apostles, in the full blaze of the gospel, we see that the brethren at Jerusalem made great lamentation for Stephen.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:95
verses.text: This great lamentation, however, refers not to the mourners, but to the funeral procession and to the crowds which accompanied it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:96
verses.text: This is what the Scripture says of Jacob: "Joseph went up to bury his father: and with him went up all the servants of Pharaoh, the elders of his house, and all the elders of the land of Egypt, and all the house of Joseph and his brethren"; and a few lines farther on: "And there went up with him both chariots and horsemen: and it was a great company".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:97
verses.text: Finally, "they mourned with a great and very sore lamentation".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:98
verses.text: This solemn lamentation does not impose prolonged weeping upon the Egyptians, but simply describes the funeral ceremony.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:99
verses.text: In like manner, when we read of weeping made for Moses and Aaron, this is all that is meant.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:100
verses.text: I cannot adequately extol the mysteries of Scripture, nor sufficiently admire the spiritual meaning conveyed in its most simple words.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:101
verses.text: We are told, for instance, that lamentation was made for Moses; yet when the funeral of Joshua is described no mention at all is made of weeping.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:102
verses.text: The reason, of course, is that under Moses—that is under the old Law—all men were bound by the sentence passed on Adam's sin, and when they descended into hell were rightly accompanied with tears.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:103
verses.text: For, as the apostle says, "death reigned from Adam to Moses, even over them that had not sinned".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:104
verses.text: But under Jesus, that is, under the Gospel of Christ, who has unlocked for us the gate of paradise, death is accompanied, not with sorrow, but with joy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:105
verses.text: The Jews go on weeping to this day; they make bare their feet, they crouch in sackcloth, they roll in ashes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:106
verses.text: And to make their superstition complete, they follow a foolish custom of the Pharisees, and eat lentils, to show, it would seem, for what poor fare they have lost their birthright.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:107
verses.text: Of course they are right to weep, for as they do not believe in the Lord's resurrection they are being made ready for the advent of antichrist.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:108
verses.text: But we who have put on Christ and according to the apostle are a royal and priestly race, we ought not to grieve for the dead.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:109
verses.text: "Moses," the Scripture tells us, "said unto Aaron and unto Eleazar, and unto Ithamar, his sons that were left: Uncover not your heads, neither rend your clothes; lest ye die, and lest wrath come upon all the people".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:110
verses.text: Rend not your clothes, he says, neither mourn as pagans, lest you die.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:111
verses.text: For, for us sin is death.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:112
verses.text: In this same book, Leviticus, there is a provision which may perhaps strike some as cruel, yet is necessary to faith: the high priest is forbidden to approach the dead bodies of his father and mother, of his brothers and of his children; to the end, that no grief may distract a soul engaged in offering sacrifice to God, and wholly devoted to the Divine mysteries.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:113
verses.text: Are we not taught the same lesson in the Gospel in other words? Is not the disciple forbidden to say farewell to his home or to bury his dead father? Of the high priest, again, it is said: "He shall not go out of the sanctuary, and the sanctification of his God shall not be contaminated, for the anointing oil of his God is upon him".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:114
verses.text: Certainly, now that we have believed in Christ, and bear Him within us, by reason of the oil of His anointing which we have received, we ought not to depart from His temple—that is, from our Christian profession—we ought not to go forth to mingle with the unbelieving Gentiles, but always to remain within, as servants obedient to the will of the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:116
verses.text: I have spoken plainly, lest you might ignorantly suppose that Scripture sanctions your grief; and that, if you err, you have reason on your side.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:117
verses.text: And, so far, my words have been addressed to the average Christian woman.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:118
verses.text: But now it will not be so.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:119
verses.text: For in your case, as I well know, renunciation of the world has been complete; you have rejected and trampled on the delights of life, and you give yourself daily to fasting, to reading, and to prayer.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:120
verses.text: Like Abraham, you desire to leave your country and kindred, to forsake Mesopotamia and the Chaldaeans, to enter into the promised land.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:121
verses.text: Dead to the world before your death, you have spent all your mere worldly substance upon the poor, or have bestowed it upon your children.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:122
verses.text: I am the more surprised, therefore, that you should act in a manner which in others would justly call for reprehension.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:123
verses.text: You call to mind Blaesilla's companionship, her conversation, and her endearing ways; and you cannot endure the thought that you have lost them all.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:124
verses.text: I pardon you the tears of a mother, but I ask you to restrain your grief.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:125
verses.text: When I think of the parent I cannot blame you for weeping: but when I think of the Christian and the recluse, the mother disappears from my view.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:126
verses.text: Your wound is still fresh, and any touch of mine, however gentle, is more likely to inflame than to heal it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:127
verses.text: Yet why do you not try to overcome by reason a grief which time must inevitably assuage? Naomi, fleeing because of famine to the land of Moab, there lost her husband and her sons.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:128
verses.text: Yet when she was thus deprived of her natural protectors, Ruth, a stranger, never left her side.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:129
verses.text: And see what a great thing it is to comfort a lonely woman! Ruth, for her reward, is made an ancestress of Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:130
