verses.text: Consider the great trials which Job endured, and you will see that you are over-delicate.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:131
verses.text: Amid the ruins of his house, the pains of his sores, his countless bereavements, and, last of all, the snares laid for him by his wife, he still lifted up his eyes to heaven, and maintained his patience unbroken.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:132
verses.text: I know what you are going to say: "All this befell him as a righteous man, to try his righteousness".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:133
verses.text: Well, choose which alternative you please.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:134
verses.text: Either you are holy, in which case God is putting your holiness to the proof; or else you are a sinner, in which case you have no right to complain.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:135
verses.text: For if so, you endure far less than your deserts.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:136
verses.text: Why should I repeat old stories? Listen to a modern instance.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:137
verses.text: The holy Melanium, eminent among Christians for her true nobility (may the Lord grant that you and I may have part with her in His day!), while the dead body of her husband was still unburied, still warm, had the misfortune to lose at one stroke two of her sons.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:138
verses.text: The sequel seems incredible, but Christ is my witness that my words are true.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:139
verses.text: Would you not suppose that in her frenzy she would have unbound her hair, and rent her clothes, and torn her breast? Yet not a tear fell from her eyes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:140
verses.text: Motionless she stood there; then casting herself at the feet of Christ, she smiled, as though she held Him with her hands.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:141
verses.text: "Henceforth, Lord," she said, "I will serve Thee more readily, for Thou hast freed me from a great burden".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:142
verses.text: But perhaps her remaining children overcame her determination.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:143
verses.text: No, indeed; she set so little store by them that she gave up all that she had to her only son, and then, in spite of the approaching winter, took ship for Jerusalem.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:145
verses.text: Spare yourself, I beseech you, spare Blaesilla, who now reigns with Christ; at least spare Eustochium, whose tender years and inexperience depend on you for guidance and instruction.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:146
verses.text: Now does the devil rage and complain that he is set at naught, because he sees one of your children exalted in triumph.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:147
verses.text: The victory which he failed to win over her that is gone he hopes to obtain over her who still remains.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:148
verses.text: Too great affection towards one's children is disaffection towards God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:149
verses.text: Abraham gladly prepares to slay his only son, and do you complain if one child out of several has received her crown? I cannot say what I am going to say without a groan.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:150
verses.text: When you were carried fainting out of the funeral procession, whispers such as these were audible in the crowd.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:151
verses.text: "Is not this what we have often said.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:152
verses.text: She weeps for her daughter, killed with fasting.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:153
verses.text: She wanted her to marry again, that she might have grandchildren.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:154
verses.text: How long must we refrain from driving these detestable monks out of Rome? Why do we not stone them or hurl them into the Tiber? They have misled this unhappy lady; that she is not a nun from choice is clear.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:155
verses.text: No heathen mother ever wept for her children as she does for Blaesilla".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:156
verses.text: What sorrow, think you, must not Christ have endured when He listened to such words as these! And how triumphantly must Satan have exulted, eager as he is to snatch your soul! Luring you with the claims of a grief which seems natural and right, and always keeping before you the image of Blaesilla, his aim is to slay the mother of the victress, and then to fall upon her forsaken sister.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:157
verses.text: I do not speak thus to terrify you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:158
verses.text: The Lord is my witness that I address you now as though I were standing at His judgment seat.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:159
verses.text: Tears which have no meaning are an object of abhorrence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:160
verses.text: Yours are detestable tears, sacrilegious tears, unbelieving tears; for they know no limits, and bring you to the verge of death.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:161
verses.text: You shriek and cry out as though on fire within, and do your best to put an end to yourself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:162
verses.text: But to you and others like you Jesus comes in His mercy and says: "Why weepest thou? the damsel is not dead but sleepeth".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:163
verses.text: The bystanders may laugh him to scorn; such unbelief is worthy of the Jews.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:164
verses.text: If you prostrate yourself in grief at your daughter's tomb you too will hear the chiding of the angel, "Why seek ye the living among the dead?" It was because Mary Magdalene had done this that when she recognized the Lord's voice calling her and fell at His feet, He said to her: "Touch me not, for I am not yet ascended to my Father;" that is to say, you are not worthy to touch, as risen, one whom you suppose still in the tomb.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:166
verses.text: What crosses and tortures, think you, must not our Blaesilla endure to see Christ angry with you, though it be but a little! At this moment she cries to you as you weep: "If ever you loved me, mother, if I was nourished at your breast, if I was taught by your precepts, do not grudge me my exaltation, do not so act that we shall be separated forever.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:167
verses.text: Do you fancy that I am alone? In place of you I now have Mary the mother of the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:168
verses.text: Here I see many whom before I have not known.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:169
verses.text: My companions are infinitely better than any that I had on earth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:170
verses.text: Here I have the company of Anna, the prophetess of the Gospel; and—what should kindle in you more fervent joy—I have gained in three short months what cost her the labor of many years to win.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:171
verses.text: Both of us widows indeed, we have been both rewarded with the palm of chastity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:172
verses.text: Do you pity me because I have left the world behind me? It is I who should, and do, pity you who, still immured in its prison, daily fight with anger, with covetousness, with lust, with this or that temptation leading the soul to ruin.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:173
verses.text: If you wish to be indeed my mother, you must please Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:174
verses.text: She is not my mother who displeases my Lord".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:175
verses.text: Many other things does she say which here I pass over; she prays also to God for you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:176
verses.text: For me, too, I feel sure, she makes intercession and asks God to pardon my sins in return for the warnings and advice that I bestowed on her, when to secure her salvation I braved the ill will of her family.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:178
verses.text: Therefore, so long as breath animates my body, so long as I continue in the enjoyment of life, I engage, declare, and promise that Blaesilla's name shall be forever on my tongue, that my labors shall be dedicated to her honor, and that my talents shall be devoted to her praise.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:179
verses.text: No page will I write in which Blaesilla's name shall not occur.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:180
verses.text: Wherever the records of my utterance shall find their way, thither she, too, will travel with my poor writings.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:181
verses.text: Virgins, widows, monks and priests, as they read, will see how deeply her image is impressed upon my mind.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:182
verses.text: Everlasting remembrance will make up for the shortness of her life.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:183
verses.text: Living as she does with Christ in heaven, she will live also on the lips of men.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:184
verses.text: The present will soon pass away and give place to the future, and that future will judge her without partiality and without prejudice.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:185
verses.text: As a childless widow she will occupy a middle place between Paula, the mother of children, and Eustochium the virgin.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:186
verses.text: In my writings she will never die.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 39:187
verses.text: She will hear me conversing of her always, either with her sister or with her mother.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 40:1
verses.text: Letter XL.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 40:2
verses.text: To Marcella.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 40:3
verses.text: Onasus, of Segesta, the subject of this letter, was among Jerome's Roman opponents.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 40:4
verses.text: He is here held up to ridicule in a manner which reflects little credit on the writer's urbanity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 40:5
verses.text: The date of the letter is 385 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 40:6
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 40:8
verses.text: The medical men called surgeons pass for being cruel, but really deserve pity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 40:9
verses.text: For is it not pitiful to cut away the dead flesh of another man with merciless knives without being moved by his pangs? Is it not pitiful that the man who is curing the patient is callous to his sufferings, and has to appear as his enemy? Yet such is the order of nature.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 40:10
verses.text: While truth is always bitter, pleasantness waits upon evil-doing.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 40:11
verses.text: Isaiah goes naked without blushing as a type of captivity to come.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 40:12
verses.text: Jeremiah is sent from Jerusalem to the Euphrates (a river in Mesopotamia), and leaves his girdle to be marred in the Chaldaean camp, among the Assyrians hostile to his people.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 40:13
verses.text: Ezekiel is told to eat bread made of mingled seeds and sprinkled with the dung of men and cattle.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 40:14
verses.text: He has to see his wife die without shedding a tear.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 40:15
verses.text: Amos is driven from Samaria.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 40:16
verses.text: Why is he driven from it? Surely in this case as in the others, because he was a spiritual surgeon, who cut away the parts diseased by sin and urged men to repentance.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 40:17
verses.text: The apostle Paul says: "Am I therefore become your enemy because I tell you the truth?" And so the Saviour Himself found it, from whom many of the disciples went back because His sayings seemed hard.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 40:19
verses.text: It is not surprising, then, that by exposing their faults I have offended many.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 40:20
verses.text: I have arranged to operate on a cancerous nose; let him who suffers from wens tremble.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 40:21
verses.text: I wish to rebuke a chattering daw; let the crow realize that she is offensive.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 40:22
verses.text: Yet, after all, is there but one person in Rome  "Whose nostrils are disfigured by a scar?"  Is Onasus of Segesta alone in puffing out his cheeks like bladders and balancing hollow phrases on his tongue?  I say that certain persons have, by crime, perjury, and false pretences, attained to this or that high position.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 40:23
verses.text: How does it hurt you who know that the charge does not touch you? I laugh at a pleader who has no clients, and sneer at a penny-a-liner's eloquence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 40:24
verses.text: What does it matter to you who are such a refined speaker? It is my whim to inveigh against mercenary priests.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 40:25
verses.text: You are rich already, why should you be angry? I wish to shut up Vulcan and burn him in his own flames.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 40:26
verses.text: Are you his guest or his neighbor that you try to save an idol's shrine from the fire? I choose to make merry over ghosts and owls and monsters of the Nile; and whatever I say, you take it as aimed at you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 40:27
verses.text: At whatever fault I point my pen, you cry out that you are meant.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 40:28
verses.text: You collar me and drag me into court and absurdly charge me with writing satires when I only write plain prose!  So you really think yourself a pretty fellow just because you have a lucky name! Why it does not follow at all.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 40:29
verses.text: A brake is called a brake just because the light does not break through it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 40:30
verses.text: The Fates are called "sparers," just because they never spare.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 40:31
verses.text: The Furies are spoken of as gracious, because they show no grace.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 40:32
verses.text: And in common speech Ethiopians go by the name of silverlings.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 40:33
verses.text: Still, if the showing up of faults always angers you, I will soothe you now with the words of Persius: "May you be a catch for my lord and lady's daughter! May the pretty ladies scramble for you! May the ground you walk on turn to a rose-bed!"  3.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 40:34
verses.text: All the same, I will give you a hint what features to hide if you want to look your best.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 40:35
verses.text: Show no nose upon your face and keep your mouth shut.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 40:36
verses.text: You will then stand some chance of being counted both handsome and eloquent.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 41:1
verses.text: Letter XLI.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 41:2
verses.text: To Marcella.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 41:3
verses.text: An effort having been made to convert Marcella to Montanism, Jerome here summarizes for her its leading doctrines, which he contrasts with those of the Church.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 41:4
verses.text: Written at Rome in 385 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 41:5
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 41:7
verses.text: As regards the passages brought together from the gospel of John with which a certain votary of Montanus has assailed you, passages in which our Saviour promises that He will go to the Father, and that He will send the Paraclete—as regards these, the Acts of the Apostles inform us both for what time the promises were made, and at what time they were actually fulfilled.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 41:8
verses.text: Ten days had elapsed, we are told, from the Lord's ascension and fifty from His resurrection, when the Holy Spirit came down, and the tongues of the believers were cloven, so that each spoke every language.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 41:9
verses.text: Then it was that, when certain persons of those who as yet believed not declared that the disciples were drunk with new wine, Peter standing in the midst of the apostles, and of all the concourse said: "Ye men of Judaea and all ye that dwell at Jerusalem, be this known unto you and hearken to my words: for these are not drunken as ye suppose, seeing it is but the third hour of the day.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 41:10
verses.text: But this is that which was spoken of by the prophet Joel.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 41:11
verses.text: And it shall come to pass in the last days, saith God, I will pour out of my spirit upon all flesh: and your sons and daughters shall prophesy, and your young men shall see visions, and your old men shall dream dreams: and on my servants, and on my handmaidens I will pour out…of my spirit".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 41:13
verses.text: If, then, the apostle Peter, upon whom the Lord has founded the Church, has expressly said that the prophecy and promise of the Lord were then and there fulfilled, how can we claim another fulfilment for ourselves? if the Montanists reply that Philip's four daughters prophesied at a later date, and that a prophet is mentioned named Agabus, and that in the partition of the spirit, prophets are spoken of as well as apostles, teachers and others, and that Paul himself prophesied many things concerning heresies still future, and the end of the world; we tell them that we do not so much reject prophecy—for this is attested by the passion of the Lord—as refuse to receive prophets whose utterances fail to accord with the Scriptures old and new.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 41:15
verses.text: In the first place we differ from the Montanists regarding the rule of faith.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 41:16
verses.text: We distinguish the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit as three persons, but unite them as one substance.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 41:17
verses.text: They, on the other hand, following the doctrine of Sabellius, force the Trinity into the narrow limits of a single personality.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 41:18
verses.text: We, while we do not encourage them, yet allow second marriages, since Paul bids the younger widows to marry.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 41:19
verses.text: They suppose a repetition of marriage a sin so awful that he who has committed it is to be regarded as an adulterer.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 41:20
verses.text: We, according to the apostolic tradition (in which the whole world is at one with us), fast through one Lent yearly; whereas they keep three in the year as though three saviours had suffered.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 41:21
verses.text: I do not mean, of course, that it is unlawful to fast at other times through the year—always excepting Pentecost—only that while in Lent it is a duty of obligation, at other seasons it is a matter of choice.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 41:22
verses.text: With us, again, the bishops occupy the place of the apostles, but with them a bishop ranks not first but third.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 41:23
verses.text: For while they put first the patriarchs of Pepusa in Phrygia, and place next to these the ministers called stewards, the bishops are relegated to the third or almost the lowest rank.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 41:24
verses.text: No doubt their object is to make their religion more pretentious by putting that last which we put first.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 41:25
verses.text: Again they close the doors of the Church to almost every fault, whilst we read daily, "I desire the repentance of a sinner rather than his death," and "Shall they fall and not arise, saith the Lord," and once more "Return ye backsliding children and I will heal your backslidings".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 41:26
verses.text: Their strictness does not prevent them from themselves committing grave sins, far from it; but there is this difference between us and them, that, whereas they in their self-righteousness blush to confess their faults, we do penance for ours, and so more readily gain pardon for them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 41:28
verses.text: I pass over their sacraments of sin, made up as they are said to be, of sucking children subjected to a triumphant martyrdom.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 41:29
verses.text: I prefer, I say, not to credit these; accusations of blood-shedding may well be false.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 41:30
verses.text: But I must confute the open blasphemy of men who say that God first determined in the Old Testament to save the world by Moses and the prophets, but that finding Himself unable to fulfil His purpose He took to Himself a body of the Virgin, and preaching under the form of the Son in Christ, underwent death for our salvation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 41:31
verses.text: Moreover that, when by these two steps He was unable to save the world, He last of all descended by the Holy Spirit upon Montanus and those demented women Prisca and Maximilia; and that thus the mutilated and emasculate Montanus possessed a fulness of knowledge such as was never claimed by Paul; for he was content to say, "We know in part, and we prophesy in part," and again, "Now we see through a glass darkly".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 41:32
verses.text: These are statements which require no refutation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 41:33
verses.text: To expose the infidelity of the Montanists is to triumph over it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 41:34
verses.text: Nor is it necessary that in so short a letter as this I should overthrow the several absurdities which they bring forward.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 41:35
verses.text: You are well acquainted with the Scriptures; and, as I take it, you have written, not because you have been disturbed by their cavils, but only to learn my opinion about them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 42:1
verses.text: Letter XLII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 42:2
verses.text: To Marcella.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 42:3
verses.text: At Marcella's request Jerome explains to her what is "the sin against the Holy Ghost" spoken of by Christ, and shows Novatian's explanation of it to be untenable.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 42:4
verses.text: Written at Rome in 385 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 42:5
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 42:7
verses.text: The question you send is short and the answer is clear.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 42:8
verses.text: There is this passage in the gospel: "Whosoever speaketh a word against the Son of Man, it shall be forgiven him; but whosoever speaketh against the Holy Ghost, it shall not be forgiven him neither in this world nor in the world to come".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 42:9
verses.text: Now if Novatian affirms that none but Christian renegades can sin against the Holy Ghost, it is plain that the Jews who blasphemed Christ were not guilty of this sin.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 42:10
verses.text: Yet they were wicked husbandmen, they had slain the prophets, they were then compassing the death of the Lord; and so utterly lost were they that the Son of God told them that it was they whom he had come to save.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 42:11
verses.text: It must be proved to Novatian, therefore, that the sin which shall never be forgiven is not the blasphemy of men disembowelled by torture who in their agony deny their Lord, but is the captious clamor of those who, while they see that God's works are the fruit of virtue, ascribe the virtue to a demon and declare the signs wrought to belong not to the divine excellence but to the devil.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 42:12
verses.text: And this is the whole gist of our Saviour's argument, when He teaches that Satan cannot be cast out by Satan, and that his kingdom is not divided against itself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 42:13
verses.text: If it is the devil's object to injure God's creation, how can he wish to cure the sick and to expel himself from the bodies possessed by him? Let Novatian prove that of those who have been compelled to sacrifice before a judge's tribunal any has declared of the things written in the gospel that they were wrought not by the Son of God but by Beelzebub, the prince of the devils; and then he will be able to make good his contention that this is the blasphemy against the Holy Ghost which shall never be forgiven.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 42:15
verses.text: But to put a more searching question still: let Novatian tell us how he distinguishes speaking against the Son of Man from blasphemy against the Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 42:16
verses.text: For I maintain that on his principles men who have denied Christ under persecution have only spoken against the Son of Man, and have not blasphemed the Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 42:17
verses.text: For when a man is asked if he is a Christian, and declares that he is not; obviously in denying Christ, that is the Son of Man, he does no despite to the Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 42:18
verses.text: But if his denial of Christ involves a denial of the Holy Ghost, this heretic can perhaps tell us how the Son of Man can be denied without sinning against the Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 42:19
verses.text: If he thinks that we are here intended by the term Holy Ghost to understand the Father, no mention at all of the Father is made by the denier in his denial.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 42:20
verses.text: When the apostle Peter, taken aback by a maid's question, denied the Lord, did he sin against the Son of Man or against the Holy Ghost? If Novatian absurdly twists Peter's words, "I know not the man," to mean a denial not of Christ's Messiahship but of His humanity, he will make the Saviour a liar, for He foretold that He Himself, that is His divine Sonship, must be denied.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 42:21
verses.text: Now, when Peter denied the Son of God, he wept bitterly and effaced his threefold denial by a threefold confession.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 42:22
verses.text: His sin, therefore, was not the sin against the Holy Ghost which can never be forgiven.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 42:23
verses.text: It is obvious, then, that this sin involves blasphemy, calling one Beelzebub for his actions, whose virtues prove him to be God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 42:24
verses.text: If Novatian can bring an instance of a renegade who has called Christ Beelzebub, I will at once give up my position and admit that after such a fall the denier can win no forgiveness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 42:25
verses.text: To give way under torture and to deny oneself to be a Christian is one thing, to say that Christ is the devil is another.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 42:26
verses.text: And this you will yourself see if you read the passage attentively.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 42:28
verses.text: I ought to have discussed the matter more fully, but some friends have visited my humble abode, and I cannot refuse to give myself up to them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 42:29
verses.text: Still, as it might seem arrogant not to answer you at once, I have compressed a wide subject into a few words, and have sent you not a letter but an explanatory note.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 43:1
verses.text: Letter XLIII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 43:2
verses.text: To Marcella.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 43:3
verses.text: Jerome draws a contrast between his daily life and that of Origen, and sorrowfully admits his own shortcomings.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 43:4
verses.text: He then suggests to Marcella the advantages which life in the country offers over life in town, and hints that he is himself disposed to make trial of it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 43:5
verses.text: Written at Rome in 385 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 43:6
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 43:8
verses.text: Ambrose who supplied Origen, true man of adamant and of brass, with money, materials and amanuenses to bring out his countless books—Ambrose, in a letter to his friend from Athens, states that they never took a meal together without something being read, and never went to bed till some portion of Scripture had been brought home to them by a brother's voice.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 43:9
verses.text: Night and day, in fact, were so ordered that prayer only gave place to reading and reading to prayer.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 43:11
verses.text: Have we, brute beasts that we are, ever done the like? Why, we yawn if we read for over an hour; we rub our foreheads and vainly try to suppress our languor.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 43:12
verses.text: And then, after this great feat, we plunge for relief into worldly business once more.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 43:13
verses.text: I say nothing of the meals with which we dull our faculties, and I would rather not estimate the time that we spend in paying and receiving visits.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 43:14
verses.text: Next we fall into conversation; we waste our words, we attack people behind their backs, we detail their way of living, we carp at them and are carped at by them in turn.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 43:15
verses.text: Such is the fare that engages our attention at dinner and afterwards.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 43:16
verses.text: Then, when our guests have retired, we make up our accounts, and these are sure to cause us either anger or anxiety.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 43:17
verses.text: The first makes us like raging lions, and the second seeks vainly to make provision for years to come.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 43:18
verses.text: We do not recollect the words of the Gospel: "Thou fool, this night thy soul shall be required of thee: then whose shall those things be which thou hast provided?" The clothing which we buy is designed not merely for use but for display.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 43:19
verses.text: Where there is a chance of saving money we quicken our pace, speak promptly, and keep our ears open.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 43:20
verses.text: If we hear of household losses—such as often occur—our looks become dejected and gloomy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 43:21
verses.text: The gain of a penny fills us with joy; the loss of a half-penny plunges us into sorrow.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 43:22
verses.text: One man is of so many minds that the prophet's prayer is: "Lord, in thy city scatter their image".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 43:23
verses.text: For created as we are in the image of God and after His likeness, it is our own wickedness which makes us assume masks.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 43:24
verses.text: Just as on the stage the same actor now figures as a brawny Hercules, now softens into a tender Venus, now shivers in the role of Cybele; so we—who, if we were not of the world, would be hated by the world—for every sin that we commit have a corresponding mask.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 43:26
verses.text: Wherefore, seeing that we have journeyed for much of our life through a troubled sea, and that our vessel has been in turn shaken by raging blasts and shattered upon treacherous reefs, let us, as soon as may be, make for the haven of rural quietude.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 43:27
verses.text: There such country dainties as milk and household bread, and greens watered by our own hands, will supply us with coarse but harmless fare.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 43:28
verses.text: So living, sleep will not call us away from prayer, nor satiety from reading.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 43:29
verses.text: In summer the shade of a tree will afford us privacy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 43:30
verses.text: In autumn the quality of the air and the leaves strewn under foot will invite us to stop and rest.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 43:31
verses.text: In springtime the fields will be bright with flowers, and our psalms will sound the sweeter for the twittering of the birds.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 43:32
verses.text: When winter comes with its frost and snow, I shall not have to buy fuel, and, whether I sleep or keep vigil, shall be warmer than in town.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 43:33
verses.text: At least, so far as I know, I shall keep off the cold at less expense.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 43:34
verses.text: Let Rome keep to itself its noise and bustle, let the cruel shows of the arena go on, let the crowd rave at the circus, let the playgoers revel in the theatres and—for I must not altogether pass over our Christian friends—let the House of Ladies hold its daily sittings.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 43:35
verses.text: It is good for us to cleave to the Lord, and to put our hope in the Lord God, so that when we have exchanged our present poverty for the kingdom of heaven, we may be able to exclaim: "Whom have I in heaven but thee? and there is none upon earth that I desire beside thee".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 43:36
verses.text: Surely if we can find such blessedness in heaven we may well grieve to have sought after pleasures poor and passing here upon earth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 43:37
verses.text: Farewell.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 44:1
verses.text: Letter XLIV.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 44:2
verses.text: To Marcella.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 44:3
verses.text: Marcella had sent some small articles as a present (probably to Paula and Eustochium) and Jerome now writes in their name to thank her for them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 44:4
verses.text: He notices the appropriateness of the gifts, not only to the ladies, but also to himself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 44:5
verses.text: Written at Rome in 385 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 44:6
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 44:7
verses.text: When absent in body we are wont to converse together in spirit.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 44:8
verses.text: Each of us does what he or she can.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 44:9
verses.text: You send us gifts, we send you back letters of thanks.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 44:10
verses.text: And as we are virgins who have taken the veil, it is our duty to show that hidden meanings lurk under your nice presents.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 44:11
verses.text: Sackcloth, then, is a token of prayer and fasting, the chairs remind us that a virgin should never stir abroad, and the wax tapers that we should look for the bridegroom's coming with our lights burning.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 44:12
verses.text: The cups also warn us to mortify the flesh and always to be ready for martyrdom.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 44:13
verses.text: "How bright," says the psalmist, "is the cup of the Lord, intoxicating them that drink it!" Moreover, when you offer to matrons little fly-flaps to brush away mosquitoes, it is a charming way of hinting that they should at once check voluptuous feelings, for "dying flies," we are told, "spoil sweet ointment".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 44:14
verses.text: In such presents, then, as these, virgins can find a model, and matrons a pattern.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 44:15
verses.text: To me, too, your gifts convey a lesson, although one of an opposite kind.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 44:16
verses.text: For chairs suit idlers, sackcloth does for penitents, and cups are wanted for the thirsty.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 44:17
verses.text: And I shall be glad to light your tapers, if only to banish the terrors of the night and the fears of an evil conscience.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:1
verses.text: Letter XLV.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:2
verses.text: To Asella.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:3
verses.text: After leaving Rome for the East, Jerome writes to Asella to refute the calumnies by which he had been assailed, especially as regards his intimacy with Paula and Eustochium.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:4
verses.text: Written on board ship at Ostia, in August, 385 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:5
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:7
verses.text: Were I to think myself able to requite your kindness I should be foolish.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:8
verses.text: God is able in my stead to reward a soul which is consecrated to Him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:9
verses.text: So unworthy, indeed, am I of your regard that I have never ventured to estimate its value or even to wish that it might be given me for Christ's sake.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:10
verses.text: Some consider me a wicked man, laden with iniquity; and such language is more than justified by my actual sins.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:11
verses.text: Yet in dealing with the bad you do well to account them good.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:12
verses.text: It is dangerous to judge another man's servant; and to speak evil of the righteous is a sin not easily pardoned.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:13
verses.text: The day will surely come when you and I shall mourn for others; for not a few will be in the flames.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:15
verses.text: I am said to be an infamous turncoat, a slippery knave, one who lies and deceives others by Satanic arts.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:16
verses.text: Which is the safer course, I should like to know, to invent or credit these charges against innocent persons, or to refuse to believe them, even of the guilty? Some kissed my hands, yet attacked me with the tongues of vipers; sympathy was on their lips, but malignant joy in their hearts.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:17
verses.text: The Lord saw them and had them in derision, reserving my poor self and them for judgment to come.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:18
verses.text: One would attack my gait or my way of laughing; another would find something amiss in my looks; another would suspect the simplicity of my manner.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:19
verses.text: Such is the company in which I have lived for almost three years.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:20
verses.text: It often happened that I found myself surrounded with virgins, and to some of these I expounded the divine books as best I could.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:21
verses.text: Our studies brought about constant intercourse, this soon ripened into intimacy, and this, in turn, produced mutual confidence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:22
verses.text: If they have ever seen anything in my conduct unbecoming a Christian let them say so.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:23
verses.text: Have I taken any one's money? Have I not disdained all gifts, whether small or great? Has the chink of any one's coin been heard in my hand? Has my language been equivocal, or my eye wanton? No; my sex is my one crime, and even on this score I am not assailed, save when there is a talk of Paula going to Jerusalem.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:24
verses.text: Very well, then.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:25
verses.text: They believed my accuser when he lied; why do they not believe him when he retracts? He is the same man now that he was then, and yet he who before declared me guilty now confesses that I am innocent.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:26
verses.text: Surely a man's words under torture are more trustworthy than in moments of gayety, except, indeed, that people are prone to believe falsehoods designed to gratify their ears, or, worse still, stories which, till then uninvented, they have urged others to invent.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:28
verses.text: Before I became acquainted with the family of the saintly Paula, all Rome resounded with my praises.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:29
verses.text: Almost every one concurred in judging me worthy of the episcopate.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:30
verses.text: Damasus, of blessed memory, spoke no words but mine.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:31
verses.text: Men called me holy, humble, eloquent.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:32
verses.text: Did I ever cross the threshold of a light woman? Was I ever fascinated by silk dresses, or glowing gems, or rouged faces, or display of gold? Of all the ladies in Rome but one had power to subdue me, and that one was Paula.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:33
verses.text: She mourned and fasted, she was squalid with dirt, her eyes were dim from weeping.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:34
verses.text: For whole nights she would pray to the Lord for mercy, and often the rising sun found her still at her prayers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:35
verses.text: The psalms were her only songs, the Gospel her whole speech, continence her one indulgence, fasting the staple of her life.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:36
verses.text: The only woman who took my fancy was one whom I had not so much as seen at table.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:37
verses.text: But when I began to revere, respect, and venerate her as her conspicuous chastity deserved, all my former virtues forsook me on the spot.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:39
verses.text: Oh! envy, that dost begin by tearing thyself! Oh! cunning malignity of Satan, that dost always persecute things holy! Of all the ladies in Rome, the only ones that caused scandal were Paula and Melanium, who, despising their wealth and deserting their children, uplifted the cross of the Lord as a standard of religion.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:40
verses.text: Had they frequented the baths, or chosen to use perfumes, or taken advantage of their wealth and position as widows to enjoy life and to be independent, they would have been saluted as ladies of high rank and saintliness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:41
verses.text: As it is, of course, it is in order to appear beautiful that they put on sackcloth and ashes, and they endure fasting and filth merely to go down into the Gehenna of fire! As if they could not perish with the crowd whom the mob applauds! If it were Gentiles or Jews who thus assailed their mode of life, they would at least have the consolation of failing to please only those whom Christ Himself has failed to please.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:42
verses.text: But, shameful to say, it is Christians who thus neglect the care of their own households, and, disregarding the beams in their own eyes, look for motes in those of their neighbors.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:43
verses.text: They pull to pieces every profession of religion, and think that they have found a remedy for their own doom, if they can disprove the holiness of others, if they can detract from every one, if they can show that those who perish are many, and sinners, a great multitude.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:45
verses.text: You bathe daily; another regards such over-niceness as defilement.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:46
verses.text: You surfeit yourself on wild fowl and pride yourself on eating sturgeon; I, on the contrary, fill my belly with beans.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:47
verses.text: You find pleasure in troops of laughing girls; I prefer Paula and Melanium who weep.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:48
verses.text: You covet what belongs to others; they disdain what is their own.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:49
verses.text: You like wines flavored with honey; they drink cold water, more delicious still.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:50
verses.text: You count as lost what you cannot have, eat up, and devour on the moment; they believe in the Scriptures, and look for good things to come.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:51
verses.text: And if they are wrong, and if the resurrection of the body on which they rely is a foolish delusion, what does it matter to you? We, on our side, look with disfavor on such a life as yours.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:52
verses.text: You can fatten yourself on your good things as much as you please; I for my part prefer paleness and emaciation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:53
verses.text: You suppose that men like me are unhappy; we regard you as more unhappy still.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:54
verses.text: Thus we reciprocate each other's thoughts, and appear to each other mutually insane.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:56
verses.text: I write this in haste, dear Lady Asella, as I go on board, overwhelmed with grief and tears; yet I thank my God that I am counted worthy of the world's hatred.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:57
verses.text: Pray for me that, after Babylon, I may see Jerusalem once more; that Joshua, the son of Josedech, may have dominion over me, and not Nebuchadnezzar, that Ezra, whose name means helper, may come and restore me to my own country.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:58
verses.text: I was a fool in wishing to sing the Lord's song in a strange land, and in leaving Mount Sinai, to seek the help of Egypt.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:59
verses.text: I forgot that the Gospel warns us that he who goes down from Jerusalem immediately falls among robbers, is spoiled, is wounded, is left for dead.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:60
verses.text: But, although priest and Levite may disregard me, there is still the good Samaritan who, when men said to him, "Thou art a Samaritan and hast a devil," disclaimed having a devil, but did not disclaim being a Samaritan, this being the Hebrew equivalent for our word guardian.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:61
verses.text: Men call me a mischief-maker, and I take the title as a recognition of my faith.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:62
verses.text: For I am but a servant, and the Jews still call my master a magician.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:63
verses.text: The apostle, likewise, is spoken of as a deceiver.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:64
verses.text: There hath no temptation taken me but such as is common to man.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:65
verses.text: How few distresses have I endured, I who am yet a soldier of the cross! Men have laid to my charge a crime of which I am not guilty; but I know that I must enter the kingdom of heaven through evil report as well as through good.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:67
verses.text: Salute Paula and Eustochium, who, whatever the world may think, are always mine in Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:68
verses.text: Salute Albina, your mother, and Marcella, your sister; Marcellina also, and the holy Felicitas; and say to them all: "We must all stand before the judgment seat of Christ, and there shall be revealed the principle by which each has lived".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 45:69
verses.text: And now, illustrious model of chastity and virginity, remember me, I beseech you, in your prayers, and by your intercessions calm the waves of the sea.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:1
verses.text: Letter XLVI.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:2
verses.text: Paula and Eustochium to Marcella.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:3
verses.text: Jerome writes to Marcella in the name of Paula and Eustochium, describing the charms of the Holy Land, and urging her to leave Rome and to join her old companions at Bethlehem.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:4
verses.text: Much of the letter is devoted to disposing of the objection that since the Passion of Christ the Holy Land has been under a curse.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:5
verses.text: The date of the letter is a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:6
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:8
verses.text: It is written from Bethlehem, which now becomes Jerome's home for the remainder of his life.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:10
verses.text: Love cannot be measured, impatience knows no bounds, and eagerness can brook no delay.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:11
verses.text: Wherefore we, oblivious of our weakness, and relying more on our will than our capacity, desire—pupils though we be—to instruct our mistress.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:12
verses.text: We are like the sow in the proverb, which sets up to teach the goddess of invention.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:13
verses.text: You were the first to set our tinder alight; the first, by precept and example, to urge us to adopt our present life.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:14
verses.text: As a hen gathers her chickens, so did you take us under your wing.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:15
verses.text: And will you now let us fly about at random with no mother near us? Will you leave us to dread the swoop of the hawk and the shadow of each passing bird of prey? Separated from you, we do what we can: we utter our mournful plaint, and more by sobs than by tears we adjure you to give back to us the Marcella whom we love.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:16
verses.text: She is mild, she is suave, she is sweeter than the sweetest honey.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:17
verses.text: She must not, therefore, be stern and morose to us, whom her winning ways have roused to adopt a life like her own.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:19
verses.text: Assuming that what we ask is for the best, our eagerness to obtain it is nothing to be ashamed of.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:20
verses.text: And if all the Scriptures agree with our view, we are not too bold in urging you to a course to which you have yourself often urged us.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:21
verses.text: What are God's first words to Abraham? "Get thee out of thy country and from thy kindred unto a land that I will show thee".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:22
verses.text: The patriarch—the first to receive a promise of Christ—is here told to leave the Chaldees, to leave the city of confusion and its rehobothor broad places; to leave also the plain of Shinar, where the tower of pride had been raised to heaven.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:23
verses.text: He has to pass through the waves of this world, and to ford its rivers; those by which the saints sat down and wept when they remembered Zion, and Chebar's flood, whence Ezekiel was carried to Jerusalem by the hair of his head.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:24
verses.text: All this Abraham undergoes that he may dwell in a land of promise watered from above, and not like Egypt, from below, no producer of herbs for the weak and ailing, but a land that looks for the early and the latter rain from heaven.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:25
verses.text: It is a land of hills and valleys, and stands high above the sea.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:26
verses.text: The attractions of the world it entirely wants, but its spiritual attractions are for this all the greater.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:27
verses.text: Mary, the mother of the Lord, left the lowlands and made her way to the hill country, when, after receiving the angel's message, she realized that she bore within her womb the Son of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:28
verses.text: When of old the Philistines had been overcome, when their devilish audacity had been smitten, when their champion had fallen on his face to the earth, it was from this city that there went forth a procession of jubilant souls, a harmonious choir to sing our David's victory over tens of thousands.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:29
verses.text: Here, too, it was that the angel grasped his sword, and while he laid waste the whole of the ungodly city, marked out the temple of the Lord in the threshing floor of Ornan, king of the Jebusites.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:30
verses.text: Thus early was it made plain that Christ's church would grow up, not in Israel, but among the Gentiles.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:31
verses.text: Turn back to Genesis, and you will find that this was the city over which Melchizedek held sway, that king of Salem who, as a type of Christ, offered to Abraham bread and wine, and even then consecrated the mystery which Christians consecrate in the body and blood of the Saviour.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:33
verses.text: Perhaps you will tacitly reprove us for deserting the order of Scripture, and letting our confused account ramble this way and that, as one thing or another strikes us.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:34
verses.text: If so, we say once more what we said at the outset: love has no logic, and impatience knows no rule.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:35
verses.text: In the Song of Songs the precept is given as a hard one: "Regulate your love towards me".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:36
verses.text: And so we plead that, if we err, we do so not from ignorance but from feeling.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:37
verses.text: Well, then, to bring forward something still more out of place, we must go back to yet remoter times.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:38
verses.text: Tradition has it that in this city, nay, more, on this very spot, Adam lived and died.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:39
verses.text: The place where our Lord was crucified is called Calvary, because the skull of the primitive man was buried there.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:40
verses.text: So it came to pass that the second Adam, that is the blood of Christ, as it dropped from the cross, washed away the sins of the buried protoplast, the first Adam, and thus the words of the apostle were fulfilled: "Awake, thou that sleepest, and arise from the dead, and Christ shall give thee light".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:41
verses.text: It would be tedious to enumerate all the prophets and holy men who have been sent forth from this place.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:42
verses.text: All that is strange and mysterious to us is familiar and natural to this city and country.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:43
verses.text: By its very names, three in number, it proves the doctrine of the trinity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:44
verses.text: For it is called first Jebus, then Salem, then Jerusalem: names of which the first means "down-trodden," the second "peace," and the third "vision of peace".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:45
verses.text: For it is only by slow stages that we reach our goal; it is only after we have been trodden down that we are lifted up to see the vision of peace.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:46
verses.text: Because of this peace Solomon, the man of peace, was born there, and "in peace was his place made".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:47
verses.text: King of kings, and lord of lords, his name and that of the city show him to be a type of Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:48
verses.text: Need we speak of David and his descendants, all of whom reigned here? As Judaea is exalted above all other provinces, so is this city exalted above all Judaea.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:49
verses.text: To speak more tersely, the glory of the province is derived from its capital; and whatever fame the members possess is in every case due to the head.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:51
verses.text: You have long been anxious to break forth into speech; the very letters we have formed perceive it, and our paper already understands the question you are going to put.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:52
verses.text: You will reply to us by saying: it was so of old, when "the Lord loved the gates of Zion more than all the dwellings of Jacob," and when her foundations were in the holy mountains.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:53
verses.text: Even these verses, however, are susceptible of a deeper interpretation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:54
verses.text: But things are changed since then.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:55
verses.text: The risen Lord has proclaimed in tones of thunder: "Your house is left unto you desolate".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:56
verses.text: With tears He has prophesied its downfall: "O Jerusalem, Jerusalem, thou that killest the prophets, and stonest them which are sent unto thee; how often would I have gathered thy children together even as a hen gathereth her chickens under her wings, and ye would not.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:57
verses.text: Behold your house is left unto you desolate".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:58
verses.text: The veil of the temple has been rent; an army has encompassed Jerusalem, it has been stained by the blood of the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:59
verses.text: Now, therefore, its guardian angels have forsaken it and the grace of Christ has been withdrawn.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:60
verses.text: Josephus, himself a Jewish writer, asserts that at the Lord's crucifixion there broke from the temple voices of heavenly powers, saying: "Let us depart hence".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:61
verses.text: These and other considerations show that where grace abounded there did sin much more abound.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:62
verses.text: Again, when the apostles received the command: "Go ye and teach all nations," and when they said themselves: "It was necessary that the word of God should first have been spoken to you, but seeing ye put it from you…lo we turn to the Gentiles," then all the spiritual importance of Judaea and its old intimacy with God were transferred by the apostles to the nations.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:64
verses.text: The difficulty is strongly stated, and may well puzzle even those proficient in Scripture; but for all that, it admits of an easy solution.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:65
verses.text: The Lord wept for the fall of Jerusalem, and He would not have done so if He did not love it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:66
verses.text: He wept for Lazarus because He loved him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:67
verses.text: The truth is that it was the people who sinned and not the place.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:68
verses.text: The capture of a city is involved in the slaying of its inhabitants.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:69
verses.text: If Jerusalem was destroyed, it was that its people might be punished; if the temple was overthrown, it was that its figurative sacrifices might be abolished.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:70
verses.text: As regards its site, lapse of time has but invested it with fresh grandeur.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:71
verses.text: The Jews of old reverenced the Holy of Holies, because of the things contained in it—the cherubim, the mercy-seat, the ark of the covenant, the manna, Aaron's rod, and the golden altar.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:72
verses.text: Does the Lord's sepulchre seem less worthy of veneration? As often as we enter it we see the Saviour in His grave clothes, and if we linger we see again the angel sitting at His feet, and the napkin folded at His head.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:73
verses.text: Long before this sepulchre was hewn out by Joseph, its glory was foretold in Isaiah's prediction, "his rest shall be glorious," meaning that the place of the Lord's burial should be held in universal honor.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:75
verses.text: How, then, you will say, do we read in the apocalypse written by John: "The beast that ascendeth out of the bottomless pit shall…kill them [that is, obviously, the prophets], and their dead bodies shall lie in the street of the great city which spiritually is called Sodom and Egypt, where also their Lord was crucified?" If the great city where the Lord was crucified is Jerusalem, and if the place of His crucifixion is spiritually called Sodom and Egypt; then as the Lord was crucified at Jerusalem, Jerusalem must be Sodom and Egypt.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:76
verses.text: Holy Scripture, I reply first of all, cannot contradict itself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:77
verses.text: One book cannot invalidate the drift of the whole.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:78
verses.text: A single verse cannot annul the meaning of a book.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:79
verses.text: Ten lines earlier in the apocalypse it is written: "Rise and measure the temple of God, and the altar, and them that worship therein.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:80
verses.text: But the court which is without the temple leave out and measure it not; for it is given unto the Gentiles; and the holy city shall they tread under foot forty and two months".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:81
verses.text: The apocalypse was written by John long after the Lord's passion, yet in it he speaks of Jerusalem as the holy city.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:82
verses.text: But if so, how can he spiritually call it Sodom and Egypt? It is no answer to say that the Jerusalem which is called holy is the heavenly one which is to be, while that which is called Sodom is the earthly one tottering to its downfall.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:83
verses.text: For it is the Jerusalem to come that is referred to in the description of the beast, "which shall ascend out of the bottomless pit, and shall make war against the two prophets, and shall overcome them and kill them, and their dead bodies shall lie in the street of the great city".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:84
verses.text: At the close of the book it is farther described thus: "And the city lieth four-square, and the length of it and the breadth are the same as the height; and he measured the city with the golden reed twelve thousand furlongs.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:85
verses.text: The length and the breadth and the height of it are equal.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:86
verses.text: And he measured the walls thereof, an hundred and forty and four cubits, according to the measure of a man, that is, of the angel.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:87
verses.text: And the building of the wall of it was of jasper; and the city was pure gold"—and so on.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:88
verses.text: Now where there is a square there can be neither length nor breadth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:89
verses.text: And what kind of measurement is that which makes length and breadth equal to height? And how can there be walls of jasper, or a whole city of pure gold; its foundations and its streets of precious stones, and its twelve gates each glowing with pearls?  7.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:90
verses.text: Evidently this description cannot be taken literally (in fact, it is absurd to suppose a city the length, breadth and height of which are all twelve thousand furlongs), and therefore the details of it must be mystically understood.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:91
verses.text: The great city which Cain first built and called after his son must be taken to represent this world, which the devil, that accuser of his brethren, that fratricide who is doomed to perish, has built of vice cemented with crime, and filled with iniquity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:92
verses.text: Therefore it is spiritually called Sodom and Egypt.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:93
verses.text: Thus it is written, "Sodom shall return to her former estate," that is to say, the world must be restored as it has been before.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:94
verses.text: For we cannot believe that Sodom and Gomorrah, Admah and Zeboim are to be built again: they must be left to lie in ashes forever.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:95
verses.text: We never read of Egypt as put for Jerusalem: it always stands for this world.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:96
verses.text: To collect from Scripture the countless proofs of this would be tedious: I shall adduce but one passage, a passage in which this world is most clearly called Egypt.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:97
verses.text: The apostle Jude, the brother of James, writes thus in his catholic epistle: "I will, therefore, put you in remembrance, though ye once knew this how that Jesus, having saved the people out of the land of Egypt, afterward destroyed them that believed not".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:98
verses.text: And, lest you should fancy Joshua the son of Nun to be meant, the passage goes on thus: "And the angels which kept not their first estate, but left their own habitation, he hath reserved in everlasting chains, under darkness, unto the judgment of the great day".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:99
verses.text: Moreover, to convince you that in every place where Egypt, Sodom and Gomorrah are named together it is not these spots, but the present world, which is meant, he mentions them immediately in this sense.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:100
verses.text: "Even as Sodom and Gomorrah," he writes, "and the cities about them, in like manner giving themselves over to fornication and going after strange flesh, are set forth for an example, suffering the vengeance of eternal fire".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:101
verses.text: But what need is there to collect more proofs when, after the passion and the resurrection of the Lord, the evangelist Matthew tells us: "The rocks rent, and the graves were opened; and many bodies of the saints which slept arose and came out of the graves after his resurrection, and went into the holy city and appeared unto many"? We must not interpret this passage straight off, as many people absurdly do, of the heavenly Jerusalem: the apparition there of the bodies of the saints could be no sign to men of the Lord's rising.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:102
verses.text: Since, therefore, the evangelists and all the Scriptures speak of Jerusalem as the holy city, and since the psalmist commands us to worship the Lord "at his footstool;" allow no one to call it Sodom and Egypt, for by it the Lord forbids men to swear because "it is the city of the great king".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:104
verses.text: The land is accursed, you say, because it has drunk in the blood of the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:105
verses.text: On what grounds, then, do men regard as blessed those spots where Peter and Paul, the leaders of the Christian host, have shed their blood for Christ? If the confession of men and servants is glorious, must there not be glory likewise in the confession of their Lord and God? Everywhere we venerate the tombs of the martyrs; we apply their holy ashes to our eyes; we even touch them, if we may, with our lips.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:106
verses.text: And yet some think that we should neglect the tomb in which the Lord Himself is buried.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:107
verses.text: If we refuse to believe human testimony, let us at least credit the devil and his angels.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:108
verses.text: For when in front of the Holy Sepulchre they are driven out of those bodies which they have possessed, they moan and tremble as if they stood before Christ's judgment-seat, and grieve, too late that they have crucified Him in whose presence they now cower.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:109
verses.text: If—as a wicked theory maintains—this holy place has, since the Lord's passion, become an abomination, why was Paul in such haste to reach Jerusalem to keep Pentecost in it? Yet to those who held him back he said: "What mean ye to weep and to break my heart? For I am ready not to be bound only, but also to die at Jerusalem, for the name of the Lord Jesus".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:110
verses.text: Need I speak of those other holy and illustrious men who, after the preaching of Christ, brought their votive gifts and offerings to the brethren who were at Jerusalem?  9.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:111
verses.text: Time forbids me to survey the period which has passed since the Lord's ascension, or to recount the bishops, the martyrs, the divines, who have come to Jerusalem from a feeling that their devotion and knowledge would be incomplete and their virtue without the finishing touch, unless they adored Christ in the very spot where the gospel first flashed from the gibbet.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:112
verses.text: If a famous orator blames a man for having learned Greek at Lilybaeum instead of at Athens, and Latin in Sicily instead of at Rome (on the ground, obviously, that each province has its own characteristics), can we suppose a Christian's education complete who has not visited the Christian Athens?  10.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:113
verses.text: In speaking thus we do not mean to deny that the kingdom of God is within us, or to say that there are no holy men elsewhere; we merely assert in the strongest manner that those who stand first throughout the world are here gathered side by side.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:114
verses.text: We ourselves are among the last, not the first; yet we have come hither to see the first of all nations.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:115
verses.text: Of all the ornaments of the Church our company of monks and virgins is one of the finest; it is like a fair flower or a priceless gem.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:116
verses.text: Every man of note in Gaul hastens hither.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:117
verses.text: The Briton, "sundered from our world," no sooner makes progress in religion than he leaves the setting sun in quest of a spot of which he knows only through Scripture and common report.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:118
verses.text: Need we recall the Armenians, the Persians, the peoples of India and Arabia? Or those of our neighbor, Egypt, so rich in monks; of Pontus and Cappadocia; of Caele-Syria and Mesopotamia and the teeming east? In fulfilment of the Saviour's words, "Wherever the body is, thither will the eagles be gathered together," they all assemble here and exhibit in this one city the most varied virtues.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:119
verses.text: Differing in speech, they are one in religion, and almost every nation has a choir of its own.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:120
verses.text: Yet amid this great concourse there is no arrogance, no disdain of self-restraint; all strive after humility, that greatest of Christian virtues.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:121
verses.text: Whosoever is last is here regarded as first.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:122
verses.text: Their dress neither provokes remark nor calls for admiration.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:123
verses.text: In whatever guise a man shows himself he is neither censured nor flattered.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:124
verses.text: Long fasts help no one here.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:125
verses.text: Starvation wins no deference, and the taking of food in moderation is not condemned.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:126
verses.text: "To his own master" each one "standeth or falleth".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:127
verses.text: No man judges another lest he be judged of the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:128
verses.text: Backbiting, so common in other parts, is wholly unknown here.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:129
verses.text: Sensuality and excess are far removed from us.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:130
verses.text: And in the city there are so many places of prayer that a day would not be sufficient to go round them all.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:132
verses.text: But, as every one praises most what is within his reach, let us pass now to the cottage-inn which sheltered Christ and Mary.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:133
verses.text: With what expressions and what language can we set before you the cave of the Saviour? The stall where he cried as a babe can be best honored by silence; for words are inadequate to speak its praise.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:134
verses.text: Where are the spacious porticoes? Where are the gilded ceilings? Where are the mansions furnished by the miserable toil of doomed wretches? Where are the costly halls raised by untitled opulence for man's vile body to walk in? Where are the roofs that intercept the sky, as if anything could be finer than the expanse of heaven? Behold, in this poor crevice of the earth the Creator of the heavens was born; here He was wrapped in swaddling clothes; here He was seen by the shepherds; here He was pointed out by the star; here He was adored by the wise men.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:135
verses.text: This spot is holier, me-thinks, than that Tarpeian rock which has shown itself displeasing to God by the frequency with which it has been struck by lightning.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:137
verses.text: Read the apocalypse of John, and consider what is sung therein of the woman arrayed in purple, and of the blasphemy written upon her brow, of the seven mountains, of the many waters, and of the end of Babylon.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:138
verses.text: "Come out of her, my people," so the Lord says, "that ye be not partakers of her sins, and that ye receive not of her plagues".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:139
verses.text: Turn back also to Jeremiah and pay heed to what he has written of like import: "Flee out of the midst of Babylon, and deliver every man his soul".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:140
verses.text: For "Babylon the great is fallen, is fallen, and is become the habitation of devils, and the hold of every foul spirit".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:141
verses.text: It is true that Rome has a holy church, trophies of apostles and martyrs, a true confession of Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:142
verses.text: The faith has been preached there by an apostle, heathenism has been trodden down, the name of Christian is daily exalted higher and higher.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:143
verses.text: But the display, power, and size of the city, the seeing and the being seen, the paying and the receiving of visits, the alternate flattery and detraction, talking and listening, as well as the necessity of facing so great a throng even when one is least in the mood to do so—all these things are alike foreign to the principles and fatal to the repose of the monastic life.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:144
verses.text: For when people come in our way we either see them coming and are compelled to speak, or we do not see them and lay ourselves open to the charge of haughtiness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:145
verses.text: Sometimes, also, in returning visits we are obliged to pass through proud portals and gilded doors and to face the clamor of carping lackeys.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:146
verses.text: But, as we have said above, in the cottage of Christ all is simple and rustic: and except for the chanting of psalms there is complete silence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:147
verses.text: Wherever one turns the laborer at his plough sings alleluia, the toiling mower cheers himself with psalms, and the vine-dresser while he prunes his vine sings one of the lays of David.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:148
verses.text: These are the songs of the country; these, in popular phrase, its love ditties: these the shepherd whistles; these the tiller uses to aid his toil.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:150
verses.text: But what are we doing? Forgetting what is required of us, we are taken up with what we wish.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:151
verses.text: Will the time never come when a breathless messenger shall bring the news that our dear Marcella has reached the shores of Palestine, and when every band of monks and every troop of virgins shall unite in a song of welcome? In our excitement we are already hurrying to meet you: without waiting for a vehicle, we hasten off at once on foot.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:152
verses.text: We shall clasp you by the hand, we shall look upon your face; and when, after long waiting, we at last embrace you, we shall find it hard to tear ourselves away.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:153
verses.text: Will the day never come when we shall together enter the Saviour's cave, and together weep in the sepulchre of the Lord with His sister and with His mother? Then shall we touch with our lips the wood of the cross, and rise in prayer and resolve upon the Mount of Olives with the ascending Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:154
verses.text: We shall see Lazarus come forth bound with grave clothes, we shall look upon the waters of Jordan purified for the washing of the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:155
verses.text: Thence we shall pass to the folds of the shepherds, we shall pray together in the mausoleum of David.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:156
verses.text: We shall see the prophet, Amos, upon his crag blowing his shepherd's horn.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:157
verses.text: We shall hasten, if not to the tents, to the monuments of Abraham, Isaac and Jacob, and of their three illustrious wives.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:158
verses.text: We shall see the fountain in which the eunuch was immersed by Philip.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:159
verses.text: We shall make a pilgrimage to Samaria, and side by side venerate the ashes of John the Baptist, of Elisha, and of Obadiah.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:160
verses.text: We shall enter the very caves where in the time of persecution and famine the companies of the prophets were fed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:161
verses.text: If only you will come, we shall go to see Nazareth, as its name denotes, the flower of Galilee.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:162
verses.text: Not far off Cana will be visible, where the water was turned into wine.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:163
verses.text: We shall make our way to Tabor, and see the tabernacles there which the Saviour shares, not, as Peter once wished, with Moses and Elijah, but with the Father and with the Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:164
verses.text: Thence we shall come to the Sea of Gennesaret, and when there we shall see the spots where the five thousand were filled with five loaves, and the four thousand with seven.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:165
verses.text: The town of Nain will meet our eyes, at the gate of which the widow's son was raised to life.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:166
verses.text: Hermon too will be visible, and the torrent of Endor, at which Sisera was vanquished.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:167
verses.text: Our eyes will look also on Capernaum, the scene of so many of our Lord's signs—yes, and on all Galilee besides.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:168
verses.text: And when, accompanied by Christ, we shall have made our way back to our cave through Shiloh and Bethel, and those other places where churches are set up like standards to commemorate the Lord's victories, then we shall sing heartily, we shall weep copiously, we shall pray unceasingly.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 46:169
verses.text: Wounded with the Saviour's shaft, we shall say one to another: "I have found Him whom my soul loveth; I will hold Him and will not let Him go".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 47:1
verses.text: Letter XLVII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 47:2
verses.text: To Desiderius.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 47:3
verses.text: Jerome invites two of his old friends at Rome, Desiderius and his sister (or wife) Serenilla, to join him at Bethlehem.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 47:4
verses.text: It is possible but not probable that this Desiderius is the same with Desiderius of Aquitaine, who afterwards induced Jerome to write against Vigilantius.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 47:5
verses.text: An interval of seven years separates this letter (of which the date is 393 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 47:6
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 47:7
verses.text: ) from the preceding, and all the letters written during this period have wholly perished.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 47:9
verses.text: Surprised as I have been, my excellent friend, to read the language which your kindness has prompted you to hold concerning me, I have rejoiced that I possess the testimony of one both eloquent and sincere; but when I turn from you to myself I feel vexed that, owing to my unworthiness, your words of praise and eulogy rather weigh me down than lift me up.
