verses.text: Shall there be but one reward, then, for hunger and for excess, for filth and for finery, for sackcloth and for silk? Lazarus, in his lifetime, received evil things, and the rich man, clothed in purple, fat and sleek, while he lived enjoyed the good things of the flesh but, now that they are dead, they occupy different positions.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 48:374
verses.text: Misery has given place to satisfaction, and satisfaction to misery.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 48:375
verses.text: And it rests with us whether we will follow Lazarus or the rich man.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 49:1
verses.text: Letter XLIX.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 49:2
verses.text: To Pammachius.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 49:3
verses.text: Jerome encloses the preceding letter, thanks Pammachius for his efforts to suppress his treatise "against Jovinian," but declares these to be useless, and exhorts him, if he still has any hesitation in his mind, to turn to the Scriptures and the commentaries made upon them by Origen and others.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 49:4
verses.text: Written at the same time as the preceding letter.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 49:6
verses.text: Christian modesty sometimes requires us to be silent even to our friends, and to nurse our humility in peace, where the renewal of an old friendship would expose us to the charge of self-seeking.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 49:7
verses.text: Thus, when you have kept silence I have kept silence too, and have not cared to remonstrate with you, lest I should be thought more anxious to conciliate a person of influence than to cultivate a friend.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 49:8
verses.text: But, now that it has become a duty to reply to your letter, I will endeavor always to be beforehand with you, and not so much to answer your queries as to write independently of them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 49:9
verses.text: Thus, if I have shown my modesty hitherto by silence, I will henceforth show it still more by coming forward to speak.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 49:11
verses.text: I quite recognize the kindness and forethought which have induced you to withdraw from circulation some copies of my work against Jovinian.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 49:12
verses.text: Your diligence, however, has been of no avail, for several people coming from the city have repeatedly read aloud to me passages which they have come across in Rome.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 49:13
verses.text: In this province, also, the books have already been circulated; and, as you have read yourself in Horace, "Words once uttered cannot be recalled".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 49:14
verses.text: I am not so fortunate as are most of the writers of the day—able, that is, to correct my trifles whenever I like.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 49:15
verses.text: When once I have written anything, either my admirers or my ill-wishers—from different motives, but with equal zeal—sow my work broadcast among the public; and their language, whether it is that of eulogy or of criticism, is apt to run to excess.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 49:16
verses.text: They are guided not by the merits of the piece, but by their own angry feelings.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 49:17
verses.text: Accordingly, I have done what I could.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 49:18
verses.text: I have dedicated to you a defence of the work in question, feeling sure that when you have read it you will yourself satisfy the doubts of others on my behalf; or else, if you too turn up your nose at the task, you will have to explain in some new manner that section of the apostle in which he discusses virginity and marriage.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 49:20
verses.text: I do not speak thus that I may provoke you to write on the subject yourself—although I know your zeal in the study of the sacred writings to be greater than my own—but that you may compel my tormentors to do so.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 49:21
verses.text: They are educated; in their own eyes no mean scholars; competent not merely to censure but to instruct me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 49:22
verses.text: If they write on the subject, my view will be the sooner neglected when it is compared with theirs.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 49:23
verses.text: Read, I pray you, and diligently consider the words of the apostle, and you will then see that—with a view to avoid misrepresentation—I have been much more gentle towards married persons than he was disposed to be.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 49:24
verses.text: Origen, Dionysius, Pierius, Eusebius of Caesarea, Didymus, Apollinaris, have used great latitude in the interpretation of this epistle.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 49:25
verses.text: When Pierius, sifting and expounding the apostle's meaning, comes to the words, "I would that all men were even as I myself," he makes this comment upon them: "In saying this Paul plainly preaches abstinence from marriage".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 49:26
verses.text: Is the fault here mine, or am I responsible for harshness? Compared with this sentence of Pierius, all that I have ever written is mild indeed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 49:27
verses.text: Consult the commentaries of the above-named writers and take advantage of the Church libraries; you will then more speedily finish as you would wish the enterprise which you have so happily begun.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 49:29
verses.text: I hear that the hopes of the entire city are centred in you, and that bishop and people are agreed in wishing for your exaltation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 49:30
verses.text: To be a bishop is much, to deserve to be one is more.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 49:31
verses.text: If you read the books of the sixteen prophets which I have rendered into Latin from the Hebrew; and if, when you have done so, you express satisfaction with my labors, the news will encourage me to take out of my desk some other works now shut up in it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 49:32
verses.text: I have lately translated Job into our mother tongue: you will be able to borrow a copy of it from your cousin, the saintly Marcella.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 49:33
verses.text: Read it both in Greek and in Latin, and compare the old version with my rendering.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 49:34
verses.text: You will then clearly see that the difference between them is that between truth and falsehood.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 49:35
verses.text: Some of my commentaries upon the twelve prophets I have sent to the reverend father Domnio, also the four books of Kings—that is, the two called Samuel and the two called Malâchim.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 49:36
verses.text: If you care to read these you will learn for yourself how difficult it is to understand the Holy Scriptures, and particularly the prophets; and how through the fault of the translators passages which for the Jews flow clearly on for us abound with mistakes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 49:37
verses.text: Once more, you must not in my small writings look for any such eloquence as that which for Christ's sake you disregard in Cicero.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 49:38
verses.text: A version made for the use of the Church, even though it may possess a literary charm, ought to disguise and avoid it as far as possible; in order that it may not speak to the idle schools and few disciples of the philosophers, but may address itself rather to the entire human race.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:1
verses.text: Letter L.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:2
verses.text: To Domnio.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:3
verses.text: Domnio, a Roman (called in Letter XLV.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:4
verses.text: "the Lot of our time"), had written to Jerome to tell him that an ignorant monk had been traducing his books "against Jovinian".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:5
verses.text: Jerome, in reply, sharply rebukes the folly of his critic and comments on the want of straightforwardness in his conduct.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:6
verses.text: He concludes the letter with an emphatic restatement of his original position.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:7
verses.text: Written in 394 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:8
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:10
verses.text: Your letter is full at once of affection and of complaining.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:11
verses.text: The affection is your own, which prompts you unceasingly to warn me of impending danger, and which makes you on my behalf  Of safest things distrustful and afraid.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:12
verses.text: The complaining is of those who have no love for me, and seek an occasion against me in my sins.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:13
verses.text: They speak against their brother, they slander their own mother's son.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:14
verses.text: You write to me of these—nay, of one in particular—a lounger who is to be seen in the streets, at crossings, and in public places; a monk who is a noisy news-monger, clever only in detraction, and eager, in spite of the beam in his own eye, to remove the mote in his neighbor's.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:15
verses.text: And you tell me that he preaches publicly against me, gnawing, rending, and tearing asunder with his fangs the books that I have written against Jovinian.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:16
verses.text: You inform me, moreover, that this home-grown dialectician, this mainstay of the Plautine company, has read neither the "Categories" of Aristotle nor his treatise "On Interpretation," nor his "Analytics," nor yet the "Topics" of Cicero, but that, moving as he does only in uneducated circles, and frequenting no society but that of weak women, he ventures to construct illogical syllogisms and to unravel by subtle arguments what he is pleased to call my sophisms.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:17
verses.text: How foolish I have been to suppose that without philosophy there can be no knowledge of these subjects; and to account it a more important part of composition to erase than to write! In vain have I perused the commentaries of Alexander; to no purpose has a skilled teacher used the "Introduction" of Porphyry to instruct me in logic; and—to make light of human learning—I have gained nothing at all by having Gregory of Nazianzum and Didymus as my catechists in the Holy Scriptures.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:18
verses.text: My acquisition of Hebrew has been wasted labor; and so also has been the daily study which from my youth I have bestowed upon the Law and the Prophets, the Gospels and the Apostles.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:20
verses.text: Here we have a man who has reached perfection without a teacher, so as to be a vehicle of the spirit and a self-taught genius.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:21
verses.text: He surpasses Cicero in eloquence, Aristotle in argument, Plato in discretion, Aristarchus in learning, Didymus, that man of brass, in the number of his books; and not only Didymus, but all the writers of his time in his knowledge of the Scriptures.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:22
verses.text: It is reported that you have only to give him a theme and he is always ready—like Carneades—to argue on this side or on that, for justice or against it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:23
verses.text: The world escaped a great danger, and civil actions and suits concerning succession were saved from a yawning gulf on the day when, despising the bar, he transferred himself to the Church.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:24
verses.text: For, had he been unwilling, who could ever have been proved innocent? And, if he once began to reckon the points of the case upon his fingers, and to spread his syllogistic nets, what criminal would his pleading have failed to save? Had he but stamped his foot, or fixed his eyes, or knitted his brow, or moved his hand, or twirled his beard, he would at once have thrown dust in the eyes of the jury.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:25
verses.text: No wonder that such a complete Latinist and so profound a master of eloquence overcomes poor me, who—as I have been some time away (from Rome), and without opportunities for speaking Latin—am half a Greek if not altogether a barbarian.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:26
verses.text: No wonder, I say, that he overcomes me when his eloquence has crushed Jovinian in person.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:27
verses.text: Good Jesus! what! even Jovinian that great and clever man! So clever, indeed, that no one can understand his writings, and that when he sings it is only for himself—and for the muses!  3.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:28
verses.text: Pray, my dear father, warn this man not to hold language contrary to his profession, and not to undo with his words the chastity which he professes by his garb.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:29
verses.text: Whether he elects to be a virgin or a married celibate—and the choice must rest with himself—he must not compare wives with virgins, for that would be to have striven in vain against Jovinian's eloquence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:30
verses.text: He likes, I am told, to visit the cells of widows and virgins, and to lecture them with his brows knit on sacred literature.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:31
verses.text: What is it that he teaches these poor women in the privacy of their own chambers? Is it to feel assured that virgins are no better than wives? Is it to make the most of the flower of their age, to eat and drink, to frequent the baths, to live in luxury, and not to disdain the use of perfumes? Or does he preach to them chastity, fasting, and neglect of their persons? No doubt the precepts that he inculcates are full of virtue.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:32
verses.text: But if so, let him admit publicly what he says privately.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:33
verses.text: Or, if his private teaching is the same as his public, he should keep aloof altogether from the society of girls.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:34
verses.text: He is a young man—a monk, and in his own eyes an eloquent one (do not pearls fall from his lips, and are not his elegant phrases sprinkled with comic salt and humor?)—I am surprised, therefore, that he can without a blush frequent noblemen's houses, pay constant visits to married ladies, make our religion a subject of contention, distort the faith of Christ by misapplying words, and—in addition to all this—detract from one who is his brother in the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:35
verses.text: He may, however, have supposed me to be in error (for "in many things we offend all," and "if any man offend not in word he is a perfect man").

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:36
verses.text: In that case he should have written to convict me or to question me, the course taken by Pammachius, a man of high attainments and position.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:37
verses.text: To this latter I defended myself as best I could, and in a lengthy letter explained the exact sense of my words.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:38
verses.text: He might at least have copied the diffidence which led you to extract and arrange such passages as seemed to give offence; asking me for corrections or explanations, and not supposing me so mad that in one and the same book I should write for marriage and against it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:40
verses.text: Let him spare himself, let him spare me, let him spare the Christian name.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:41
verses.text: Let him realize his position as a monk, not by talking and arguing, but by holding his peace and sitting still.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:42
verses.text: Let him read the words of Jeremiah: "It is good for a man that he bear the yoke in his youth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:43
verses.text: He sitteth alone and keepeth silence, because he hath borne it upon him".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:44
verses.text: Or if he has really the right to apply the censor's rod to all writers, and fancies himself a man of learning because he alone understands Jovinian (you know the proverb: Balbus best knows what Balbus means); yet, as Atilius reminds us, "we are not all writers".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:45
verses.text: Jovinian himself—an unlettered man of letters if ever there was one—will with most justice proclaim the fact to him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:46
verses.text: "That the bishops condemn me," he says, "is not reason but treason.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:47
verses.text: I want no answers from nobodies, who, while they have authority to put me down, have not the wit to teach me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:48
verses.text: Let one write against me who has a tongue that I can understand, and whom to vanquish will be to vanquish all.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:49
verses.text: "'I know full well: believe me, I have felt  The hero's force when rising o'er his shield  He hurls his whizzing spear.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:50
verses.text: '  He is strong in argument, intricate and tenacious, one to fight with his head down.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:51
verses.text: Often has he cried out against me in the streets from late one night till early the next.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:52
verses.text: He is a well-built man, and his thews are those of an athlete.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:53
verses.text: Secretly I believe him to be a follower of my teaching.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:54
verses.text: He never blushes or stops to weigh his words: his only aim is to speak as loud as possible.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:55
verses.text: So famous is he for his eloquence that his sayings are held up as models to our curly-headed youngsters.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:56
verses.text: How often, when I have met him at meetings, has he aroused my wrath and put me into a passion! How often has he spat upon me, and then departed spat upon! But these are vulgar methods, and any of my followers can use them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:57
verses.text: I appeal to books, to those memorials which must be handed down to posterity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:58
verses.text: Let us speak by our writings, that the silent reader may judge between us; and that, as I have a flock of disciples, he may have one also—flatterers and parasites worthy of the Gnatho and Phormio who is their master".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:60
verses.text: It is no difficult matter, my dear Domnio, to chatter at street corners or in apothecaries' shops and to pass judgment on the world.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:61
verses.text: "So-and-so has made a good speech, so-and-so a bad one; this man knows the Scriptures, that one is crazy; this man talks glibly, that never says a word at all".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:62
verses.text: But who considers him worthy thus to judge every one? To make an outcry against a man in every street, and to heap, not definite charges, but vague imputations, on his head, is nothing.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:63
verses.text: Any buffoon or litigiously disposed person can do as much.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:64
verses.text: Let him put forth his hand, put pen to paper, and bestir himself; let him write books and prove in them all he can.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:65
verses.text: Let him give me a chance of replying to his eloquence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:66
verses.text: I can return bite for bite, if I like; when hurt myself, I can fix my teeth in my opponent.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:67
verses.text: I too have had a liberal education.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:68
verses.text: As Juvenal says, "I also have often withdrawn my hand from the ferule".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:69
verses.text: Of me, too, it may be said in the words of Horace, "Flee from him; he has hay on his horn".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:70
verses.text: But I prefer to be a disciple of Him who says, "I gave my back to the smiters…I hid not my face from shame and spitting".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:71
verses.text: When He was reviled He reviled not again.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:72
verses.text: After the buffeting, the cross, the scourge, the blasphemies, at the very last He prayed for His crucifiers, saying, "Father, forgive them, for they know not what they do".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:73
verses.text: I, too, pardon the error of a brother.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:74
verses.text: He has been deceived, I feel sure, by the art of the devil.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:75
verses.text: Among the women he was held clever and eloquent; but, when my poor writings reached Rome, dreading me as a rival, he tried to rob me of my laurels.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:76
verses.text: No man on earth, he resolved, should please his eloquent self, unless such as commanded respect rather than sought it, and showed themselves men to be feared more than favored.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:77
verses.text: A man of consummate address, he desired, like an old soldier, with one stroke of the sword to strike down both his enemies, and to make clear to every one that, whatever view he might take, Scripture was always with him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:78
verses.text: Well, he must condescend to send me his account of the matter, and to correct my indiscreet language, not by censure but by instruction.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:79
verses.text: If he tries to do this, he will find that what seems forcible on a lounge is not equally forcible in court; and that it is one thing to discuss the doctrines of the divine law amid the spindles and work-baskets of girls and another to argue concerning them among men of education.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:80
verses.text: As it is, without hesitation or shame, he raises again and again the noisy shout, "Jerome condemns marriage," and, whilst he constantly moves among women with child, crying infants, and marriage-beds, he suppresses the words of the apostle just to cover me—poor me—with odium.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:81
verses.text: However, when he comes by and by to write books and to grapple with me at close quarters, then he will feel it, then he will stick fast; Epicurus and Aristippus will not be near him then; the swineherds will not come to his aid; the prolific sow will not so much as grunt.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:82
verses.text: For I also may say, with Turnus:  Father, I too can launch a forceful spear,  And when I strike blood follows from the wound.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:83
verses.text: But if he refuses to write, and fancies that abuse is as effective as criticism, then, in spite of all the lands and seas and peoples which lie between us, he must hear at least the echo of my cry, "I do not condemn marriage," "I do not condemn wedlock".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 50:84
verses.text: Indeed—and this I say to make my meaning quite clear to him—I should like every one to take a wife who, because they get frightened in the night, cannot manage to sleep alone.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:1
verses.text: Letter LI.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:2
verses.text: From Epiphanius, Bishop of Salamis, in Cyprus, to John, Bishop of Jerusalem.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:3
verses.text: A coolness had arisen between these two bishops in connection with the Origenistic controversy, which at this time was at its height.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:4
verses.text: Epiphanius had openly charged John with being an Origenist, and had also uncanonically conferred priests' orders on Jerome's brother Paulinian, in order that the monastery at Bethlehem might henceforth be entirely independent of John.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:5
verses.text: Naturally, John resented this conduct and showed his resentment.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:6
verses.text: The present letter is a kind of half-apology made by Epiphanius for what he had done, and like all such, it only seems to have made matters worse.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:7
verses.text: The controversy is fully detailed in the treatise "Against John of Jerusalem" in this volume, esp.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:9
verses.text: An interesting paragraph (§9) narrates how Epiphanius destroyed at Anablatha a church-curtain on which was depicted "a likeness of Christ or of some saint"—an early instance of the iconoclastic spirit.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:10
verses.text: Originally written in Greek, the letter was (by the writer's request) rendered into Latin by Jerome.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:11
verses.text: Its date is 394 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:12
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:13
verses.text: To the lord bishop and dearly beloved brother, John, Epiphanius sends greeting.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:15
verses.text: It surely becomes us, dearly beloved, not to abuse our rank as clergy, so as to make it an occasion of pride, but by diligently keeping and observing God's commandments, to be in reality what in name we profess to be.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:16
verses.text: For, if the Holy Scriptures say, "Their lots shall not profit them," what pride in our clerical position will be able to avail us who sin not only in thought and feeling, but in speech? I have heard, of course, that you are incensed against me, that you are angry, and that you threaten to write about me—not merely to particular places and provinces, but to the uttermost ends of the earth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:17
verses.text: Where is that fear of God which should make us tremble with the trembling spoken of by the Lord—"Whosoever is angry with his brother without a cause shall be in danger of the judgment"? Not that I greatly care for your writing what you please.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:18
verses.text: For Isaiah tells us of letters written on papyrus and cast upon the waters—missives soon carried away by time and tide.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:19
verses.text: I have done you no harm, I have inflicted no injury upon you, I have extorted nothing from you by violence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:20
verses.text: My action concerned a monastery whose inmates were foreigners in no way subject to your provincial jurisdiction.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:21
verses.text: Moreover their regard for my insignificance and for the letters which I frequently addressed to them had commenced to produce a feeling of dislike to communion with you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:22
verses.text: Feeling, therefore, that too great strictness or scrupulosity on my part might have the effect of alienating them from the Church with its ancient faith, I ordained one of the brothers deacon, and after he had ministered as such, admitted him to the priesthood.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:23
verses.text: You should, I think, have been grateful to me for this, knowing, as you surely must, that it is the fear of God which has compelled me to act in this way, and particularly when you recollect that God's priesthood is everywhere the same, and that I have simply made provision for the wants of the Church.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:24
verses.text: For, although each individual bishop of the Church has under him churches which are placed in his charge, and although no man may stretch himself beyond his measure, yet the love of Christ, which is without dissimulation, is set up as an example to us all; and we must consider not so much the thing done as the time and place, the mode and motive, of doing it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:25
verses.text: I saw that the monastery contained a large number of reverend brothers, and that the reverend presbyters, Jerome and Vincent, through modesty and humility, were unwilling to offer the sacrifices permitted to their rank, and to labor in that part of their calling which ministers more than any other to the salvation of Christians.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:26
verses.text: I knew, moreover, that you could not find or lay hands on this servant of God who had several times fled from you simply because he was reluctant to undertake the onerous duties of the priesthood, and that no other bishop could easily find him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:27
verses.text: Accordingly, I was a good deal surprised when, by the ordering of God, he came to me with the deacons of the monastery and others of the brethren, to make satisfaction to me for some grievance or other which I had against them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:28
verses.text: While, therefore, the Collect was being celebrated in the church of the villa which adjoins our monastery—he being quite ignorant and wholly unsuspicious of my purpose—I gave orders to a number of deacons to seize him and to stop his mouth, lest in his eagerness to free himself he might adjure me in the name of Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:29
verses.text: First of all, then, I ordained him deacon, setting before him the fear of God, and forcing him to minister; for he made a hard struggle against it, crying out that he was unworthy, and protesting that this heavy burden was beyond his strength.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:30
verses.text: It was with difficulty, then, that I overcame his reluctance, persuading him as well as I could with passages from Scripture, and setting before him the commandments of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:31
verses.text: And when he had ministered in the offering of the holy sacrifices, once more with great difficulty I closed his mouth and ordained him presbyter.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:32
verses.text: Then, using the same arguments as before, I induced him to sit in the place set apart for the presbyters.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:33
verses.text: After this I wrote to the reverend presbyters and other brothers of the monastery, chiding them for not having written to me about him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:34
verses.text: For a year before I had heard many of them complain that they had no one to celebrate for them the sacraments of the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:35
verses.text: All then agreed in asking him to undertake the duty, pointing out how great his usefulness would be to the community of the monastery.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:36
verses.text: I blamed them for omitting to write to me and to propose that I should ordain him, when the opportunity was given to them to do so.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:38
verses.text: All this I have done, as I said just now, relying on that Christian love which you, I feel sure, cherish towards my insignificance; not to mention the fact that I held the ordination in a monastery, and not within the limits of your jurisdiction.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:39
verses.text: How truly blessed is the mildness and complacency of the bishops of (my own) Cyprus, as well as their simplicity, though to your refinement and discrimination it appears deserving only of God's pity! For many bishops in communion with me have ordained presbyters in my province whom I had been unable to capture, and have sent to me deacons and subdeacons whom I have been glad to receive.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:40
verses.text: I myself, too, have urged the bishop Philo of blessed memory, and the reverend Theoprepus, to make provision for the Church of Christ by ordaining presbyters in those churches of Cyprus which, although they were accounted to belong to my see, happened to be close to them, and this for the reason that my province was large and straggling.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:41
verses.text: But for my part I have never ordained deaconesses nor sent them into the provinces of others, nor have I done anything to rend the Church.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:42
verses.text: Why, then, have you thought fit to be so angry and indignant with me for that work of God which I have wrought for the edification of the brethren, and not for their destruction? Moreover, I have been much surprised at the assertion which you have made to my clergy, that you sent me a message by that reverend presbyter, the abbot Gregory, that I was to ordain no one, and that I promised to comply, saying, "Am I a stripling, or do I not know the canons?" By God's word I am telling you the truth when I say that I know and have heard nothing of all this, and that I have not the slightest recollection of using any language of the sort.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:43
verses.text: As, however, I have had misgivings, lest possibly, being only a man, I may have forgotten this among so many other matters, I have made inquiry of the reverend Gregory, and of the presbyter Zeno, who is with him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:44
verses.text: Of these, the abbot Gregory replies that he knows nothing whatever about the matter, while Zeno says that the presbyter Rufinus, in the course of some desultory remarks, spoke these words.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:45
verses.text: "Will the reverend bishop, think you, venture to ordain any persons?" but that the conversation went no further.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:46
verses.text: I, Epiphanius, however, have never either received the message or answered it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:47
verses.text: Do not, then, dearly beloved, allow your anger to overcome you or your indignation to get the better of you, lest you should disquiet yourself in vain; and lest you should be thought to be putting forward this grievance only to get scope for tendencies of another kind, and thus to have sought out an occasion of sinning.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:48
verses.text: It is to avoid this that the prophet prays to the Lord, saying: "Turn not aside my heart to words of wickedness, to making excuses for my sins".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:50
verses.text: This also I have been surprised to hear, that certain persons who are in the habit of carrying tales backwards and forwards, and of always adding something fresh to what they have heard, to stir up grievances and disputes between brothers, have succeeded in disquieting you by saying that, when I offer sacrifices to God, I am wont to say this prayer on your behalf: "Grant, O Lord, to John grace to believe aright".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:51
verses.text: Do not suppose me so untutored as to be capable of saying this so openly.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:52
verses.text: To tell you the simple truth, my dearest brother, although I continually use this prayer mentally, I have never confided it to the ears of others, lest I should seem to dishonor you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:53
verses.text: But when I repeat the prayers required by the ritual of the mysteries, then I say on behalf of all and of you as well as others, "Guard him, that he may preach the truth," or at least this, "Do Thou, O Lord, grant him Thine aid, and guard him, that he may preach the word of truth," as occasion offers itself for the words, and as the turn comes for the particular prayer.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:54
verses.text: Wherefore I beseech you, dearly beloved, and, casting myself down at your feet, I entreat you to grant to me and to yourself this one prayer, that you would save yourself, as it is written, "from an untoward generation".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:55
verses.text: Withdraw, dearly beloved, from the heresy of Origen and from all heresies.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:56
verses.text: For I see that all your indignation has been roused against me simply because I have told you that you ought not to eulogize one who is the spiritual father of Arius, and the root and parent of all heresies.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:57
verses.text: And when I appealed to you not to go astray, and warned you of the consequences, you traversed my words, and reduced me to tears and sadness; and not me only, but many other Catholics who were present.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:58
verses.text: This I take to be the origin of your indignation and of your passion on the present occasion.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:59
verses.text: On this account you threaten to send out letters against me, and to circulate your version of the matter in all directions; and thus, while with a view to defending your heresy you kindle men's passions against me, you break through the charity which I have shown towards you, and act with so little discretion that you make me regret that I have held communion with you, and that I have by so doing upheld the erroneous opinions of Origen.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:61
verses.text: I speak plainly.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:62
verses.text: To use the language of Scripture, I do not spare to pluck out my own eye if it cause me to offend, nor to cut off my hand and my foot if they cause me to do so.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:63
verses.text: And you must be treated in the same way whether you are my eyes, or my hands, or my feet.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:64
verses.text: For what Catholic, what Christian who adorns his faith with good works, can hear with calmness Origen's teaching and counsel, or believe in his extraordinary preaching? "The Son," he tells us, "cannot see the Father, and the Holy Spirit cannot see the Son".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:65
verses.text: These words occur in his book "On First Principles;" thus we read, and thus Origen has spoken.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:66
verses.text: "For as it is unsuitable to say that the Son can see the Father, it is consequently unsuitable to suppose that the Spirit can see the Son".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:67
verses.text: Can any one, moreover, brook Origen's assertion that men's souls were once angels in heaven, and that having sinned in the upper world, they have been cast down into this, and have been confined in bodies as in barrows or tombs, to pay the penalty for their former sins; and that the bodies of believers are not temples of Christ, but prisons of the condemned? Again, he tampers with the true meaning of the narrative by a false use of allegory, multiplying words without limit; and undermines the faith of the simple by the most varied arguments.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:68
verses.text: Now he maintains that souls, in Greek the "cool things," from a word meaning to be cool, are so called because in coming down from the heavenly places to the lower world they have lost their former heat; and now, that our bodies are called by the Greeks chains, from a word meaning chain, or else (on the analogy of our own Latin word) "things fallen," because our souls have fallen from heaven; and that the other word for body which the abundance of the Greek idiom supplies is by many taken to mean a funeral monument, because the soul is shut up within it in the same way as the corpses of the dead are shut up in tombs and barrows.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:69
verses.text: If this doctrine is true what becomes of our faith? Where is the preaching of the resurrection? Where is the teaching of the apostles, which lasts on to this day in the churches of Christ? Where is the blessing to Adam, and to his seed, and to Noah and his sons? "Be fruitful, and multiply, and replenish the earth".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:70
verses.text: According to Origen, these words must be a curse and not a blessing; for he turns angels into human souls, compelling them to leave the place of highest rank and to come down lower, as though God were unable through the action of His blessing to grant souls to the human race, had the angels not sinned, and as though for every birth on earth there must be a fall in heaven.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:71
verses.text: We are to give up, then, the teaching of apostles and prophets, of the law, and of our Lord and Saviour Himself, in spite of His language loud as thunder in the gospel.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:72
verses.text: Origen, on the other hand, commands and urges—not to say binds—his disciples not to pray to ascend into heaven, lest sinning once more worse than they had sinned on earth they should be hurled down into the world again.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:73
verses.text: Such foolish and insane notions he generally confirms by distorting the sense of the Scriptures and making them mean what they do not mean at all.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:74
verses.text: He quotes this passage from the Psalms: "Before thou didst humble me by reason of my wickedness, I went wrong;" and this, "Return unto thy rest, O my soul;" this also, "Bring my soul out of prison;" and this, "I will make confession unto the Lord in the land of the living," although there can be no doubt that the meaning of the divine Scripture is different from the interpretation by which he unfairly wrests it to the support of his own heresy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:75
verses.text: This way of acting is common to the Manichaeans, the Gnostics, the Ebionites, the Marcionites, and the votaries of the other eighty heresies, all of whom draw their proofs from the pure well of the Scriptures, not, however, interpreting it in the sense in which it is written, but trying to make the simple language of the Church's writers accord with their own wishes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:77
verses.text: Of one position which he strives to maintain I hardly know whether it calls for my tears or my laughter.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:78
verses.text: This wonderful doctor presumes to teach that the devil will once more be what he at one time was, that he will return to his former dignity and rise again to the kingdom of heaven.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:79
verses.text: Oh horror! that a man should be so frantic and foolish as to hold that John the Baptist, Peter, the apostle and evangelist John, Isaiah, Jeremiah, and the rest of the prophets, are made co-heirs of the devil in the kingdom of heaven! I pass over his idle explanation of the coats of skins, and say nothing of the efforts and arguments he has used to induce us to believe that these coats of skins represent human bodies.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:80
verses.text: Among many other things, he says this: "Was God a tanner or a saddler, that He should prepare the hides of animals, and should stitch from them coats of skins for Adam and Eve?" "It is clear," he goes on, "that he is speaking of human bodies".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:81
verses.text: If this is so, how is it that before the coats of skins, and the disobedience, and the fall from paradise, Adam speaks not in an allegory, but literally, thus: "This is now bone of my bones and flesh of my flesh;" or what is the ground of the divine narrative, "And the Lord God caused a deep sleep to fall upon Adam, and he slept; and he took one of his ribs, and closed up the flesh instead thereof; and the rib which the Lord God had taken from man, made He a woman" for him? Or what bodies can Adam and Eve have covered with fig-leaves after eating of the forbidden tree? Who can patiently listen to the perilous arguments of Origen when he denies the resurrection of this flesh, as he most clearly does in his book of explanations of the first psalm and in many other places? Or who can tolerate him when he gives us a paradise in the third heaven, and transfers that which the Scripture mentions from earth to the heavenly places, and when he explains allegorically all the trees which are mentioned in Genesis, saying in effect that the trees are angelic potencies, a sense which the true drift of the passage does not admit? For the divine Scripture has not said, "God put down Adam and Eve upon the earth," but "He drove them out of the paradise, and made them dwell over against the paradise".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:82
verses.text: He does not say "under the paradise".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:83
verses.text: "He placed…cherubims and a flaming sword…to keep the way of the tree of life".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:84
verses.text: He says nothing about an ascent to it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:85
verses.text: "And a river went out of Eden".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:86
verses.text: He does not say "went down from Eden".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:87
verses.text: "It was parted and became into four heads.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:88
verses.text: The name of the first is Pison…and the name of the second is Gihon".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:89
verses.text: I myself have seen the waters of Gihon, have seen them with my bodily eyes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:90
verses.text: It is this Gihon to which Jeremiah points when he says, "What hast thou to do in the way of Egypt to drink the muddy water of Gihon?" I have drunk also from the great river Euphrates, not spiritual but actual water, such as you can touch with your hand and imbibe with your mouth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:91
verses.text: But where there are rivers which admit of being seen and of being drunk, it follows that there also there will be fig-trees and other trees; and it is of these that the Lord says, "Of every tree of the garden thou mayest freely eat".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:92
verses.text: They are like other trees and timber, just as the rivers are like other rivers and waters.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:93
verses.text: But if the water is visible and real, then the fig-tree and the rest of the timber must be real also, and Adam and Eve must have been originally formed with real and not phantasmal bodies, and not, as Origen would have us believe, have afterwards received them on account of their sin.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:94
verses.text: But, you say, "we read that Saint Paul was caught up to the third heaven, into paradise".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:95
verses.text: You explain the words rightly: "When he mentions the third heaven, and then adds the word paradise, he shows that heaven is in one place and paradise in another".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:96
verses.text: Must not every one reject and despise such special pleading as that by which Origen says of the waters that are above the firmament that they are not waters, but heroic beings of angelic power, and again of the waters that are over the earth—that is, below the firmament—that they are potencies of the contrary sort—that is, demons? If so, why do we read in the account of the deluge that the windows of heaven were opened, and that the waters of the deluge prevailed? in consequence of which the fountains of the deep were opened, and the whole earth was covered with the waters.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:98
verses.text: Oh! the madness and folly of those who have forsaken the teaching of the book of Proverbs, "My son, keep thy father's commandment, and forsake not the law of thy mother," and have turned to error, and say to the fool that he shall be their leader, and do not despise the foolish things which are said by the foolish man, even as the scripture bears witness, "The foolish man speaketh foolishly, and his heart understandeth vanity".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:99
verses.text: I beseech you, dearly beloved, and by the love which I feel towards you, I implore you—as though it were my own members on which I would have pity—by word and letter to fulfil that which is written, "Do not I hate them, O Lord, that hate thee? and am not I grieved with those that rise up against thee?" Origen's words are the words of an enemy, hateful and repugnant to God and to His saints; and not only those which I have quoted, but countless others.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:100
verses.text: For it is not now my intention to argue against all his opinions.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:101
verses.text: Origen has not lived in my day, nor has he robbed me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:102
verses.text: I have not conceived a dislike to him nor quarrelled with him because of an inheritance or of any worldly matter; but—to speak plainly—I grieve, and grieve bitterly, to see numbers of my brothers, and of those in particular who show the most promise, and have reached the highest rank in the sacred ministry, deceived by his persuasive arguments, and made by his most perverse teaching the food of the devil, whereby the saying is fulfilled: "He derides every stronghold, and his fare is choice, and he hath gathered captives as the sand".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:103
verses.text: But may God free you, my brother, and the holy people of Christ which is intrusted to you, and all the brothers who are with you, and especially the presbyter Rufinus, from the heresy of Origen, and other heresies, and from the perdition to which they lead.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:104
verses.text: For, if for one word or for two opposed to the faith many heresies have been rejected by the Church, how much more shall he be held a heretic who has contrived such perverse interpretations and such mischievous doctrines to destroy the faith, and has in fact declared himself the enemy of the Church! For, among other wicked things, he has presumed to say this, too, that Adam lost the image of God, although Scripture nowhere declares that he did.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:105
verses.text: Were it so, never would all the creatures in the world be subject to Adam's seed—that is, to the entire human race; yet, in the words of the apostle, everything "is tamed and hath been tamed of mankind".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:106
verses.text: For never would all things be subjected to men if men had not—together with their authority over all—the image of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:107
verses.text: But the divine Scripture conjoins and associates with this the grace of the blessing which was conferred upon Adam and upon the generations which descended from him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:108
verses.text: No one can by twisting the meaning of words presume to say that this grace of God was given to one only, and that he alone was made in the image of God (he and his wife, that is, for while he was formed of clay she was made of one of his ribs), but that those who were subsequently conceived in the womb and not born as was Adam did not possess God's image, for the Scripture immediately subjoins the following statement: "And Adam lived two hundred and thirty years, and knew Eve his wife, and she bare him a son in his image and after his likeness, and called his name Seth".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:109
verses.text: And again, in the tenth generation, two thousand two hundred and forty-two years afterwards, God, to vindicate His own image and to show that the grace which He had given to men still continued in them, gives the following commandment: "Flesh…with the blood thereof shall ye not eat.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:110
verses.text: And surely your blood will I require at the hand of every man that sheddeth it; for in the image of God have I made man".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:111
verses.text: From Noah to Abraham ten generations passed away, and from Abraham's time to David's, fourteen more, and these twenty-four generations make up, taken together, two thousand one hundred and seventeen years.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:112
verses.text: Yet the Holy Spirit in the thirty-ninth psalm, while lamenting that all men walk in a vain show, and that they are subject to sins, speaks thus: "For all that every man walketh in the image".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:113
verses.text: Also after David's time, in the reign of Solomon his son, we read a somewhat similar reference to the divine likeness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:114
verses.text: For in the book of Wisdom, which is inscribed with his name, Solomon says: "God created man to be immortal, and made him to be an image of His own eternity".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:115
verses.text: And again, about eleven hundred and eleven years afterwards, we read in the New Testament that men have not lost the image of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:116
verses.text: For James, an apostle and brother of the Lord, whom I have mentioned above—that we may not be entangled in the snares of Origen—teaches us that man does possess God's image and likeness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:117
verses.text: For, after a somewhat discursive account of the human tongue, he has gone on to say of it: "It is an unruly evil…therewith bless we God, even the Father and therewith curse we men, which are made after the similitude of God".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:118
verses.text: Paul, too, the "chosen vessel," who in his preaching has fully maintained the doctrine of the gospel, instructs us that man is made in the image and after the likeness of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:119
verses.text: "A man," he says, "ought not to wear long hair, forasmuch as he is the image and glory of God".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:120
verses.text: He speaks of "the image" simply, but explains the nature of the likeness by the word "glory".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:122
verses.text: Instead of the three proofs from Holy Scripture which you said would satisfy you if I could produce them, behold I have given you seven.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:123
verses.text: Who, then, will put up with the follies of Origen? I will not use a severer word and so make myself like him or his followers, who presume at the peril of their soul to assert dogmatically whatever first comes into their head, and to dictate to God, whereas they ought either to pray to Him or to learn the truth from Him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:124
verses.text: For some of them say that the image of God which Adam had previously received was lost when he sinned.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:125
verses.text: Others surmise that the body which the Son of God was destined to take of Mary was the image of the Creator.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:126
verses.text: Some identify this image with the soul, others with sensation, others with virtue.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:127
verses.text: These make it baptism, those assert that it is in virtue of God's image that man exercises universal sway.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:128
verses.text: Like drunkards in their cups, they ejaculate now this, now that, when they ought rather to have avoided so serious a risk, and to have obtained salvation by simple faith, not denying the words of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:129
verses.text: To God they ought to have left the sure and exact knowledge of His own gift, and of the particular way in which He has created men in His image and after His likeness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:130
verses.text: Forsaking this course, they have involved themselves in many subtle questions, and through these they have been plunged into the mire of sin.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:131
verses.text: But we, dearly beloved, believe the words of the Lord, and know that God's image remains in all men, and we leave it to Him to know in what respect man is created in His image.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:132
verses.text: And let no one be deceived by that passage in the epistle of John, which some readers fail to understand, where he says: "Now are we the sons of God, and it doth not yet appear what we shall be: but we know that, when He shall appear, we shall be like Him; for we shall see Him as He is".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:133
verses.text: For this refers to the glory which is then to be revealed to His saints; just as also in another place we read the words "from glory to glory," of which glory the saints have even in this world received an earnest and a small portion.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:134
verses.text: At their head stands Moses, whose face shone exceedingly, and was bright with the brightness of the sun.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:135
verses.text: Next to him comes Elijah, who was caught up into heaven in a chariot of fire, and did not feel the effects of the flame.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:136
verses.text: Stephen, too, when he was being stoned, had the face of an angel visible to all.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:137
verses.text: And this which we have verified in a few cases is to be understood of all, that what is written may be fulfilled.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:138
verses.text: "Every one that sanctifieth himself shall be numbered among the blessed".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:139
verses.text: For, "blessed are the pure in heart, for they shall see God".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:141
verses.text: These things being so, dearly beloved, keep watch over your own soul and cease to murmur against me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:142
verses.text: For the divine Scripture says: "Neither murmur ye [one against another] as some of them also murmured, and were destroyed of serpents".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:143
verses.text: Rather give way to the truth and love me who love both you and the truth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:144
verses.text: And may the God of peace, according to His mercy, grant to us that Satan may be bruised under the feet of Christians, and that every occasion of evil may be shunned, so that the bond of love and peace may not be rent asunder between us, or the preaching of the right faith be anywise hindered.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:146
verses.text: Moreover, I have heard that certain persons have this grievance against me: When I accompanied you to the holy place called Bethel, there to join you in celebrating the Collect, after the use of the Church, I came to a villa called Anablatha and, as I was passing, saw a lamp burning there.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:147
verses.text: Asking what place it was, and learning it to be a church, I went in to pray, and found there a curtain hanging on the doors of the said church, dyed and embroidered.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:148
verses.text: It bore an image either of Christ or of one of the saints; I do not rightly remember whose the image was.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:149
verses.text: Seeing this, and being loth that an image of a man should be hung up in Christ's church contrary to the teaching of the Scriptures, I tore it asunder and advised the custodians of the place to use it as a winding sheet for some poor person.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:150
verses.text: They, however, murmured, and said that if I made up my mind to tear it, it was only fair that I should give them another curtain in its place.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:151
verses.text: As soon as I heard this, I promised that I would give one, and said that I would send it at once.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:152
verses.text: Since then there has been some little delay, due to the fact that I have been seeking a curtain of the best quality to give to them instead of the former one, and thought it right to send to Cyprus for one.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:153
verses.text: I have now sent the best that I could find, and I beg that you will order the presbyter of the place to take the curtain which I have sent from the hands of the Reader, and that you will afterwards give directions that curtains of the other sort—opposed as they are to our religion—shall not be hung up in any church of Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:154
verses.text: A man of your uprightness should be careful to remove an occasion of offence unworthy alike of the Church of Christ and of those Christians who are committed to your charge.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:155
verses.text: Beware of Palladius of Galatia—a man once dear to me, but who now sorely needs God's pity—for he preaches and teaches the heresy of Origen; and see to it that he does not seduce any of those who are intrusted to your keeping into the perverse ways of his erroneous doctrine.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 51:156
verses.text: I pray that you may fare well in the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:1
verses.text: Letter LII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:2
verses.text: To Nepotian.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:3
verses.text: Nepotian, the nephew of Heliodorus (for whom see Letter XIV.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:4
verses.text: ), had, like his uncle, abandoned the military for the clerical calling, and was now a presbyter at Altinum, where Heliodorus was bishop.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:5
verses.text: The letter is a systematic treatise on the duties of the clergy and on the rule of life which they ought to adopt.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:6
verses.text: It had a great vogue, and called forth much indignation against Jerome.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:7
verses.text: Its date is 394 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:8
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:10
verses.text: Again and again you ask me, my dear Nepotian, in your letters from over the sea, to draw for you a few rules of life, showing how one who has renounced the service of the world to become a monk or a clergyman may keep the straight path of Christ, and not be drawn aside into the haunts of vice.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:11
verses.text: As a young man, or rather as a boy, and while I was curbing by the hard life of the desert the first onslaughts of youthful passion, I sent a letter of remonstrance to your reverend uncle, Heliodorus, which, by the tears and complainings with which it was filled, showed him the feelings of the friend whom he had deserted.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:12
verses.text: In it I acted the part suited to my age, and as I was still aglow with the methods and maxims of the rhetoricians, I decked it out a good deal with the flourishes of the schools.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:13
verses.text: Now, however, my head is gray, my brow is furrowed, a dewlap like that of an ox hangs from my chin, and, as Virgil says,  The chilly blood stands still around my heart.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:14
verses.text: Elsewhere he sings:  Old age bears all, even the mind, away.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:15
verses.text: And a little further on:  So many of my songs are gone from me,  And even my very voice has left me now.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:17
verses.text: But that I may not seem to quote only profane literature, listen to the mystical teaching of the sacred writings.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:18
verses.text: Once David had been a man of war, but at seventy age had chilled him so that nothing would make him warm.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:19
verses.text: A girl is accordingly sought from the coasts of Israel—Abishag the Shunamite—to sleep with the king and warm his aged frame.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:20
verses.text: Does it not seem to you—if you keep to the letter that killeth—like some farcical story or some broad jest from an Atellan play? A chilly old man is wrapped up in blankets, and only grows warm in a girl's embrace.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:21
verses.text: Bathsheba was still living, Abigail was still left, and the remainder of those wives and concubines whose names the Scripture mentions.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:22
verses.text: Yet they are all rejected as cold, and only in the one young girl's embrace does the old man become warm.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:23
verses.text: Abraham was far older than David; still, so long as Sarah lived he sought no other wife.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:24
verses.text: Isaac counted twice the years of David, yet never felt cold with Rebekah, old though she was.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:25
verses.text: I say nothing of the antediluvians, who, although after nine hundred years their limbs must have been not old merely, but decayed with age, had no recourse to girls' embraces.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:26
verses.text: Moses, the leader of the Israelites, counted one hundred and twenty years, yet sought no change from Zipporah.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:28
verses.text: Who, then, is this Shunamite, this wife and maid, so glowing as to warm the cold, yet so holy as not to arouse passion in him whom she warmed? Let Solomon, wisest of men, tell us of his father's favorite; let the man of peace recount to us the embraces of the man of war.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:29
verses.text: "Get wisdom," he writes, "get understanding: forget it not; neither decline from the words of my mouth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:30
verses.text: Forsake her not and she shall preserve thee: love her and she shall keep thee.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:31
verses.text: Wisdom is the principal thing, therefore get wisdom, and with all thy getting get understanding.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:32
verses.text: Exalt her and she shall promote thee.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:33
verses.text: She shall bring thee to honor when thou dost embrace her.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:34
verses.text: She shall give to thine head an ornament of grace: a crown of glory shall she deliver to thee".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:35
verses.text: Almost all bodily excellences alter with age, and while wisdom alone increases all things else decay.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:36
verses.text: Fasts and vigils and almsdeeds become harder.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:37
verses.text: So also do sleeping on the ground, moving from place to place, hospitality to travellers, pleading for the poor, earnestness and steadfastness in prayer, the visitation of the sick, manual labor to supply money for alms-giving.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:38
verses.text: All acts, in short, of which the body is the medium decrease with its decay.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:39
verses.text: Now, there are young men still full of life and vigor who, by toil and burning zeal, as well as by holiness of life and constant prayer to the Lord Jesus, have obtained knowledge.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:40
verses.text: I do not speak of these, or say that in them the love of wisdom is cold, for this withers in many of the old by reason of age.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:41
verses.text: What I mean is that youth, as such, has to cope with the assaults of passion, and amid the allurements of vice and the tinglings of the flesh is stifled like a fire among green boughs, and cannot develop its proper brightness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:42
verses.text: But when men have employed their youth in commendable pursuits and have meditated on the law of the Lord day and night, they learn with the lapse of time, fresh experience and wisdom come as the years go by, and so from the pursuits of the past their old age reaps a harvest of delight.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:43
verses.text: Hence that wise man of Greece, Themistocles, perceiving, after the expiration of one hundred and seven years, that he was on the verge of the grave, is reported to have said that he regretted extremely having to leave life just when he was beginning to grow wise.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:44
verses.text: Plato died in his eighty-first year, his pen still in his hand.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:45
verses.text: Isocrates completed ninety years and nine in the midst of literary and scholastic work.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:46
verses.text: I say nothing of other philosophers, such as Pythagoras, Democritus, Xenocrates, Zeno, and Cleanthes, who in extreme old age displayed the vigor of youth in the pursuit of wisdom.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:47
verses.text: I pass on to the poets, Homer, Hesiod, Simonides, Stesichorus, who all lived to a great age, yet at the approach of death sang each of them a swan song sweeter than their wont.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:48
verses.text: Sophocles, when charged by his sons with dotage on account of his advanced years and his neglect of his property, read out to his judges his recently composed play of oedipus, and made so great a display of wisdom—in spite of the inroads of time—that he changed the decorous silence of the law court into the applause of the theatre.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:49
verses.text: And no wonder, when Cato the censor, that most eloquent of Romans, in his old age neither blushed at the thought of learning Greek nor despaired of succeeding.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:50
verses.text: Homer, for his part, relates that from the tongue of Nestor, even when quite aged and helpless, there flowed speech sweeter than honey.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:51
verses.text: Even the very name Abishag in its mystic meaning points to the greater wisdom of old men.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:52
verses.text: For the translation of it is, "My father is over and above," or "my father's roaring".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:53
verses.text: The term "over and above" is obscure, but in this passage is indicative of excellence, and implies that the old have a larger stock of wisdom, and that it even overflows by reason of its abundance.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:54
verses.text: In another passage "over and above" forms an antithesis to "necessary".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:55
verses.text: Moreover, Abishag, that is, "roaring," is properly used of the sound which the waves make, and of the murmur which we hear coming from the sea.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:56
verses.text: From which it is plain that the thunder of the divine voice dwells in old men's ears with a volume of sound beyond the voices of men.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:57
verses.text: Again, in our tongue Shunamite means "scarlet," a hint that the love of wisdom becomes warm and glowing through religious study.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:58
verses.text: For though the color may point to the mystery of the Lord's blood, it also sets forth the warm glow of wisdom.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:59
verses.text: Hence it is a scarlet thread that in Genesis the midwife binds upon the hand of Pharez—Pharez "the divider," so called because he divided the partition which had before separated two peoples.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:60
verses.text: So, too, with a mystic reference to the shedding of blood, it was a scarlet cord which the harlot Rahab (a type of the church) hung in her window to preserve her house in the destruction of Jericho.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:61
verses.text: Hence, in another place Scripture says of holy men: "These are they which came from the warmth of the house of the father of Rechab".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:62
verses.text: And in the gospel the Lord says: "I am come to cast fire upon the earth, and fain am I to see it kindled".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:63
verses.text: This was the fire which, when it was kindled in the disciples' hearts, constrained them to say: "Did not our heart burn within us while He talked with us by the way, and while He opened to us the Scriptures?"  4.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:64
verses.text: To what end, you ask, these recondite references? To show that you need not expect from me boyish declamation, flowery sentiments, a meretricious style, and at the close of every paragraph the terse and pointed aphorisms which call forth approving shouts from those who hear them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:65
verses.text: Let Wisdom alone embrace me; let her nestle in my bosom, my Abishag who grows not old.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:66
verses.text: Undefiled truly is she, and a virgin forever for although she daily conceives and unceasingly brings to the birth, like Mary she remains undeflowered.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:67
verses.text: When the apostle says "be fervent in spirit," he means "be true to wisdom".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:68
verses.text: And when our Lord in the gospel declares that in the end of the world—when the shepherd shall grow foolish, according to the prophecy of Zechariah—"the love of many shall wax cold," He means that wisdom shall decay.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:69
verses.text: Hear, therefore—to quote the sainted Cyprian—"words forcible rather than elegant".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:70
verses.text: Hear one who, though he is your brother in orders, is in years your father; who can conduct you from the cradle of faith to spiritual manhood; and who, while he builds up stage by stage the rules of holy living, can instruct others in instructing you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:71
verses.text: I know, of course, that from your reverend uncle, Heliodorus, now a bishop of Christ, you have learned and are daily learning all that is holy; and that in him you have before you a rule of life and a pattern of virtue.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:72
verses.text: Take, then, my suggestions for what they are worth, and compare my precepts with his.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:73
verses.text: He will teach you the perfection of a monk, and I shall show you the whole duty of a clergyman.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:75
verses.text: A clergyman, then, as he serves Christ's church, must first understand what his name means; and then, when he realizes this, must endeavor to be that which he is called.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:76
verses.text: For since the Greek word κλῆρος means "lot," or "inheritance," the clergy are so called either because they are the lot of the Lord, or else because the Lord Himself is their lot and portion.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:77
verses.text: Now, he who in his own person is the Lord's portion, or has the Lord for his portion, must so bear himself as to possess the Lord and to be possessed by Him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:78
verses.text: He who possesses the Lord, and who says with the prophet, "The Lord is my portion," can hold to nothing beside the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:79
verses.text: For if he hold to something beside the Lord, the Lord will not be his portion.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:80
verses.text: Suppose, for instance, that he holds to gold or silver, or possessions or inlaid furniture; with such portions as these the Lord will not deign to be his portion.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:81
verses.text: I, if I am the portion of the Lord, and the line of His heritage, receive no portion among the remaining tribes; but, like the Priest and the Levite, I live on the tithe, and serving the altar, am supported by its offerings.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:82
verses.text: Having food and raiment, I shall be content with these, and as a disciple of the Cross shall share its poverty.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:83
verses.text: I beseech you, therefore, and  Again and yet again admonish you;  do not look to your military experience for a standard of clerical obligation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:84
verses.text: Under Christ's banner seek for no worldly gain, lest having more than when you first became a clergyman, you hear men say, to your shame, "Their portion shall not profit them".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:85
verses.text: Welcome poor men and strangers to your homely board, that with them Christ may be your guest.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:86
verses.text: A clergyman who engages in business, and who rises from poverty to wealth, and from obscurity to a high position, avoid as you would the plague.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:87
verses.text: For "evil communications corrupt good manners".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:88
verses.text: You despise gold; he loves it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:89
verses.text: You spurn wealth; he eagerly pursues it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:90
verses.text: You love silence, meekness, privacy; he takes delight in talking and effrontery, in squares, and streets, and apothecaries' shops.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:91
verses.text: What unity of feeling can there be where there is so wide a divergency of manners?  A woman's foot should seldom, if ever, cross the threshold of your home.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:92
verses.text: To all who are Christ's virgins show the same regard or the same disregard.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:93
verses.text: Do not linger under the same roof with them, and do not rely on your past continence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:94
verses.text: You cannot be holier than David or wiser than Solomon.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:95
verses.text: Always bear in mind that it was a woman who expelled the tiller of paradise from his heritage.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:96
verses.text: In case you are sick one of the brethren may attend you; your sister also or your mother or some woman whose faith is approved with all.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:97
verses.text: But if you have no persons so connected with you or so marked out by chaste behaviour, the Church maintains many elderly women who by their ministrations may oblige you and benefit themselves so that even your sickness may bear fruit in the shape of almsdeeds.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:98
verses.text: I know of cases where the recovery of the body has but preluded the sickness of the soul.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:99
verses.text: There is danger for you in the service of one for whose face you constantly watch.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:100
verses.text: If in the course of your clerical duty you have to visit a widow or a virgin, never enter the house alone.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:101
verses.text: Let your companions be persons association with whom will not disgrace you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:102
verses.text: If you take a reader with you or an acolyte or a psalm-singer, let their character not their garb be their adornment; let them use no tongs to curl their hair; rather let their mien be an index of their chastity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:103
verses.text: You must not sit alone with a woman or see one without witnesses.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:104
verses.text: If she has anything confidential to disclose, she is sure to have some nurse or housekeeper, some virgin, some widow, some married woman.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:105
verses.text: She cannot be so friendless as to have none save you to whom she can venture to confide her secret.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:106
verses.text: Beware of all that gives occasion for suspicion; and, to avoid scandal, shun every act that may give colour to it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:107
verses.text: Frequent gifts of handkerchiefs and garters, of face-cloths and dishes first tasted by the giver—to say nothing of notes full of fond expressions—of such things as these a holy love knows nothing.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:108
verses.text: Such endearing and alluring expressions as 'my honey' and 'my darling,' 'you who are all my charm and my delight' the ridiculous courtesies of lovers and their foolish doings, we blush for on the stage and abhor in men of the world.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:109
verses.text: How much more do we loathe them in monks and clergymen who adorn the priesthood by their vows while their vows are adorned by the priesthood.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:110
verses.text: I speak thus not because I dread such evils for you or for men of saintly life, but because in all ranks and callings and among both men and women there are found both good and bad and in condemning the bad I commend the good.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:112
