verses.text: Shameful to say, idol-priests, play-actors, jockeys, and prostitutes can inherit property: clergymen and monks alone lie under a legal disability, a disability enacted not by persecutors but by Christian emperors.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:113
verses.text: I do not complain of the law, but I grieve that we have deserved a statute so harsh.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:114
verses.text: Cauterizing is a good thing, no doubt; but how is it that I have a wound which makes me need it? The law is strict and far-seeing, yet even so rapacity goes on unchecked.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:115
verses.text: By a fiction of trusteeship we set the statute at defiance; and, as if imperial decrees outweigh the mandates of Christ, we fear the laws and despise the Gospels.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:116
verses.text: If heir there must be, the mother has first claim upon her children, the Church upon her flock—the members of which she has borne and reared and nourished.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:117
verses.text: Why do we thrust ourselves in between mother and children?  It is the glory of a bishop to make provision for the wants of the poor; but it is the shame of all priests to amass private fortunes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:118
verses.text: I who was born (suppose) in a poor man's house, in a country cottage, and who could scarcely get of common millet and household bread enough to fill an empty stomach, am now come to disdain the finest wheat flour and honey.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:119
verses.text: I know the several kinds of fish by name.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:120
verses.text: I can tell unerringly on what coast a mussel has been picked.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:121
verses.text: I can distinguish by the flavour the province from which a bird comes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:122
verses.text: Dainty dishes delight me because their ingredients are scarce and I end by finding pleasure in their ruinous cost.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:123
verses.text: I hear also of servile attention shewn by some towards old men and women when these are childless.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:124
verses.text: They fetch the basin, beset the bed and perform with their own hands the most revolting offices.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:125
verses.text: They anxiously await the advent of the doctor and with trembling lips they ask whether the patient is better.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:126
verses.text: If for a little while the old fellow shews signs of returning vigour, they are in agonies.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:127
verses.text: They pretend to be delighted, but their covetous hearts undergo secret torture.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:128
verses.text: For they are afraid that their labours may go for nothing and compare an old man with a clinging to life to the patriarch Methuselah.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:129
verses.text: How great a reward might they have with God if their hearts were not set on a temporal prize! With what great exertions do they pursue an empty heritage! Less labour might have purchased for them the pearl of Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:131
verses.text: Read the divine scriptures constantly; never, indeed, let the sacred volume be out of your hand.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:132
verses.text: Learn what you have to teach.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:133
verses.text: "Hold fast the faithful word as you have been taught that you may be able by sound doctrine to exhort and convince the gainsayers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:134
verses.text: Continue thou in the things that thou hast learned and hast been assured of, knowing of whom thou hast learned them;" and "be ready always to give an answer to every man that asketh you a reason of the hope and faith that are in you".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:135
verses.text: Do not let your deeds belie your words; lest when you speak in church someone may mentally reply "Why do you not practise what you profess? Here is a lover of dainties turned censor! his stomach is full and he reads us a homily on fasting.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:136
verses.text: As well might a robber accuse others of covetousness".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:137
verses.text: In a priest of Christ mouth, mind, and hand should be at one.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:138
verses.text: Be obedient to your bishop and welcome him as the parent of your soul.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:139
verses.text: Sons love their fathers and slaves fear their masters.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:140
verses.text: "If I be a father," He says, "where is mine honour? And if I am a master where is my fear?" In your case the bishop combines in himself many titles to your respect.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:141
verses.text: He is at once a monk, a prelate, and an uncle who has before now instructed you in all holy things.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:142
verses.text: This also I say that the bishops should know themselves to be priests not lords.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:143
verses.text: Let them render to the clergy the honour which is their due that the clergy may offer to them the respect which belongs to bishops.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:144
verses.text: There is a witty saying of the orator Domitius which is here to the point: "Why am I to recognize you as leader of the Senate when you will not recognize my rights as a private member?" We should realize that a bishop and his presbyters are like Aaron and his sons.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:145
verses.text: As there is but one Lord and one Temple; so also should there be but one ministry.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:146
verses.text: Let us ever bear in mind the charge which the apostle Peter gives to priests: "feed the flock of God which is among you, taking the oversight thereof not by constraint but willingly as God would have you; not for filthy lucre but of a ready mind; neither as being lords over God's heritage but being ensamples to the flock," and that gladly; that "when the chief-shepherd shall appear ye may receive a crown of glory that fadeth not away".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:147
verses.text: It is a bad custom which prevails in certain churches for presbyters to be silent when bishops are present on the ground that they would be jealous or impatient hearers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:148
verses.text: "If anything," writes the apostle Paul, "be revealed to another that sitteth by, let the first hold his peace.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:149
verses.text: For ye may all prophesy one by one that all may learn and all may be comforted; and the spirits of the prophets are subject to the prophets.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:150
verses.text: For God is not the author of confusion but of peace".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:151
verses.text: "A wise son maketh a glad father;" and a bishop should rejoice in the discrimination which has led him to choose such for the priests of Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:153
verses.text: When teaching in church seek to call forth not plaudits but groans.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:154
verses.text: Let the tears of your hearers be your glory.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:155
verses.text: A presbyter's words ought to be seasoned by his reading of scripture.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:156
verses.text: Be not a declaimer or a ranter, one who gabbles without rhyme or reason; but shew yourself skilled in the deep things and versed in the mysteries of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:157
verses.text: To mouth your words and by your quickness of utterance astonish the unlettered crowd is a mark of ignorance.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:158
verses.text: Assurance often explains that of which it knows nothing; and when it has convinced others imposes on itself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:159
verses.text: My teacher, Gregory of Nazianzus, when I once asked him to explain Luke's phrase σάββατον δευτερόπρωτον , that is "the second-first Sabbath," playfully evaded my request saying: "I will tell you about it in church, and there, when all the people applaud me, you will be forced against your will to know what you do not know at all.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:160
verses.text: For, if you alone remain silent, every one will put you down for a fool".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:161
verses.text: There is nothing so easy as by sheer volubility to deceive a common crowd or an uneducated congregation: such most admire what they fail to understand.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:162
verses.text: Hear Marcus Tullius, the subject of that noble eulogy: "You would have been the first of orators but for Demosthenes: he would have been the only one but for you".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:163
verses.text: Hear what in his speech for Quintus Gallius he has to say about unskilled speakers and popular applause and then you will not be the sport of such illusions.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:164
verses.text: "What I am telling you," said he, "is a recent experience of my own.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:165
verses.text: One who has the name of a poet and a man of culture has written a book entitled Conversations of Poets and Philosophers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:166
verses.text: In this he represents Euripides as conversing with Menander and Socrates with Epicurus—men whose lives we know to be separated not by years but by centuries.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:167
verses.text: Nevertheless he calls forth limitless applause and endless acclamations.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:168
verses.text: For the theatre contains many who belong to the same school as he: like him they have never learned letters".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:170
verses.text: In dress avoid sombre colours as much as bright ones.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:171
verses.text: Showiness and slovenliness are alike to be shunned; for the one savours of vanity and the other of pride.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:172
verses.text: To go about without a linen scarf on is nothing: what is praiseworthy is to be without money to buy one.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:173
verses.text: It is disgraceful and absurd to boast of having neither napkin nor handkerchief and yet to carry a well-filled purse.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:174
verses.text: Some bestow a trifle on the poor to receive a larger sum themselves and under the cloak of almsgiving do but seek for riches.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:175
verses.text: Such are almshunters rather than almsgivers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:176
verses.text: Their methods are those by which birds, beasts, and fishes are taken.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:177
verses.text: A morsel of bait is put on the hook—to land a married lady's purse! The church is committed to the bishop; let him take heed whom he appoints to be his almoner.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:178
verses.text: It is better for me to have no money to give away than shamelessly to beg what I mean to hoard.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:179
verses.text: It is arrogance too to wish to seem more liberal than he who is Christ's bishop.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:180
verses.text: "All things are not open to us all".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:181
verses.text: In the church one is the eye, another is the tongue, another the hand, another the foot, others ears, belly, and so on.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:182
verses.text: Read Paul's epistle to the Corinthians and learn how the one body is made up of different members.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:183
verses.text: The rude and simple brother must not suppose himself a saint just because he knows nothing; and he who is educated and eloquent must not measure his saintliness merely by his fluency.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:184
verses.text: Of two imperfect things holy rusticity is better than sinful eloquence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:186
verses.text: Many build churches nowadays; their walls and pillars of glowing marble, their ceilings glittering with gold, their altars studded with jewels.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:187
verses.text: Yet to the choice of Christ's ministers no heed is paid.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:188
verses.text: And let no one allege against me the wealth of the temple in Judaea, its table, its lamps, its censers, its dishes, its cups, its spoons, and the rest of its golden vessels.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:189
verses.text: If these were approved by the Lord it was at a time when the priests had to offer victims and when the blood of sheep was the redemption of sins.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:190
verses.text: They were figures typifying things still future and were "written for our admonition upon whom the ends of the world are come".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:191
verses.text: But now our Lord by His poverty has consecrated the poverty of His house.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:192
verses.text: Let us, therefore, think of His cross and count riches to be but dirt.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:193
verses.text: Why do we admire what Christ calls "the mammon of unrighteousness"? Why do we cherish and love what it is Peter's boast not to possess? Or if we insist on keeping to the letter and find the mention of gold and wealth so pleasing, let us keep to everything else as well as the gold.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:194
verses.text: Let the bishops of Christ be bound to marry wives, who must be virgins.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:195
verses.text: Let the best-intentioned priest be deprived of his office if he bear a scar and be disfigured.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:196
verses.text: Let bodily leprosy be counted worse than spots upon the soul.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:197
verses.text: Let us be fruitful and multiply and replenish the earth, but let us slay no lamb and celebrate no mystic passover, for where there is no temple, the law forbids these acts.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:198
verses.text: Let us pitch tents in the seventh month and noise abroad a solemn fast with the sound of a horn.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:199
verses.text: But if we compare all these things as spiritual with things which are spiritual; and if we allow with Paul that "the Law is spiritual" and call to mind David's words: "open thou mine eyes that I may behold wondrous things out of thy law;" and if on these grounds we interpret it as our Lord interprets it—He has explained the Sabbath in this way: then, rejecting the superstitions of the Jews, we must also reject the gold; or, approving the gold, we must approve the Jews as well.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:200
verses.text: For we must either accept them with the gold or condemn them with it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:202
verses.text: Avoid entertaining men of the world, especially those whose honours make them swell with pride.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:203
verses.text: You are the priest of Christ—one poor and crucified who lived on the bread of strangers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:204
verses.text: It is a disgrace to you if the consul's lictors or soldiers keep watch before your door, and if the Judge of the province has a better dinner with you than in his own palace.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:205
verses.text: If you plead as an excuse your wish to intercede for the unhappy and the oppressed, I reply that a worldly judge will defer more to a clergyman who is self-denying than to one who is rich; he will pay more regard to your holiness than to your wealth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:206
verses.text: Or if he is a man who will not hear the clergy on behalf of the distressed except over the bowl, I will readily forego his aid and will appeal to Christ who can help more effectively and speedily than any judge.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:207
verses.text: Truly "it is better to trust in the Lord than to put confidence in man.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:208
verses.text: It is better to trust in the Lord than to put confidence in princes".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:209
verses.text: Let your breath never smell of wine lest the philosopher's words be said to you: "instead of offering me a kiss you are giving me a taste of wine".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:210
verses.text: Priests given to wine are both condemned by the apostle and forbidden by the old Law.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:211
verses.text: Those who serve the altar, we are told, must drink neither wine nor shechar.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:212
verses.text: Now every intoxicating drink is in Hebrew called shechar whether it is made of corn or of the juice of apples, whether you distil from the honeycomb a rude kind of mead or make a liquor by squeezing dates or strain a thick syrup from a decoction of corn.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:213
verses.text: Whatever intoxicates and disturbs the balance of the mind avoid as you would wine.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:214
verses.text: I do not say that we are to condemn what is a creature of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:215
verses.text: The Lord Himself was called a "wine-bibber" and wine in moderation was allowed to Timothy because of his weak stomach.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:216
verses.text: I only require that drinkers should observe that limit which their age, their health, or their constitution requires.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:217
verses.text: But if without drinking wine at all I am aglow with youth and am inflamed by the heat of my blood and am of a strong and lusty habit of body, I will readily forego the cup in which I cannot but suspect poison.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:218
verses.text: The Greeks have an excellent saying which will perhaps bear translation,  Fat bellies have no sentiments refined.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:220
verses.text: Lay upon yourself only as much fasting as you can bear, and let your fasts be pure, chaste, simple, moderate, and not superstitious.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:221
verses.text: What good is it to use no oil if you seek after the most troublesome and out-of-the-way kinds of food, dried figs, pepper, nuts, dates, fine flour, honey, pistachios? All the resources of gardening are strained to save us from eating household bread; and to pursue dainties we turn our backs on the kingdom of heaven.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:222
verses.text: There are some, I am told, who reverse the laws of nature and the race; for they neither eat bread nor drink water but imbibe thin decoctions of crushed herbs and beet-juice—not from a cup but from a shell.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:223
verses.text: Shame on us that we have no blushes for such follies and that we feel no disgust at such superstition! To crown all, in the midst of our dainties we seek a reputation for abstinence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:224
verses.text: The strictest fast is bread and water.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:225
verses.text: But because it brings with it no glory and because we all of us live on bread and water, it is reckoned no fast at all but an ordinary and common matter.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:227
verses.text: Do not angle for compliments, lest, while you win the popular applause, you do despite to God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:228
verses.text: "If I yet pleased men," says the apostle, "I should not be the servant of Christ".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:229
verses.text: He ceased to please men when he became Christ's servant.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:230
verses.text: Christ's soldier marches on through good report and evil report, the one on the right hand and the other on the left.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:231
verses.text: No praise elates him, no reproaches crush him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:232
verses.text: He is not puffed up by riches, nor does he shrink into himself because of poverty.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:233
verses.text: Joy and sorrow he alike despises.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:234
verses.text: The sun does not burn him by day nor the moon by night.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:235
verses.text: Do not pray at the corners of the streets, lest the applause of men interrupt the straight course of your prayers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:236
verses.text: Do not broaden your fringes and for show wear phylacteries, or, despite of conscience, wrap yourself in the self-seeking of the Pharisee.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:237
verses.text: Would you know what mode of apparel the Lord requires? Have prudence, justice, temperance, fortitude.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:238
verses.text: Let these be the four quarters of your horizon, let them be a four-horse team to bear you, Christ's charioteer, at full speed to your goal.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:239
verses.text: No necklace can be more precious than these; no gems can form a brighter galaxy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:240
verses.text: By them you are decorated, you are girt about, you are protected on every side.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:241
verses.text: They are your defence as well as your glory; for every gem is turned into a shield.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:243
verses.text: Beware also of a blabbing tongue and of itching ears.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:244
verses.text: Neither detract from others nor listen to detractors.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:245
verses.text: "Thou sittest," says the psalmist, "and speakest against thy brother; thou slanderest thine own mother's son.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:246
verses.text: These things hast thou done and I kept silence; thou thoughtest wickedly that I was such an one as thyself, but I will reprove thee and set them in order before thine eyes".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:247
verses.text: Keep your tongue from cavilling and watch over your words.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:248
verses.text: Know that in judging others you are passing sentence on yourself and that you are yourself guilty of the faults which you blame in them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:249
verses.text: It is no excuse to say: "if others tell me things I cannot be rude to them".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:250
verses.text: No one cares to speak to an unwilling listener.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:251
verses.text: An arrow never lodges in a stone: often it recoils upon the shooter of it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:252
verses.text: Let the detractor learn from your unwillingness to listen not to be so ready to detract.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:253
verses.text: Solomon says:—"meddle not with them that are given to detraction: for their calamity shall rise suddenly; and who knoweth the destruction of them both?"—of the detractor, that is, and of the person who lends an ear to his detraction.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:255
verses.text: It is your duty to visit the sick, to know the homes and children of ladies who are married, and to guard the secrets of noblemen.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:256
verses.text: Make it your object, therefore, to keep your tongue chaste as well as your eyes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:257
verses.text: Never discuss a woman's figure nor let one house know what is going on in another.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:258
verses.text: Hippocrates, before he will teach his pupils, makes them take an oath and compels them to swear fealty to him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:259
verses.text: He binds them over to silence, and prescribes for them their language, their gait, their dress, their manners.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:260
verses.text: How much more reason have we to whom the medicine of the soul has been committed to love the houses of all Christians as our own homes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:261
verses.text: Let them know us as comforters in sorrow rather than as guests in time of mirth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:262
verses.text: That clergyman soon becomes an object of contempt who being often asked out to dinner never refuses to go.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:264
verses.text: Let us never seek for presents and rarely accept them when we are asked to do so.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:265
verses.text: For "it is more blessed to give than to receive".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:266
verses.text: Somehow or other the very man who begs leave to offer you a gift holds you the cheaper for your acceptance of it; while, if you refuse it, it is wonderful how much more he will come to respect you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:267
verses.text: The preacher of continence must not be a maker of marriages.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:268
verses.text: Why does he who reads the apostle's words "it remaineth that they that have wives be as though they had none"—why does he press a virgin to marry? Why does a priest, who must be a monogamist, urge a widow to marry again? How can the clergy be managers and stewards of other men's households, when they are bidden to disregard even their own interests? To wrest a thing from a friend is theft but to cheat the Church is sacrilege.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:269
verses.text: When you have received money to be doled out to the poor, to be cautious or to hesitate while crowds are starving is to be worse than a robber; and to subtract a portion for yourself is to commit a crime of the deepest dye.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:270
verses.text: I am tortured with hunger and are you to judge what will satisfy my cravings? Either divide immediately what you have received, or, if you are a timid almoner, send the donor to distribute his own gifts.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:271
verses.text: Your purse ought not to remain full while I am in need.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:272
verses.text: No one can look after what is mine better than I can.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:273
verses.text: He is the best almoner who keeps nothing for himself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:275
verses.text: You have compelled me, my dear Nepotian, in spite of the castigation which my treatise on Virginity has had to endure—the one which I wrote for the saintly Eustochium at Rome:—you have compelled me after ten years have passed once more to open my mouth at Bethlehem and to expose myself to the stabs of every tongue.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:276
verses.text: For I could only escape from criticism by writing nothing—a course made impossible by your request; and I knew when I took up my pen that the shafts of all gainsayers would be launched against me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:277
verses.text: I beg such to hold their peace and to desist from gainsaying: for I have written to them not as to opponents but as to friends.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:278
verses.text: I have not inveighed against those who sin: I have but warned them to sin no more.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:279
verses.text: My judgment of myself has been as strict as my judgment of them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:280
verses.text: When I have wished to remove the mote from my neighbour's eye, I have first cast out the beam in my own.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:281
verses.text: I have calumniated no one.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:282
verses.text: Not a name has been hinted at.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:283
verses.text: My words have not been aimed at individuals and my criticism of shortcomings has been quite general.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 52:284
verses.text: If any one wishes to be angry with me he will have first to own that he himself suits my description.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:1
verses.text: Letter LIII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:2
verses.text: To Paulinus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:3
verses.text: Jerome urges Paulinus, bishop of Nola, (for whom see Letter LVIII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:4
verses.text: ) to make a diligent study of the Scriptures and to this end reminds him of the zeal for learning displayed not only by the wisest of the pagans but also by the apostle Paul.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:5
verses.text: Then going through the two Testaments in detail he describes the contents of the several books and the lessons which may be learned from them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:6
verses.text: He concludes with an appeal to Paulinus to divest himself wholly of his earthly wealth and to devote himself altogether to God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:7
verses.text: Written in 394 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:8
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:10
verses.text: Our brother Ambrose along with your little gifts has delivered to me a most charming letter which, though it comes at the beginning of our friendship, gives assurance of tried fidelity and of long continued attachment.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:11
verses.text: A true intimacy cemented by Christ Himself is not one which depends upon material considerations, or upon the presence of the persons, or upon an insincere and exaggerated flattery; but one such as ours, wrought by a common fear of God and a joint study of the divine scriptures.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:12
verses.text: We read in old tales that men traversed provinces, crossed seas, and visited strange peoples, simply to see face to face persons whom they only knew from books.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:13
verses.text: Thus Pythagoras visited the prophets of Memphis; and Plato, besides visiting Egypt and Archytas of Tarentum, most carefully explored that part of the coast of Italy which was formerly called Great Greece.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:14
verses.text: In this way the influential Athenian master with whose lessons the schools of the Academy resounded became at once a pilgrim and a pupil choosing modestly to learn what others had to teach rather than over confidently to propound views of his own.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:15
verses.text: Indeed his pursuit of learning—which seemed to fly before him all the world over—finally led to his capture by pirates who sold him into slavery to a cruel tyrant.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:16
verses.text: Thus he became a prisoner, a bond-man, and a slave; yet, as he was always a philosopher, he was greater still than the man who purchased him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:17
verses.text: Again we read that certain noblemen journeyed from the most remote parts of Spain and Gaul to visit Titus Livius, and listen to his eloquence which flowed like a fountain of milk.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:18
verses.text: Thus the fame of an individual had more power to draw men to Rome than the attractions of the city itself; and the age displayed an unheard of and noteworthy portent in the shape of men who, entering the great city, bestowed their attention not upon it but upon something else.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:19
verses.text: Apollonius too was a traveller—the one I mean who is called the sorcerer by ordinary people and the philosopher by such as follow Pythagoras.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:20
verses.text: He entered Persia, traversed the Caucasus and made his way through the Albanians, the Scythians, the Massagetae, and the richest districts of India.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:21
verses.text: At last, after crossing that wide river the Pison, he came to the Brahmans.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:22
verses.text: There he saw Hiarcas sitting upon his golden throne and drinking from his Tantalus-fountain, and heard him instructing a few disciples upon the nature, motions, and orbits of the heavenly bodies.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:23
verses.text: After this he travelled among the Elamites, the Babylonians, the Chaldeans, the Medes, the Assyrians, the Parthians, the Syrians, the Phenicians, the Arabians, and the Philistines.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:24
verses.text: Then returning to Alexandria he made his way to Ethiopia to see the gymnosophists and the famous table of the sun spread in the sands of the desert.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:25
verses.text: Everywhere he found something to learn, and as he was always going to new places, he became constantly wiser and better.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:26
verses.text: Philostratus has written the story of his life at length in eight books.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:28
verses.text: But why should I confine my allusions to the men of this world, when the Apostle Paul, the chosen vessel the doctor of the Gentiles, who could boldly say: "Do ye seek a proof of Christ speaking in me?" knowing that he really had within him that greatest of guests—when even he after visiting Damascus and Arabia "went up to Jerusalem to see Peter and abode with him fifteen days".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:29
verses.text: For he who was to be a preacher to the Gentiles had to be instructed in the mystical numbers seven and eight.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:30
verses.text: And again fourteen years after he took Barnabas and Titus and communicated his gospel to the apostles lest by any means he should have run or had run in vain.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:31
verses.text: Spoken words possess an indefinable hidden power, and teaching that passed directly from the mouth of the speaker into the ears of the disciples is more impressive than any other.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:32
verses.text: When the speech of Demosthenes against aeschines was recited before the latter during his exile at Rhodes, amid all the admiration and applause he sighed "if you could but have heard the brute deliver his own periods!"  3.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:33
verses.text: I do not adduce these instances because I have anything in me from which you either can or will learn a lesson, but to show you that your zeal and eagerness to learn—even though you cannot rely on help from me—are in themselves worthy of praise.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:34
verses.text: A mind willing to learn deserves commendation even when it has no teacher.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:35
verses.text: What is of importance to me is not what you find but what you seek to find.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:36
verses.text: Wax is soft and easy to mould even where the hands of craftsman and modeller are wanting to work it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:37
verses.text: It is already potentially all that it can be made.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:38
verses.text: The apostle Paul learned the Law of Moses and the prophets at the feet of Gamaliel and was glad that he had done so, for armed with this spiritual armour, he was able to say boldly "the weapons of our warfare are not carnal, but mighty through God to the pulling down of strongholds;" armed with these we war "casting down imaginations and every high thing that exalteth itself against the knowledge of God, and bringing into captivity every thought to the obedience of Christ; and being in a readiness to revenge all disobedience".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:39
verses.text: He writes to Timothy who had been trained in the holy writings from a child exhorting him to study them diligently and not to neglect the gift which was given him with the laying on of the hands of the presbytery.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:40
verses.text: To Titus he gives commandment that among a bishop's other virtues (which he briefly describes) he should be careful to seek a knowledge of the scriptures: A bishop, he says, must hold fast "the faithful word as he hath been taught that he may be able by sound doctrine both to exhort and to convince the gainsayers".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:41
verses.text: In fact want of education in a clergyman prevents him from doing good to any one but himself and much as the virtue of his life may build up Christ's church, he does it an injury as great by failing to resist those who are trying to pull it down.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:42
verses.text: The prophet Haggai says—or rather the Lord says it by the mouth of Haggai—"Ask now the priests concerning the law".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:43
verses.text: For such is the important function of the priesthood to give answers to those who question them concerning the law.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:44
verses.text: And in Deuteronomy we read "Ask thy father and he will shew thee; thy elders and they will tell thee".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:45
verses.text: Also in the one hundred and nineteenth psalm "thy statutes have been my songs in the house of my pilgrimage".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:46
verses.text: David too, in the description of the righteous man whom he compares to the tree of life in paradise, amongst his other excellences speaks of this, "His delight is in the law of the Lord; and in his law doth he meditate day and night".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:47
verses.text: In the close of his most solemn vision Daniel declares that "the righteous shall shine as the stars; and the wise, that is the learned, as the firmament".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:48
verses.text: You can see, therefore, how great is the difference between righteous ignorance and instructed righteousness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:49
verses.text: Those who have the first are compared with the stars, those who have the second with the heavens.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:50
verses.text: Yet, according to the exact sense of the Hebrew, both statements may be understood of the learned, for it is to be read in this way:—"They that be wise shall shine as the brightness of the firmament; and they that turn many to righteousness as the stars forever and ever".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:51
verses.text: Why is the apostle Paul called a chosen vessel? Assuredly because he is a repertory of the Law and of the holy scriptures.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:52
verses.text: The learned teaching of our Lord strikes the Pharisees dumb with amazement, and they are filled with astonishment to find that Peter and John know the Law although they have not learned letters.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:53
verses.text: For to these the Holy Ghost immediately suggested what comes to others by daily study and meditation; and, as it is written, they were "taught of God".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:54
verses.text: The Saviour had only accomplished his twelfth year when the scene in the temple took place; but when he interrogated the elders concerning the Law His wise questions conveyed rather than sought information.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:56
verses.text: But perhaps we ought to call Peter and John ignorant, both of whom could say of themselves, "though I be rude in speech, yet not in knowledge".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:57
verses.text: Was John a mere fisherman, rude and untaught? If so, whence did he get the words "In the beginning was the word, and the word was with God and the word was God".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:58
verses.text: Logos in Greek has many meanings.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:59
verses.text: It signifies word and reason and reckoning and the cause of individual things by which those which are subsist.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:60
verses.text: All of which things we rightly predicate of Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:61
verses.text: This truth Plato with all his learning did not know, of this Demosthenes with all his eloquence was ignorant.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:62
verses.text: "I will destroy," it is said, "the wisdom of the wise, and will bring to nothing the understanding of the prudent".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:63
verses.text: The true wisdom must destroy the false, and, although the foolishness of preaching is inseparable from the Cross, Paul speaks "wisdom among them that are perfect, yet not the wisdom of this world, nor of the princes of this world that come to nought," but he speaks "the wisdom of God in a mystery, even the hidden wisdom, which God ordained before the world".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:64
verses.text: God's wisdom is Christ, for Christ, we are told, is "the power of God and the wisdom of God".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:65
verses.text: He is the wisdom which is hidden in a mystery, of which also we read in the heading of the ninth psalm "for the hidden things of the son".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:66
verses.text: In Him are hidden all the treasures of wisdom and knowledge.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:67
verses.text: He also who was hidden in a mystery is the same that was foreordained before the world.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:68
verses.text: Now it was in the Law and in the Prophets that he was foreordained and prefigured.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:69
verses.text: For this reason too the prophets were called seers, because they saw Him whom others did not see.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:70
verses.text: Abraham saw His day and was glad.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:71
verses.text: The heavens which were sealed to a rebellious people were opened to Ezekiel.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:72
verses.text: "Open thou mine eyes," saith David, "that I may behold wonderful things out of thy Law".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:73
verses.text: For "the law is spiritual" and a revelation is needed to enable us to comprehend it and, when God uncovers His face, to behold His glory.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:75
verses.text: In the apocalypse a book is shewn sealed with seven seals, which if you deliver to one that is learned saying, Read this, he will answer you, I cannot, for it is sealed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:76
verses.text: How many there are to-day who fancy themselves learned, yet the scriptures are a sealed book to them, and one which they cannot open save through Him who has the key of David, "he that openeth and no man shutteth; and shutteth and no man openeth".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:77
verses.text: In the Acts of the Apostles the holy eunuch (or rather "man" for so the scripture calls him) when reading Isaiah he is asked by Philip "Understandest thou what thou readest?", makes answer:—"How can I except some man should guide me?" To digress for a moment to myself, I am neither holier nor more diligent than this eunuch, who came from Ethiopia, that is from the ends of the world, to the Temple leaving behind him a queen's palace, and was so great a lover of the Law and of divine knowledge that he read the holy scriptures even in his chariot.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:78
verses.text: Yet although he had the book in his hand and took into his mind the words of the Lord, nay even had them on his tongue and uttered them with his lips, he still knew not Him, whom—not knowing—he worshipped in the book.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:79
verses.text: Then Philip came and shewed him Jesus, who was concealed beneath the letter.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:80
verses.text: Wondrous excellence of the teacher! In the same hour the eunuch believed and was baptized; he became one of the faithful and a saint.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:81
verses.text: He was no longer a pupil but a master; and he found more in the church's font there in the wilderness than he had ever done in the gilded temple of the synagogue.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:83
verses.text: These instances have been just touched upon by me (the limits of a letter forbid a more discursive treatment of them) to convince you that in the holy scriptures you can make no progress unless you have a guide to shew you the way.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:84
verses.text: I say nothing of the knowledge of grammarians, rhetoricians, philosophers, geometers, logicians, musicians, astronomers, astrologers, physicians, whose several kinds of skill are most useful to mankind, and may be ranged under the three heads of teaching, method, and proficiency.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:85
verses.text: I will pass to the less important crafts which require manual dexterity more than mental ability.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:86
verses.text: Husbandmen, masons, carpenters, workers in wood and metal, wool-dressers and fullers, as well as those artisans who make furniture and cheap utensils, cannot attain the ends they seek without instruction from qualified persons.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:87
verses.text: As Horace says  Doctors alone profess the healing art  And none but joiners ever try to join.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:89
verses.text: The art of interpreting the scriptures is the only one of which all men everywhere claim to be masters.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:90
verses.text: To quote Horace again  Taught or untaught we all write poetry.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:91
verses.text: The chatty old woman, the doting old man, and the wordy sophist, one and all take in hand the Scriptures, rend them in pieces and teach them before they have learned them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:92
verses.text: Some with brows knit and bombastic words, balanced one against the other philosophize concerning the sacred writings among weak women.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:93
verses.text: Others—I blush to say it—learn of women what they are to teach men; and as if even this were not enough, they boldly explain to others what they themselves by no means understand.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:94
verses.text: I say nothing of persons who, like myself have been familiar with secular literature before they have come to the study of the holy scriptures.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:95
verses.text: Such men when they charm the popular ear by the finish of their style suppose every word they say to be a law of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:96
verses.text: They do not deign to notice what Prophets and apostles have intended but they adapt conflicting passages to suit their own meaning, as if it were a grand way of teaching—and not rather the faultiest of all—to misrepresent a writer's views and to force the scriptures reluctantly to do their will.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:97
verses.text: They forget that we have read centos from Homer and Virgil; but we never think of calling the Christless Maro a Christian because of his lines:—  Now comes the Virgin back and Saturn's reign,  Now from high heaven comes a Child newborn.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:98
verses.text: Another line might be addressed by the Father to the Son:—  Hail, only Son, my Might and Majesty.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:99
verses.text: And yet another might follow the Saviour's words on the cross:—  Such words he spake and there transfixed remained.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:100
verses.text: But all this is puerile, and resembles the sleight-of-hand of a mountebank.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:101
verses.text: It is idle to try to teach what you do not know, and—if I may speak with some warmth—is worse still to be ignorant of your ignorance.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:103
verses.text: Genesis, we shall be told, needs no explanation; its topics are too simple—the birth of the world, the origin of the human race, the division of the earth, the confusion of tongues, and the descent of the Hebrews into Egypt! Exodus, no doubt, is equally plain, containing as it does merely an account of the ten plagues, the decalogue, and sundry mysterious and divine precepts! The meaning of Leviticus is of course self-evident, although every sacrifice that it describes, nay more every word that it contains, the description of Aaron's vestments, and all the regulations connected with the Levites are symbols of things heavenly! The book of Numbers too—are not its very figures, and Balaam's prophecy, and the forty-two camping places in the wilderness so many mysteries? Deuteronomy also, that is the second law or the foreshadowing of the law of the gospel,—does it not, while exhibiting things known before, put old truths in a new light? So far the 'five words' of the Pentateuch, with which the apostle boasts his wish to speak in the Church.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:104
verses.text: Then, as for Job, that pattern of patience, what mysteries are there not contained in his discourses? Commencing in prose the book soon glides into verse and at the end once more reverts to prose.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:105
verses.text: By the way in which it lays down propositions, assumes postulates, adduces proofs, and draws inferences, it illustrates all the laws of logic.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:106
verses.text: Single words occurring in the book are full of meaning.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:107
verses.text: To say nothing of other topics, it prophesies the resurrection of men's bodies at once with more clearness and with more caution than any one has yet shewn.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:108
verses.text: "I know," Job says, "that my redeemer liveth, and that at the last day I shall rise again from the earth; and I shall be clothed again with my skin, and in my flesh shall I see God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:109
verses.text: Whom I shall see for myself, and mine eyes shall behold, and not another.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:110
verses.text: This my hope is stored up in my own bosom".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:111
verses.text: I will pass on to Jesus the son of Nave—a type of the Lord in name as well as in deed—who crossed over Jordan, subdued hostile kingdoms, divided the land among the conquering people and who, in every city, village, mountain, river, hill-torrent, and boundary which he dealt with, marked out the spiritual realms of the heavenly Jerusalem, that is, of the church.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:112
verses.text: In the book of Judges every one of the popular leaders is a type.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:113
verses.text: Ruth the Moabitess fulfils the prophecy of Isaiah:—"Send thou a lamb, O Lord, as ruler of the land from the rock of the wilderness to the mount of the daughter of Zion".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:114
verses.text: Under the figures of Eli's death and the slaying of Saul Samuel shews the abolition of the old law.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:115
verses.text: Again in Zadok and in David he bears witness to the mysteries of the new priesthood and of the new royalty.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:116
verses.text: The third and fourth books of Kings called in Hebrew Malâchim give the history of the kingdom of Judah from Solomon to Jeconiah, and of that of Israel from Jeroboam the son of Nebat to Hoshea who was carried away into Assyria.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:117
verses.text: If you merely regard the narrative, the words are simple enough, but if you look beneath the surface at the hidden meaning of it, you find a description of the small numbers of the church and of the wars which the heretics wage against it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:118
verses.text: The twelve prophets whose writings are compressed within the narrow limits of a single volume, have typical meanings far different from their literal ones.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:119
verses.text: Hosea speaks many times of Ephraim, of Samaria, of Joseph, of Jezreel, of a wife of whoredoms and of children of whoredoms, of an adulteress shut up within the chamber of her husband, sitting for a long time in widowhood and in the garb of mourning, awaiting the time when her husband will return to her.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:120
verses.text: Joel the son of Pethuel describes the land of the twelve tribes as spoiled and devastated by the palmerworm, the canker-worm, the locust, and the blight, and predicts that after the overthrow of the former people the Holy Spirit shall be poured out upon God's servants and handmaids; the same spirit, that is, which was to be poured out in the upper chamber at Zion upon the one hundred and twenty believers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:121
verses.text: These believers rising by gradual and regular gradations from one to fifteen form the steps to which there is a mystical allusion in the "psalms of degrees".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:122
verses.text: Amos, although he is only "an herdman" from the country, "a gatherer of sycomore fruit," cannot be explained in a few words.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:123
verses.text: For who can adequately speak of the three transgressions and the four of Damascus, of Gaza, of Tyre, of Idumaea, of Moab, of the children of Ammon, and in the seventh and eighth place of Judah and of Israel? He speaks to the fat kine that are in the mountain of Samaria, and bears witness that the great house and the little house shall fall.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:124
verses.text: He sees now the maker of the grasshopper, now the Lord, standing upon a wall daubed or made of adamant, now a basket of apples that brings doom to the transgressors, and now a famine upon the earth "not a famine of bread, nor a thirst for water, but of hearing the words of the Lord".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:125
verses.text: Obadiah, whose name means the servant of God, thunders against Edom red with blood and against the creature born of earth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:126
verses.text: He smites him with the spear of the spirit because of his continual rivalry with his brother Jacob.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:127
verses.text: Jonah, fairest of doves, whose shipwreck shews in a figure the passion of the Lord, recalls the world to penitence, and while he preaches to Nineveh, announces salvation to all the heathen.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:128
verses.text: Micah the Morasthite a joint heir with Christ announces the spoiling of the daughter of the robber and lays siege against her, because she has smitten the jawbone of the judge of Israel.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:129
verses.text: Nahum, the consoler of the world, rebukes "the bloody city" and when it is overthrown cries:—"Behold upon the mountains the feet of him that bringeth good tidings".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:130
verses.text: Habakkuk, like a strong and unyielding wrestler, stands upon his watch and sets his foot upon the tower that he may contemplate Christ upon the cross and say "His glory covered the heavens and the earth was full of his praise.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:131
verses.text: And his brightness was as the light; he had horns coming out of his hand: and there was the hiding of his power".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:132
verses.text: Zephaniah, that is the bodyguard and knower of the secrets of the Lord, hears "a cry from the fishgate, and an howling from the second, and a great crashing from the hills".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:133
verses.text: He proclaims "howling to the inhabitants of the mortar; for all the people of Canaan are undone; all they that were laden with silver are cut off".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:134
verses.text: Haggai, that is he who is glad or joyful, who has sown in tears to reap in joy, is occupied with the rebuilding of the temple.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:135
verses.text: He represents the Lord (the Father, that is) as saying "Yet once, it is a little while, and I will shake the heavens, and the earth, and the sea, and the dry land; and I will shake all nations and he who is desired of all nations shall come".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:136
verses.text: Zechariah, he that is mindful of his Lord, gives us many prophecies.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:137
verses.text: He sees Jesus, "clothed with filthy garments," a stone with seven eyes, a candle-stick all of gold with lamps as many as the eyes, and two olive trees on the right side of the bowl and on the left.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:138
verses.text: After he has described the horses, red, black, white, and grisled, and the cutting off of the chariot from Ephraim and of the horse from Jerusalem he goes on to prophesy and predict a king who shall be a poor man and who shall sit "upon a colt the foal of an ass".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:139
verses.text: Malachi, the last of all the prophets, speaks openly of the rejection of Israel and the calling of the nations.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:140
verses.text: "I have no pleasure in you, saith the Lord of hosts, neither will I accept an offering at your hand.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:141
verses.text: For from the rising of the sun even unto the going down of the same, my name is great among the Gentiles: and in every place incense is offered unto my name, and a pure offering".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:142
verses.text: As for Isaiah, Jeremiah, Ezekiel, and Daniel, who can fully understand or adequately explain them? The first of them seems to compose not a prophecy but a gospel.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:143
verses.text: The second speaks of a rod of an almond tree and of a seething pot with its face toward the north, and of a leopard which has changed its spots.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:144
verses.text: He also goes four times through the alphabet in different metres.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:145
verses.text: The beginning and ending of Ezekiel, the third of the four, are involved in so great obscurity that like the commencement of Genesis they are not studied by the Hebrews until they are thirty years old.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:146
verses.text: Daniel, the fourth and last of the four prophets, having knowledge of the times and being interested in the whole world, in clear language proclaims the stone cut out of the mountain without hands that overthrows all kingdoms.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:147
verses.text: David, who is our Simonides, Pindar, and Alcaeus, our Horace, our Catullus, and our Serenus all in one, sings of Christ to his lyre; and on a psaltery with ten strings calls him from the lower world to rise again.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:148
verses.text: Solomon, a lover of peace and of the Lord, corrects morals, teaches nature, unites Christ and the church, and sings a sweet marriage song to celebrate that holy bridal.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:149
verses.text: Esther, a type of the church, frees her people from danger and, after having slain Haman whose name means iniquity, hands down to posterity a memorable day and a great feast.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:150
verses.text: The book of things omitted or epitome of the old dispensation is of such importance and value that without it any one who should claim to himself a knowledge of the scriptures would make himself a laughing stock in his own eyes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:151
verses.text: Every name used in it, nay even the conjunction of the words, serves to throw light on narratives passed over in the books of Kings and upon questions suggested by the gospel.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:152
verses.text: Ezra and Nehemiah, that is the Lord's helper and His consoler, are united in a single book.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:153
verses.text: They restore the Temple and build up the walls of the city.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:154
verses.text: In their pages we see the throng of the Israelites returning to their native land, we read of priests and Levites, of Israel proper and of proselytes; and we are even told the several families to which the task of building the walls and towers was assigned.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:155
verses.text: These references convey one meaning upon the surface, but another below it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:157
verses.text: [In Migne, 8.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:158
verses.text: ] You see how, carried away by my love of the scriptures, I have exceeded the limits of a letter yet have not fully accomplished my object.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:159
verses.text: We have heard only what it is that we ought to know and to desire, so that we too may be able to say with the psalmist:—"My soul breaketh out for the very fervent desire that it hath alway unto thy judgments".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:160
verses.text: But the saying of Socrates about himself—"this only I know that I know nothing"—is fulfilled in our case also.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:161
verses.text: The New Testament I will briefly deal with.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:162
verses.text: Matthew, Mark, Luke and John are the Lord's team of four, the true cherubim or store of knowledge.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:163
verses.text: With them the whole body is full of eyes, they glitter as sparks, they run and return like lightning, their feet are straight feet, and lifted up, their backs also are winged, ready to fly in all directions.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:164
verses.text: They hold together each by each and are interwoven one with another: like wheels within wheels they roll along and go whithersoever the breath of the Holy Spirit wafts them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:165
verses.text: The apostle Paul writes to seven churches (for the eighth epistle—that to the Hebrews—is not generally counted in with the others).

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:166
verses.text: He instructs Timothy and Titus; he intercedes with Philemon for his runaway slave.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:167
verses.text: Of him I think it better to say nothing than to write inadequately.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:168
verses.text: The Acts of the Apostles seem to relate a mere unvarnished narrative descriptive of the infancy of the newly born church; but when once we realize that their author is Luke the physician whose praise is in the gospel, we shall see that all his words are medicine for the sick soul.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:169
verses.text: The apostles James, Peter, John, and Jude, have published seven epistles at once spiritual and to the point, short and long, short that is in words but lengthy in substance so that there are few indeed who do not find themselves in the dark when they read them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:170
verses.text: The apocalypse of John has as many mysteries as words.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:171
verses.text: In saying this I have said less than the book deserves.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:172
verses.text: All praise of it is inadequate; manifold meanings lie hid in its every word.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:174
verses.text: [In Migne, 9.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:175
verses.text: ] I beg of you, my dear brother, to live among these books, to meditate upon them, to know nothing else, to seek nothing else.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:176
verses.text: Does not such a life seem to you a foretaste of heaven here on earth? Let not the simplicity of the scripture or the poorness of its vocabulary offend you; for these are due either to the faults of translators or else to deliberate purpose: for in this way it is better fitted for the instruction of an unlettered congregation as the educated person can take one meaning and the uneducated another from one and the same sentence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:177
verses.text: I am not so dull or so forward as to profess that I myself know it, or that I can pluck upon the earth the fruit which has its root in heaven, but I confess that I should like to do so.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:178
verses.text: I put myself before the man who sits idle and, while I lay no claim to be a master, I readily pledge myself to be a fellow-student.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:179
verses.text: "Every one that asketh receiveth; and he that seeketh findeth; and to him that knocketh it shall be opened".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:180
verses.text: Let us learn upon earth that knowledge which will continue with us in heaven.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:182
verses.text: [In Migne, 10.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:183
verses.text: ] I will receive you with open hands and—if I may boast and speak foolishly like Hermagoras—I will strive to learn with you whatever you desire to study.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:184
verses.text: Eusebius who is here regards you with the affection of a brother; he has made your letter twice as precious by telling me of your sincerity of character, your contempt for the world, your constancy in friendship, and your love to Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:185
verses.text: The letter bears on its face (without any aid from him) your prudence and the charm of your style.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:186
verses.text: Make haste then, I beseech you, and cut instead of loosing the hawser which prevents your vessel from moving in the sea.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:187
verses.text: The man who sells his goods because he despises them and means to renounce the world can have no desire to sell them dear.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:188
verses.text: Count as money gained the sum that you must expend upon your outfit.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:189
verses.text: There is an old saying that a miser lacks as much what he has as what he has not.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:190
verses.text: The believer has a whole world of wealth; the unbeliever has not a single farthing.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:191
verses.text: Let us always live "as having nothing and yet possessing all things".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:192
verses.text: Food and raiment, these are the Christian's wealth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:193
verses.text: If your property is in your own power, sell it: if not, cast it from you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:194
verses.text: "If any man…will take away thy coat, let him have thy cloke also".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:195
verses.text: You are all for delay, you wish to defer action: unless—so you argue—unless I sell my goods piecemeal and with caution, Christ will be at a loss to feed his poor.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:196
verses.text: Nay, he who has offered himself to God, has given Him everything once for all.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:197
verses.text: The apostles did but forsake ships and nets.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:198
verses.text: The widow cast but two brass coins into the treasury and yet she shall be preferred before Croesus with all his wealth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 53:199
verses.text: He readily despises all things who reflects always that he must die.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:1
verses.text: Letter LIV.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:2
verses.text: To Furia.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:3
verses.text: A letter of guidance to a widow on the best means of preserving her widowhood (according to Jerome 'the second of the three degrees of chastity').

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:4
verses.text: Furia had at one time thought of marrying again but eventually abandoned her intention and devoted herself to the care of her young children and her aged father.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:5
verses.text: Jerome draws a vivid picture of the dangers to which she is exposed at Rome, lays down rules of conduct for her guidance, and commends her to the care of the presbyter Exuperius (afterwards bishop of Toulouse).

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:6
verses.text: The date of the letter is 394 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:7
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:9
verses.text: You beg and implore me in your letter to write to you—or rather write back to you—what mode of life you ought to adopt to preserve the crown of widowhood and to keep your reputation for chastity unsullied.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:10
verses.text: My mind rejoices, my reins exult, and my heart is glad that you desire to be after marriage what your mother Titiana of holy memory was for a long time in marriage.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:11
verses.text: Her prayers and supplications are heard.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:12
verses.text: She has succeeded in winning afresh in her only daughter that which she herself when living possessed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:13
verses.text: It is a high privilege of your family that from the time of Camillus few or none of your house are described as contracting second marriages.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:14
verses.text: Therefore it will not redound so much to your praise if you continue a widow as to your shame if being a Christian you fail to keep what heathen women have jealously guarded for so many centuries.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:16
verses.text: I say nothing of Paula and Eustochium, the fairest flowers of your stock; for, as my object is to exhort you, I do not wish it to appear that I am praising them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:17
verses.text: Blaesilla too I pass over who following her husband—your brother—to the grave, fulfilled in a short time of life a long time of virtue.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:18
verses.text: Would that men would imitate the laudable examples of women, and that wrinkled old age would pay at last what youth gladly offers at first! In saying this I am putting my hand into the fire deliberately and with my eyes open.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:19
verses.text: Men will knit their brows and shake their clenched fists at me;  In swelling tones will angry Chremes rave.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:20
verses.text: The leaders will rise as one man against my epistle; the mob of patricians will thunder at me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:21
verses.text: They will cry out that I am a sorcerer and a seducer; and that I should be transported to the ends of the earth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:22
verses.text: They may add, if they will, the title of Samaritan; for in it I shall but recognize a name given to my Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:23
verses.text: But one thing is certain.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:24
verses.text: I do not sever the daughter from the mother, I do not use the words of the gospel: "let the dead bury their dead".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:25
verses.text: For whosoever believes in Christ is alive; and he who believes in Him "ought himself also so to walk even as He walked".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:27
verses.text: A truce to the calumnies which the malice of backbiters continually fastens upon all who call themselves Christians to keep them through fear of shame from aspiring to virtue.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:28
verses.text: Except by letter we have no knowledge of each other; and where there is no knowledge after the flesh, there can be no motive for intercourse save a religious one.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:29
verses.text: "Honour thy father," the commandment says, but only if he does not separate you from your true Father.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:30
verses.text: Recognize the tie of blood but only so long as your parent recognizes his Creator.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:31
verses.text: Should he fail to do so, David will sing to you: "hearken, O daughter, and consider, and incline thine ear; forget also thine own people and thy father's house.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:32
verses.text: So shall the king greatly desire thy beauty, for he is thy Lord".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:33
verses.text: Great is the prize offered for the forgetting of a parent, "the king shall desire thy beauty".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:34
verses.text: You have heard, you have considered, you have inclined your ear, you have forgotten your people and your father's house; therefore the king shall desire your beauty and shall say to you:—"thou art all fair, my love; there is no spot in thee".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:35
verses.text: What can be fairer than a soul which is called the daughter of God, and which seeks for herself no outward adorning.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:36
verses.text: She believes in Christ, and, dowered with this hope of greatness makes her way to her spouse; for Christ is at once her bridegroom and her Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:38
verses.text: What troubles matrimony involves you have learned in the marriage state itself; you have been surfeited with quails' flesh even to loathing; your mouth has been filled with the gall of bitterness; you have expelled the indigestible and unwholesome food; you have relieved a heaving stomach.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:39
verses.text: Why will you again swallow what has disagreed with you? "The dog is turned to his own vomit again and the sow that was washed to her wallowing in the mire".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:40
verses.text: Even brute beasts and flying birds do not fall into the same snares twice.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:41
verses.text: Do you fear extinction for the line of Camillus if you do not present your father with some little fellow to crawl upon his breast and slobber his neck? As if all who marry have children! and as if when they do come, they always resemble their forefathers! Did Cicero's son exhibit his father's eloquence? Had your own Cornelia, pattern at once of chastity and of fruitfulness, cause to rejoice that she was mother of her Gracchi? It is ridiculous to expect as certain the offspring which many, as you can see, have not got, while others who have had it have lost it again.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:42
verses.text: To whom then are you to leave your great riches? To Christ who cannot die.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:43
verses.text: Whom shall you make your heir? The same who is already your Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:44
verses.text: Your father will be sorry but Christ will be glad; your family will grieve but the angels will rejoice with you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:45
verses.text: Let your father do what he likes with what is his own.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:46
verses.text: You are not his to whom you have been born, but His to whom you have been born again, and who has purchased you at a great price with His own blood.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:48
verses.text: Beware of nurses and waiting maids and similar venomous creatures who try to satisfy their greed by sucking your blood.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:49
verses.text: They advise you to do not what is best for you but what is best for them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:50
verses.text: They are for ever dinning into your ears Virgil's lines:—  Will you waste all your youth in lonely grief  And children sweet, the gifts of love, forswear?  Wherever there is holy chastity, there is also frugal living; and wherever there is frugal living, servants lose by it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:51
verses.text: What they do not get is in their minds so much taken from them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:52
verses.text: The actual sum received is what they look to, and not its relative amount.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:53
verses.text: The moment they see a Christian they at once repeat the hackneyed saying:—"The Greek! The impostor!" They spread the most scandalous reports and, when any such emanates from themselves, they pretend that they have heard it from others, managing thus at once to originate the story and to exaggerate it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:54
verses.text: A lying rumour goes forth; and this, when it has reached the married ladies and has been fanned by their tongues, spreads through the provinces.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:55
verses.text: You may see numbers of these—their faces painted, their eyes like those of vipers, their teeth rubbed with pumice-stone—raving and carping at Christians with insane fury.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:56
verses.text: One of these ladies,  A violet mantle round her shoulders thrown,  Drawls out some mawkish stuff, speaks through her nose,  And minces half her words with tripping tongue.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:57
verses.text: Hereupon the rest chime in and every bench expresses hoarse approval.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:58
verses.text: They are backed up by men of my own order who, finding themselves assailed, assail others.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:59
verses.text: Always fluent in attacking me, they are dumb in their own defence; just as though they were not monks themselves, and as though every word said against monks did not tell also against their spiritual progenitors the clergy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:60
verses.text: Harm done to the flock brings discredit on the shepherd.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:61
verses.text: On the other hand we cannot but praise the life of a monk who holds up to veneration the priests of Christ and refuses to detract from that order to which he owes it that he is a Christian.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:63
verses.text: I have spoken thus, my daughter in Christ, not because I doubt that you will be faithful to your vows, (you would never have asked for a letter of advice had you been uncertain as to the blessedness of monogamy): but that you may realize the wickedness of servants who merely wish to sell you for their own advantage, the snares which relations may set for you and the well meant but mistaken suggestions of a father.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:64
verses.text: While I allow that this latter feels love toward you, I cannot admit that it is love according to knowledge.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:65
verses.text: I must say with the apostle: "I bear them record that they have a zeal of God, but not according to knowledge".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:66
verses.text: Imitate rather—I cannot say it too often—your holy mother whose zeal for Christ comes into my mind as often as I remember her, and not her zeal only but the paleness induced in her by fasting, the alms given by her to the poor, the courtesy shewn by her to the servants of God, the lowliness of her garb and heart, and the constant moderation of her language.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:67
verses.text: Of your father too I speak with respect, not because he is a patrician and of consular rank but because he is a Christian.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:68
verses.text: Let him be true to his profession as such.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:69
verses.text: Let him rejoice that he has begotten a daughter for Christ and not for the world.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:70
verses.text: Nay rather let him grieve that you have in vain lost your virginity as the fruits of matrimony have not been yours.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:71
verses.text: Where is the husband whom he gave to you? Even had he been lovable and good, death would still have snatched all away, and his decease would have terminated the fleshly bond between you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:72
verses.text: Seize the opportunity, I beg of you, and make a virtue of necessity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:73
verses.text: In the lives of Christians we look not to the beginnings but to the endings.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:74
verses.text: Paul began badly but ended well.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:75
verses.text: The start of Judas wins praise; his end is condemned because of his treachery.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:76
verses.text: Read Ezekiel, "The righteousness of the righteous shall not deliver him in the day of his transgression; as for the wickedness of the wicked he shall not fall thereby in the day that he turneth from his wickedness".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:77
