verses.text: The Christian life is the true Jacob's ladder on which the angels ascend and descend, while the Lord stands above it holding out His hand to those who slip and sustaining by the vision of Himself the weary steps of those who ascend.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:78
verses.text: But while He does not wish the death of a sinner, but only that he should be converted and live, He hates the lukewarm and they quickly cause him loathing.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:79
verses.text: To whom much is forgiven, the same loveth much.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:81
verses.text: In the gospel a harlot wins salvation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:82
verses.text: How? She is baptized in her tears and wipes the Lord's feet with that same hair with which she had before deceived many.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:83
verses.text: She does not wear a waving headdress or creaking boots, she does not darken her eyes with antimony.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:84
verses.text: Yet in her squalor she is lovelier than ever.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:85
verses.text: What place have rouge and white lead on the face of a Christian woman? The one simulates the natural red of the cheeks and of the lips; the other the whiteness of the face and of the neck.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:86
verses.text: They serve only to inflame young men's passions, to stimulate lust, and to indicate an unchaste mind.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:87
verses.text: How can a woman weep for her sins whose tears lay bare her true complexion and mark furrows on her cheeks? Such adorning is not of the Lord; a mask of this kind belongs to Antichrist.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:88
verses.text: With what confidence can a woman raise features to heaven which her Creator must fail to recognize? It is idle to allege in excuse for such practices girlishness and youthful vanity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:89
verses.text: A widow who has ceased to have a husband to please, and who in the apostle's language is a widow indeed, needs nothing more but perseverance only.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:90
verses.text: She is mindful of past enjoyments, she knows what gave her pleasure and what she has now lost.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:91
verses.text: By rigid fast and vigil she must quench the fiery darts of the devil.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:92
verses.text: If we are widows, we must either speak as we are dressed, or else dress as we speak.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:93
verses.text: Why do we profess one thing, and practise another? The tongue talks of chastity, but the rest of the body reveals incontinence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:95
verses.text: So much for dress and adornment.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:96
verses.text: But a widow "that liveth in pleasure"—the words are not mine but those of the apostle—"is dead while she liveth".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:97
verses.text: What does that mean—"is dead while she liveth"? To those who know no better she seems to be alive and not, as she is, dead in sin; yes, and in another sense dead to Christ, from whom no secrets are hid.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:98
verses.text: "The soul that sinneth it shall die".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:99
verses.text: "Some men's sins are open…going before to judgment: and some they follow after.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:100
verses.text: Likewise also good works are manifest, and they that are otherwise cannot be hid.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:101
verses.text: The words mean this:—Certain persons sin so deliberately and flagrantly that you no sooner see them than you know them at once to be sinners.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:102
verses.text: But the defects of others are so cunningly concealed that we only learn them from subsequent information.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:103
verses.text: Similarly the good deeds of some people are public property, while those of others we come to know only through long intimacy with them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:104
verses.text: Why then must we needs boast of our chastity, a thing which cannot prove itself to be genuine without its companions and attendants, continence and plain living? The apostle macerates his body and brings it into subjection to the soul lest what he has preached to others he should himself fail to keep; and can a mere girl whose passions are kindled by abundance of food, can a mere girl afford to be confident of her own chastity?  9.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:105
verses.text: In saying this, I do not of course condemn food which God created to be enjoyed with thanksgiving, but I seek to remove from youths and girls what are incentives to sensual pleasure.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:106
verses.text: Neither the fiery Etna nor the country of Vulcan, nor Vesuvius, nor Olympus, burns with such violent heat as the youthful marrow of those who are flushed with wine and filled with food.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:107
verses.text: Many trample covetousness under foot, and lay it down as readily as they lay down their purse.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:108
verses.text: An enforced silence serves to make amends for a railing tongue.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:109
verses.text: The outward appearance and the mode of dress can be changed in a single hour.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:110
verses.text: All other sins are external, and what is external can easily be cast away.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:111
verses.text: Desire alone, implanted in men by God to lead them to procreate children, is internal; and this, if it once oversteps its own bounds, becomes a sin, and by a law of nature cries out for sexual intercourse.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:112
verses.text: It is therefore a work of great merit, and one which requires unremitting diligence to overcome that which is innate in you; while living in the flesh not to live after the flesh; to strive with yourself day by day and to watch the foe shut up within you with the hundred eyes of the fabled Argus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:113
verses.text: This is what the apostle says in other words: "Every sin that a man doeth is without the body; but he that committeth fornication sinneth against his own body".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:114
verses.text: Physicians and others who have written on the nature of the human body, and particularly Galen in his books entitled On matters of health, say that the bodies of boys and of young men and of full grown men and women glow with an interior heat and consequently that for persons of these ages all food is injurious which tends to promote this heat: while on the other hand it is highly conducive to health in eating and in drinking to take things cold and cooling.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:115
verses.text: Contrariwise they tell us that warm food and old wine are good for the old who suffer from humours and from chilliness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:116
verses.text: Hence it is that the Saviour says "Take heed to yourselves lest at any time your hearts be overcharged with surfeiting and drunkenness, and cares of this life".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:117
verses.text: So too speaks the apostle: "Be not drunk with wine, wherein is excess".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:118
verses.text: No wonder that the potter spoke thus of the vessel which He had made when even the comic poet whose only object is to know and to describe the ways of men tells us that  Where Ceres fails and Liber, Venus droops.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:120
verses.text: In the first place then, till you have passed the years of early womanhood, take only water to drink, for this is by nature of all drinks the most cooling.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:121
verses.text: This, if your stomach is strong enough to bear it; but if your digestion is weak, hear what the apostle says to Timothy: "use a little wine for thy stomach's sake and thine often infirmities".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:122
verses.text: Then as regards your food you must avoid all heating dishes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:123
verses.text: I do not speak of flesh dishes only (although of these the chosen vessel declares his mind thus: "it is good neither to eat flesh nor to drink wine") but of vegetables as well.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:124
verses.text: Everything provocative or indigestible is to be refused.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:125
verses.text: Be assured that nothing is so good for young Christians as the eating of herbs.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:126
verses.text: Accordingly in another place he says: "another who is weak eateth herbs".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:127
verses.text: Thus the heat of the body must be tempered with cold food.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:128
verses.text: Daniel and the three children lived on pulse.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:129
verses.text: They were still boys and had not come yet to that frying-pan on which the King of Babylon fried the elders who were judges.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:130
verses.text: Moreover, by an express privilege of God's own giving their bodily condition was improved by their regimen.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:131
verses.text: We do not expect that it will be so with us, but we look for increased vigour of soul which becomes stronger as the flesh grows weaker.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:132
verses.text: Some persons who aspire to the life of chastity fall midway in their journey from supposing that they need only abstain from flesh.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:133
verses.text: They load their stomachs with vegetables which are only harmless when taken sparingly and in moderation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:134
verses.text: If I am to say what I think, there is nothing which so much heats the body and inflames the passions as undigested food and breathing broken with hiccoughs.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:135
verses.text: As for you, my daughter, I would rather wound your modesty than endanger my case by understatement.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:136
verses.text: Regard everything as poison which bears within it the seeds of sensual pleasure.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:137
verses.text: A meagre diet which leaves the appetite always unsatisfied is to be preferred to fasts three days long.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:138
verses.text: It is much better to take a little every day than some days to abstain wholly and on others to surfeit oneself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:139
verses.text: That rain is best which falls slowly to the ground.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:140
verses.text: Showers that come down suddenly and with violence wash away the soil.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:142
verses.text: When you eat your meals, reflect that you must immediately afterwards pray and read.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:143
verses.text: Have a fixed number of lines of holy scripture, and render it as your task to your Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:144
verses.text: On no account resign yourself to sleep until you have filled the basket of your breast with a woof of this weaving.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:145
verses.text: After the holy scriptures you should read the writings of learned men; of those at any rate whose faith is well known.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:146
verses.text: You need not go into the mire to seek for gold; you have many pearls, buy the one pearl with these.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:147
verses.text: Stand, as Jeremiah says, in more ways than one that so you may come on the true way that leads to the Father.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:148
verses.text: Exchange your love of necklaces and of gems and of silk dresses for earnestness in studying the scriptures.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:149
verses.text: Enter the land of promise that flows with milk and honey.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:150
verses.text: Eat fine flour and oil.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:151
verses.text: Let your clothing be, like Joseph's, of many colors.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:152
verses.text: Let your ears like those of Jerusalem be pierced by the word of God that the precious grains of new corn may hang from them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:153
verses.text: In that reverend man Exuperius you have a man of tried years and faith ready to give you constant support with his advice.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:155
verses.text: Make to yourself friends of the mammon of unrighteousness that they may receive you into everlasting habitations.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:156
verses.text: Give your riches not to those who feed on pheasants but to those who have none but common bread to eat, such as stays hunger while it does not stimulate lust.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:157
verses.text: Consider the poor and needy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:158
verses.text: Give to everyone that asks of you, but especially unto them who are of the household of faith.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:159
verses.text: Clothe the naked, feed the hungry, visit the sick.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:160
verses.text: Every time that you hold out your hand, think of Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:161
verses.text: See to it that you do not, when the Lord your God asks an alms of you, increase riches which are none of His.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:163
verses.text: Avoid the company of young men.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:164
verses.text: Let long baited youths dandified and wanton never be seen under your roof.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:165
verses.text: Repel a singer as you would some bane.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:166
verses.text: Hurry from your house women who live by playing and singing, the devil's choir whose songs are the fatal ones of sirens.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:167
verses.text: Do not arrogate to yourself a widow's license and appear in public preceded by a host of eunuchs.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:168
verses.text: It is a most mischievous thing for those who are weak owing to their sex and youth to misuse their own discretion and to suppose that things are lawful because they are pleasant.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:169
verses.text: "All things are lawful, but all things are not expedient".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:170
verses.text: No frizzled steward nor shapely foster brother nor fair and ruddy footman must dangle at your heels.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:171
verses.text: Sometimes the tone of the mistress is inferred from the dress of the maid.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:172
verses.text: Seek the society of holy virgins and widows; and, if need arises for holding converse with men, do not shun having witnesses, and let your conversation be marked with such confidence that the entry of a third person shall neither startle you nor make you blush.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:173
verses.text: The face is the mirror of the mind and a woman's eyes without a word betray the secrets of her heart.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:174
verses.text: I have lately seen a most miserable scandal traverse the entire East.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:175
verses.text: The lady's age and style, her dress and mien, the indiscriminate company she kept, her dainty table and her regal appointments bespoke her the bride of a Nero or of a Sardanapallus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:176
verses.text: The scars of others should teach us caution.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:177
verses.text: 'When he that causeth trouble is scourged the fool will be wiser.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:178
verses.text: ' A holy love knows no impatience.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:179
verses.text: A false rumor is quickly crushed and the after life passes judgment on that which has gone before.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:180
verses.text: It is not indeed possible that any one should come to the end of life's race without suffering from calumny; the wicked find it a consolation to carp at the good, supposing the guilt of sin to be less, in proportion as the number of those who commit it is greater.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:181
verses.text: Still a fire of straw quickly dies out and a spreading flame soon expires if fuel to it be wanting.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:182
verses.text: Whether the report which prevailed a year ago was true or false, when once the sin ceases, the scandal also will cease.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:183
verses.text: I do not say this because I fear anything wrong in your case but because, owing to my deep affection for you, there is no safety that I do not fear.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:184
verses.text: Oh! that you could see your sister and that it might be yours to hear the eloquence of her holy lips and to behold the mighty spirit which animates her diminutive frame.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:185
verses.text: You might hear the whole contents of the old and new testaments come bubbling up out of her heart.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:186
verses.text: Fasting is her sport, and prayer she makes her pastime.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:187
verses.text: Like Miriam after the drowning Pharaoh she takes up her timbrel and sings to the virgin choir, "Let us sing to the Lord for He hath triumphed gloriously; the horse and his rider hath he thrown into the sea".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:188
verses.text: She teaches her companions to be music girls but music girls for Christ, to be luteplayers but luteplayers for the Saviour.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:189
verses.text: In this occupation she passes both day and night and with oil ready to put in the lamps she waits the coming of the Bridegroom.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:190
verses.text: Do you therefore imitate your kinswoman.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:191
verses.text: Let Rome have in you what a grander city than Rome, I mean Bethlehem, has in her.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:193
verses.text: You have wealth and can easily therefore supply food to those who want it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:194
verses.text: Let virtue consume what was provided for self-indulgence; one who means to despise matrimony need fear no degree of want.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:195
verses.text: Have about you troops of virgins whom you may lead into the king's chamber.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:196
verses.text: Support widows that you may mingle them as a kind of violets with the virgins' lilies and the martyrs' roses.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:197
verses.text: Such are the garlands you must weave for Christ in place of that crown of thorns in which he bore the sins of the world.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:198
verses.text: Let your most noble father thus find in you his joy and support, let him learn from his daughter the lessons he used to learn from his wife.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:199
verses.text: His hair is already gray, his knees tremble, his teeth fall out, his brow is furrowed through years, death is nigh even at the doors, the pyre is all but laid out hard by.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:200
verses.text: Whether we like it or not, we grow old.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:201
verses.text: Let him provide for himself the provision which is needful for his long journey.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:202
verses.text: Let him take with him what otherwise he must unwillingly leave behind, nay let him send before him to heaven what if he declines it, will be appropriated by earth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:204
verses.text: Young widows, of whom some "are already turned aside after Satan, when they have begun to wax wanton against Christ " and wish to marry, generally make such excuses as these.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:205
verses.text: "My little patrimony is daily decreasing, the property which I have inherited is being squandered, a servant has spoken insultingly to me, a maid has neglected my orders.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:206
verses.text: Who will appear for me before the authorities? Who will be responsible for the rents of my estates? Who will see to the education of my children, and to the bringing up of my slaves?" Thus, shameful to say, they put that forward as a reason for marrying again, which alone should deter them from doing so.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:207
verses.text: For by marrying again a mother places over her sons not a guardian but a foe, not a father but a tyrant.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:208
verses.text: Inflamed by her passions she forgets the fruit of her womb, and among the children who know nothing of their sad fate the lately weeping widow dresses herself once more as a bride.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:209
verses.text: Why these excuses about your property and the insolence of slaves? Confess the shameful truth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:210
verses.text: No woman marries to avoid cohabiting with a husband.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:211
verses.text: At least, if passion is not your motive, it is mere madness to play the harlot just to increase wealth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:212
verses.text: You do but purchase a paltry and passing gain at the price of a grace which is precious and eternal! If you have children already, why do you want to marry? If you have none, why do you not fear a recurrence of your former sterility? Why do you put an uncertain gain before a certain loss of self-respect?  A marriage-settlement is made in your favour to-day but in a short time you will be constrained to make your will.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:213
verses.text: Your husband will feign sickness and will do for you what he wants you to do for him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:214
verses.text: Yet he is sure to live and you are sure to die.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:215
verses.text: Or if it happens that you have sons by the second husband, domestic strife is certain to result and intestine disputes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:216
verses.text: You will not be allowed to love your first children, nor to look kindly on those to whom you have yourself given birth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:217
verses.text: You will have to give them their food secretly; yet even so your present husband will bear a grudge against your previous one and, unless you hate your sons, he will think that you still love their father.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:218
verses.text: But your husband may have issue by a former wife.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:219
verses.text: If so when he takes you to his home, though you should be the kindest person in the world, all the commonplaces of rhetoricians and declamations of comic poets and writers of mimes will be hurled at you as a cruel stepmother.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:220
verses.text: If your stepson fall sick or have a headache you will be calumniated as a poisoner.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:221
verses.text: If you refuse him food, you will be cruel, while if you give it, you will be held to have bewitched him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:222
verses.text: I ask you what benefit has a second marriage to confer great enough to compensate for these evils?  16.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:223
verses.text: Do we wish to know what widows ought to be? Let us read the gospel according to Luke.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:224
verses.text: "There was one Anna," he says, "a prophetess, the daughter of Phanuel of the tribe of Aser".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:225
verses.text: The meaning of the name Anna is grace.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:226
verses.text: Phanuel is in our tongue the face of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:227
verses.text: Aser may be translated either as blessedness or as wealth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:228
verses.text: From her youth up to the age of fourscore and four years she had borne the burden of widowhood, not departing from the temple and giving herself to fastings and prayers night and day; therefore she earned spiritual grace, received the title 'daughter of the face of God,' and obtained a share in the 'blessedness and wealth' which belonged to her ancestry.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:229
verses.text: Let us recall to mind the widow of Zarephath who thought more of satisfying Elijah's hunger than of preserving her own life and that of her son.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:230
verses.text: Though she believed that she and he must die that very night unless they had food, she determined that her guest should survive.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:231
verses.text: She preferred to sacrifice her life rather than to neglect the duty of almsgiving.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:232
verses.text: In her handful of meal she found the seed from which she was to reap a harvest sent her by the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:233
verses.text: She sows her meal and lo! a cruse of oil comes from it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:234
verses.text: In the land of Judah grain was scarce for the corn of wheat had died there; but in the house of a heathen widow oil flowed in streams.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:235
verses.text: In the book of Judith—if any one is of opinion that it should be received as canonical—we read of a widow wasted with fasting and wearing the sombre garb of a mourner, whose outward squalor indicated not so much the regret which she felt for her dead husband as the temper in which she looked forward to the coming of the Bridegroom.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:236
verses.text: I see her hand armed with the sword and stained with blood.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:237
verses.text: I recognize the head of Holofernes which she has carried away from the camp of the enemy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:238
verses.text: Here a woman vanquishes men, and chastity beheads lust.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:239
verses.text: Quickly changing her garb, she puts on once more in the hour of victory her own mean dress finer than all the splendours of the world.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:241
verses.text: Some from a misapprehension number Deborah among the widows, and suppose that Barak the leader of the army is her son, though the scripture tells a different story.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:242
verses.text: I will mention her here because she was a prophetess and is reckoned among the judges, and again because she might have said with the psalmist:—"How sweet are thy words unto my taste! yea sweeter than honey to my mouth".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:243
verses.text: Well was she called the bee for she fed on the flowers of scripture, was enveloped with the fragrance of the Holy Spirit, and gathered into one with prophetic lips the sweet juices of the nectar.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:244
verses.text: Then there is Naomi, in Greek παρακεκλημένη or she who is consoled, who, when her husband and her children died abroad, carried her chastity back home and, being supported on the road by its aid, kept with her her Moabitish daughter-in-law, that in her the prophecy of Isaiah might find a fulfilment.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:245
verses.text: "Send out the lamb, O Lord, to rule over the land from the rock of the desert to the mount of the daughter of Zion".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:246
verses.text: I pass on to the widow in the gospel who, though she was but a poor widow was yet richer than all the people of Israel.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:247
verses.text: She had but a grain of mustard seed, but she put her leaven in three measures of flour; and, combining her confession of the Father and of the Son with the grace of the Holy Spirit, she cast her two mites into the treasury.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:248
verses.text: All the substance that she had, her entire possessions, she offered in the two testaments of her faith.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:249
verses.text: These are the two seraphim which glorify the Trinity with threefold song and are stored among the treasures of the church.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:250
verses.text: They also form the legs of the tongs by which the live coal is caught up to purge the sinner's lips.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:252
verses.text: But why should I recall instances from history and bring from books types of saintly women, when in your own city you have many before your eyes whose example you may well imitate? I shall not recount their merits here lest I should seem to flatter them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:253
verses.text: It will suffice to mention the saintly Marcella who, while she is true to the claims of her birth and station, has set before us a life which is worthy of the gospel.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:254
verses.text: Anna "lived with an husband seven years from her virginity"; Marcella lived with one for seven months.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:255
verses.text: Anna looked for the coming of Christ; Marcella holds fast the Lord whom Anna received in her arms.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:256
verses.text: Anna sang His praise when He was still a wailing infant; Marcella proclaims His glory now that He has won His triumph.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:257
verses.text: Anna spoke of Him to all those who waited for the redemption of Israel; Marcella cries out with the nations of the redeemed: "A brother redeemeth not, yet a man shall redeem," and from another psalm: "A man was born in her, and the Highest Himself hath established her".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:258
verses.text: About two years ago, as I well remember, I published a book against Jovinian in which by the authority of scripture I crushed the objections raised on the other side on account of the apostle's concession of second marriages.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:259
verses.text: It is unnecessary that I should repeat my arguments afresh here, as you can find them all in this treatise.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:260
verses.text: That I may not exceed the limits of a letter, I will only give you this one last piece of advice.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 54:261
verses.text: Think every day that you must die, and you will then never think of marrying again.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:1
verses.text: Letter LV.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:2
verses.text: To Amandus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:3
verses.text: A very interesting letter.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:4
verses.text: Amandus a presbyter of Burdigala (Bourdeaux) had written to Jerome for an explanation of three passages of scripture, viz.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:5
verses.text: Matt.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:6
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:8
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:10
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:11
verses.text: 25, 26, and had in the same letter on behalf of a 'sister' (supposed by Thierry to have been Fabiola) put the following question: 'Can a woman who has divorced her first husband on account of his vices and who has during his lifetime under compulsion married again, communicate with the Church without first doing penance?' Jerome in his reply gives the explanations asked for but answers the farther question, that concerning the 'sister,' with an emphatic negative.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:12
verses.text: Written about the year 394 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:13
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:15
verses.text: A short letter does not admit of long explanations; compressing much matter into a small space it can only give a few words to topics which suggest many thoughts.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:16
verses.text: You ask me what is the meaning of the passage in the gospel according to Matthew, "take no thought for the morrow.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:17
verses.text: Sufficient unto the day is the evil thereof".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:18
verses.text: In the holy scriptures "the morrow" signifies the time to come.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:19
verses.text: Thus in Genesis Jacob says: "So shall my righteousness answer for me to-morrow".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:20
verses.text: Again when the two tribes of Reuben and Gad and the half tribe of Manasseh had built an altar and when all Israel had sent to them an embassy, they made answer to Phinehas the high priest that they had built the altar lest "to-morrow" it might be said to their children, "ye have no part in the Lord".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:21
verses.text: You may find many similar passages in the old instrument.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:22
verses.text: While then Christ forbids us to take thought for things future, He has allowed us to do so for things present, knowing as He does the frailty of our mortal condition.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:23
verses.text: His remaining words "sufficient unto the day is the evil thereof" are to be understood as meaning that it is sufficient for us to think of the present troubles of this life.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:24
verses.text: Why need we extend our thoughts to contingencies, to objects which we either cannot obtain or else having obtained must soon relinquish? The Greek word κακία rendered in the Latin version "wickedness" has two distinct meanings, wickedness and tribulation, which latter the Greek call κακωσίν and in this passage "tribulation" would be a better rendering than "wickedness".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:25
verses.text: But if any one demurs to this and insists that the word κακία must mean "wickedness" and not "tribulation" or "trouble," the meaning must be the same as in the words "the whole world lieth in wickedness" and as in the Lord's prayer in the clause, "deliver us from evil:" the purport of the passage will then be that our present conflict with the wickedness of this world should be enough for us.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:27
verses.text: Secondly, you ask me concerning the passage in the first epistle of the blessed apostle Paul to the Corinthians where he says: "every sin that a man doeth is without the body; but he that committeth fornication sinneth against his own body".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:28
verses.text: Let us go back a little farther and read on until we come to these words, for we must not seek to learn the whole meaning of the section, from the concluding parts of it, or, if I may so say, from the tail of the chapter.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:29
verses.text: "The body is not for fornication but for the Lord; and the Lord for the body.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:30
verses.text: And God hath both raised up the Lord and will also raise up us [with Him] by his own power.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:31
verses.text: Know ye not that your bodies are the members of Christ? Shall I then take the members of Christ, and make them the members of an harlot? God forbid.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:32
verses.text: What! Know ye not that he which is joined to an harlot is one body? For two, saith he, shall be one flesh.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:33
verses.text: But he that is joined unto the Lord is one spirit.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:34
verses.text: Flee fornication.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:35
verses.text: Every sin that a man doeth is without the body; but he that committeth fornication sinneth against his own body," and so on.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:36
verses.text: The holy apostle has been arguing against excess and has just before said "meats for the belly and the belly for meats: but God shall destroy both it and them".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:37
verses.text: Now he comes to treat of fornication.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:38
verses.text: For excess in eating is the mother of lust; a belly that is distended with food and saturated with draughts of wine is sure to lead to sensual passion.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:39
verses.text: As has been elsewhere said "the arrangement of man's organs suggests the course of his vices".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:40
verses.text: Accordingly all such sins as theft, manslaughter, pillage, perjury, and the like can be repented of after they have been committed; and, however much interest may tempt him, conscience always smites the offender.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:41
verses.text: It is only lust and sensual pleasure that in the very hour of penitence undergo once more the temptations of the past, the itch of the flesh, and the allurements of sin; so that the very thought which we bestow on the correction of such transgressions becomes in itself a new source of sin.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:42
verses.text: Or to put the matter in a different light: other sins are outside of us; and whatever we do we do against others.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:43
verses.text: But fornication defiles the fornicator both in conscience and body; and in accordance with the words of the Lord, "for this cause shall a man leave father and mother, and shall cleave to his wife; and they twain shall be one flesh," he too becomes one body with a harlot and sins against his own body by making what is the temple of Christ the body of a harlot.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:44
verses.text: Not to pass over any suggestion of the Greek commentators, I shall give you one more explanation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:45
verses.text: It is one thing, they say, to sin with the body, and another to sin in the body.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:46
verses.text: Theft, manslaughter, and all other sins except fornication we commit with our hands outside ourselves.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:47
verses.text: Fornication alone we commit inside ourselves in our bodies and not with our bodies upon others.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:48
verses.text: The preposition 'with' denotes the instrument used in sinning, while the preposition 'in' signifies the sphere of the passion is ourselves.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:49
verses.text: Some again give this explanation that according to the scripture a man's body is his wife and that when a man commits fornication he is said to sin against his own body that is against his wife inasmuch as he defiles her by his own fornication and causes her though herself free from sin to become a sinner through her intercourse with him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:51
verses.text: I find joined to your letter of inquiries a short paper containing the following words: "ask him, (that is me,) whether a woman who has left her husband on the ground that he is an adulterer and sodomite and has found herself compelled to take another may in the lifetime of him whom she first left be in communion with the church without doing penance for her fault".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:52
verses.text: As I read the case put I recall the verse "they make excuses for their sins".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:53
verses.text: We are all human and all indulgent to our own faults; and what our own will leads us to do we attribute to a necessity of nature.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:54
verses.text: It is as though a young man were to say, "I am over-borne by my body, the glow of nature kindles my passions, the structure of my frame and its reproductive organs call for sexual intercourse".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:55
verses.text: Or again a murderer might say, "I was in want, I stood in need of food, I had nothing to cover me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:56
verses.text: If I shed the blood of another, it was to save myself from dying of cold and hunger".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:57
verses.text: Tell the sister, therefore, who thus enquires of me concerning her condition, not my sentence but that of the apostle.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:58
verses.text: "Know ye not, brethren (for I speak to them that know the law,) how that the law hath dominion over a man as long as he liveth? For the woman which hath an husband is bound by the law to her husband, so long as he liveth; but if the husband be dead, she is loosed from the law of her husband.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:59
verses.text: So then, if, while her husband liveth, she be married to another man, she shall be called an adulteress".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:60
verses.text: And in another place: "the wife is bound by the law as long as her husband liveth; but if her husband be dead, she is at liberty to be married to whom she will; only in the Lord".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:61
verses.text: The apostle has thus cut away every plea and has clearly declared that, if a woman marries again while her husband is living, she is an adulteress.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:62
verses.text: You must not speak to me of the violence of a ravisher, a mother's pleading, a father's bidding, the influence of relatives, the insolence and the intrigues of servants, household losses.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:63
verses.text: A husband may be an adulterer or a sodomite, he may be stained with every crime and may have been left by his wife because of his sins; yet he is still her husband and, so long as he lives, she may not marry another.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:64
verses.text: The apostle does not promulgate this decree on his own authority but on that of Christ who speaks in him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:65
verses.text: For he has followed the words of Christ in the gospel: "whosoever shall put away his wife, saving for the cause of fornication, causeth her to commit adultery: and whosoever shall marry her that is divorced, committeth adultery".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:66
verses.text: Mark what he says: "whosoever shall marry her that is divorced committeth adultery".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:67
verses.text: Whether she has put away her husband or her husband her, the man who marries her is still an adulterer.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:68
verses.text: Wherefore the apostles seeing how heavy the yoke of marriage was thus made said to Him: "if the case of the man be so with his wife, it is not good to marry," and the Lord replied, "he that is able to receive it, let him receive it".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:69
verses.text: And immediately by the instance of the three eunuchs he shows the blessedness of virginity which is bound by no carnal tie.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:71
verses.text: I have not been able quite to determine what it is that she means by the words "has found herself compelled" to marry again.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:72
verses.text: What is this compulsion of which she speaks? Was she overborne by a crowd and ravished against her will? If so, why has she not, thus victimized, subsequently put away her ravisher? Let her read the books of Moses and she will find that if violence is offered to a betrothed virgin in a city and she does not cry out, she is punished as an adulteress: but if she is forced in the field, she is innocent of sin and her ravisher alone is amenable to the laws.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:73
verses.text: Therefore if your sister, who, as she says, has been forced into a second union, wishes to receive the body of Christ and not to be accounted an adulteress, let her do penance; so far at least as from the time she begins to repent to have no farther intercourse with that second husband who ought to be called not a husband but an adulterer.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:74
verses.text: If this seems hard to her and if she cannot leave one whom she has once loved and will not prefer the Lord to sensual pleasure, let her hear the declaration of the apostle: "ye cannot drink the cup of the Lord and the cup of devils: ye cannot be partakers of the Lord's table and of the table of devils," and in another place: "what communion hath light with darkness? and what concord hath Christ with Belial?" What I am about to say may sound novel but after all it is not new but old for it is supported by the witness of the old testament.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:75
verses.text: If she leaves her second husband and desires to be reconciled with her first, she cannot be so now; for it is written in Deuteronomy: "When a man hath taken a wife, and married her, and it come to pass that she find no favour in his eyes, because he hath found some uncleanness in her; then let him write her a bill of divorcement, and give it in her hand, and send her out of his house.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:76
verses.text: And when she is departed out of his house, she may go and be another man's wife.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:77
verses.text: And if the latter husband hate her, and write her a bill of divorcement and giveth it in her hand, and sendeth her out of his house; or if the latter husband die which took her to be his wife; her former husband, which sent her away may not take her again to be his wife, after that she is defiled; for that is abomination before the Lord: and thou shalt not cause the land to sin, which the Lord thy God giveth thee for an inheritance".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:78
verses.text: Wherefore, I beseech you, do your best to comfort her and to urge her to seek salvation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:79
verses.text: Diseased flesh calls for the knife and the searing-iron.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:80
verses.text: The wound is to blame and not the healing art, if with a cruelty that is really kindness a physician to spare does not spare, and to be merciful is cruel.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:82
verses.text: Your third and last question relates to the passage in the same epistle where the apostle in discussing the resurrection, comes to the words: "for he must reign, till he hath put all things under his feet.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:83
verses.text: The last enemy that shall be destroyed is death.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:84
verses.text: For he hath put all things under his feet.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:85
verses.text: But when he saith, all things are put under him, it is manifest that he is excepted, which did put all things under him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:86
verses.text: And when all things shall be subdued unto him, then shall the Son also himself be subject unto him that put all things under him that God may be all in all".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:87
verses.text: I am surprised that you have resolved to question me about this passage when that reverend man, Hilary, bishop of Poictiers, has occupied the eleventh book of his treatise against the Arians with a full examination and explanation of it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:88
verses.text: Yet I may at least say a few words.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:89
verses.text: The chief stumbling-block in the passage is that the Son is said to be subject to the Father.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:90
verses.text: Now which is the more shameful and humiliating, to be subject to the Father (often a mark of loving devotion as in the psalm "truly my soul is subject unto God") or to be crucified and made the curse of the cross? For "cursed is everyone that hangeth on a tree".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:91
verses.text: If Christ then for our sakes was made a curse that He might deliver us from the curse of the law, are you surprised that He is also for our sakes subject to the Father to make us too subject to Him as He says in the gospel: "No man cometh unto the Father but by me," and "I, if I be lifted up from the earth, will draw all men unto me".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:92
verses.text: Christ then is subject to the Father in the faithful; for all believers, nay the whole human race, are accounted members of His body.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:93
verses.text: But in unbelievers, that is in Jews, heathens, and heretics, He is said to be not subject; for these members of His body are not subject to the faith.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:94
verses.text: But in the end of the world when all His members shall see Christ, that is their own body, reigning, they also shall be made subject to Christ, that is to their own body, that the whole of Christ's body may be subject unto God and the Father, and that God may be all in all.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:95
verses.text: He does not say "that the Father may be all in all" but that "God" may be, a title which properly belongs to the Trinity and may be referred not only to the Father but also to the Son and to the Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:96
verses.text: His meaning therefore is "that humanity may be subject to the Godhead".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:97
verses.text: By humanity we here intend not that gentleness and kindness which the Greeks call philanthropy but the whole human race.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:98
verses.text: Moreover when he says "that God may be all in all," it is to be taken in this sense.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:99
verses.text: At present our Lord and Saviour is not all in all, but only a part in each of us.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:100
verses.text: For instance He is wisdom in Solomon, generosity in David, patience in Job, knowledge of things to come in Daniel, faith in Peter, zeal in Phinehas and Paul, virginity in John, and other virtues in others.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 55:101
verses.text: But when the end of all things shall come, then shall He be all in all, for then the saints shall severally possess all the virtues and all will possess Christ in His entirety.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 56:1
verses.text: Letter LVI.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 56:2
verses.text: From Augustine.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 56:3
verses.text: Augustine's first letter to Jerome (printed in his correspondence in this Library as Letter XXVIII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 56:4
verses.text: ): through a series of accidents it was not delivered until nine years after it had been written.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 56:5
verses.text: In it Augustine comments on Jerome's new Latin version of the O.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 56:6
verses.text: T.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 56:7
verses.text: and advises him in his future labours to adhere more closely to the text of the LXX.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 56:8
verses.text: He also discusses Jerome's account (in his commentary on the epistle to the Galatians) of the quarrel between Paul and Peter at Antioch.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 56:9
verses.text: This according to Jerome was not a real misunderstanding but only one artificially 'got up' to put clearly before the Church the mischief of Christians conforming to the now obsolete Mosaic Law.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 56:10
verses.text: Augustine strongly controverts this view and maintains that it is fatal to the veracity and authority claimed for scripture.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 56:11
verses.text: Written from Hippo about the year 394 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 56:12
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:1
verses.text: Letter LVII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:2
verses.text: To Pammachius on the Best Method of Translating.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:3
verses.text: Written to Pammachius (for whom see Letter LXVI.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:4
verses.text: ) in a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:5
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:7
verses.text: In the previous year Jerome had rendered into Latin Letter LI.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:8
verses.text: (from Epiphanius to John of Jerusalem) under circumstances which he here describes (§2).

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:9
verses.text: His version soon became public and incurred severe criticism from some person not named by Jerome but supposed by him to have been instigated by Rufinus (§12).

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:10
verses.text: Charged with having falsified his original he now repudiates the charge and defends his method of translation ("to give sense for sense and not word for word" §5) by an appeal to the practice of classical (§5), ecclesiastical (§6), and N.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:11
verses.text: T.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:12
verses.text: (§§7–10) writers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:13
verses.text: When at a subsequent period Rufinus gave to the world what was in Jerome's opinion a misleading version of Origen's First Principles, he appealed to this letter as giving him ample warranty for what he had done.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:14
verses.text: See Letters LXXX, and LXXXI, and Rufinus' Preface to the περί ᾽Αεχῶν in Vol.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:15
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:16
verses.text: of this series.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:18
verses.text: The apostle Paul when he appeared before King Agrippa to answer the charges which were brought against him, wishing to use language intelligible to his hearers and confident of the success of his cause, began by congratulating himself in these words: "I think myself happy, King Agrippa, because I shall answer for myself this day before thee touching all the things whereof I am accused by the Jews: especially because thou art expert in all customs and questions which are among the Jews".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:19
verses.text: He had read the saying of Jesus: "Well is him that speaketh in the ears of them that will hear;" and he knew that a pleader only succeeds in proportion as he impresses his judge.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:20
verses.text: On this occasion I too think myself happy that learned ears will hear my defence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:21
verses.text: For a rash tongue charges me with ignorance or falsehood; it alleges that in translating another man's letter I have made mistakes through incapacity or carelessness; it convicts me of either an involuntary error or a deliberate offence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:22
verses.text: And lest it should happen that my accuser—encouraged by a volubility which stops at nothing and by an impunity which arrogates to itself an unlimited license—should accuse me as he has already done our father (Pope) Epiphanius; I send this letter to inform you—and through you others who think me worthy of their regard—of the true order of the facts.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:24
verses.text: About two years ago the aforesaid Pope Epiphanius sent a letter to Bishop John, first finding fault with him as regarded some of his opinions and then mildly calling him to penitence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:25
verses.text: Such was the repute of the writer or else the elegance of the letter that all Palestine fought for copies of it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:26
verses.text: Now there was in our monastery a man of no small estimation in his country, Eusebius of Cremona, who, when he found that this letter was in everybody's mouth and that the ignorant and the educated alike admired it for its teaching and for the purity of its style, set to work to beg me to translate it for him into Latin and at the same time to simplify the argument so that he might more readily understand it; for he was himself altogether unacquainted with the Greek language.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:27
verses.text: I consented to his request and calling to my aid a secretary speedily dictated my version, briefly marking on the side of the page the contents of the several chapters.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:28
verses.text: The fact is that he asked me to do this merely for himself, and I requested of him in return to keep his copy private and not too readily to circulate it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:29
verses.text: A year and six months went by, and then the aforesaid translation found its way by a novel stratagem from his desk to Jerusalem.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:30
verses.text: For a pretended monk—either bribed as there is much reason to believe or actuated by malice of his own as his tempter vainly tries to convince us—shewed himself a second Judas by robbing Eusebius of his literary property and gave to the adversary an occasion of railing against me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:31
verses.text: They tell the unlearned that I have falsified the original, that I have not rendered word for word, that I have put 'dear friend' in place of 'honourable sir,' and more shameful still! that I have cut down my translation by omitting the words αἰδεσιμῶτατε Πάππα.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:32
verses.text: These and similar trifles form the substance of the charges brought against me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:34
verses.text: At the outset before I defend my version I wish to ask those persons who confound wisdom with cunning, some few questions.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:35
verses.text: Where did you get your copy of the letter? Who gave it to you? How have you the effrontery to bring forward what you have procured by fraud? What place of safety will be left us if we cannot conceal our secrets even within our own walls and our own writing-desks? Were I to press such a charge against you before a legal tribunal, I could make you amenable to the laws which even in fiscal cases appoint penalties for meddlesome informers and condemn the traitor even while they accept his treachery.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:36
verses.text: For though they welcome the profit which the information gives them, they disapprove the motive which actuates the informer.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:37
verses.text: A little while ago a man of consular rank named Hesychius (against whom the patriarch Gamaliel waged an implacable war) was condemned to death by the emperor Theodosius simply because he had laid hold of imperial papers through a secretary whom he had tempted.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:38
verses.text: We read also in old histories that the schoolmaster who betrayed the children of the Faliscans was sent back to his boys and handed over to them in bonds, the Roman people refusing to accept a dishonourable victory.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:39
verses.text: When Pyrrhus king of Epirus was lying in his camp ill from the effects of a wound, his physician offered to poison him, but Fabricius thinking it shame that the king should die by treachery sent the traitor back in chains to his master, refusing to sanction crime even when its victim was an enemy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:40
verses.text: A principle which the laws uphold, which is maintained by enemies, which warfare and the sword fail to violate, has hitherto been held unquestioned among the monks and priests of Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:41
verses.text: And can any one of them presume now, knitting his brow and snapping his fingers, to spend his breath in saying: "What if he did use bribes or other inducements! he did what suited his purpose".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:42
verses.text: A strange plea truly to defend a fraud as though robbers, thieves, and pirates did not do the same.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:43
verses.text: Certainly, when Annas and Caiaphas led hapless Judas astray, they only did what they believed to be expedient for themselves.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:45
verses.text: Suppose that I wish to write down in my note books this or that silly trifle, or to make comments upon the scriptures, to retort upon my calumniators, to digest my wrath, to practise myself in the use of commonplaces and to stow away sharp shafts for the day of battle.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:46
verses.text: So long as I do not publish my thoughts, they are only unkind words not matter for a charge of libel; in fact they are not even unkind words for the public ear never hears them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:47
verses.text: You may bribe my slaves and tamper with my clients.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:48
verses.text: You may, as the fable has it, penetrate by means of your gold to the chamber of Danaë; and then, dissembling what you have done, you may call me a falsifier; but, if you do so, you will have to plead guilty yourself to a worse charge than any that you can bring against me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:49
verses.text: One man inveighs against you as a heretic, another as a perverter of doctrine.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:50
verses.text: You are silent yourself; you do not venture to answer; you assail the translator; you cavil about syllables and you fancy your defence complete if your calumnies provoke no reply.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:51
verses.text: Suppose that I have made a mistake or an omission in my rendering.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:52
verses.text: Your whole case turns upon this; this is the defence which you offer to your accusers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:53
verses.text: Are you no heretic because I am a bad translator? Mind, I do not say that I know you to be a heretic; I leave such knowledge to your accuser, to him who wrote the letter: what I do say is that it is the height of folly for you when you are accused by one man to attack another, and when you are covered with wounds yourself to seek comfort by wounding one who is still quiescent and unaggressive.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:55
verses.text: In the above remarks I have assumed that I have made alterations in the letter and that a simple translation may contain errors though not wilful ones.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:56
verses.text: As, however the letter itself shews that no changes have been made in the sense, that nothing has been added, and that no doctrine has been foisted into it, "obviously their object is understanding to understand nothing;" and while they desire to arraign another's want of skill, they betray their own.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:57
verses.text: For I myself not only admit but freely proclaim that in translating from the Greek (except in the case of the holy scriptures where even the order of the words is a mystery) I render sense for sense and not word for word.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:58
verses.text: For this course I have the authority of Tully who has so translated the Protagoras of Plato, the oeconomicus of Xenophon, and the two beautiful orations which aeschines and Demosthenes delivered one against the other.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:59
verses.text: What omissions, additions, and alterations he has made substituting the idioms of his own for those of another tongue, this is not the time to say.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:60
verses.text: I am satisfied to quote the authority of the translator who has spoken as follows in a prologue prefixed to the orations.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:61
verses.text: "I have thought it right to embrace a labour which though not necessary for myself will prove useful to those who study.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:62
verses.text: I have translated the noblest speeches of the two most eloquent of the Attic orators, the speeches which aeschines and Demosthenes delivered one against the other; but I have rendered them not as a translator but as an orator, keeping the sense but altering the form by adapting both the metaphors and the words to suit our own idiom.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:63
verses.text: I have not deemed it necessary to render word for word but I have reproduced the general style and emphasis.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:64
verses.text: I have not supposed myself bound to pay the words out one by one to the reader but only to give him an equivalent in value".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:65
verses.text: Again at the close of his task he says, "I shall be well satisfied if my rendering is found, as I trust it will be, true to this standard.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:66
verses.text: In making it I have utilized all the excellences of the originals, I mean the sentiments, the forms of expression and the arrangement of the topics, while I have followed the actual wording only so far as I could do so without offending our notions of taste.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:67
verses.text: If all that I have written is not to be found in the Greek, I have at any rate striven to make it correspond with it".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:68
verses.text: Horace too, an acute and learned writer, in his Art of Poetry gives the same advice to the skilled translator:—  And care not thou with over anxious thought  To render word for word.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:69
verses.text: Terence has translated Menander; Plautus and Caecilius the old comic poets.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:70
verses.text: Do they ever stick at words? Do they not rather in their versions think first of preserving the beauty and charm of their originals? What men like you call fidelity in transcription, the learned term pestilent minuteness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:71
verses.text: Such were my teachers about twenty years ago; and even then I was the victim of a similar error to that which is now imputed to me, though indeed I never imagined that you would charge me with it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:72
verses.text: In translating the Chronicle of Eusebius of Caesarea into Latin, I made among others the following prefatory observations: "It is difficult in following lines laid down by others not sometimes to diverge from them, and it is hard to preserve in a translation the charm of expressions which in another language are most felicitous.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:73
verses.text: Each particular word conveys a meaning of its own, and possibly I have no equivalent by which to render it, and if I make a circuit to reach my goal, I have to go many miles to cover a short distance.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:74
verses.text: To these difficulties must be added the windings of hyperbata, differences in the use of cases, divergencies of metaphor; and last of all the peculiar and if I may so call it, inbred character of the language.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:75
verses.text: If I render word for word, the result will sound uncouth, and if compelled by necessity I alter anything in the order or wording, I shall seem to have departed from the function of a translator".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:76
verses.text: And after a long discussion which it would be tedious to follow out here, I added what follows:—"If any one imagines that translation does not impair the charm of style, let him render Homer word for word into Latin, nay I will go farther still and say, let him render it into Latin prose, and the result will be that the order of the words will seem ridiculous and the most eloquent of poets scarcely articulate".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:78
verses.text: In quoting my own writings my only object has been to prove that from my youth up I at least have always aimed at rendering sense not words, but if such authority as they supply is deemed insufficient, read and consider the short preface dealing with this matter which occurs in a book narrating the life of the blessed Antony.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:79
verses.text: "A literal translation from one language into another obscures the sense; the exuberance of the growth lessens the yield.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:80
verses.text: For while one's diction is enslaved to cases and metaphors, it has to explain by tedious circumlocutions what a few words would otherwise have sufficed to make plain.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:81
verses.text: I have tried to avoid this error in the translation which at your request I have made of the story of the blessed Antony.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:82
verses.text: My version always preserves the sense although it does not invariably keep the words of the original.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:83
verses.text: Leave others to catch at syllables and letters, do you for your part look for the meaning".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:84
verses.text: Time would fail me were I to unfold the testimonies of all who have translated only according to the sense.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:85
verses.text: It is sufficient for the present to name Hilary the confessor who has turned some homilies on Job and several treatises on the Psalms from Greek into Latin; yet has not bound himself to the drowsiness of the letter or fettered himself by the stale literalism of inadequate culture.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:86
verses.text: Like a conqueror he has led away captive into his own tongue the meaning of his originals.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:88
verses.text: That secular and church writers should have adopted this line need not surprise us when we consider that the translators of the Septuagint, the evangelists, and the apostles, have done the same in dealing with the sacred writings.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:89
verses.text: We read in Mark of the Lord saying Talitha cumi and it is immediately added "which is interpreted, Damsel, I say unto thee, arise".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:90
verses.text: The evangelist may be charged with falsehood for having added the words "I say unto thee" for the Hebrew is only "Damsel arise".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:91
verses.text: To emphasize this and to give the impression of one calling and commanding he has added "I say unto thee".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:92
verses.text: Again in Matthew when the thirty pieces of silver are returned by the traitor Judas and the potter's field is purchased with them, it is written:—"Then was fulfilled that which was spoken of by Jeremy the prophet, saying, 'And they took the thirty pieces of silver the price of him that was valued which they of the children of Israel did value, and gave them for the potter's field, as the Lord appointed me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:93
verses.text: '" This passage is not found in Jeremiah at all but in Zechariah, in quite different words and an altogether different order.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:94
verses.text: In fact the Vulgate renders it as follows:—"And I will say unto them, If it is good in your sight, give ye me a price or refuse it: So they weighed for my price thirty pieces of silver.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:95
verses.text: And the Lord said unto me, Put them into the melting furnace and consider if it is tried as I have been tried by them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:96
verses.text: And I took the thirty pieces of silver and cast them into the house of the Lord".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:97
verses.text: It is evident that the rendering of the Septuagint differs widely from the quotation of the evangelist.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:98
verses.text: In the Hebrew also, though the sense is the same, the words are quite different and differently arranged.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:99
verses.text: It says: "And I said unto them, If ye think good, give me my price; and, if not, forbear.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:100
verses.text: So they weighed for my price thirty pieces of silver.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:101
verses.text: And the Lord said unto me, Cast it unto the potter; a goodly price that I was priced at of them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:102
verses.text: And I took the thirty pieces of silver and cast them to the potter in the house of the Lord".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:103
verses.text: They may accuse the apostle of falsifying his version seeing that it agrees neither with the Hebrew nor with the translators of the Septuagint: and worse than this, they may say that he has mistaken the author's name putting down Jeremiah when it should be Zechariah.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:104
verses.text: Far be it from us to speak thus of a follower of Christ, who made it his care to formulate dogmas rather than to hunt for words and syllables.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:105
verses.text: To take another instance from Zechariah, the evangelist John quotes from the Hebrew, "They shall look on him whom they pierced," for which we read in the Septuagint, "And they shall look upon me because they have mocked me," and in the Latin version, "And they shall look upon me for the things which they have mocked or insulted".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:106
verses.text: Here the evangelist, the Septuagint, and our own version all differ; yet the divergence of language is atoned by oneness of spirit.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:107
verses.text: In Matthew again we read of the Lord preaching flight to the apostles and confirming His counsel with a passage from Zechariah.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:108
verses.text: "It is written," he says, "I will smite the shepherd, and the sheep of the flock shall be scattered abroad".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:109
verses.text: But in the Septuagint and in the Hebrew it reads differently, for it is not God who speaks, as the evangelist makes out, but the prophet who appeals to God the Father saying:—"Smite the shepherd, and the sheep shall be scattered".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:110
verses.text: In this instance according to my judgment—and I have some careful critics with me—the evangelist is guilty of a fault in presuming to ascribe to God what are the words of the prophet.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:111
verses.text: Again the same evangelist writes that at the warning of an angel Joseph took the young child and his mother and went into Egypt and remained there till the death of Herod; "that it might be fulfilled which was spoken of the Lord by the prophet saying, Out of Egypt have I called my son".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:112
verses.text: The Latin manuscripts do not so give the passage, but in Hosea the true Hebrew text has the following:—"When Israel was a child then I loved him, and called my son out of Egypt".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:113
verses.text: Which the Septuagint renders thus:—"When Israel was a child then I loved him, and called his sons out of Egypt".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:114
verses.text: Are they altogether to be rejected because they have given another turn to a passage which refers primarily to the mystery of Christ? Or should we not rather pardon the shortcomings of the translators on the score of their human frailty according to the saying of James, "In many things we offend all.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:115
verses.text: If any man offend not in word the same is a perfect man and able also to bridle the whole body".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:116
verses.text: Once more it is written in the pages of the same evangelist, "And he came and dwelt in a city called Nazareth: that it might be fulfilled which was spoken by the prophets, He shall be called a Nazarene".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:117
verses.text: Let these word fanciers and nice critics of all composition tell us where they have read the words; and if they cannot, let me tell them that they are in Isaiah.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:118
verses.text: For in the place where we read and translate, "There shall come forth a rod out of the stem of Jesse, and a branch shall grow out of his roots," in the Hebrew idiom it is written thus, "There shall come forth a rod out of the root of Jesse and a Nazarene shall grow from his root".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:119
verses.text: How can the Septuagint leave out the word 'Nazarene,' if it is unlawful to substitute one word for another? It is sacrilege either to conceal or to set at naught a mystery.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:121
verses.text: Let us pass on to other passages, for the brief limits of a letter do not suffer us to dwell too long on any one point.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:122
verses.text: The same Matthew says:—"Now all this was done that it might be fulfilled which was spoken of the Lord by the prophet saying, Behold a virgin shall be with child and shall bring forth a son and they shall call his name Emmanuel".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:123
verses.text: The rendering of the Septuagint is, "Behold a virgin shall receive seed and shall bring forth a son, and ye shall call his name Emmanuel".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:124
verses.text: If people cavil at words, obviously 'to receive seed' is not the exact equivalent of 'to be with child,' and 'ye shall call' differs from 'they shall call.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:125
verses.text: ' Moreover in the Hebrew we read thus, "Behold a virgin shall conceive and bear a son and shall call his name Immanuel".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:126
verses.text: Ahaz shall not call him so for he was convicted of want of faith, nor the Jews for they were destined to deny him, but she who is to conceive him, and bear him, the virgin herself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:127
verses.text: In the same evangelist we read that Herod was troubled at the coming of the Magi and that gathering together the scribes and the priests he demanded of them where Christ should be born and that they answered him, "In Bethlehem of Judaea: for thus it is written by the prophet; And thou Bethlehem in the land of Judah art not the least among the princes of Judah, for out of thee shall come a governour that shall rule my people Israel".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:128
verses.text: In the Vulgate this passage appears as follows:—"And thou Bethlehem, the house of Ephratah, art small to be among the thousands of Judah, yet one shall come out of thee for me to be a prince in Israel".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:129
verses.text: You will be more surprised still at the difference in words and order between Matthew and the Septuagint if you look at the Hebrew which runs thus:—"But thou Bethlehem Ephratah, though thou be little among the thousands of Judah, yet out of thee shall he come forth unto me that is to be ruler in Israel".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:130
verses.text: Consider one by one the words of the evangelist:—"And thou Bethlehem in the land of Judah".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:131
verses.text: For "the land of Judah" the Hebrew has "Ephratah" while the Septuagint gives "the house of Ephratah".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:132
verses.text: The evangelist writes, "art not the least among the princes of Judah".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:133
verses.text: In the Septuagint this is, "art small to be among the thousands of Judah," while the Hebrew gives, "though thou be little among the thousands of Judah".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:134
verses.text: There is a contradiction here—and that not merely verbal—between the evangelist and the prophet; for in this place at any rate both Septuagint and Hebrew agree.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:135
verses.text: The evangelist says that he is not little among the princes of Judah, while the passage from which he queries says exactly the opposite of this, "Thou art small indeed and little; but yet out of thee, small and little as thou art, there shall come forth for me a leader in Israel," a sentiment in harmony with that of the apostle, "God hath chosen the weak things of the world to confound the things which are mighty".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:136
verses.text: Moreover the last clause "to rule" or "to feed my people Israel" clearly runs differently in the original.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:138
