verses.text: I refer to these passages, not to convict the evangelists of falsification—a charge worthy only of impious men like Celsus, Porphyry, and Julian—but to bring home to my critics their own want of knowledge, and to gain from them such consideration that they may concede to me in the case of a simple letter what, whether they like it or not, they will have to concede to the Apostles in the Holy Scriptures.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:139
verses.text: Mark, the disciple of Peter, begins his gospel thus:—"The beginning of the gospel of Jesus Christ, as it is written in the prophet Isaiah: Behold I send my messenger before thy face which shall prepare thy way before thee.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:140
verses.text: The voice of one crying in the wilderness, Prepare ye the way of the Lord, make his paths straight".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:141
verses.text: This quotation is made up from two prophets, Malachi that is to say and Isaiah.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:142
verses.text: For the first part: "Behold I send my messenger before thy face which shall prepare thy way before thee," occurs at the close of Malachi.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:143
verses.text: But the second part: "The voice of one crying, etc.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:144
verses.text: ," we read in Isaiah.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:145
verses.text: On what grounds then has Mark in the very beginning of his book set the words: "As it is written in the prophet Isaiah, Behold I send my messenger," when, as we have said, it is not written in Isaiah at all, but in Malachi the last of the twelve prophets? Let ignorant presumption solve this nice question if it can, and I will ask pardon for being in the wrong.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:146
verses.text: The same Mark brings before us the Saviour thus addressing the Pharisees: "Have ye never read what David did when he had need and was an hungred, he and they that were with him, how he went into the house of God in the days of Abiathar the highpriest, and did eat the shew-bread which is not lawful to eat but for the priests?" Now let us turn to the books of Samuel, or, as they are commonly called, of Kings, and we shall find there that the highpriest's name was not Abiathar but Ahimelech, the same that was afterwards put to death with the rest of the priests by Doeg at the command of Saul.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:147
verses.text: Let us pass on now to the apostle Paul who writes thus to the Corinthians: "For had they known it, they would not have crucified the Lord of glory.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:148
verses.text: But, as it is written, Eye hath not seen nor ear heard, neither have entered into the heart of man, the things which God hath prepared for them that love Him".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:149
verses.text: Some writers on this passage betake themselves to the ravings of the apocryphal books and assert that the quotation comes from the Revelation of Elijah; whereas the truth is that it is found in Isaiah according to the Hebrew text: "Since the beginning of the world men have not heard nor perceived by the ear, neither hath the eye seen, O God, beside thee what thou hast prepared for them that wait for thee".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:150
verses.text: The Septuagint has rendered the words quite differently: "Since the beginning of the world we have not heard, neither have our eyes seen any God beside thee and thy true works, and thou wilt shew mercy to them that wait for thee".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:151
verses.text: We see then from what place the quotation is taken and yet the apostle has not rendered his original word for word, but, using a paraphrase, he has given the sense in different terms.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:152
verses.text: In his epistle to the Romans the same apostle quotes these words from Isaiah: "Behold I lay in Sion a stumbling-stone and rock of offence," a rendering which is at variance with the Greek version yet agrees with the original Hebrew.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:153
verses.text: The Septuagint gives an opposite meaning, "that you fall not on a stumblingstone nor on a rock of offence".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:154
verses.text: The apostle Peter agrees with Paul and the Hebrew, writing: "but to them that do not believe, a stone of stumbling and a rock of offence".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:155
verses.text: From all these passages it is clear that the apostles and evangelists in translating the old testament scriptures have sought to give the meaning rather than the words, and that they have not greatly cared to preserve forms or constructions, so long as they could make clear the subject to the understanding.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:157
verses.text: Luke the evangelist and companion of apostles describes Christ's first martyr Stephen as relating what follows in a Jewish assembly.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:158
verses.text: "With threescore and fifteen souls Jacob went down into Egypt, and died himself, and our fathers were carried over into Sychem, and laid in the sepulchre that Abraham bought for a sum of money of the sons of Emmor the father of Sychem".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:159
verses.text: In Genesis this passage is quite differently given, for it is Abraham that buys of Ephron the Hittite, the son of Zohar, near Hebron, for four hundred shekels of silver, a double cave, and the field that is about it, and that buries in it Sarah his wife.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:160
verses.text: And in the same book we read that, after his return from Mesopotamia with his wives and his sons, Jacob pitched his tent before Salem, a city of Shechem which is in the land of Canaan, and that he dwelt there and "bought a parcel of a field where he had spread his tent at the hand of Hamor, the father of Sychem, for an hundred lambs," and that "he erected there an altar and called there upon the God of Israel".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:161
verses.text: Abraham does not buy the cave from Hamor the father of Sychem, but from Ephron the son of Zohar, and he is not buried in Sychem but in Hebron which is corruptly called Arboch.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:162
verses.text: Whereas the twelve patriarchs are not buried in Arboch but in Sychem, in the field purchased not by Abraham but by Jacob.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:163
verses.text: I postpone the solution of this delicate problem to enable those who cavil at me to search and see that in dealing with the scriptures it is the sense we have to look to and not the words.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:164
verses.text: In the Hebrew the twenty-second psalm begins with the exact words which the Lord uttered on the cross: Eli Eli lama azabthani, which means, "My God, my God, why hast thou forsaken me?" Let my critics tell me why the Septuagint introduces here the words "look thou upon me".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:165
verses.text: For its rendering is as follows: "My God, my God, look thou upon me, why hast thou forsaken me?" They will answer no doubt that no harm is done to the sense by the addition of a couple of words.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:166
verses.text: Let them acknowledge then that, if in the haste of dictation I have omitted a few, I have not by so doing endangered the position of the churches.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:168
verses.text: It would be tedious now to enumerate, what great additions and omissions the Septuagint has made, and all the passages which in church-copies are marked with daggers and asterisks.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:169
verses.text: The Jews generally laugh when they hear our version of this passage of Isaiah, "Blessed is he that hath seed in Zion and servants in Jerusalem".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:170
verses.text: In Amos also after a description of self-indulgence there come these words: "They have thought of these things as halting and not likely to fly," a very rhetorical sentence quite worthy of Tully.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:171
verses.text: But how shall we deal with the Hebrew originals in which these passages and others like them are omitted, passages so numerous that to reproduce them all would require books without number? The number of the omissions is shown alike by the asterisks mentioned above and by my own version when compared by a careful reader with the old translation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:172
verses.text: Yet the Septuagint has rightly kept its place in the churches, either because it is the first of all the versions in time, made before the coming of Christ, or else because it has been used by the apostles (only however in places where it does not disagree with the Hebrew).

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:173
verses.text: On the other hand we do right to reject Aquila, the proselyte and controversial translator, who has striven to translate not words only but their etymologies as well.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:174
verses.text: Who could accept as renderings of "corn and wine and oil" such words as χεῖμα ὀπωρισμός στιλπνότης , or, as we might say, 'pouring,' and 'fruitgathering,' and 'shining'? or, because Hebrew has in addition to the article other prefixes as well, he must with an unhappy pedantry translate syllable by syllable and letter by letter thus: σὺν τὸν ὀυρανὸν καὶ σὺν τὴν γήν, a construction which neither Greek nor Latin admits of, as many passages in our own writers shew.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:175
verses.text: How many are the phrases charming in Greek which, if rendered word for word, do not sound well in Latin, and again how many there are that are pleasing to us in Latin, but which—assuming the order of the words not to be altered—would not please in Greek.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:177
verses.text: But to pass by this limitless field of discussion and to shew you, most Christian of nobles, and most noble of Christians, what is the kind of falsification which is censured in my translation, I will set before you the opening words of the letter in the Greek original and as rendered by me, that from one count in the indictment you may form an opinion of all.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:178
verses.text: The letter begins ῎Εδει ἡμᾶς, ἀγάπητε, μή τῇ οἰ& 208·σει τῶν κλήρων φέρεσθαι which I remember to have rendered as follows: "Dearly beloved, we ought not to misuse our position as ministers to gratify our pride".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:179
verses.text: See there, they cry, what a number of falsehoods in a single line! In the first place ἀγαπητός means 'loved,' not 'dearly beloved.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:180
verses.text: ' Then οἴησις means 'estimate,' not 'pride,' for this and not οἰδημα is the word used.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:181
verses.text: Οιδῆμα signifies 'a swelling' but οἰ& 208·σις means 'judgment.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:182
verses.text: ' All the rest, say they: "not to misuse our position to gratify our pride" is your own.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:183
verses.text: What is this you are saying, O pillar of learning and latter day Aristarchus, who are so ready to pass judgment upon all writers? It is all for nothing then that I have studied so long; that, as Juvenal says, "I have so often withdrawn my hand from the ferule".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:184
verses.text: The moment I leave the harbour I run aground.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:185
verses.text: Well, to err is human and to confess one's error wise.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:186
verses.text: Do you therefore, who are so ready to criticise and to instruct me, set me right and give me a word for word rendering of the passage.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:187
verses.text: You tell me I should have said: "Beloved, we ought not to be carried away by the estimation of the clergy".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:188
verses.text: Here, indeed we have eloquence worthy of Plautus, here we have Attic grace, the true style of the Muses.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:189
verses.text: The common proverb is true of me: "He who trains an ox for athletics loses both oil and money".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:190
verses.text: Still he is not to blame who merely puts on the mask and plays the tragedy for another: his teachers are the real culprits; since they for a great price have taught him—to know nothing.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:191
verses.text: I do not think the worse of any Christian because he lacks skill to express himself; and I heartily wish that we could all say with Socrates "I know that I know nothing;" and carry out the precept of another wise man, "Know thyself".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:192
verses.text: I have always held in esteem a holy simplicity but not a wordy rudeness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:193
verses.text: He who declares that he imitates the style of apostles should first imitate the virtue of their lives; the great holiness of which made up for much plainness of speech.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:194
verses.text: They confuted the syllogisms of Aristotle and the perverse ingenuities of Chrysippus by raising the dead.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:195
verses.text: Still it would be absurd for one of us—living as we do amid the riches of Croesus and the luxuries of Sardanapalus—to make his boast of mere ignorance.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:196
verses.text: We might as well say that all robbers and criminals would be men of culture if they were to hide their blood-stained swords in books of philosophy and not in trunks of trees.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:198
verses.text: I have exceeded the limits of a letter, but I have not exceeded in the expression of my chagrin.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:199
verses.text: For, though I am called a falsifier, and have my reputation torn to shreds, wherever there are shuttles and looms and women to work them; I am content to repudiate the charge without retaliating in kind.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:200
verses.text: I leave everything to your discretion.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:201
verses.text: You can read the letter of Epiphanius both in Greek and in Latin; and, if you do so, you will see at once the value of my accusers' lamentations and insulting complaints.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:202
verses.text: For the rest, I am satisfied to have instructed one of my dearest friends and am content simply to stay quiet in my cell and to wait for the day of judgment.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 57:203
verses.text: If it may be so, and if my enemies allow it, I hope to write for you, not philippics like those of Demosthenes or Tully, but commentaries upon the scriptures.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:1
verses.text: Letter LVIII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:2
verses.text: To Paulinus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:3
verses.text: In this his second letter to Paulinus of Nola Jerome dissuades him from making a pilgrimage to the Holy Places, and describes Jerusalem not as it ought to be but as it is.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:4
verses.text: He then gives his friend counsels for his life similar to those which he has previously addressed to Nepotian, praises Paulinus for his Panegyric (now no longer extant) on the Emperor Theodosius, compares his style with those of the great writers of the Latin Church, and concludes with a commendation of his messenger, that Vigilantius who was soon to become the object of his bitterest contempt.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:5
verses.text: Written about the year 395 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:6
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:8
verses.text: "A good man out of the good treasure of the heart bringeth forth good things," and "every tree is known by his fruit".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:9
verses.text: You measure me by the scale of your own virtues and because of your own greatness magnify my littleness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:10
verses.text: You take the lowest room at the banquet that the goodman of the house may bid you to go up higher.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:11
verses.text: For what is there in me or what qualities do I possess that I should merit praise from a man of learning? that I, small and lowly as I am, should be eulogized by lips which have pleaded on behalf of our most religious sovereign? Do not, my dearest brother, estimate my worth by the number of my years.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:12
verses.text: Gray hairs are not wisdom; it is wisdom which is as good as gray hairs.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:13
verses.text: At least that is what Solomon says: "wisdom is the gray hair unto men".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:14
verses.text: Moses too in choosing the seventy elders is told to take those whom he knows to be elders indeed, and to select them not for their years but for their discretion.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:15
verses.text: And, as a boy, Daniel judges old men and in the flower of youth condemns the incontinence of age.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:16
verses.text: Do not, I repeat, weigh faith by years, nor suppose me better than yourself merely because I have enlisted under Christ's banner earlier than you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:17
verses.text: The apostle Paul, that chosen vessel framed out of a persecutor, though last in the apostolic order is first in merit.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:18
verses.text: For though last he has laboured more than they all.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:19
verses.text: To Judas it was once said: thou art a man who didst take sweet food with me, my guide and mine acquaintance; we walked in the house of God with company:" yet the Saviour accuses him of betraying his friend and master.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:20
verses.text: A line of Virgil well describes his end:  From a high beam he knots a hideous death.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:21
verses.text: The dying robber, on the contrary, exchanges the cross for paradise and turns to martyrdom the penalty of murder.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:22
verses.text: How many there are nowadays who have lived so long that they bear corpses rather than bodies and are like whited sepulchres filled with dead men's bones! A newly kindled heat is more effective than a long continued lukewarmness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:24
verses.text: As for you, when you hear the Saviour's counsel: "if thou wilt be perfect, go and sell that thou hast, and give to the poor, and come follow me," you translate his words into action; and baring yourself to follow the bare cross you mount Jacob's ladder the easier for carrying nothing.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:25
verses.text: Your dress changes with the change in your convictions, and you aim at no showy shabbiness which leaves your purse as full as before.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:26
verses.text: No, with pure hands and a clear conscience you make it your glory that you are poor both in spirit and in deed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:27
verses.text: There is nothing great in wearing a sad or a disfigured face, in simulating and in showing off fasts, or in wearing a cheap cloak while you retain a large income.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:28
verses.text: When Crates the Theban—a millionaire of days gone by—was on his way to Athens to study philosophy, he cast away untold gold in the belief that wealth could not be compatible with virtue.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:29
verses.text: What a contrast he offers to us, the disciples of a poor Christ, who cram our pockets with gold and cling under pretext of almsgiving to our old riches.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:30
verses.text: How can we faithfully distribute what belongs to another when we thus timidly keep back what is our own? When the stomach is full, it is easy to talk of fasting.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:31
verses.text: What is praiseworthy is not to have been at Jerusalem but to have lived a good life while there.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:32
verses.text: The city which we are to praise and to seek is not that which has slain the prophets and shed the blood of Christ, but that which is made glad by the streams of the river, which is set upon a mountain and so cannot be hid, which the apostle declares to be a mother of the saints, and in which he rejoices to have his citizenship with the righteous.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:34
verses.text: In speaking thus I am not laying myself open to a charge of inconsistency or condemning the course which I have myself taken.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:35
verses.text: It is not, I believe, for nothing that I, like Abraham, have left my home and people.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:36
verses.text: But I do not presume to limit God's omnipotence or to restrict to a narrow strip of earth Him whom the heaven cannot contain.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:37
verses.text: Each believer is judged not by his residence in this place or in that but according to the deserts of his faith.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:38
verses.text: The true worshippers worship the Father neither at Jerusalem nor on mount Gerizim; for "God is a spirit, and they that worship Him must worship Him in spirit and in truth".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:39
verses.text: "Now the spirit bloweth where it listeth," and "the earth is the Lord's and the fulness thereof".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:40
verses.text: When the fleece of Judaea was made dry although the whole world was wet with the dew of heaven, and when many came from the East and from the West and sat in Abraham's bosom: then God ceased to be known in Judah only and His name to be great in Israel alone; the sound of the apostles went out into all the earth and their words into the ends of the world.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:41
verses.text: The Saviour Himself speaking to His disciples in the temple said: "arise, let us go hence," and to the Jews: "your house is left unto you desolate".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:42
verses.text: If heaven and earth must pass away, obviously all things that are earthly must pass away also.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:43
verses.text: Therefore the spots which witnessed the crucifixion and the resurrection profit those only who bear their several crosses, who day by day rise again with Christ, and who thus shew themselves worthy of an abode so holy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:44
verses.text: Those who say "the temple of the Lord, the temple of the Lord," should give ear to the words of the apostle: "ye are the temple of the Lord," and the Holy Ghost "dwelleth in you".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:45
verses.text: Access to the courts of heaven is as easy from Britain as it is from Jerusalem; for "the kingdom of God is within you".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:46
verses.text: Antony and the hosts of monks who are in Egypt, Mesopotamia, Pontus, Cappadocia, and Armenia, have never seen Jerusalem: and the door of Paradise is opened for them at a distance from it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:47
verses.text: The blessed Hilarion, though a native of and a dweller in Palestine, only set eyes on Jerusalem for a single day, not wishing on the one hand when he was so near to neglect the holy places, nor yet on the other to appear to confine God within local limits.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:48
verses.text: From the time of Hadrian to the reign of Constantine—a period of about one hundred and eighty years—the spot which had witnessed the resurrection was occupied by a figure of Jupiter; while on the rock where the cross had stood, a marble statue of Venus was set up by the heathen and became an object of worship.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:49
verses.text: The original persecutors, indeed, supposed that by polluting our holy places they would deprive us of our faith in the passion and in the resurrection.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:50
verses.text: Even my own Bethlehem, as it now is, that most venerable spot in the whole world of which the psalmist sings: "the truth hath sprung out of the earth," was overshadowed by a grove of Tammuz, that is of Adonis; and in the very cave where the infant Christ had uttered His earliest cry lamentation was made for the paramour of Venus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:52
verses.text: Why, you will say, do I make these remote allusions? To assure you that nothing is lacking to your faith although you have not seen Jerusalem and that I am none the better for living where I do.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:53
verses.text: Be assured that, whether you dwell here or elsewhere, a like recompense is in store for your good works with our Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:54
verses.text: Indeed, if I am frankly to express my own feelings, when I take into consideration your vows and the earnestness with which you have renounced the world, I hold that as long as you live in the country one place is as good as another.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:55
verses.text: Forsake cities and their crowds, live on a small patch of ground, seek Christ in solitude, pray on the mount alone with Jesus, keep near to holy places: keep out of cities, I say, and you will never lose your vocation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:56
verses.text: My advice concerns not bishops, presbyters, or the clergy, for these have a different duty.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:57
verses.text: I am speaking only to a monk who having been a man of note in the world has laid the price of his possessions at the apostles' feet, to shew men that they must trample on their money, and has resolved to live a life of loneliness and seclusion and always to continue to reject what he has once rejected.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:58
verses.text: Had the scenes of the Passion and of the Resurrection been elsewhere than in a populous city with court and garrison, with prostitutes, playactors, and buffoons, and with the medley of persons usually found in such centres; or had the crowds which thronged it been composed of monks; then a city would be a desirable abode for those who have embraced the monastic life.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:59
verses.text: But, as things are, it would be the height of folly first to renounce the world, to forswear one's country, to forsake cities, to profess one's self a monk; and then to live among still greater numbers the same kind of life that you would have lived in your own country.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:60
verses.text: Men rush here from all quarters of the world, the city is filled with people of every race, and so great is the throng of men and women that here you will have to tolerate in its full dimensions an evil from which you desired to flee when you found it partially developed elsewhere.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:62
verses.text: Since you ask me as a brother in what path you should walk, I will be open with you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:63
verses.text: If you wish to take duty as a presbyter, and are attracted by the work or dignity which falls to the lot of a bishop, live in cities and walled towns, and by so doing turn the salvation of others into the profit of your own soul.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:64
verses.text: But if you desire to be in deed what you are in name—a monk, that is, one who lives alone, what have you to do with cities which are the homes not of solitaries but of crowds? Every mode of life has its own exponents.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:65
verses.text: For instance, let Roman generals imitate men like Camillus, Fabricius, Regulus, and Scipio.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:66
verses.text: Let philosophers take for models Pythagoras, Socrates, Plato, and Aristotle.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:67
verses.text: Let poets strive to rival Homer, Virgil, Menander, and Terence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:68
verses.text: Let writers of history follow Thucydides, Sallust, Herodotus and Livy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:69
verses.text: Let orators find masters in Lysias, the Gracchi, Demosthenes, and Tully.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:70
verses.text: And, to come to our own case, let bishops and presbyters take for their examples the apostles or their companions; and as they hold the rank which these once held, let them endeavour to exhibit the same excellence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:71
verses.text: And last of all let us monks take as the patterns which we are to follow the lives of Paul, of Antony, of Julian, of Hilarion, of the Macarii.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:72
verses.text: And to go back to the authority of scripture, we have our masters in Elijah and Elisha, and our leaders in the sons of the prophets; who lived in fields and solitary places and made themselves tents by the waters of Jordan.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:73
verses.text: The sons of Rechab too are of the number who drank neither wine nor strong drink and who abode in tents; men whom God's voice praises through Jeremiah, and to whom a promise is made that there shall never be wanting a man of their stock to stand before God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:74
verses.text: This is probably what is meant by the title of the seventy-first psalm: "of the sons of Jonadab and of those who were first led into captivity".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:75
verses.text: The person intended is Jonadab the son of Rechab who is described in the book of Kings as having gone up into the chariot of Jehu.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:76
verses.text: His sons having always lived in tents until at last (owing to the inroads made by the Chaldean army) they were forced to come into Jerusalem, are described as being the first to undergo captivity; because after the freedom of their lonely life they found confinement in a city as bad as imprisonment.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:78
verses.text: Since you are not wholly independent but are bound to a wife who is your sister in the Lord, I entreat you—whether here or there—that you will avoid large gatherings, visits official and complimentary, and social parties, indulgences all of which tend to enchain the soul.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:79
verses.text: Let your food be coarse—say cabbage and pulse—and do not take it until evening.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:80
verses.text: Sometimes as a great delicacy you may have some small fish.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:81
verses.text: He who longs for Christ and feeds upon the true bread cares little for dainties which must be transmuted into ordure.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:82
verses.text: Food that you cannot taste when once it has passed your gullet might as well be—so far as you are concerned—bread and pulse.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:83
verses.text: You have my books against Jovinian which speak yet more largely of despising the appetite and the palate.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:84
verses.text: Let some holy volume be ever in your hand.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:85
verses.text: Pray constantly, and bowing down your body lift up your mind to the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:86
verses.text: Keep frequent vigils and sleep often on an empty stomach.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:87
verses.text: Avoid tittle-tattle and all self-laudation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:88
verses.text: Flee from wheedling flatterers as from open enemies.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:89
verses.text: Distribute with your own hand provisions to alleviate the miseries of the poor and of the brethren.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:90
verses.text: With your own hands, I say, for good faith is rare among men.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:91
verses.text: You do not believe what I say? Think of Judas and his bag.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:92
verses.text: Seek not a lowly garb for a swelling soul.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:93
verses.text: Avoid the society of men of the world, especially if they are in power.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:94
verses.text: Why need you look again on things contempt for which has made you a monk? Above all let your sister hold aloof from married ladies.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:95
verses.text: And, if women round her wear silk dresses and gems while she is meanly attired, let her neither fret nor congratulate herself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:96
verses.text: For by so doing she will either regret her resolution or sow the seeds of pride.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:97
verses.text: If you are already famed as a faithful steward of your own substance, do not take other people's money to give away.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:98
verses.text: You understand what I mean, for the Lord has given you understanding in all things.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:99
verses.text: Be simple as a dove and lay snares for no man: but be cunning as a serpent and let no man lay snares for you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:100
verses.text: For a Christian who allows others to deceive him is almost at much at fault as one who tries to deceive others.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:101
verses.text: If a man talks to you always or nearly always about money (except it be about alms-giving, a topic which is open to all) treat him as a broker rather than a monk.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:102
verses.text: Besides food and clothing and things manifestly necessary give no man anything; for dogs must not eat the children's bread.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:104
verses.text: The true temple of Christ is the believer's soul; adorn this, clothe it, offer gifts to it, welcome Christ in it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:105
verses.text: What use are walls blazing with jewels when Christ in His poor is in danger of perishing from hunger? Your possessions are no longer your own but a stewardship is entrusted to you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:106
verses.text: Remember Ananias and Sapphira who from fear of the future kept what was their own, and be careful for your part not rashly to squander what is Christ's.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:107
verses.text: Do not, that is, by an error of judgment give the property of the poor to those who are not poor; lest, as a wise man has told us, charity prove the death of charity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:108
verses.text: Look not upon  Gay trappings or a Cato's empty name.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:109
verses.text: In the words of Persius, God says:—  I know thy thoughts and read thine inmost soul.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:110
verses.text: To be a Christian is the great thing, not merely to seem one.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:111
verses.text: And somehow or other those please the world most who please Christ least.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:112
verses.text: In speaking thus I am not like the sow lecturing Minerva; but, as a friend warns a friend, so I warn you before you embark on your new course.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:113
verses.text: I would rather fail in ability than in will to serve you; for my wish is that where I have fallen you may keep your footing.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:115
verses.text: It is with much pleasure that I have read the book which you have sent to me containing your wise and eloquent defence of the emperor Theodosius; and your arrangement of the subject has particularly pleased me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:116
verses.text: While in the earlier chapters you surpass others, in the latter you surpass yourself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:117
verses.text: Your style is terse and neat; it has all the purity of Tully, and yet it is packed with meaning.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:118
verses.text: For, as someone has said, that speech is a failure of which men only praise the diction.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:119
verses.text: You have been successful in preserving both sequence of subjects and logical connexion.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:120
verses.text: Whatever sentence one takes, it is always a conclusion to what goes before or an introduction to what follows.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:121
verses.text: Theodosius is fortunate in having a Christian orator like you to plead his cause.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:122
verses.text: You have made his purple illustrious and have consecrated for future ages his useful laws.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:123
verses.text: Go on and prosper, for, if such be your first ventures in the field, what will you not do when you become a trained soldier? Oh! that it were mine to conduct a genius like you, not (as the poets sing) through the Aonian mountains and the peaks of Helicon but through Zion and Tabor and the high places of Sinai.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:124
verses.text: If I might teach you what I have learned myself and might pass on to you the mystic rolls of the prophets, then might we give birth to something such as Greece with all her learning could not shew.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:126
verses.text: Hear me, therefore, my fellow-servant, my friend, my brother; give ear for a moment that I may tell you how you are to walk in the holy scriptures.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:127
verses.text: All that we read in the divine books, while glistening and shining without, is yet far sweeter within.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:128
verses.text: "He who desires to eat the kernel must first break the nut".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:129
verses.text: "Open thou mine eyes," says David, "that I may behold wondrous things out of thy law".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:130
verses.text: Now, if so great a prophet confesses that he is in the darkness of ignorance; how deep, think you, must be the night of misapprehension with which we, mere babes and unweaned infants, are enveloped! Now this veil rests not only on the face of Moses, but on the evangelists and the apostles as well.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:131
verses.text: To the multitudes the Saviour spoke only in parables and, to make it clear that His words had a mystical meaning, said:—"he that hath ears to hear, let him hear".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:132
verses.text: Unless all things that are written are opened by Him "who hath the key of David, who openeth and no man shutteth, and shutteth and no man openeth," no one can undo the lock or set them before you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:133
verses.text: If only you had the foundation which He alone can give; nay, if even His fingers were but passed over your work; there would be nothing finer than your volumes, nothing more learned, nothing more attractive, nothing more Latin.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:135
verses.text: Tertullian is packed with meaning but his style is rugged and uncouth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:136
verses.text: The blessed Cyprian like a fountain of pure water flows softly and sweetly but, as he is taken up with exhortations to virtue and with the troubles consequent on persecution, he has nowhere discussed the divine scriptures.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:137
verses.text: Victorinus, although he has the glory of a martyr's crown, yet cannot express what he knows.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:138
verses.text: Lactantius has a flow of eloquence worthy of Tully: would that he had been as ready to teach our doctrines as he was to pull down those of others! Arnobius is lengthy and unequal, and often confused from not making a proper division of his subject.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:139
verses.text: That reverend man Hilary gains in height from his Gallic buskin; yet, adorned as he is with the flowers of Greek rhetoric, he sometimes entangles himself in long periods and offers by no means easy reading to the less learned brethren.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:140
verses.text: I say nothing of other writers whether dead or living; others will hereafter judge them both for good and for evil.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:142
verses.text: I will come to yourself, my fellow-mystic, my companion, and my friend; my friend, I say, though not yet personally known: and I will ask you not to suspect a flatterer in one so intimate.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:143
verses.text: Better that you should think me mistaken or led astray by affection than that you should hold me capable of fawning on a friend.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:144
verses.text: You have a great intellect and an inexhaustible store of language, your diction is fluent and pure, your fluency and purity are mingled with wisdom.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:145
verses.text: Your head is clear and all your senses keen.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:146
verses.text: Were you to add to this wisdom and eloquence a careful study and knowledge of scripture, I should soon see you holding our citadel against all comers; you would go up with Joab upon the roof of Zion, and sing upon the housetops what you had learned in the secret chambers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:147
verses.text: Gird up, I pray you, gird up your loins.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:148
verses.text: As Horace says:—  Life hath no gifts for men except they toil.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:149
verses.text: Shew yourself as much a man of note in the church, as you were before in the senate.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:150
verses.text: Provide for yourself riches which you may spend daily yet they will not fail.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:151
verses.text: Provide them while you are still strong and while as yet your head has no gray hairs: before, in the words of Virgil,  Diseases creep on you, and gloomy age,  And pain, and cruel death's inclemency.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:152
verses.text: I am not content with mediocrity for you: I desire all that you do to be of the highest excellence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:153
verses.text: How heartily I have welcomed the reverend presbyter Vigilantius, his own lips will tell you better than this letter.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:154
verses.text: Why he has so soon left us and started afresh I cannot say; and, indeed, I do not wish to hurt anyone's feelings.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:155
verses.text: Still, mere passer-by as he was, in haste to continue his journey, I managed to keep him back until I had given him a taste of my friendship for you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:156
verses.text: Thus you can learn from him what you want to know about me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 58:157
verses.text: Kindly salute your reverend sister and fellow-servant, who with you fights the good fight in the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 59:1
verses.text: Letter LIX.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 59:2
verses.text: To Marcella.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 59:3
verses.text: An answer to five questions put to Jerome by Marcella in a letter not preserved.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 59:4
verses.text: The questions are as follows.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 59:5
verses.text: (1) What are the things which eye hath not seen nor ear heard (1 Cor.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 59:6
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 59:7
verses.text: 9)? Jerome answers that they are spiritual things which as such can only be spiritually discerned.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 59:8
verses.text: (2) Is it not a mistake to identify the sheep and the goats of Christ's parable (Matt.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 59:9
verses.text: xxv.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 59:10
verses.text: 31 sqq.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 59:11
verses.text: ) with Christians and heathens? Are they not rather the good and the bad? For an answer to this question Jerome refers Marcella to his treatise against Jovinian (II.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 59:13
verses.text: (3) Paul says that some shall be "alive and remain unto the coming of the Lord;" and that they shall be "caught up to meet the Lord in the air" (1 Thess.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 59:14
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 59:16
verses.text: Are we to suppose this assumption to be corporeal and that those assumed will escape death? Yes, Jerome answers, but their bodies will be glorified.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 59:17
verses.text: (4) How is John xx.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 59:18
verses.text: 17, "touch me not," to be reconciled with Matt.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 59:19
verses.text: xxviii.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 59:20
verses.text: 9, "they came and held him by the feet"? In the one case, Jerome replies, Mary Magdalen failed to recognize the divinity of Jesus; in the other the women recognized it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 59:21
verses.text: Accordingly they were admitted to a privilege which was denied to her.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 59:22
verses.text: (5) Was the risen Christ before His ascension present only with the disciples, or was He in heaven and elsewhere as well? The latter according to Jerome is the true doctrine.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 59:23
verses.text: "The Divine Nature," he writes, "exists everywhere in its entirety.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 59:24
verses.text: Christ, therefore, was at one and the same time with the apostles and with the angels; in the Father and in the uttermost parts of the sea.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 59:25
verses.text: So afterwards he was with Thomas in India, with Peter at Rome, with Paul in Illyricum, with Titus in Crete, with Andrew in Achaia".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 59:26
verses.text: The date of the letter is a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 59:27
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 59:28
verses.text: 395 or a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 59:29
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:1
verses.text: Letter LX.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:2
verses.text: To Heliodorus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:3
verses.text: One of Jerome's finest letters, written to console his old friend, Heliodorus, now Bp.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:4
verses.text: of Altinum, for the loss of his nephew Nepotian who had died of fever a short time previously.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:5
verses.text: Jerome tries to soothe his friend's grief (1) by contrasting pagan despair or resignation with Christian hope, (2) by an eulogy of the departed both as man and presbyter, and (3) by a review of the evils which then beset the Empire and from which, as he contended, Nepotian had been removed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:6
verses.text: The letter is marked throughout with deep and sincere feeling.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:7
verses.text: Its date is 396 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:8
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:10
verses.text: Small wits cannot grapple large themes but venturing beyond their strength fail in the very attempt; and, the greater a subject is, the more completely is he overwhelmed who cannot find words to unfold its grandeur.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:11
verses.text: Nepotian who was mine and yours and ours—or rather who was Christ's and because Christ's all the more ours—has forsaken us his elders so that we are smitten with pangs of regret and overcome with a grief which is past bearing.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:12
verses.text: We supposed him our heir, yet now his corpse is all that is ours.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:13
verses.text: For whom shall my intellect now labour? Whom shall my poor letters desire to please? Where is he, the impeller of my work, whose voice was sweeter than a swan's last song? My mind is dazed, my hand trembles, a mist covers my eyes, stammering seizes my tongue.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:14
verses.text: Whatever my words, they seem as good as unspoken seeing that he no longer hears them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:15
verses.text: My very pen seems to feel his loss, my very wax tablet looks dull and sad; the one is covered with rust, the other with mould.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:16
verses.text: As often as I try to express myself in words and to scatter the flowers of this encomium upon his tomb, my eyes fill with tears, my grief returns, and I can think of nothing but his death.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:17
verses.text: It was a custom in former days for children over the dead bodies of their parents publicly to proclaim their praises and (as when pathetic songs are sung) to draw tears from the eyes and sighs from the breasts of those who heard them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:18
verses.text: But in our case, behold, the order of things is changed: to deal us this blow nature has forfeited her rights.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:19
verses.text: For the respect which the young man should have paid to his elders, we his elders are paying to him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:21
verses.text: What shall I do then? Shall I join my tears to yours? The apostle forbids me for he speaks of dead Christians as "them which are asleep".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:22
verses.text: So too in the gospel the Lord says, "the damsel is not dead but sleepeth," and Lazarus when he is raised from the dead is said to have been asleep.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:23
verses.text: No, I will be glad and rejoice that "speedily he was taken away lest that wickedness should alter his understanding" for "his soul pleased the Lord".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:24
verses.text: But though I am loth to give way and combat my feelings, tears flow down my cheeks, and in spite of the teachings of virtue and the hope of the resurrection a passion of regret crushes my too yielding mind.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:25
verses.text: O death that dividest brothers knit together in love, how cruel, how ruthless thou art so to sunder them! "The Lord hath fetched a burning wind that cometh up from the wilderness: which hath dried thy veins and hath made thy well spring desolate".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:26
verses.text: Thou didst swallow up our Jonah, but even in thy belly He still lived.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:27
verses.text: Thou didst carry Him as one dead, that the world's storm might be stilled and our Nineveh saved by His preaching.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:28
verses.text: He, yes He, conquered thee, He slew thee, that fugitive prophet who left His home, gave up His inheritance and surrendered his dear life into the hands of those who sought it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:29
verses.text: He it was who of old threatened thee in Hosea: "O death, I will be thy plagues; O grave, I will be thy destruction".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:30
verses.text: By His death thou art dead; by His death we live.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:31
verses.text: Thou hast swallowed up and thou art swallowed up.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:32
verses.text: Whilst thou art smitten with a longing for the body assumed by Him, and whilst thy greedy jaws fancy it a prey, thy inward parts are wounded with hooked fangs.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:34
verses.text: To Thee, O Saviour Christ, do we Thy creatures offer thanks that, when Thou wast slain, Thou didst slay our mighty adversary.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:35
verses.text: Before Thy coming was there any being more miserable than man who cowering at the dread prospect of eternal death did but receive life that he might perish! For "death reigned from Adam to Moses even over them that had not sinned after the similitude of Adam's transgression".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:36
verses.text: If Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob be in hell, who can be in the kingdom of heaven? If Thy friends—even those who had not sinned themselves—were yet for the sins of another liable to the punishment of offending Adam, what must we think of those who have said in their hearts "There is no God;" who "are corrupt and abominable" in their self-will, and of whom it is said "they are gone out of the way, they are become unprofitable; there is none that doeth good, no not one"? Even if Lazarus is seen in Abraham's bosom and in a place of refreshment, still the lower regions cannot be compared with the kingdom of heaven.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:37
verses.text: Before Christ's coming Abraham is in the lower regions: after Christ's coming the robber is in paradise.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:38
verses.text: And therefore at His rising again "many bodies of the saints which slept arose, and were seen in the heavenly Jerusalem".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:39
verses.text: Then was fulfilled the saying: "Awake thou that sleepest, and arise from the dead, and Christ shall give thee light".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:40
verses.text: John the Baptist cries in the desert: "repent ye; for the kingdom of heaven is at hand".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:41
verses.text: For "from the days of John the Baptist the kingdom of heaven suffereth violence and the violent take it by force".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:42
verses.text: The flaming sword that keeps the way of paradise and the cherubim that are stationed at its doors are alike quenched and unloosed by the blood of Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:43
verses.text: It is not surprising that this should be promised us in the resurrection: for as many of us as living in the flesh do not live after the flesh, have our citizenship in heaven, and while we are still here on earth we are told that "the kingdom of heaven is within us".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:45
verses.text: Moreover before the resurrection of Christ God was "known in Judah" only and "His name was great in Israel" alone.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:46
verses.text: And they who knew Him were despite their knowledge dragged down to hell.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:47
verses.text: Where in those days were the inhabitants of the globe from India to Britain, from the frozen zone of the North to the burning heat of the Atlantic ocean? Where were the countless peoples of the world? Where the great multitudes?  Unlike in tongue, unlike in dress and arms?  They were crushed like fishes and locusts, like flies and gnats.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:48
verses.text: For apart from knowledge of his Creator every man is but a brute.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:49
verses.text: But now the voices and writings of all nations proclaim the passion and the resurrection of Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:50
verses.text: I say nothing of the Jews, the Greeks, and the Romans, peoples which the Lord has dedicated to His faith by the title written on His cross.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:51
verses.text: The immortality of the soul and its continuance after the dissolution of the body—truths of which Pythagoras dreamed, which Democritus refused to believe, and which Socrates discussed in prison to console himself for the sentence passed upon him—are now the familiar themes of Indian and of Persian, of Goth and of Egyptian.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:52
verses.text: The fierce Bessians and the throng of skinclad savages who used to offer human sacrifices in honour of the dead have broken out of their harsh discord into the sweet music of the cross and Christ is the one cry of the whole world.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:54
verses.text: What can we do, my soul? Whither must we turn? What must we take up first? What must we pass over? Have you forgotten the precepts of the rhetoricians? Are you so preoccupied with grief, so overcome with tears, so hindered with sobs, that you forget all logical sequence? Where are the studies you have pursued from your childhood? Where is that saying of Anaxagoras and Telamon (which you have always commended) "I knew myself to have begotten a mortal"? I have read the books of Crantor which he wrote to soothe his grief and which Cicero has imitated.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:55
verses.text: I have read the consolatory writings of Plato, Diogenes, Clitomachus, Carneades, Posidonius, who at different times strove by book or letter to lessen the grief of various persons.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:56
verses.text: Consequently, were my own wit to dry up, it could be watered anew from the fountains which these have opened.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:57
verses.text: They set before us examples without number; and particularly those of Pericles and of Socrates's pupil Xenophon.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:58
verses.text: The former of these after the loss of his two sons put on a garland and delivered a harangue; while the latter, on hearing when he was offering sacrifice that his son had been slain in war, is said to have laid down his garland; and then, on learning that he had fallen fighting bravely, is said to have put it on his head again.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:59
verses.text: What shall I say of those Roman generals whose heroic virtues glitter like stars on the pages of Latin history? Pulvillus was dedicating the capitol when receiving the news of his son's sudden death, he gave orders that the funeral should take place without him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:60
verses.text: Lucius Paullus entered the city in triumph in the week which intervened between the funerals of his two sons.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:61
verses.text: I pass over the Maximi, the Catos, the Galli, the Pisos, the Bruti, the Scaevolas, the Metelli, the Scauri, the Marii, the Crassi, the Marcelli, the Aufidii, men who shewed equal fortitude in sorrow and war, and whose bereavements Tully has set forth in his book Of consolation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:62
verses.text: I pass them over lest I should seem to have chosen the words and woes of others in preference to my own.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:63
verses.text: Yet even these instances may suffice to ensure us mortification if our faith fails to surpass the achievements of unbelief.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:65
verses.text: Let me come then to my proper subject.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:66
verses.text: I will not beat my breast with Jacob and with David for sons dying in the Law, but I will receive them rising again with Christ in the Gospel.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:67
verses.text: The Jew's mourning is the Christian's joy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:68
verses.text: "Weeping may endure for a night but joy cometh in the morning".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:69
verses.text: "The night is far spent, the day is at hand".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:70
verses.text: Accordingly when Moses dies, mourning is made for him, but when Joshua is buried, it is without tears or funeral pomp.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:71
verses.text: All that can be drawn from scripture on the subject of lamentation I have briefly set forth in the letter of consolation which I addressed to Paula at Rome.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:72
verses.text: Now I must take another path to arrive at the same goal.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:73
verses.text: Otherwise I shall seem to be walking anew in a track once beaten but now long disused.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:75
verses.text: We know indeed that our Nepotian is with Christ and that he has joined the choirs of the saints.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:76
verses.text: What here with us he groped after on earth afar off and sought for to the best of his judgment, there he sees nigh at hand, so that he can say: "as we have heard so have we seen in the city of the Lord of hosts, in the city of our God".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:77
verses.text: Still we cannot bear the feeling of his absence, and grieve, if not for him, for ourselves.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:78
verses.text: The greater the happiness which he enjoys, the deeper the sorrow in which the loss of a blessing so great plunges us.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:79
verses.text: The sisters of Lazarus could not help weeping for him, although they knew that he would rise again.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:80
verses.text: And the Saviour himself—to shew that he possessed true human feeling—mourned for him whom He was about to raise.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:81
verses.text: His apostle also, though he says: "I desire to depart and to be with Christ," and elsewhere "to me to live is Christ and to die is gain," thanks God that Epaphras (who had been "sick nigh unto death") has been given back to him that he might not have sorrow upon sorrow.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:82
verses.text: Words prompted not by the fear that springs of unbelief but by the passionate regret that comes of true affection.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:83
verses.text: How much more deeply must you who were to Nepotian both uncle and bishop, (that is, a father both in the flesh and in the spirit), deplore the loss of one so dear, as though your heart were torn from you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:84
verses.text: Set a limit, I pray you, to your sorrow and remember the saying "in nothing overmuch".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:85
verses.text: Bind up for a little while your wound and listen to the praises of one in whose virtue you have always delighted.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:86
verses.text: Do not grieve that you have lost such a paragon: rejoice rather that he has once been yours.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:87
verses.text: As on a small tablet men depict the configuration of the earth, so in this little scroll of mine you may see his virtues if not fully depicted at least sketched in outline.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:88
verses.text: I beg that you will take the will for the performance.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:90
verses.text: The advice of the rhetoricians in such cases is that you should first search out the remote ancestors of the person to be eulogized and recount their exploits, and then come gradually to your hero; so as to make him more illustrious by the virtues of his forefathers, and to show either that he is a worthy successor of good men, or that he has conferred lustre upon a lineage in itself obscure.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:91
verses.text: But as my duty is to sing the praises of the soul, I will not dwell upon those fleshly advantages which Nepotian for his part always despised.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:92
verses.text: Nor will I boast of his family, that is of the good points belonging not to him but to others; for even those holy men Abraham and Isaac had for sons the sinners Ishmael and Esau.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:93
verses.text: And on the other hand Jephthah who is reckoned by the apostle in the roll of the righteous is the son of a harlot.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:94
verses.text: It is said "the soul that sinneth, it shall die".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:95
verses.text: The soul therefore that has not sinned shall live.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:96
verses.text: Neither the virtues nor the vices of parents are imputed to their children.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:97
verses.text: God takes account of us only from the time when we are born anew in Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:98
verses.text: Paul, the persecutor of the church, who is in the morning the ravening wolf of Benjamin, in the evening "gave food," that is yields himself up to the sheep Ananias.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:99
verses.text: Let us likewise reckon our Nepotian a crying babe and an untutored child who has been born to us in a moment fresh from the waters of Jordan.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:101
verses.text: Another would perhaps describe how for his salvation you left the east and the desert and how you soothed me your dearest comrade by holding out hopes of a return: and all this that you might save, if possible, both your sister, then a widow with one little child, or, should she reject your counsels, at any rate your sweet little nephew.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:102
verses.text: It was of him that I once used the prophetic words: "though your little nephew cling to your neck".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:103
verses.text: Another, I say, would relate how while Nepotian was still in the service of the court, beneath his uniform and his brilliantly white linen, his skin was chafed with sackcloth; how, while standing before the powers of this world, his lips were discoloured with fasting; how still in the uniform of one master he served another; and how he wore the sword-belt only that he might succour widows and wards, the afflicted and the unhappy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:104
verses.text: For my part I dislike men to delay the complete dedication of themselves to God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:105
verses.text: When I read of the centurion Cornelius that he was a just man I immediately hear of his baptism.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:107
verses.text: Still we may approve these things as the swathing bands of an infant faith.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:108
verses.text: He who has been a loyal soldier under a strange banner is sure to deserve the laurel when he comes to serve his own king.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:109
verses.text: When Nepotian laid aside his baldrick and changed his dress, he bestowed upon the poor all the pay that he had received.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:110
verses.text: For he had read the words: "if thou wilt be perfect, sell that thou hast, and give to the poor and follow me," and again: "ye cannot serve two masters, God and Mammon".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:111
verses.text: He kept nothing for himself but a common tunic and cloak to cover him and to keep out the cold.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:112
verses.text: Made in the fashion of his province his attire was not remarkable either for elegance or for squalor.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:113
verses.text: He burned daily to make his way to the monasteries of Egypt, or to visit the communities of Mesopotamia, or at least to live a lonely life in the Dalmatian islands, separated from the mainland only by the strait of Altinum.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:114
verses.text: But he had not the heart to forsake his episcopal uncle in whom he beheld a pattern of many virtues and from whom he could take lessons without going abroad.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:115
verses.text: In one and the same person he both found a monk to imitate and a bishop to revere.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:116
verses.text: What so often happens did not happen here.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:117
verses.text: Constant intimacy did not produce familiarity, nor did familiarity breed contempt.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:118
verses.text: He revered him as a father and every day admired him for some new virtue.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:119
verses.text: To be brief, he became a clergyman, and after passing through the usual stages was ordained a presbyter.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:120
verses.text: Good Jesus! how he sighed and groaned! how he fasted and fled the eyes of all! For the first and only time he was angry with his uncle, complaining that the burthen laid upon him was too heavy for him and that his youth unfitted him for the priesthood.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:121
verses.text: But the more he struggled against it, the more he drew to himself the hearts of all: his refusal did but prove him worthy of an office which he was reluctant to assume, and all the more worthy because he declared himself unworthy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:122
verses.text: We too in our day have our Timothy; we too have seen that wisdom which is as good as gray hairs; our Moses has chosen an elder whom he has known to be an elder indeed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:123
verses.text: Nepotian regarded the clerical state less as an honour than a burthen.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:124
verses.text: He made it his first care to silence envy by humility, and his next to give no cause for scandal that such as assailed his youth might marvel at his continence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:125
verses.text: He helped the poor, visited the sick, stirred men up to hospitality, soothed them with soft words, rejoiced with those who rejoiced and wept with those who wept.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:126
verses.text: He was a staff to the blind, food to the hungry, hope to the dejected, consolation to the bereaved.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:127
verses.text: Each single virtue was as conspicuous in him as if he possessed no other.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:128
verses.text: Among his fellow-presbyters while ever foremost in work, he was ever satisfied with the lowest place.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:129
verses.text: Any good that he did he ascribed to his uncle: but if the result did not correspond to his expectations, he would say that his uncle knew nothing of it, that it was his own mistake.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:130
verses.text: In public he recognized him as a bishop; at home he looked upon him as a father.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:131
verses.text: The seriousness of his disposition was mitigated by a cheerful expression.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:132
verses.text: But while his laughter was joyous it was never loud.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:133
verses.text: Christ's virgins and widows he honoured as mothers and exhorted as sisters "with all purity".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:134
verses.text: When he returned home he used to leave the clergyman outside and to give himself over to the hard rule of a monk.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:135
verses.text: Frequent in supplication and watchful in prayer he would offer his tears not to man but to God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:136
verses.text: His fasts he regulated—as a driver does the pace of his horses—according to the weariness or vigour of his body.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:137
verses.text: When at his uncle's table he would just taste what was set before him, so as to avoid superstition and yet to preserve self-control.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:138
verses.text: In conversing at entertainments his habit was to propose some topic from scripture, to listen modestly, to answer diffidently, to support the right, to refute the wrong, but both without bitterness; to instruct his opponent rather than to vanquish him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:139
verses.text: Such was the ingenuous modesty which adorned his youth that he would frankly confess from what sources his several arguments came; and in this way, while disclaiming a reputation for learning, he came to be held most learned.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:140
verses.text: This he would say is the opinion of Tertullian, that of Cyprian; this of Lactantius, that of Hilary; to this effect speaks Minucius Felix, thus Victorinus, after this manner Arnobius.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:141
verses.text: Myself too he would sometimes quote, for he loved me because of my intimacy with his uncle.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:142
verses.text: Indeed by constant reading and long-continued meditation he had made his breast a library of Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:144
verses.text: How often in letters from beyond the sea he urged me to write something to him! How often he reminded me of the man in the gospel who sought help by night and of the widow who importuned the cruel judge! And when I silently ignored his request and made my petitioner blush by blushing to reply, he put forward his uncle to enforce his suit, knowing that as the boon was for another he would more readily ask it, and that as I held his episcopal office in respect he would more easily obtain it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:145
verses.text: Accordingly I did what he wished and in a brief essay dedicated our mutual friendship to everlasting remembrance.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:146
verses.text: On receiving this Nepotian boasted that he was richer than Croesus and wealthier than Darius.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:147
verses.text: He held it in his hands, devoured it with his eyes, kept it in his bosom, repeated it with his lips.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:148
verses.text: And often when he unrolled it upon his couch, he fell asleep with the cherished page upon his breast.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:149
verses.text: When a stranger came or a friend, he rejoiced to let them know my witness to him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:150
verses.text: The deficiencies of my little book he made good by careful punctuation and varied emphasis, so that when it was read aloud it was always he not I who seemed to please or to displease.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:151
verses.text: Whence came such zeal, if not from the love of God? Whence came such untiring study of Christ's law, if not from a yearning for Him who gave it? Let others add coin to coin till their purses are chock-full; let others demean themselves to sponge on married ladies; let them be richer as monks than they were as men of the world; let them possess wealth in the service of a poor Christ such as they never had in the service of a rich devil; let the church lose breath at the opulence of men who in the world were beggars.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:152
verses.text: Our Nepotian spurns gold and begs only for written books.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:153
verses.text: But while he despises himself in the flesh and walks abroad more splendid than ever in his poverty, he still seeks out everything that may adorn the church.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:155
verses.text: In comparison with what has gone before what I am now about to say may appear trivial, but even in trifles the same spirit makes itself manifest.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:156
verses.text: For as we admire the Creator not only as the framer of heaven and earth, of sun and ocean, of elephants, camels, horses, oxen, pards, bears, and lions; but also as the maker of the most tiny creatures, ants, gnats, flies, worms, and the like, whose shapes we know better than their names, and as in all alike we revere the same creative skill; so the mind that is given to Christ shews the same earnestness in things of small as of great importance, knowing that it must render an account of every idle word.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:157
verses.text: Nepotian took pains to keep the altar bright, the church walls free from soot and the pavement duly swept.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:158
verses.text: He saw that the doorkeeper was constantly at his post, that the doorhangings were in their places, the sanctuary clean and the vessels shining.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:159
verses.text: The careful reverence that he shewed to every rite led him to neglect no duty small or great.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:160
verses.text: Whenever you looked for him in church you found him there.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:161
verses.text: In Quintus Fabius antiquity admired a nobleman and the author of a history of Rome, yet his paintings gained him more renown than his writings.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:162
verses.text: Our own Bezaleel also and Hiram, the son of a Tyrian woman, are spoken of in scripture as filled with wisdom and the spirit of God because they framed, the one the furniture of the tabernacle, the other that of the temple.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:163
verses.text: For, as it is with fertile tillage-fields and rich plough-lands which at times go out into redundant growths of stalk or ear, so is it with distinguished talents and a mind filled with virtue.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:164
verses.text: They are sure to overflow into elegant and varied accomplishments.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:165
verses.text: Accordingly among the Greeks we hear of a philosopher who used to boast that everything he wore down to his cloak and ring was made by himself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:166
verses.text: We may pass the same eulogy on our friend, for he adorned both the basilicas of the church and the halls of the martyrs with sketches of flowers, foliage, and vine-tendrils, so that everything attractive in the church, whether made so by its position or by its appearance, bore witness to the labour and zeal of the presbyter set over it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:168
verses.text: Go on blessed in thy goodness! What kind of ending should we expect after such a beginning! Ah! hapless plight of mortal men and vanity of all life that is not lived in Christ! Why, O my words, do you shrink back? Why do you shift and turn? I fear to come to the end, as if I could put off his death or make his life longer.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:169
verses.text: "All flesh is as grass and all the glory of man as the flower of grass".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:170
verses.text: Where now are that handsome face and dignified figure with which as with a fair garment his beautiful soul was clothed? The lily began to wither, alas! when the south wind blew, and the purple violet slowly faded into paleness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:171
verses.text: Yet while he burned with fever and while the fire of sickness was drying up the fountains of his veins, gasping and weary he still tried to comfort his sorrowing uncle.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:172
verses.text: His countenance shone with gladness, and while all around him wept he and he only smiled.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:173
verses.text: He flung aside his cloak, put out his hand, saw what others failed to see, and even tried to rise that he might welcome new comers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:174
verses.text: You would have thought that he was starting on a journey instead of dying and that in place of leaving all his friends behind him he was merely passing from some to others.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:175
verses.text: Tears roll down my cheeks and, however much I steel my mind, I cannot disguise the grief that I feel.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:176
verses.text: Who could suppose that at such an hour he would remember his intimacy with me, and that while he struggled for life he would recall the sweetness of study? Yet grasping his uncle's hand he said to him: "Send this tunic that I wore in the service of Christ to my dear friend, my father in age, but my brother in office, and transfer the affection hitherto claimed by your nephew to one who is as dear to you as he is to me".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:177
verses.text: With these words he passed away holding his uncle's hand and with my name upon his lips.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:179
verses.text: I know how unwilling you were to prove the affection of your people at such a cost, and that you would have preferred to win your countrymen's love while retaining your happiness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:180
verses.text: Such expressions of feeling, pleasant as they are when all goes well, are doubly welcome in time of sorrow.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:181
verses.text: All Altinum, all Italy mourned Nepotian.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:182
verses.text: The earth received his body; his soul was given back to Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:183
verses.text: You lost a nephew, the church a priest.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:184
verses.text: He who should have followed you went before you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:185
verses.text: To the office which you held, he in the judgment of all deserved to succeed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:186
