verses.text: And so one family has had the honour of producing two bishops, the first to be congratulated because he has held the office, the second to be lamented because he has been taken away too soon to hold it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:187
verses.text: Plato thinks that a wise man's whole life ought to be a meditation of death; and philosophers praise the sentiment and extol it to the skies.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:188
verses.text: But much more full of power are the words of the apostle: "I die daily through your glory".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:189
verses.text: For to have an ideal is one thing, to realize it another.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:190
verses.text: It is one thing to live so as to die, another to die so as to live.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:191
verses.text: The sage and Christian must both of them die: but the one always dies out of his glory, the other into it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:192
verses.text: Therefore we also should consider beforehand the end which must one day overtake us and which, whether we wish it or not, cannot be very far distant.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:193
verses.text: For though we should live nine hundred years or more, as men did before the deluge, and though the days of Methuselah should be granted us, yet that long space of time, when once it should have passed away and come to an end, would be as nothing.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:194
verses.text: For to the man who has lived ten years and to him who has lived a thousand, when once the end of life comes and death's inexorable doom, all the past whether long or short is just the same; except that the older a man is, the heavier is the load of sin that he has to take with him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:195
verses.text: First hapless mortals lose from out their life  The fairest days: disease and age come next;  And lastly cruel death doth claim his prey.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:196
verses.text: The poet Naevius too says that  Mortals must many woes perforce endure.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:197
verses.text: Accordingly antiquity has feigned that Niobe because of her much weeping was turned to stone and that other women were metamorphosed into beasts.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:198
verses.text: Hesiod also bewails men's birthdays and rejoices in their deaths, and Ennius wisely says:  The mob has one advantage o'er its king:  For it may weep while tears for him are shame.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:199
verses.text: If a king may not weep, neither may a bishop; indeed a bishop has still less license than a king.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:200
verses.text: For the king rules over unwilling subjects, the bishop over willing ones.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:201
verses.text: The king compels submission by terror; the bishop exercises lordship by becoming a servant.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:202
verses.text: The king guards men's bodies till they die; the bishop saves their souls for life eternal.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:203
verses.text: The eyes of all are turned upon you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:204
verses.text: Your house is set on a watchtower; your life fixes for others the limits of their self-control.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:205
verses.text: Whatever you do, all think that they may do the same.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:206
verses.text: Do not so commit yourself that those who seek ground for cavil may be thought to have rightly assailed you, or that those who are eager to imitate you may be forced to do wrong.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:207
verses.text: Overcome as much as you can—nay even more than you can—the sensitiveness of your mind and check the copious flow of your tears.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:208
verses.text: Else your deep affection for your nephew may be construed by unbelievers as indicating despair of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:209
verses.text: You must regretim not as dead but as absent.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:210
verses.text: You must seem to be looking for him rather than have lost him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:212
verses.text: But why do I try to heal a sorrow which has already, I suppose, been assuaged by time and reason? Why do I not rather unfold to you—they are not far to seek—the miseries of our rulers and the calamities of our time? He who has lost the light of life is not so much to be pitied as he is to be congratulated who has escaped from such great evils.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:213
verses.text: Constantius, the patron of the Arian heresy, was hurrying to do battle with his enemy when he died at the village of Mopsus and to his great vexation left the empire to his foe.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:214
verses.text: Julian, the betrayer of his own soul, the murderer of a Christian army, felt in Media the hand of the Christ whom he had previously denied in Gaul.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:215
verses.text: Desiring to annex new territories to Rome, he did but lose annexations previously made.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:216
verses.text: Jovian had but just tasted the sweets of sovereignty when a coal-fire suffocated him: a good instance of the transitoriness of human power.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:217
verses.text: Valentinian died of a broken blood vessel, the land of his birth laid waste, and his country unavenged.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:218
verses.text: His brother Valens defeated in Thrace by the Goths, was buried where he died.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:219
verses.text: Gratian, betrayed by his army and refused admittance by the cities on his line of march, became the laughing-stock of his foe; and your walls, Lyons, still bear the marks of that bloody hand.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:220
verses.text: Valentinian was yet a youth—I may say, a mere boy—when, after flight and exile and the recovery of his power by bloodshed, he was put to death not far from the city which had witnessed his brother's end.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:221
verses.text: And not only so but his lifeless body was gibbeted to do him shame.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:222
verses.text: What shall I say of Procopius, of Maximus, of Eugenius, who while they held sovereign sway were a terror to the nations, yet stood one and all as prisoners in the presence of their conquerors, and—cruellest wound of all to the great and powerful—felt the pang of an ignominious slavery before they fell by the edge of the sword.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:224
verses.text: Some one may say: such is the lot of kings:  The lightning ever smites the mountain-tops.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:225
verses.text: I will come therefore to persons of private position, and in speaking of these I will not go farther back than the last two years.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:226
verses.text: In fact I will content myself—omitting all others—with recounting the respective fates of three recent consulars.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:227
verses.text: Abundantius is a beggared exile at Pityus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:228
verses.text: The head of Rufinus has been carried on a pike to Constantinople, and his severed hand has begged alms from door to door to shame his insatiable greed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:229
verses.text: Timasius, hurled suddenly from a position of the highest rank thinks it an escape that he is allowed to live in obscurity at Assa.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:230
verses.text: I am describing not the misfortunes of an unhappy few but the thread upon which human fortunes as a whole depend.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:231
verses.text: I shudder when I think of the catastrophes of our time.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:232
verses.text: For twenty years and more the blood of Romans has been shed daily between Constantinople and the Julian Alps.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:233
verses.text: Scythia, Thrace, Macedonia, Dardania, Dacia, Thessaly, Achaia, Epirus, Dalmatia, the Pannonias—each and all of these have been sacked and pillaged and plundered by Goths and Sarmatians, Quades and Alans, Huns and Vandals and Marchmen.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:234
verses.text: How many of God's matrons and virgins, virtuous and noble ladies, have been made the sport of these brutes! Bishops have been made captive, priests and those in minor orders have been put to death.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:235
verses.text: Churches have been overthrown, horses have been stalled by the altars of Christ, the relics of martyrs have been dug up.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:236
verses.text: Mourning and fear abound on every side  And death appears in countless shapes and forms.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:237
verses.text: The Roman world is falling: yet we hold up our heads instead of bowing them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:238
verses.text: What courage, think you, have the Corinthians now, or the Athenians or the Lacedaemonians or the Arcadians, or any of the Greeks over whom the barbarians bear sway? I have mentioned only a few cities, but these once the capitals of no mean states.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:239
verses.text: The East, it is true, seemed to be safe from all such evils: and if men were panic-stricken here, it was only because of bad news from other parts.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:240
verses.text: But lo! in the year just gone by the wolves (no longer of Arabia but of the whole North) were let loose upon us from the remotest fastnesses of Caucasus and in a short time overran these great provinces.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:241
verses.text: What a number of monasteries they captured! What many rivers they caused to run red with blood! They laid siege to Antioch and invested other cities on the Halys, the Cydnus, the Orontes, and the Euphrates.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:242
verses.text: They carried off troops of captives.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:243
verses.text: Arabia, Phenicia, Palestine and Egypt, in their terror fancied themselves already enslaved.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:244
verses.text: Had I a hundred tongues, a hundred lips,  A throat of iron and a chest of brass,  I could not tell men's countless sufferings.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:245
verses.text: And indeed it is not my purpose to write a history: I only wish to shed a few tears over your sorrows and mine.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:246
verses.text: For the rest, to treat such themes as they deserve, Thucydides and Sallust would be as good as dumb.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:248
verses.text: Nepotian is happy who neither sees these things nor hears them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:249
verses.text: We are unhappy, for either we suffer ourselves or we see our brethren suffer.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:250
verses.text: Yet we desire to live, and regard those beyond the reach of these evils as miserable rather than blessed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:251
verses.text: We have long felt that God is angry, yet we do not try to appease Him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:252
verses.text: It is our sins which make the barbarians strong, it is our vices which vanquish Rome's soldiers: and, as if there were here too little material for carnage, civil wars have made almost greater havoc among us than the swords of foreign foes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:253
verses.text: Miserable must those Israelites have been compared with whom Nebuchadnezzar was called God's servant.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:254
verses.text: Unhappy too are we who are so displeasing to God that He uses the fury of the barbarians to execute His wrath against us.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:255
verses.text: Still when Hezekiah repented, one hundred and eighty-five thousand Assyrians were destroyed in one night by a single angel.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:256
verses.text: When Jehosaphat sang the praises of the Lord, the Lord gave His worshipper the victory.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:257
verses.text: Again when Moses fought against Amalek, it was not with the sword but with prayer that he prevailed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:258
verses.text: Therefore, if we wish to be lifted up, we must first prostrate ourselves.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:259
verses.text: Alas! for our shame and folly reaching even to unbelief! Rome's army, once victor and lord of the world, now trembles with terror at the sight of the foe and accepts defeat from men who cannot walk afoot and fancy themselves dead if once they are unhorsed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:260
verses.text: We do not understand the prophet's words: "One thousand shall flee at the rebuke of one".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:261
verses.text: We do not cut away the causes of the disease, as we must do to remove the disease itself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:262
verses.text: Else we should soon see the enemies' arrows give way to our javelins, their caps to our helmets, their palfreys to our chargers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:264
verses.text: But I have gone beyond the office of a consoler, and while forbidding you to weep for one dead man I have myself mourned the dead of the whole world.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:265
verses.text: Xerxes the mighty king who rased mountains and filled up seas, looking from high ground upon the untold host, the countless army before him, is said to have wept at the thought that in a hundred years not one of those whom he then saw would be alive.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:266
verses.text: Oh! if we could but get up into a watch-tower so high that from it we might behold the whole earth spread out under our feet, then I would shew you the wreck of a world, nation warring against nation and kingdom in collision with kingdom; some men tortured, others put to the sword, others swallowed up by the waves, some dragged away into slavery; here a wedding, there a funeral; men born here, men dying there; some living in affluence, others begging their bread; and not the army of Xerxes, great as that was, but all the inhabitants of the world alive now but destined soon to pass away.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:267
verses.text: Language is inadequate to a theme so vast and all that I can say must fall short of the reality.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:269
verses.text: Let us return then to ourselves and coming down from the skies let us look for a few moments upon what more nearly concerns us.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:270
verses.text: Are you conscious, I would ask, of the stages of your growth? Can you fix the time when you became a babe, a boy, a youth, an adult, an old man? Every day we are changing, every day we are dying, and yet we fancy ourselves eternal.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:271
verses.text: The very moments that I spend in dictation, in writing, in reading over what I write, and in correcting it, are so much taken from my life.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:272
verses.text: Every dot that my secretary makes is so much gone from my allotted time.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:273
verses.text: We write letters and reply to those of others, our missives cross the sea, and, as the vessel ploughs its furrow through wave after wave, the moments which we have to live vanish one by one.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:274
verses.text: Our only gain is that we are thus knit together in the love of Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:275
verses.text: "Charity suffereth long and is kind; charity envieth not; charity vaunteth not itself, is not puffed up; beareth all things, believeth all things, hopeth all things, endureth all things.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:276
verses.text: Charity never faileth".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:277
verses.text: It lives always in the heart, and thus our Nepotian though absent is still present, and widely sundered though we are has a hand to offer to each.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:278
verses.text: Yes, in him we have a hostage for mutual charity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:279
verses.text: Let us then be joined together in spirit, let us bind ourselves each to each in affection and let us who have lost a son shew the same fortitude with which the blessed pope Chromatius bore the loss of a brother.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:280
verses.text: Let every page that we write echo his name, let all our letters ring with it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 60:281
verses.text: If we can no longer clasp him to our hearts, let us hold him fast in memory; and if we can no longer speak with him, let us never cease to speak of him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:1
verses.text: Letter LXI.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:2
verses.text: To Vigilantius.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:3
verses.text: Vigilantius on his return to the West after his visit to Jerusalem (whither he had gone as the bearer of letters from Paulinus of Nola—see Letter LVIII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:5
verses.text: ) had openly accused Jerome of a leaning to the heresy of Origen.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:6
verses.text: Jerome now writes to him in the most severe tone repudiating the charge of Origenism and fastening upon his opponent those of ignorance and blasphemy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:7
verses.text: He singles out for especial reprobation Vigilantius's explanation of 'the stone cut out without hands' in Daniel and urges him to repent of his sins in which case he will have as much chance of forgiveness as the devil has according to Origen! The letter is often referred to as showing Jerome's way of dealing with Origen's works.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:8
verses.text: Jerome subsequently wrote a refutation of Vigilantius's work, of all his controversial writings the most violent and the least reasonable.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:9
verses.text: See the translation of it in this volume.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:10
verses.text: See also Letter CIX.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:11
verses.text: The date of this letter is 396 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:12
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:14
verses.text: Since you have refused to believe your own ears, I might justly decline to satisfy you by a letter; for, if you have failed to credit the living voice, it is not likely that you will give way to a written paper.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:15
verses.text: But, since Christ has shown us in Himself a pattern of perfect humility, bestowing a kiss upon His betrayer and receiving the robber's repentance upon the cross, I tell you now when absent as I have told you already when present, that I read and have read Origen only as I read Apollinaris, or other writers whose books in some things the Church does not receive.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:16
verses.text: I by no means say that everything contained in such books is to be condemned, but I admit that there are things in them deserving of censure.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:17
verses.text: Still, as it is my task and study by reading many authors to cull different flowers from as large a number as possible, not so much making it an object to prove all things as to choose what are good.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:18
verses.text: I take up many writers that from the many I may learn many things; according to that which is written "reading all things, holding fast those that are good".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:19
verses.text: Hence I am much surprised that you have tried to fasten upon me the doctrines of Origen, of whose mistaken teaching on many points you are up to the present altogether unaware.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:20
verses.text: Am I a heretic? Why pray then do heretics dislike me so? And are you orthodox, you who either against your convictions and the words of your own mouth signed unwillingly and are consequently a prevaricator, or else signed deliberately and are consequently a heretic? You have taken no account of Egypt; you have relinquished all those provinces where numbers plead freely and openly for your sect; and you have singled out me for assault, me who not only censure but publicly condemn all doctrines that are contrary to the church.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:22
verses.text: Origen is a heretic, true; but what does that take from me who do not deny that on very many points he is heretical? He has erred concerning the resurrection of the body, he has erred concerning the condition of souls, he has erred by supposing it possible that the devil may repent, and—an error more important than these—he has declared in his commentary upon Isaiah that the Seraphim mentioned by the prophet are the divine Son and the Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:23
verses.text: If I did not allow that he has erred or if I did not daily anathematize his errors I should be partaker of his fault.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:24
verses.text: For while we receive what is good in his writings we must on no account bind ourselves to accept also what is evil.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:25
verses.text: Still in many passages he has interpreted the scriptures well, has explained obscure places in the prophets, and has brought to light very great mysteries, both in the old and in the new testament.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:26
verses.text: If then I have taken over what is good in him and have either cut away or altered or ignored what is evil, am I to be regarded as guilty on the score that through my agency those who read Latin receive the good in his writings without knowing anything of the bad? If this be a crime the confessor Hilary must be convicted; for he has rendered from Greek into Latin Origen's Explanation of the Psalms and his Homilies on Job.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:27
verses.text: Eusebius of Vercellae, who witnessed a like confession, must also be held in fault; for he has translated into our tongue the Commentaries upon all the Psalms of his heretical namesake, omitting however the unsound portions and rendering only those parts which are profitable.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:28
verses.text: I say nothing of Victorinus of Petavium and others who have merely followed and expanded Origen in their explanation of the scriptures.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:29
verses.text: Were I to do so, I might seem less anxious to defend myself than to find for myself companions in guilt.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:30
verses.text: I will come to your own case: Why do you keep copies of his treatises on Job? In these, while arguing against the devil and concerning the stars and heavens, he has said certain things which the Church does not receive.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:31
verses.text: Is it for you alone, with that very wise head of yours, to pass sentence upon all writers Greek and Latin, with a wave of your censor's wand to eject some from our libraries and to admit others, and as the whim takes you to pronounce me either a Catholic or a heretic? And am I to be forbidden to reject things which are wrong and to condemn what I have often condemned already? Read what I have written upon the epistle to the Ephesians, read my other works, particularly my commentary upon Ecclesiastes, and you will clearly see that from my youth up I have never been terrified by any man's influence into acquiescence in heretical pravity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:33
verses.text: It is no small gain to know your own ignorance.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:34
verses.text: It is a man's wisdom to know his own measure, that he may not be led away at the instigation of the devil to make the whole world a witness of his incapacity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:35
verses.text: You are bent, I suppose, on magnifying yourself and boast in your own country that I found myself unable to answer your eloquence and that I dreaded in you the sharp satire of a Chrysippus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:36
verses.text: Christian modesty holds me back and I do not wish to lay open the retirement of my poor cell with biting words.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:37
verses.text: Otherwise I should soon shew up all your bravery and your parade of triumph.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:38
verses.text: But these I leave to others either to talk of or to laugh at; while for my own part as a Christian speaking to a Christian I beseech you my brother not to pretend to know more than you do, lest your pen may proclaim your innocence and simplicity, or at any rate those qualities of which I say nothing but which, though you do not see them in yourself others see in you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:39
verses.text: For then you will give everyone reason to laugh at your folly.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:40
verses.text: From your earliest childhood you have been taught other lessons and have been used to a different kind of schooling.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:41
verses.text: One and the same person can hardly be a tester both of gold coins on the counter and also of the scriptures, or be a connoisseur of wines and an adept in expounding prophets or apostles.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:42
verses.text: As for me, you tear me limb from limb, our reverend brother Oceanus you charge with heresy, you dislike the judgment of the presbyters Vincent and Paulinian, and our brother Eusebius also displeases you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:43
verses.text: You alone are to be our Cato, the most eloquent of the Roman race, and you wish us to accept what you say as the words of prudence herself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:44
verses.text: Pray call to mind the day when I preached on the resurrection and on the reality of the risen body, and when you jumped up beside me and clapped your hands and stamped your feet and applauded my orthodoxy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:45
verses.text: Now, however, that you have taken to sea travelling the stench of the bilge water has affected your head, and you have called me to mind only as a heretic.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:46
verses.text: What can I do for you? I believed the letters of the reverend presbyter Paulinus, and it did not occur to me that his judgment concerning you could be wrong.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:47
verses.text: And although, the moment that you handed me the letter, I noticed a certain incoherency in your language, yet I fancied this due to want of culture and knowledge in you and not to an unsettled brain.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:48
verses.text: I do not censure the reverend writer who preferred, no doubt, in writing to me to keep back what he knew rather than to accuse in his missive one who was both under his patronage and entrusted with his letter; but I find fault with myself that I have rested in another's judgment rather than my own, and that, while my eyes saw one thing, I believed on the evidence of a scrap of paper something else than what I saw.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:50
verses.text: Wherefore cease to worry me and to overwhelm me with your scrolls.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:51
verses.text: Spare at least your money with which you hire secretaries and copyists, employing the same persons to write for you and to applaud you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:52
verses.text: Possibly their praise is due to the fact that they make a profit out of writing for you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:53
verses.text: If you wish to exercise your mind, hand yourself over to the teachers of grammar and rhetoric, learn logic, have yourself instructed in the schools of the philosophers; and when you have learned all these things you will perhaps begin to hold your tongue.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:54
verses.text: And yet I am acting foolishly in seeking teachers for one who is competent to teach everyone, and in trying to limit the utterance of one who does not know how to speak yet cannot remain silent.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:55
verses.text: The old Greek proverb is quite true "A lyre is of no use to an ass".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:56
verses.text: For my part I imagine that even your name was given you out of contrariety.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:57
verses.text: For your whole mind slumbers and you actually snore, so profound is the sleep—or rather the lethargy—in which you are plunged.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:58
verses.text: In fact amongst the other blasphemies which with sacrilegious lips you have uttered you have dared to say that the mountain in Daniel out of which the stone was cut without hands is the devil, and that the stone is Christ, who having taken a body from Adam (whose sins had before connected him with the devil) is born of a virgin to separate mankind from the mountain, that is, from the devil.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:59
verses.text: Your tongue deserves to be cut out and torn into fragments.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:60
verses.text: Can any true Christian explain this image of the devil instead of referring it to God the Father Almighty, or defile the ears of the whole world with so frightful an enormity? If your explanation has ever been accepted by any—I will not say Catholic but—heretic or heathen, let your words be regarded as pious.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:61
verses.text: If on the other hand the Church of Christ has never yet heard of such an impiety, and if yours has been the first mouth through which he who once said "I will be like the Most High" has declared that he is the mountain spoken of by Daniel, then repent, put on sackcloth and ashes, and with fast-flowing tears wash away your awful guilt; if so be that this impiety may be forgiven you, and, supposing Origen's heresy to be true, that you may obtain pardon when the devil himself shall obtain it, the devil who has never been convicted of greater blasphemy than that which he has uttered through you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:62
verses.text: Your insult offered to myself I bear with patience: your impiety towards God I cannot bear.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:63
verses.text: Accordingly I may seem to have been somewhat more acrid in this latter part of my letter than I declared I would be at the outset.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:64
verses.text: Yet having once before repented and asked pardon of me, it is extremely foolish in you again to commit a sin for which you must anew do penance.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 61:65
verses.text: May Christ give you grace to hear and to hold your peace, to understand and so to speak.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 62:1
verses.text: Letter LXII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 62:2
verses.text: To Tranquillinus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 62:3
verses.text: Tranquillinus, one of Jerome's Roman friends, had written (1) to tell him of the stand that Oceanus was making against the Origenists at Rome, and (2) to ask whether any parts of Origen's works might be studied with safety and profit.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 62:4
verses.text: Jerome welcomes the tidings about Oceanus and answers the question of Tranquillinus in the affirmative.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 62:5
verses.text: He classes Origen with Tertullian, Apollinaris and others whose works continued to be read in spite of their heresies.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 62:6
verses.text: Written in 396 or 397 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 62:7
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 62:9
verses.text: Though I formerly doubted the fact, I have now proved that the links which bind spirit to spirit are stronger than any physical bond.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 62:10
verses.text: For you, my reverend friend, cling to me with all your soul, and I am united to you by the love of Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 62:11
verses.text: I speak simply and sincerely to your spotless heart: the very paper on which you write, the very letters which you have formed—voiceless though they are—inspire in me a sense of your affection.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 62:13
verses.text: You tell me that many have been deceived by the mistaken teaching of Origen, and that that saintly man, my son Oceanus, is doing battle with their madness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 62:14
verses.text: I grieve to think that simple folk have been thrown off their balance, but I am rejoiced to know that one so learned as Oceanus is doing his best to set them right again.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 62:15
verses.text: Moreover you ask me, insignificant though I am, for an opinion as to the advisability of reading Origen's works.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 62:16
verses.text: Are we, you say, to reject him altogether with our brother Faustinus, or are we, as others tell us, to read him in part? My opinion is that we should sometimes read him for his learning just as we read Tertullian, Novatus, Arnobius, Apollinarius and some other church writers both Greek and Latin, and that we should select what is good and avoid what is bad in their writings according to the words of the Apostle, "Prove all things: hold fast that which is good".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 62:17
verses.text: Those, however, who are led by some perversity in their dispositions to conceive for him too much fondness or too much aversion seem to me to lie under the curse of the Prophet:—"Woe unto them that call evil good and good evil; that put bitter for sweet and sweet for bitter!" For while the ability of his teaching must not lead us to embrace his wrong opinions, the wrongness of his opinions should not cause us altogether to reject the useful commentaries which he has published on the holy scriptures.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 62:18
verses.text: But if his admirers and his detractors are bent on having a tug of war one against the other, and if, seeking no mean and observing no moderation, they must either approve or disapprove his works indiscriminately, I would choose rather to be a pious boor than a learned blasphemer.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 62:19
verses.text: Our reverend brother, Tatian the deacon, heartily salutes you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 63:1
verses.text: Letter LXIII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 63:2
verses.text: To Theophilus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 63:3
verses.text: When the dispute arose between Jerome and Epiphanius on the one side and Rufinus and John of Jerusalem on the other (see Letter LI.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 63:4
verses.text: ), Theophilus bishop of Alexandria, being appealed to by the latter sent the presbyter Isidore to report to him on the matter.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 63:5
verses.text: Isidore reported against Jerome and consequently Theophilus refused to answer several of his letters.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 63:6
verses.text: Finally he wrote counselling him to obey the canons of the church.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 63:7
verses.text: Jerome replies that to do this has always been his first object.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 63:8
verses.text: He then remonstrates with Theophilus on his too great leniency towards the Origenists and declares it to be productive of the worst results.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 63:9
verses.text: The date of the letter is probably 397 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 63:10
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 63:11
verses.text: Jerome to the most blessed pope Theophilus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 63:13
verses.text: Your holiness will remember that at the time when you kept silence towards me, I never ceased to do my duty by writing to you, not taking so much into account what you in the exercise of your discretion were then doing as what it became me to do.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 63:14
verses.text: And now that I have received a letter from your grace, I see that my reading of the gospel has not been without fruit.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 63:15
verses.text: For if the frequent prayers of a woman changed the determination of an unyielding judge, how much more must my constant appeals have softened a fatherly heart like yours?  2.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 63:16
verses.text: I thank you for your reminder concerning the canons of the Church.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 63:17
verses.text: Truly, "whom the Lord loveth he chasteneth, and scourgeth every son whom he receiveth".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 63:18
verses.text: Still I would assure you that nothing is more my aim than to maintain the rights of Christ, to keep to the lines laid down by the fathers, and always to remember the faith of Rome; that faith which is praised by the lips of an apostle, and of which the Alexandrian church boasts to be a sharer.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 63:20
verses.text: Many religious persons are displeased that you are so long-suffering in regard to that shocking heresy, and that you suppose yourself able by such lenity to amend those who are attacking the Church's vitals.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 63:21
verses.text: They believe that, while you are waiting for the penitence of a few, your action is fostering the boldness of abandoned men and making their party stronger.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 63:22
verses.text: Farewell in Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 64:1
verses.text: Letter LXIV.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 64:2
verses.text: To Fabiola.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 64:3
verses.text: Fabiola's visit to Bethlehem had been shortened by the threatened invasion of the Huns which compelled Jerome and his friends to take refuge for a time on the seaboard of Palestine.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 64:4
verses.text: Fabiola here took leave of her companions and set sail for Italy, but not until Jerome had completed this letter for her use (§22).

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 64:5
verses.text: It contains a mystical account of the vestments of the High Priest worked out with Jerome's usual ingenuity and learning.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 64:6
verses.text: Similar treatises are ascribed to Tertullian and to Hosius bishop of Cordova, but these have long since perished.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 64:7
verses.text: Its date is 396 or 397 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 64:8
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 65:1
verses.text: Letter LXV.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 65:2
verses.text: To Principia.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 65:3
verses.text: A commentary on Ps.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 65:4
verses.text: XLV.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 65:5
verses.text: addressed to Marcella's friend and companion Principia (see Letter CXXVII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 65:7
verses.text: Jerome prefaces what he has to say by a defence of his practice of writing for women, a practice which had exposed him to many foolish sneers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 65:8
verses.text: He deals with the same subject in his dedication of the Commentary of Sophronius.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 65:9
verses.text: The date of the letter is 397 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 65:10
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:1
verses.text: Letter LXVI.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:2
verses.text: To Pammachius.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:3
verses.text: Pammachius a Roman senator, had lost his wife Paulina one of Paula's daughters, while she was still in the flower of her youth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:4
verses.text: It was not till two years had elapsed that Jerome ventured to write to him; and when he did so he dwelt but little on the life and virtues of Paulina.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:5
verses.text: Probably there was but little to tell.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:6
verses.text: The greater part of the letter is taken up with commendation of Pammachius himself who, in spite of his high rank and position, had become a monk and was now living a life of severe self-denial.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:7
verses.text: Jerome speaks approvingly of the Hospice for Strangers which, in conjunction with Fabiola, Pammachius had set up at Portus, and describes his own somewhat similar institutions at Bethlehem.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:8
verses.text: He also mentions Paula, Eustochium, and the dead Blaesilla, all in terms of the highest praise.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:9
verses.text: The date of the letter is 397 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:10
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:12
verses.text: Supposing a wound to be healed and a scar to have been formed upon the skin, any course of treatment designed to remove the mark must in its effort to improve the appearance renew the smart of the original wound.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:13
verses.text: After two years of inopportune silence my condolence now comes rather late; yet even so I am afraid that my present speech may be still more inopportune.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:14
verses.text: I fear lest in touching the sore spot in your heart I may by my words inflame afresh a wound which time and reflection have availed to cure.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:15
verses.text: For who can have ears so dull or hearts so flinty as to hear the name of your Paulina without weeping? Even though reared on the milk of Hyrcanian tigresses they must still shed tears.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:16
verses.text: Who can with dry eyes see thus untimely cut down and withered an opening rose, an undeveloped bud, which has not yet formed itself into a cup nor spread forth the proud display of its crimson petals? In her a most priceless pearl is broken.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:17
verses.text: In her a vivid emerald is shattered.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:18
verses.text: Sickness alone shews us the blessedness of health.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:19
verses.text: We realize better what we have had when we cease to have it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:21
verses.text: The good ground of which we read in the parable brought forth fruit, some an hundred-fold, some sixtyfold, and some thirtyfold.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:22
verses.text: In this threefold yield I recognize an emblem of the three different rewards of Christ which have fallen to three women closely united in blood and moral excellence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:23
verses.text: Eustochium culls the flowers of virginity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:24
verses.text: Paula sweeps the toilsome threshing floor of widowhood.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:25
verses.text: Paulina keeps the bed undefiled of marriage.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:26
verses.text: A mother with such daughters wins for herself on earth all that Christ has promised to give in heaven.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:27
verses.text: Then to complete the team—if I may so call it—of four saints turned out by a single family, and to match the women's virtues by those of a man, the three have a fit companion in Pammachius who is a cherub such as Ezekiel describes, brother-in-law to the first, son-in-law to the second, husband to the third.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:28
verses.text: Husband did I say? Nay, rather a most devoted brother; for the language of marriage is inadequate to describe the holy bonds of the Spirit.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:29
verses.text: Of this team Jesus holds the reins, and it is of steeds like these that Habakkuk sings: "ride upon thy horses and let thy riding be salvation".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:30
verses.text: With like resolve if with unlike speed they strain after the victor's palm.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:31
verses.text: Their colours are different; their object is the same.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:32
verses.text: They are harnessed in one yoke, they obey one driver, not waiting for the lash but answering the call of his voice with fresh efforts.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:34
verses.text: Let me use for a moment the language of philosophy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:35
verses.text: According to the Stoics there are four virtues so closely related and mutually coherent that he who lacks one lacks all.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:36
verses.text: They are prudence, justice, fortitude, and temperance.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:37
verses.text: While all of you possess the four, yet each is remarkable for one.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:38
verses.text: You have prudence, your mother has justice, your virgin sister has fortitude, your wedded wife has temperance.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:39
verses.text: I speak of you as wise, for who can be wiser than one who, despising the folly of the world, has followed Christ "the power of God and the wisdom of God"? Or what better instance can there be of justice than your mother, who having divided her substance among her offspring has taught them by her own contempt of riches the true object on which to fix their affections? Who has set a better example of courage than Eustochium, who by resolving to be a virgin has breached the gates of the nobility and broken down the pride of a consular house? The first of Roman ladies, she has brought under the yoke the first of Roman families.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:40
verses.text: Has there ever been temperance greater than that of Paulina, who, reading the words of the apostle: "marriage is honourable in all and the bed undefiled," and not presuming to aspire to the happiness of her virgin sister or the continence of her widowed mother, has preferred to keep to the safe track of a lower path rather than treading on air to lose herself in the clouds? When once she had entered upon the married state, her one thought day and night was that, as soon as her union should be blessed with offspring, she would live thenceforth in the second degree of chastity, and  Though woman, foremost in the high emprise,  would induce her husband to follow a like course.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:41
verses.text: She would not forsake him but looked for the day when he would become a companion in salvation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:42
verses.text: Finding by several miscarriages that her womb was not barren, she could not give up all hope of having children and had to allow her own reluctance to give way to the eagerness of her mother-in-law and the chagrin of her husband.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:43
verses.text: Thus she suffered much as Rachel suffered, although instead of bringing forth like her a son of pangs and of the right hand, the heir she had longed for was no other than her husband.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:44
verses.text: I have learned on good authority that her wish in submitting herself to her husband was not to take advantage of God's primitive command "Be faithful and multiply and replenish the earth" but that she only desired children that she might bring forth virgins to Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:46
verses.text: We read that the wife of Phinehas the priest, on hearing that the ark of the Lord had been taken, was seized suddenly with the pains of travail and that she brought forth a son Ichabod and died a mother in the hands of the women who nursed her.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:47
verses.text: Rachel's son is called Benjamin, that is 'son of excellence' or 'of the right hand'; but the son of the other, afterwards to be a distinguished priest of God, derives his name from the ark.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:48
verses.text: The same thing has come to pass in our own day, for since Paulina fell asleep the Church has posthumously borne the monk Pammachius, a patrician by his parentage and marriage, rich in alms, and lofty in lowliness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:49
verses.text: The apostle writes to the Corinthians, "Ye see your calling, brethren, how that not many wise men, not many noble are called".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:50
verses.text: The conditions of the nascent church required this to be so that the grain of mustard seed might grow up little by little into a tree, and that the leaven of the gospel might gradually raise more and more the whole lump of the church.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:51
verses.text: In our day Rome possesses what the world in days gone by knew not of.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:52
verses.text: Then few of the wise or mighty or noble were Christians; now many wise powerful and noble are not Christians only but even monks.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:53
verses.text: And among them all my Pammachius is the wisest, the mightiest, and the noblest; great among the great, a leader among leaders, he is the commander in chief of all monks.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:54
verses.text: He and others like him are the offspring which Paulina desired to have in her life time and which she has given us in her death.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:55
verses.text: "Sing, O barren, thou that didst not bear; break forth into singing and cry aloud, thou that didst not travail with child"; for in a moment thou hast brought forth as many sons as there are poor men in Rome.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:57
verses.text: The glowing gems which in old days adorned the neck and face of Paulina now purchase food for the needy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:58
verses.text: Her silk dresses and gold brocades are exchanged for soft woollen garments intended to keep out the cold and not to expose the body to vain admiration.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:59
verses.text: All that formerly ministered to luxury is now at the service of virtue.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:60
verses.text: That blind man holding out his hand, and often crying aloud when there is none to hear, is the heir of Paulina, is co-heir with Pammachius.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:61
verses.text: That poor cripple who can scarcely drag himself along, owes his support to the help of a tender girl.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:62
verses.text: Those doors which of old poured forth crowds of visitors, are now beset only by the wretched.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:63
verses.text: One suffers from a dropsy, big with death; another mute and without the means of begging, begs the more appealingly because he cannot beg; another maimed from his childhood implores an alms which he may not himself enjoy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:64
verses.text: Still another has his limbs rotted with jaundice and lives on after his body has become a corpse.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:65
verses.text: To use the language of Virgil:  Had I a hundred tongues, a hundred lips,  I could not tell men's countless sufferings.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:66
verses.text: Such is the bodyguard which accompanies Pammachius wherever he walks; in the persons of such he ministers to Christ Himself; and their squalor serves to whiten his soul.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:67
verses.text: Thus he speeds on his way to heaven, beneficent as a giver of games to the poor, and kind as a provider of shows for the needy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:68
verses.text: Other husbands scatter on the graves of their wives violets, roses, lilies, and purple flowers; and assuage the grief of their hearts by fulfilling this tender duty.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:69
verses.text: Our dear Pammachius also waters the holy ashes and the revered bones of Paulina, but it is with the balm of almsgiving.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:70
verses.text: These are the confections and the perfumes with which he cherishes the dead embers of his wife knowing that it is written: "Water will quench a flaming fire; and alms maketh an atonement for sins".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:71
verses.text: What great power compassion has and what high rewards it is destined to win, the blessed Cyprian sets forth in an extensive work.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:72
verses.text: It is proved also by the counsel of Daniel who desired the most impious of kings—had he been willing to hear him—to be saved by shewing mercy to the poor.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:73
verses.text: Paulina's mother may well be glad of Paulina's heir.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:74
verses.text: She cannot regret that her daughter's wealth has passed into new hands when she sees it still spent upon the objects she had at heart.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:75
verses.text: Nay, rather she must congratulate herself that without any exertion of her own her wishes are being carried out.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:76
verses.text: The sum available for distribution is the same as before: only the distributor is changed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:78
verses.text: Who can credit the fact that one, who is the glory of the Furian stock and whose grandfathers and great grandfathers have been consuls, moves amid the senators in their purple clothed in sombre garb, and that, so far from blushing when he meets the eyes of his companions, he actually derides those who deride him! "There is a shame that leadeth to death and there is a shame that leadeth to life".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:79
verses.text: It is a monk's first virtue to despise the judgments of men and always to remember the apostle's words:—"If I yet pleased men, I should not be the servant of Christ".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:80
verses.text: In the same sense the Lord says to the prophets that He has made their face a brazen city and a stone of adamant and an iron pillar, to the end that they shall not be afraid of the insults of the people but shall by the sternness of their looks discompose the effrontery of those who sneered at them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:81
verses.text: A finely strung mind is more readily overcome by contumely than by terror.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:82
verses.text: And men whom no tortures can overawe are sometimes prevailed over by the fear of shame.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:83
verses.text: Surely it is no small thing for a man of birth, eloquence, and wealth to avoid the company of the powerful in the streets, to mingle with the crowd, to cleave to the poor, to associate on equal terms with the untaught, to cease to be a leader and to become one of the people.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:84
verses.text: The more he humbles himself, the more he is exalted.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:86
verses.text: A pearl will shine in the midst of squalor and a gem of the first water will sparkle in the mire.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:87
verses.text: This is what the Lord promised when He said: "Them that honour me I will honour".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:88
verses.text: Others may understand this of the future when sorrow shall be turned into joy and when, although the world shall pass away, the saints shall receive a crown which shall never pass.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:89
verses.text: But I for my part see that the promises made to the saints are fulfilled even in this present life.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:90
verses.text: Before he began to serve Christ with his whole heart, Pammachius was a well known person in the senate.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:91
verses.text: Still there were many other senators who wore the badges of proconsular rank.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:92
verses.text: The whole world is filled with similar decorations.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:93
verses.text: He was in the first rank it is true, but there were others in it besides him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:94
verses.text: Whilst he took precedence of some, others took precedence of him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:95
verses.text: The most distinguished privilege loses its prestige when lavished on a crowd, and dignities themselves become less dignified in the eyes of good men when held by persons who have no dignity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:96
verses.text: Thus Tully finely says of Caesar, when he wished to advance some of his adherents, "he did not so much honour them as dishonour the honourable positions in which he placed them".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:97
verses.text: To-day all the churches of Christ are talking of Pammachius.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:98
verses.text: The whole world admires as a poor man one whom heretofore it ignored as rich.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:99
verses.text: Can anything be more splendid than the consulate? Yet the honour lasts only for a year and when another has succeeded to the post its former occupant gives way.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:100
verses.text: Each man's laurels are lost in the crowd and sometimes triumphs themselves are marred by the shortcomings of those who celebrate them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:101
verses.text: An office which was once handed down from patrician to patrician, which only men of noble birth could hold, of which the consul Marius—victor though he was over Numidia and the Teutons and the Cimbri—was held unworthy on account of the obscurity of his family, and which Scipio won before his time as the reward of valour,—this great office is now obtained by merely belonging to the army; and the shining robe of victory now envelops men who a little while ago were country boors.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:102
verses.text: Thus we have received more than we have given.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:103
verses.text: The things we have renounced are small; the things we possess are great.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:104
verses.text: All that Christ promises is duly performed and for what we have given up we have received an hundredfold.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:105
verses.text: This was the ground in which Isaac sowed his seed, Isaac who in his readiness to die bore the cross of the Gospel before the Gospel came.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:107
verses.text: "If thou wilt be perfect," the Lord says, "go and sell that thou hast and give to the poor.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:108
verses.text: …and come and follow me".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:109
verses.text: If thou wilt be perfect.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:110
verses.text: Great enterprises are always left to the free choice of those who hear of them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:111
verses.text: Thus the apostle refrains from making virginity a positive duty, because the Lord in speaking of eunuchs who had made themselves such for the kingdom of heaven's sake finally said: "He that is able to receive it, let him receive it".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:112
verses.text: For, to quote the apostle, "it is not of him that willeth, nor of him that runneth, but of God that sheweth mercy".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:113
verses.text: If thou wilt be perfect.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:114
verses.text: There is no compulsion laid upon you: if you are to win the prize it must be by the exercise of your own free will.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:115
verses.text: If therefore you will to be perfect and desire to be as the prophets, as the apostles, as Christ Himself, sell not a part of your substance (lest the fear of want become an occasion of unfaithfulness, and so you perish with Ananias and Sapphira) but all that you have.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:116
verses.text: And when you have sold all, give the proceeds not to the wealthy or to the high-minded but to the poor.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:117
verses.text: Give each man enough for his immediate need but do not give money to swell what a man has already.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:118
verses.text: "Thou shalt not muzzle the mouth of the ox that treadeth out the corn," and "the labourer is worthy of his reward".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:119
verses.text: Again "they which wait at the altar are partakers with the altar".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:120
verses.text: Remember also these words: "having food and raiment let us be therewith content".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:121
verses.text: Where you see smoking dishes, steaming pheasants, massive silver plate, spirited nags, long-haired boy-slaves, expensive clothing, and embroidered hangings, give nothing there.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:122
verses.text: For he to whom you would give is richer than you the giver.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:123
verses.text: It is moreover a kind of sacrilege to give what belongs to the poor to those who are not poor.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:124
verses.text: Yet to be a perfect and complete Christian it is not enough to despise wealth or to squander and fling away one's money, a thing which can be lost and found in a single moment.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:125
verses.text: Crates the Theban did this, so did Antisthenes and several others, whose lives shew them to have had many faults.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:126
verses.text: The disciple of Christ must do more for the attainment of spiritual glory than the philosopher of the world, than the venal slave of flying rumours and of the people's breath.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:127
verses.text: It is not enough for you to despise wealth unless you follow Christ as well.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:128
verses.text: And only he follows Christ who forsakes his sins and walks hand in hand with virtue.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:129
verses.text: We know that Christ is wisdom.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:130
verses.text: He is the treasure which in the scriptures a man finds in his field.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:131
verses.text: He is the peerless gem which is bought by selling many pearls.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:132
verses.text: But if you love a captive woman, that is, worldly wisdom, and if no beauty but hers attracts you, make her bald and cut off her alluring hair, that is to say, the graces of style, and pare away her dead nails.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:133
verses.text: Wash her with the nitre of which the prophet speaks, and then take your ease with her and say "Her left hand is under my head, and her right hand doth embrace me".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:134
verses.text: Then shall the captive bring to you many children; from a Moabitess she shall become an Israelitish woman.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:135
verses.text: Christ is that sanctification without which no man shall see the face of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:136
verses.text: Christ is our redemption, for He is at once our Redeemer and our Ransom.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:137
verses.text: Christ is all, that he who has left all for Christ may find One in place of all, and may be able to proclaim freely, "The Lord is my portion".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:139
verses.text: I see clearly that you have a warm affection for divine learning and that far from trying—like some rash persons—to teach that of which you are yourself ignorant you make it your first object to learn what you are going to teach.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:140
verses.text: Your letters in their simplicity are redolent of the prophets and savour strongly of the apostles.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:141
verses.text: You do not affect a stilted eloquence, nor boylike balance shallow sentences in clauses neatly-turned.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:142
verses.text: The quickly frothing foam disappears with equal quickness; and a tumour though it enlarges the size of the body is injurious to health.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:143
verses.text: It is moreover a shrewd maxim, this of Cato, "Fast enough if well enough".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:144
verses.text: Long ago it is true in the days of our youth we laughed outright at this dictum when the finished orator used it in his exordium.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:145
verses.text: I fancy you remember the mistake shared by the speaker in our Athenaeum and how the whole room resounded with the cry taken up by the students "Fast enough if well enough".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:146
verses.text: According to Fabius crafts would be sure to prosper if none but craftsmen were allowed to criticise them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:147
verses.text: No man can adequately estimate a poet unless he is competent himself to write verse.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:148
verses.text: No man can comprehend philosophers, unless he is acquainted with the various theories that they have held.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:149
verses.text: Material and visible products are best appraised by those who make them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:150
verses.text: To what a cruel lot we men of letters are exposed you may gather from the fact that we are forced to rely on the judgment of the public; and many a man is in company a formidable opponent who would certainly be despised could he be seen alone.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:151
verses.text: I have touched on this in passing to make you content, if possible, with the ear of the learned.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:152
verses.text: Disregard the remarks which uneducated persons make concerning your ability; but day by day imbibe the marrow of the prophets, that you may know the mystery of Christ and share this mystery with the patriarchs.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:154
verses.text: Whether you read or write, whether you wake or sleep, let the herdsman's horn of Amos always ring in your ears.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:155
verses.text: Let the sound of the clarion arouse your soul, let the divine love carry you out of yourself; and then seek upon your bed him whom your soul loveth, and boldly say: "I sleep, but my heart waketh".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:156
verses.text: And when you have found him and taken hold of him, let him not go.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:157
verses.text: And if you fall asleep for a moment and He escapes from your hands, do not forthwith despair.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:158
verses.text: Go out into the streets and charge the daughters of Jerusalem: then shall you find him lying down in the noontide weary and drunk with passion, or wet with the dew of night by the flocks of his companions, or fragrant with many kinds of spices, amid the apples of the garden.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:159
verses.text: There give to him your breasts, let him suck your learned bosom, let him rest in the midst of his heritage, his feathers as those of a dove overlaid with silver and his inward parts with the brightness of gold.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:160
verses.text: This young child, this mere boy, who is fed on butter and honey, and who is reared among curdled mountains, quickly grows up to manhood, speedily spoils all that is opposed to him in you, and when the time is ripe plunders [the spiritual] Damascus and puts in chains the king of [the spiritual] Assyria.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:162
verses.text: I hear that you have erected a hospice for strangers at Portus and that you have planted a twig from the tree of Abraham upon the Ausonian shore.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:163
verses.text: Like aeneas you are tracing the outlines of a new encampment; only that, whereas he, when he reached the waters of the Tiber, under pressure of want had to eat the square flat cakes which formed the tables spoken of by the oracle, you are able to build a house of bread to rival this little village of Bethlehem wherein I am staying; and here after their long privations you propose to satisfy travellers with sudden plenty.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:164
verses.text: Well done.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:165
verses.text: You have surpassed my poor beginning.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:166
verses.text: You have reached the highest point.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:167
verses.text: You have made your way from the root to the top of the tree.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:168
verses.text: You are the first of monks in the first city of the world: you do right therefore to follow the first of the patriarchs.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:169
verses.text: Let Lot, whose name means 'one who turns aside' choose the plain and let him follow the left and easy branch of the famous letter of Pythagoras.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:170
verses.text: But do you make ready for yourself a monument like Sarah's on steep and rocky heights.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:171
verses.text: Let the City of Books be near; and when you have destroyed the giants, the sons of Anak, make over your heritage to joy and merriment.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:172
verses.text: Abraham was rich in gold and silver and cattle, in substance and in raiment: his household was so large that on an emergency he could bring a picked body of young men into the field, and could pursue as far as Dan and then slay four kings who had already put five kings to flight.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:173
verses.text: Frequently exercising hospitality and never turning any man away from his door, he was accounted worthy at last to entertain God himself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:174
verses.text: He was not satisfied with giving orders to his servants and hand-maids to attend to his guests, nor did he lessen the favour he conferred by leaving others to care for them; but as though he had found a prize, he and Sarah his wife gave themselves to the duties of hospitality.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:175
verses.text: With his own hands he washed the feet of his guests, upon his own shoulders he brought home a fat calf from the herd.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:176
verses.text: While the strangers dined he stood by to serve them, and set before them the dishes cooked by Sarah's hands—though meaning to fast himself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:178
verses.text: The regard which I feel for you, my dear brother, makes me remind you of these things; for you must offer to Christ not only your money but yourself, to be a "living sacrifice, holy, acceptable unto God, which is your reasonable service," and you must imitate the son of man who "came not to be ministered unto but to minister".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:179
verses.text: What the patriarch did for strangers that our Lord and Master did for His servants and disciples.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:180
verses.text: "Skin for skin, yea, all that a man hath will he give for his life.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:181
verses.text: But," says the devil, "touch his flesh and he will curse thee to thy face".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:182
verses.text: The old enemy knows that the battle with impurity is a harder one than that with covetousness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:183
verses.text: It is easy to cast off what clings to us from without, but a war within our borders involves far greater peril.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:184
verses.text: We have to unfasten things joined together, we have to sunder things firmly united.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:185
verses.text: Zacchaeus was rich while the apostles were poor.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:186
verses.text: He restored fourfold all that he had taken and gave to the poor the half of his remaining substance.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:187
verses.text: He welcomed Christ as his guest, and salvation came unto his house.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:188
verses.text: And yet because he was little of stature and could not reach the apostolic standard of height, he was not numbered with the twelve apostles.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:189
verses.text: Now as regards wealth the apostles gave up nothing at all, but as regards will they one and all gave up the whole world.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:190
verses.text: If we offer to Christ our souls as well as our riches, he will gladly receive our offering.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:191
verses.text: But if we give to God only those things which are without while we give to the devil those things which are within, the division is not fair, and the divine voice says: "Hast thou not sinned in offering aright, and yet not dividing aright?"  13.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:192
verses.text: That you, the leader of the patrician order, first set the example of turning monk should not be to you an occasion of boasting but rather one of humility, knowing as you do that the Son of God became the Son of man.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:193
verses.text: However low you may abase yourself, you cannot be more lowly than Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:194
verses.text: Even supposing that you walk barefooted, that you dress in sombre garb, that you rank yourself with the poor, that you condescend to enter the tenements of the needy, that you are eyes to the blind, hands to the weak, feet to the lame, that you carry water and hew wood and make fires—even supposing that you do all this, where are the chains, the buffets, the spittings, the scourgings, the gibbet, the death which the Lord endured? And even when you have done all the things I have mentioned, you are still surpassed by your sister Eustochium as well as by Paula: for considering the weakness of their sex they have done more work relatively if less absolutely, than you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:195
verses.text: I myself was not at Rome but in the desert—would that I had continued there—at the time when your father-in-law Toxotius was still alive and his daughters were still given up to the world.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:196
verses.text: But I have heard that they were too dainty to walk in the muddy streets, that they were carried about in the arms of eunuchs, that they disliked crossing uneven ground, that they found a silk dress a burthen and felt sunshine too scorching.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:197
verses.text: But now, squalid and sombre in their dress, they are positive heroines in comparison with what they used to be.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:198
verses.text: They trim lamps, light fires, sweep floors, clean vegetables, put heads of cabbage in the pot to boil, lay tables, hand cups, help dishes and run to and fro to wait on others.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:199
verses.text: And yet there is no lack of virgins under the same roof with them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:200
verses.text: Is it then that they have no servants upon whom they can lay these duties? Surely not.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:201
verses.text: They are unwilling that others should surpass them in physical toil whom they themselves surpass in rigour of mind.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:202
verses.text: I say all this not because I doubt your mental ardour but that I may quicken the pace at which you are running, and in the heat of battle may add warmth to your warmth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:204
verses.text: I for my part am building in this province a monastery and a hospice close by; so that, if Joseph and Mary chance to come to Bethlehem, they may not fail to find shelter and welcome.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:205
verses.text: Indeed, the number of monks who flock here from all quarters of the world is so overwhelming that I can neither desist from my enterprise nor bear so great a burthen.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:206
verses.text: The warning of the gospel has been all but fulfilled in me, for I did not sufficiently count the cost of the tower I was about to build; accordingly I have been constrained to send my brother Paulinian to Italy to sell some ruinous villas which have escaped the hands of the barbarians, and also the property inherited from our common parents.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:207
verses.text: For I am loth, now that I have begun it, to give up ministering to the saints, lest I incur the ridicule of carping and envious persons.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:209
verses.text: Now that I have come to the conclusion of my letter I recall my metaphor of the four-horse team, and recollect that Blaesilla would have made a fifth had she been spared to share your resolve.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:210
verses.text: I had almost forgotten to mention her, the first of you all to go to meet the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:211
verses.text: You who once were five I now see to be two and three.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 66:212
verses.text: Blaesilla and her sister Paulina rest in sweet sleep: you with the two others on either side of you will fly upward to Christ more easily.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 67:1
verses.text: Letter LXVII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 67:2
verses.text: From Augustine.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 67:3
verses.text: Jerome having written him a short letter (no longer extant) Augustine now replies.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 67:4
verses.text: He speaks with approval of Jerome's treatise On Famous Men, incorrectly called the Epitaph (see Letter CXII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 67:6
verses.text: He also repeats his objections to Jerome's account of the quarrel between Paul and Peter at Antioch and then concludes with a request that he will draw up a short notice of the principal heresies condemned by the Church.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 67:7
verses.text: Like the preceding letter of Augustine (Letter LVI.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 67:8
verses.text: ) this also failed to reach Jerome.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 67:9
verses.text: It was however published in the West, but without Augustine's knowledge and by degrees its contents found their way to Bethlehem where they caused much annoyance and pain.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 67:10
verses.text: The date of the letter is 397 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 67:11
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 67:12
verses.text: In Augustine's correspondence in this Library it is printed in full as Letter XL.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 68:1
verses.text: Letter LXVIII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 68:2
verses.text: To Castrutius.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 68:3
verses.text: Castrutius, a blind man of Pannonia, had set out for Bethlehem to visit Jerome.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 68:4
verses.text: However, on reaching Cissa (whether that in Thrace or that on the Adriatic is uncertain) he was induced by his friends to turn back.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 68:5
verses.text: Jerome writes to thank him for his intention and to console him for his inability to carry it out.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 68:6
verses.text: He then tries to comfort him in his blindness (1) by referring to Christ's words concerning the man born blind (Joh.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 68:7
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 68:8
verses.text: 3) and (2) by telling him the story of Antony and Didymus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 68:9
verses.text: The date of the letter is 397 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 68:10
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 68:12
verses.text: My reverend son Heraclius the deacon has reported to me that in your eagerness to see me you came as far as Cissa, and that, though a Pannonian and consequently a land animal, you did not quail before the surges of the Adriatic and the dangers of the aegean and Ionian seas.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 68:13
verses.text: He tells me that you would have actually accomplished your purpose, had not our brethren with affectionate care held you back.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 68:14
verses.text: I thank you all the same and regard it as a kindness shewn.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 68:15
verses.text: For in the case of friends one must accept the will for the deed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 68:16
