verses.text: Enemies often give us the latter, but only sincere attachment can bring us the former.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 68:17
verses.text: And now that I am writing to you I beseech you do not regard the bodily affliction which has befallen you as due to sin.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 68:18
verses.text: When the Apostles speculated concerning the man that was born blind from the womb and asked our Lord and Saviour: "Who did sin, this man or his parents, that he was born blind?" they were told "Neither hath this man sinned nor his parents, but that the works of God should be made manifest in him".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 68:19
verses.text: Do we not see numbers of heathens, Jews, heretics and men of various opinions rolling in the mire of lust, bathed in blood, surpassing wolves in ferocity and kites in rapacity, and for all this the plague does not come nigh their dwellings? They are not smitten as other men, and accordingly they wax insolent against God and lift up their faces even to heaven.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 68:20
verses.text: We know on the other hand that holy men are afflicted with sicknesses, miseries, and want, and perhaps they are tempted to say "Verily I have cleansed my heart in vain, and washed my hands in innocency".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 68:21
verses.text: Yet immediately they go on to reprove themselves, "If I say, I will speak thus; behold I should offend against the generation of thy children".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 68:22
verses.text: If you suppose that your blindness is caused by sin, and that a disease which physicians are often able to cure is an evidence of God's anger, you will think Isaac a sinner because he was so wholly sightless that he was deceived into blessing one whom he did not mean to bless.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 68:23
verses.text: You will charge Jacob with sin, whose vision became so dim that he could not see Ephraim and Manasseh, although with the inner eye and the prophetic spirit he could foresee the distant future and the Christ that was to come of his royal line.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 68:24
verses.text: Were any of the kings holier than Josiah? Yet he was slain by the sword of the Egyptians.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 68:25
verses.text: Were there ever loftier saints than Peter and Paul? Yet their blood stained the blade of Nero.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 68:26
verses.text: And to say no more of men, did not the Son of God endure the shame of the cross? And yet you fancy those blessed who enjoy in this world happiness and pleasure? God's hottest anger against sinners is when he shews no anger.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 68:27
verses.text: Wherefore in Ezekiel he says to Jerusalem: "My jealousy will depart from thee and I will be quiet and will be no more angry".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 68:28
verses.text: For "whom the Lord loveth He chasteneth, and scourgeth every son whom He receiveth".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 68:29
verses.text: The father does not instruct his son unless he loves him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 68:30
verses.text: The master does not correct his disciple unless he sees in him signs of promise.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 68:31
verses.text: When once the doctor gives over caring for the patient, it is a sign that he despairs.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 68:32
verses.text: You should answer thus: "as Lazarus in his lifetime received evil things so will I now gladly suffer torments that future glory may be laid up for me".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 68:33
verses.text: For "affliction shall not rise up the second time".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 68:34
verses.text: If Job, a man holy and spotless and righteous in his generation, suffered terrible afflictions, his own book explains the reason why.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 68:36
verses.text: That I may not make myself tedious or exceed the due limits of a letter by repeating old stories, I will briefly relate to you an incident which happened in my childhood.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 68:37
verses.text: The saintly Athanasius bishop of Alexandria had summoned the blessed Antony to that city to confute the heretics there.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 68:38
verses.text: Hereupon Didymus, a man of great learning who had lost his eyes, came to visit the hermit and, the conversation turning upon the holy scriptures, Antony could not help admiring his ability and eulogizing his insight.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 68:39
verses.text: At last he said: You do not regret, do you, the loss of your eyes? At first Didymus was ashamed to answer, but when the question had been repeated a second time and a third, he frankly confessed that his blindness was a great grief to him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 68:40
verses.text: Whereupon Antony said: "I am surprised that a wise man should grieve at the loss of a faculty which he shares with ants and flies and gnats, and not rejoice rather in having one of which only saints and apostles have been thought worthy".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 68:41
verses.text: From this story you may perceive how much better it is to have spiritual than carnal vision and to possess eyes into which the mote of sin cannot fall.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 68:42
verses.text: Though you have failed to come this year, I do not yet despair of your coming.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 68:43
verses.text: If the reverend deacon who is the bearer of this letter is again caught in the toils of your affection, and if you come hither in his company I shall be delighted to welcome you and shall readily acknowledge that the delay in payment is made up for by the largeness of the interest.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:1
verses.text: Letter LXIX.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:2
verses.text: To Oceanus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:3
verses.text: Oceanus, a Roman nobleman zealous for the faith, had asked Jerome to back him in a protest against Carterius a Spanish bishop who contrary to the apostolic rule that a bishop is to be "the husband of one wife" had married a second time.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:4
verses.text: Jerome refuses to take the line suggested on the ground that Carterius's first marriage having preceded his baptism cannot be taken into account.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:5
verses.text: He therefore advises Oceanus to let the matter drop.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:6
verses.text: The date of the letter is 397 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:7
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:9
verses.text: I never supposed, son Oceanus, that the clemency of the Emperor would be assailed by criminals, or that persons just released from prison would after their own experience of its filth and fetters complain of relaxations allowed to others.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:10
verses.text: In the gospel he who envies another's salvation is thus addressed: "Friend, is thine eye evil because I am good?" "God hath concluded them all in sin that he might have mercy upon all".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:11
verses.text: "When sin abounded grace did much more abound".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:12
verses.text: The first born of Egypt are slain and not even a beast belonging to Israel is left behind in Egypt.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:13
verses.text: The heresy of the Cainites rises before me and the once slain viper lifts up its shattered head, destroying not partially as most often hitherto but altogether the mystery of Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:14
verses.text: This heresy declares that there are some sins which Christ cannot cleanse with His blood, and that the scars left by old transgressions on the body and the soul are sometimes so deep that they cannot be effaced by the remedy which He supplies.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:15
verses.text: What else is this but to say that Christ has died in vain? He has indeed died in vain if there are any whom He cannot make alive.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:16
verses.text: When John the Baptist points to Christ and says: "Behold the lamb of God which taketh away the sins of the world" he utters a falsehood if after all there are persons living whose sins Christ has not taken away.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:17
verses.text: For either it must be shewn that they are not of the world whom the grace of Christ thus ignores: or, if it be admitted that they are of the world, we have to choose between the horns of a dilemma.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:18
verses.text: Either they have been delivered from their sins, in which case the power of Christ to save all men is proved; or they remain undelivered and as it were still under the charge of misdoing, in which case Christ is proved to be powerless.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:19
verses.text: But far be it from us to believe of the Almighty that He is powerless in aught.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:20
verses.text: For "what things soever the Father doeth, these also doeth the Son likewise".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:21
verses.text: To ascribe weakness to the Son is to ascribe it to the Father also.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:22
verses.text: The shepherd carries the whole sheep and not only this or that part of it: all the epistles of the apostle speak continually of the grace of Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:23
verses.text: And, lest a single announcement of this grace might seem a little thing, Peter says: "Grace unto you and peace be multiplied".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:24
verses.text: The Scripture promises abundance; yet we affirm scarcity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:26
verses.text: To what does all this tend, you ask.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:27
verses.text: I reply; you remember the question that you proposed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:28
verses.text: It was this.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:29
verses.text: A Spanish bishop named Carterius, old in years and in the priesthood has married two wives, one before he was baptized, and, she having died, another since he has passed through the laver; and you are of opinion that he has violated the precept of the apostle, who in his list of episcopal qualifications commands that a bishop shall be "the husband of one wife".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:30
verses.text: I am surprised that you have pilloried an individual when the whole world is filled with persons ordained in similar circumstances; I do not mean presbyters or clergy of lower rank, but speak only of bishops of whom if I were to enumerate them all one by one I should gather a sufficient number to surpass the crowd which attended the synod of Ariminum.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:31
verses.text: Still it does not become me to defend one by incriminating many; nor if reason condemns a sin, to make the number of those who commit it an excuse for it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:32
verses.text: At Rome an eloquent pleader caught me, as the phrase goes, between the horns of a dilemma: whichever way I turned I was held fast.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:33
verses.text: Is it sinful, said he, to marry a wife, or is it not sinful? I in my simplicity, not being wary enough to avoid the snare laid for me, replied that it was not sinful.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:34
verses.text: Then he propounded another question: Is it good deeds which are done away with in baptism or is it evil? Here again my simplicity induced me to say that it was sins which were forgiven.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:35
verses.text: At this point, just as I began to fancy myself secure, the horns of the dilemma commenced to close in on me from this side and from that and their points hidden before began to shew themselves.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:36
verses.text: If, said he, to marry a wife is not sinful, and if baptism forgives sins, all that is not done away with is held over.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:37
verses.text: On the instant a dark mist rose before my eyes as though I had been struck by a strong boxer.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:38
verses.text: Yet recalling the sophism attributed to Chrysippus: "Whether you lie or whether you speak the truth, in either case you lie," I came to myself again and turned upon my opponent with a dilemma of my own.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:39
verses.text: Pray tell me, I said, does baptism make a new man or does it not? He grudgingly admitted that it did.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:40
verses.text: I pursued my advantage by saying, Does it make him wholly new or only partially so? He replied, Wholly.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:41
verses.text: Then I asked, Is there nothing then of the old man held over in baptism? He assented.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:42
verses.text: Hereupon I propounded the argument; If baptism makes a man new and creates a wholly new being, and if there is nothing of the old man held over in the new, that which once was in the old cannot be imputed to the new.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:43
verses.text: At first my thorny friend held his tongue; afterwards however, making Piso's mistake, though he had nothing to say he could not remain silent.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:44
verses.text: Sweat stood upon his brow, his cheeks turned pale, his lips trembled, his tongue clove to his mouth, his throat became dry; and fear (not age) made him cower.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:45
verses.text: At last he broke out in these words, Have you not read how the apostle permits none to be ordained priest save the husband of one wife, and that what he lays stress upon is the fact of the marriage and not the time at which it is contracted? Now as the fellow had challenged me with syllogisms, and as I saw that he was feeling his way towards some intricate and awkward questions, I proceeded to turn his own weapons against him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:46
verses.text: I said therefore, Whom did the apostle select for the episcopate, baptized persons or catechumens? He refused to reply.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:47
verses.text: I however made a fresh onslaught repeating my question a second time and a third.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:48
verses.text: You would have taken him for Niobe changed to stone by excessive weeping.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:49
verses.text: I turned to the audience and said: It is all the same to me, good people, whether I bind my opponent awake or sleeping; but it is easier to fetter a man who offers no resistance.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:50
verses.text: If those whom the apostle admits into the ranks of the clergy are not catechumens but the faithful, and if he who is ordained bishop is always one of the faithful, being one of the faithful he cannot have the faults of a catechumen imputed to him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:51
verses.text: Such were the darts I hurled at my paralysed opponent.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:52
verses.text: Such the quivering spears I cast at him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:53
verses.text: At last his mouth opened and he vomited forth the contents of his mind.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:54
verses.text: Certainly, he blurted out, that is the doctrine of the apostle Paul.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:56
verses.text: Accordingly I bring out two epistles of the apostle, the first to Timothy, and the second to Titus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:57
verses.text: In the first is the following passage: "If a man desire the office of a bishop he desireth a good work.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:58
verses.text: A bishop then must be blameless, the husband of one wife, vigilant, sober, of good behaviour, given to hospitality, apt to teach, not given to wine, no striker…but patient, not a brawler, not covetous; one that ruleth well his own house, having his children in subjection with all gravity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:59
verses.text: (For if a man know not how to rule his own house, how shall he take care of the church of God?) Not a novice lest being lifted up with pride he fall into the condemnation of the devil.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:60
verses.text: Moreover he must have a good report of them which are without; lest he fall into reproach and the snare of the devil".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:61
verses.text: While immediately at the commencement of the epistle to Titus the following behests are laid down: "For this cause left I thee in Crete that thou shouldest set in order the things that are wanting, and ordain elders in every city, as I had appointed thee: if any be blameless, the husband of one wife, having faithful children not accused of riot or unruly.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:62
verses.text: For a bishop must be blameless as the steward of God; not self-willed, not soon angry, not given to wine, no striker, not given to filthy lucre; but a lover of hospitality, a lover of good men, sober, just, holy, temperate; holding fast the faithful word as he hath been taught, that he may be able by sound doctrine both to exhort and to convince the gainsayers".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:63
verses.text: In both epistles commandment is given that only monogamists should be chosen for the clerical office whether as bishops or as presbyters.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:64
verses.text: Indeed with the ancients these names were synonymous, one alluding to the office, the other to the age of the clergy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:65
verses.text: No one at any rate can doubt that the apostle is speaking only of those who have been baptized.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:66
verses.text: If therefore it in no wise prejudices the case of one who is to be ordained bishop that before his baptism he has not possessed all the requisite qualifications (for it is asked what he is and not what he has been), why should a previous marriage—the one thing which is in itself not sinful—prove a hindrance to his ordination? You argue that as his marriage was not a sin it was not done away with at his baptism.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:67
verses.text: This is news to me indeed, that what in itself was not a sin is to be reckoned as such.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:68
verses.text: All fornication and contamination with open vice, impiety towards God, parricide and incest, the change of the natural use of the sexes into that which is against nature and all extraordinary lusts are washed away in the fountain of Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:69
verses.text: Can it be possible that the stains of marriage are indelible, and that harlotry is judged more leniently than honourable wedlock? I do not, Carterius might say, hold you to blame for the hosts of mistresses and the troops of favourites that you have kept; I do not charge you with your bloodshedding and sow-like wallowings in the mire of uncleanness: yet you are ready to drag from her grave for my confusion my poor wife, who has been dead long years, and whom I married that I might be kept from those sins into which you have fallen.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:70
verses.text: Tell this to the heathen who form the church's harvest with which she stores her granaries; tell this to the catechumens who seek admission to the number of the faithful; tell them, I say, not to contract marriages before their baptism, not to enter upon honourable wedlock, but like the Scots and the Atacotti and the people of Plato's republic to have community of wives and no discrimination of children, nay more, to beware of any semblance even of matrimony; lest, after they have come to believe in Christ, He shall tell them that those whom they have had have not been concubines or mistresses but wedded wives.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:72
verses.text: Let every man examine his own conscience and let him deplore the violence he has done to it at every period of his life; and then when he has brought himself to deliver a true judgment on his own former misdeeds, let him give ear to the chiding of Jesus: "Thou hypocrite, first cast out the beam out of thine own eye; and then shalt thou see clearly to cast out the mote out of thy brother's eye".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:73
verses.text: Truly like the scribes and pharisees we strain out the gnat and swallow the camel, we pay tithe of mint and anise, and we omit the just judgment which God requires.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:74
verses.text: What parallel can be drawn between a wife and a prostitute? Is it fair to make a marriage now dissolved by death a ground of accusation, while dissolute living wins for itself a garland of praise? He, had his former wife lived, would not have married another; but as for you, how can you defend the bestial unions you indiscriminately make? Perhaps indeed you will say that you feared to contract marriage lest by so doing you might disqualify yourself for ordination.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:75
verses.text: He took a wife that he might have children by her; you by taking a harlot have lost the hope of children.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:76
verses.text: He withdrew into the privacy of his own chamber when he sought to obey nature and to win God's blessing: "Be fruitful and multiply and replenish the earth".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:77
verses.text: You on the contrary outraged public decency in the hot eagerness of your lust.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:78
verses.text: He covered a lawful indulgence beneath a veil of modesty; you pursued an unlawful one shamelessly before the eyes of all.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:79
verses.text: For him it is written "Marriage is honourable and the bed undefiled," while to you the words are read, "but whoremongers and adulterers God wilt judge," and "if any man destroyeth the temple of God, him shall God destroy".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:80
verses.text: All iniquities, we are told, are forgiven us at our baptism, and when once we have received God's mercy we need not afterwards dread from Him the severity of a judge.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:81
verses.text: The apostle says:—"And such were some of you: but ye are washed, but ye are sanctified, but ye are justified in the name of the Lord Jesus, and by the Spirit of our God".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:82
verses.text: All sins then are forgiven; it is an honest and faithful saying.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:83
verses.text: But I ask you, how comes it that, while your uncleanness is washed away, my cleanness is made unclean? You reply, "No, it is not made unclean, it remains just what it was.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:84
verses.text: Had it been uncleanness, it would have been washed away like mine".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:85
verses.text: I want to know what you mean by this shuffling.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:86
verses.text: Your remarks seem to have no more point in them than the round end of a pestle.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:87
verses.text: Is a thing sin because it is not sin? or is a thing unclean because it is not unclean? The Lord, you say, has not forgiven because He had nothing to forgive; yet because He has not forgiven, that which has not been forgiven still remains.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:89
verses.text: What the true effect of baptism is, and what is the real grace conveyed by water hallowed in Christ, I will presently tell you; meantime I will deal with this argument as it deserves.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:90
verses.text: 'An ill knot,' says the common proverb, 'requires but an ill wedge to split it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:91
verses.text: ' The text quoted by the objector, "a bishop must be the husband of one wife," admits of quite another explanation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:92
verses.text: The apostle came of the Jews and the primitive Christian church was gathered out of the remnants of Israel.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:93
verses.text: Paul knew that the Law allowed men to have children by several wives, and was aware that the example of the patriarchs had made polygamy familiar to the people.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:94
verses.text: Even the very priests might at their own discretion enjoy the same license.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:95
verses.text: He gave commandment therefore that the priests of the church should not claim this liberty, that they should not take two wives or three together, but that they should each have but one wife at one time.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:96
verses.text: Perhaps you may say that this explanation which I have given is disputed; in that case listen to another.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:97
verses.text: You must not have a monopoly of bending the Law to suit your will instead of bending your will to suit the Law.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:98
verses.text: Some by a strained interpretation say that wives are in this passage to be taken for churches and husbands for their bishops.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:99
verses.text: A decree was made by the fathers assembled at the council of Nicaea that no bishop should be translated from one church to another, lest scorning the society of a poor yet virgin see he should seek the embraces of a wealthy and adulterous one.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:100
verses.text: For as the word λογισμόι, that is, "disputings," refers to the fault and misdoing of sons in the faith, and as the precept concerning the management of a house refers to the right direction of body and of soul, so by the wives of the bishops we are to understand their churches.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:101
verses.text: Concerning whom it is written in Isaiah, "Make haste ye women and come from the show, for it is a people of no understanding".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:102
verses.text: And again "Rise up, ye women that are wealthy, and hear my voice".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:103
verses.text: And in the Book of Proverbs, "Who can find a virtuous woman? for her price is far above rubies.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:104
verses.text: The heart of her husband doth safely trust in her".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:105
verses.text: In the same book too it is written, "Every wise woman buildeth her house: but the foolish plucketh it down with her hands".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:106
verses.text: Nor does this, say they, derogate from the dignity of the episcopate; for the same figure is used in relation to God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:107
verses.text: Jeremiah writes: "As a wife treacherously departeth from her husband, so have ye dealt treacherously with me, O house of Israel".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:108
verses.text: And the apostle employs the same comparison: "I have espoused you," he says to his converts, "to one husband, that I may present you as a chaste virgin to Christ".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:109
verses.text: The word woman is in the Greek ambiguous and should in all these places be understood as meaning wife.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:110
verses.text: You will say that this interpretation is harsh and does violence to the sense.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:111
verses.text: In that case give back to the scripture its simple meaning and save me from the necessity of fighting you on your own ground.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:112
verses.text: I will ask you the following question, Can a man who before his baptism has kept a concubine, and after her death has received baptism and has taken a wife, become a clergyman or not? You will answer me that he can, because his first partner was a concubine and not a wife.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:113
verses.text: What the apostle condemns then, it would seem, is not mere sexual intercourse but marriage contracts and conjugal rights.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:114
verses.text: Many persons, we see, because of narrow circumstances refuse to take upon them the burthen of matrimony.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:115
verses.text: Instead of taking wives they live with their maid-servants and bring up as their own the children which these bear to them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:116
verses.text: Thus, if through the bounty of the Emperor they gain for their mistresses the right of wearing a matron's robes, they will at once come beneath the yoke of the apostle and sorely against their will will have to receive their partners as their wedded wives.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:117
verses.text: But, if their poverty prevents them from obtaining an imperial rescript such as I have mentioned, the decrees of the Church will vary with the laws of Rome.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:118
verses.text: Be careful therefore not to interpret the words "the husband of one wife," that is, of one woman, as approving indiscriminate intercourse and condemning only contracts of marriage.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:119
verses.text: I bring forward all these explanations not for the purpose of resisting the true and simple sense of the words in question but to shew you that you must take the holy scriptures as they are written, and that you must not empty of its efficacy the baptismal rite ordained by the Saviour, or render vain the whole mystery of the cross.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:121
verses.text: Let me now fulfil the promise I made a little while ago and with all the skill of a rhetorician sing the praises of water and of baptism.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:122
verses.text: In the beginning the earth was without form and void, there was no dazzling sun or pale moon, there were no glittering stars.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:123
verses.text: There was nothing but matter inorganic and invisible, and even this was lost in abysmal depths and shrouded in a distorting gloom.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:124
verses.text: The Spirit of God above moved, as a charioteer, over the face of the waters, and produced from them the infant world, a type of the Christian child that is drawn from the laver of baptism.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:125
verses.text: A firmament is constructed between heaven and earth, and to this is allotted the name heaven,—in the Hebrew Shamayim or 'what comes out of the waters,'—and the waters which are above the heavens are parted from the others to the praise of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:126
verses.text: Wherefore also in the vision of the prophet Ezekiel there is seen above the cherubim a crystal stretched forth, that is, the compressed and denser waters.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:127
verses.text: The first living beings come out of the waters; and believers soar out of the laver with wings to heaven.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:128
verses.text: Man is formed out of clay and God holds the mystic waters in the hollow of his hand.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:129
verses.text: In Eden a garden is planted, and a fountain in the midst of it parts into four heads.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:130
verses.text: This is the same fountain which Ezekiel later on describes as issuing out of the temple and flowing towards the rising of the sun, until it heals the bitter waters and quickens those that are dead.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:131
verses.text: When the world falls into sin nothing but a flood of waters can cleanse it again.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:132
verses.text: But as soon as the foul bird of wickedness is driven away, the dove of the Holy Spirit comes to Noah as it came afterwards to Christ in the Jordan, and, carrying in its beak a branch betokening restoration and light, brings tidings of peace to the whole world.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:133
verses.text: Pharaoh and his host, loth to allow God's people to leave Egypt, are overwhelmed in the Red Sea figuring thereby our baptism.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:134
verses.text: His destruction is thus described in the book of Psalms: "Thou didst endow the sea with virtue through thy power: thou brakest the heads of the dragons in the waters: thou brakest the heads of leviathan in pieces".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:135
verses.text: For this reason adders and scorpions haunt dry places and whenever they come near water behave as if rabid or insane.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:136
verses.text: As wood sweetens Marah so that seventy palm-trees are watered by its streams, so the cross makes the waters of the law lifegiving to the seventy who are Christ's apostles.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:137
verses.text: It is Abraham and Isaac who dig wells, the Philistines who try to prevent them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:138
verses.text: Beersheba too, the city of the oath, and [Gihon], the scene of Solomon's coronation, derive their names from springs.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:139
verses.text: It is beside a well that Eliezer finds Rebekah.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:140
verses.text: Rachel too is a drawer of water and wins a kiss thereby from the supplanter Jacob.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:141
verses.text: When the daughters of the priests of Midian are in a strait to reach the well, Moses opens a way for them and delivers them from outrage.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:142
verses.text: The Lord's forerunner at Salem (a name which means peace or perfection) makes ready the people for Christ with spring-water.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:143
verses.text: The Saviour Himself does not preach the kingdom of heaven until by His baptismal immersion He has cleansed the Jordan.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:144
verses.text: Water is the matter of His first miracle and it is from a well that the Samaritan woman is bidden to slake her thirst.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:145
verses.text: To Nicodemus He secretly says:—"Except a man be born of water and of the Spirit, he cannot enter into the Kingdom of God".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:146
verses.text: As His earthly course began with water, so it ended with it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:147
verses.text: His side is pierced by the spear, and blood and water flow forth, twin emblems of baptism and of martyrdom.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:148
verses.text: After His resurrection also, when sending His apostles to the Gentiles, He commands them to baptize these in the mystery of the Trinity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:149
verses.text: The Jewish people repenting of their misdoing are sent forthwith by Peter to be baptized.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:150
verses.text: Before Sion travails she brings forth children, and a nation is born at once.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:151
verses.text: Paul the persecutor of the church, that ravening wolf out of Benjamin, bows his head before Ananias one of Christ's sheep, and only recovers his sight when he applies the remedy of baptism.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:152
verses.text: By the reading of the prophet the eunuch of Candace the queen of Ethiopia is made ready for the baptism of Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:153
verses.text: Though it is against nature the Ethiopian does change his skin and the leopard his spots.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:154
verses.text: Those who have received only John's baptism and have no knowledge of the Holy Spirit are baptized again, lest any should suppose that water unsanctified thereby could suffice for the salvation of either Jew or Gentile.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:155
verses.text: "The voice of the Lord is upon the waters…The Lord is upon many waters…the Lord maketh the flood to inhabit it".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:156
verses.text: His "teeth are like a flock of sheep that are even shorn which came up from the washing; whereof everyone bear twins, and none is barren among them".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:157
verses.text: If none is barren among them, all of them must have udders filled with milk and be able to say with the apostle: "Ye are my little children, of whom I travail in birth again until Christ be formed in you;" and "I have fed you with milk and not with meat".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:158
verses.text: And it is to the grace of baptism that the prophecy of Micah refers: "He will turn again, he will have compassion upon us: he will subdue our iniquities, and will cast all our sins into the depths of the sea".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:160
verses.text: How then can you say that all sins are drowned in the baptismal laver if a man's wife is still to swim on the surface as evidence against him? The psalmist says:—"Blessed is he whose transgression is forgiven, whose sin is covered.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:161
verses.text: Blessed is the man unto whom the Lord imputeth not iniquity".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:162
verses.text: It would seem that we must add something to this song and say "Blessed is the man to whom the Lord imputeth not a wife".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:163
verses.text: Let us hear also the declaration which Ezekiel the so called "son of man" makes concerning the virtue of him who is to be the true son of man, the Christian: "I will take you," he says, "from among the heathen…then will I sprinkle clean water upon you, and ye shall be clean from all your filthiness…a new heart also will I give you and a new spirit".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:164
verses.text: "From all your filthiness" he says, "will I cleanse you".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:165
verses.text: If all is taken away nothing can be left.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:166
verses.text: If filthiness is cleansed, how much more is cleanness kept from defilement.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:167
verses.text: "A new heart also will I give you and a new spirit".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:168
verses.text: Yes, for "in Christ Jesus neither circumcision availeth anything nor uncircumcision but a new nature".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:169
verses.text: Wherefore the song also which we sing is a new song, and putting off the old man we walk not in the oldness of the letter but in the newness of the spirit.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:170
verses.text: This is the new stone wherein the new name is written, "which no man knoweth saving he that receiveth it".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:171
verses.text: "Know ye not," says the apostle, "that so many of us as were baptized into Jesus Christ were baptized into his death? Therefore we are buried with him by baptism into death: that like as Christ was raised up from the dead by the glory of the Father, even so we also should walk in newness of life".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:172
verses.text: Do we read so often of newness and of making new and yet can no renewing efface the stain which the word wife brings with it? We are buried with Christ by baptism and we have risen again by faith in the working of God who hath called Him from the dead.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:173
verses.text: And "when we were dead in our sins and in the uncircumcision of our flesh, God hath quickened us together with Him, having forgiven us all trespasses; blotting out the handwriting of ordinances that was against us, which was contrary to us, and took it out of the way nailing it to His cross".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:174
verses.text: Can it be that when our whole being is dead with Christ and when all the sins noted down in the old "handwriting" are blotted out, the one word "wife" alone lives on? Time would fail me were I to try to lay before you in order all the passages in the Holy Scriptures which relate to the efficacy of baptism or to explain the mysterious doctrine of that second birth which though it is our second is yet our first in Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:176
verses.text: Before I make an end of dictating (for I perceive that I have already exceeded the just limits of a letter) I wish to give a brief explanation of the previous verses of the epistle in which the apostle describes the life of him that is to be made a bishop.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:177
verses.text: We shall thus recognize him as Doctor of the Nations not only for his praise of monogamy but also for all his precepts.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:178
verses.text: At the same time I beg that no one will suppose that in what I write my design is to blacken the priests of the present day.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:179
verses.text: My one object is to promote the interest of the church.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:180
verses.text: Just as orators and philosophers in giving their notions of the perfect orator and the perfect philosopher do not detract from Demosthenes and Plato but merely set forth abstract ideals; so, when I describe a bishop and explain the qualifications laid down for the episcopate, I am but supplying a mirror for priests.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:181
verses.text: Every man's conscience will tell him that it rests with himself what image he will see reflected there, whether one that will grieve him by its deformity or one that will gladden him by its beauty.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:182
verses.text: I turn now to the passage in question.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:183
verses.text: "If a man desire the office of a bishop, he desireth a good work".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:184
verses.text: Work, you see, not rank; toil not pleasure; work that he may increase in lowliness, not grow proud by reason of elevation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:185
verses.text: "A bishop then must be blameless".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:186
verses.text: The same thing that he says to Titus, "if any be blameless".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:187
verses.text: All the virtues are comprehended in this one word; thus he seems to require an impossible perfection.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:188
verses.text: For if every sin, even every idle word, is deserving of blame, who is there in this world that is sinless and blameless? Still he who is chosen to be shepherd of the church must be one compared with whom other men are rightly regarded as but a flock of sheep.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:189
verses.text: Rhetoricians define an orator as a good man able to speak.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:190
verses.text: To be worthy of so high an honour he must be blameless in life and lip.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:191
verses.text: For a teacher loses all his influence whose words are rendered null by his deeds.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:192
verses.text: "The husband of one wife".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:193
verses.text: Concerning this requirement I have spoken above.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:194
verses.text: I will now only warn you that if monogamy is insisted on before baptism the other conditions laid down must be insisted on before baptism too.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:195
verses.text: For it is impossible to regard the remaining obligations as binding only on the baptized and this alone as binding also on the unbaptized.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:196
verses.text: "Vigilant (or "temperate" for νηφαλιος means both), wise, of good behaviour, given to hospitality, apt to teach".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:197
verses.text: The priests who minister in God's temple are forbidden to drink wine and strong drink, to keep their wits from being stupefied with drunkenness and to enable their understanding to do its duty in God's service.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:198
verses.text: By the word 'wise' those are excluded who plead simplicity as an excuse for a priest's folly.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:199
verses.text: For if the brain be not sound, all the members will be amiss.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:200
verses.text: The phrase "of good behaviour" is an extension of the previous epithet "blameless".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:201
verses.text: One who has no faults is called "blameless;" one who is rich in virtues is said to be "of good behaviour".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:202
verses.text: Or the words may be differently explained in accord with Tully's maxim, 'the main thing is that what you do you should do gracefully.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:203
verses.text: ' For some persons are so ignorant of their own measure and so stupid and foolish that they make themselves laughing stocks to those who see them because of their gesture or gait or dress or conversation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:204
verses.text: Fancying that they knew what is and what is not good taste they deck themselves out with finery and bodily adornments and give banquets which profess to be elegant: but all such attempts at dress and display are nastier than a beggar's rags.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:205
verses.text: As regards the obligation of priests to be teachers we bare have the precepts of the old Law and the fuller instructions given on the subject to Titus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:206
verses.text: For an innocent and unobtrusive conversation does as much harm by its silence as it does good by its example.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:207
verses.text: If the ravening wolves are to be frightened away it must be by the barking of dogs and by the staff of the shepherd.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:208
verses.text: "Not given to wine, no striker".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:209
verses.text: With the virtues they are to aim at he contrasts the vices they are to avoid.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:211
verses.text: We have learned what we ought to be: let us now learn what priests ought not to be.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:212
verses.text: Indulgence in wine is the fault of diners out and revellers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:213
verses.text: When the body is heated with drink it soon boils over with lust.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:214
verses.text: Wine drinking means self-indulgence, self-indulgence means sensual gratification, sensual gratification means a breach of chastity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:215
verses.text: He that lives in pleasure is dead while he lives, and he that drinks himself drunk is not only dead but buried.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:216
verses.text: One hour's debauch makes Noah uncover his nakedness which through sixty years of sobriety he had kept covered.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:217
verses.text: Lot in a fit of intoxication unwittingly adds incest to incontinence, and wine overcomes the man whom Sodom failed to conquer.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:218
verses.text: A bishop that is a striker is condemned by Him who gave His back to the smiters, and when He was reviled reviled not again.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:219
verses.text: "But moderate"; one good thing is set over against two evil things.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:220
verses.text: Drunkenness and passion are to be held in check by moderation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:221
verses.text: "Not a brawler, not covetous".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:222
verses.text: Nothing is more overweening than the assurance of the ignorant who fancy that incessant chatter will carry conviction with it and are always ready for a dispute that they may thunder with turgid eloquence against the flock committed to their charge.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:223
verses.text: That a priest must avoid covetousness even Samuel teaches when he proves before all the people that he has taken nothing from any man.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:224
verses.text: And the same lesson is taught by the poverty of the apostles who used to receive sustenance and refreshment from their brethren and to boast that they neither had nor wished to have anything besides food and raiment.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:225
verses.text: What the epistle to Timothy calls covetousness, that to Titus openly censures as the desire for filthy lucre.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:226
verses.text: "One that ruleth well his own house".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:227
verses.text: Not by increasing riches, not by providing regal banquets, not by having a pile of finely-wrought plates, not by slowly steaming pheasants so that the heat may reach the bones without melting the flesh upon them; no, but by first requiring of his own household the conduct which he has to inculcate in others.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:228
verses.text: "Having his children in subjection with all gravity".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:229
verses.text: They must not, that is, follow the example of the sons of Eli who lay with the women in the vestibule of the Temple and, supposing religion to consist in plunder, diverted to the gratification of their own appetites all the best parts of the victims.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:230
verses.text: "Not a novice lest being lifted up with pride he fall into the condemnation of the devil".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:231
verses.text: I cannot sufficiently express my amazement at the great blindness which makes men discuss such questions as that of marriage before baptism and causes them to charge people with a transaction which is dead in baptism, nay even quickened into a new life with Christ, while no one regards a commandment so clear and unmistakable as this about bishops not being novices.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:232
verses.text: One who was yesterday a catechumen is to-day a bishop; one who was yesterday in the amphitheatre is to-day in the church; one who spent the evening in the circus stands in the morning at the altar: one who a little while ago was a patron of actors is now a dedicator of virgins.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:233
verses.text: Was the apostle ignorant of our shifts and subterfuges? did he know nothing of our foolish arguments? He not only says that a bishop must be the husband of one wife, but he has given commandment that he must be blameless, vigilant, sober, of good behaviour, given to hospitality, apt to teach, moderate, not given to wine, no striker, not a brawler, not covetous, not a novice.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:234
verses.text: Yet to all these requirements we shut our eyes and notice nothing but the wives of the aspirants.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:235
verses.text: Who cannot give instances to shew the need of the warning: "lest being lifted up with pride he fall into the condemnation of the devil?" A priest who is made such in a moment knows nothing of the lowliness and meekness which mark the meanest of the faithful, he knows nothing of Christian courtesy, he is not wise enough to think little of himself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:236
verses.text: He passes from one dignity to another, yet he has not fasted, he has not wept, he has not taken himself to task for his life, he has not striven by constant meditation to amend it, he has not given his substance to the poor.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:237
verses.text: Yet he is moved from one see to another, he passes, that is, from pride to pride.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:238
verses.text: There can be no doubt that arrogance is what the Apostle means when he speaks of the condemnation and downfall of the devil.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:239
verses.text: And all men fall into this who are in a moment made masters, actually before they are disciples.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:240
verses.text: "Moreover he must have a good report of them which are without".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:241
verses.text: The last requirement is like the first.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:242
verses.text: One who is really "blameless" obtains the unanimous approval not only of his own household but of outsiders as well.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:243
verses.text: By aliens and persons outside the church we are to understand Jews, heretics and Gentiles.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:244
verses.text: A Christian bishop then must be such that they who cavil at his religion may not venture to cavil at his life.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:245
verses.text: At present however we see but too many bishops who are willing, like the charioteers in the horse races, to bid money for the popular applause; while there are some so universally hated that they can wring no money from their people, a feat which clowns accomplish by means of a few gestures.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:247
verses.text: Such are the conditions, son Oceanus, which the master-teachers of the church ought with anxiety and fear to require of others and to observe themselves.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:248
verses.text: Such too are the canons which they should follow in the choice of persons for the priesthood; for they must not interpret the law of Christ to suit private animosities and feuds or to gratify ill-feeling which is sure to recoil on the man who cherishes it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:249
verses.text: Consider how unimpeachable is the character of Carterius in whose life his ill-wishers can find nothing to censure except a marriage contracted before baptism.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:250
verses.text: "He that said, Do not commit adultery, said also, Do not kill.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:251
verses.text: If we commit no adultery yet if we kill, we are become transgressors of the law".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:252
verses.text: "Whosoever shall keep the whole law and yet offend in one point, he is guilty of all".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:253
verses.text: Accordingly when they cast in our teeth a marriage entered into before baptism, we must require of them compliance with all the precepts which are given to the baptized.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 69:254
verses.text: For they pass over much that is not allowable while they censure much that is allowed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:1
verses.text: Letter LXX.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:2
verses.text: To Magnus an Orator of Rome.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:3
verses.text: Jerome thanks Magnus, a Roman orator, for his services in bringing a young man named Sebesius to apologize to him for some fault that he had committed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:4
verses.text: He then replies to a criticism of Magnus on his fondness for making quotations from profane writers, a practice which he defends by the example of the fathers of the church and of the inspired penmen of scripture.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:5
verses.text: He ends by hinting that the objection really comes not from Magnus himself but from Rufinus (here nicknamed Calpurnius Lanarius).

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:6
verses.text: The date of the letter is 397 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:7
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:9
verses.text: That our friend Sebesius has profited by your advice I have learned less from your letter than from his own penitence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:10
verses.text: And strange to say the pleasure which he has given me since his rebuke is greater than the pain he caused me from his previous waywardness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:11
verses.text: There has been indeed a conflict between indulgence in the father, and affection in the son; while the former is anxious to forget the past, the latter is eager to promise dutiful behaviour in the future.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:12
verses.text: Accordingly you and I must equally rejoice, you because you have successfully put a pupil to the test, I because I have received a son again.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:14
verses.text: You ask me at the close of your letter why it is that sometimes in my writings I quote examples from secular literature and thus defile the whiteness of the church with the foulness of heathenism.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:15
verses.text: I will now briefly answer your question.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:16
verses.text: You would never have asked it, had not your mind been wholly taken up with Tully; you would never have asked it had you made it a practice instead of studying Volcatius to read the holy scriptures and the commentators upon them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:17
verses.text: For who is there who does not know that both in Moses and in the prophets there are passages cited from Gentile books and that Solomon proposed questions to the philosophers of Tyre and answered others put to him by them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:18
verses.text: In the commencement of the book of Proverbs he charges us to understand prudent maxims and shrewd adages, parables and obscure discourse, the words of the wise and their dark sayings; all of which belong by right to the sphere of the dialectician and the philosopher.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:19
verses.text: The Apostle Paul also, in writing to Titus, has used a line of the poet Epimenides: "The Cretians are always liars, evil beasts, slow bellies".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:20
verses.text: Half of which line was afterwards adopted by Callimachus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:21
verses.text: It is not surprising that a literal rendering of the words into Latin should fail to preserve the metre, seeing that Homer when translated into the same language is scarcely intelligible even in prose.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:22
verses.text: In another epistle Paul quotes a line of Menander: "Evil communications corrupt good manners".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:23
verses.text: And when he is arguing with the Athenians upon the Areopagus he calls Aratus as a witness citing from him the words "For we are also his offspring;" in Greek τοῦ γὰρ καὶ γένος ἐσμεν, the close of a heroic verse.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:24
verses.text: And as if this were not enough, that leader of the Christian army, that unvanquished pleader for the cause of Christ, skilfully turns a chance inscription into a proof of the faith.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:25
verses.text: For he had learned from the true David to wrench the sword of the enemy out of his hand and with his own blade to cut off the head of the arrogant Goliath.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:26
verses.text: He had read in Deuteronomy the command given by the voice of the Lord that when a captive woman had had her head shaved, her eyebrows and all her hair cut off, and her nails pared, she might then be taken to wife.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:27
verses.text: Is it surprising that I too, admiring the fairness of her form and the grace of her eloquence, desire to make that secular wisdom which is my captive and my handmaid, a matron of the true Israel? Or that shaving off and cutting away all in her that is dead whether this be idolatry, pleasure, error, or lust, I take her to myself clean and pure and beget by her servants for the Lord of Sabaoth? My efforts promote the advantage of Christ's family, my so-called defilement with an alien increases the number of my fellow-servants.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:28
verses.text: Hosea took a wife of whoredoms, Gomer the daughter of Diblaim, and this harlot bore him a son called Jezreel or the seed of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:29
verses.text: Isaiah speaks of a sharp razor which shaves "the head of sinners and the hair of their feet;" and Ezekiel shaves his head as a type of that Jerusalem which has been an harlot, in sign that whatever in her is devoid of sense and life must be removed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:31
verses.text: Cyprian, a man renowned both for his eloquence and for his martyr's death, was assailed—so Firmian tells us—for having used in his treatise against Demetrius passages from the Prophets and the Apostles which the latter declared to be fabricated and made up, instead of passages from the philosophers and poets whose authority he, as a heathen, could not well gainsay.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:32
verses.text: Celsus and Porphyry have written against us and have been ably answered, the former by Origen, the latter by Methodius, Eusebius, and Apollinaris.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:33
verses.text: Origen wrote a treatise in eight books, the work of Methodius extended to ten thousand lines while Eusebius and Apollinaris composed twenty-five and thirty volumes respectively.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:34
verses.text: Read these and you will find that compared with them I am a mere tyro in learning, and that, as my wits have long lain fallow, I can barely recall as in a dream what I have learned as a boy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:35
verses.text: The emperor Julian found time during his Parthian campaign to vomit forth seven books against Christ and, as so often happens in poetic legends, only wounded himself with his own sword.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:36
verses.text: Were I to try to confute him with the doctrines of philosophers and stoics you would doubtless forbid me to strike a mad dog with the club of Hercules.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:37
verses.text: It is true that he presently felt in battle the hand of our Nazarene or, as he used to call him, the Galilaean, and that a spear-thrust in the vitals paid him due recompense for his foul calumnies.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:38
verses.text: To prove the antiquity of the Jewish people Josephus has written two books against Appio a grammarian of Alexandria; and in these he brings forward so many quotations from secular writers as to make me marvel how a Hebrew brought up from his childhood to read the sacred scriptures could also have perused the whole library of the Greeks.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:39
verses.text: Need I speak of Philo whom critics call the second or the Jewish Plato?  4.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:40
verses.text: Let me now run through the list of our own writers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:41
verses.text: Did not Quadratus a disciple of the apostles and bishop of the Athenian church deliver to the Emperor Hadrian (on the occasion of his visit to the Eleusinian mysteries) a treatise in defence of our religion.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:42
verses.text: And so great was the admiration caused in everyone by his eminent ability that it stilled a most severe persecution.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:43
verses.text: The philosopher Aristides, a man of great eloquence, presented to the same Emperor an apology for the Christians composed of extracts from philosophic writers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:44
verses.text: His example was afterwards followed by Justin another philosopher who delivered to Antoninus Pius and his sons and to the senate a treatise Against the Gentiles, in which he defended the ignominy of the cross and preached the resurrection of Christ with all freedom.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:45
verses.text: Need I speak of Melito bishop of Sardis, of Apollinaris chief-priest of the Church of Hierapolis, of Dionysius bishop of the Corinthians, of Tatian, of Bardesanes, of Irenaeus successor to the martyr Pothinus; all of whom have in many volumes explained the uprisings of the several heresies and tracked them back, each to the philosophic source from which it flows.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:46
verses.text: Pantaenus, a philosopher of the Stoic school, was on account of his great reputation for learning sent by Demetrius bishop of Alexandria to India, to preach Christ to the Brahmans and philosophers there.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:47
verses.text: Clement, a presbyter of Alexandria, in my judgment the most learned of men, wrote eight books of Miscellaniesand as many of Outline Sketches, a treatise against the Gentiles, and three volumes called the Pedagogue.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:48
verses.text: Is there any want of learning in these, or are they not rather drawn from the very heart of philosophy? Imitating his example Origen wrote ten books of Miscellanies, in which he compares together the opinions held respectively by Christians and by philosophers, and confirms all the dogmas of our religion by quotations from Plato and Aristotle, from Numenius and Cornutus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:49
verses.text: Miltiades also wrote an excellent treatise against the Gentiles.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:50
verses.text: Moreover Hippolytus and a Roman senator named Apollonius have each compiled apologetic works.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:51
verses.text: The books of Julius Africanus who wrote a history of his own times are still extant, as also are those of Theodore who was afterwards called Gregory, a man endowed with apostolic miracles as well as with apostolic virtues.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:52
verses.text: We still have the works of Dionysius bishop of Alexandria, of Anatolius chief priest of the church of Laodicea, of the presbyters Pamphilus, Pierius, Lucian, Malchion; of Eusebius bishop of Caesarea, Eustathius of Antioch and Athanasius of Alexandria; of Eusebius of Emisa, of Triphyllius of Cyprus, of Asterius of Scythopolis, of the confessor Serapion, of Titus bishop of Bostra; and of the Cappadocians Basil, Gregory, and Amphilochius.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:53
verses.text: All these writers so frequently interweave in their books the doctrines and maxims of the philosophers that you might easily be at a loss which to admire most, their secular erudition or their knowledge of the scriptures.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:55
verses.text: I will pass on to Latin writers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:56
verses.text: Can anything be more learned or more pointed than the style of Tertullian? His Apology and his books Against the Gentiles contain all the wisdom of the world.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:57
verses.text: Minucius Felix a pleader in the Roman courts has ransacked all heathen literature to adorn the pages of his Octavius and of his treatise Against the astrologers (unless indeed this latter is falsely ascribed to him).

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:58
verses.text: Arnobius has published seven books against the Gentiles, and his pupil Lactantius as many, besides two volumes, one on Anger and the other on the creative activity of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:59
verses.text: If you read any of these you will find in them an epitome of Cicero's dialogues.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:60
verses.text: The Martyr Victorinus though as a writer deficient in learning is not deficient in the wish to use what learning he has.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:61
verses.text: Then there is Cyprian.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:62
verses.text: With what terseness, with what knowledge of all history, with what splendid rhetoric and argument has he touched the theme that idols are no Gods! Hilary too, a confessor and bishop of my own day, has imitated Quintilian's twelve books both in number and in style, and has also shewn his ability as a writer in his short treatise against Dioscorus the physician.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:63
verses.text: In the reign of Constantine the presbyter Juvencus set forth in verse the story of our Lord and Saviour, and did not shrink from forcing into metre the majestic phrases of the Gospel.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:64
verses.text: Of other writers dead and living I say nothing.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:65
verses.text: Their aim and their ability are evident to all who read them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:67
verses.text: You must not adopt the mistaken opinion, that while in dealing with the Gentiles one may appeal to their literature in all other discussions one ought to ignore it; for almost all the books of all these writers—except those who like Epicurus are no scholars—are extremely full of erudition and philosophy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:68
verses.text: I incline indeed to fancy—the thought comes into my head as I dictate—that you yourself know quite well what has always been the practice of the learned in this matter.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:69
verses.text: I believe that in putting this question to me you are only the mouthpiece of another who by reason of his love for the histories of Sallust might well be called Calpurnius Lanarius.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:70
verses.text: Please beg of him not to envy eaters their teeth because he is toothless himself, and not to make light of the eyes of gazelles because he is himself a mole.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 70:71
verses.text: Here as you see there is abundant material for discussion, but I have already filled the limits at my disposal.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:1
verses.text: Letter LXXI.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:2
verses.text: To Lucinius.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:3
verses.text: Lucinius was a wealthy Spaniard of Baetica who in conformity with the ascetic ideas of his time had made a vow of continence with his wife Theodora.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:4
verses.text: Being much interested in the study of scripture he proposed to visit Bethlehem, and in a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:5
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:6
verses.text: 397 sent several scribes thither to transcribe for him Jerome's principal writings.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:7
verses.text: To these on their return home Jerome now entrusts the following letter.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:8
verses.text: In it he encourages Lucinius to fulfil his purpose of coming to Bethlehem, describes the books which he is sending to him, and answers two questions relating to ecclesiastical usage.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:9
verses.text: He also sends him some trifling presents.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:10
verses.text: Shortly after receiving the letter (written in 398 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:11
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:12
verses.text: ) Lucinius died and Jerome wrote to Theodora to console her for her loss (Letter LXXV).

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:14
verses.text: Your letter which has suddenly arrived was not expected by me, and coming in an unlooked for way it has helped to rouse me from my torpor by the glad tidings which it conveys.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:15
verses.text: I hasten to embrace with the arms of love one whom my eyes have never seen, and silently say to myself:—'"oh that I had wings like a dove! for then would I flee away and be at rest".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:16
verses.text: ' Then would I find him "whom my soul loveth".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:17
verses.text: In you the Lord's words are now truly fulfilled: "many shall come from the east and west and shall sit down with Abraham".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:18
verses.text: In those days the faith of my Lucinius was foreshadowed in Cornelius, "centurion of the band called the Italian band".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:19
verses.text: And when the apostle Paul writes to the Romans: "whensoever I take my journey into Spain I will come to you: for I trust to see you in my journey, and to be brought on my way thitherward by you;" he shews by the tale of his previous successes what he looked to gain from that province.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:20
verses.text: Laying in a short time the foundation of the gospel "from Jerusalem and round about unto Illyricum," he enters Rome in bonds, that he may free those who are in the bonds of error and superstition.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:21
verses.text: Two years he dwells in his own hired house that he may give to us the house eternal which is spoken of in both the testaments.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:22
verses.text: The apostle, the fisher of men, has cast forth his net, and, among countless kinds of fish, has landed you like a magnificent gilt-bream.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:23
verses.text: You have left behind you the bitter waves, the salt tides, the mountain-fissures; you have despised Leviathan who reigns in the waters.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:24
verses.text: Your aim is to seek the wilderness with Jesus and to sing the prophet's song: "my soul thirsteth for thee, my flesh longeth for thee in a dry and thirsty land where no water is; to see thy power and thy glory, so as I have seen thee in the sanctuary," or, as he sings in another place, "lo, then would I wander far off and remain in the wilderness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:25
verses.text: I would hasten my escape from the windy storm and tempest".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:26
verses.text: Since you have left Sodom and are hastening to the mountains, I beseech you with a father's affection not to look behind you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:27
verses.text: Your hands have grasped the handle of the plough, the hem of the Saviour's garment, and His locks wet with the dew of night; do not let them go.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:28
verses.text: Do not come down from the housetop of virtue to seek for the clothes which you wore of old, nor return home from the field.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:29
verses.text: Do not like Lot set your heart on the plain or upon the pleasant gardens; for these are watered not, as the holy land, from heaven but by Jordan's muddy stream made salt by contact with the Dead Sea.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:31
verses.text: Many begin but few persevere to the end.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:32
verses.text: "They which run in a race run all, but one receiveth the crown".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:33
verses.text: But of us on the other hand it is said: "So run that ye may obtain".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:34
verses.text: Our master of the games is not grudging; he does not give the palm to one and disgrace another.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:35
verses.text: His wish is that all his athletes may alike win garlands.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:36
verses.text: My soul rejoices, yet the very greatness of my joy makes me feel sad.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:37
verses.text: Like Ruth when I try to speak I burst into tears.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:38
verses.text: Zacchaeus, the convert of an hour, is accounted worthy to receive the Saviour as his guest.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:39
verses.text: Martha and Mary make ready a feast and then welcome the Lord to it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:40
verses.text: A harlot washes His feet with her tears and against His burial anoints His body with the ointment of good works.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:41
verses.text: Simon the leper invites the Master with His disciples and is not refused.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:42
verses.text: To Abraham it is said: "Get thee out of thy country and from thy kindred and from thy father's house, unto a land that I will shew thee".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:43
verses.text: He leaves Chaldaea, he leaves Mesopotamia; he seeks what he knows not, not to lose Him whom he has found.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:44
verses.text: He does not deem it possible to keep both his country and his Lord; even at that early day he is already fulfilling the prophet David's words: "I am a stranger with thee and a sojourner, as all my fathers were".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:45
verses.text: He is called "a Hebrew," in Greek περάτής, a passer-over, for not content with present excellence but forgetting those things which are behind he reaches forth to that which is before.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:46
verses.text: He makes his own the words of the psalmist: "they shall go from strength to strength".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:47
verses.text: Thus his name has a mystic meaning and he has opened for you a way to seek not your own things but those of another.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:48
verses.text: You too must leave your home as he did, and must take for your parents, brothers, and relations only those who are linked to you in Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:49
verses.text: "Whosoever," He says, "shall do the will of my father…the same is my brother and sister and mother".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:51
verses.text: You have with you one who was once your partner in the flesh but is now your partner in the spirit; once your wife but now your sister; once a woman but now a man; once an inferior but now an equal.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:52
verses.text: Under the same yoke as you she hastens toward the same heavenly kingdom.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:53
verses.text: A too careful management of one's income, a too near calculation of one's expenses—these are habits not easily laid aside.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:54
verses.text: Yet to escape the Egyptian woman Joseph had to leave his garment with her.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:55
verses.text: And the young man who followed Jesus having a linen cloth cast about him, when he was assailed by the servants had to throw away his earthly covering and to flee naked.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:56
verses.text: Elijah also when he was carried up in a chariot of fire to heaven left his mantle of sheepskin on earth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:57
verses.text: Elisha used for sacrifice the oxen and the yokes which hitherto he had employed in his work.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:58
verses.text: We read in Ecclesiasticus: "he that toucheth pitch shall be defiled therewith".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:59
verses.text: As long as we are occupied with the things of the world, as long as our soul is fettered with possessions and revenues, we cannot think freely of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:60
verses.text: "For what fellowship hath righteousness with unrighteousness? And what communion hath light with darkness? And what concord hath Christ with Belial? Or what part hath he that believeth with an infidel?" "Ye cannot," the Lord says, "serve God and Mammon".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:61
verses.text: Now the laying aside of money is for those who are beginners in the way, not for those who are made perfect.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:62
verses.text: Heathens like Antisthenes and Crates the Theban have done as much before now.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:63
verses.text: But to offer one's self to God, this is the mark of Christians and apostles.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:64
verses.text: These like the widow out of their penury cast their two mites into the treasury, and giving all that they have to the Lord are counted worthy to hear his words: "ye also shall sit upon twelve thrones judging the twelve tribes of Israel".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:66
verses.text: You can see for yourself why I mention these things; without expressly saying it I am inviting you to take up your abode at the holy places.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:67
verses.text: Your abundance has supported the want of many that some day their riches may abound to supply your want; you have made to yourself "friends of the mammon of unrighteousness that they may receive you into everlasting habitations".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:68
verses.text: Such conduct deserves praise and merits to be compared with the virtue of apostolic times.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:69
verses.text: Then, as you know, believers sold their possessions and brought the prices of them and laid them down at the apostles' feet: a symbolic act designed to shew that men must trample on covetousness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:70
verses.text: But the Lord yearns for believers' souls more than for their riches.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:71
verses.text: We read in the Proverbs: "the ransom of a man's soul are his own riches".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:72
