verses.text: We may, indeed, take a man's own riches to be those which do not come from some one else, or from plunder; according to the precept: "honour God with thy just labours".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:73
verses.text: But the sense is better if we understand a man's "own riches" to be those hidden treasures which no thief can steal and no robber wrest from him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:75
verses.text: As for my poor works which from no merits of theirs but simply from your own kindness you say that you desire to have; I have given them to your servants to transcribe, I have seen the paper-copies made by them, and I have repeatedly ordered them to correct them by a diligent comparison with the originals.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:76
verses.text: For so many are the pilgrims passing to and fro that I have been unable to read so many volumes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:77
verses.text: They have found me also troubled by a long illness from which this Lent I am slowly recovering as they are leaving me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:78
verses.text: If then you find errors or omissions which interfere with the sense, these you must impute not to me but to your own servants; they are due to the ignorance or carelessness of the copyists, who write down not what they find but what they take to be the meaning, and do but expose their own mistakes when they try to correct those of others.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:79
verses.text: It is a false rumour which has reached you to the effect that I have translated the books of Josephus and the volumes of the holy men Papias and Polycarp.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:80
verses.text: I have neither the leisure nor the ability to preserve the charm of these masterpieces in another tongue.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:81
verses.text: Of Origen and Didymus I have translated a few things, to set before my countrymen some specimens of Greek teaching.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:82
verses.text: The canon of the Hebrew verity—except the octoteuch which I have at present in hand—I have placed at the disposal of your slaves and copyists.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:83
verses.text: Doubtless you already possess the version from the septuagint which many years ago I diligently revised for the use of students.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:84
verses.text: The new testament I have restored to the authoritative form of the Greek original.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:85
verses.text: For as the true text of the old testament can only be tested by a reference to the Hebrew, so the true text of the new requires for its decision an appeal to the Greek.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:87
verses.text: You ask me whether you ought to fast on the Sabbath and to receive the eucharist daily according to the custom—as currently reported—of the churches of Rome and Spain.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:88
verses.text: Both these points have been treated by the eloquent Hippolytus, and several writers have collected passages from different authors bearing upon them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:89
verses.text: The best advice that I can give you is this.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:90
verses.text: Church-traditions—especially when they do not run counter to the faith—are to be observed in the form in which previous generations have handed them down; and the use of one church is not to be annulled because it is contrary to that of another.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:91
verses.text: As regards fasting, I wish that we could practise it without intermission as—according to the Acts of the Apostles—Paul did and the believers with him even in the season of Pentecost and on the Lord's Day.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:92
verses.text: They are not to be accused of manichaeism, for carnal food ought not to be preferred before spiritual.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:93
verses.text: As regards the holy eucharist you may receive it at all times without qualm of conscience or disapproval from me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:94
verses.text: You may listen to the psalmist's words:—"O taste and see that the Lord is good;" you may sing as he does:—"my heart poureth forth a good word".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:95
verses.text: But do not mistake my meaning.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:96
verses.text: You are not to fast on feast-days, neither are you to abstain on the week days in Pentecost.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:97
verses.text: In such matters each province may follow its own inclinations, and the traditions which have been handed down should be regarded as apostolic laws.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:99
verses.text: You send me two small cloaks and a sheepskin mantle from your wardrobe and ask me to wear them myself or to give them to the poor.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:100
verses.text: In return I send to you and your sister in the Lord four small haircloths suitable to your religious profession and to your daily needs, for they are the mark of poverty and the outward witness of a continual penitence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:101
verses.text: To these I have added a manuscript containing Isaiah's ten most obscure visions which I have lately elucidated with a critical commentary.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:102
verses.text: When you look upon these trifles call to mind the friend in whom you delight and hasten the voyage which you have for a time deferred.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 71:103
verses.text: And because "the way of man is not in himself" but it is the Lord that "directeth his steps;" if any hindrance should interfere—I hope none may—to prevent you from coming, I pray that distance may not sever those united in affection and that I may find my Lucinius present in absence through an interchange of letters.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 72:1
verses.text: Letter LXXII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 72:2
verses.text: To Vitalis.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 72:3
verses.text: Vitalis had asked Jerome "Is Scripture credible when it tells us that Solomon and Ahaz became fathers at the age of eleven?" The difficulty had previously occurred to Jerome himself (Letter XXXVI.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 72:4
verses.text: 10, whence perhaps Vitalis took it) and in this letter he suggests several ways in which it may be met.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 72:5
verses.text: He is quite prepared, if necessary, to accept the alleged fact on the grounds that "there are many things in Scripture which sound incredible and yet are true" and that "nature cannot resist the Lord of nature" (§2).

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 72:6
verses.text: He is disposed, however, to regard the question as trivial and of no importance.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 72:7
verses.text: The date of the letter is 398 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 72:8
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 73:1
verses.text: Letter LXXIII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 73:2
verses.text: To Evangelus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 73:3
verses.text: Evangelus had sent Jerome an anonymous treatise in which Melchisedek was identified with the Holy Ghost, and had asked him what he thought of the theory.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 73:4
verses.text: Jerome in his reply repudiates the idea as absurd and insists that Melchisedek was a real man, possibly, as the Jews said, Shem the eldest son of Noah.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 73:5
verses.text: The date of the letter is 398 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 73:6
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 74:1
verses.text: Letter LXXIV.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 74:2
verses.text: To Rufinus of Rome.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 74:3
verses.text: Rufinus, a Roman Presbyter (to be carefully distinguished from Rufinus of Aquileia and Rufinus the Syrian), had written to Jerome for an explanation of the judgment of Solomon (1 Kings iii.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 74:5
verses.text: This Jerome gives at length, treating the narrative as a parable and making the false and true mothers types of the Synagogue and the Church.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 74:6
verses.text: The date of the letter is 398 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 74:7
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 75:1
verses.text: Letter LXXV.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 75:2
verses.text: To Theodora.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 75:3
verses.text: Theodora the wife of the learned Spaniard Lucinius (for whom see Letter LXXI.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 75:4
verses.text: ) had recently lost her husband, a bereavement which suggested the present letter.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 75:5
verses.text: In it Jerome recounts the many virtues of Lucinius and especially his zeal in resisting the gnostic heresy of Marcus which during his life was prevalent in Spain.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 75:6
verses.text: The date of the letter is 399 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 75:7
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 75:9
verses.text: So overpowered am I by the sad intelligence of the falling asleep of the holy and by me deeply revered Lucinius that I am scarcely able to dictate even a short letter.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 75:10
verses.text: I do not, it is true, lament his fate, for I know that he has passed to better things: like Moses he can say: "I will now turn aside and see this great sight," but I am tormented with regret that I was not allowed to look upon the face of one, who was likely, as I believed, in a short time to come hither.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 75:11
verses.text: True indeed is the prophetic warning concerning the doom of death that it divides brothers, and with harsh and cruel hand sunders those whose names are linked together in the bonds of love.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 75:12
verses.text: But we have this consolation that it is slain by the word of the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 75:13
verses.text: For it is said: "O death, I will be thy plagues; O grave, I will be thy destruction," and in the next verse: "An east wind shall come, the wind of the Lord shall come up from the wilderness, and his spring shall become dry, and his fountain shall be dried up".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 75:14
verses.text: For, as Isaiah says, "there shall come forth a rod out of the stem of Jesse, and a branch shall grow out of his roots": and He says Himself in the Song of Songs, "I am the rose of Sharon and the lily of the valley".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 75:15
verses.text: Our rose is the destruction of death, and died that death itself might die in His dying.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 75:16
verses.text: But, when it is said that He is to be brought "from the wilderness," the virgin's womb is indicated, which without sexual intercourse or impregnation has given to us God in the form of an infant able to quench by the glow of the Holy Spirit the fountains of lust and to sing in the words of the psalm: "as in a dry and pathless and waterless land, so have I appeared unto thee in the sanctuary".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 75:17
verses.text: Thus when we have to face the hard and cruel necessity of death, we are upheld by this consolation, that we shall shortly see again those whose absence we now mourn.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 75:18
verses.text: For their end is not called death but a slumber and a falling asleep.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 75:19
verses.text: Wherefore also the blessed apostle forbids us to sorrow concerning them which are asleep, telling us to believe that those whom we know to sleep now may hereafter be roused from their sleep, and when their slumber is ended may watch once more with the saints and sing with the angels:—"Glory to God in the highest and on earth peace among men of good will".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 75:20
verses.text: In heaven where there is no sin, there is glory and perpetual praise and unwearied singing; but on earth where sedition reigns, and war and discord hold sway, peace must be gained by prayer, and it is to be found not among all but only among men of good will, who pay heed to the apostolic salutation: "Grace to you and peace from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 75:21
verses.text: For "His abode is in peace and His dwelling place is in Zion," that is, on a watch-tower, on a height of doctrines and of virtues, in the soul of the believer; for the angel of this latter daily beholds the face of God, and contemplates with unveiled face the glory of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 75:23
verses.text: Wherefore, though you are already running in the way, I urge a willing horse, as the saying goes, and implore you, while you regret in your Lucinius a true brother, to rejoice as well that he now reigns with Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 75:24
verses.text: For, as it is written in the book of Wisdom, he was "taken away lest that wickedness should alter his understanding…for his soul pleased the Lord…and he…in a short time fulfilled a long time".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 75:25
verses.text: We may with more right weep for ourselves that we stand daily in conflict with our sins, that we are stained with vices, that we receive wounds, and that we must give account for every idle word.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 75:26
verses.text: Victorious now and free from care he looks down upon you from on high and supports you in your struggle, nay more, he prepares for you a place near to himself; for his love and affection towards you are still the same as when, disregarding his claim on you as a husband, he resolved to treat you even on earth as a sister, or indeed I may say as a brother, for difference of sex while essential to marriage is not so to a continent tie.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 75:27
verses.text: And since even in the flesh, if we are born again in Christ, we are no longer Greek and Barbarian, bond and free, male and female, but are all one in Him, how much more true will this be when this corruptible has put on incorruption and when this mortal has put on immortality.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 75:28
verses.text: "In the resurrection," the Lord tells us, "they neither marry nor are given in marriage but are as the angels…in heaven".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 75:29
verses.text: Now when it is said that they neither marry nor are given in marriage but are as the angels in heaven, there is no taking away of a natural and real body but only an indication of the greatness of the glory to come.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 75:30
verses.text: For the words are not "they shall be angels" but "they shall be as the angels": thus while likeness to the angels is promised identity with them is refused.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 75:31
verses.text: "They shall be," Christ tells us, "as the angels," that is like the angels; therefore they will not cease to be human.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 75:32
verses.text: Glorious indeed they shall be, and graced with angelic splendour, but they will still be human; the apostle Paul will still be Paul, Mary will still be Mary.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 75:33
verses.text: Then shall confusion overtake that heresy which holds out great but vague promises only that it may take away hopes which are at once modest and certain.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 75:35
verses.text: And now that I have once mentioned the word "heresy," where can I find a trumpet loud enough to proclaim the eloquence of our dear Lucinius, who, when the filthy heresy of Basilides raged in Spain and like a pestilence ravaged the provinces between the Pyrenees and the ocean, upheld in all its purity the faith of the church and altogether refused to embrace Armagil, Barbelon, Abraxas, Balsamum, and the absurd Leusibora.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 75:36
verses.text: Such are the portentous names which, to excite the minds of unlearned men and weak women, they pretend to draw from Hebrew sources, terrifying the simple by barbarous combinations which they admire the more the less they understand them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 75:37
verses.text: The growth of this heresy is described for us by Irenaeus, bishop of the church of Lyons, a man of the apostolic times, who was a disciple of Papias the hearer of the evangelist John.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 75:38
verses.text: He informs us that a certain Mark, of the stock of the gnostic Basilides, came in the first instance to Gaul, that he contaminated with his teaching those parts of the country which are watered by the Rhone and the Garonne, and that in particular he misled by his errors high-born women; to whom he promised certain secret mysteries and whose affection he enlisted by magic arts and hidden indulgence in unlawful intercourse.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 75:39
verses.text: Irenaeus goes on to say that subsequently Mark crossed the Pyrenees and occupied Spain, making it his object to seek out the houses of the wealthy, and in these especially the women, concerning whom we are told that they are "led away with divers lusts, ever learning and never able to come to the knowledge of the truth".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 75:40
verses.text: All this he wrote about three hundred years ago in the extremely learned and eloquent books which he composed under the title Against all heresies.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 75:42
verses.text: From these facts you in your wisdom will realize how worthy of praise our dear Lucinius shewed himself when he shut his ears that he might not have to hear the judgement passed upon blood shedders, and dispersed all his substance and gave to the poor that his righteousness might endure for ever.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 75:43
verses.text: And not satisfied with bestowing his bounty upon his own country, he sent to the churches of Jerusalem and Alexandria gold enough to alleviate the want of large numbers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 75:44
verses.text: But while many will admire and extol in him this liberality, I for my part will rather praise him for his zeal and diligence in the study of the scriptures.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 75:45
verses.text: With what eagerness he asked for my poor works! He actually sent six copyists (for in this province there is a dearth of scribes who understand Latin) to copy for him all that I have ever dictated from my youth until the present time.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 75:46
verses.text: The honour was not of course paid to me who am but a little child, the least of all Christians, living in the rocks near Bethlehem because I know myself a sinner; but to Christ who is honoured in his servants and who makes this promise to them, "He that receiveth you receiveth me, and he that receiveth me receiveth him that sent me".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 75:48
verses.text: Therefore, my beloved daughter, regard this letter as the epitaph which love prompts me to write upon your husband, and if there is any spiritual work of which you think me to be capable, boldly command me to undertake it: that so ages to come may know that He who says of Himself in Isaiah, "He hath made me a polished shaft; in his quiver hath he hid me," has with His sharp arrow so wounded two men severed by an immense interval of sea and land, that, although they know each other not in the flesh, they are knit together in love in the spirit.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 75:49
verses.text: May you be kept holy both in body and spirit by the Samaritan—that is, saviour and keeper—of whom it is said in the psalm, "He that keepeth Israel shall neither slumber nor sleep".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 75:50
verses.text: May the watcher and the holy one who came down to Daniel come also to you, that you too may be able to say, "I sleep but my heart waketh".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 76:1
verses.text: Letter LXXVI.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 76:2
verses.text: To Abigaus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 76:3
verses.text: Abigaus the recipient of this letter was a blind presbyter of Baetica in Spain.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 76:4
verses.text: He had asked the help of Jerome's prayers in his struggles with evil and Jerome now writes to cheer and to console him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 76:5
verses.text: He concludes his remarks by commending to his especial care the widow Theodora.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 76:6
verses.text: The letter should be compared with that addressed to Castrutius (LXVIII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 76:8
verses.text: It was written at the same time with the preceding.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 76:10
verses.text: Although I am conscious of many sins and every day pray on bended knees, "Remember not the sins of my youth nor my transgressions, yet because I know that it has been said by the Apostle "let a man not be lifted up with pride lest he fall into the condemnation of the devil," and that it is written in another passage, "God resisteth the proud but giveth grace to the humble," there is nothing I have striven so much to avoid from my boyhood up as a swelling mind and a stiff neck, things which always provoke against themselves the wrath of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 76:11
verses.text: For I know that my master and Lord and God has said in the lowliness of His flesh: "Learn of me; for I am meek and lowly in heart," and that before this He has sung by the mouth of David: "Lord, remember David and all his gentleness".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 76:12
verses.text: Again we read in another passage, "Before destruction the heart of man is haughty; and before honour is humility".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 76:13
verses.text: Do not, then, I implore you, suppose that I have received your letter and have passed it over in silence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 76:14
verses.text: Do not, I beseech you, lay to my charge the dishonesty and negligence of which others have been guilty.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 76:15
verses.text: For why should I, when called on to respond to your kind advances, continue dumb and repel by my silence the friendship which you offer? I who am always forward to seek intimate relations with the good and even to thrust myself upon their affection.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 76:16
verses.text: "Two," we read, "are better than one.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 76:17
verses.text: …for if they fall, the one will lift up his fellow.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 76:18
verses.text: …a three fold cord is not quickly broken, and a brother that helps his brother shall be exalted".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 76:19
verses.text: Write to me, therefore, boldly, and overcome the effect of absence by frequent colloquies.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 76:21
verses.text: You should not grieve that you are destitute of those bodily eyes which ants, flies, and creeping things have as well as men; rather you should rejoice that you possess that eye of which it is said in the Song of Songs, "Thou hast ravished my heart, my sister, my spouse; thou hast ravished my heart with one of thine eyes".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 76:22
verses.text: This is the eye with which God is seen and to which Moses refers when he says:—"I will now turn aside and see this great sight".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 76:23
verses.text: We even read of some philosophers of this world that they have plucked out their eyes in order to turn all their thoughts upon the pure depths of the mind.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 76:24
verses.text: And a prophet has said "Death has entered through your windows".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 76:25
verses.text: Our Lord too tells the Apostles: "Whosoever looketh upon a woman to lust after her hath committed adultery with her already in his heart".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 76:26
verses.text: Consequently they are commanded to lift up their eyes and to look on the fields, for these are white and ready for harvest.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 76:28
verses.text: You request me by my exhortations to slay in you Nebuchadnezzar and Rabshakeh and Nebuzar-adan and Holofernes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 76:29
verses.text: Were they alive in you, you would never have sought my aid.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 76:30
verses.text: No, they are dead within you, and you have begun to build up the ruins of Jerusalem with the help of Zerubbabel and of Joshua the son of Josedech the high priest, of Ezra and of Nehemiah.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 76:31
verses.text: You do not put your wages into a bag with holes, but you lay up for yourselves treasures in heaven, and if you seek my friendship, it is because you believe me to be a servant of Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 76:32
verses.text: I commend to you—although she needs no commendation but her own—my holy daughter Theodora, formerly the wife or rather the sister of Lucinius of blessed memory.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 76:33
verses.text: Tell her that she must not grow weary of the path upon which she has entered, and that she can only reach the Holy Land by toiling through the wilderness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 76:34
verses.text: Warn her against supposing that the work of virtue is perfected when she has made her exodus from Egypt.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 76:35
verses.text: Remind her that she must pass through snares innumerable to arrive at mount Nebo and the River Jordan, that she must receive circumcision anew at Gilgal, that Jericho must fall before her, overthrown by the blasts of priestly trumpets, that Adoni-zedec must be slain, that Ai and Hazor, once fairest of cities, must both fall.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 76:36
verses.text: The brothers who are with me in the monastery salute you, and I through you earnestly salute those reverend persons who deign to bestow upon me their regard.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:1
verses.text: Letter LXXVII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:2
verses.text: To Oceanus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:3
verses.text: The eulogy of Fabiola whose restless life had come to an end in 399 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:4
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:5
verses.text: Jerome tells the story of her sin and of her penitence (for which see Letter LV.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:6
verses.text: ), of the hospital established by her at Portus, of her visit to Bethlehem, and of her earnestness in the study of scripture.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:7
verses.text: He relates how he wrote for her his account of the vestments of the high priest (Letter LXIV.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:8
verses.text: ) and how at the time of her death he was at her request engaged upon a commentary on the forty-two halting-places of the Israelites in the wilderness (Letter LXXIX.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:10
verses.text: This last he now sends along with this letter to Oceanus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:11
verses.text: Jerome also bestows praise upon Pammachius as the companion of all Fabiola's labours.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:12
verses.text: The date of the letter is 399 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:13
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:15
verses.text: Several years since I consoled the venerated Paula, whilst her affliction was still recent for the falling asleep of Blaesilla.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:16
verses.text: Four summers ago I wrote for the bishop Heliodorus the epitaph of Nepotian, and expended what ability I possessed in giving expression to my grief at his loss.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:17
verses.text: Only two years have elapsed since I sent a brief letter to my dear Pammachius on the sudden flitting of his Paulina.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:18
verses.text: I blushed to say more to one so learned or to give him back his own thoughts: lest I should seem less the consoler of a friend than the officious instructor of one already perfect.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:19
verses.text: But now, Oceanus my son, the duty that you lay upon me is one that I gladly accept and would even seek unasked.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:20
verses.text: For when new virtues have to be dealt with, an old subject itself becomes new.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:21
verses.text: In previous cases I have had to soften and restrain a mother's affection, an uncle's grief, and a husband's yearning; according to the different requirements of each I have had to apply from scripture different remedies.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:23
verses.text: To-day you give me as my theme Fabiola, the praise of the Christians, the marvel of the gentiles, the sorrow of the poor, and the consolation of the monks.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:24
verses.text: Whatever point in her character I choose to treat of first, pales into insignificance compared with those which follow after.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:25
verses.text: Shall I praise her fasts? Her alms are greater still.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:26
verses.text: Shall I commend her lowliness? The glow of her faith is yet brighter.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:27
verses.text: Shall I mention her studied plainness in dress, her voluntary choice of plebeian costume and the garb of a slave that she might put to shame silken robes? To change one's disposition is a greater achievement than to change one's dress.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:28
verses.text: It is harder for us to part with arrogance than with gold and gems.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:29
verses.text: For, even though we throw away these, we plume ourselves sometimes on a meanness that is really ostentatious, and we make a bid with a saleable poverty for the popular applause.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:30
verses.text: But a virtue that seeks concealment and is cherished in the inner consciousness appeals to no judgement but that of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:31
verses.text: Thus the eulogies which I have to bestow upon Fabiola will be altogether new: I must neglect the order of the rhetoricians and begin all I have to say only from the cradle of her conversion and of her penitence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:32
verses.text: Another writer, mindful of the school, would perhaps bring forward Quintus Maximus, "the man who by delaying rescued Rome," and the whole Fabian family; he would describe their struggles and battles and would exult that Fabiola had come to us through a line so noble, shewing that qualities not apparent in the branch still existed in the root.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:33
verses.text: But as I am a lover of the inn at Bethlehem and of the Lord's stable in which the virgin travailed with and gave birth to an infant God, I shall deduce the lineage of Christ's handmaid not from a stock famous in history but from the lowliness of the church.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:35
verses.text: And because at the very outset there is a rock in the path and she is overwhelmed by a storm of censure, for having forsaken her first husband and having taken a second, I will not praise her for her conversion till I have first cleared her of this charge.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:36
verses.text: So terrible then were the faults imputed to her former husband that not even a prostitute or a common slave could have put up with them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:37
verses.text: If I were to recount them, I should undo the heroism of the wife who chose to bear the blame of a separation rather than to blacken the character and expose the stains of him who was one body with her.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:38
verses.text: I will only urge this one plea which is sufficient to exonerate a chaste matron and a Christian woman.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:39
verses.text: The Lord has given commandment that a wife must not be put away "except it be for fornication, and that, if put away, she must remain unmarried".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:40
verses.text: Now a commandment which is given to men logically applies to women also.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:41
verses.text: For it cannot be that, while an adulterous wife is to be put away, an incontinent husband is to be retained.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:42
verses.text: The apostle says: "he which is joined to an harlot is one body".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:43
verses.text: Therefore she also who is joined to a whoremonger and unchaste person is made one body with him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:44
verses.text: The laws of Caesar are different, it is true, from the laws of Christ: Papinianus commands one thing; our own Paul another.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:45
verses.text: Earthly laws give a free rein to the unchastity of men, merely condemning seduction and adultery; lust is allowed to range unrestrained among brothels and slave girls, as if the guilt were constituted by the rank of the person assailed and not by the purpose of the assailant.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:46
verses.text: But with us Christians what is unlawful for women is equally unlawful for men, and as both serve the same God both are bound by the same obligations.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:47
verses.text: Fabiola then has put away—they are quite right—a husband that was a sinner, guilty of this and that crime, sins—I have almost mentioned their names—with which the whole neighbourhood resounded but which the wife alone refused to disclose.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:48
verses.text: If however it is made a charge against her that after repudiating her husband she did not continue unmarried, I readily admit this to have been a fault, but at the same time declare that it may have been a case of necessity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:49
verses.text: "It is better," the apostle tells us, "to marry than to burn".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:50
verses.text: She was quite a young woman, she was not able to continue in widowhood.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:51
verses.text: In the words of the apostle she saw another law in her members warring against the law of her mind; she felt herself dragged in chains as a captive towards the indulgences of wedlock.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:52
verses.text: Therefore she thought it better openly to confess her weakness and to accept the semblance of an unhappy marriage than, with the name of a monogamist, to ply the trade of a courtesan.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:53
verses.text: The same apostle wills that the younger widows should marry, bear children, and give no occasion to the adversary to speak reproachfully.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:54
verses.text: And he at once goes on to explain his wish: "for some are already turned aside after Satan".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:55
verses.text: Fabiola therefore was fully persuaded in her own mind: she thought she had acted legitimately in putting away her husband, and that when she had done so she was free to marry again.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:56
verses.text: She did not know that the rigour of the gospel takes away from women all pretexts for re-marriage so long as their former husbands are alive; and not knowing this, though she contrived to evade other assaults of the devil, she at this point unwittingly exposed herself to a wound from him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:58
verses.text: But why do I linger over old and forgotten matters, seeking to excuse a fault for which Fabiola has herself confessed her penitence? Who would believe that, after the death of her second husband at a time when most widows, having shaken off the yoke of servitude, grow careless and allow themselves more liberty than ever, frequenting the baths, flitting through the streets, shewing their harlot faces everywhere; that at this time Fabiola came to herself? Yet it was then that she put on sackcloth to make public confession of her error.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:59
verses.text: It was then that in the presence of all Rome (in the basilica which formerly belonged to that Lateranus who perished by the sword of Caesar) she stood in the ranks of the penitents and exposed before bishop, presbyters, and people—all of whom wept when they saw her weep—her dishevelled hair, pale features, soiled hands and unwashed neck.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:60
verses.text: What sins would such a penance fail to purge away? What ingrained stains would such tears be unable to wash out? By a threefold confession Peter blotted out his threefold denial.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:61
verses.text: If Aaron committed sacrilege by fashioning molten gold into the head of a calf, his brother's prayers made amends for his transgressions.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:62
verses.text: If holy David, meekest of men, committed the double sin of murder and adultery, he atoned for it by a fast of seven days.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:63
verses.text: He lay upon the earth, he rolled in the ashes, he forgot his royal power, he sought for light in the darkness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:64
verses.text: And then, turning his eyes to that God whom he had so deeply offended, he cried with a lamentable voice: "Against thee, thee only, have I sinned, and done this evil in thy sight," and "Restore unto me the joy of thy salvation and uphold me with thy free spirit".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:65
verses.text: He who by his virtues teaches me how to stand and not to fall, by his penitence teaches me how, if I fall, I may rise again.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:66
verses.text: Among the kings do we read of any so wicked as Ahab, of whom the scripture says: "there was none like unto Ahab which did sell himself to work wickedness in the sight of the Lord"? For shedding Naboth's blood Elijah rebuked him, and the prophet denounced God's wrath against him: "Hast thou killed and also taken possession?…behold I will bring evil upon thee and will take away thy posterity" and so on.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:67
verses.text: Yet when Ahab heard these words "he rent his clothes, and put sackcloth upon his flesh, and fasted…in sackcloth, and went softly".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:68
verses.text: Then came the word of God to Elijah the Tishbite saying: "Seest thou how Ahab humbleth himself before me? Because he humbleth himself before me, I will not bring the evil in his days".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:69
verses.text: O happy penitence which has drawn down upon itself the eyes of God, and which has by confessing its error changed the sentence of God's anger! The same conduct is in the Chronicles attributed to Manasseh, and in the book of the prophet Jonah to Nineveh, and in the gospel to the publican.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:70
verses.text: The first of these not only was allowed to obtain forgiveness but also recovered his kingdom, the second broke the force of God's impending wrath, while the third, smiting his breast with his hands, "would not lift up so much as his eyes to heaven".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:71
verses.text: Yet for all that the publican with his humble confession of his faults went back justified far more than the Pharisee with his arrogant boasting of his virtues.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:72
verses.text: This is not however the place to preach penitence, neither am I writing against Montanus and Novatus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:73
verses.text: Else would I say of it that it is "a sacrifice…well pleasing to God," I would cite the words of the psalmist: "the sacrifices of God are a broken spirit," and those of Ezekiel "I prefer the repentance of a sinner rather than his death," and those of Baruch, "Arise, arise, O Jerusalem," and many other proclamations made by the trumpets of the prophets.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:75
verses.text: But this one thing I will say, for it is at once useful to my readers and pertinent to my present theme.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:76
verses.text: As Fabiola was not ashamed of the Lord on earth, so He shall not be ashamed of her in heaven.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:77
verses.text: She laid bare her wound to the gaze of all, and Rome beheld with tears the disfiguring scar which marred her beauty.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:78
verses.text: She uncovered her limbs, bared her head, and closed her mouth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:79
verses.text: She no longer entered the church of God but, like Miriam the sister of Moses, she sat apart without the camp, till the priest who had cast her out should himself call her back.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:80
verses.text: She came down like the daughter of Babylon from the throne of her daintiness, she took the millstones and ground meal, she passed barefooted through rivers of tears.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:81
verses.text: She sat upon the coals of fire, and these became her aid.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:82
verses.text: That face by which she had once pleased her second husband she now smote with blows; she hated jewels, shunned ornaments and could not bear to look upon fine linen.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:83
verses.text: In fact she bewailed the sin she had committed as bitterly as if it had been adultery, and went to the expense of many remedies in her eagerness to cure her one wound.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:85
verses.text: Having found myself aground in the shallows of Fabiola's sin, I have dwelt thus long upon her penitence in order that I might open up a larger and quite unimpeded space for the description of her praises.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:86
verses.text: Restored to communion before the eyes of the whole church, what did she do? In the day of prosperity she was not forgetful of affliction; and, having once suffered shipwreck she was unwilling again to face the risks of the sea.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:87
verses.text: Instead therefore of re-embarking on her old life, she broke up and sold all that she could lay hands on of her property (it was large and suitable to her rank), and turning it into money she laid out this for the benefit of the poor.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:88
verses.text: She was the first person to found a hospital, into which she might gather sufferers out of the streets, and where she might nurse the unfortunate victims of sickness and want.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:89
verses.text: Need I now recount the various ailments of human beings? Need I speak of noses slit, eyes put out, feet half burnt, hands covered with sores? Or of limbs dropsical and atrophied? Or of diseased flesh alive with worms? Often did she carry on her own shoulders persons infected with jaundice or with filth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:90
verses.text: Often too did she wash away the matter discharged from wounds which others, even though men, could not bear to look at.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:91
verses.text: She gave food to her patients with her own hand, and moistened the scarce breathing lips of the dying with sips of liquid.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:92
verses.text: I know of many wealthy and devout persons who, unable to overcome their natural repugnance to such sights, perform this work of mercy by the agency of others, giving money instead of personal aid.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:93
verses.text: I do not blame them and am far from construing their weakness of resolution into a want of faith.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:94
verses.text: While however I pardon such squeamishness, I extol to the skies the enthusiastic zeal of a mind that is above it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:95
verses.text: A great faith makes little of such trifles.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:96
verses.text: But I know how terrible was the retribution which fell upon the proud mind of the rich man clothed in purple for not having helped Lazarus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:97
verses.text: The poor wretch whom we despise, whom we cannot so much as look at, and the very sight of whom turns our stomachs, is human like ourselves, is made of the same clay as we are, is formed out of the same elements.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:98
verses.text: All that he suffers we too may suffer.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:99
verses.text: Let us then regard his wounds as though they were our own, and then all our insensibility to another's suffering will give way before our pity for ourselves.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:100
verses.text: Not with a hundred tongues or throat of bronze  Could I exhaust the forms of fell disease  which Fabiola so wonderfully alleviated in the suffering poor that many of the healthy fell to envying the sick.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:101
verses.text: However she showed the same liberality towards the clergy and monks and virgins.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:102
verses.text: Was there a monastery which was not supported by Fabiola's wealth? Was there a naked or bedridden person who was not clothed with garments supplied by her? Were there ever any in want to whom she failed to give a quick and unhesitating supply? Even Rome was not wide enough for her pity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:103
verses.text: Either in her own person or else through the agency of reverend and trustworthy men she went from island to island and carried her bounty not only round the Etruscan Sea, but throughout the district of the Volscians, as it stands along those secluded and winding shores where communities of monks are to be found.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:105
verses.text: Suddenly she made up her mind, against the advice of all her friends, to take ship and to come to Jerusalem.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:106
verses.text: Here she was welcomed by a large concourse of people and for a short time took advantage of my hospitality.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:107
verses.text: Indeed, when I call to mind our meeting, I seem to see her here now instead of in the past.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:108
verses.text: Blessed Jesus, what zeal, what earnestness she bestowed upon the sacred volumes! In her eagerness to satisfy what was a veritable craving she would run through Prophets, Gospels, and Psalms: she would suggest questions and treasure up the answers in the desk of her own bosom.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:109
verses.text: And yet this eagerness to hear did not bring with it any feeling of satiety: increasing her knowledge she also increased her sorrow, and by casting oil upon the flame she did but supply fuel for a still more burning zeal.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:110
verses.text: One day we had before us the book of Numbers written by Moses, and she modestly questioned me as to the meaning of the great mass of names there to be found.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:111
verses.text: Why was it, she inquired, that single tribes were differently associated in this passage and in that, how came it that the soothsayer Balaam in prophesying of the future mysteries of Christ spoke more plainly of Him than almost any other prophet? I replied as best I could and tried to satisfy her enquiries.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:112
verses.text: Then unrolling the book still farther she came to the passage in which is given the list of all the halting-places by which the people after leaving Egypt made its way to the waters of Jordan.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:113
verses.text: And when she asked me the meaning and reason of each of these, I spoke doubtfully about some, dealt with others in a tone of assurance, and in several instances simply confessed my ignorance.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:114
verses.text: Hereupon she began to press me harder still, expostulating with me as though it were a thing unallowable that I should be ignorant of what I did not know, yet at the same time affirming her own unworthiness to understand mysteries so deep.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:115
verses.text: In a word I was ashamed to refuse her request and allowed her to extort from me a promise that I would devote a special work to this subject for her use.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:116
verses.text: Till the present time I have had to defer the fulfilment of my promise: as I now perceive, by the Will of God in order that it should be consecrated to her memory.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:117
verses.text: As in a previous work I clothed her with the priestly vestments, so in the pages of the present she may rejoice that she has passed through the wilderness of this world and has come at last to the land of promise.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:119
verses.text: But let me continue the task which I have begun.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:120
verses.text: Whilst I was in search of a suitable dwelling for so great a lady, whose only conception of the solitary life included a place of resort like Mary's inn; suddenly messengers flew this way and that and the whole East was terror-struck.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:121
verses.text: For news came that the hordes of the Huns had poured forth all the way from Maeotis (they had their haunts between the icy Tanais and the rude Massagetae where the gates of Alexander keep back the wild peoples behind the Caucasus); and that, speeding hither and thither on their nimble-footed horses, they were filling all the world with panic and bloodshed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:122
verses.text: The Roman army was absent at the time, being detained in Italy on account of the civil wars.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:123
verses.text: Of these Huns Herodotus tells us that under Darius King of the Medes they held the East in bondage for twenty years and that from the Egyptians and Ethiopians they exacted a yearly tribute.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:124
verses.text: May Jesus avert from the Roman world the farther assaults of these wild beasts! Everywhere their approach was unexpected, they outstripped rumour in speed, and, when they came, they spared neither religion nor rank nor age, even for wailing infants they had no pity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:125
verses.text: Children were forced to die before it could be said that they had begun to live; and little ones not realizing their miserable fate might be seen smiling in the hands and at the weapons of their enemies.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:126
verses.text: It was generally agreed that the goal of the invaders was Jerusalem and that it was their excessive desire for gold which made them hasten to this particular city.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:127
verses.text: Its walls uncared for in time of peace were accordingly put in repair.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:128
verses.text: Antioch was in a state of siege.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:129
verses.text: Tyre, desirous of cutting itself off from the land, sought once more its ancient island.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:130
verses.text: We too were compelled to man our ships and to lie off the shore as a precaution against the arrival of our foes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:131
verses.text: No matter how hard the winds might blow, we could not but dread the barbarians more than shipwreck.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:132
verses.text: It was not, however, so much for our own safety that we were anxious as for the chastity of the virgins who were with us.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:133
verses.text: Just at that time also there was dissension among us, and our intestine struggles threw into the shade our battle with the barbarians.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:134
verses.text: I myself clung to my long-settled abode in the East and gave way to my deep-seated love for the holy places.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:135
verses.text: Fabiola, used as she was to moving from city to city and having no other property but what her baggage contained, returned to her native land; to live in poverty where she had once been rich, to lodge in the house of another, she who in old days had lodged many guests in her own, and—not unduly to prolong my account—to bestow upon the poor before the eyes of Rome the proceeds of that property which Rome knew her to have sold.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:137
verses.text: This only do I lament that in her the holy places lost a necklace of the loveliest.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:138
verses.text: Rome recovered what it had previously parted with, and the wanton and slanderous tongues of the heathen were confuted by the testimony of their own eyes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:139
verses.text: Others may commend her pity, her humility, her faith: I will rather praise her ardour of soul.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:140
verses.text: The letter in which as a young man I once urged Heliodorus to the life of a hermit she knew by heart, and whenever she looked upon the walls of Rome she complained that she was in a prison.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:141
verses.text: Forgetful of her sex, unmindful of her frailty, and only desiring to be alone she was in fact there where her soul lingered.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:142
verses.text: The counsels of her friends could not hold her back; so eager was she to burst from the city as from a place of bondage.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:143
verses.text: Nor did she leave the distribution of her alms to others; she distributed them herself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:144
verses.text: Her wish was that, after equitably dispensing her money to the poor, she might herself find support from others for the sake of Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:145
verses.text: In such haste was she and so impatient of delay that you would fancy her on the eve of her departure.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:146
verses.text: As she was always ready, death could not find her unprepared.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:148
verses.text: As I pen her praises, my dear Pammachius seems suddenly to rise before me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:149
verses.text: His wife Paulina sleeps that he may keep vigil; she has gone before her husband that he remaining behind may be Christ's servant.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:150
verses.text: Although he was his wife's heir, others—I mean the poor—are now in possession of his inheritance.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:151
verses.text: He and Fabiola contended for the privilege of setting up a tent like that of Abraham at Portus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:152
verses.text: The contest which arose between them was for the supremacy in shewing kindness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:153
verses.text: Each conquered and each was overcome.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:154
verses.text: Both admitted themselves to be at once victors and vanquished for what each had desired to effect alone both accomplished together.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:155
verses.text: They united their resources and combined their plans that harmony might forward what rivalry must have brought to nought.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:156
verses.text: No sooner was the scheme broached than it was carried out.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:157
verses.text: A house was purchased to serve as a shelter, and a crowd flocked into it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:158
verses.text: "There was no more travail in Jacob nor distress in Israel".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:159
verses.text: The seas carried voyagers to find a welcome here on landing.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:160
verses.text: Travellers left Rome in haste to take advantage of the mild coast before setting sail.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:161
verses.text: What Publius once did in the island of Malta for one apostle and—not to leave room for gainsaying—for a single ship's crew, Fabiola and Pammachius have done over and over again for large numbers; and not only have they supplied the wants of the destitute, but so universal has been their munificence that they have provided additional means for those who have something already.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:162
verses.text: The whole world knows that a home for strangers has been established at Portus; and Britain has learned in the summer what Egypt and Parthia knew in the spring.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:164
verses.text: In the death of this noble lady we have seen a fulfilment of the apostle's words:—"All things work together for good to them that fear God".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:165
verses.text: Having a presentiment of what would happen, she had written to several monks to come and release her from the burthen under which she laboured; for she wished to make to herself friends of the mammon of unrighteousness that they might receive her into everlasting habitations.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:166
verses.text: They came to her and she made them her friends; she fell asleep in the way that she had wished, and having at last laid aside her burthen she soared more lightly up to heaven.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:167
verses.text: How great a marvel Fabiola had been to Rome while she lived came out in the behaviour of the people now that she was dead.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:168
verses.text: Hardly had she breathed her last breath, hardly had she given back her soul to Christ whose it was when  Flying Rumour heralding the woe  gathered the entire city to attend her obsequies.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:169
verses.text: Psalms were chaunted and the gilded ceilings of the temples were shaken with uplifted shouts of Alleluia.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:170
verses.text: The choirs of young and old extolled her deeds  And sang the praises of her holy soul.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:171
verses.text: Her triumph was more glorious far than those won by Furius over the Gauls, by Papirius over the Samnites, by Scipio over Numantia, by Pompey over Pontus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:172
verses.text: They had conquered physical force, she had mastered spiritual iniquities.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:173
verses.text: I seem to hear even now the squadrons which led the van of the procession, and the sound of the feet of the multitude which thronged in thousands to attend her funeral.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:174
verses.text: The streets, porches, and roofs from which a view could be obtained were inadequate to accommodate the spectators.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:175
verses.text: On that day Rome saw all her peoples gathered together in one, and each person present flattered himself that he had some part in the glory of her penitence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:176
verses.text: No wonder indeed that men should thus exult in the salvation of one at whose conversion there was joy among the angels in heaven.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:178
verses.text: I give you this, Fabiola, the best gift of my aged powers, to be as it were a funeral offering.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:179
verses.text: Oftentimes have I praised virgins and widows and married women who have kept their garments always white and who follow the Lamb whithersoever He goeth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:180
verses.text: Happy indeed is she in her encomium who throughout her life has been stained by no defilement.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:181
verses.text: But let envy depart and censoriousness be silent.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:182
verses.text: If the father of the house is good why should our eye be evil? The soul which fell among thieves has been carried home upon the shoulders of Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:183
verses.text: In our father's house are many mansions.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:184
verses.text: Where sin hath abounded, grace hath much more abounded.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 77:185
verses.text: To whom more is forgiven the same loveth more.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 78:1
verses.text: Letter LXXVIII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 78:2
verses.text: To Fabiola.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 78:3
verses.text: A treatise on the Forty-two Mansions or Halting-places of the Israelites, originally intended for Fabiola but not completed until after her death.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 78:4
verses.text: Sent to Oceanus along with the preceding letter.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 78:5
verses.text: These Mansions are made an emblem of the Christian's pilgrimage, the true Hebrew hastening to pass from earth to heaven.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:1
verses.text: Letter LXXIX.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:2
verses.text: To Salvina.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:3
verses.text: A letter of consolation addressed by Jerome to Salvina (a lady of the imperial court) on the death of her husband Nebridius.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:4
verses.text: After excusing his temerity in addressing a complete stranger Jerome eulogizes the virtues of Nebridius, particularly his chastity and his bounty to the poor.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:5
verses.text: He next warns Salvina (in no courtier-like terms) of the dangers that will beset her as a widow and recommends her to devote all her energies to the careful training of the son and daughter who are now her principal charge.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:6
verses.text: The tone of the letter is somewhat arrogant and it can hardly be regarded as one of Jerome's happiest efforts.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:7
verses.text: Salvina, however, consecrated her life to deeds of piety, and became one of Chrysostom's deaconesses.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:8
verses.text: Its date is 400 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:9
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:11
verses.text: My desire to do my duty may, I fear, expose me to a charge of self-seeking; and although I do but follow the example of Him who said: "learn of me for I am meek and lowly of heart," the course that I am taking may be attributed to a desire for notoriety.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:12
verses.text: Men may say that I am not so much trying to console a widow in affliction as endeavouring to creep into the imperial court; and that, while I make a pretext of offering comfort, I am really seeking the friendship of the great.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:13
verses.text: Clearly this will not be the opinion of any one who knows the commandment: "thou shalt not respect the person of the poor," a precept given lest under pretext of shewing pity we should judge unjust judgment.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:14
verses.text: For each individual is to be judged not by his personal importance but by the merits of his case.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:15
verses.text: His wealth need not stand in the way of the rich man, if he makes a good use of it; and poverty can be no recommendation to the poor if in the midst of squalor and want he fails to keep clear of wrong doing.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:16
verses.text: Proofs of these things are not wanting either in scriptural times or our own; for Abraham, in spite of his immense wealth, was "the friend of God" and poor men are daily arrested and punished for their crimes by law.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:17
verses.text: She whom I now address is both rich and poor so that she cannot say what she actually has.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:18
verses.text: For it is not of her purse that I am speaking but of the purity of her soul.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:19
verses.text: I do not know her face but I am well acquainted with her virtues; for report speaks well of her and her youth makes her chastity all the more commendable.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:20
verses.text: By her grief for her young husband she has set an example to all wives; and by her resignation she has proved that she believes him not lost but gone before.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:21
verses.text: The greatness of her bereavement has brought out the reality of her religion.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:22
verses.text: For while she forgets her lost Nebridius, she knows that in Christ he is with her still.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:23
verses.text: But why do I write to one who is a stranger to me? For three reasons.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:24
verses.text: First, because (as a priest is bound to do) I love all Christians as my children and find my glory in promoting their welfare.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:25
verses.text: Secondly because the father of Nebridius was bound to me by the closest ties.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:26
verses.text: Lastly—and this is a stronger reason than the others—because I have failed to say no to my son Avitus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:27
verses.text: With an importunacy surpassing that of the widow towards the unjust judge he wrote to me so frequently and put before me so many instances in which I had previously dealt with a similar theme, that he overcame my modest reluctance and made the resolve to do not what would best become me but what would most nearly meet his wishes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:29
verses.text: As the mother of Nebridius was sister to the empress and as he was brought up in the bosom of his aunt, another might perhaps praise him for having so much endeared himself to the unvanquished emperor.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:30
verses.text: Theodosius, indeed, procured him from Africa a wife of the highest rank, who, as her native land at this time was distracted by civil wars, became a kind of hostage for its loyalty.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:31
verses.text: I ought to say at the very outset that Nebridius seems to have had a presentiment that he would die early.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:32
verses.text: For amid the splendour of the palace and in the high positions to which his rank and not his years entitled him he lived always as one who believed that he must soon go to meet Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:33
verses.text: Of Cornelius, the centurion of the Italian band, the sacred narrative tells us that God so fully accepted him as to send to him an angel; and that this angel told him that to his merit was due the mystery whereby Peter from the narrow limits of the circumcision was conveyed to the wide field of the uncircumcision.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:34
verses.text: He was the first Gentile baptized by the apostle, and in him the Gentiles were set apart to salvation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:35
verses.text: Now of this man it is written: "there was a certain man in Caesarea called Cornelius, a centurion of the band called the Italian band, a devout man and one that feared God with all his house, which gave much alms to the people, and prayed to God alway".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:36
verses.text: All this that is said of him I claim—with a change of name only—for my dear Nebridius.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:37
verses.text: So "devout" was this latter and so enamoured of chastity that at his marriage he was still pure.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:38
verses.text: So truly did he "fear God with all his house" that forgetting his high position he spent all his time with monks and clergymen.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:39
verses.text: So profuse were the alms which he gave to the people that his doors were continually beset with swarms of sick and poor.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:40
verses.text: And assuredly he "prayed to God alway" that what was for the best might happen to him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:41
verses.text: Therefore "speedily was he taken away lest that wickedness should alter his understanding…for his soul pleased the Lord".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:42
verses.text: Thus I may truthfully apply to him the apostle's words: "Of a truth I perceive that God is no respecter of persons: but in every nation he that feareth Him and worketh righteousness, is accepted with Him".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:43
verses.text: As a soldier Nebridius took no harm from his cloak and sword-belt and troops of orderlies; for while he wore the uniform of the emperor he was enlisted in the service of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:44
verses.text: On the other hand nothing is gained by men who while they affect coarse mantles, sombre tunics, dirt, and poverty, belie by their deeds their lofty pretensions.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:45
verses.text: Of another centurion we find in the gospel this testimony from our Lord:—"I have not found so great faith, no not in Israel".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:46
verses.text: And, to go back to earlier times, we read of Joseph who gave proof of his integrity both when he was in want and when he was rich, and who inculcated freedom of soul both as slave and as lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:47
verses.text: He was made next to Pharaoh and invested with the emblems of royalty; yet so dear was he to God that, alone of all the patriarchs, he became the father of two tribes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:48
verses.text: Daniel and the three children were set over the affairs of Babylon and were numbered among the princes of the state; yet although they wore the dress of Nebuchadnezzar, in their hearts they served God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:49
verses.text: Mordecai also and Esther amid purple and silk and jewels overcame pride with humility; and although captives were so highly esteemed as to be able to impose commands upon their conquerors.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:51
verses.text: These remarks are intended to shew that the youth of whom I speak used his kinship to the royal family, his abundant wealth, and the outward tokens of power, as helps to virtue.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:52
verses.text: For, as the preacher says, "wisdom is a defence and money is a defence" also.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:53
verses.text: We must not hastily conclude that this statement conflicts with that of the Lord: "verily I say unto you that a rich man shall hardly enter into the kingdom of heaven; and again I say unto you, It is easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle than for a rich man to enter into the kingdom of heaven".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:54
verses.text: Were it so, the salvation of Zacchaeus the publican, described in scripture as a man of great wealth, would contradict the Lord's declaration.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:55
verses.text: But that what is impossible with men is possible with God we are taught by the counsel of the apostle who thus writes to Timothy:—"charge them that are rich in this world that they be not highminded, nor trust in uncertain riches, but in the living God who giveth us richly all things to enjoy, that they do good, that they be rich in good works, ready to distribute.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:56
verses.text: willing to communicate, laying up in store for themselves a good foundation against the time to come that they may lay hold on the true life".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:57
verses.text: We have learned how a camel can pass through a needle's eye, how an animal with a hump on its back, when it has laid down its packs, can take to itself the wings of a dove and rest in the branches of the tree which has grown from a grain of mustard seed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:58
verses.text: In Isaiah we read of camels, the dromedaries of Midian and Ephah and Sheba, which carry gold and incense to the city of the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:59
verses.text: On like typical camels the Ishmaelitish merchantmen bring down to the Egyptians perfume and incense and balm (of the kind that grows in Gilead good for the healing of wounds); and so fortunate are they that in the purchase and sale of Joseph they have for their merchandise the Saviour of the world.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:60
verses.text: And aesop's fable tells us of a mouse which after eating its fill can no longer creep out as before it crept in.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:62
verses.text: Daily did my dear Nebridius revolve the words: "they that will be rich fall into temptation and a snare" of the devil "and into many lusts".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:63
verses.text: All the money that the Emperor's bounty gave him or that his badges of office procured him he laid out for the benefit of the poor.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:64
verses.text: For he knew the commandment of the Lord: "If thou wilt be perfect go and sell that thou hast, and give to the poor, and come and follow me".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:65
verses.text: And because he could not literally fulfil these directions, having a wife and little children and a large household, he made to himself friends of the mammon of unrighteousness that they might receive him into everlasting habitations.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:66
verses.text: He did not once for all cast away his brethren, as did the apostles who forsook father and nets and ship, but by an equality he ministered to the want of others out of his own abundance that afterwards their wealth might be a supply for his own want.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:67
verses.text: The lady to whom this letter is addressed knows that what I narrate is only known to me by hearsay, but she is aware also that I am no Greek writer repaying with flattery some benefit conferred upon me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:68
verses.text: Far be such an imputation from all Christians.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:69
verses.text: Having food and raiment we are therewith content.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:70
verses.text: Where there is cheap cabbage and household bread, a sufficiency to eat and a sufficiency to drink, these riches are superfluous and no place is left for flattery with its sordid calculations.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:71
verses.text: You may conclude therefore that, where there is no motive to tell a falsehood, the testimony given is true.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:73
verses.text: It must not, however, be supposed that I praise Nebridius only for his liberality in alms-giving, although we are taught the great importance of this in the words: "water will quench a flaming fire; and alms maketh an atonement for sins".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:74
verses.text: I will pass on now to his other virtues each one of which is to be found but in few men.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:75
verses.text: Who ever entered the furnace of the King of Babylon without being burned? Was there ever a young man whose garment his Egyptian mistress did not seize? Was there ever a eunuch's wife contented with a childless marriage bed? Is there any man who is not appalled by the struggle of which the apostle says: "I see another law in my members warring against the law of my mind, and bringing me into captivity to the law of sin which is in my members?" But wonderful to say Nebridius, though bred up in a palace as a companion and fellow pupil of the Augusti (whose table is supplied by the whole world and ministered to by land and sea); Nebridius, I say, though in the midst of abundance and in the flower of his age, shewed himself more modest than a girl and never gave occasion, even the slightest, for scandalous rumours.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:76
verses.text: Again though he was the friend, companion, and cousin of princes and had been educated along with them—a thing which makes even strangers intimate—he did not allow pride to inflate him or frown with contempt upon others who were less fortunate than he: no, he was kind to all, and while he loved the princes as brothers he revered them as sovereigns.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:77
verses.text: He used to avow that his own health and safety were dependent upon theirs.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:78
verses.text: Their attendants and all those officers of the palace who by their numbers add to the grandeur of the imperial court he had so well conciliated by shewing his regard for them, that men who were in reality inferior to him were led by his attention to believe themselves his peers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:79
verses.text: It is no easy task to throw one's rank into the shade by one's virtue, or to gain the affection of men who are forced to yield you precedence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:80
verses.text: What widow was not supported by his help? What ward did not find in him a father? To him the bishops of the entire East used to bring the prayers of the unfortunate and the petitions of the distressed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:81
verses.text: Whenever he asked the Emperor for a boon, he sought either alms for the poor or ransom for captives or clemency for the afflicted.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:82
verses.text: Accordingly the princes also used gladly to accede to his requests, for they knew well that their bounty would benefit not one man but many.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:84
verses.text: Why do I farther postpone the end? "All flesh is grass and all the goodliness thereof is as the flower of the field".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:85
verses.text: The dust has returned to the dust.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:86
verses.text: He has fallen asleep in the Lord and has been laid with his fathers, full of days and of light and fostered in a good old age.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:87
verses.text: For "wisdom is the grey hair unto men".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:88
verses.text: "In a short time he" has "fulfilled a long time".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:89
verses.text: In his place we now have his charming children.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:90
verses.text: His wife is the heir of his chastity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:91
verses.text: To those who miss his father the tiny Nebridius shews him once more, for  Such were the eyes and hands and looks he bore.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:92
verses.text: A spark of the parent's excellence shines in the son: the child's face betrays like a mirror a resemblance in character.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:93
verses.text: That narrow frame contains a hero's heart.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:94
verses.text: And with him there is his sister, a basket of roses and lilies, a mixture of ivory and purple.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:95
verses.text: Her face though it takes after that of her father inclines to be still more attractive; and, while her complexion is that of her mother, she is so like both her parents that the lineaments of each are reflected in her features.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:96
verses.text: So sweet and honied is she that she is the pride of all her kinsfolk.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:97
verses.text: The Emperor does not disdain to hold her in his arms, and the Empress likes nothing better than to nurse her on her lap.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:98
verses.text: Everyone runs to be the first to catch her up.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:99
verses.text: Now she clings to the neck of one, and now she is fondled in the arms of another.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:100
verses.text: She prattles and stammers, and is all the sweeter for her faltering tongue.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:102
verses.text: You have, therefore, Salvina, those to nurse who may well represent to you your absent husband: "Lo, children are an heritage of the Lord; and the fruit of the womb is his reward".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:103
verses.text: In the place of one husband you have received two children, and thus your affection has more objects than before.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:104
verses.text: All that was due to him you can give to them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:105
