verses.text: Temper grief with love, for if he is gone they are still with you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:106
verses.text: It is no small merit in God's eyes to bring up children well.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:107
verses.text: Hear the apostle's counsel: "Let not a widow be taken into the number under threescore years old, having been the wife of one man, well reported of for good works; if she have brought up children, if she have lodged strangers, if she have washed the saints' feet, if she have relieved the afflicted, if she have diligently followed every good work".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:108
verses.text: Here you learn the roll of the virtues which God requires of you, what is due to the name of widow which you bear, and by what good deeds you can attain to that second degree of chastity which is still open to you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:109
verses.text: Do not be disturbed because the apostle allows none to be chosen as a widow under threescore years old, neither suppose that he intends to reject those who are still young.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:110
verses.text: Believe that you are indeed chosen by him who said to his disciple, "Let no man despise thy youth," your want of age that is, not your want of continence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:111
verses.text: If this be not his meaning, all who become widows under threescore years will have to take husbands.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:112
verses.text: He is training a church still untaught in Christ, and making provision for people of all stations but especially for the poor, the charge of whom had been committed to himself and Barnabas.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:113
verses.text: Thus he wishes only those to be supported by the exertions of the church who cannot labour with their own hands, and who are widows indeed, approved by their years and by their lives.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:114
verses.text: The faults of his children made Eli the priest an offence to God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:115
verses.text: On the other hand He is appeased by the virtues of such as "continue in faith and charity and holiness with chastity".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:116
verses.text: "O Timothy," cries the apostle, "keep thyself pure".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:117
verses.text: Far be it from me to suspect you capable of doing anything wrong; still it is only a kindness to admonish one whose youth and opulence lead her into temptation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:118
verses.text: You must take what I am going to say as addressed not to you but to your girlish years.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:119
verses.text: A widow "that liveth in pleasure is dead while she liveth".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:120
verses.text: So speaks the "chosen vessel" and the words are brought out from his treasure who could boldly say: "Do ye seek a proof of Christ speaking in me?" Yet they are the words of one who in his own person admitted the weakness of the human body, saying: "The good that I would I do not: but the evil which I would not that I do".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:121
verses.text: And again: Therefore "I keep under my body and bring it into subjection lest that by any means when I have preached to others I myself should be a castaway".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:122
verses.text: If Paul is afraid, which of us can venture to be confident? If David the friend of God and Solomon who loved God were overcome like other men, if their fall is meant to warn us and their penitence to lead us to salvation, who in this slippery life can be sure of not falling? Never let pheasants be seen upon your table, or plump turtledoves or black cock from Ionia, or any of those birds so expensive that they fly away with the largest properties.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:123
verses.text: And do not fancy that you eschew meat diet when you reject pork, hare, and venison and the savoury flesh of other quadrupeds.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:124
verses.text: It is not the number of feet that makes the difference but delicacy of flavour.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:125
verses.text: I know that the apostle has said: "every creature of God is good and nothing to be refused if it be received with thanksgiving".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:126
verses.text: But the same apostle says: "it is good neither to eat flesh nor to drink wine," and in another place: "be not drunk with wine wherein is excess".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:127
verses.text: "Every creature of God is good"—the precept is intended for those who are careful how they may please their husbands.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:128
verses.text: Let those feed on flesh who serve the flesh, whose bodies boil with desire, who are tied to husbands, and who set their hearts on having offspring.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:129
verses.text: Let those whose wombs are burthened cram their stomachs with flesh.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:130
verses.text: But you have buried every indulgence in your husband's tomb: over his bier you have cleansed with tears a face stained with rouge and whitelead; you have exchanged a white robe and gilded buskins for a sombre tunic and black shoes; and only one thing more is needed, perseverance in fasting.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:131
verses.text: Let paleness and squalor be henceforth your jewels.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:132
verses.text: Do not pamper your youthful limbs with a bed of down or kindle your young blood with hot baths.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:133
verses.text: Hear what words a heathen poet puts into the mouth of a chaste widow:  He, my first spouse, has robbed me of my loves.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:134
verses.text: So be it: let him keep them in the tomb.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:135
verses.text: If common glass is worth so much, what must be the value of a pearl of price? If in deference to a law of nature a Gentile widow can condemn all sensual indulgence, what must we expect from a Christian widow who owes her chastity not to one who is dead but to one with whom she shall reign in heaven?  8.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:136
verses.text: Do not, I pray you, regard these general remarks—applying as they do to all young women—as intended to insult you or to take you to task.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:137
verses.text: I write in a spirit of apprehension, yet pray that you may never know the nature of my fears.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:138
verses.text: A woman's reputation is a tender plant; it is like a fair flower which withers at the slightest blast and fades away at the first breath of wind.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:139
verses.text: Especially is this so when she is of an age to fall into temptation and the authority of a husband is wanting to her.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:140
verses.text: For the very shadow of a husband is a wife's safeguard.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:141
verses.text: What has a widow to do with a large household or with troops of retainers? As servants, it is true, she must not despise them, but as men she ought to blush before them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:142
verses.text: If a grand establishment requires such domestics, let her at least set over them an old man of spotless morals whose dignity may guard the honour of his mistress.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:143
verses.text: I know of many widows who, although they live with closed doors, have not escaped the imputation of too great intimacy with their servants.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:144
verses.text: These latter become objects of suspicion when they dress above their degree, or when they are stout and sleek, or when they are of an age inclined to passion, or when knowledge of the favour in which they are secretly held betrays itself in a too confident demeanour.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:145
verses.text: For such pride, however carefully concealed, is sure to break out in a contempt for fellow-servants as servants.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:146
verses.text: I make these seemingly superfluous remarks that you may keep your heart with all diligence and guard against every scandal that may be broached concerning you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:148
verses.text: Take no well-curled steward to walk with you, no effeminate actor, no devilish singer of poisoned sweetness, no spruce and smooth-shorn youth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:149
verses.text: Let no theatrical compliments, no obsequious adulation be associated with you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:150
verses.text: Keep with you bands of widows and virgins; and let your consolers be of your own sex.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:151
verses.text: The character of the mistress is judged by that of the maid.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:152
verses.text: So long as you have with you a holy mother, so long as an aunt vowed to virginity is at your side, you ought not to neglect them and at your own risk to seek the company of strangers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:153
verses.text: Let the divine scripture be always in your hands, and give yourself so frequently to prayer that such shafts of evil thoughts as ever assail the young may thereby find a shield to repel them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:154
verses.text: It is difficult, nay more it is impossible, to escape the beginnings of those internal motions which the Greeks with much significance call προπάθειαι that is 'predispositions to passion.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:155
verses.text: ' The fact is that suggestions of sin tickle all our minds, and the decision rests with our own hearts either to admit or to reject the thoughts which come.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:156
verses.text: The Lord of nature Himself says in the gospel:—"out of the heart proceed evil thoughts, murders, adulteries, fornications, thefts, false witness, blasphemies".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:157
verses.text: It is clear from the testimony of another book that "the imagination of man's heart is evil from his youth," and that the soul wavers between the works of the flesh and of the spirit enumerated by the apostle, desiring now the former and now the latter.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:158
verses.text: For  From faults no mortal man is wholly free;  The best is he who has but few of them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:159
verses.text: And, to quote the same poet,  At moles men cavil when they mark fair skins.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:160
verses.text: To the same effect in different words the prophet says:—"I am so troubled that I cannot speak," and in the same book, "Be ye angry and sin not".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:161
verses.text: So Archytas of Tarentum once said to a careless steward: "I should have flogged you to death had I not been in a passion".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:162
verses.text: For "the wrath of man worketh not the righteousness of God".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:163
verses.text: Now what is here said of one form of perturbation may be applied to all.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:164
verses.text: Just as anger is human and the repression of it Christian, so it is with other passions.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:165
verses.text: The flesh always lusts after the things of the flesh, and by its allurements draws the soul to partake of deadly pleasures; but it is for us Christians to restrain the desire for sensual indulgence by an intenser love for Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:166
verses.text: It is for us to break in the mettlesome brute within us by fasting, in order that it may desire not lust but food and amble easily and steadily forward having for its rider the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:168
verses.text: Why do I write thus? To shew you that you are but human and subject, unless you guard against them, to human passions.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:169
verses.text: We are all of us made of the same clay and formed of the same elements.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:170
verses.text: Whether we wear silk or rags we are all at the mercy of the same desire.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:171
verses.text: It does not fear the royal purple; it does not disdain the squalor of the mendicant.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:172
verses.text: It is better then to suffer in stomach than in soul, to rule the body than to serve it, to lose one's balance than to lose one's chastity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:173
verses.text: Let us not lull ourselves with the delusion that we can always fall back on penitence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:174
verses.text: For this is at best but a remedy for misery.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:175
verses.text: Let us shrink from incurring a wound which must be painful to cure.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:176
verses.text: For it is one thing to enter the haven of salvation with ship safe and merchandise uninjured, and another to cling naked to a plank and, as the waves toss you this way and that, to be dashed again and again on the sharp rocks.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:177
verses.text: A widow should be ignorant that second marriage is permitted; she should know nothing of the apostle's words:—"It is better to marry than to burn".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:178
verses.text: Remove what is said to be worse, the risk of burning, and marriage will cease to be regarded as good.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:179
verses.text: Of course I repudiate the slanders of the heretics; I know that "marriage is honourable…and the bed undefiled".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:180
verses.text: Yet Adam even after he was expelled from paradise had but one wife.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:181
verses.text: The accursed and blood-stained Lamech, descended from the stock of Cain, was the first to make out of one rib two wives; and the seedling of digamy then planted was altogether destroyed by the doom of the deluge.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:182
verses.text: It is true that in writing to Timothy the apostle from fear of fornication is forced to countenance second marriage.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:183
verses.text: His words are these:—"I will therefore that the younger women marry, bear children, guide the house, give none occasion to the adversary to speak reproachfully".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:184
verses.text: But he immediately adds as a reason for this concession; "for some are already turned aside after Satan".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:185
verses.text: Thus we see that he is offering not a crown to those who stand but a helping hand to those who are down.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:186
verses.text: What must a second marriage be if it is looked on merely as an alternative to the brothel! "For some," he writes, "are already turned aside after Satan".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:187
verses.text: The upshot of the whole matter is that, if a young widow cannot or will not contain herself, she had better take a husband to her bed than the devil.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:188
verses.text: A noble alternative truly which is only to be embraced in preference to Satan! In old days even Jerusalem went a-whoring and opened her feet to every one that passed by.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:189
verses.text: It was in Egypt that she was first deflowered and there that her teats were bruised.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:190
verses.text: And afterwards when she had come to the wilderness and, impatient of the delays of her leader Moses, had said when maddened by the stings of lust: "these be thy gods, O Israel, which brought thee up out of the land of Egypt," she received statutes that were not good and commandments that were altogether evil whereby she should not live but should be punished through them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:191
verses.text: Is it surprising then that when the apostle had said in another place of young widows: "when they have begun to wax wanton against Christ they will marry, having damnation because they have cast off their first faith," he granted to such as should wax wanton statutes of digamy that were not good and commandments that were altogether evil? For the reason which he gives for allowing a second husband would justify a woman in marrying a third or even, if she liked, a twentieth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:192
verses.text: He evidently wished to shew them that he was not so much anxious that they should take husbands as that they should avoid paramours.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:193
verses.text: These things, dearest daughter in Christ, I impress upon you and frequently repeat, that you may forget those things which are behind and reach forth unto those things which are before.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:194
verses.text: You have widows like yourself worthy to be your models, Judith renowned in Hebrew story and Anna the daughter of Phanuel famous in the gospel.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:195
verses.text: Both these lived day and night in the temple and preserved the treasure of their chastity by prayer and by fasting.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:196
verses.text: One was a type of the Church which cuts off the head of the devil and the other first received in her arms the saviour of the world and had revealed to her the holy mysteries which were to come.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 79:197
verses.text: In conclusion I beg you to attribute the shortness of my letter not to want of language or scarcity of matter but to a deep sense of modesty which makes me fear to force myself too long upon the ears of a stranger, and causes me to dread the secret verdict of those who read my words.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 80:1
verses.text: Letter LXXX.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 80:2
verses.text: From Rufinus to Macarius.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 80:3
verses.text: Rufinus on his return from Bethlehem to Rome published a Latin version of Origen's treatise περι ᾽Αρχῶν, On First Principles.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 80:4
verses.text: To this he prefixed the preface which is here printed among Jerome's letters.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 80:5
verses.text: Professing to take as his model Jerome's own translations of Origen's commentaries which he greatly praises, he declares that, following his example, he has paraphrased the obscure passages of the treatise and has paraphrased the obscure passages of the treatise and has omitted as due to interpolators such parts as seem heretical.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 80:6
verses.text: This preface with its insincere praise of Jerome (whose name, however, is not mentioned) and its avowed manipulation of Origen's text caused much perplexity at Rome (see Letters LXXXI.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 80:7
verses.text: , LXXXIII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 80:8
verses.text: , and LXXXIV.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 80:9
verses.text: ), and gave rise to the controversy between Rufinus and Jerome described in the Prolegomena, and given at length in vol.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 80:10
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 80:11
verses.text: of this Series.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 80:12
verses.text: The date is 398 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 80:13
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 80:15
verses.text: Large numbers of the brethren have, I know, in their zeal for the knowledge of the scriptures begged learned men skilled in Greek literature to make Origen a Roman by bringing home his teaching to Latin ears.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 80:16
verses.text: One of these scholars, a dear brother and associate, at the request of bishop Damasus translated from Greek into Latin his two homilies on the Song of Songs and prefaced the work with an eloquent and eulogistic introduction such as could not fail to arouse in all an ardent desire to read and to study Origen.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 80:17
verses.text: To the soul of that just man—so he declared—the words of the Song were applicable: "the king hath brought me into his chambers;" and he went on to speak thus: "while in his other books Origen surpasses all former writers, in dealing with the Song of Songs he surpasses himself".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 80:18
verses.text: In his preface he pledges himself to give to Roman ears these homilies of Origen and as many of his other works as he can.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 80:19
verses.text: His style is certainly attractive but I can see that he aims at a more ambitious task than that of a mere translator.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 80:20
verses.text: Not content with rendering the words of Origen he desires to be himself the teacher.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 80:21
verses.text: I for my part do but follow up an enterprise which he has sanctioned and commenced, but I lack his vigorous eloquence with which to adorn the sayings of this great man.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 80:22
verses.text: I am even afraid lest my deficiencies and inadequate command of Latin may detract seriously from the reputation of one whom this writer has deservedly termed second only to the apostles as a teacher of the Church in knowledge and in wisdom.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 80:24
verses.text: Often turning this over in my mind I held my peace and refused to listen to the brethren when—as frequently happened—they urged me to undertake the work.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 80:25
verses.text: But your persistence, most faithful brother Macarius, is so great that even want of ability cannot resist it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 80:26
verses.text: Thus, to escape the constant importunings to which you subject me, I have given way contrary to my resolution; yet only on these terms that, so far as is possible, I am to be free to follow the rules of translation laid down by my predecessors, and particularly those acted upon by the writer whom I have just mentioned.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 80:27
verses.text: He has rendered into Latin more than seventy of Origen's homiletical treatises and a few also of his commentaries upon the apostle; and in these wherever the Greek text presents a stumbling block, he has smoothed it down in his version and has so emended the language used that a Latin writer can find no word that is at variance with our faith.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 80:28
verses.text: In his steps, therefore, I propose to walk, if not displaying the same vigorous eloquence at least observing the same rules.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 80:29
verses.text: I shall not reproduce passages in Origen's books which disagree with or contradict his own statements elsewhere.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 80:30
verses.text: The reason of these inconsistencies I have put more fully before you in the defence of Origen's writings composed by Pamphilianus which I have supplemented by a short treatise of my own.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 80:31
verses.text: I have given what I consider plain proofs that his books have been corrupted in numbers of places by heretics and ill-disposed persons, and particularly those which you now urge me to translate.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 80:32
verses.text: The books περὶ ᾽Αρχῶν, that is of Principles or of Powers, are in fact in other respects extremely obscure and difficult.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 80:33
verses.text: For they treat of subjects on which the philosophers have spent all their days and yet have been able to discover nothing.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 80:34
verses.text: In dealing with these themes Origen has done his best to make belief in a Creator and a rational account of things created subservient to religion and not, as with the philosophers, to irreligion.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 80:35
verses.text: Wherever then in his books I have found a statement concerning the Trinity contrary to those which in other places he has faithfully made on the same subject, I have either omitted the passage as garbled and misleading or have substituted that view of the matter which I find him to have frequently asserted.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 80:36
verses.text: Again, wherever—in haste to get on with his theme—he is brief or obscure relying on the skill and intelligence of his readers, I, to make the passage clearer, have sought to explain it by adding any plainer statements that I have read on the point in his other books.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 80:37
verses.text: But I have added nothing of my own.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 80:38
verses.text: The words used may be found in other parts of his writings: they are his, not mine.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 80:39
verses.text: I mention this here to take from cavillers all pretext for once more finding fault.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 80:40
verses.text: But let such perverse and contentious persons look well to what they are themselves doing.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 80:42
verses.text: Meantime I have taken up this great task—if so be that God will grant your prayers—not to stop the mouths of slanderers (an impossible feat except perhaps to God) but to give to those who desire it the means of making progress in knowledge.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 80:43
verses.text: In the sight of God, the Father, the Son, and the Holy Ghost, I adjure and require everyone who shall either read or copy these books of mine, by his belief in a kingdom to come, by the mystery of the resurrection from the dead, by the eternal fire which is "prepared for the devil and his angels;" as he hopes not to inherit eternally that place where "there is weeping and gnashing of teeth," and where "their worm dieth not and the fire is not quenched," let him add nothing to what is written, let him subtract nothing, let him insert nothing, let him alter nothing, but let him compare his transcript with the copies from which it is made, let him correct it to the letter, and let him punctuate it aright.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 80:44
verses.text: Every manuscript that is not properly corrected and punctuated he must reject: for otherwise the difficulties in the text arising from the want of punctuation will make obscure arguments still more obscure to those who read them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 81:1
verses.text: Letter LXXXI.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 81:2
verses.text: To Rufinus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 81:3
verses.text: A friendly letter of remonstrance written by Jerome to Rufinus on receipt of his version of the περὶ ᾽Αρχῶν see the preceding letter).

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 81:4
verses.text: Being sent in the first instance to Pammachius this latter treacherously suppressed it and thus put an end to all hope of the reconciliation of the two friends.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 81:5
verses.text: The date of the letter is 399 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 81:6
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 81:8
verses.text: That you have lingered some time at Rome your own language shews.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 81:9
verses.text: Yet I feel sure that a yearning to see your spiritual parents would have drawn you to your native country, had not grief for your mother deterred you lest a sorrow scarce bearable away might have proved unbearable at home.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 81:10
verses.text: As to your complaint that men listen only to the dictates of passion and refuse to acquiesce in your judgement and mine; the Lord is witness to my conscience that since our reconciliation I have harboured no rancour in my breast to injure anyone; on the contrary I have taken the utmost pains to prevent any chance occurrence being set down to ill-will.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 81:11
verses.text: But what can I do so long as everyone supposes that he has a right to do as he does and thinks that in publishing a slander he is requiting not originating a calumny? True friendship ought never to conceal what it thinks.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 81:12
verses.text: The short preface to the books περὶ ᾽Αρχῶν which has been sent to me I recognize as yours by the style.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 81:13
verses.text: You know best with what intention it was written; but even a fool can see how it must necessarily be understood.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 81:14
verses.text: Covertly or rather openly I am the person aimed at.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 81:15
verses.text: I have often myself feigned a controversy to practise declamation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 81:16
verses.text: Thus I might now recall this well-worn artifice and praise you in your own method.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 81:17
verses.text: But far be it from me to imitate what I blame in you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 81:18
verses.text: In fact I have so far restrained my feelings that I make no charge against you, and, although injured, decline for my part to injure a friend.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 81:19
verses.text: But another time, if you wish to follow any one, pray be satisfied with your own judgement.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 81:20
verses.text: The objects which we seek are either good or bad.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 81:21
verses.text: If they are good, they need no help from another; and if they are bad, the fact that many sin together is no excuse.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 81:22
verses.text: I prefer thus to expostulate with you as a friend rather than to give public vent to my indignation at the wrong I have suffered.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 81:23
verses.text: I want you to see that when I am reconciled to anyone I become his sincere friend and do not—to borrow a figure from Plautus—while offering him bread with one hand, hold a stone in the other.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 81:25
verses.text: My brother Paulinian has not yet returned from home and I fancy that you will see him at Aquileia at the house of the reverend pope Chromatius.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 81:26
verses.text: I am also sending the reverend presbyter Rufinus on business to Milan by way of Rome, and have requested him to communicate to you my feelings and respects.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 81:27
verses.text: I am sending the same message to the rest of my friends; lest, as the apostle says, ye bite and devour one another, ye be consumed one of another.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 81:28
verses.text: It only remains for you and your friends to shew your moderation by giving no offence to those who are disinclined to put up with it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 81:29
verses.text: For you will hardly find everyone like me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 81:30
verses.text: There are few who can be pleased with pretended eulogies.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:1
verses.text: Letter LXXXII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:2
verses.text: To Theophilus Bishop of Alexandria.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:3
verses.text: Two years after his former attempt (see Letter LXIII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:4
verses.text: ) Theophilus again wrote to Jerome urging him to be reconciled with John of Jerusalem.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:5
verses.text: Jerome replies that there is nothing he desires more earnestly than peace but that this must be real and not a hollow truce.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:6
verses.text: He speaks very bitterly of John who has, he alleges, intrigued to procure his banishment from Palestine.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:7
verses.text: He also deals with the ordination of his brother Paulinian (for which see Letter LI.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:8
verses.text: ) and defends himself for having translated Origen's commentaries by adducing the example of Hilary of Poitiers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:9
verses.text: This letter should be compared with the Treatise "Against John of Jerusalem" in this volume.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:10
verses.text: Its date is 399 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:11
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:13
verses.text: Your letter shews you to possess that heritage of the Lord of which when going to the Father he said to the apostles, "peace I leave with you, my peace I give unto you," and to own the happiness described in the words, "blessed are the peace-makers".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:14
verses.text: You coax as a father, you teach as a master, you enjoin as a bishop.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:15
verses.text: You come to me not with a rod and severity but in a spirit of kindness, gentleness, and meekness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:16
verses.text: Your opening words echo the humility of Christ who saved men not with thunder and lightning but as a wailing babe in the manger and as a silent sufferer upon the cross.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:17
verses.text: You have read the prediction made in one who was a type of Him, "Lord, remember David and all his meekness," and you know how it was fulfilled afterwards in Himself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:18
verses.text: "Learn of me," He said, "for I am meek and lowly in heart".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:19
verses.text: You have quoted many passages from the sacred books in praise of peace, you have flitted like a bee over the flowery fields of scripture, you have culled with cunning eloquence all that is sweet and conducive to concord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:20
verses.text: I was already running after peace, but you have made me quicken my pace: my sails were set for the voyage but your exhortation has filled them with a stronger breeze.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:21
verses.text: I drink in the sweet streams of peace not reluctantly and with aversion but eagerly and with open mouth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:23
verses.text: But what can I do, I who can only wish for peace and have no power to bring it about? Even though the wish may win its recompense with God, its futility must still sadden him who cherishes it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:24
verses.text: When the apostle said, "as much as lieth in you, live peaceably with all men," he knew quite well that the realisation of peace depends upon the consent of two parties.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:25
verses.text: The prophet truly cries "They say Peace, peace: and yet there is no peace".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:26
verses.text: To overthrow peace by actions while professing it in words is not hard.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:27
verses.text: To point out its advantages is one thing and to strive for it another.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:28
verses.text: Men's speeches may be all for unity but their actions may enforce bondage.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:29
verses.text: I wish for peace as much as others; and not only do I wish for it, I ask for it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:30
verses.text: But the peace which I want is the peace of Christ; a true peace, a peace without rancour, a peace which does not involve war, a peace which will not reduce opponents but will unite friends.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:31
verses.text: How can I term domination peace? I must call things by their right names.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:32
verses.text: Where there is hatred there let men talk of feuds; and where there is mutual esteem, there only let peace be spoken of.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:33
verses.text: For my part I neither rend the church nor separate myself from the communion of the fathers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:34
verses.text: From my very cradle, I may say, I have been reared on Catholic milk; and no one can be a better churchman than one who has never been a heretic.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:35
verses.text: But I know nothing of a peace that is without love or of a communion that is without peace.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:36
verses.text: In the gospel I read:—"if thou bring thy gift to the altar and there rememberest that thy brother hath aught against thee; leave there thy gift before the altar and go thy way; first be reconciled to thy brother, and then come and offer thy gift".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:37
verses.text: If then we may not offer gifts that are our own unless we are at peace with our brothers; how much less can we receive the body of Christ if we cherish enmity in our hearts? How can I conscientiously approach Christ's eucharist and answer the Amen if I doubt the charity of him who ministers it?  3.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:38
verses.text: Hear me, I beg you with patience and do not take truthfulness for flattery.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:39
verses.text: Is any man reluctant to communicate with you? Does any turn his face away when you hold out your hand? Does any at the holy banquet offer you the kiss of Judas? At your approach the monks instead of trembling rejoice.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:40
verses.text: They race to meet you and leaving their dens in the desert are fain to master you by their humility.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:41
verses.text: What compels them to come forth? Is it not their love for you? What draws together the scattered dwellers in the desert? Is it not the esteem in which they hold you? A parent ought to love his children; and not only a parent but a bishop ought to be loved by his children.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:42
verses.text: Neither ought to be feared.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:43
verses.text: There is an old saying: "whom a man fears he hates; and whom he hates, he would fain see dead".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:44
verses.text: Accordingly, while for the young the holy scripture makes fear the beginning of knowledge, it also tells us that "perfect love casteth out fear".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:45
verses.text: You exact no obedience from them; therefore the monks obey you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:46
verses.text: You offer them a kiss; therefore they bow the neck.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:47
verses.text: You shew yourself a common soldier; therefore they make you their general.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:48
verses.text: Thus from being one among many you become one above many.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:49
verses.text: Freedom is easily roused if attempts are made to crush it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:50
verses.text: No one gets more from a free man than he who does not force him to be a slave.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:51
verses.text: I know the canons of the church; I know what rank her ministers hold; and from men and books I have daily up to the present learned and gathered many things.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:52
verses.text: The kingdom of the mild David was quickly dismembered by one who chastised his people with scorpions and fancied that his fingers were thicker than his father's loins.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:53
verses.text: The Roman people refused to brook insolence even in a king.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:54
verses.text: Moses was leader of the host of Israel; he brought ten plagues upon Egypt; sky, earth, and sea alike obeyed his commands: yet he is spoken of as "very meek above all the men which were" at that time "upon the face of the earth".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:55
verses.text: He maintained his forty-years' supremacy because he tempered the insolence of office with gentleness and meekness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:56
verses.text: When he was being stoned by the people he made intercession for them; nay more he wished to be blotted out of God's book sooner than that the flock committed to him should perish.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:57
verses.text: He sought to imitate the Shepherd who would, he knew, carry on his shoulders even the wandering sheep.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:58
verses.text: "The good Shepherd"—they are the Lord's own words—"layeth down his life for the sheep".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:59
verses.text: One of his disciples can wish to be anathema from Christ for his brethren's sake, his kinsmen according to the flesh who were Israelites.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:60
verses.text: If then Paul can desire to perish that the lost may not be lost, how much should good parents not provoke their children to wrath or by too great severity embitter those who are naturally mild.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:62
verses.text: The limits of a letter compel me to restrain myself; otherwise, indignation would make me diffuse.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:63
verses.text: In an epistle which its writer regards as conciliatory but which to me appears full of malice my opponent admits that I have never calumniated him or accused him of heresy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:64
verses.text: Why then does he calumniate me by spreading a rumour that I am infected with that awful malady and am in revolt against the Church? Why is he so ready to spare his real assailants and so eager to injure me who have done nothing to injure him? Before my brother's ordination he said nothing of any dogmatic difference between himself and pope Epiphanius.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:65
verses.text: What then can have "forced" him—I use his own word—publicly to argue a point which no one had yet raised? One so full of wisdom as you knows well the danger of such discussions and that silence is in such cases the safest course; except, indeed, on some occasion which renders it imperative to deal with great matters.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:66
verses.text: What ability and eloquence it must have needed to compress into a single sermon—as he boasts to have done—all the topics which the most learned writers have treated in detail in voluminous treatises! But this is nothing to me: it is for the hearers of the sermon to notice and for the writer of the letter to realize.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:67
verses.text: But as for me he ought of his own accord to acquit me of bringing the charge against him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:68
verses.text: I was not present and did not hear the sermon.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:69
verses.text: I was only one of the many, indeed hardly one of them; for while others were crying out I held my peace.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:70
verses.text: Let us confront the accused and the accuser, and let us give credit to him whose services, life, and doctrine are seen to be the best.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:72
verses.text: You see, do you not, that I shut my eyes to many things and touch upon others only in the most cursory manner, hinting at what I suppose rather than saying out what I think.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:73
verses.text: I understand and approve your manoeuvres; how in the interests of the peace of the Church you stop your ears when you come within range of the Sirens.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:74
verses.text: Moreover, trained as you have been from childhood in sacred studies, you know exactly what is meant by each expression which you use.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:75
verses.text: You knowingly employ ambiguous terms and carefully balanced sentences so as not to condemn others or repudiate us.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:76
verses.text: But it is not a pure faith and a frank confession which look for quibbles or circumlocutions.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:77
verses.text: What is simply believed must be professed with equal simplicity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:78
verses.text: For my part I could cry out—though it were amid the swords and fires of Babylon, "why does the answer evade the question? why is there no frank, straightforward declaration?" From beginning to end all is shrinking, compromise, ambiguity: as though he were trying to walk on spikes of corn.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:79
verses.text: His blood boils with eagerness for peace; yet he will not give a straightforward answer! others are free to insult him; for, when he is insulted, he does not venture to retaliate.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:80
verses.text: I meantime hold my peace: for the present I shall let it be thought that I am too busy, or ignorant, or afraid; for how would he treat me were I to accuse him, if when I praise him—as he admits himself that I do—he secretly traduces me?  6.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:81
verses.text: His whole letter is less an exposition of his faith than a mass of calumnies aimed at myself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:82
verses.text: Without any of those mutual courtesies which men may use towards each other without flattery, he takes up my name again and again, flouts it, and bandies it about as though I were blotted out of the book of the living.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:83
verses.text: He thinks that he has beaten me black and blue with his letter; and that I live for the trifles at which he aims, I who from my boyhood have been shut up in a monastic cell, and have always made it my aim to be rather than to seem a good man.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:84
verses.text: Some of us, it is true, he mentions with respect, but only that he may afterwards wound us more deeply.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:85
verses.text: As if, forsooth, we too have no open secrets to reveal! One of his charges is that we have allowed a slave to be ordained.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:86
verses.text: Yet he himself has clergymen of the same class, and he must have read of Onesimus who, being made regenerate by Paul in prison, from a slave became a deacon.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:87
verses.text: Then he throws out that the slave in question was a common informer; and, lest he should be compelled to prove the charge, declares he has it from hearsay only! Why, if I had chosen to repeat the talk of the crowd and to listen to scandal-mongers, he would have learned before now that I too know what all the world knows and have heard the same stories as other people.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:88
verses.text: He declares farther that ordination has been given to this slave as a reward for a slander spread abroad by him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:89
verses.text: Does not such cunning and subtlety appal one? And is there any answer to eloquence so overwhelming? Which is best, to spread a calumny or to suffer from one? To accuse a man whose love you may afterwards wish for, or to pardon a sinner? And is it more tolerable that a common informer should be made a consul than that he should be made an aedile? He knows what I pass over in silence and what I say; what I myself have heard and what—from the fear of Christ—I perhaps refuse to believe.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:91
verses.text: He charges me with having translated Origen into Latin.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:92
verses.text: In this I do not stand alone for the confessor Hilary has done the same, and we are both at one in this that while we have rendered all that is useful, we have cut away all that was harmful.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:93
verses.text: Let him read our versions for himself, if he knows how (and as he constantly converses and daily associates with Italians, I think he cannot be ignorant of Latin); or else, if he cannot quite take it in, let him use his interpreters and then he will come to know that I deserve nothing but praise for the work on which he grounds a charge against me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:94
verses.text: For, while I have always allowed to Origen his great merit as an interpreter and critic of the scriptures, I have invariably denied the truth of his doctrines.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:95
verses.text: Is it I then that let him loose upon the crowd? Is it I that act sponsor to other preachers like him? No, for I know that a difference must be made between the apostles and all other preachers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:96
verses.text: The former always speak the truth; but the latter being men sometimes go astray.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:97
verses.text: It would be a strange defence of Origen surely to admit his faults and then to excuse them by saying that other men have been guilty of similar ones! As if, when you cannot venture to defend a man openly, you may hope to shield him by imputing his mistake to a number of others! As for the six thousand volumes of Origen of which he speaks, it is impossible that any one should have read books which have never been written: and I for my part find it easier to suppose that this falsehood is due to the man who professes to have heard it rather than to him who is said to have told it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:99
verses.text: Again he avers that my brother is the cause of the disagreement which has arisen, a man who is content to stay in a monastic cell and who regards the clerical office as onerous rather than honourable.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:100
verses.text: And although up to this very day he has spoon-fed us with insincere protestations of peace, he has caused commotion in the minds of the western bishops by telling them that a mere youth, hardly more than a boy, has been ordained presbyter of Bethlehem in his own diocese.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:101
verses.text: If this is the truth, all the bishops of Palestine must be aware of it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:102
verses.text: For the monastery of the reverend pope Epiphanius—called the old monastery—where my brother was ordained presbyter is situated in the district of Eleutheropolis and not in that of aelia.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:103
verses.text: Furthermore his age is well known to your Holiness; and as he has now attained to thirty years I apprehend that no blame can attach to him on that score.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:104
verses.text: Indeed this particular age is stamped as full and complete by the mystery of Christ's assumed manhood.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:105
verses.text: Let him call to mind the ancient law, and he will see that after his twenty-fifth year a Levite might be chosen to the priesthood; or if in this passage he prefers to follow the Hebrew he will find that candidates for the priesthood must be thirty years old.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:106
verses.text: And that he may not venture to say that "old things are passed away; and, behold, all things are become new," let him hear the apostle's words to Timothy, "Let no man despise thy youth".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:107
verses.text: Certainly when my opponent was himself ordained bishop, he was not much older than my brother is now.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:108
verses.text: And if he argues that youth is no hindrance to a bishop but that it is to a presbyter because a young elder is a contradiction in terms, I ask him this question: Why has he himself ordained a presbyter of this age or younger still, and that too to minister in another man's church? But if he cannot be at peace with my brother unless he consents to submit and to renounce the bishop who has ordained him, he shews plainly that his object is not peace but revenge, and that he will not rest satisfied with the quietude of repose and peace unless he is able to inflict to the full every penalty that he now threatens.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:109
verses.text: Had he himself ordained my brother, it would have made no difference to this latter.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:110
verses.text: So dearly does he love seclusion that he would even then have continued to live quietly and would not have exercised his office.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:111
verses.text: And should the bishop have seen fit to rend the church on that score, he would then have owed him nothing save the respect which is due to all who offer sacrifice.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:113
verses.text: So much for his prolix defence of himself or I should rather say his attack on me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:114
verses.text: In this letter I have only answered him briefly and cursorily that from what I have said he may perceive what I do not say, and may know that as I am a human being I am a rational animal and well able to understand his shrewdness, and that I am not so obtuse or brutish as to catch only the sound of his words and not their meaning.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:115
verses.text: I now ask of you to pardon my chagrin and to allow that if it is arrogant to answer back, it is yet more arrogant to bring baseless charges.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:116
verses.text: Yet my answer has indicated what I might have said rather than has actually said it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:117
verses.text: Why do men look for peace at a distance? and why do they wish to have it enforced by word of command? Let them shew themselves peacemakers, and peace will follow at once.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:118
verses.text: Why do they use the name of your holiness to terrorize us, when your letter—strange contrast to their harsh and menacing words—breathes only peace and meekness? For that the letter which Isidore the presbyter has brought for me from you does make for peace and harmony I know by this, that these insincere professors of a wish for peace have refused to deliver it to me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:119
verses.text: Let them choose whichever alternative they please.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:120
verses.text: Either I am a good man or I am a bad one.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:121
verses.text: If I am a good one let them leave me in quiet: if I am a bad one, why do they desire to be in bad company? Surely my opponent has learnt by experience the value of humility.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:122
verses.text: He who now tears asunder things which, formerly separate, he of his own will put together, proves that in severing now what he then joined, he is acting at the instigation of another.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:124
verses.text: Recently he sought and obtained a decree of exile against me, and I only wish that he had been able to carry it out, so that, as the will is imputed to him for the deed, so I too not in will only but in deed might wear the crown of exile.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:125
verses.text: The church of Christ has been founded by shedding its own blood not that of others, by enduring outrage not by inflicting it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:126
verses.text: Persecutions have made it grow; martyrdoms have crowned it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:127
verses.text: Or if the Christians among whom I live are unique in their love of severity and know only how to persecute and not how to undergo persecution, there are Jews here, there are heretics professing various false doctrines, and in particular the foulest of all, I mean, Manichaeism.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:128
verses.text: Why is it that they do not venture to say a word against them? Why am I the only person they wish to drive into exile? Am I who communicate with the church the only person of whom it can be said that he rends the church? I put it to you, is it not a fair demand either that they should expel these others as well as myself, or that, if they keep them, they should keep me too? All the same they honour men by sending them into exile, for by so doing they separate them from the company of heretics.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:129
verses.text: It is a monk, shame to say, who menaces monks and obtains decrees of exile against them; and that too a monk who boasts that he holds an apostolic chair.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:130
verses.text: But the monastic tribe does not succumb to terrorism: it prefers to expose its neck to the impending sword rather than to allow its hands to be tied.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:131
verses.text: Is not every monk an exile from his country? Is he not an exile from the whole world? Where is the need for the public authority, the cost of a rescript, the journeyings up and down the earth to obtain one? Let him but touch me with his little finger, and I will go into exile of myself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:132
verses.text: "The earth is the Lord's and the fulness thereof".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:133
verses.text: Christ is not shut up in any one spot.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:135
verses.text: Moreover when he writes that, though I seem to be separated from communion with him, I in reality hold communion with him through you and through the church of Rome: he need not go so far afield, for I am connected with him in the same way also here in Palestine.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:136
verses.text: And lest even this should appear distant, in this village of Bethlehem I hold communion with his presbyters as much as I can.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:137
verses.text: Thus it is clear that a private chagrin is not to be taken for the cause of the church, and that one man's choler, or even that of several stirred up by him, ought not to be styled the displeasure of the church.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:138
verses.text: Accordingly I now repeat what I said at the beginning of my letter that I for my part am desirous of Christ's peace, that I pray for harmony, and that I request you to admonish him not to exact peace but to purpose it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:139
verses.text: Let him be satisfied with the pain which he has caused by the insults that he has inflicted upon me in the past.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:140
verses.text: Let him efface old wounds by a little new charity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:141
verses.text: Let him shew himself what he was before, when of his own choice he bestowed upon me his esteem.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:142
verses.text: Let his words no longer be tinged with a gall that flows from the heart of another.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:143
verses.text: Let him do what he wishes himself, and not what others force him to wish.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:144
verses.text: Either as a pontiff, let him exercise authority over all alike, or as a follower of the apostle, let him serve all for the salvation of all.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:145
verses.text: If he will shew himself such, I am ready freely to yield and to hold out my arms; he will find me a friend and a kinsman, and will perceive that in Christ I am submissive to him as to all the saints.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:146
verses.text: "Charity," writes the apostle, "suffereth long and is kind; charity envieth not;…is not puffed up…beareth all things, believeth all things".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:147
verses.text: Charity is the mother of all virtues, and the apostle's words about faith, hope and charity are like that threefold cord which is not quickly broken.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:148
verses.text: We believe, we hope, and through our faith and hope we are joined together in the bond of charity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:149
verses.text: It is for these virtues that I and others have left our homes, it is for these that we would live peaceably without any contention in the fields and alone; paying all due veneration to Christ's pontiffs—so long as they preach the right faith—not because we fear them as lords but because we honour them as fathers deferring also to bishops as bishops, but refusing to serve under compulsion, beneath the shadow of episcopal authority, men whom we do not choose to obey.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:150
verses.text: I am not so much puffed up in mind as not to know what is due to the priests of Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:151
verses.text: For he who receives them, receives not them but Him, whose bishops they are.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:152
verses.text: But let them be content with the honour which is theirs.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:153
verses.text: Let them know that they are fathers and not lords, especially in relation to those who scorn the ambitions of the world and count peace and repose the best of all things.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 82:154
verses.text: And may Christ who is Almighty God grant to your prayers that I and my opponent may be united not in a feigned and hollow peace but in true and sincere mutual esteem, lest biting and devouring one another we be consumed one of another.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 83:1
verses.text: Letter LXXXIII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 83:2
verses.text: From Pammachius and Oceanus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 83:3
verses.text: A letter from Pammachius and Oceanus in which they express the perplexity into which they have been thrown by Rufinus's version of Origen's treatise, On First Principles (see Letter LXXX.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 83:4
verses.text: ) and request Jerome to make for them a literal translation of the work.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 83:5
verses.text: Written in 399 or 400 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 83:6
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 83:8
verses.text: Pammachius and Oceanus to the presbyter Jerome, health.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 83:9
verses.text: A reverend brother has brought to us sheets containing a certain person's translation into Latin of a treatise by Origen—entitled περὶ ἀρχῶν.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 83:10
verses.text: These contain many things which disturb our poor wits and which appear to us to be uncatholic.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 83:11
verses.text: We suspect also that with a view of clearing the author many passages of his books have been removed which had they been left would have plainly proved the irreligious character of his teaching.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 83:12
verses.text: We therefore request your excellency to be so good as to bestow upon this particular matter an attention which will benefit not only ourselves but all who reside in the city; we ask you to publish in your own language the abovementioned book of Origen exactly as it was brought out by the author himself; and we desire you to make evident the interpolations which his defender has introduced.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 83:13
verses.text: You will also confute and overthrow all statements in the sheets which we have sent to your holiness that are ignorantly made or contradict the Catholic faith.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 83:14
verses.text: The writer in the preface to his work has, with much subtlety but without mentioning your holiness's name, implied that he has done no more than complete a work which you had yourself promised, thus indirectly suggesting that you agree with him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 83:15
verses.text: Remove then the suspicions men cannot help feeling and confute your assailant; for, if you ignore his implications, people will say that you admit their truth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:1
verses.text: Letter LXXXIV.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:2
verses.text: To Pammachius and Oceanus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:3
verses.text: A calm letter in which Jerome defines and justifies his own attitude towards Origen, but unduly minimizes his early enthusiasm for him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:4
verses.text: He admires him in the same way that Cyprian admired Tertullian but does not in any way adopt his errors.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:5
verses.text: He then describes his own studies and recounts his obligations to Apollinaris, Didymus, and a Jew named Bar-anina.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:6
verses.text: The rest of the letter deals with the errors of Origen, the state of the text of his writings, and the eulogy of him composed by the martyr Pamphilus (the authenticity of which Jerome assails without any sufficient reason).

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:7
verses.text: The date of the letter is 400 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:8
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:9
verses.text: Jerome to the brothers Pammachius and Oceanus, with all good wishes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:11
verses.text: The sheets that you send me cover me at once with compliments and confusion; for, while they praise my ability, they take away my sincerity in the faith.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:12
verses.text: But as both at Alexandria and at Rome and, I may say, throughout the whole world good men have made it a habit to take the same liberties with my name, esteeming me only so far that they cannot bear to be heretics without having me of the number, I will leave aside personalities and only answer specific charges.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:13
verses.text: For it is of no benefit to a cause to encounter railing with railing and to retaliate for attacks upon oneself by attacks upon one's opponents.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:14
verses.text: We are commanded not to return evil for evil but to overcome evil with good, to take our fill of insults, and to turn the other cheek to the smiter.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:16
verses.text: It is charged against me that I have sometimes praised Origen.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:17
verses.text: If I am not mistaken I have only done so in two places, in the short preface (addressed to Damasus) to his homilies on the Song of Songs and in the prologue to my book of Hebrew Names.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:18
verses.text: In these passages do the dogmas of the church come into question? Is anything said of the Father, the Son, and the Holy Ghost? or of the resurrection of the flesh? or of the condition and material of the soul? I have merely praised the simplicity of his rendering and commentary and neither the faith nor the dogmas of the Church come in at all.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:19
verses.text: Ethics only are dealt with and the mist of allegory is dispelled by a clear explanation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:20
verses.text: I have praised the commentator but not the theologian, the man of intellect but not the believer, the philosopher but not the apostle.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:21
verses.text: But if men wish to know my real judgement upon Origen; let them read my commentaries upon Ecclesiastes, let them go through my three books upon the epistle to the Ephesians: they will then see that I have always opposed his doctrines.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:22
verses.text: How foolish it would be to eulogize a system so far as to endorse its blasphemy! The blessed Cyprian takes Tertullian for his master, as his writings prove; yet, delighted as he is with the ability of this learned and zealous writer he does not join him in following Montanus and Maximilla.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:23
verses.text: Apollinaris is the author of a most weighty book against Porphyry, and Eusebius has composed a fine history of the Church; yet of these the former has mutilated Christ's incarnate humanity, while the latter is the most open champion of the Arian impiety.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:24
verses.text: "Woe," says Isaiah, "unto them that call evil good and good evil; that put bitter for sweet and sweet for bitter".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:25
verses.text: We must not detract from the virtues of our opponents—if they have any praiseworthy qualities—but neither must we praise the defects of our friends.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:26
verses.text: Each several case must be judged on its own merits and not by a reference to the persons concerned.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:27
verses.text: While Lucilius is rightly assailed by Horace for the unevenness of his verses, he is equally rightly praised for his wit and his charming style.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:29
verses.text: In my younger days I was carried away with a great passion for learning, yet I was not like some presumptuous enough to teach myself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:30
verses.text: At Antioch I frequently listened to Apollinaris of Laodicea, and attended his lectures; yet, although he instructed me in the holy scriptures, I never embraced his disputable doctrine as to their meaning.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:31
verses.text: At length my head became sprinkled with gray hairs so that I looked more like a master than a disciple.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:32
verses.text: Yet I went on to Alexandria and heard Didymus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:33
verses.text: And I have much to thank him for: for what I did not know I learned from him, and what I knew already I did not forget.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:34
verses.text: So excellent was his teaching.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:35
verses.text: Men fancied that I had now made an end of learning.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:36
verses.text: Yet once more I came to Jerusalem and to Bethlehem.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:37
verses.text: What trouble and expense it cost me to get Baraninas to teach me under cover of night.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:38
verses.text: For by his fear of the Jews he presented to me in his own person a second edition of Nicodemus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:39
verses.text: Of all of these I have frequently made mention in my works.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:40
verses.text: The doctrines of Apollinaris and of Didymus are mutually contradictory.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:41
verses.text: The squadrons of the two leaders must drag me in different directions, for I acknowledge both as my masters.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:42
verses.text: If it is expedient to hate any men and to loath any race, I have a strange dislike to those of the circumcision.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:43
verses.text: For up to the present day they persecute our Lord Jesus Christ in the synagogues of Satan.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:44
verses.text: Yet can anyone find fault with me for having had a Jew as a teacher? Does a certain person dare to bring forward against me the letter I wrote to Didymus calling him my master? It is a great crime, it would seem, for me a disciple to give to one both old and learned the name of master.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:45
verses.text: And yet when I ask leave to look at the letter which has been held over so long to discredit me at last, there is nothing in it but courteous language and a few words of greeting.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:46
verses.text: Such charges are both foolish and frivolous.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:47
verses.text: It would be more to the point to exhibit a passage in which I have defended heresy or praised some wicked doctrine of Origen.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:48
verses.text: In the portion of Isaiah which describes the crying of the two seraphim he explains these to be the Son and the Holy Ghost; but have not I altered this hateful explanation into a reference to the two testaments? I have the book in my hand as it was published twenty years ago.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:49
verses.text: In numbers of my works and especially in my commentaries I have, as occasion has offered, mangled this heathen school.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:50
verses.text: And if my opponents allege that I have done more than anyone else to form a collection of Origen's books, I answer that I only wish I could have the works of all theological writers that by diligent study of them, I might make up for the slowness of my own wits.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:51
verses.text: I have made a collection of his books, I admit; but because I know everything that he has written I do not follow his errors.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:52
verses.text: I speak as a Christian to Christians: believe one who has tried him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:53
verses.text: His doctrines are poisonous, they are unknown to the Holy Scriptures, nay more, they do them violence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:54
verses.text: I have read Origen, I repeat, I have read him; and if it is a crime to read him, I admit my guilt: indeed, these Alexandrian writings have emptied my purse.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:55
verses.text: If you will believe me, I have never been an Origenist: if you will not believe me, I have now ceased to be one.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:56
verses.text: But if even this fails to convince you, you will compel me in self-defence to write against your favourite, so that, if you will not believe me when I disclaim him, you will have to believe me when I attack him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:57
verses.text: But I find readier credence when I go wrong than when I shew amendment.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:58
verses.text: And this is not surprising, for my would-be friends suppose me a fellow-disciple with them in the arcana of their system.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:59
verses.text: I am loath, they fancy, to profess esoteric doctrines before persons who according to them are brute-like and made of clay.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:60
verses.text: For it is an axiom with them that pearls ought not to be lightly cast before swine, nor that which is holy given to the dogs.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:61
verses.text: They agree with David when he says: "Thy word have I hid in mine heart that I might not sin against thee;" and when in another place he describes the righteous man as one "who speaketh truth with his neighbour," that is with those who "are of the household of faith".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:62
verses.text: From these passages they conclude that those of us who as yet are uninitiated ought to be told falsehoods, lest, being still unweaned babes, we should be choked by too solid food.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:63
verses.text: Now that perjury and lying enter into their mysteries and form a bond between them appears most clearly from the sixth book of Origen's Miscellanies, in which he harmonizes the Christian doctrine with the conceptions of Plato.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:65
verses.text: What must I do then? deny that I am of Origen's opinion? They will not believe me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:66
verses.text: Swear that I am not? They will laugh and say that I deal in lies.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:67
verses.text: I will do the one thing which they dread.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:68
verses.text: I will bring forward their sacred rites and mysteries, and will expose the cunning whereby they delude simple folk like myself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:69
verses.text: Perhaps, although they refuse credence to my voice when I deny, they may believe my pen when I accuse.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:70
verses.text: Of one thing they are particularly apprehensive, and that is that their writings may some day be taken as evidence against their master.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:71
verses.text: They are ready to make statements on oath and to disclaim them afterwards with an oath as false as the first.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:72
verses.text: When asked for their signatures they use shifts and seek excuses.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:73
verses.text: One says: "I cannot condemn what no one else has condemned".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:74
verses.text: Another says: "No decision was arrived at on the point by the Fathers".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:75
verses.text: It is thus that they appeal to the judgment of the world to put off the necessity of assenting to a condemnation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:76
verses.text: Another says with yet more assurance: "how am I to condemn men whom the council of Nicaea has left untouched? For the council which condemned Arius would surely have condemned Origen too, had it disapproved of his doctrines".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:77
verses.text: They were bound in other words to cure all the diseases of the church at once and with one remedy; and by parity of reasoning we must deny the majesty of the Holy Ghost because nothing was said of his nature in that council.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:78
verses.text: But the question was of Arius, not of Origen; of the Son, not of the Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:79
verses.text: The bishops at the council proclaimed their adherence to a dogma which was at the time denied; they said nothing about a difficulty which no one had raised.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:80
verses.text: And yet they covertly struck at Origen as the source of the Arian heresy: for, in condemning those who deny the Son to be of the substance of the Father, they have condemned Origen as much as Arius.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:81
verses.text: On the ground taken by these persons we have no right to condemn Valentine, Marcion, or the Cataphrygians, or Manichaeus, none of whom are named by the council of Nicaea, and yet there is no doubt that in time they were prior to it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:82
verses.text: But when they find themselves pressed either to subscribe or to leave the Church, you may see some strange twisting.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:83
verses.text: They qualify their words, they arrange them anew, they use vague expressions; so as, if possible, to hold both our confession and that of our opponents, to be called indifferently heretics and Catholics.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:84
verses.text: As if it were not in the same spirit that the Delphian Apollo (or, as he is sometimes called, Loxias) gave his oracles to Croesus and to Pyrrhus; cheating with a similar device two men widely separated in time.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:85
verses.text: To make my meaning clear I will give a few examples.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:87
verses.text: We believe, say they, in the resurrection of the body.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:88
verses.text: This confession, if only it be sincere, is free from objection.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:89
verses.text: But as there are bodies celestial and bodies terrestrial and as thin air and the aether are both according to their natures called bodies, they use the word body instead of the word flesh in order that an orthodox person hearing them say body may take them to mean flesh while a heretic will understand that they mean spirit.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:90
verses.text: This is their first piece of craft, and if this is found out, they devise fresh wiles, and, pretending innocence themselves, accuse us of malice.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:91
verses.text: As though they were frank believers they say, "We believe in the resurrection of the flesh".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:92
verses.text: Now when they have said this, the ignorant crowd thinks it ought to be satisfied, particularly because these exact words are found in the creed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:93
verses.text: If you go on to question them farther, a buzz of disapproval is heard in the ring and their backers cry out: "You have heard them say that they believe in the resurrection of the flesh; what more do you want?" the popular favour is transferred from our side to theirs, and while they are called honest, we are looked on as false accusers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:94
verses.text: But if you set your face steadily and keeping a firm hold of their admission about the flesh, proceed to press them as to whether they assert the resurrection of that flesh which is visible and tangible, which walks and speaks, they first laugh and then signify their assent.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:95
