verses.text: And when we inquire whether the resurrection will exhibit anew the hair and the teeth, the chest and the stomach, the hands and the feet, and all the other members of the body, then no longer able to contain their mirth they burst out laughing and tell us that in that case we shall need barbers, and cakes, and doctors, and cobblers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:96
verses.text: Do we, they ask us in turn, believe that after the resurrection men's cheeks will still be rough and those of women smooth, and that sex will differentiate their bodies as it does at present? Then if we admit this, they at once deduce from our admission conclusions involving the grossest materialism.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:97
verses.text: Thus, while they maintain the resurrection of the body as a whole, they deny the resurrection of its separate members.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:99
verses.text: The present is not a time to speak rhetorically against a perverse doctrine.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:100
verses.text: Neither the rich vocabulary of Cicero nor the fervid eloquence of Demosthenes could adequately convey the warmth of my feeling, were I to attempt to expose the quibbles by which these heretics, while verbally professing a belief in the resurrection, in their hearts deny it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:101
verses.text: For their women finger their breasts, slap their chests, pinch their legs and arms, and say, "What will a resurrection profit us if these frail bodies are to rise again? No, if we are to be like angels, we shall have the bodies of angels".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:102
verses.text: That is to say they scorn to rise again with the flesh and bones wherewith even Christ rose.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:103
verses.text: Now suppose for a moment that in my youth I went astray and that, trained as I was in the schools of heathen philosophy, I was ignorant, in the beginning of my faith, of the dogmas of Christianity, and fancied that what I had read in Pythagoras and Plato and Empedocles was also contained in the writings of the apostle: Supposing, I say, that I believed all this, why do you yet follow the error of a mere babe and sucking child in Christ? Why do you learn irreligion of one who as yet knew not religion? After shipwreck one has still a plank to cling to; and one may atone for sin by a frank confession.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:104
verses.text: You have followed me when I have gone astray; follow me also now that I have been brought back.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:105
verses.text: In youth we have wandered; now that we are old let us mend our ways.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:106
verses.text: Let us unite our tears and our groans; let us weep together, and return to the Lord our Maker.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:107
verses.text: Let us not wait for the repentance of the devil; for this is a vain anticipation and one that will drag us into the deep of hell.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:108
verses.text: Life must be sought or lost here.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:109
verses.text: If I have never followed Origen, it is in vain that you seek to discredit me: if I have been his disciple, imitate my penitence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:110
verses.text: You have believed my confession; credit also my denial.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:112
verses.text: But it will be said, "If you knew these things, why did you praise him in your works?" I should praise him today but that you and men like you praise his errors.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:113
verses.text: I should still find his talent attractive, but that some people have been attracted by his impiety.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:114
verses.text: "Read all things," says the apostle, "hold fast that which is good".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:115
verses.text: Lactantius in his books and particularly in his letters to Demetrian altogether denies the subsistence of the Holy Spirit, and following the error of the Jews says that the passages in which he is spoken of refer to the Father or to the Son and that the words 'holy spirit' merely prove the holiness of these two persons in the Godhead.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:116
verses.text: But who can forbid me to read his Institutes—in which he has written against the Gentiles with much ability—simply because this opinion of his is to be abhorred? Apollinaris has written excellent treatises against Porphyry, and I approve of his labours, although I despise his doctrine in many points because of its foolishness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:117
verses.text: If you too for your parts will but admit that Origen errs in certain things I will not say another syllable.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:118
verses.text: Acknowledge that he thought amiss concerning the Son, and still more amiss concerning the Holy Spirit, point out the impiety of which he has been guilty in speaking of men's souls as having fallen from heaven, and shew that, while in word he asserts the resurrection of the flesh, he destroys the force of this language by other assertions.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:119
verses.text: As, for instance, that, after many ages and one "restitution of all things," it will be the same for Gabriel as for the devil, for Paul as for Caiaphas, for virgins as for prostitutes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:120
verses.text: When once you have rejected these misstatements and have parted them with your censor's wand from the faith of the Church, I may read what is left with safety, and having first taken the antidote need no longer dread the poison.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:121
verses.text: For instance it will do me no harm to say as I have said, "Whereas in his other books Origen has surpassed all other writers, in commenting on the Song of Songs he has surpassed himself"; nor will I fear to face the words with which formerly in my younger days I spoke of him as a doctor of the churches.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:122
verses.text: Will it be pretended, that I was bound to accuse a man whose works I was translating by special request? that I was bound to say in my preface, "This writer whose books I translate is a heretic: beware of him, reader, read him not, flee from the viper: or, if you are bent on reading him, know that the treatises which I have translated have been garbled by heretics and wicked men; yet you need not fear, for I have corrected all the places which they have corrupted," that in other words I ought to have said: "the writer that I translate is a heretic, but I, his translator, am a Catholic".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:123
verses.text: The fact is that you and your party in your anxiety to be straightforward, ingenuous, and honest, have paid too little regard to the precepts of rhetoric and to the devices of oratory.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:124
verses.text: For in admitting that his books On First Principles are heretical and in trying to lay the blame of this upon others, you raise difficulties for your readers; you induce them to examine the whole life of the author and to form a judgment on the question from the remainder of his writings.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:125
verses.text: I on the other hand have been wise enough to emend silently what I wished to emend: thus by ignoring the crime I have averted prejudice from the criminal.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:126
verses.text: Doctors tell us that serious maladies ought not to be subjected to treatment, but should be left to nature, lest the remedies applied should intensify the disease.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:127
verses.text: It is now almost one hundred and fifty years since Origen died at Tyre.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:128
verses.text: Yet what Latin writer has ever ventured to translate his books On the Resurrection and On First Principles, his Miscellanies and his Commentaries or as he himself calls them his Tomes? Who has ever cared by so infamous a work to cover himself with infamy? I am not more eloquent than Hilary or truer to the faith than Victorinus who both have rendered his Homiliesnot in exact versions but in independent paraphrases.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:129
verses.text: Recently also Ambrose appropriated his Six Days' Work, but in such a way that it expressed the views of Hippolytus and Basil rather than of Origen.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:130
verses.text: You profess to take me for your model, and blind as moles in relation to others you scan me with the eyes of gazelles.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:131
verses.text: Well, had I been ill-disposed towards Origen, I might have translated these very books so as to make his worst writings known to Latin readers; but this I have never done; and, though many have asked me, I have always refused.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:132
verses.text: For it has never been my habit to crow over the mistakes of men whose talents I admire.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:133
verses.text: Origen himself, were he still alive, would soon fall out with you his would-be patrons and would say with Jacob: "Ye have troubled me to make me to stink among the inhabitants of the land".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:135
verses.text: Does any one wish to praise Origen? Let him praise him as I do.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:136
verses.text: From his childhood he was a great man, and truly a martyr's son.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:137
verses.text: At Alexandria he presided over the school of the church, succeeding a man of great learning the presbyter Clement.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:138
verses.text: So greatly did he abhor sensuality that, out of a zeal for God but yet one not according to knowledge, he castrated himself with a knife.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:139
verses.text: Covetousness he trampled under foot.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:140
verses.text: He knew the scriptures by heart and laboured hard day and night to explain their meaning.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:141
verses.text: He delivered in church more than a thousand sermons, and published innumerable commentaries which he called tomes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:142
verses.text: These I now pass over, for it is not my purpose to catalogue his writings.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:143
verses.text: Which of us can read all that he has written? and who can fail to admire his enthusiasm for the scriptures? If some one in the spirit of Judas the Zealot brings up to me his mistakes, he shall have his answer in the words of Horace:  'Tis true that sometimes Homer sleeps, but then  He's not without excuse:  The fault is venial, for his work is long.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:144
verses.text: Let us not imitate the faults of one whose virtues we cannot equal.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:145
verses.text: Other men have erred concerning the faith, both Greeks and Latins, but I must not mention their names lest I should be supposed to defend Origen not by his own merits but by the errors of others.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:146
verses.text: This, you will say, is to accuse them and not to excuse him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:147
verses.text: You would be right, if I had declared him not to have erred, or if I had professed a belief that the apostle Paul or an angel from heaven ought to be listened to in a depravation of the faith.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:148
verses.text: But as it is seeing I frankly admit him to be wrong, I may read him on the same terms as I read others, because if he is wrong so also are they.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:149
verses.text: But you may say, If error is common to many, why do you assail him alone? I answer, because he alone is praised by you as an apostle.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:150
verses.text: Take away your exaggerated love for him, and I am ready to take away the greatness of my dislike.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:151
verses.text: While you gather other men's faulty statements out of their books merely to defend Origen in his error, you extol this latter to the sky and will not allow that he has erred at all.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:152
verses.text: Whosoever you are who are thus preaching new doctrines, I beseech you, spare the ears of the Romans, spare the faith of a church which an apostle has praised.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:153
verses.text: Why after four hundred years do you try to teach us Romans doctrines of which until now we have known nothing? Why do you publicly proclaim opinions which Peter and Paul refused to profess? Until now no such teaching has been heard of, and yet the world has become christian.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:154
verses.text: For my part I will hold fast in my old age the faith wherein I was born again in my boyhood.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:155
verses.text: They speak of us as claytowners, made out of dirt, brutish and carnal, because, say they, we refuse to receive the things of the spirit; but of course they themselves are citizens of Jerusalem and their mother is in heaven.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:156
verses.text: I do not despise the flesh in which Christ was born and rose again, or scorn the mud which, baked into a clean vessel, reigns in heaven.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:157
verses.text: And yet I wonder why they who detract from the flesh live after the flesh, and cherish and delicately nurture that which is their enemy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:158
verses.text: Perhaps indeed they wish to fulfil the words of scripture: "love your enemies and bless them that persecute you".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:159
verses.text: I love the flesh, but I love it only when it is chaste, when it is virginal, when it is mortified by fasting: I love not its works but itself, that flesh which knows that it must be judged, and therefore dies as a martyr for Christ, which is scourged and torn asunder and burned with fire.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:161
verses.text: The folly also of their contention that certain heretics and ill-disposed persons have tampered with Origen's writings may be shewn thus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:162
verses.text: Could any person be more wise, more learned, or more eloquent than were Eusebius and Didymus, Origen's supporters? Of these the former in the six volumes of his Apologyasserts that Origen is of the same mind with himself; while the latter, though he tries to excuse his errors, admits that he has made them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:163
verses.text: Not being able to deny what he finds written, he endeavours to explain it away.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:164
verses.text: It is one thing to say that additions have been made by heretics, but another to maintain that heretical statements are commendable.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:165
verses.text: Origen's case would be unique if his writings were falsified all over the world and if in one day by an edict like that of Mithridates all the truth were shorn from his volumes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:166
verses.text: Even supposing that some one treatise of his has been tampered with, can it be possible that all his works, published as they were at different times and places, have been corrupted? Origen himself in a letter written to Fabian, bishop of Rome, expresses penitence for having made erroneous statements, and charges Ambrose with over haste in making public what was meant only for private circulation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:167
verses.text: And yet to this day his disciples search for shifts to prove that all that excites disapprobation in his writings is due not to him but to others.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:169
verses.text: Moreover, when they speak of Pamphilus as one who praised Origen, I am personally much obliged to them for accounting me worthy to be calumniated with that martyr.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:170
verses.text: For if, sirs, you tell me that Origen's books have been tampered with by his enemies to bring them into discredit; why may not I in my turn allege that his friends and followers have attributed to Pamphilus a volume composed by themselves to vindicate their master from disrepute by the testimony of a martyr? Lo and behold, you yourselves correct in Origen's books passages which (according to you) he never wrote: and yet you are surprised if a man is said to have published a book which as a matter of fact he did not publish.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:171
verses.text: But while your statements can easily be brought to the test by an appeal to Origen's published works; as Pamphilus has published nothing else, it is easier for calumny to fix a book upon him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:172
verses.text: For shew me any other work of Pamphilus; you will nowhere find any, this is his only one.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:173
verses.text: How then can I know that it is by Pamphilus? You will tell me, that the style and tone ought to inform me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:174
verses.text: Well, I shall never believe that a man so learned has dedicated the first fruits of his talent to defend doubtful and discredited positions.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:175
verses.text: The very name of an apology which the treatise bears implies a previous charge made; for nothing is defended that is not first attacked.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:176
verses.text: I will now bring forward but a single argument, one, however, the force of which only folly and effrontery can deny.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:177
verses.text: The treatise attributed to Pamphilus contains nearly the first thousand lines of Eusebius's sixth book in defence of Origen.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:178
verses.text: Yet in the remaining parts of his work the writer brings forward passages by which he seeks to prove that Origen was a Catholic.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:179
verses.text: Now Eusebius and Pamphilus were in such thorough harmony with each other that they seemed to have but one soul between them, and one even went so far as to adopt the other's name.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:180
verses.text: How then could they have disagreed so fundamentally on this point, Eusebius in all his works proving Origen to be an Arian, and Pamphilus describing him as a supporter of the Nicene council, which had not yet been held? It is evident from this consideration that the book belongs not to Pamphilus but to Didymus or somebody else, who having cut off the head of Eusebius's sixth book supplied the other members himself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:181
verses.text: But I am willing to be generous and to allow that the book is written by Pamphilus, only by Pamphilus not yet a martyr.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:182
verses.text: For he must have written the book before he underwent martyrdom.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:183
verses.text: And why, you will say, was he accounted worthy of martyrdom? Surely that he might efface his error by a martyr's death, and wash away his one fault by shedding his blood.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:184
verses.text: How many martyrs there have been all the world over who before their deaths have been the slaves of sins! Are we then to palliate the sins because those who committed them have afterwards become martyrs?  11.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:185
verses.text: This reply to your letter, my most loving brothers, I have dictated in all haste; and, overcoming my scruples, I have taken up my pen against a man whose ability I once eulogized.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:186
verses.text: I would sooner, indeed, risk my reputation than my faith.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:187
verses.text: My friends have placed me in the awkward dilemma that if I say nothing I shall be held guilty, and if I offer a defence I shall be accounted an enemy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:188
verses.text: Both alternatives are hard; but of the two I will choose that which is the least so.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:189
verses.text: A quarrel can be made up, but blasphemy can find no forgiveness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 84:190
verses.text: I leave to your judgment to discover how much labour I have expended in translating the books On First Principles; for on the one hand if one alters anything from the Greek the work becomes less a version than a perversion; and on the other hand a literal adherence to the original by no means tends to preserve the charm of its eloquence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 85:1
verses.text: Letter LXXXV.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 85:2
verses.text: To Paulinus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 85:3
verses.text: Paulinus had asked Jerome two questions, (1) how can certain passages of scripture (Exod.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 85:4
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 85:5
verses.text: 13; Rom.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 85:6
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 85:7
verses.text: 16) be reconciled with Free Will? and (2) Why are the children of believers said to be holy (1 Cor.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 85:8
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 85:9
verses.text: 14) apart from baptismal grace? For the first of these questions Jerome refers Paulinus to his version (newly made) of Origen's treatise, On First Principles.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 85:10
verses.text: For the second he quotes the explanation of Tertullian.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 85:11
verses.text: Written in 400 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 85:12
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 85:14
verses.text: Your words urge me to write to you but your eloquence deters me from doing so.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 85:15
verses.text: For as a letter-writer you are almost as good as Tully.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 85:16
verses.text: You complain that my letters are short and unpolished: this is not due to carelessness but to fear of you, lest writing to you at greater length I should but send you more sentences to find fault with.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 85:17
verses.text: Moreover, to make a clean breast of it to a good man like you, just about the time the vessels sail for the west, so many letters are demanded of me at once that, if I were to reply to all my correspondents, I should be unable to accomplish my task.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 85:18
verses.text: Hence it happens that, neglecting the niceties of composition and not revising the work of my secretaries, I dictate whatever first comes into my head.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 85:19
verses.text: Thus when I write to you I regard you as a friend and not as a critic.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 85:21
verses.text: Your letter propounds two questions, the first, why God hardened Pharaoh's heart, and why the apostle said: "So then it is not of him that willeth, nor of him that runneth, but of God that sheweth mercy;" and other things which appear to do away with free will: the second, how those are holy who are born of believing, that is, of baptized parents, seeing that without the gift of grace afterwards received and kept they cannot be saved.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 85:23
verses.text: Your first question is most ably answered by Origen in his treatise on First Principles which, at the request of my friend Pammachius, I have recently translated.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 85:24
verses.text: This task has occupied me so fully that I am unable to keep my word with you and must again postpone the sending my commentary on Daniel.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 85:25
verses.text: Indeed, distinguished and devoted to me as Pammachius is, had he been alone in his request, I should have deferred it to another time, but, as it was, almost all our brothers at Rome urged the same demand declaring that many persons were in danger, and that some even accepted Origen's heretical teaching.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 85:26
verses.text: I have found myself forced therefore to translate a book in which there is more of bad than of good, and to keep to this rule that I should neither add nor subtract but should preserve in Latin in its integrity the true sense of the Greek.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 85:27
verses.text: You will be able to borrow a copy of my version from the aforesaid brother, though in your case the Greek will serve quite as well; neither should you, who can drink from the fountain head, turn to the muddy streamlets supplied by my poor wits.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 85:29
verses.text: Moreover, as I am speaking to an educated man, well versed both in the sacred scriptures and in secular literature, I desire to give your excellency this note of warning.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 85:30
verses.text: Do not suppose that I am a clumsy buffoon who condemn everything that Origen has written,—as his injudicious friends falsely assert—or that I have changed my mind as suddenly as the philosopher Dionysius.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 85:31
verses.text: The fact is that I repudiate merely his objectionable dogmas.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 85:32
verses.text: For I know that one curse hangs over those who call evil good and over those who call good evil, over those who put bitter for sweet, and over those who put sweet for bitter.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 85:33
verses.text: Who would go so far in praise of another man's teaching as to acquiesce in blasphemy?  5.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 85:34
verses.text: Your second question is discussed by Tertullian in his books on Monogamywhere he declares that the children of believers are called holy because they are as it were candidates for the faith and have suffered no pollution from idolatry.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 85:35
verses.text: Consider also that the vessels of which we read in the tabernacle are called holy and everything else required for the ceremonial worship: although in strictness of speech there can be nothing holy except creatures which know of and worship God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 85:36
verses.text: But it is a scriptural usage sometimes to give the name of holy to those who are clean, or who have been purified, or who have made expiation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 85:37
verses.text: For instance, it is written of Bathsheba that she was made holy from her uncleanness, and the temple itself is called the holy place.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 85:39
verses.text: I beg that you will not silently in your mind accuse me either of vanity or of insincerity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 85:40
verses.text: God bears me witness in my conscience that the unavoidable circumstances mentioned above drew me back when I was just going to grapple with my commentary; and you know that what is done when the mind is pre-occupied is never well done.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 85:41
verses.text: I gladly accept the cap that you have sent me, a mark, though small, of no small affection and just the thing to keep an old man's head warm.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 85:42
verses.text: I am delighted alike with the gift and with the giver.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 86:1
verses.text: Letter LXXXVI.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 86:2
verses.text: To Theophilus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 86:3
verses.text: Jerome congratulates Theophilus on the success of his crusade against Origenism, and speaks of the good work done in Palestine by his emissaries Priscus and E.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 87:1
verses.text: ubulus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 87:2
verses.text: He then (by a singular change in his sentiments) asks Theophilus to forgive John of Jerusalem for having unwittingly received an excommunicated Egyptian.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 87:3
verses.text: The date of the Letter is 400 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 87:4
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 87:5
verses.text: Jerome to the most blessed Pope Theophilus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 87:6
verses.text: I have recently received despatches from your blessedness setting right your long silence and summoning me to return to my duty.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 87:7
verses.text: So, though the reverend brothers Priscus and Eubulus have been slow in bringing me your letters, yet, as they are now hastening in the ardour of faith from end to end of Palestine and scattering and driving into their holes the basilisks of heresy, I write a few lines to congratulate you on your success.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 87:8
verses.text: The whole world glories in your victories.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 87:9
verses.text: An exultant crowd of all nations gazes on the standard of the cross raised by you at Alexandria and upon the shining trophies which mark your triumph over heresy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 87:10
verses.text: Blessings on your courage! blessings on your zeal! You have shewn that your long silence has been due to policy and not to inclination.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 87:11
verses.text: I speak quite openly to your reverence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 87:12
verses.text: I grieved to find you too forbearing, and, knowing nothing of the course shaped by the pilot, I yearned for the destruction of those abandoned men.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 87:13
verses.text: But, as I now see, you have had your hand raised and, if you have delayed to strike, it has only been that you might strike harder.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 87:14
verses.text: As regards the welcome given to a certain person, you have no reason to be vexed with the prelate of this city; for as you gave no instructions on the point in your letter, it would have been rash in him to decide a case of which he knew nothing.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 87:15
verses.text: Still I think that he would neither wish nor venture to annoy you in any way.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 88:1
verses.text: Letter LXXXVII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 88:2
verses.text: From Theophilus to Jerome.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 88:3
verses.text: Theophilus informs Jerome that he has expelled the Origenists from the monasteries of Nitria, and urges him to shew his zeal for the faith by writing against the prevalent heresy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 88:4
verses.text: The date of the letter is 400 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 88:5
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 88:6
verses.text: Theophilus, bishop, to the well-beloved and most loving brother, the presbyter Jerome.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 88:7
verses.text: The reverend bishop Agatho with the well-beloved deacon Athanasius is accredited to you with tidings relating to the church.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 88:8
verses.text: When you learn their import I feel no doubt but that you will approve my resolution and will exult in the church's victory.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 88:9
verses.text: For we have cut down with the prophet's sickle certain wicked fanatics who were eager to sow broadcast in the monasteries of Nitria the heresy of Origen.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 88:10
verses.text: We have remembered the warning words of the apostle, "rebuke with all authority".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 88:11
verses.text: Do you therefore on your part, as you hope to receive a share in this reward, make haste to bring back with scriptural discourses those who have been deceived.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 88:12
verses.text: It is our desire, if possible, to guard in our days not only the Catholic faith and the rules of the church, but the people committed to our charge, and to give a quietus to all strange doctrines.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 89:1
verses.text: Letter LXXXVIII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 89:2
verses.text: To Theophilus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 89:3
verses.text: Replying to the preceding letter Jerome again congratulates Theophilus on the success of his efforts to put down Origenism, and informs him that they have already borne fruit as far west as Italy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 89:4
verses.text: He then asks him for the decrees of his council (held recently at Alexandria).

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 89:5
verses.text: The date of the letter is 400 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 89:6
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 89:7
verses.text: Jerome to the most blessed pope Theophilus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 89:8
verses.text: The letter of your holiness has given me a twofold pleasure, partly because it has had for its bearers those reverend and estimable men, the bishop Agatho and the deacon Athanasius, and partly because it has shewn your zeal for the faith against a most wicked heresy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 89:9
verses.text: The voice of your holiness has rung throughout the world, and to the joy of all Christ's churches the poisonous suggestions of the devil have been silenced.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 89:10
verses.text: The old serpent hisses no longer, but, writhing and disembowelled, lurks in dark caverns unable to bear the shining of the sun.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 89:11
verses.text: I have already, before the writing of your letter, sent missives to the West pointing out to those of my own language some of the quibbles employed by the heretics.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 89:12
verses.text: I hold it due to the special providence of God that you should have written to the pope Anastasius at the same time as myself, and should thus without knowing it have been the means of confirming my testimony.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 89:13
verses.text: Now that you have directly urged me to do so, I shall shew myself more zealous than ever to recall from their error simple souls both near and far.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 89:14
verses.text: Nor shall I hesitate, if needful, to incur odium with some, for we ought to please God rather than men: although indeed they have been much more forward to defend their heresy than I and others have been to attack it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 89:15
verses.text: At the same time I beg that if you have any synodical decrees bearing upon the subject you will forward them to me, that, strengthened with the authority of so great a prelate, I may open my mouth for Christ with more freedom and confidence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 89:16
verses.text: The presbyter Vincent has arrived from Rome two days ago and humbly salutes you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 89:17
verses.text: He tells me again and again that Rome and almost the whole of Italy owe their deliverance after Christ to your letters.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 89:18
verses.text: Shew diligence therefore, most loving and most blessed pope, and whenever opportunity offers write to the bishops of the West not to hesitate—in your own words—to cut down with a sharp sickle the sprouts of evil.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 90:1
verses.text: Letter LXXXIX.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 90:2
verses.text: From Theophilus to Jerome.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 90:3
verses.text: This letter (probably earlier in date than the three preceding) commends to Jerome the monk Theodore, who, having come from Rome to declare the condemnation of Origenism by the church there, had visited the monasteries of Nitria now purged of heresy, and wished before returning to the West to see the Holy Places as well.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 90:4
verses.text: The date of the letter is 400 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 90:5
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 90:6
verses.text: Theophilus, bishop, to the well-beloved lord and most loving brother the presbyter Jerome.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 90:7
verses.text: I have learned the project of the monk Theodore—which will be known also to your holiness—and I approve of it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 90:8
verses.text: Having to leave us on a voyage for Rome, he has been unwilling to set out without first visiting and embracing as his own flesh and blood you and the reverend brothers who are with you in the monastery.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 90:9
verses.text: You will, I am sure, rejoice in the news with which he will meet your welcome, that quiet has been restored to the church here.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 90:10
verses.text: He has seen all the monasteries of Nitria and can tell you of the continence and meekness of the monks in them; as also how the Origenists have been put down and scattered, how peace has been restored to the church, and how the discipline of the Lord is being upheld.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 90:11
verses.text: How gladly would I see the mask of hypocrisy laid aside by those also who near you are said to be undermining the truth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 90:12
verses.text: I feel obliged to write thus because the brothers in your neighbourhood are mistaken concerning them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 90:13
verses.text: Wherefore take heed to yourselves and shun men of this type; even as it is written:—"if any man bring not to you the faith of the church, bid him not God speed".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 90:14
verses.text: It may, indeed, be superfluous to write thus to you who can recall the erring from their error, yet no harm is done when those careful for the faith admonish even the wise and learned.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 90:15
verses.text: Kindly salute in my name all the brothers who are with you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 91:1
verses.text: Letter XC.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 91:2
verses.text: From Theophilus to Epiphanius.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 91:3
verses.text: Theophilus writes to Epiphanius to convoke a council in Cyprus for the condemnation of Origenism and asks him to transmit to Constantinople by a trustworthy messenger a copy of its decrees together with the synodical letter of Theophilus himself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 91:4
verses.text: His anxiety about this last point is caused by the news that certain of the excommunicated monks have set sail for Constantinople to lay their case before the bishop, John Chrysostom.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 91:5
verses.text: The date of the letter is 400 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 91:6
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 91:7
verses.text: Theophilus to his well-beloved lord, brother, and fellow-bishop Epiphanius.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 91:8
verses.text: The Lord has said to his prophet "See, I have this day set thee over the nations and over the kingdoms to root out and to pull down and to destroy and…to build and to plant".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 91:9
verses.text: In every age he bestows the same grace upon his church, that His Body may be preserved intact and that the poison of heretical opinions may nowhere prevail over it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 91:10
verses.text: And now also do we see the words fulfilled.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 91:11
verses.text: For the church of Christ "not having spot or wrinkle or any such thing" has with the sword of the gospel cut down the Origenist serpents crawling out of their caves, and has delivered from their deadly contagion the fruitful host of the monks of Nitria.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 91:12
verses.text: I have compressed a short account of my proceedings (it was all that time would allow) into the general letter which I have addressed indiscriminately to all.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 91:13
verses.text: As your excellency has often fought in contests of the kind before me, it is your present duty to strengthen the hands of those who are in the field and to gather together to this end the bishops of your entire island.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 91:14
verses.text: A synodical letter should be sent to myself and the bishop of Constantinople and to any others whom you think fit; that by universal consent Origen himself may be expressly condemned and also the infamous heresy of which he was the author.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 91:15
verses.text: I have learned that certain calumniators of the true faith, named Ammonius, Eusebius, and Euthymius, filled with a fresh access of enthusiasm in behalf of the heresy, have taken ship for Constantinople, to ensnare with their deceits as many new converts as they can and to confer anew with the old companions of their impiety.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 91:16
verses.text: Let it be your care, therefore, to set forth the course of the matter to all the bishops throughout Isauria and Pamphylia and the rest of the neighbouring provinces: moreover, if you think fit, you can add my letter, so that all of us gathered together in one spirit with the power of our Lord Jesus Christ may deliver these men unto Satan for the destruction of the impiety which possesses them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 91:17
verses.text: And to ensure the speedy arrival of my despatches at Constantinople, send a diligent messenger, one of the clergy (as I send fathers from the monasteries of Nitria with others also of the monks, learned men and continent) that when they arrive they may be able themselves to relate what has been done.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 91:18
verses.text: Above all I beg of you to offer up earnest prayers to the Lord that we may be able in this contest also to gain the victory; for no small joy has filled the hearts of the people both in Alexandria and throughout all Egypt, because a few men have been expelled from the Church that the body of it might be kept pure.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 91:19
verses.text: Salute the brothers who are with you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 91:20
verses.text: The people with us salute you in the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 92:1
verses.text: Letter XCI.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 92:2
verses.text: From Epiphanius to Jerome.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 92:3
verses.text: An exultant letter from Epiphanius in which he describes the success of his council (convened at the suggestion of Theophilus), sends Jerome a copy of its synodical letter.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 92:4
verses.text: and urges him to go on with his work of translating into Latin documents bearing on the Origenistic controversy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 92:5
verses.text: Written in 400 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 92:6
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 92:7
verses.text: To his most loving lord, son, and brother, the presbyter Jerome, Epiphanius sends greeting in the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 92:8
verses.text: The general epistle written to all Catholics belongs particularly to you; for you, having a zeal for the faith against all heresies, particularly oppose the disciples of Origen and of Apollinaris whose poisoned roots and deeply planted impiety almighty God has dragged forth into our midst, that having been unearthed at Alexandria they might wither throughout the world.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 92:9
verses.text: For know, my beloved son, that Amalek has been destroyed root and branch and that the trophy of the cross has been set up on the hill of Rephidim.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 92:10
verses.text: For as when the hands of Moses were held up on high Israel prevailed, so the Lord has strengthened His servant Theophilus to plant His standard against Origen on the altar of the church of Alexandria; that in him might be fulfilled the words: "Write this for a memorial, for I will utterly put out Origen's heresy from under heaven together with that Amalek himself".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 92:11
verses.text: And that I may not appear to be repeating the same things over and over and thus to be making my letter tedious, I send you the actual missive written to me that you may know what Theophilus has said to me, and what a great blessing the Lord has granted to my last days in approving the principles which I have always proclaimed by the testimony of so great a prelate.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 92:12
verses.text: I fancy that by this time you also have published something and that, as I suggested in my former letter to you on this subject, you have elaborated a treatise for readers of your own language.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 92:13
verses.text: For I hear that certain of those who have made shipwreck have come also to the West, and that, not content with their own destruction, they desire to involve others in death with them; as if they thought that the multitude of sinners lessens the guilt of sin and the flames of Gehenna do not grow in size in proportion as more logs are heaped upon them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 92:14
verses.text: With you and by you we send our best greetings to the reverend brothers who are with you in the monastery serving God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 93:1
verses.text: Letter XCII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 93:2
verses.text: The Synodical Letter of Theophilus to the Bishops of Palestine and of Cyprus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 93:3
verses.text: The synodical letter of the council held at Alexandria in 400 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 93:4
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 93:5
verses.text: to condemn Origenism.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 93:6
verses.text: Written originally in Greek it was translated into Latin by Jerome.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 93:7
verses.text: This letter has been sent in identical terms to the Bishops of Palestine and to those of Cyprus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 93:8
verses.text: We reproduce the headings of both copies.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 93:9
verses.text: That to the Bishops of Palestine commences thus: To the well-beloved lords, brothers, and fellow-bishops, Eulogius, John, Zebianus, Auxentius, Dionysius, Gennadius, Zeno, Theodosius, Dicterius, Porphyry, Saturninus, Alan, Paul, Ammonius, Helianus, Eusebius, the other Paul, and to all the Catholic bishops gathered together at the dedication festival of aelid, Theophilus [sends] greeting in the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 93:10
verses.text: The Cyprians he addresses thus: To the well-beloved lords, brothers, and fellow-bishops, Epiphanius, Marcianus, Agapetus, Boethius, Helpidius, Entasius, Norbanus, Macedonius.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 93:11
verses.text: Aristo, Zeno, Asiaticus, Heraclides, the other Zeno, Cyriacus, and Aphroditus, Theophilus [sends] greeting in the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 93:12
verses.text: The scope of the letter is as follows:  We have personally visited the monasteries of Nitria and find that the Origenistic heresy has made great ravages among them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 93:13
verses.text: It is accompanied by a strange fanaticism: men even maim themselves or cut out their tongues to show how they despise the body.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 93:14
verses.text: I find that some men of this kind have gone from Egypt into Syria and other countries where they speak against us and the truth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 93:15
verses.text: The books of Origen have been read before a council of bishops and unanimously condemned.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 93:16
verses.text: The following are his chief errors, mainly found in the περὶ ᾽Αρχῶν.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 93:18
verses.text: The Son compared with us is truth, but compared with the Father he is falsehood.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 93:20
verses.text: Christ's kingdom will one day come to an end.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 93:22
verses.text: We ought to pray to the Father alone, not to the Son.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 93:24
verses.text: Our bodies after the resurrection will be corruptible and mortal.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 93:26
verses.text: There is nothing perfect even in heaven; the angels themselves are faulty, and some of them feed on the Jewish sacrifices.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 93:28
verses.text: The stars are conscious of their own movements, and the demons know the future by their courses.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 93:30
verses.text: Magic, if real, is not evil.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 93:32
verses.text: Christ suffered once for men; he will suffer again for the demons.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 93:33
verses.text: The Origenists have tried to coerce me; they have even stirred up the heathen by denouncing the destruction of the Serapeum; and have sought to withdraw from the ecclesiastical jurisdiction two persons accused of grave crimes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 93:34
verses.text: One of these is the woman who was wrongly placed on the list of widows by Isidore, the other Isidore himself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 93:35
verses.text: He is the standard-bearer of the heretical faction, and his wealth supplies them with unbounded resources for their violent enterprises.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 93:36
verses.text: They have tried to murder me; they seized the monastery church at Nitria, and for a time prevented the bishops from entering and the offices from being performed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 93:37
verses.text: Now, like Zebul (Beelzebub) they go to and fro on the earth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 93:38
verses.text: I have done them no harm; I have even protected them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 93:39
verses.text: But I would not let an old friendship (with Isidore) impair our faith and discipline.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 93:40
verses.text: I implore you to oppose them wherever they come, and to prevent them from unsettling the brethren committed to you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 94:1
verses.text: Letter XCIII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 94:2
verses.text: From the Bishops of Palestine to Theophilus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 94:3
verses.text: The synodical letter of the council of Jerusalem sent to Theophilus in reply to the preceding.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 94:4
verses.text: The translation as before is due to Jerome.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 94:5
verses.text: The following is an epitome: We have done all that you wished, and Palestine is almost wholly free from the taint of heresy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 94:6
verses.text: We wish that not only the Origenists, but Jews, Samaritans and heathen also, could be put down.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 94:7
verses.text: Origenism does not exist among us.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 94:8
verses.text: The doctrines you describe are never heard here.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 94:9
verses.text: We anathematize those who hold such doctrines, and also those of Apollinaris, and shall not receive anyone whom you excommunicate.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 95:1
verses.text: Letter XCIV.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 95:2
verses.text: From Dionysius to Theophilus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 95:3
verses.text: In this letter (translated into Latin by Jerome) Dionysius, bishop of Lydda, praises Theophilus for his signal victories over Origenism and urges him to continue his efforts against that heresy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 95:4
verses.text: Written in 400 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 95:5
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 96:1
verses.text: Letter XCV.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 96:2
verses.text: From Pope Anastasius to Simplicianus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 96:3
verses.text: At the request of Theophilus Anastasius, bishop of Rome, writes to Simplicianus, bishop of Milan, to inform him that he, like Theophilus, has condemned Origen whose blasphemies have been brought under his notice by Eusebius of Cremona.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 96:4
verses.text: This latter had shown him a copy of the version by Rufinus of the treatise On First Principles.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 96:5
verses.text: The date of the letter is 400 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 96:6
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 96:7
verses.text: To his lord and brother Simplicianus, Anastasius.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 96:9
verses.text: It is felt right that a shepherd should bestow great care and watchfulness upon his flock.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 96:10
verses.text: In like manner too from his lofty tower the careful watchman keeps a lookout day and night on behalf of the city.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 96:11
verses.text: So also in the hour of tempest when the sea is dangerous the shipmaster suffers keen anxiety lest the gale and the violence of the waves shall dash his vessel upon the rocks.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 96:12
verses.text: It is with similar feelings that the reverend and honourable Theophilus our brother and fellow-bishop, ceases not to watch over the things that make for salvation, that God's people in the different churches may not by reading Origen run into awful blasphemies.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 96:14
verses.text: Being informed, then, by a letter of the aforesaid bishop, we inform your holiness that we in like manner who are set in the city of Rome in which the prince of the apostles, the glorious Peter, first founded the church and then by his faith strengthened it; to the end that no man may contrary to the commandment read these books which we have mentioned, have condemned the same; and have with earnest prayers urged the strict observance of the precepts which God and Christ have inspired the evangelists to teach.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 96:15
verses.text: We have charged men to remember the words of the venerable apostle Paul, prophetic and full of warning:—"if any than preach any other gospel unto you than that which we have preached unto you, let him be accursed".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 96:16
verses.text: Holding fast, therefore, this precept, we have intimated that everything written in days gone by Origen that is contrary to our faith is even by us rejected and condemned.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 96:18
verses.text: I send this letter to your holiness by the hand of the presbyter Eusebius, a man filled with a glowing faith and love for the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 96:19
verses.text: He has shewn to me some blasphemous chapters which made me shudder as I passed judgement on them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 96:20
verses.text: If Origen has put forth any other writings, you are to know that they and their author are alike condemned by me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 96:21
verses.text: The Lord have you in safe keeping, my lord and brother deservedly held in honour.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 97:1
verses.text: Letter XCVI.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 97:2
verses.text: From Theophilus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 97:3
verses.text: A translation by Jerome of Theophilus's paschal letter for the year 401 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 97:4
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 97:5
verses.text: In it Theophilus refutes at length the heresies of Apollinaris and Origen.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 98:1
verses.text: Letter XCVII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 98:2
verses.text: To Pammachius and Marcella.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 98:3
verses.text: With this letter Jerome sends to Pammachius and Marcella a translation of the paschal letter issued by Theophilus for the year 402 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 98:4
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 98:5
verses.text: together with the Greek original.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 98:6
verses.text: He takes the precaution of sending this latter because in the preceding year complaints have been made that his translation was not accurate.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 98:7
verses.text: Written in 402 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 98:8
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 98:10
verses.text: Once more with the return of spring I enrich you with the wares of the east and send the treasures of Alexandria to Rome: as it is written, "God shall come from the south and the Holy One from Mount Paran, even a thick shadow".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 98:11
verses.text: (Hence in the Song of Songs the joyous cry of the bride: "I sat down under his shadow with great delight and his fruit was sweet to my taste".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 98:12
verses.text: ) Now truly is Isaiah's prophecy fulfilled: "In that day shall there be an altar to the Lord in the land of Egypt".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 98:13
verses.text: "Where sin hath abounded, grace doth much more abound".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 98:14
verses.text: They who fostered the infant Christ now with glowing faith defend Him in His manhood; and they who once saved Him from the hands of Herod are ready to save Him again from this blasphemer and heretic.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 98:15
verses.text: Demetrius expelled Origen from the city of Alexander; but he is now thanks to Theophilus outlawed from the whole world.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 98:16
verses.text: Like him to whom Luke has dedicated the Acts of the Apostles this bishop derives his name from his love to God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 98:17
verses.text: Where now is the wriggling serpent? In what plight does the venomous viper find himself? His is  A human face with wolfish body joined.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 98:18
verses.text: Where now is that heresy which crawled hissing through the world and boasted that both the bishop Theophilus and I were partisans of its errors? Where now is the yelping of those shameless hounds who, to win over the simple minded, falsely proclaimed our adherence to their cause? Crushed by the authority and eloquence of Theophilus they are now like demon-spirits only able to mutter and that from out of the earth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 98:19
verses.text: For they know nothing of Him who, as He comes from above, speaks only of the things that are above.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 98:21
verses.text: Would that this generation of vipers would either honestly accept our doctrines, or else consistently defend its own; that we might know whom we are to esteem and whom we are to shun.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 98:22
verses.text: As it is they have invented a new kind of penitence, hating us as enemies though they dare not deny our faith.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 98:23
verses.text: What, I ask, is this chagrin of theirs which neither time nor reason seems able to cure? When swords flash in battle and men fall and blood flows in streams, hostile hands are often clasped in amity and the fury of war is exchanged for an unexpected peace.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 98:24
verses.text: The partisans of this heresy alone can make no terms with churchmen; for they repudiate mentally the verbal assent that is extorted from them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 98:25
verses.text: When their open blasphemy is made plain to the public ear, and when they perceive their hearers clamouring against them; then they assume an air of simplicity, declaring that they hear such doctrines for the first time and that they have no previous knowledge of them as taught by their master.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 98:26
verses.text: And when you hold their writings in your hand, they deny with their lips what their hands have written.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 98:27
verses.text: Why, sirs, need you beset the Propontis, shift your abode, wander through different countries, and rend with foaming mouths a distinguished prelate of Christ and his followers? If your recantations are sincere, you should replace your former zeal for error with an equal zeal for the faith.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 98:28
verses.text: Why do you patch together from this quarter and from that these rags of cursing? And why do you rail at the lives of men whose faith you cannot resist? Do you cease to be heretics because according to you sundry persons believe us to be sinners? And does impiety cease to disfigure your lips because you can point to scars on our ears? So long as you have a leopard's spots and an Ethiopian's skin, how can it help your perfidy to know that I too am marked by moles? See, Pope Theophilus is freely allowed to prove Origen a heretic; and the disciples do not defend the master's words.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 98:29
verses.text: They merely pretend that they have been altered by heretics and tampered with, like the works of many other writers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 98:30
verses.text: Thus they seek to maintain his cause not by their own belief but by other people's errors.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 98:31
verses.text: So much I would say against heretics who in the fury of their unjust hostility to us betray the secret feelings of their minds and prove the incurable nature of the wound that rankles in their breasts.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 98:33
verses.text: But you are Christians and the lights of the senate: accept therefore from me the letter which I append.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 98:34
verses.text: This year I send it both in Greek and Latin that the heretics may not again lyingly assert that I have made many changes in and additions to the original.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 98:35
verses.text: I have laboured hard, I must confess, to preserve the charm of the diction by a like elegance in my version: and keeping within fixed lines and never allowing myself to deviate from these I have done my best to maintain the smooth flow of the writer's eloquence and to render his remarks in the tone in which they are made.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 98:36
verses.text: Whether I have succeeded in these two objects or not I must leave to your judgement to determine.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 98:37
verses.text: As for the letter itself you are to know that it is divided into four parts.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 98:38
verses.text: In the first Theophilus exhorts believers to celebrate the Lord's passover; in the second he slays Apollinarius; in the third he demolishes Origen; while in the fourth and last he exhorts the heretics to penitence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 98:39
verses.text: If the polemic against Origen should seem to you to be inadequate, you are to remember that Origenism was fully treated in last year's letter; and that this which I have just translated, as it aims at brevity, was not bound to dwell farther upon the subject.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 98:40
verses.text: Besides, its terse and clear confession of faith directed against Apollinarius is not lacking in dialectical subtlety.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 98:41
verses.text: Theophilus first wrests the dagger from his opponent's hand, and then stabs him to the heart.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 98:43
verses.text: Entreat the Lord, therefore, that a composition which has won favour in Greek may not fail to win it also in Latin, and that what the whole East admires and praises Rome may gladly take to her heart.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 98:44
verses.text: And may the chair of the apostle Peter by its preaching confirm the preaching of the chair of the evangelist Mark.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 98:45
verses.text: Popular rumour, indeed, has it that the blessed pope Anastasius is of like zeal and spirit with Theophilus and that he has pursued the heretics even to the dens in which they lurk.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 98:46
verses.text: Moreover his own letters inform us that he condemns in the West what is already condemned in the East.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 98:47
verses.text: May he live for many years so that the reviving sprouts of heresy may in course of time by his efforts be made to wither and to die.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 99:1
verses.text: Letter XCVIII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 99:2
verses.text: From Theophilus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 99:3
verses.text: A translation by Jerome of Theophilus's paschal letter for the year 402 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 99:4
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 99:5
verses.text: Like that of the previous year (Letter XCVI.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 99:6
verses.text: ) it deals mainly with the heresies of Apollinarius and Origen.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 100:1
verses.text: Letter XCIX.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 100:2
verses.text: To Theophilus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 100:3
verses.text: Jerome forwards to Theophilus a translation of the latter's paschal letter for 404 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 100:4
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 100:5
verses.text: and apologizes for his delay in sending it, on the ground that ill-health and grief for the death of Paula have prevented him from doing literary work.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 100:6
verses.text: The date of the letter is 404 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 100:7
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 100:8
verses.text: To the most blessed pope Theophilus, Jerome.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 100:10
verses.text: From the time that I received the letters of your holiness together with the paschal treatise until the present day I have been so harassed with sorrow and mourning, with anxiety, and with the different reports which have come from all quarters concerning the condition of the church, that I have hardly been able to turn your volume into Latin.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 100:11
verses.text: You know the truth of the old saying, grief chokes utterance; and it is more than ever true when to sickness of the mind is added sickness of the body.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 100:12
verses.text: I have now been five days in bed in a burning fever: consequently it is only by using the greatest haste that I can dictate this very letter.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 100:13
verses.text: But I wish to shew your holiness in a few words what pains I have taken, in translating your treatise, to transfer the charm of diction which marks every sentence in the original, and to make the style of the Latin correspond in some degree with that of the Greek.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 100:15
verses.text: At the outset you use the language of philosophy; and, without appearing to particularize, you slay one while you instruct all.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 100:16
verses.text: In the remaining sections—a task most difficult of accomplishment—you combine philosophy and rhetoric and draw together for us Demosthenes and Plato.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 100:17
verses.text: What diatribes you have launched against self-indulgence! What eulogies you have bestowed upon the virtue of continence! With what secret stores of wisdom you have spoken of the interchange of day and night, the course of the moon, the laws of the sun, the nature of our world; always appealing to the authority of scripture lest in a paschal treatise you should appear to have borrowed anything from secular sources! To be brief, I am afraid to praise you for these things lest I should be charged with offering flattery.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 100:18
verses.text: The book is excellent both in the philosophical portions and where, without making personal attacks, you plead the cause which you have espoused.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 100:19
verses.text: Wherefore, I beseech you, pardon me my backwardness: I have been so completely overcome by the falling asleep of the holy and venerable Paula that except my translation of this book I have hitherto written nothing bearing on sacred subjects.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 100:20
verses.text: As you yourself know, I have suddenly lost the comforter whom I have led about with me, not—the Lord is my witness—to minister to my own needs, but for the relief and refreshment of the saints upon whom she has waited with all diligence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 100:21
verses.text: Your holy and estimable daughter Eustochium (who refuses to be comforted for the loss of her mother), and with her all the brotherhood humbly salute you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 100:22
verses.text: Kindly send me the books which you say that you have lately written that I may translate them or, if not that, at least read them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 100:23
verses.text: Farewell in Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 101:1
verses.text: Letter C.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 101:2
verses.text: From Theophilus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 101:3
verses.text: A translation by Jerome of Theophilus's paschal letter for 404 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 101:4
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 101:5
verses.text: In it Theophilus inculcates penitence for sinners, recommends the practice of fasting and condemns the errors of Origen.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 102:1
verses.text: Letter CI.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 102:2
verses.text: From Augustine.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 102:3
verses.text: A letter from Augustine in which he denies that he has written a book against Jerome and sent it to Rome but confesses that he has criticized him although without giving details.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 102:4
verses.text: Written in 402 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 102:5
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 102:6
verses.text: This and the following letters are to be found in the First Volume of the First Series of this Library.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 102:7
verses.text: Letter LXVII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 103:1
verses.text: Letter CII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 103:2
verses.text: To Augustine.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 103:3
verses.text: Jerome's reply to the foregoing in which, it has been said, friendship struggles with suspicion and resentment.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 103:4
verses.text: He warns Augustine not to provoke him, lest old as he is he may prove a dangerous opponent; and encloses part of his reply to the apology of Rufinus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 105:3
verses.text: In this letter Augustine (1) commends to Jerome the deacon Cyprian, (2) explains how it is that his first letter (Letter LVI.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 105:4
verses.text: ) has miscarried, and (3) urges Jerome to base his scriptural labours not on the Hebrew text but on the version of the LXX.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 105:5

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 106:1
verses.text: Letter CV.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 106:2
verses.text: To Augustine.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 106:3
verses.text: Jerome's answer to the foregoing.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 106:4
verses.text: He complains that even now he has not received Augustine's letter and asks him to send him a copy of it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 106:5
verses.text: Popular rumour, he declares, credits Augustine with a deliberate suppression of the letter in order that he may seem to win an easy victory over his opponent.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 106:6
verses.text: Jerome next deals with Augustine's denial of having made a written attack upon him and concludes by refusing for the present all discussion of points of criticism.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 106:7
verses.text: The date of the letter is 403 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 106:8
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 106:9

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 106:11

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 107:1
verses.text: Letter CVI.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 107:2
verses.text: To Sunnias and Fretela.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 107:3
verses.text: A long letter in which Jerome answers a number of questions put to him by two sojourners in Getica, Sunnias and Fretela.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 107:4
verses.text: Diligent students of scripture, these men were at a loss to understand the frequent differences between Jerome's Latin psalter of 383 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 107:5
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 107:6
verses.text: (the so-called Roman psalter) and the LXX, and accordingly sent him a long list of passages with a request for explanation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 107:7
verses.text: Jerome in his reply deals fully with all these and points out to his correspondents that they have been misled by their edition of the LXX.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 107:8
verses.text: (the "common" edition) which differs widely from the critical text of Origen as given in the Hexapla and used by himself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 107:9
verses.text: He also expresses his joy to find that even among the Getae the scriptures are now diligently studied.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 107:10
verses.text: The date of the letter is about 403 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 107:11
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:1
verses.text: Letter CVII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:2
verses.text: To Laeta.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:3
verses.text: Laeta, the daughter-in-law of Paula, having written from Rome to ask Jerome how she ought to bring up her infant daughter (also called Paula) as a virgin consecrated to Christ, Jerome now instructs her in detail as to the child's training and education.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:4
verses.text: Feeling some doubt, however, as to whether the scheme proposed by him will be practicable at Rome, he advises Laeta in case of difficulty to send Paula to Bethlehem where she will be under the care of her grandmother and aunt, the elder Paula and Eustochium.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:5
verses.text: Laeta subsequently accepted Jerome's advice and sent the child to Bethlehem where she eventually succeeded Eustochium as head of the nunnery founded by her grandmother.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:6
verses.text: The date of the letter is 403 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:7
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:9
verses.text: The apostle Paul writing to the Corinthians and instructing in sacred discipline a church still untaught in Christ has among other commandments laid down also this: "The woman which hath an husband that believeth not, and if he be pleased to dwell with her, let her not leave him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:10
verses.text: For the unbelieving husband is sanctified by the believing wife, and the unbelieving wife is sanctified by the believing husband; else were your children unclean but now are they holy".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:11
verses.text: Should any person have supposed hitherto that the bonds of discipline are too far relaxed and that too great indulgence is conceded by the teacher, let him look at the house of your father, a man of the highest distinction and learning, but one still walking in darkness; and he will perceive as the result of the apostle's counsel sweet fruit growing from a bitter stock and precious balsams exhaled from common canes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:12
verses.text: You yourself are the offspring of a mixed marriage; but the parents of Paula—you and my friend Toxotius—are both Christians.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:13
verses.text: Who could have believed that to the heathen pontiff Albinus should be born—in answer to a mother's vows—a Christian granddaughter; that a delighted grandfather should hear from the little one's faltering lips Christ's Alleluia, and that in his old age he should nurse in his bosom one of God's own virgins? Our expectations have been fully gratified.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:14
verses.text: The one unbeliever is sanctified by his holy and believing family.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:15
verses.text: For, when a man is surrounded by a believing crowd of children and grandchildren, he is as good as a candidate for the faith.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:16
verses.text: I for my part think that, had he possessed so many Christian kinsfolk when he was a young man, he might then have been brought to believe in Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:17
verses.text: For though he may spit upon my letter and laugh at it, and though he may call me a fool or a madman, his son-in-law did the same before he came to believe.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:18
verses.text: Christians are not born but made.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:19
verses.text: For all its gilding the Capitol is beginning to look dingy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:20
verses.text: Every temple in Rome is covered with soot and cobwebs.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:21
verses.text: The city is stirred to its depths and the people pour past their half-ruined shrines to visit the tombs of the martyrs.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:22
verses.text: The belief which has not been accorded to conviction may come to be extorted by very shame.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:24
verses.text: I speak thus to you, Laeta my most devout daughter in Christ, to teach you not to despair of your father's salvation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:25
verses.text: My hope is that the same faith which has gained you your daughter may win your father too, and that so you may be able to rejoice over blessings bestowed upon your entire family.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:26
verses.text: You know the Lord's promise: "The things which are impossible with men are possible with God".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:27
verses.text: It is never too late to mend.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:28
verses.text: The robber passed even from the cross to paradise.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:29
verses.text: Nebuchadnezzar also, the king of Babylon, recovered his reason, even after he had been made like the beasts in body and in heart and had been compelled to live with the brutes in the wilderness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:30
verses.text: And to pass over such old stories which to unbelievers may well seem incredible, did not your own kinsman Gracchus whose name betokens his patrician origin, when a few years back he held the prefecture of the City, overthrow, break in pieces, and shake to pieces the grotto of Mithras and all the dreadful images therein? Those I mean by which the worshippers were initiated as Raven, Bridegroom, Soldier, Lion, Perseus, Sun, Crab, and Father? Did he not, I repeat, destroy these and then, sending them before him as hostages, obtain for himself Christian baptism?  Even in Rome itself paganism is left in solitude.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:31
verses.text: They who once were the gods of the nations remain under their lonely roofs with horned-owls and birds of night.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:32
verses.text: The standards of the military are emblazoned with the sign of the Cross.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:33
verses.text: The emperor's robes of purple and his diadem sparkling with jewels are ornamented with representations of the shameful yet saving gibbet.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:34
verses.text: Already the Egyptian Serapis has been made a Christian; while at Gaza Marnas mourns in confinement and every moment expects to see his temple overturned.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:35
verses.text: From India, from Persia, from Ethiopia we daily welcome monks in crowds.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:36
verses.text: The Armenian bowman has laid aside his quiver, the Huns learn the psalter, the chilly Scythians are warmed with the glow of the faith.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:37
verses.text: The Getae, ruddy and yellow-haired, carry tent-churches about with their armies: and perhaps their success in fighting against us may be due to the fact that they believe in the same religion.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:39
verses.text: I have nearly wandered into a new subject, and while I have kept my wheel going, my hands have been moulding a flagon when it has been my object to frame an ewer.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:40
verses.text: For, in answer to your prayers and those of the saintly Marcella, I wish to address you as a mother and to instruct you how to bring up our dear Paula, who has been consecrated to Christ before her birth and vowed to His service before her conception.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:41
