verses.text: Thus in our own day we have seen repeated the story told us in the Prophets, of Hannah, who though at first barren afterwards became fruitful.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:42
verses.text: You have exchanged a fertility bound up with sorrow for offspring which shall never die.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:43
verses.text: For I am confident that having given to the Lord your first-born you will be the mother of sons.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:44
verses.text: It is the first-born that is offered under the Law.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:45
verses.text: Samuel and Samson are both instances of this, as is also John the Baptist who when Mary came in leaped for joy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:46
verses.text: For he heard the Lord speaking by the mouth of the Virgin and desired to break from his mother's womb to meet Him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:47
verses.text: As then Paula has been born in answer to a promise, her parents should give her a training suitable to her birth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:48
verses.text: Samuel, as you know, was nurtured in the Temple, and John was trained in the wilderness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:49
verses.text: The first as a Nazarite wore his hair long, drank neither wine nor strong drink, and even in his childhood talked with God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:50
verses.text: The second shunned cities, wore a leathern girdle, and had for his meat locusts and wild honey.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:51
verses.text: Moreover, to typify that penitence which he was to preach, he was clothed in the spoils of the hump-backed camel.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:53
verses.text: Thus must a soul be educated which is to be a temple of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:54
verses.text: It must learn to hear nothing and to say nothing but what belongs to the fear of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:55
verses.text: It must have no understanding of unclean words, and no knowledge of the world's songs.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:56
verses.text: Its tongue must be steeped while still tender in the sweetness of the psalms.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:57
verses.text: Boys with their wanton thoughts must be kept from Paula: even her maids and female attendants must be separated from worldly associates.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:58
verses.text: For if they have learned some mischief they may teach more.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:59
verses.text: Get for her a set of letters made of boxwood or of ivory and called each by its proper name.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:60
verses.text: Let her play with these, so that even her play may teach her something.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:61
verses.text: And not only make her grasp the right order of the letters and see that she forms their names into a rhyme, but constantly disarrange their order and put the last letters in the middle and the middle ones at the beginning that she may know them all by sight as well as by sound.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:62
verses.text: Moreover, so soon as she begins to use the style upon the wax, and her hand is still faltering, either guide her soft fingers by laying your hand upon hers, or else have simple copies cut upon a tablet; so that her efforts confined within these limits may keep to the lines traced out for her and not stray outside of these.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:63
verses.text: Offer prizes for good spelling and draw her onwards with little gifts such as children of her age delight in.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:64
verses.text: And let her have companions in her lessons to excite emulation in her, that she may be stimulated when she sees them praised.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:65
verses.text: You must not scold her if she is slow to learn but must employ praise to excite her mind, so that she may be glad when she excels others and sorry when she is excelled by them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:66
verses.text: Above all you must take care not to make her lessons distasteful to her lest a dislike for them conceived in childhood may continue into her maturer years.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:67
verses.text: The very words which she tries bit by bit to put together and to pronounce ought not to be chance ones, but names specially fixed upon and heaped together for the purpose, those for example of the prophets or the apostles or the list of patriarchs from Adam downwards as it is given by Matthew and Luke.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:68
verses.text: In this way while her tongue will be well-trained, her memory will be likewise developed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:69
verses.text: Again, you must choose for her a master of approved years, life, and learning.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:70
verses.text: A man of culture will not, I think, blush to do for a kinswoman or a highborn virgin what Aristotle did for Philip's son when, descending to the level of an usher, he consented to teach him his letters.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:71
verses.text: Things must not be despised as of small account in the absence of which great results cannot be achieved.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:72
verses.text: The very rudiments and first beginnings of knowledge sound differently in the mouth of an educated man and of an uneducated.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:73
verses.text: Accordingly you must see that the child is not led away by the silly coaxing of women to form a habit of shortening long words or of decking herself with gold and purple.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:74
verses.text: Of these habits one will spoil her conversation and the other her character.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:75
verses.text: She must not therefore learn as a child what afterwards she will have to unlearn.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:76
verses.text: The eloquence of the Gracchi is said to have been largely due to the way in which from their earliest years their mother spoke to them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:77
verses.text: Hortensius became an orator while still on his father's lap.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:78
verses.text: Early impressions are hard to eradicate from the mind.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:79
verses.text: When once wool has been dyed purple who can restore it to its previous whiteness? An unused jar long retains the taste and smell of that with which it is first filled.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:80
verses.text: Grecian history tells us that the imperious Alexander who was lord of the whole world could not rid himself of the tricks of manner and gait which in his childhood he had caught from his governor Leonides.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:81
verses.text: We are always ready to imitate what is evil; and faults are quickly copied where virtues appear inattainable.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:82
verses.text: Paula's nurse must not be intemperate, or loose, or given to gossip.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:83
verses.text: Her bearer must be respectable, and her foster-father of grave demeanour.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:84
verses.text: When she sees her grandfather, she must leap upon his breast, put her arms round his neck, and, whether he likes it or not, sing Alleluia in his ears.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:85
verses.text: She may be fondled by her grandmother, may smile at her father to shew that she recognizes him, and may so endear herself to everyone, as to make the whole family rejoice in the possession of such a rosebud.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:86
verses.text: She should be told at once whom she has for her other grandmother and whom for her aunt; and she ought also to learn in what army it is that she is enrolled as a recruit, and what Captain it is under whose banner she is called to serve.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:87
verses.text: Let her long to be with the absent ones and encourage her to make playful threats of leaving you for them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:89
verses.text: Let her very dress and garb remind her to Whom she is promised.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:90
verses.text: Do not pierce her ears or paint her face consecrated to Christ with white lead or rouge.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:91
verses.text: Do not hang gold or pearls about her neck or load her head with jewels, or by reddening her hair make it suggest the fires of gehenna.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:92
verses.text: Let her pearls be of another kind and such that she may sell them hereafter and buy in their place the pearl that is "of great price".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:93
verses.text: In days gone by a lady of rank, Praetextata by name, at the bidding of her husband Hymettius, the uncle of Eustochium, altered that virgin's dress and appearance and arranged her neglected hair after the manner of the world, desiring to overcome the resolution of the virgin herself and the expressed wishes of her mother.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:94
verses.text: But lo in the same night it befell her that an angel came to her in her dreams.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:95
verses.text: With terrible looks he menaced punishment and broke silence with these words, 'Have you presumed to put your husband's commands before those of Christ? Have you presumed to lay sacrilegious hands upon the head of one who is God's virgin? Those hands shall forthwith wither that you may know by torment what you have done, and at the end of five months you shall be carried off to hell.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:96
verses.text: And farther, if you persist still in your wickedness, you shall be bereaved both of your husband and of your children.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:97
verses.text: ' All of which came to pass in due time, a speedy death marking the penitence too long delayed of the unhappy woman.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:98
verses.text: So terribly does Christ punish those who violate His temple, and so jealously does He defend His precious jewels.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:99
verses.text: I have related this story here not from any desire to exult over the misfortunes of the unhappy, but to warn you that you must with much fear and carefulness keep the vow which you have made to God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:101
verses.text: We read of Eli the priest that he became displeasing to God on account of the sins of his children; and we are told that a man may not be made a bishop if his sons are loose and disorderly.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:102
verses.text: On the other hand it is written of the woman that "she shall be saved in childbearing, if they continue in faith and charity and holiness with chastity".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:103
verses.text: If then parents are responsible for their children when these are of ripe age and independent; how much more must they be responsible for them when, still unweaned and weak, they cannot, in the Lord's words, "discern between their right hand and their left:"—when, that is to say, they cannot yet distinguish good from evil? If you take precautions to save your daughter from the bite of a viper, why are you not equally careful to shield her from "the hammer of the whole earth"? to prevent her from drinking of the golden cup of Babylon? to keep her from going out with Dinah to see the daughters of a strange land? to save her from the tripping dance and from the trailing robe? No one administers drugs till he has rubbed the rim of the cup with honey; so, the better to deceive us, vice puts on the mien and the semblance of virtue.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:104
verses.text: Why then, you will say, do we read:—"the son shall not bear the iniquity of the father, neither shall the father bear the iniquity of the son," but "the soul that sinneth it shall die"? The passage, I answer, refers to those who have discretion, such as he of whom his parents said in the gospel:—"he is of age…he shall speak for himself".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:105
verses.text: While the son is a child and thinks as a child and until he comes to years of discretion to choose between the two roads to which the letter of Pythagoras points, his parents are responsible for his actions whether these be good or bad.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:106
verses.text: But perhaps you imagine that, if they are not baptized, the children of Christians are liable for their own sins; and that no guilt attaches to parents who withhold from baptism those who by reason of their tender age can offer no objection to it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:107
verses.text: The truth is that, as baptism ensures the salvation of the child, this in turn brings advantage to the parents.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:108
verses.text: Whether you would offer your child or not lay within your choice, but now that you have offered her, you neglect her at your peril.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:109
verses.text: I speak generally for in your case you have no discretion, having offered your child even before her conception.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:110
verses.text: He who offers a victim that is lame or maimed or marked with any blemish is held guilty of sacrilege.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:111
verses.text: How much more then shall she be punished who makes ready for the embraces of the king a portion of her own body and the purity of a stainless soul, and then proves negligent of this her offering?  7.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:112
verses.text: When Paula comes to be a little older and to increase like her Spouse in wisdom and stature and in favour with God and man, let her go with her parents to the temple of her true Father but let her not come out of the temple with them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:113
verses.text: Let them seek her upon the world's highway amid the crowds and the throng of their kinsfolk, and let them find her nowhere but in the shrine of the scriptures, questioning the prophets and the apostles on the meaning of that spiritual marriage to which she is vowed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:114
verses.text: Let her imitate the retirement of Mary whom Gabriel found alone in her chamber and who was frightened, it would appear, by seeing a man there.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:115
verses.text: Let the child emulate her of whom it is written that "the king's daughter is all glorious within".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:116
verses.text: Wounded with love's arrow let her say to her beloved, "the king hath brought me into his chambers".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:117
verses.text: At no time let her go abroad, lest the watchmen find her that go about the city, and lest they smite and wound her and take away from her the veil of her chastity, and leave her naked in her blood.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:118
verses.text: Nay rather when one knocketh at her door let her say: "I am a wall and my breasts like towers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:119
verses.text: I have washed my feet; how shall I defile them?"  8.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:120
verses.text: Let her not take her food with others, that is, at her parents' table; lest she see dishes she may long for.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:121
verses.text: Some, I know, hold it a greater virtue to disdain a pleasure which is actually before them, but I think it a safer self-restraint to shun what must needs attract you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:122
verses.text: Once as a boy at school I met the words: 'It is ill blaming what you allow to become a habit.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:123
verses.text: ' Let her learn even now not to drink wine "wherein is excess".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:124
verses.text: But as, before children come to a robust age, abstinence is dangerous and trying to their tender frames, let her have baths if she require them, and let her take a little wine for her stomach's sake.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:125
verses.text: Let her also be supported on a flesh diet, lest her feet fail her before they commence to run their course.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:126
verses.text: But I say this by way of concession not by way of command; because I fear to weaken her, not because I wish to teach her self-indulgence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:127
verses.text: Besides why should not a Christian virgin do wholly what others do in part? The superstitious Jews reject certain animals and products as articles of food, while among the Indians the Brahmans and among the Egyptians the Gymnosophists subsist altogether on porridge, rice, and apples.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:128
verses.text: If mere glass repays so much labour, must not a pearl be worth more labour still? Paula has been born in response to a vow.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:129
verses.text: Let her life be as the lives of those who were born under the same conditions.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:130
verses.text: If the grace accorded is in both cases the same, the pains bestowed ought to be so too.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:131
verses.text: Let her be deaf to the sound of the organ, and not know even the uses of the pipe, the lyre, and the cithern.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:133
verses.text: And let it be her task daily to bring to you the flowers which she has culled from scripture.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:134
verses.text: Let her learn by heart so many verses in the Greek, but let her be instructed in the Latin also.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:135
verses.text: For, if the tender lips are not from the first shaped to this, the tongue is spoiled by a foreign accent and its native speech debased by alien elements.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:136
verses.text: You must yourself be her mistress, a model on which she may form her childish conduct.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:137
verses.text: Never either in you nor in her father let her see what she cannot imitate without sin.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:138
verses.text: Remember both of you that you are the parents of a consecrated virgin, and that your example will teach her more than your precepts.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:139
verses.text: Flowers are quick to fade and a baleful wind soon withers the violet, the lily, and the crocus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:140
verses.text: Let her never appear in public unless accompanied by you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:141
verses.text: Let her never visit a church or a martyr's shrine unless with her mother.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:142
verses.text: Let no young man greet her with smiles; no dandy with curled hair pay compliments to her.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:143
verses.text: If our little virgin goes to keep solemn eves and all-night vigils, let her not stir a hair's breadth from her mother's side.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:144
verses.text: She must not single out one of her maids to make her a special favourite or a confidante.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:145
verses.text: What she says to one all ought to know.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:146
verses.text: Let her choose for a companion not a handsome well-dressed girl, able to warble a song with liquid notes but one pale and serious, sombrely attired and with the hue of melancholy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:147
verses.text: Let her take as her model some aged virgin of approved faith, character, and chastity, apt to instruct her by word and by example.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:148
verses.text: She ought to rise at night to recite prayers and psalms; to sing hymns in the morning; at the third, sixth, and ninth hours to take her place in the line to do battle for Christ; and, lastly, to kindle her lamp and to offer her evening sacrifice.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:149
verses.text: In these occupations let her pass the day, and when night comes let it find her still engaged in them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:150
verses.text: Let reading follow prayer with her, and prayer again succeed to reading.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:151
verses.text: Time will seem short when employed on tasks so many and so varied.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:153
verses.text: Let her learn too how to spin wool, to hold the distaff, to put the basket in her lap, to turn the spinning wheel and to shape the yarn with her thumb.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:154
verses.text: Let her put away with disdain silken fabrics, Chinese fleeces, and gold brocades: the clothing which she makes for herself should keep out the cold and not expose the body which it professes to cover.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:155
verses.text: Let her food be herbs and wheaten bread with now and then one or two small fishes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:156
verses.text: And that I may not waste more time in giving precepts for the regulation of appetite (a subject I have treated more at length elsewhere) let her meals always leave her hungry and able on the moment to begin reading or chanting.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:157
verses.text: I strongly disapprove—especially for those of tender years—of long and immoderate fasts in which week is added to week and even oil and apples are forbidden as food.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:158
verses.text: I have learned by experience that the ass toiling along the high way makes for an inn when it is weary.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:159
verses.text: Our abstinence may turn to glutting, like that of the worshippers of Isis and of Cybele who gobble up pheasants and turtle-doves piping hot that their teeth may not violate the gifts of Ceres.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:160
verses.text: If perpetual fasting is allowed, it must be so regulated that those who have a long journey before them may hold out all through; and we must take care that we do not, after starting well, fall halfway.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:161
verses.text: However in Lent, as I have written before now, those who practise self-denial should spread every stitch of canvas, and the charioteer should for once slacken the reins and increase the speed of his horses.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:162
verses.text: Yet there will be one rule for those who live in the world and another for virgins and monks.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:163
verses.text: The layman in Lent consumes the coats of his stomach, and living like a snail on his own juices makes ready a paunch for rich foods and feasting to come.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:164
verses.text: But with the virgin and the monk the case is different; for, when these give the rein to their steeds, they have to remember that for them the race knows of no intermission.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:165
verses.text: An effort made only for a limited time may well be severe, but one that has no such limit must be more moderate.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:166
verses.text: For whereas in the first case we can recover our breath when the race is over, in the last we have to go on continually and without stopping.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:168
verses.text: When you go a short way into the country, do not leave your daughter behind you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:169
verses.text: Leave her no power or capacity of living without you, and let her feel frightened when she is left to herself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:170
verses.text: Let her not converse with people of the world or associate with virgins indifferent to their vows.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:171
verses.text: Let her not be present at the weddings of your slaves and let her take no part in the noisy games of the household.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:172
verses.text: As regards the use of the bath, I know that some are content with saying that a Christian virgin should not bathe along with eunuchs or with married women, with the former because they are still men, at all events in mind, and with the latter because women with child offer a revolting spectacle.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:173
verses.text: For myself, however, I wholly disapprove of baths for a virgin of full age.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:174
verses.text: Such an one should blush and feel overcome at the idea of seeing herself undressed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:175
verses.text: By vigils and fasts she mortifies her body and brings it into subjection.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:176
verses.text: By a cold chastity she seeks to put out the flame of lust and to quench the hot desires of youth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:177
verses.text: And by a deliberate squalor she makes haste to spoil her natural good looks.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:178
verses.text: Why, then, should she add fuel to a sleeping fire by taking baths?  12.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:179
verses.text: Let her treasures be not silks or gems but manuscripts of the holy scriptures; and in these let her think less of gilding, and Babylonian parchment, and arabesque patterns, than of correctness and accurate punctuation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:180
verses.text: Let her begin by learning the psalter, and then let her gather rules of life out of the proverbs of Solomon.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:181
verses.text: From the Preacher let her gain the habit of despising the world and its vanities.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:182
verses.text: Let her follow the example set in Job of virtue and of patience.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:183
verses.text: Then let her pass on to the gospels never to be laid aside when once they have been taken in hand.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:184
verses.text: Let her also drink in with a willing heart the Acts of the Apostles and the Epistles.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:185
verses.text: As soon as she has enriched the storehouse of her mind with these treasures, let her commit to memory the prophets, the heptateuch, the books of Kings and of Chronicles, the rolls also of Ezra and Esther.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:186
verses.text: When she has done all these she may safely read the Song of Songs but not before: for, were she to read it at the beginning, she would fail to perceive that, though it is written in fleshly words, it is a marriage song of a spiritual bridal.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:187
verses.text: And not understanding this she would suffer hurt from it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:188
verses.text: Let her avoid all apocryphal writings, and if she is led to read such not by the truth of the doctrines which they contain but out of respect for the miracles contained in them; let her understand that they are not really written by those to whom they are ascribed, that many faulty elements have been introduced into them, and that it requires infinite discretion to look for gold in the midst of dirt.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:189
verses.text: Cyprian's writings let her have always in her hands.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:190
verses.text: The letters of Athanasius and the treatises of Hilary she may go through without fear of stumbling.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:191
verses.text: Let her take pleasure in the works and wits of all in whose books a due regard for the faith is not neglected.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:192
verses.text: But if she reads the works of others let it be rather to judge them than to follow them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:194
verses.text: You will answer, 'How shall I, a woman of the world, living at Rome, surrounded by a crowd, be able to observe all these injunctions?' In that case do not undertake a burthen to which you are not equal.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:195
verses.text: When you have weaned Paula as Isaac was weaned and when you have clothed her as Samuel was clothed, send her to her grandmother and aunt; give up this most precious of gems, to be placed in Mary's chamber and to rest in the cradle where the infant Jesus cried.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:196
verses.text: Let her be brought up in a monastery, let her be one amid companies of virgins, let her learn to avoid swearing, let her regard lying as sacrilege, let her be ignorant of the world, let her live the angelic life, while in the flesh let her be without the flesh, and let her suppose that all human beings are like herself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:197
verses.text: To say nothing of its other advantages this course will free you from the difficult task of minding her, and from the responsibility of guardianship.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:198
verses.text: It is better to regret her absence than to be for ever trembling for her.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:199
verses.text: For you cannot but tremble as you watch what she says and to whom she says it, to whom she bows and whom she likes best to see.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:200
verses.text: Hand her over to Eustochium while she is still but an infant and her every cry is a prayer for you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:201
verses.text: She will thus become her companion in holiness now as well as her successor hereafter.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:202
verses.text: Let her gaze upon and love, let her "from her earliest years admire" one whose language and gait and dress are an education in virtue.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:203
verses.text: Let her sit in the lap of her grandmother, and let this latter repeat to her granddaughter the lessons that she once bestowed upon her own child.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:204
verses.text: Long experience has shewn Paula how to rear, to preserve, and to instruct virgins; and daily inwoven in her crown is the mystic century which betokens the highest chastity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:205
verses.text: O happy virgin! happy Paula, daughter of Toxotius, who through the virtues of her grandmother and aunt is nobler in holiness than she is in lineage! Yes, Laeta: were it possible for you with your own eyes to see your mother-in-law and your sister, and to realize the mighty souls which animate their small bodies; such is your innate thirst for chastity that I cannot doubt but that you would go to them even before your daughter, and would emancipate yourself from God's first decree of the Law to put yourself under His second dispensation of the Gospel.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:206
verses.text: You would count as nothing your desire for other offspring and would offer up yourself to the service of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:207
verses.text: But because "there is a time to embrace, and a time to refrain from embracing," and because "the wife hath not power of her own body," and because the apostle says "Let every man abide in the same calling wherein he was called" in the Lord, and because he that is under the yoke ought so to run as not to leave his companion in the mire, I counsel you to pay back to the full in your offspring what meantime you defer paying in your own person.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:208
verses.text: When Hannah had once offered in the tabernacle the son whom she had vowed to God she never took him back; for she thought it unbecoming that one who was to be a prophet should grow up in the same house with her who still desired to have other children.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:209
verses.text: Accordingly after she had conceived him and given him birth, she did not venture to come to the temple alone or to appear before the Lord empty, but first paid to Him what she owed; and then, when she had offered up that great sacrifice, she returned home and because she had borne her firstborn for God, she was given five children for herself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:210
verses.text: Do you marvel at the happiness of that holy woman? Imitate her faith.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:211
verses.text: Moreover, if you will only send Paula, I promise to be myself both a tutor and a foster father to her.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 108:212
verses.text: Old as I am I will carry her on my shoulders and train her stammering lips; and my charge will be a far grander one than that of the worldly philosopher; for while he only taught a King of Macedon who was one day to die of Babylonian poison, I shall instruct the handmaid and spouse of Christ who must one day be offered to her Lord in heaven.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:1
verses.text: Letter CVIII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:2
verses.text: To Eustochium.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:3
verses.text: This, one of the longest of Jerome's letters, was written to console Eustochium for the loss of her mother who had recently died.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:4
verses.text: Jerome relates the story of Paula in detail; speaking first of her high birth, marriage, and social success at Rome, and then narrating her conversion and subsequent life as a Christian ascetic.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:5
verses.text: Much space is devoted to an account of her journey to the East which included a visit to Egypt and to the monasteries of Nitria as well as a tour of the most sacred spots in the Holy Land.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:6
verses.text: The remainder of the letter describes her daily routine and studies at Bethlehem, and recounts the many virtues for which she was distinguished.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:7
verses.text: It then concludes with a touching description of her death and burial and gives the epitaph placed upon her grave.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:8
verses.text: The date of the letter is 404 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:9
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:11
verses.text: If all the members of my body were to be converted into tongues, and if each of my limbs were to be gifted with a human voice, I could still do no justice to the virtues of the holy and venerable Paula.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:12
verses.text: Noble in family, she was nobler still in holiness; rich formerly in this world's goods, she is now more distinguished by the poverty that she has embraced for Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:13
verses.text: Of the stock of the Gracchi and descended from the Scipios, the heir and representative of that Paulus whose name she bore, the true and legitimate daughter of that Martia Papyria who was mother to Africanus, she yet preferred Bethlehem to Rome, and left her palace glittering with gold to dwell in a mud cabin.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:14
verses.text: We do not grieve that we have lost this perfect woman; rather we thank God that we have had her, nay that we have her still.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:15
verses.text: For "all live unto" God, and they who return unto the Lord are still to be reckoned members of his family.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:16
verses.text: We have lost her, it is true, but the heavenly mansions have gained her; for as long as she was in the body she was absent from the Lord and would constantly complain with tears:—"Woe is me that I sojourn in Mesech, that I dwell in the tents of Kedar; my soul hath been this long time a pilgrim".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:17
verses.text: It was no wonder that she sobbed out that even she was in darkness (for this is the meaning of the word Kedar) seeing that, according to the apostle, "the world lieth in the evil one;" and that, "as its darkness is, so is its light;" and that "the light shineth in darkness and the darkness comprehended it not".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:18
verses.text: She would frequently exclaim: "I am a stranger with thee and a sojourner as all my fathers were," and again, I desire "to depart and to be with Christ".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:19
verses.text: As often too as she was troubled with bodily weakness (brought on by incredible abstinence and by redoubled fastings), she would be heard to say: "I keep under my body and bring it into subjection; lest that by any means, when I have preached to others, I myself should be a castaway;" and "It is good neither to eat flesh nor to drink wine;" and "I humbled my soul with fasting;" and "thou wilt make all" my "bed in" my "sickness;" and "Thy hand was heavy upon me: my moisture is turned into the drought of summer".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:20
verses.text: And when the pain which she bore with such wonderful patience darted through her, as if she saw the heavens opened she would say "Oh that I had wings like a dove! for then would I fly away and be at rest".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:22
verses.text: I call Jesus and his saints, yes and the particular angel who was the guardian and the companion of this admirable woman to bear witness that these are no words of adulation and flattery but sworn testimony every one of them borne to her character.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:23
verses.text: They are, indeed, inadequate to the virtues of one whose praises are sung by the whole world, who is admired by bishops, regretted by bands of virgins, and wept for by crowds of monks and poor.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:24
verses.text: Would you know all her virtues, reader, in short? She has left those dependent on her poor, but not so poor as she was herself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:25
verses.text: In dealing thus with her relatives and the men and women of her small household—her brothers and sisters rather than her servants—she has done nothing strange; for she has left her daughter Eustochium—a virgin consecrated to Christ for whose comfort this sketch is made—far from her noble family and rich only in faith and grace.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:27
verses.text: Let me then begin my narrative.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:28
verses.text: Others may go back a long way even to Paula's cradle and, if I may say so, to her swaddling-clothes, and may speak of her mother Blaesilla and her father Rogatus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:29
verses.text: Of these the former was a descendant of the Scipios and the Gracchi; whilst the latter came of a line distinguished in Greece down to the present day.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:30
verses.text: He was said, indeed, to have in his veins the blood of Agamemnon who destroyed Troy after a ten years siege.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:31
verses.text: But I shall praise only what belongs to herself, what wells forth from the pure spring of her holy mind.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:32
verses.text: When in the gospel the apostles ask their Lord and Saviour what He will give to those who have left all for His sake, He tells them that they shall receive an hundredfold now in this time and in the world to come eternal life.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:33
verses.text: From which we see that it is not the possession of riches that is praiseworthy but the rejection of them for Christ's sake; that, instead of glorying in our privileges, we should make them of small account as compared with God's faith.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:34
verses.text: Truly the Saviour has now in this present time made good His promise to His servants and handmaidens.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:35
verses.text: For one who despised the glory of a single city is to-day famous throughout the world; and one who while she lived at Rome was known by no one outside it has by hiding herself at Bethlehem become the admiration of all lands Roman and barbarian.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:36
verses.text: For what race of men is there which does not send pilgrims to the holy places? And who could there find a greater marvel than Paula? As among many jewels the most precious shines most brightly, and as the sun with its beams obscures and puts out the paler fires of the stars; so by her lowliness she surpassed all others in virtue and influence and, while she was least among all, was greater than all.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:37
verses.text: The more she cast herself down, the more she was lifted up by Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:38
verses.text: She was hidden and yet she was not hidden.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:39
verses.text: By shunning glory she earned glory; for glory follows virtue as its shadow; and deserting those who seek it, it seeks those who despise it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:40
verses.text: But I must not neglect to proceed with my narrative or dwell too long on a single point forgetful of the rules of writing.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:42
verses.text: Being then of such parentage, Paula married Toxotius in whose veins ran the noble blood of aeneas and the Julii.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:43
verses.text: Accordingly his daughter, Christ's virgin Eustochium, is called Julia, as he Julius.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:44
verses.text: A name from great Iulus handed down.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:45
verses.text: I speak of these things not as of importance to those who have them, but as worthy of remark in those who despise them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:46
verses.text: Men of the world look up to persons who are rich in such privileges.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:47
verses.text: We on the other hand praise those who for the Saviour's sake despise them; and strangely depreciating all who keep them, we eulogize those who are unwilling to do so.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:48
verses.text: Thus nobly born, Paula through her fruitfulness and her chastity won approval from all, from her husband first, then from her relatives, and lastly from the whole city.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:49
verses.text: She bore five children; Blaesilla, for whose death I consoled her while at Rome; Paulina, who has left the reverend and admirable Pammachius to inherit both her vows and property, to whom also I addressed a little book on her death; Eustochium, who is now in the holy places, a precious necklace of virginity and of the church; Rufina, whose untimely end overcame the affectionate heart of her mother; and Toxotius, after whom she had no more children.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:50
verses.text: You can thus see that it was not her wish to fulfil a wife's duty, but that she only complied with her husband's longing to have male offspring.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:52
verses.text: When he died, her grief was so great that she nearly died herself: yet so completely did she then give herself to the service of the Lord, that it might have seemed that she had desired his death.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:53
verses.text: In what terms shall I speak of her distinguished, and noble, and formerly wealthy house; all the riches of which she spent upon the poor? How can I describe the great consideration she shewed to all and her far reaching kindness even to those whom she had never seen? What poor man, as he lay dying, was not wrapped in blankets given by her? What bedridden person was not supported with money from her purse? She would seek out such with the greatest diligence throughout the city, and would think it a misfortune were any hungry or sick person to be supported by another's food.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:54
verses.text: So lavish was her charity that she robbed her children; and, when her relatives remonstrated with her for doing so, she declared that she was leaving to them a better inheritance in the mercy of Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:56
verses.text: Nor was she long able to endure the visits and crowded receptions, which her high position in the world and her exalted family entailed upon her.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:57
verses.text: She received the homage paid to her sadly, and made all the speed she could to shun and to escape those who wished to pay her compliments.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:58
verses.text: It so happened that at that time the bishops of the East and West had been summoned to Rome by letter from the emperors to deal with certain dissensions between the churches, and in this way she saw two most admirable men and Christian prelates, Paulinus bishop of Antioch and Epiphanius, bishop of Salamis or, as it is now called, Constantia, in Cyprus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:59
verses.text: Epiphanius, indeed, she received as her guest; and, although Paulinus was staying in another person's house, in the warmth of her heart she treated him as if he too were lodged with her.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:60
verses.text: Inflamed by their virtues she thought more and more each moment of forsaking her home.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:61
verses.text: Disregarding her house, her children, her servants, her property, and in a word everything connected with the world, she was eager—alone and unaccompanied (if ever it could be said that she was so)—to go to the desert made famous by its Pauls and by its Antonies.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:62
verses.text: And at last when the winter was over and the sea was open, and when the bishops were returning to their churches, she also sailed with them in her prayers and desires.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:63
verses.text: Not to prolong the story, she went down to Portus accompanied by her brother, her kinsfolk and above all her own children eager by their demonstrations of affection to overcome their loving mother.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:64
verses.text: At last the sails were set and the strokes of the rowers carried the vessel into the deep.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:65
verses.text: On the shore the little Toxotius stretched forth his hands in entreaty, while Rufina, now grown up, with silent sobs besought her mother to wait till she should be married.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:66
verses.text: But still Paula's eyes were dry as she turned them heavenwards; and she overcame her love for her children by her love for God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:67
verses.text: She knew herself no more as a mother, that she might approve herself a handmaid of Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:68
verses.text: Yet her heart was rent within her, and she wrestled with her grief, as though she were being forcibly separated from parts of herself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:69
verses.text: The greatness of the affection she had to overcome made all admire her victory the more.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:70
verses.text: Among the cruel hardships which attend prisoners of war in the hands of their enemies, there is none severer than the separation of parents from their children.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:71
verses.text: Though it is against the laws of nature, she endured this trial with unabated faith; nay more she sought it with a joyful heart: and overcoming her love for her children by her greater love for God, she concentrated herself quietly upon Eustochium alone, the partner alike of her vows and of her voyage.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:72
verses.text: Meantime the vessel ploughed onwards and all her fellow-passengers looked back to the shore.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:73
verses.text: But she turned away her eyes that she might not see what she could not behold without agony.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:74
verses.text: No mother, it must be confessed, ever loved her children so dearly.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:75
verses.text: Before setting out she gave them all that she had, disinheriting herself upon earth that she might find an inheritance in heaven.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:77
verses.text: The vessel touched at the island of Pontia ennobled long since as the place of exile of the illustrious lady Flavia Domitilla who under the Emperor Domitian was banished because she confessed herself a Christian; and Paula, when she saw the cells in which this lady passed the period of her long martyrdom, taking to herself the wings of faith, more than ever desired to see Jerusalem and the holy places.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:78
verses.text: The strongest winds seemed weak and the greatest speed slow.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:79
verses.text: After passing between Scylla and Charybdis she committed herself to the Adriatic sea and had a calm passage to Methone.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:80
verses.text: Stopping here for a short time to recruit her wearied frame  She stretched her dripping limbs upon the shore:  Then sailed past Malea and Cythera's isle,  The scattered Cyclades, and all the lands  That narrow in the seas on every side.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:81
verses.text: Then leaving Rhodes and Lycia behind her, she at last came in sight of Cyprus, where falling at the feet of the holy and venerable Epiphanius, she was by him detained ten days; though this was not, as he supposed, to restore her strength but, as the facts prove, that she might do God's work.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:82
verses.text: For she visited all the monasteries in the island, and left, so far as her means allowed, substantial relief for the brothers in them whom love of the holy man had brought thither from all parts of the world.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:83
verses.text: Then crossing the narrow sea she landed at Seleucia, and going up thence to Antioch allowed herself to be detained for a little time by the affection of the reverend confessor Paulinus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:84
verses.text: Then, such was the ardour of her faith that she, a noble lady who had always previously been carried by eunuchs, went her way—and that in midwinter—riding upon an ass.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:86
verses.text: I say nothing of her journey through Coele-Syria and Phoenicia (for it is not my purpose to give you a complete itinerary of her wanderings); I shall only name such places as are mentioned in the sacred books.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:87
verses.text: After leaving the Roman colony of Berytus and the ancient city of Zidon she entered Elijah's town on the shore at Zarephath and therein adored her Lord and Saviour.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:88
verses.text: Next passing over the sands of Tyre on which Paul had once knelt she came to Acco or, as it is now called, Ptolemais, rode over the plains of Megiddo which had once witnessed the slaying of Josiah, and entered the land of the Philistines.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:89
verses.text: Here she could not fail to admire the ruins of Dor, once a most powerful city; and Strato's Tower, which though at one time insignificant was rebuilt by Herod king of Judaea and named Caesarea in honour of Caesar Augustus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:90
verses.text: Here she saw the house of Cornelius now turned into a Christian church; and the humble abode of Philip; and the chambers of his daughters the four virgins "which did prophesy".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:91
verses.text: She arrived next at Antipatris, a small town half in ruins, named by Herod after his father Antipater, and at Lydda, now become Diospolis, a place made famous by the raising again of Dorcas and the restoration to health of aeneas.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:92
verses.text: Not far from this are Arimathaea, the village of Joseph who buried the Lord, and Nob, once a city of priests but now the tomb in which their slain bodies rest.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:93
verses.text: Joppa too is hard by, the port of Jonah's flight; which also—if I may introduce a poetic fable—saw Andromeda bound to the rock.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:94
verses.text: Again resuming her journey, she came to Nicopolis, once called Emmaus, where the Lord became known in the breaking of bread; an action by which He dedicated the house of Cleopas as a church.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:95
verses.text: Starting thence she made her way up lower and higher Beth-horon, cities founded by Solomon but subsequently destroyed by several devastating wars; seeing on her right Ajalon and Gibeon where Joshua the son of Nun when fighting against the five kings gave commandments to the sun and moon, where also he condemned the Gibeonites (who by a crafty stratagem had obtained a treaty) to be hewers of wood and drawers of water.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:96
verses.text: At Gibeah also, now a complete ruin, she stopped for a little while remembering its sin, and the cutting of the concubine into pieces, and how in spite of all this three hundred men of the tribe of Benjamin were saved that in after days Paul might be called a Benjamite.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:98
verses.text: To make a long story short, leaving on her left the mausoleum of Helena queen of Adiabene who in time of famine had sent corn to the Jewish people, Paula entered Jerusalem, Jebus, or Salem, that city of three names which after it had sunk to ashes and decay was by aelius Hadrianus restored once more as aelia.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:99
verses.text: And although the proconsul of Palestine, who was an intimate friend of her house, sent forward his apparitors and gave orders to have his official residence placed at her disposal, she chose a humble cell in preference to it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:100
verses.text: Moreover, in visiting the holy places so great was the passion and the enthusiasm she exhibited for each, that she could never have torn herself away from one had she not been eager to visit the rest.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:101
verses.text: Before the Cross she threw herself down in adoration as though she beheld the Lord hanging upon it: and when she entered the tomb which was the scene of the Resurrection she kissed the stone which the angel had rolled away from the door of the sepulchre.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:102
verses.text: Indeed so ardent was her faith that she even licked with her mouth the very spot on which the Lord's body had lain, like one athirst for the river which he has longed for.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:103
verses.text: What tears she shed there, what groans she uttered, and what grief she poured forth, all Jerusalem knows; the Lord also to whom she prayed knows.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:104
verses.text: Going out thence she made the ascent of Zion; a name which signifies either "citadel" or "watch-tower".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:105
verses.text: This formed the city which David formerly stormed and afterwards rebuilt.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:106
verses.text: Of its storming it is written, "Woe to Ariel, to Ariel"—that is, God's lion, (and indeed in those days it was extremely strong)—"the city which David stormed:" and of its rebuilding it is said, "His foundation is in the holy mountains: the Lord loveth the gates of Zion more than all the dwellings of Jacob".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:107
verses.text: He does not mean the gates which we see to-day in dust and ashes; the gates he means are those against which hell prevails not and through which the multitude of those who believe in Christ enter in.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:108
verses.text: There was shewn to her upholding the portico of a church the bloodstained column to which our Lord is said to have been bound when He suffered His scourging.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:109
verses.text: There was shewn to her also the spot where the Holy Spirit came down upon the souls of the one hundred and twenty believers, thus fulfilling the prophecy of Joel.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:111
verses.text: Then, after distributing money to the poor and her fellow-servants so far as her means allowed, she proceeded to Bethlehem stopping only on the right side of the road to visit Rachel's tomb.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:112
verses.text: (Here it was that she gave birth to her son destined to be not what his dying mother called him, Benoni, that is the "Son of my pangs" but as his father in the spirit prophetically named him Benjamin, that is "the Son of the right hand)".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:113
verses.text: After this she came to Bethlehem and entered into the cave where the Saviour was born.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:114
verses.text: Here, when she looked upon the inn made sacred by the virgin and the stall where the ox knew his owner and the ass his master's crib, and where the words of the same prophet had been fulfilled "Blessed is he that soweth beside the waters where the ox and the ass trample the seed under their feet:" when she looked upon these things I say, she protested in my hearing that she could behold with the eyes of faith the infant Lord wrapped in swaddling clothes and crying in the manger, the wise men worshipping Him, the star shining overhead, the virgin mother, the attentive foster-father, the shepherds coming by night to see "the word that was come to pass" and thus even then to consecrate those opening phrases of the evangelist John "In the beginning was the word" and "the word was made flesh".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:115
verses.text: She declared that she could see the slaughtered innocents, the raging Herod, Joseph and Mary fleeing into Egypt; and with a mixture of tears and joy she cried: 'Hail Bethlehem, house of bread, wherein was born that Bread that came down from heaven.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:116
verses.text: Hail Ephratah, land of fruitfulness and of fertility, whose fruit is the Lord Himself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:117
verses.text: Concerning thee has Micah prophesied of old, "Thou Bethlehem Ephratah art not the least among the thousands of Judah, for out of thee shall he come forth unto me that is to be ruler in Israel; whose goings forth have been from of old, from everlasting.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:118
verses.text: Therefore wilt thou give them up, until the time that she which travaileth hath brought forth: then the remnant of his brethren shall return unto the children of Israel".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:119
verses.text: For in thee was born the prince begotten before Lucifer.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:120
verses.text: Whose birth from the Father is before all time: and the cradle of David's race continued in thee, until the virgin brought forth her son and the remnant of the people that believed in Christ returned unto the children of Israel and preached freely to them in words like these: "It was necessary that the word of God should first have been spoken to you; but seeing ye put it from you and judge yourselves unworthy of everlasting life, lo, we turn to the Gentiles".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:121
verses.text: For the Lord hath said: "I am not sent but unto the lost sheep of the house of Israel".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:122
verses.text: At that time also the words of Jacob were fulfilled concerning Him, "A prince shall not depart from Judah nor a lawgiver from between his feet, until He come for whom it is laid up, and He shall be for the expectation of the nations".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:123
verses.text: Well did David swear, well did he make a vow saying: "Surely I will not come into the tabernacle of my house nor go up into my bed: I will not give sleep to mine eyes, or slumber to my eyelids, or rest to the temples of my head, until I find out a place for the Lord, an habitation for the…God of Jacob".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:124
verses.text: And immediately he explained the object of his desire, seeing with prophetic eyes that He would come whom we now believe to have come.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:125
verses.text: "Lo we heard of Him at Ephratah: we found Him in the fields of the wood".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:126
verses.text: The Hebrew word Zo as have learned from your lessons means not her, that is Mary the Lord's mother, but him that is the Lord Himself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:127
verses.text: Therefore he says boldly: "We will go into His tabernacle: we will worship at His footstool".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:128
verses.text: I too, miserable sinner though I am, have been accounted worthy to kiss the manger in which the Lord cried as a babe, and to pray in the cave in which the travailing virgin gave birth to the infant Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:129
verses.text: "This is my rest" for it is my Lord's native place; "here will I dwell" for this spot has my Saviour chosen.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:130
verses.text: "I have prepared a lamp for my Christ".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:131
verses.text: "My soul shall live unto Him and my seed shall serve Him".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:132
verses.text: After this Paula went a short distance down the hill to the tower of Edar, that is 'of the flock,' near which Jacob fed his flocks, and where the shepherds keeping watch by night were privileged to hear the words: "Glory to God in the highest and on earth peace, goodwill toward men".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:133
verses.text: While they were keeping their sheep they found the Lamb of God; whose fleece bright and clean was made wet with the dew of heaven when it was dry upon all the earth beside, and whose blood when sprinkled on the doorposts drove off the destroyer of Egypt and took away the sins of the world.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:135
verses.text: Then immediately quickening her pace she began to move along the old road which leads to Gaza, that is to the 'power' or 'wealth' of God, silently meditating on that type of the Gentiles, the Ethiopian eunuch, who in spite of the prophet changed his skin and whilst he read the old testament found the fountain of the gospel.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:136
verses.text: Next turning to the right she passed from Bethzur to Eshcol which means "a cluster of grapes".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:137
verses.text: It was hence that the spies brought back that marvellous cluster which was the proof of the fertility of the land and a type of Him who says of Himself: "I have trodden the wine press alone; and of the people there was none with me".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:138
verses.text: Shortly afterwards she entered the home of Sarah and beheld the birthplace of Isaac and the traces of Abraham's oak under which he saw Christ's day and was glad.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:139
verses.text: And rising up from thence she went up to Hebron, that is Kirjath-Arba, or the City of the Four Men.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:140
verses.text: These are Abraham, Isaac, Jacob, and the great Adam whom the Hebrews suppose (from the book of Joshua the son of Nun) to be buried there.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:141
verses.text: But many are of opinion that Caleb is the fourth and a monument at one side is pointed out as his.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:142
verses.text: After seeing these places she did not care to go on to Kirjath-sepher, that is "the village of letters;" because despising the letter that killeth she had found the spirit that giveth life.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:143
verses.text: She admired more the upper springs and the nether springs which Othniel the son of Kenaz the son of Jephunneh received in place of a south land and a waterless possession, and by the conducting of which he watered the dry fields of the old covenant.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:144
verses.text: For thus did he typify the redemption which the sinner finds for his old sins in the waters of baptism.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:145
verses.text: On the next day soon after sunrise she stood upon the brow of Capharbarucha, that is, "the house of blessing," the point to which Abraham pursued the Lord when he made intercession with Him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:146
verses.text: And here, as she looked down upon the wide solitude and upon the country once belonging to Sodom and Gomorrah, to Admah and Zeboim, she beheld the balsam vines of Engedi and Zoar.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:147
verses.text: By Zoar I mean that "heifer of three years old" which was formerly called Bela and in Syriac is rendered Zoar that is 'little.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:148
verses.text: ' She called to mind the cave in which Lot found refuge, and with tears in her eyes warned the virgins her companions to beware of "wine wherein is excess;" for it was to this that the Moabites and Ammonites owe their origin.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:150
verses.text: I linger long in the land of the midday sun for it was there and then that the spouse found her bridegroom at rest and Joseph drank wine with his brothers once more.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:151
verses.text: I will return to Jerusalem and, passing through Tekoa the home of Amos, I will look upon the glistening cross of Mount Olivet from which the Saviour made His ascension to the Father.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:152
verses.text: Here year by year a red heifer was burned as a holocaust to the Lord and its ashes were used to purify the children of Israel.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:153
verses.text: Here also according to Ezekiel the Cherubim after leaving the temple founded the church of the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:154
verses.text: After this Paula visited the tomb of Lazarus and beheld the hospitable roof of Mary and Martha, as well as Bethphage, 'the town of the priestly jaws.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:155
verses.text: ' Here it was that a restive foal typical of the Gentiles received the bridle of God, and covered with the garments of the apostles offered its lowly back for Him to sit on.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:156
verses.text: From this she went straight on down the hill to Jericho thinking of the wounded man in the gospel, of the savagery of the priests and Levites who passed him by, and of the kindness of the Samaritan, that is, the guardian, who placed the half-dead man upon his own beast and brought him down to the inn of the church.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:157
verses.text: She noticed the place called Adomim or the Place of Blood, so-called because much blood was shed there in the frequent incursions of marauders.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:158
verses.text: She beheld also the sycamore tree of Zacchaeus, by which is signified the good works of repentance whereby he trod under foot his former sins of bloodshed and rapine, and from which he saw the Most High as from a pinnacle of virtue.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:159
verses.text: She was shewn too the spot by the wayside where the blind men sat who, receiving their sight from the Lord, became types of the two peoples who should believe upon Him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:160
verses.text: Then entering Jericho she saw the city which Hiel founded in Abiram his firstborn and of which he set up the gates in his youngest son Segub.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:161
verses.text: She looked upon the camp of Gilgal and the hill of the foreskins suggestive of the mystery of the second circumcision: and she gazed at the twelve stones brought thither out of the bed of Jordan to be symbols of those twelve foundations on which are written the names of the twelve apostles.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:162
verses.text: She saw also that fountain of the Law most bitter and barren which the true Elisha healed by his wisdom changing it into a well sweet and fertilising.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:163
verses.text: Scarcely had the night passed away when burning with eagerness she hastened to the Jordan, stood by the brink of the river, and as the sun rose recalled to mind the rising of the sun of righteousness; how the priest's feet stood firm in the middle of the river-bed; how afterwards at the command of Elijah and Elisha the waters were divided hither and thither and made way for them to pass; and again how the Lord had cleansed by His baptism waters which the deluge had polluted and the destruction of mankind had defiled.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:165
verses.text: It would be tedious were I tell of the valley of Achor, that is, of 'trouble and crowds,' where theft and covetousness were condemned; and of Bethel, 'the house of God,' where Jacob poor and destitute slept upon the bare ground.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:166
verses.text: Here it was that, having set beneath his head a stone which in Zechariah is described as having seven eyes and in Isaiah is spoken of as a corner-stone, he beheld a ladder reaching up to heaven; yes, and the Lord standing high above it holding out His hand to such as were ascending and hurling from on high such as were careless.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:167
verses.text: Also when she was in Mount Ephraim she made pilgrimages to the tombs of Joshua the son of Nun and of Eleazar the son of Aaron the priest, exactly opposite the one to the other; that of Joshua being built at Timnath-serah "on the north side of the hill of Gaash," and that of Eleazar "in a hill that pertained to Phinehas his son".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:168
verses.text: She was somewhat surprised to find that he who had had the distribution of the land in his own hands had selected for himself portions uneven and rocky.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:169
verses.text: What shall I say about Shiloh where a ruined altar is still shewn to-day, and where the tribe of Benjamin anticipated Romulus in the rape of the Sabine women? Passing by Shechem (not Sychar as many wrongly read) or as it is now called Neapolis, she entered the church built upon the side of Mount Gerizim around Jacob's well; that well where the Lord was sitting when hungry and thirsty He was refreshed by the faith of the woman of Samaria.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:170
verses.text: Forsaking her five husbands by whom are intended the five books of Moses, and that sixth not a husband of whom she boasted, to wit the false teacher Dositheus, she found the true Messiah and the true Saviour.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:171
verses.text: Turning away thence Paula saw the tombs of the twelve patriarchs, and Samaria which in honour of Augustus Herod renamed Augusta or in Greek Sebaste.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:172
verses.text: There lie the prophets Elisha and Obadiah and John the Baptist than whom there is not a greater among those that are born of women.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:173
verses.text: And here she was filled with terror by the marvels she beheld; for she saw demons screaming under different tortures before the tombs of the saints, and men howling like wolves, baying like dogs, roaring like lions, hissing like serpents and bellowing like bulls.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:174
verses.text: They twisted their heads and bent them backwards until they touched the ground; women too were suspended head downward and their clothes did not fall off.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:175
verses.text: Paula pitied them all, and shedding tears over them prayed Christ to have mercy on them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:176
verses.text: And weak as she was she climbed the mountain on foot; for in two of its caves Obadiah in a time of persecution and famine had fed a hundred prophets with bread and water.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:177
verses.text: Then she passed quickly through Nazareth the nursery of the Lord; Cana and Capernaum familiar with the signs wrought by Him; the lake of Tiberias sanctified by His voyages upon it; the wilderness where countless Gentiles were satisfied with a few loaves while the twelve baskets of the tribes of Israel were filled with the fragments left by them that had eaten.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:178
verses.text: She made the ascent of mount Tabor whereon the Lord was transfigured.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:179
verses.text: In the distance she beheld the range of Hermon; and the wide stretching plains of Galilee where Sisera and all his host had once been overcome by Barak; and the torrent Kishon separating the level ground into two parts.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:180
verses.text: Hard by also the town of Nain was pointed out to her, where the widow's son was raised.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:181
verses.text: Time would fail me sooner than speech were I to recount all the places to which the revered Paula was carried by her incredible faith.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:183
verses.text: I will now pass on to Egypt, pausing for a while on the way at Socoh, and at Samson's well which he clave in the hollow place that was in the jaw.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:184
verses.text: Here I will lave my parched lips and refresh myself before visiting Moresheth; in old days famed for the tomb of the prophet Micah, and now for its church.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:185
verses.text: Then skirting the country of the Horites and Gittites, Mareshah, Edom, and Lachish, and traversing the lonely wastes of the desert where the tracks of the traveller are lost in the yielding sand, I will come to the river of Egypt called Sihor, that is "the muddy river," and go through the five cities of Egypt which speak the language of Canaan, and through the land of Goshen and the plains of Zoan on which God wrought his marvellous works.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:186
verses.text: And I will visit the city of No, which has since become Alexandria; and Nitria, the town of the Lord, where day by day the filth of multitudes is washed away with the pure nitre of virtue.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:187
verses.text: No sooner did Paula come in sight of it than there came to meet her the reverend and estimable bishop, the confessor Isidore, accompanied by countless multitudes of monks many of whom were of priestly or of Levitical rank.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:188
verses.text: On seeing these Paula rejoiced to behold the Lord's glory manifested in them; but protested that she had no claim to be received with such honour.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:189
verses.text: Need I speak of the Macarii, Arsenius, Serapion, or other pillars of Christ! Was there any cell that she did not enter? Or any man at whose feet she did not throw herself? In each of His saints she believed that she saw Christ Himself; and whatever she bestowed upon them she rejoiced to feel that she had bestowed it upon the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:190
verses.text: Her enthusiasm was wonderful and her endurance scarcely credible in a woman.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:191
verses.text: Forgetful of her sex and of her weakness she even desired to make her abode, together with the girls who accompanied her, among these thousands of monks.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:192
verses.text: And, as they were all willing to welcome her, she might perhaps have sought and obtained permission to do so; had she not been drawn away by a still greater passion for the holy places.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:193
verses.text: Coming by sea from Pelusium to Maioma on account of the great heat, she returned so rapidly that you would have thought her a bird.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:194
verses.text: Not long afterwards, making up her mind to dwell permanently in holy Bethlehem, she took up her abode for three years in a miserable hostelry; till she could build the requisite cells and monastic buildings, to say nothing of a guest house for passing travellers where they might find the welcome which Mary and Joseph had missed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:195
verses.text: At this point I conclude my narrative of the journeys that she made accompanied by Eustochium and many other virgins.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:197
verses.text: I am now free to describe at greater length the virtue which was her peculiar charm; and in setting forth this I call God to witness that I am no flatterer.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:198
verses.text: I add nothing.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:199
verses.text: I exaggerate nothing.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:200
verses.text: On the contrary I tone down much that I may not appear to relate incredibilities.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:201
verses.text: My carping critics must not insinuate that I am drawing on my imagination or decking Paula, like aesop's crow, with the fine feathers of other birds.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:202
verses.text: Humility is the first of Christian graces, and hers was so pronounced that one who had never seen her, and who on account of her celebrity had desired to see her, would have believed that he saw not her but the lowest of her maids.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:203
verses.text: When she was surrounded by companies of virgins she was always the least remarkable in dress, in speech, in gesture, and in gait.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:204
verses.text: From the time that her husband died until she fell asleep herself she never sat at meat with a man, even though she might know him to stand upon the pinnacle of the episcopate.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:205
verses.text: She never entered a bath except when dangerously ill.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:206
verses.text: Even in the severest fever she rested not on an ordinary bed but on the hard ground covered only with a mat of goat's hair; if that can be called rest which made day and night alike a time of almost unbroken prayer.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:207
verses.text: Well did she fulfil the words of the psalter: "All the night make I my bed to swim; I water my couch with my tears"! Her tears welled forth as it were from fountains, and she lamented her slightest faults as if they were sins of the deepest dye.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:208
verses.text: Constantly did I warn her to spare her eyes and to keep them for the reading of the gospel; but she only said: 'I must disfigure that face which contrary to God's commandment I have painted with rouge, white lead, and antimony.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:209
verses.text: I must mortify that body which has been given up to many pleasures.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:210
verses.text: I must make up for my long laughter by constant weeping.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:211
verses.text: I must exchange my soft linen and costly silks for rough goat's hair.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:212
verses.text: I who have pleased my husband and the world in the past, desire now to please Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:213
verses.text: ' Were I among her great and signal virtues to select her chastity as a subject of praise, my words would seem superfluous; for, even when she was still in the world, she set an example to all the matrons of Rome, and bore herself so admirably that the most slanderous never ventured to couple scandal with her name.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:214
verses.text: No mind could be more considerate than hers, or none kinder towards the lowly.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:215
verses.text: She did not court the powerful; at the same time, if the proud and the vainglorious sought her, she did not turn from them with disdain.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:216
verses.text: If she saw a poor man, she supported him: and if she saw a rich one, she urged him to do good.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:217
verses.text: Her liberality alone knew no bounds.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:218
verses.text: Indeed, so anxious was she to turn no needy person away that she borrowed money at interest and often contracted new loans to pay off old ones.
