verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:219
verses.text: I was wrong, I admit; but when I saw her so profuse in giving, I reproved her alleging the apostle's words: "I mean not that other men be eased and ye burthened; but by an equality that now at this time your abundance may be a supply for their want, that their abundance also may be a supply for your want".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:220
verses.text: I quoted from the gospel the Saviour's words: "he that hath two coats, let him impart one of them to him that hath none"; and I warned her that she might not always have means to do as she would wish.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:221
verses.text: Other arguments I adduced to the same purpose; but with admirable modesty and brevity she overruled them all.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:222
verses.text: "God is my witness," she said, "that what I do I do for His sake.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:223
verses.text: My prayer is that I may die a beggar not leaving a penny to my daughter and indebted to strangers for my winding sheet".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:224
verses.text: She then concluded with these words: "I, if I beg, shall find many to give to me; but if this beggar does not obtain help from me who by borrowing can give it to him, he will die; and if he dies, of whom will his soul be required?" I wished her to be more careful in managing her concerns, but she with a faith more glowing than mine clave to the Saviour with her whole heart and poor in spirit followed the Lord in His poverty, giving back to Him what she had received and becoming poor for His sake.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:225
verses.text: She obtained her wish at last and died leaving her daughter overwhelmed with a mass of debt.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:226
verses.text: This Eustochium still owes and indeed cannot hope to pay off by her own exertions; only the mercy of Christ can free her from it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:228
verses.text: Many married ladies make it a habit to confer gifts upon their own trumpeters, and while they are extremely profuse to a few, withhold all help from the many.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:229
verses.text: From this fault Paula was altogether free.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:230
verses.text: She gave her money to each according as each had need, not ministering to self-indulgence but relieving want.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:231
verses.text: No poor person went away from her empty handed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:232
verses.text: And all this she was enabled to do not by the greatness of her wealth but by her careful management of it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:233
verses.text: She constantly had on her lips such phrases as these: "Blessed are the merciful for they shall obtain mercy:" and "water will quench a flaming fire; and alms maketh an atonement for sins;" and "make to yourselves friends of the mammon of unrighteousness that…they may receive you into everlasting habitations;" and "give alms…and behold all things are clean unto you;" and Daniel's words to King Nebuchadnezzar in which he admonished him to redeem his sins by almsgiving.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:234
verses.text: She wished to spend her money not upon these stones, that shall pass away with the earth and the world, but upon those living stones, which roll over the earth; of which in the apocalypse of John the city of the great king is built; of which also the scripture tells us that they shall be changed into sapphire and emerald and jasper and other gems.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:236
verses.text: But these qualities she may well share with a few others and the devil knows that it is not in these that the highest virtue consists.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:237
verses.text: For, when Job has lost his substance and when his house and children have been destroyed, Satan says to the Lord: "Skin for skin, yea all that a man hath, will he give for his life.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:238
verses.text: But put forth thine hand now and touch his bone and his flesh, and he will curse thee to thy face".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:239
verses.text: We know that many persons while they have given alms have yet given nothing which touches their bodily comfort; and while they have held out a helping hand to those in need are themselves overcome with sensual indulgences; they whitewash the outside but within they are "full of dead men's bones".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:240
verses.text: Paula was not one of these.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:241
verses.text: Her self-restraint was so great as to be almost immoderate; and her fasts and labours were so severe as almost to weaken her constitution.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:242
verses.text: Except on feast days she would scarcely ever take oil with her food; a fact from which may be judged what she thought of wine, sauce, fish, honey, milk, eggs, and other things agreeable to the palate.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:243
verses.text: Some persons believe that in taking these they are extremely frugal; and, even if they surfeit themselves with them, they still fancy their chastity safe.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:245
verses.text: Envy always follows in the track of virtue: as Horace says, it is ever the mountain top that is smitten by the lightning.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:246
verses.text: It is not surprising that I declare this of men and women, when the jealousy of the Pharisees succeeded in crucifying our Lord Himself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:247
verses.text: All the saints have had illwishers, and even Paradise was not free from the serpent through whose malice death came into the world.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:248
verses.text: So the Lord stirred up against Paula Hadad the Edomite to buffet her that she might not be exalted, and warned her frequently by the thorn in her flesh not to be elated by the greatness of her own virtues or to fancy that, compared with other women, she had attained the summit of perfection.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:249
verses.text: For my part I used to say that it was best to give in to rancour and to retire before passion.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:250
verses.text: So Jacob dealt with his brother Esau; so David met the unrelenting persecution of Saul.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:251
verses.text: I reminded her how the first of these fled into Mesopotamia; and how the second surrendered himself to the Philistines, and chose to submit to foreign foes rather than to enemies at home.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:252
verses.text: She however replied as follows:—'Your suggestion would be a wise one if the devil did not everywhere fight against God's servants and handmaidens, and did he not always precede the fugitives to their chosen refuges.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:253
verses.text: Moreover, I am deterred from accepting it by my love for the holy places; and I cannot find another Bethlehem elsewhere.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:254
verses.text: Why may I not by my patience conquer this ill will? Why may I not by my humility break down this pride, and when I am smitten on the one cheek offer to the smiter the other? Surely the apostle Paul says "Overcome evil with good".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:255
verses.text: Did not the apostles glory when they suffered reproach for the Lord's sake? Did not even the Saviour humble Himself, taking the form of a servant and being made obedient to the Father unto death, even the death of the cross, that He might save us by His passion? If Job had not fought the battle and won the victory, he would never have received the crown of righteousness, or have heard the Lord say: "Thinkest thou that I have spoken unto thee for aught else than this, that thou mightest appear righteous".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:256
verses.text: In the gospel those only are said to be blessed who suffer persecution for righteousness' sake.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:257
verses.text: My conscience is at rest, and I know that it is not from any fault of mine that I am suffering; moreover affliction in this world is a ground for expecting a reward hereafter.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:258
verses.text: ' When the enemy was more than usually forward and ventured to reproach her to her face, she used to chant the words of the psalter: "While the wicked was before me, I was dumb with silence; I held my peace even from good:" and again, "I as a deaf man heard not; and I was as a dumb man that openeth not his mouth:" and "I was as a man that heareth not, and in whose mouth are no reproofs".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:259
verses.text: When she felt herself tempted, she dwelt upon the words in Deuteronomy: "The Lord your God proveth you, to know whether ye love the Lord your God with all your heart and with all your soul".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:260
verses.text: In tribulations and afflictions she turned to the splendid language of Isaiah: "Ye that are weaned from the milk and drawn from the breasts, look for tribulation upon tribulation, for hope also upon hope: yet a little while must these things be by reason of the malice of the lips and by reason of a spiteful tongue".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:261
verses.text: This passage of scripture she explained for her own consolation as meaning that the weaned, that is, those who have come to full age, must endure tribulation upon tribulation that they may be accounted worthy to receive hope upon hope.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:262
verses.text: She recalled to mind also the words of the apostle, "we glory in tribulations also: knowing that tribulation worketh patience, and patience experience, and experience hope: and hope maketh not ashamed" and "though our outward man perish, yet the inward man is renewed day by day": and "our light affliction which is but for a moment worketh in us an eternal weight of glory; while we look not at the things which are seen but at the things which are not seen: for the things which are seen are temporal but the things which are not seen are eternal".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:263
verses.text: She used to say that, although to human impatience the time might seem slow in coming, yet that it would not be long but that presently help would come from God who says: "In an acceptable time have I heard thee, and in a day of salvation have I helped thee".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:264
verses.text: We ought not, she declared, to dread the deceitful lips and tongues of the wicked, for we rejoice in the aid of the Lord who warns us by His prophet: "fear ye not the reproach of men, neither be ye afraid of their revilings; for the moth shall eat them up like a garment, and the worm shall eat them like wool": and she quoted His own words, "In your patience ye shall win your souls": as well as those of the apostle, "the sufferings of this present time are not worthy to be compared with the glory which shall be revealed in us": and in another place, "we are to suffer affliction" that we may be patient in all things that befall us, for "he that is slow to wrath is of great understanding: but he that is hasty of spirit exalteth folly".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:266
verses.text: In her frequent sicknesses and infirmities she used to say, "when I am weak, then am I strong:" "we have our treasure in earthen vessels" until "this corruptible shall have put on incorruption and this mortal shall have put on immortality" and again "as the sufferings of Christ abound in us, so our consolation also aboundeth by Christ:" and then as ye are partakers of the sufferings, so shall ye be also of the consolation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:267
verses.text: In sorrow she used to sing: "Why art thou cast down, O my soul? and why art thou disquieted within me? hope thou in God for I shall yet praise him who is the health of my countenance and my God".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:268
verses.text: In the hour of danger she used to say: "If any man will come after me, let him deny himself and take up his cross and follow me:" and again "whosoever will save his life shall lose it," and "whosoever will lose his life for my sake the same shall save it".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:269
verses.text: When the exhaustion of her substance and the ruin of her property were announced to her she only said: "What is a man profited, if he shall gain the whole world and lose his own soul? or what shall a man give in exchange for his soul:" and "naked came I out of my mother's womb, and naked shall I return thither.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:270
verses.text: The Lord gave, and the Lord hath taken away: blessed be the name of the Lord:" and Saint John's words, "Love not the world neither the things that are in the world.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:271
verses.text: For all that is in the world, the lust of the flesh, and the lust of the eyes and the pride of life, is not of the Father but is of the world.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:272
verses.text: And the world passeth away and the lust thereof".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:273
verses.text: I know that when word was sent to her of the serious illnesses of her children and particularly of Toxotius whom she dearly loved, she first by her self-control fulfilled the saying: "I was troubled and I did not speak," and then cried out in the words of scripture, "He that loveth son or daughter more than me is not worthy of me".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:274
verses.text: And she prayed to the Lord and said: Lord "preserve thou the children of those that are appointed to die," that is, of those who for thy sake every day die bodily.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:275
verses.text: I am aware that a talebearer—a class of persons who do a great deal of harm—once told her as a kindness that owing to her great fervour in virtue some people thought her mad and declared that something should be done for her head.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:276
verses.text: She replied in the words of the apostle, "we are made a spectacle unto the world and to angels and to men," and "we are fools for Christ's sake" but "the foolishness of God is wiser than men".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:277
verses.text: It is for this reason she said that even the Saviour says to the Father, "Thou knowest my foolishness," and again "I am as a wonder unto many, but thou art my strong refuge".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:278
verses.text: "I was as a beast before thee; nevertheless I am continually with thee".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:279
verses.text: In the gospel we read that even His kinsfolk desired to bind Him as one of weak mind.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:280
verses.text: His opponents also reviled him saying "thou art a Samaritan and hast a devil," and another time "he casteth out devils through Beelzebub the chief of the devils".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:281
verses.text: But let us, she continued, listen to the exhortation of the apostle, "Our rejoicing is this, the testimony of our conscience that in simplicity and sincerity…by the grace of God we have had our conversation in the world".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:282
verses.text: And let us hear the Lord when He says to His apostles, "If ye were of the world the world would love his own; but because ye are not of the world…therefore the world hateth you".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:283
verses.text: And then she turned to the Lord Himself, saying, "Thou knowest the secrets of the heart," and "all this is come upon us; yet have we not forgotten thee, neither have we dealt falsely in thy covenant; our heart is not turned back".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:284
verses.text: "Yea for thy sake are we killed all the day long; we are counted as sheep for the slaughter".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:285
verses.text: But "the Lord is on my side: I will not fear what man doeth unto me".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:286
verses.text: She had read the words of Solomon, "My son, honour the Lord and thou shalt be made strong; and beside the Lord fear thou no man".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:287
verses.text: These passages and others like them she used as God's armour against the assaults of wickedness, and particularly to defend herself against the furious onslaughts of envy; and thus by patiently enduring wrongs she soothed the violence of the most savage breasts.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:288
verses.text: Down to the very day of her death two things were conspicuous in her life, one her great patience and the other the jealousy which was manifested towards her.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:289
verses.text: Now jealousy gnaws the heart of him who harbours it: and while it strives to injure its rival raves with all the force of its fury against itself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:291
verses.text: I shall now describe the order of her monastery and the method by which she turned the continence of saintly souls to her own profit.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:292
verses.text: She sowed carnal things that she might reap spiritual things; she gave earthly things that she might receive heavenly things; she forewent things temporal that she might in their stead obtain things eternal.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:293
verses.text: Besides establishing a monastery for men, the charge of which she left to men, she divided into three companies and monasteries the numerous virgins whom she had gathered out of different provinces, some of whom are of noble birth while others belonged to the middle or lower classes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:294
verses.text: But, although they worked and had their meals separately from each other, these three companies met together for psalm-singing and prayer.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:295
verses.text: After the chanting of the Alleluia—the signal by which they were summoned to the Collect—no one was permitted to remain behind.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:296
verses.text: But either first or among the first Paula used to await the arrival of the rest, urging them to diligence rather by her own modest example than by motives of fear.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:297
verses.text: At dawn, at the third, sixth, and ninth hours, at evening, and at midnight they recited the psalter each in turn.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:298
verses.text: No sister was allowed to be ignorant of the psalms, and all had every day to learn a certain portion of the holy scriptures.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:299
verses.text: On the Lord's day only they proceeded to the church beside which they lived, each company following its own mother-superior.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:300
verses.text: Returning home in the same order, they then devoted themselves to their allotted tasks, and made garments either for themselves or else for others.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:301
verses.text: If a virgin was of noble birth, she was not allowed to have an attendant belonging to her own household lest her maid having her mind full of the doings of old days and of the license of childhood might by constant converse open old wounds and renew former errors.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:302
verses.text: All the sisters were clothed alike.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:303
verses.text: Linen was not used except for drying the hands.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:304
verses.text: So strictly did Paula separate them from men that she would not allow even eunuchs to approach them; lest she should give occasion to slanderous tongues (always ready to cavil at the religious) to console themselves for their own misdoing.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:305
verses.text: When a sister was backward in coming to the recitation of the psalms or shewed herself remiss in her work, Paula used to approach her in different ways.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:306
verses.text: Was she quick-tempered? Paula coaxed her.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:307
verses.text: Was she phlegmatic? Paula chid her, copying the example of the apostle who said: "What will ye? Shall I come to you with a rod or in love and in the spirit of meekness?" Apart from food and raiment she allowed no one to have anything she could call her own, for Paul had said, "Having food and raiment let us be therewith content".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:308
verses.text: She was afraid lest the custom of having more should breed covetousness in them; an appetite which no wealth can satisfy, for the more it has the more it requires, and neither opulence nor indigence is able to diminish it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:309
verses.text: When the sisters quarrelled one with another she reconciled them with soothing words.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:310
verses.text: If the younger ones were troubled with fleshly desires, she broke their force by imposing redoubled fasts; for she wished her virgins to be ill in body rather than to suffer in soul.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:311
verses.text: If she chanced to notice any sister too attentive to her dress, she reproved her for her error with knitted brows and severe looks, saying; "a clean body and a clean dress mean an unclean soul.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:312
verses.text: A virgin's lips should never utter an improper or an impure word, for such indicate a lascivious mind and by the outward man the faults of the inward are made manifest".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:313
verses.text: When she saw a sister verbose and talkative or forward and taking pleasure in quarrels, and when she found after frequent admonitions that the offender shewed no signs of improvement; she placed her among the lowest of the sisters and outside their society, ordering her to pray at the door of the refectory instead of with the rest, and commanding her to take her food by herself, in the hope that where rebuke had failed shame might bring about a reformation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:314
verses.text: The sin of theft she loathed as if it were sacrilege; and that which among men of the world is counted little or nothing she declared to be in a monastery a crime of the deepest dye.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:315
verses.text: How shall I describe her kindness and attention towards the sick or the wonderful care and devotion with which she nursed them? Yet, although when others were sick she freely gave them every indulgence, and even allowed them to eat meat; when she fell ill herself, she made no concessions to her own weakness, and seemed unfairly to change in her own case to harshness the kindness which she was always ready to shew to others.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:317
verses.text: No young girl of sound and vigorous constitution could have delivered herself up to a regimen so rigid as that imposed upon herself by Paula whose physical powers age had impaired and enfeebled.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:318
verses.text: I admit that in this she was too determined, refusing to spare herself or to listen to advice.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:319
verses.text: I will relate what I know to be a fact.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:320
verses.text: In the extreme heat of the month of July she was once attacked by a violent fever and we despaired of her life.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:321
verses.text: However by God's mercy she rallied, and the doctors urged upon her the necessity of taking a little light wine to accelerate her recovery; saying that if she continued to drink water they feared that she might become dropsical.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:322
verses.text: I on my side secretly appealed to the blessed pope Epiphanius to admonish, nay even to compel her, to take the wine.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:323
verses.text: But she with her usual sagacity and quickness at once perceived the stratagem, and with a smile let him see that the advice he was giving her was after all not his but mine.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:324
verses.text: Not to waste more words, the blessed prelate after many exhortations left her chamber; and, when I asked him what he had accomplished, replied, "Only this that old as I am I have been almost persuaded to drink no more wine".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:325
verses.text: I relate this story not because I approve of persons rashly taking upon themselves burthens beyond their strength (for does not the scripture say: "Burden not thyself above thy power"?) but because I wish from this quality of perseverance in her to shew the passion of her mind and the yearning of her believing soul; both of which made her sing in David's words, "My soul thirsteth for thee, my flesh longeth after thee".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:326
verses.text: Difficult as it is always to avoid extremes, the philosophers are quite right in their opinion that virtue is a mean and vice an excess, or as we may express it in one short sentence "In nothing too much".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:327
verses.text: While thus unyielding in her contempt for food Paula was easily moved to sorrow and felt crushed by the deaths of her kinsfolk, especially those of her children.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:328
verses.text: When one after another her husband and her daughters fell asleep, on each occasion the shock of their loss endangered her life.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:329
verses.text: And although she signed her mouth and her breast with the sign of the cross, and endeavoured thus to alleviate a mother's grief; her feelings overpowered her and her maternal instincts were too much for her confiding mind.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:330
verses.text: Thus while her intellect retained its mastery she was overcome by sheer physical weakness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:331
verses.text: On one occasion a sickness seized her and clung to her so long that it brought anxiety to us and danger to herself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:332
verses.text: Yet even then she was full of joy and repeated every moment the apostle's words: "O wretched man that I am! who shall deliver me from the body of this death?"  The careful reader may say that my words are an invective rather than an eulogy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:333
verses.text: I call that Jesus whom she served and whom I desire to serve to be my witness that so far from unduly eulogizing her or depreciating her I tell the truth about her as one Christian writing of another; that I am writing a memoir and not a panegyric, and that what were faults in her might well be virtues in others less saintly.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:334
verses.text: I speak thus of her faults to satisfy my own feelings and the passionate regret of us her brothers and sisters, who all of us love her still and all of us deplore her loss.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:336
verses.text: However, she has finished her course, she has kept the faith, and now she enjoys the crown of righteousness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:337
verses.text: She follows the Lamb whithersoever he goes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:338
verses.text: She is filled now because once she was hungry.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:339
verses.text: With joy does she sing: "as we have heard, so have we seen in the city of the Lord of hosts, in the city of our God".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:340
verses.text: O blessed change! Once she wept but now laughs for evermore.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:341
verses.text: Once she despised the broken cisterns of which the prophet speaks; but now she has found in the Lord a fountain of life.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:342
verses.text: Once she wore haircloth but now she is clothed in white raiment, and can say: "thou hast put off my sackcloth, and girded me with gladness".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:343
verses.text: Once she ate ashes like bread and mingled her drink with weeping; saying "my tears have been my meat day and night;" but now for all time she eats the bread of angels and sings: "O taste and see that the Lord is good;" and "my heart is overflowing with a goodly matter; I speak the things which I have made touching the king".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:344
verses.text: She now sees fulfilled Isaiah's words, or rather those of the Lord speaking through Isaiah: "Behold, my servants shall eat but ye shall be hungry: behold, my servants shall drink but ye shall be thirsty: behold, my servants shall rejoice, but ye shall be ashamed: behold, my servants shall sing for joy of heart, but ye shall cry for sorrow of heart, and shall howl for vexation of spirit".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:345
verses.text: I have said that she always shunned the broken cisterns: she did so that she might find in the Lord a fountain of life, and that she might rejoice and sing: "as the hart panteth after the waterbrooks, so panteth my soul after Thee, O God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:346
verses.text: When shall I come and appear before God?"  23.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:347
verses.text: I must briefly mention the manner in which she avoided the foul cisterns of the heretics whom she regarded as no better than heathen.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:348
verses.text: A certain cunning knave, in his own estimation both learned and clever, began without my knowledge to put to her such questions as these: What sin has an infant committed that it should be seized by the devil? Shall we be young or old when we rise again? If we die young and rise young, we shall after the resurrection require to have nurses.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:349
verses.text: If however we die young and rise old, the dead will not rise again at all: they will be transformed into new beings.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:350
verses.text: Will there be a distinction of sexes in the next world? Or will there be no such distinction? If the distinction continues, there will be wedlock and sexual intercourse and procreation of children.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:351
verses.text: If however it does not continue, the bodies that rise again will not be the same.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:352
verses.text: For, he argued, "the earthy tabernacle weigheth down the mind that museth upon many things," but the bodies that we shall have in heaven will be subtle and spiritual according to the words of the apostle: "it is sown a natural body: it is raised a spiritual body".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:353
verses.text: From all of which considerations he sought to prove that rational creatures have been for their faults and previous sins subjected to bodily conditions; and that according to the nature and guilt of their transgression they are born in this or that state of life.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:354
verses.text: Some, he said, rejoice in sound bodies and wealthy and noble parents; others have for their portion diseased frames and poverty stricken homes; and by imprisonment in the present world and in bodies pay the penalty of their former sins.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:355
verses.text: Paula listened and reported what she heard to me, at the same time pointing out the man.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:356
verses.text: Thus upon me was laid the task of opposing this most noxious viper and deadly pest.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:357
verses.text: It is of such that the Psalmist speaks when he writes: "deliver not the soul of thy turtle dove unto the wild beast," and "Rebuke the wild beast of the reeds;" creatures who write iniquity and speak lies against the Lord and lift up their mouths against the Most High.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:358
verses.text: As the fellow had tried to deceive Paula, I at her request went to him, and by asking him a few questions involved him in a dilemma.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:359
verses.text: Do you believe, said I, that there will be a resurrection of the dead or do you disbelieve? He replied, I believe.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:360
verses.text: I went on: Will the bodies that rise again be the same or different? He said, The same.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:361
verses.text: Then I asked: What of their sex? Will that remain unaltered or will it be changed? At this question he became silent and swayed his head this way and that as a serpent does to avoid being struck.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:362
verses.text: Accordingly I continued, As you have nothing to say I will answer for you and will draw the conclusion from your premises.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:363
verses.text: If the woman shall not rise again as a woman nor the man as a man, there will be no resurrection of the dead.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:364
verses.text: For the body is made up of sex and members.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:365
verses.text: But if there shall be no sex and no members what will become of the resurrection of the body, which cannot exist without sex and members? And if there shall be no resurrection of the body, there can be no resurrection of the dead.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:366
verses.text: But as to your objection taken from marriage, that, if the members shall remain the same, marriage must inevitably be allowed; it is disposed of by the Saviour's words: "ye do err not knowing the scriptures nor the power of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:367
verses.text: For in the resurrection they neither marry nor are given in marriage but are as the angels".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:368
verses.text: When it is said that they neither marry nor are given in marriage, the distinction of sex is shewn to persist.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:369
verses.text: For no one says of things which have no capacity for marriage such as a stick or a stone that they neither marry nor are given in marriage; but this may well be said of those who while they can marry yet abstain from doing so by their own virtue and by the grace of Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:370
verses.text: But if you cavil at this and say, how shall we in that case be like the angels with whom there is neither male nor female, hear my answer in brief as follows.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:371
verses.text: What the Lord promises to us is not the nature of angels but their mode of life and their bliss.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:372
verses.text: And therefore John the Baptist is called an angel even before he is beheaded, and all God's holy men and virgins manifest in themselves even in this world the life of angels.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:373
verses.text: When it is said "ye shall be like the angels," likeness only is promised and not a change of nature.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:375
verses.text: And now do you in your turn answer me these questions.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:376
verses.text: How do you explain the fact that Thomas felt the hands of the risen Lord and beheld His side pierced by the spear? And the fact that Peter saw the Lord standing on the shore and eating a piece of a roasted fish and a honeycomb.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:377
verses.text: If He stood, He must certainly have had feet.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:378
verses.text: If He pointed to His wounded side He must have also had chest and belly for to these the sides are attached and without them they cannot be.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:379
verses.text: If He spoke, He must have used a tongue and palate and teeth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:380
verses.text: For as the bow strikes the strings, so to produce vocal sound does the tongue come in contact with the teeth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:381
verses.text: If His hands were felt, it follows that He must have had arms as well.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:382
verses.text: Since therefore it is admitted that He had all the members which go to make up the body, He must have also had the whole body formed of them, and that not a woman's but a man's; that is to say, He rose again in the sex in which He died.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:383
verses.text: And if you cavil farther and say: We shall eat then, I suppose, after the resurrection; or How can a solid and material body enter in contrary to its nature through closed doors? you shall receive from me this reply.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:384
verses.text: Do not for this matter of food find fault with belief in the resurrection: for our Lord after raising the daughter of the ruler of the synagogue commanded food to be given her.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:385
verses.text: And Lazarus who had been dead four days is described as sitting at meat with Him, the object in both cases being to shew that the resurrection was real and not merely apparent.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:386
verses.text: And if from our Lord's entering in through closed doors you strive to prove that His body was spiritual and aerial, He must have had this spiritual body even before He suffered; since—contrary to the nature of heavy bodies—He was able to walk upon the sea.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:387
verses.text: The apostle Peter also must be believed to have had a spiritual body for he also walked upon the waters with buoyant step.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:388
verses.text: The true explanation is that when anything is done against nature, it is a manifestation of God's might and power.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:389
verses.text: And to shew plainly that in these great signs our attention is asked not to a change in nature but to the almighty power of God, he who by faith had walked on water began to sink for the want of it and would have done so had not the Lord lifted him up with the reproving words, "O thou of little faith wherefore didst thou doubt?" I wonder that you can display such effrontery when the Lord Himself said, "reach hither thy finger, and behold my hands; and reach hither thy hand and thrust it into my side: and be not faithless but believing," and in another place, "behold my hands and my feet that it is I myself: handle me and see; for a spirit hath not flesh and bones as ye see me have.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:390
verses.text: And when he had thus spoken he shewed them his hands and his feet".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:391
verses.text: You hear Him speak of bones and flesh, of feet and hands; and yet you want to palm off on me the bubbles and airy nothings of which the stoics rave!  25.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:392
verses.text: Moreover, if you ask how it is that a mere infant which has never sinned is seized by the devil, or at what age we shall rise again seeing that we die at different ages; my only answer—an unwelcome one, I fancy—will be in the words of scripture: "The judgments of God are a great deep," and "O the depth of the riches both of the wisdom and knowledge of God! how unsearchable are his judgments, and his ways past finding out! For who hath known the mind of the Lord? or who hath been his counsellor?" No difference of age can affect the reality of the body.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:393
verses.text: Although our frames are in a perpetual flux and lose or gain daily, these changes do not make us different individuals.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:394
verses.text: I was not one person at ten years old, another at thirty and another at fifty; nor am I another now when all my head is gray.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:395
verses.text: According to the traditions of the church and the teaching of the apostle Paul, the answer must be this; that we shall rise as perfect men in the measure of the stature of the fulness of Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:396
verses.text: At this age the Jews suppose Adam to have been created and at this age we read that the Lord and Saviour rose again.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:397
verses.text: Many other arguments did I adduce from both testaments to stifle the outcry of this heretic.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:399
verses.text: From that day forward so profoundly did Paula commence to loathe the man—and all who agreed with him in his doctrines—that she publicly proclaimed them as enemies of the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:400
verses.text: I have related this incident less with the design of confuting in a few words a heresy which would require volumes to confute it, than with the object of shewing the great faith of this saintly woman who preferred to subject herself to perpetual hostility from men rather than by friendships hurtful to herself to provoke or to offend God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:402
verses.text: To revert then to that description of her character which I began a little time ago; no mind was ever more docile than was hers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:403
verses.text: She was slow to speak and swift to hear, remembering the precept, "Keep silence and hearken, O Israel".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:404
verses.text: The holy scriptures she knew by heart, and said of the history contained in them that it was the foundation of the truth; but, though she loved even this, she still preferred to seek for the underlying spiritual meaning and made this the keystone of the spiritual building raised within her soul.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:405
verses.text: She asked leave that she and her daughter might read over the old and new testaments under my guidance.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:406
verses.text: Out of modesty I at first refused compliance, but as she persisted in her demand and frequently urged me to consent to it, I at last did so and taught her what I had learned not from myself—for self-confidence is the worst of teachers—but from the church's most famous writers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:407
verses.text: Wherever I stuck fast and honestly confessed myself at fault she would by no means rest content but would force me by fresh questions to point out to her which of many different solutions seemed to me the most probable.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:408
verses.text: I will mention here another fact which to those who are envious may well seem incredible.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:409
verses.text: While I myself beginning as a young man have with much toil and effort partially acquired the Hebrew tongue and study it now unceasingly lest if I leave it, it also may leave me; Paula, on making up her mind that she too would learn it, succeeded so well that she could chant the psalms in Hebrew and could speak the language without a trace of the pronunciation peculiar to Latin.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:410
verses.text: The same accomplishment can be seen to this day in her daughter Eustochium, who always kept close to her mother's side, obeyed all her commands, never slept apart from her, never walked abroad or took a meal without her, never had a penny that she could call her own, rejoiced when her mother gave to the poor her little patrimony, and fully believed that in filial affection she had the best heritage and the truest riches.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:411
verses.text: I must not pass over in silence the joy which Paula felt when she heard her little granddaughter and namesake, the child of Laeta and Toxotius—who was born and I may even say conceived in answer to a vow of her parents dedicating her to virginity—when, I say, she heard the little one in her cradle sing "alleluia" and falter out the words "grandmother" and "aunt".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:412
verses.text: One wish alone made her long to see her native land again; that she might know her son and his wife and child to have renounced the world and to be serving Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:413
verses.text: And it has been granted to her in part.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:414
verses.text: For while her granddaughter is destined to take the veil, her daughter-in-law has vowed herself to perpetual chastity, and by faith and alms emulates the example that her mother has set her.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:415
verses.text: She strives to exhibit at Rome the virtues which Paula set forth in all their fulness at Jerusalem.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:417
verses.text: What ails thee, my soul? Why dost thou shudder to approach her death? I have made my letter longer than it should be already; dreading to come to the end and vainly supposing that by saying nothing of it and by occupying myself with her praises I could postpone the evil day.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:418
verses.text: Hitherto the wind has been all in my favour and my keel has smoothly ploughed through the heaving waves.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:419
verses.text: But now my speech is running upon the rocks, the billows are mountains high, and imminent shipwreck awaits both you and me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:420
verses.text: We must needs cry out: "Master; save us we perish:" and "awake, why sleepest thou, O Lord?" For who could tell the tale of Paula's dying with dry eyes? She fell into a most serious illness and thus gained what she most desired, power to leave us and to be joined more fully to the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:421
verses.text: Eustochium's affection for her mother, always true and tried, in this time of sickness approved itself still more to all.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:422
verses.text: She sat by Paula's bedside, she fanned her, she supported her head, she arranged her pillows, she chafed her feet, she rubbed her stomach, she smoothed down the bedclothes, she heated hot water, she brought towels.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:423
verses.text: In fact she anticipated the servants in all their duties, and when one of them did anything she regarded it as so much taken away from her own gain.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:424
verses.text: How unceasingly she prayed, how copiously she wept, how constantly she ran to and fro between her prostrate mother and the cave of the Lord! imploring God that she might not be deprived of a companion so dear, that if Paula was to die she might herself no longer live, and that one bier might carry to burial her and her mother.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:425
verses.text: Alas for the frailty and perishableness of human nature! Except that our belief in Christ raises us up to heaven and promises eternity to our souls, the physical conditions of life are the same for us as for the brutes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:426
verses.text: "There is one event to the righteous and to the wicked; to the good and to the evil; to the clean and to the unclean; to him that sacrificeth and to him that sacrificeth not: as is the good so is the sinner; and he that sweareth as he that feareth an oath".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:427
verses.text: Man and beast alike are dissolved into dust and ashes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:429
verses.text: Why do I still linger, and prolong my suffering by postponing it? Paula's intelligence shewed her that her death was near.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:430
verses.text: Her body and limbs grew cold and only in her holy breast did the warm beat of the living soul continue.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:431
verses.text: Yet, as though she were leaving strangers to go home to her own people, she whispered the verses of the psalmist: "Lord, I have loved the habitation of thy house and the place where thine honour dwelleth," and "How amiable are thy tabernacles, O Lord of hosts! My soul longeth yea even fainteth for the courts of the Lord," and "I had rather be an outcast in the house of my God than to dwell in the tents of wickedness".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:432
verses.text: When I asked her why she remained silent refusing to answer my call, and whether she was in pain, she replied in Greek that she had no suffering and that all things were to her eyes calm and tranquil.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:433
verses.text: After this she said no more but closed her eyes as though she already despised all mortal things, and kept repeating the verses just quoted down to the moment in which she breathed out her soul, but in a tone so low that we could scarcely hear what she said.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:434
verses.text: Raising her finger also to her mouth she made the sign of the cross upon her lips.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:435
verses.text: Then her breath failed her and she gasped for death; yet even when her soul was eager to break free, she turned the death-rattle (which comes at last to all) into the praise of the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:436
verses.text: The bishop of Jerusalem and some from other cities were present, also a great number of the inferior clergy, both priests and levites.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:437
verses.text: The entire monastery was filled with bodies of virgins and monks.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:438
verses.text: As soon as Paula heard the bridegroom saying: "Rise up my love my fair one, my dove, and come away: for, lo, the winter is past, the rain is over and gone," she answered joyfully "the flowers appear on the earth; the time to cut them has come" and "I believe that I shall see the good things of the Lord in the land of the living".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:440
verses.text: No weeping or lamentation followed her death, such as are the custom of the world; but all present united in chanting the psalms in their several tongues.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:441
verses.text: The bishops lifted up the dead woman with their own hands, placed her upon a bier, and carrying her on their shoulders to the church in the cave of the Saviour, laid her down in the centre of it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:442
verses.text: Other bishops meantime carried torches and tapers in the procession, and yet others led the singing of the choirs.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:443
verses.text: The whole population of the cities of Palestine came to her funeral.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:444
verses.text: Not a single monk lurked in the desert or lingered in his cell.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:445
verses.text: Not a single virgin remained shut up in the seclusion of her chamber.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:446
verses.text: To each and all it would have seemed sacrilege to have withheld the last tokens of respect from a woman so saintly.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:447
verses.text: As in the case of Dorcas, the widows and the poor shewed the garments Paula had given them; while the destitute cried aloud that they had lost in her a mother and a nurse.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:448
verses.text: Strange to say, the paleness of death had not altered her expression; only a certain solemnity and seriousness had overspread her features.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:449
verses.text: You would have thought her not dead but asleep.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:450
verses.text: One after another they chanted the psalms, now in Greek, now in Latin, now in Syriac; and this not merely for the three days which elapsed before she was buried beneath the church and close to the cave of the Lord, but throughout the remainder of the week.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:451
verses.text: All who were assembled felt that it was their own funeral at which they were assisting, and shed tears as if they themselves had died.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:452
verses.text: Paula's daughter, the revered virgin Eustochium, "as a child that is weaned of his mother," could not be torn away from her parent.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:453
verses.text: She kissed her eyes, pressed her lips upon her brow, embraced her frame, and wished for nothing better than to be buried with her.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:455
verses.text: Jesus is witness that Paula has left not a single penny to her daughter but, as I said before, on the contrary a large mass of debt; and, worse even than this, a crowd of brothers and sisters whom it is hard for her to support but whom it would be undutiful to cast off.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:456
verses.text: Could there be a more splendid instance of self-renunciation than that of this noble lady who in the fervour of her faith gave away so much of her wealth that she reduced herself to the last degree of poverty? Others may boast, if they will, of money spent in charity, of large sums heaped up in God's treasury, of votive offerings hung up with cords of gold.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:457
verses.text: None of them has given more to the poor than Paula, for Paula has kept nothing for herself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:458
verses.text: But now she enjoys the true riches and those good things which eye hath not seen nor ear heard, neither have they entered into the heart of man.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:459
verses.text: If we mourn, it is for ourselves and not for her; yet even so, if we persist in weeping for one who reigns with Christ, we shall seem to envy her her glory.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:461
verses.text: Be not fearful, Eustochium: you are endowed with a splendid heritage.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:462
verses.text: The Lord is your portion; and, to increase your joy, your mother has now after a long martyrdom won her crown.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:463
verses.text: It is not only the shedding of blood that is accounted a confession: the spotless service of a devout mind is itself a daily martyrdom.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:464
verses.text: Both alike are crowned; with roses and violets in the one case, with lilies in the other.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:465
verses.text: Thus in the Song of Songs it is written: "my beloved is white and ruddy;" for, whether the victory be won in peace or in war, God gives the same guerdon to those who win it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:466
verses.text: Like Abraham your mother heard the words: "get thee out of thy country, and from thy kindred, unto a land that I will shew thee;" and not only that but the Lord's command given through Jeremiah: "flee out of the midst of Babylon, and deliver every man his soul".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:467
verses.text: To the day of her death she never returned to Chaldaea, or regretted the fleshpots of Egypt or its strong-smelling meats.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:468
verses.text: Accompanied by her virgin bands she became a fellow-citizen of the Saviour; and now that she has ascended from her little Bethlehem to the heavenly realms she can say to the true Naomi: "thy people shall be my people and thy God my God".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:470
verses.text: I have spent the labour of two nights in dictating for you this treatise; and in doing so I have felt a grief as deep as your own.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:471
verses.text: I say in 'dictating' for I have not been able to write it myself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:472
verses.text: As often as I have taken up my pen and have tried to fulfil my promise; my fingers have stiffened, my hand has fallen, and my power over it has vanished.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:473
verses.text: The rudeness of the diction, devoid as it is of all elegance or charm, bears witness to the feeling of the writer.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:475
verses.text: And now, Paula, farewell, and aid with your prayers the old age of your votary.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:476
verses.text: Your faith and your works unite you to Christ; thus standing in His presence you will the more readily gain what you ask.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:477
verses.text: In this letter "I have built" to your memory "a monument more lasting than bronze," which no lapse of time will be able to destroy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:478
verses.text: And I have cut an inscription on your tomb, which I here subjoin; that, wherever my narrative may go, the reader may learn that you are buried at Bethlehem and not uncommemorated there.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:479
verses.text: The Inscription on Paula's Tomb.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:480
verses.text: Within this tomb a child of Scipio lies,  A daughter of the farfamed Pauline house,  A scion of the Gracchi, of the stock  Of Agamemnon's self, illustrious:  Here rests the lady Paula, well-beloved  Of both her parents, with Eustochium  For daughter; she the first of Roman dames  Who hardship chose and Bethlehem for Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:481
verses.text: In front of the cavern there is another inscription as follows:—  Seest thou here hollowed in the rock a grave,  'Tis Paula's tomb; high heaven has her soul.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:482
verses.text: Who Rome and friends, riches and home forsook  Here in this lonely spot to find her rest.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:483
verses.text: For here Christ's manger was, and here the kings  To Him, both God and man, their offerings made.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:485
verses.text: The holy and blessed Paula fell asleep on the seventh day before the Kalends of February, on the third day of the week, after the sun had set.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:486
verses.text: She was buried on the fifth day before the same Kalends, in the sixth consulship of the Emperor Honorius and the first of Aristaenetus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:487
verses.text: She lived in the vows of religion five years at Rome and twenty years at Bethlehem.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 109:488
verses.text: The whole duration of her life was fifty-six years eight months and twenty-one days.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 110:1
verses.text: Letter CIX.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 110:2
verses.text: To Riparius.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 110:3
verses.text: Riparius, a presbyter of Aquitaine had written to inform Jerome that Vigilantius (for whom see Letter LXI.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 110:4
verses.text: ) was preaching in southern Gaul against the worship of relics and the keeping of night vigils; and this apparently with the consent of his bishop.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 110:5
verses.text: Jerome now replies in a letter more noteworthy for its bitterness than for its logic.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 110:6
verses.text: Nevertheless he offers to write a full confutation of Vigilantius if Riparius will send him the book containing his heresies.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 110:7
verses.text: This Riparius subsequently did and then Jerome wrote his treatise Against Vigilantius, the most extreme and least convincing of all his works.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 110:8
verses.text: The date of the letter is 404 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 110:9
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 110:11
verses.text: Now that I have received a letter from you, if I do not answer it I shall be guilty of pride, and if I do I shall be guilty of rashness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 110:12
verses.text: For the matters concerning which you ask my opinion are such that they cannot either be spoken of or listened to without profanity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 110:13
verses.text: You tell me that Vigilantius (whose very name Wakeful is a contradiction: he ought rather to be described as Sleepy) has again opened his fetid lips and is pouring forth a torrent of filthy venom upon the relics of the holy martyrs; and that he calls us who cherish them ashmongers and idolaters who pay homage to dead men's bones.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 110:14
verses.text: Unhappy wretch! to be wept over by all Christian men, who sees not that in speaking thus he makes himself one with the Samaritans and the Jews who hold dead bodies unclean and regard as defiled even vessels which have been in the same house with them, following the letter that killeth and not the spirit that giveth life.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 110:15
verses.text: We, it is true, refuse to worship or adore, I say not the relics of the martyrs, but even the sun and moon, the angels and archangels, the Cherubim and Seraphim and "every name that is named, not only in this world but also in that which is to come".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 110:16
verses.text: For we may not serve the creature rather than the Creator, who is blessed for ever.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 110:17
verses.text: Still we honour the relics of the martyrs, that we may adore Him whose martyrs they are.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 110:18
verses.text: We honour the servants that their honour may be reflected upon their Lord who Himself says:—"he that receiveth you receiveth me".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 110:19
verses.text: I ask Vigilantius, Are the relics of Peter and of Paul unclean? Was the body of Moses unclean, of which we are told (according to the correct Hebrew text) that it was buried by the Lord Himself? And do we, every time that we enter the basilicas of apostles and prophets and martyrs, pay homage to the shrines of idols? Are the tapers which burn before their tombs only the tokens of idolatry? I will go farther still and ask a question which will make this theory recoil upon the head of its inventor and which will either kill or cure that frenzied brain of his, so that simple souls shall be no more subverted by his sacrilegious reasonings.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 110:20
verses.text: Let him answer me this, Was the Lord's body unclean when it was placed in the sepulchre? And did the angels clothed in white raiment merely watch over a corpse dead and defiled, that ages afterwards this sleepy fellow might indulge in dreams and vomit forth his filthy surfeit, so as, like the persecutor Julian, either to destroy the basilicas of the saints or to convert them into heathen temples?  2.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 110:21
verses.text: I am surprised that the reverend bishop in whose diocese he is said to be a presbyter acquiesces in this his mad preaching, and that he does not rather with apostolic rod, nay with a rod of iron, shatter this useless vessel and deliver him for the destruction of the flesh that the spirit may be saved.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 110:22
verses.text: He should remember the words that are said: "When thou sawest a thief, then thou consentedst unto him; and hast been partaker with adulterers;" and in another place, "I will early destroy all the wicked of the land; that I may cut off all wicked doers from the city of the Lord;" and again "Do not I hate them, O Lord, that hate thee? and am not I grieved with those that rise up against thee? I hate them with perfect hatred".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 110:23
verses.text: If the relics of the martyrs are not worthy of honour, how comes it that we read "Precious in the sight of the Lord is the death of his saints?" If dead men's bones defile those that touch them, how came it that the dead Elisha raised another man also dead, and that life came to this latter from the body of the prophet which according to Vigilantius must have been unclean? In that case every encampment of the host of Israel and the people of God was unclean; for they carried the bodies of Joseph and of the patriarchs with them in the wilderness, and carried their unclean ashes even into the holy land.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 110:24
verses.text: In that case Joseph, who was a type of our Lord and Saviour, was a wicked man; for he carried up Jacob's bones with great pomp to Hebron merely to put his unclean father beside his unclean grandfather and great grandfather, that is, one dead body along with others.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 110:25
verses.text: The wretch's tongue should be cut out, or he should be put under treatment for insanity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 110:26
verses.text: As he does not know how to speak, he should learn to be silent.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 110:27
verses.text: I have myself before now seen the monster, and have done my best to bind the maniac with texts of scripture, as Hippocrates binds his patients with chains; but "he went away, he departed, he escaped, he broke out," and taking refuge between the Adriatic and the Alps of King Cotius declaimed in his turn against me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 110:28
verses.text: For all that a fool says must be regarded as mere noise and mouthing.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 110:30
verses.text: You may perhaps in your secret thoughts find fault with me for thus assailing a man behind his back.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 110:31
verses.text: I will frankly admit that my indignation overpowers me; I cannot listen with patience to such sacrilegious opinions.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 110:32
verses.text: I have read of the javelin of Phinehas, of the harshness of Elijah, of the jealous anger of Simon the zealot, of the severity of Peter in putting to death Ananias and Sapphira, and of the firmness of Paul who, when Elymas the sorcerer withstood the ways of the Lord, doomed him to lifelong blindness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 110:33
verses.text: There is no cruelty in regard for God's honour.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 110:34
verses.text: Wherefore also in the Law it is said: "If thy brother or thy friend or the wife of thy bosom entice thee from the truth, thine hand shall be upon them and thou shalt shed their blood, and so shalt thou put the evil away from the midst of Israel".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 110:35
verses.text: Once more I ask, Are the relics of the martyrs unclean? If so, why did the apostles allow themselves to walk in that funeral procession before the body—the unclean body—of Stephen? Why did they make great lamentation over him, that their grief might be turned into our joy?  You tell me farther that Vigilantius execrates vigils.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 110:36
verses.text: In this surely he goes contrary to his name.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 110:37
verses.text: The Wakeful one wishes to sleep and will not hearken to the Saviour's words, "What, could ye not watch with me one hour? Watch and pray that ye enter not into temptation: the spirit indeed is willing but the flesh is weak".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 110:38
verses.text: And in another place a prophet sings: "At midnight I will rise to give thanks unto thee because of thy righteous judgments".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 110:39
verses.text: We read also in the gospel how the Lord spent whole nights in prayer and how the apostles when they were shut up in prison kept vigil all night long, singing their psalms until the earth quaked, and the keeper of the prison believed, and the magistrates and citizens were filled with terror.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 110:40
verses.text: Paul says: "continue in prayer and watch in the same," and in another place he speaks of himself as "in watchings often".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 110:41
verses.text: Vigilantius may sleep if he pleases and may choke in his sleep, destroyed by the destroyer of Egypt and of the Egyptians.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 110:42
verses.text: But let us say with David: "Behold, he that keepeth Israel shall neither slumber nor sleep".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 110:43
verses.text: So will the Holy One and the Watcher come to us.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 110:44
verses.text: And if ever by reason of our sins He fall asleep, let us say to Him: "Awake, why sleepest thou, O Lord;" and when our ship is tossed by the waves let us rouse Him and say, "Master, save us: we perish".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 110:46
verses.text: I would dictate more were it not that the limits of a letter impose upon me a modest silence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 110:47
verses.text: I might have gone on, had you sent me the books which contain this man's rhapsodies, for in that case I should have known what points I had to refute.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 110:48
verses.text: As it is I am only beating the air and revealing not so much his infidelity—for this is patent to all—as my own faith.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 110:49
verses.text: But if you wish me to write against him at greater length, send me those wretched dronings of his and in my answer he shall hear an echo of John the Baptist's words "Now also the axe is laid unto the root of the trees; therefore every tree which bringeth not forth good fruit is hewn down and cast into the fire".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 111:1
verses.text: Letter CX.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 111:2
verses.text: From Augustine.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 111:3
verses.text: Augustine's answer to Letter CII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 111:4
verses.text: He now tries to soothe Jerome's wounded feelings, begs him to overlook the offence that he has committed, and implores him not to break off the friendly relations hitherto maintained between them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 111:5
verses.text: He touches on the quarrel between Jerome and Rufinus and sincerely hopes that no such breach may ever separate Jerome from himself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 111:6
verses.text: The tone of the letter is throughout conciliatory and is marked in.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 112:1
verses.text: places with deep feeling.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 112:2
verses.text: More than once Augustine dwells on Jerome's words ("would that I could embrace you and that by mutual converse we might learn one from the other," Letter CII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 112:3
verses.text: §2) and speaks of the comfort which they have brought to him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 112:4
verses.text: The date of the letter is 404 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 112:5
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 113:1
verses.text: Letter CXI.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 113:2
verses.text: From Augustine to Praesidius.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 113:3
verses.text: Augustine asks Praesidius to forward the preceding letter to Jerome and also to write himself to urge him to forgive Augustine.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 114:1
verses.text: Letter CXII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 114:2
verses.text: To Augustine.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 114:3
verses.text: On receiving Letter CIV.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 114:4
verses.text: together with duly authenticated copies of Letters LVI.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 114:5
verses.text: and LXVII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 114:6
verses.text: Jerome in three days completes an exhaustive reply to all the questions which Augustine had raised.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 114:7
verses.text: He explains what is the true title of his book On Illustrious Men, deals at great length with the dispute between Paul and Peter, expounds his views with regard to the Septuagint, and shews by the story of "the gourd" how close and accurate his translations are.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 114:8
verses.text: His language throughout is kind but rather patronising: indeed in this whole correspondence Jerome seldom sufficiently recognizes the greatness of Augustine.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 114:9
verses.text: The date of the letter is 404 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 114:10
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 115:1
verses.text: Letter CXIII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 115:2
verses.text: From Theophilus to Jerome.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 115:3
verses.text: Theophilus, bishop of Alexandria, had compiled an invective against John Chrysostom, bishop of Constantinople who was nosy (largely through his efforts) an exile from his see.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 115:4
verses.text: This he now sends to Jerome with a request that the latter will render it into Latin for dissemination in the West.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 115:5
verses.text: The invective (of which only a few fragments remain) is of the most violent kind.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 115:6
verses.text: Nevertheless Jerome translated it along with this letter, the date of which is 405 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 115:7
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 115:8
verses.text: The latter part of the letter has perished.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 115:9
verses.text: To the well-beloved and most loving brother Jerome, Theophilus sends greeting in the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 115:11
verses.text: At the outset the verdict which is in accordance with the truth satisfies but few.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 115:12
verses.text: But the Lord speaking by the prophet says: "my judgment goeth forth as the light:" and they who are surrounded with a horror of darkness and do not with clear comprehension perceive the nature of things, are covered with eternal shame and know by the issues of their acts that their efforts have been in vain.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 115:13
verses.text: Wherefore we also have always desired for John who has for a time ruled the church of Constantinople grace that he might please God, and we have been slow to attribute to him the rash acts which have caused his downfall.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 115:14
verses.text: But, not to speak of his other misdeeds, he has taken the Origenists into his confidence, has advanced many of them to the priesthood, and by committing this crime has saddened with no slight grief that man of God, Epiphanius of blessed memory, who has shone throughout all the world a bright star among bishops.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 115:15
verses.text: And therefore he has rightly come to hear the words of doom: "Babylon is fallen, is fallen".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 115:17
verses.text: Knowing then that the Saviour has said: "judge not according to the appearance but judge righteous judgment".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 116:1
verses.text: Letter CXIV.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 116:2
verses.text: To Theophilus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 116:3
verses.text: Jerome writes to Theophilus to apologize for his delay in sending Latin versions of the latter's letter (CXIII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 116:4
verses.text: ) and invective against John Chrysostom.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 116:5
verses.text: Possibly, however, the allusion may be not to these but to some other work of Theophilus (e.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 116:6
verses.text: g.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 116:7
verses.text: a paschal letter.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 116:8
verses.text: ) This delay he attributes to the disturbed state of Palestine, the severity of the winter, the prevalent famine, and his own ill-health.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 116:9
verses.text: He now sends the translations that he has made and, while he deprecates criticism on his own work, praises that of Theophilus, quoting with particular approval the directions given by this latter for the reverent care of the vessels used in celebrating the holy communion.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 116:10
verses.text: The date of the letter is 405 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 116:11
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 116:12
verses.text: To the most blessed pope Theophilus, Jerome.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 116:14
verses.text: My delay in sending back to your holiness your treatise translated into Latin is accounted for by the many interruptions and obstacles that I have met with.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 116:15
verses.text: There has been a sudden raid of the Isaurians; Phoenicia and Galilee have been laid waste; Palestine has been panic-stricken, and particularly Jerusalem; we have all been engaged in making not books but walls.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 116:16
verses.text: There has also been a severe winter and an almost unbearable famine; and these have told heavily upon me who have the charge of many brothers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 116:17
verses.text: Amid these difficulties the work of translation went on by night, as I could save or snatch time to give to it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 116:18
verses.text: At last I got it done and by Lent nothing remained but to collate the fair copy with the original.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 116:19
verses.text: However, just then a severe illness seized me and I was brought to the threshold of death, from which I have only been saved by God's mercy and your prayers; perhaps for this very purpose that I might fulfil your behest and render with its writer's elegance the charming volume which you have adorned with the scripture's fairest flowers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 116:20
verses.text: But bodily weakness and sorrow of heart have, I need hardly say, dulled the edge of my intellect and obstructed the free flow of my language.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 116:22
verses.text: I admire in your work its practical aim, designed as it is to instruct by the authority of scripture ignorant persons in all the churches concerning the reverence with which they must handle holy things and minister at Christ's altar; and to impress upon them that the sacred chalices, veils, and other accessories used in the celebration of the Lord's passion are not mere lifeless and senseless objects devoid of holiness, but that rather, from their association with the body and blood of the Lord, they are to be venerated with the same awe as the body and the blood themselves.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 116:24
verses.text: Take back then your book, nay mine or better still ours; for when you flatter me you will but flatter yourself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 116:25
verses.text: It is for you that my brain has toiled; it is for you that I have striven with the poor resources of the Latin tongue to find an equivalent for the eloquence of the Greek.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 116:26
verses.text: I have not indeed given a word-for-word rendering, as skilled translators do, nor have I counted out the money you have given to me coin by coin; but I have given you full weight.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 116:27
verses.text: Some words may be missing but none of the sense is lost.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 116:28
verses.text: Moreover I have translated into Latin and prefixed to this volume the letter that you sent to me, so that all who read it may know that I have acted under the commands of your holiness, and have not rashly and over-confidently undertaken a task that is beyond my powers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 116:29
verses.text: Whether I have succeeded in it I must leave to your judgment.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 116:30
verses.text: Even though you may blame my weakness, you will at least give me credit for my good intention.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 117:1
verses.text: Letter CXV.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 117:2
verses.text: To Augustine.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 117:3
verses.text: A short but most friendly letter in which Jerome excuses himself for the freedom with which he has dealt with Augustine's questions (the allusion is to Letter CXII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 117:4
verses.text: ) and hopes that henceforth they may be able to avoid controversy and to labour like brothers in the field of scripture.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 117:5
verses.text: Written probably in 405 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 117:6
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 118:1
verses.text: Letter CXVI.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 118:2
verses.text: From Augustine.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 118:3
verses.text: A long letter in which Augustine for the third time (see Letters LVI.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 118:4
verses.text: , LXVII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 118:5
