verses.text: ) restates his opinion about Jerome's theory of the dispute between Peter and Paul at Antioch.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 118:6
verses.text: In doing so, however, he disclaims all desire to hurt Jerome's feelings, apologizes for the tone of his previous letters, and again explains that it is not his fault that they have failed so long to reach Jerome.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 118:7
verses.text: Written shortly after the preceding.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:1
verses.text: Letter CXVII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:2
verses.text: To a Mother and Daughter Living in Gaul.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:3
verses.text: A monk of Gaul had during a visit to Bethlehem asked Jerome for advice under the following circumstances.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:4
verses.text: His mother was a church-widow and his sister a religious virgin but the two could not agree.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:5
verses.text: They were accordingly living apart but neither by herself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:6
verses.text: For each had taken into her house a monk ostensibly to act as steward but really to be a paramour.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:7
verses.text: At the request of his visitor Jerome now writes to both mother and daughter urging them to dismiss their companions; or at any rate to live together: and pointing out the grave scandal that must otherwise be caused.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:8
verses.text: From the treatise against Vigilantius (§3) we learn that ill-natured critics maintained that the persons and circumstances described in the letter were alike fictitious and that Jerome in writing it was but exercising his ingenuity on a congenial theme.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:9
verses.text: The date is a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:10
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:12
verses.text: Introduction.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:14
verses.text: A certain brother from Gaul has told me that his virgin-sister and widowed mother, though living in the same city, have separate abodes and have taken to themselves clerical protectors either as guests or stewards; and that by thus associating with strangers they have caused more scandal than by living apart.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:15
verses.text: When I groaned and expressed what I felt more by silence than words; "I beseech you," said he, "rebuke them in a letter and recall them to mutual harmony; make them once more mother and daughter".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:16
verses.text: To whom I replied, "a nice task this that you lay upon me, for me a stranger to reconcile two women whom you, a son and brother, have failed to influence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:17
verses.text: You speak as though I occupied the chair of a bishop instead of being shut up in a monastic cell where, far removed from the world's turmoil, I lament the sins of the past and try to avoid the temptations of the present.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:18
verses.text: Moreover, it is surely inconsistent, while one buries oneself out of sight, to allow one's tongue free course through the world".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:19
verses.text: "You are too fearful," he replied; "where is that old hardihood of yours which made you 'scour the world with copious salt,' as Horace says of Lucilius?" "It is this," I rejoined, "that makes me shy and forbids me to open my lips.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:20
verses.text: For through accusing crime I have been myself made out a criminal.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:21
verses.text: Men have disputed and denied my assertions until, as the proverb goes, I hardly know whether I have ears or feeling left.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:22
verses.text: The very walls have resounded with curses levelled at me, and 'I was the song of drunkards.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:23
verses.text: ' Under the compulsion of an unhappy experience I have learned to be silent, thinking it better to set a watch before my mouth and to keep the door of my lips than to incline my heart to any evil thing, or, while censuring the faults of others, myself to fall into that of detraction".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:24
verses.text: In answer to this he said: "Speaking the truth is not detraction.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:25
verses.text: Nor will you lecture the world by administering a particular rebuke; for there are few persons, if any, open to this special charge.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:26
verses.text: I beg of you, therefore, as I have put myself to the trouble of this long journey, that you will not suffer me to have come for nothing.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:27
verses.text: The Lord knows that, after the sight of the holy places, my principal object in coming has been to heal by a letter from you the division between my sister and my mother".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:28
verses.text: "Well," I replied, "I will do as you wish, for after all the letters will be to persons beyond the sea and words written with reference to definite persons can seldom offend other people.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:29
verses.text: But I must ask you to keep what I say secret.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:30
verses.text: You will take my advice with you to encourage you by the way; if it is listened to, I will rejoice as much as you; while if, as I rather think, it is rejected, I shall have wasted my words and you will have made a long journey for nothing".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:31
verses.text: The Letter.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:33
verses.text: In the first place my sister and my daughter, I wish you to know that I am not writing to you because I suspect anything evil of you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:34
verses.text: On the contrary I implore you to live in harmony, so as to give no ground for any such suspicions.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:35
verses.text: Moreover had I supposed you fast bound in sin—far be this from you—I should never have written, for I should have known that my words would be addressed to deaf ears.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:36
verses.text: Again, if I write to you somewhat sharply, I beg of you to ascribe this not to any harshness on my part but to the nature of the ailment which I attempt to treat.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:37
verses.text: Cautery and the knife are the only remedies when mortification has once set in; poison is the only antidote known for poison; great pain can only be relieved by inflicting greater pain.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:38
verses.text: Lastly I must say this that even if your own consciences acquit you of misdoing, yet the very rumour of such brings disgrace upon you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:39
verses.text: Mother and daughter are names of affection; they imply natural ties and reciprocal duties; they form the closest of human relations after that which binds the soul to God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:40
verses.text: If you love each other, your conduct calls for no praise: but if you hate each other, you have committed a crime.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:41
verses.text: The Lord Jesus was subject to His parents.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:42
verses.text: He reverenced that mother of whom He was Himself the parent; He respected the foster-father whom He had Himself fostered; for He remembered that He had been carried in the womb of the one and in the arms of the other.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:43
verses.text: Wherefore also when He hung upon the cross He commended to His disciple the mother whom He had never before His passion parted from Himself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:45
verses.text: Well, I shall say no more to the mother, for perhaps age, weakness, and loneliness make sufficient excuses for her; but to you the daughter I say: "Is a mother's house too small for you whose womb was not too small? When you have lived with her for ten months in the one, can you not bear to live with her for one day in the other? or are you unable to meet her gaze? Can it be that one who has borne you and reared you, who has brought you up and knows you, is dreaded by you as a witness of your home-life? If you are a true virgin, why do you fear her careful guardianship; and, if you have fallen, why do you not openly marry? Wedlock is like a plank offered to a shipwrecked man and by its means you may remedy what previously you have done amiss.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:46
verses.text: I do not mean that you are not to repent of your sin or that you are to continue in evil courses; but, when a tie of the kind has been formed, I despair of breaking it altogether.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:47
verses.text: However, a return to your mother will make it easier for you to bewail the virginity which you have lost through leaving her.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:48
verses.text: Or if you are still unspotted and have not lost your chastity, be careful of it for you may lose it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:49
verses.text: Why must you live in a house where you must daily struggle for life and death? Can any one sleep soundly with a viper near him? No; for, though it may not attack him it is sure to frighten him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:50
verses.text: It is better to be where there is no danger, than to be in danger and to escape.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:51
verses.text: In the one case we have a calm; in the other careful steering is necessary.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:52
verses.text: In the one case we are filled with joy; in the other we do but avoid sorrow.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:54
verses.text: But you will perhaps reply: "my mother is not well-behaved, she desires the things of the world, she loves riches, she disregards fasting, she stains her eyes with antimony, she likes to walk abroad in gay attire, she hinders me from the monastic vow, and so I cannot live with her".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:55
verses.text: But first of all, even though she is as you say, you will have the greater reward for refusing to forsake her with all her faults.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:56
verses.text: She has carried you in her womb, she has reared you; with gentle affection she has borne with the troublesome ways of your childhood.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:57
verses.text: She has washed your linen, she has tended you when sick, and the sickness of maternity was not only borne for you but caused by you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:58
verses.text: She has brought you up to womanhood, she has taught you to love Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:59
verses.text: You ought not to be displeased with the behaviour of a mother who has consecrated you as a virgin to the service of your spouse.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:60
verses.text: Still if you cannot put up with her dainty ways and feel obliged to shun them, and if your mother really is, as people so often say, a woman of the world, you have others, virgins like yourself, the holy company of chastity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:61
verses.text: Why, when you forsake your mother, do you choose for companion a man who perhaps has left behind him a sister and mother of his own? You tell me that she is hard to get on with and that he is easy; that she is quarrelsome and that he is amiable.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:62
verses.text: I will ask you one question: Did you go straight from your home to the man, or did you fall in with him afterwards? If you went straight to him, the reason why you left your mother is plain.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:63
verses.text: If you fell in with him afterwards, you shew by your choice what you missed under your mother's roof.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:64
verses.text: The pain that I inflict is severe and I feel the knife as much as you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:65
verses.text: "He that walketh uprightly walketh surely".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:66
verses.text: Only that my conscience would smite me, I should keep silence and be slow to blame others where I am not guiltless myself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:67
verses.text: Having a beam in my own eye I should be reluctant to see the mote in my neighbour's.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:68
verses.text: But as it is I live far away among Christian brothers; my life with them is honourable as eyewitnesses of it can testify; I rarely see, or am seen by, others.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:69
verses.text: It is most shameless, therefore, in you to refuse to copy me in respect of self-restraint, when you profess to take me as your model.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:70
verses.text: If you say: "my conscience is enough for me too.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:71
verses.text: God is my judge who is witness of my life.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:72
verses.text: I care not what men may say;" let me urge upon you the apostle's words: "provide things honest" not only in the sight of God but also "in the sight of all men".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:73
verses.text: If any one carps at you for being a Christian and a virgin, mind it not; you have left your mother it may be said to live in a monastery among virgins, but censure on this score is your glory.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:74
verses.text: When men blame a maid of God not for self-indulgence but only for insensibility to affection, what they condemn as callous disregard of a parent is really a lively devotion towards God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:75
verses.text: For you prefer to your mother Him whom you are bidden to prefer to your own soul.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:76
verses.text: And if the day ever comes that she also shall so prefer Him, she will find in you not a daughter only but a sister as well.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:78
verses.text: "What then?" you will say, "is it a crime to have a man of religion in the house with me?" You seize me by the collar and drag me into court either to sanction what I disapprove or else to incur the dislike of many.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:79
verses.text: A man of religion never separates a daughter from her mother.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:80
verses.text: He welcomes both and respects both.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:81
verses.text: A daughter may be as religious as she pleases; still a mother who is a widow is a guaranty for her chastity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:82
verses.text: If this person whoever he is is of the same age with yourself, he should honour your mother as though she were his own; and, if he is older, he should love you as a daughter and subject you to a mother's discipline.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:83
verses.text: It is not good either for your reputation or for his that he should like you more than your mother; for his affection might appear to be less for you than for your youth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:84
verses.text: This is what I should say if a monk were not your brother and if you had no relatives able to protect you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:85
verses.text: But what excuse has a stranger for thrusting himself in where there are both a mother and a brother, the one a widow and the other a monk? It is good for you to feel that you are a daughter and a sister.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:86
verses.text: However, if you cannot manage both, and if your mother is too hard a morsel to swallow, your brother at any rate should satisfy you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:87
verses.text: Or, if he is too harsh, she that bore you may prove more gentle.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:88
verses.text: Why do you turn pale? Why do you get excited? Why do you blush, and with trembling lips betray the restlessness of your mind? One thing only can surpass a woman's love for her mother and brother; and that is her passion for her husband.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:90
verses.text: I am told, moreover, that you frequent suburban villas and their pleasant gardens in the company of relatives and intimate friends.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:91
verses.text: I have no doubt that it is some female cousin or connexion who for her own satisfaction carries you about with her as a novel kind of attendant.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:92
verses.text: Far be it from me to suspect that you would desire men's society; even though they should be those of your own family.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:93
verses.text: But pray, maiden, answer me this; do you appear alone in your kinsfolk's society? or do you bring your favourite with you? Shameless as you may be, you will hardly venture to flaunt him in the eyes of the world.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:94
verses.text: If you ever do so, your whole circle will cry out about both you and him; every one's finger will be pointed at you; and your cousins who in your presence to please you call him a monk and a man of religion, will laugh at you behind your back for having such an unnatural husband.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:95
verses.text: If on the other hand you go out alone—which I rather suppose to be the case—you will find yourself clothed in sober garb among slave youths, women married or soon to be so, wanton girls, and dandies with long hair and tight-fitting vests.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:96
verses.text: Some bearded fop will offer you his hand, he will hold you up if you feel tired, and the pressure of his fingers will either be a temptation to you, or will shew that you are a temptation to him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:97
verses.text: Again when you sit down to table with married men and women, you will have to see kisses in which you have no part, and dishes partaken of which are not for you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:98
verses.text: Moreover it cannot but do you harm to see other women attired in silk dresses and gold brocades.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:99
verses.text: At table also whether you like it or not, you will be forced to eat flesh and that of different kinds.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:100
verses.text: To make you drink wine they will praise it as a creature of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:101
verses.text: To induce you to take baths they will speak of dirt with disgust; and, when on second thoughts you do as you are bid, they will with one voice salute you as spotless and open, a thorough lady.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:102
verses.text: Meantime some singer will give to the company a selection of softly flowing airs; and as he will not venture to look at other men's wives, he will constantly fix his eyes on you who have no protector.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:103
verses.text: He will speak by nods and convey by his tone what he is afraid to put into words.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:104
verses.text: Amid inducements to sensuality so marked as these, even iron wills are apt to be overcome with desire; an appetite which is the more imperious in virgins because they suppose that sweetest of which they have no experience.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:105
verses.text: Heathen legends tell us that sailors actually ran their ships on the rocks that they might listen to the songs of the Sirens; and that the lyre of Orpheus had power to draw to itself trees and animals and to soften flints.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:106
verses.text: In the banquet-hall chastity is hard to keep.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:107
verses.text: A shining skin shews a sin-stained soul.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:109
verses.text: As a schoolboy I have read of one—and have seen his effigy true to the life in the streets—who continued to cherish an unlawful passion even when his flesh scarcely clung to his bones, and whose malady remained uncured until death cured it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:110
verses.text: What then will become of you a young girl physically sound, dainty, stout, and ruddy, if you allow yourself free range among flesh-dishes, wines, and baths, not to mention married men and bachelors? Even if when solicited you refuse to consent, you will take the fact of your being asked as evidence that you are considered handsome.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:111
verses.text: A sensual mind pursues dishonourable objects with greater zest than honourable ones; and when a thing is forbidden hankers after it with greater pleasure.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:112
verses.text: Your very dress, cheap and sombre as it is, is an index of your secret feelings.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:113
verses.text: For it has no creases and trails along the ground to make you appear taller than you are.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:114
verses.text: Your vest is purposely ripped asunder to shew what is beneath and while hiding what is repulsive, to reveal what is fair.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:115
verses.text: As you walk, the very creaking of your black and shiny shoes attracts the notice of the young men.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:116
verses.text: You wear stays to keep your breasts in place, and a heaving girdle closely confines your chest.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:117
verses.text: Your hair covers either your forehead or your ears.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:118
verses.text: Sometimes too you let your shawl drop so as to lay bare your white shoulders; and, as if unwilling that they should be seen, you quickly conceal what you have purposely disclosed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:119
verses.text: And when in public you for modesty's sake cover your face, like a practised harlot you only shew what is likely to please.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:121
verses.text: You will exclaim "How do you know what I am like, or how, when you are so far away, can you see what I am doing?" Your own brother's tears and sobs have told me, his frequent and scarcely endurable bursts of grief.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:122
verses.text: Would that he had lied or that his words had been words of apprehension only and not of accusation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:123
verses.text: But, believe me, liars do not shed tears.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:124
verses.text: He is indignant that you prefer to himself a young man, not it is true clothed in silk or wearing his hair long but muscular and dainty in the midst of his squalor; and that this fellow holds the purse-strings, looks after the weaving, allots the servants their tasks, rules the household, and buys from the market all that is needed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:125
verses.text: He is at once steward and master, and, as he anticipates the slaves in their duties, he is carped at by all the domestics.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:126
verses.text: Everything that their mistress has not given them they declare that he has stolen from them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:127
verses.text: Servants as a class are full of complaints; and no matter what you give them, it is always too little.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:128
verses.text: For they do not consider how much you have but only how much you give; and they make up for their chagrin in the only way they can, that is, by grumbling.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:129
verses.text: One calls him a parasite, another an impostor, another a money-seeker, another by some novel appellation that hits his fancy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:130
verses.text: They noise it abroad that he is constantly at your bed-side, that when you are sick he runs to fetch nurses, that he holds basins, airs sheets, and folds bandages for you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:131
verses.text: The world is only too ready to believe scandal, and stories invented at home soon get afloat abroad.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:132
verses.text: Nor need you be surprised if your servantmen and servantmaids get up such tales about you, when even your mother and your brother complain of your conduct.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:134
verses.text: Do, therefore, what I advise you and entreat you to do: if possible, be reconciled with your mother; or, if this may not be, at least come to terms with your brother.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:135
verses.text: Or if you are filled with an implacable hatred of relationships usually so dear, separate at all events from the man, whom you are said to prefer to your own flesh and blood, and, if even this is impossible for you, (for, if you could leave him, you would certainly return to your own) pay more regard to appearances in harbouring him as your companion.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:136
verses.text: Live in a separate building and take your meals apart; for if you remain under one roof with him slanderers will say that you share with him your bed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:137
verses.text: You may thus easily get help from him when you feel you need it, and yet to a considerable degree escape public discredit.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:138
verses.text: Yet you must take care not to contract the stain of which Jeremiah tells us that no nitre or fuller's soap can wash it out.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:139
verses.text: When you wish him to come to see you, always have witnesses present; either friends, or freedmen, or slaves.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:140
verses.text: A good conscience is afraid of no man's eyes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:141
verses.text: Let him come in unembarrassed and go out at his ease.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:142
verses.text: Let his silent looks, his unspoken words and his whole carriage, though at times they may imply embarrassment, yet indicate peace of mind.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:143
verses.text: Pray, open your ears and listen to the outcry of the whole city.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:144
verses.text: You have already both of you lost your own names and are known each by that of the other.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:145
verses.text: You are spoken of as his, and he is said to be yours.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:146
verses.text: Your mother and your brother have heard this and are ready to take you in between them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:147
verses.text: They implore you to consent to this arrangement, so that the scandal of your intimacy with this man which is confined to yourself may give place to a glory common to all.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:148
verses.text: You can live with your mother and he with your brother.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:149
verses.text: You can more boldly shew your regard for one who is your brother's comrade; and your mother will more properly esteem one who is the friend of her son and not of her daughter.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:150
verses.text: But if you frown and refuse to accept my advice, this letter will openly expostulate with you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:151
verses.text: 'Why,' it will say, 'do you beset another man's servant? Why do you make Christ's minister your slave? Look at the people and scan each face as it comes under your view.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:152
verses.text: When he reads in the church all eyes are fixed upon you; and you, using the licence of a wife, glory in your shame.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:153
verses.text: Secret infamy no longer contents you; you call boldness freedom; "you have a whore's forehead and refuse to be ashamed".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:155
verses.text: Once more you exclaim that I am over-suspicious, a thinker of evil, too ready to follow rumours.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:156
verses.text: What? I suspicious? I ill-natured? I, who as I said in the beginning have taken up my pen because I have no suspicions? Or is it you that are careless, loose, disdainful? You who at the age of twenty-five have netted in your embrace a youth whose beard has scarcely grown? An excellent instructor he must be, able no doubt by his severe looks both to warn and frighten you! No age is safe from lust, yet gray hairs are some security for decent conduct.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:157
verses.text: A day will surely come (for time glides by imperceptibly) when your handsome young favourite will find a wealthier or more youthful mistress.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:158
verses.text: For women soon age and particularly if they live with men.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:159
verses.text: You will be sorry for your decision and regret your obstinacy in a day when your means and reputation shall be alike gone, and when this unhappy intimacy shall be happily broken off.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:160
verses.text: But perhaps you feel sure of your ground and see no reason to fear a breach where affection has had so long a time to develop and grow.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:162
verses.text: To you also, her mother, I must say a word.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:163
verses.text: Your years put you beyond the reach of scandal; do not take advantage of this to indulge in sin.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:164
verses.text: It is more fitting that your daughter should learn from you how to part from a companion than that you should learn from her how to give up a paramour.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:165
verses.text: You have a son, a daughter, and a son-in-law, or at least one who is your daughter's partner.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:166
verses.text: Why then should you seek other society than theirs, or wish to kindle anew expiring flames? It would be more becoming in you to screen your daughter's fault than to make it an excuse for your own misdoing.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:167
verses.text: Your son is a monk, and, if he were to live with you, he would strengthen you in your religious profession and in your vow of widowhood.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:168
verses.text: Why should you take in a complete stranger, especially in a house not large enough to hold a son and a daughter? You are old enough to have grand-children.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:169
verses.text: Invite the pair home then.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:170
verses.text: Your daughter went away by herself; let her return with this man.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:171
verses.text: I say 'man' and not 'husband' that none may cavil.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:172
verses.text: The word describes his sex and not his relation to her.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:173
verses.text: Or if she blushes to accept your offer or finds the house in which she was born too narrow for her, then move both of you to her abode.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:174
verses.text: However limited may be its accommodation, it can take in a mother and a brother better than a stranger.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:175
verses.text: In fact, if she lives in the same house and occupies the same room with a man, she cannot long preserve her chastity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:176
verses.text: It is different when two women and two men live together.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:177
verses.text: If the third person concerned—he, I mean, who fosters your old age—will not make one of the party and causes only dissension and confusion, the pair of you can do without him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:178
verses.text: But if the three of you remain together, then your brother and son will offer him a sister and a mother.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:179
verses.text: Others may speak of the two strangers as step-father and son-in-law; but your son must speak of them as his foster-father and his brother.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:180
verses.text: Note.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:182
verses.text: Working quickly I have completed this letter in a single night anxious alike to gratify a friend and to try my hand on a rhetorical theme.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:183
verses.text: Then early in the morning he has knocked at my door on the point of starting.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:184
verses.text: I wish also to shew my detractors that like them I too can say the first thing that comes into my head.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:185
verses.text: I have, therefore, introduced few quotations from the scriptures and have not, as in most of my books, interwoven its flowers in my discourse.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:186
verses.text: The letter has been, in fact, dictated off-hand and poured forth by lamp-light so fast that my tongue has outstripped my secretaries' pens and that my volubility has baffled the expedients of shorthand.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 119:187
verses.text: I have said this much that those who make no allowances for want of ability may make some for want of time.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:1
verses.text: Letter CXVIII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:2
verses.text: To Julian.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:3
verses.text: Jerome writes to Julian, a wealthy nobleman apparently of Dalmatia (§5), to console him for the loss of his wife and two daughters all of whom had recently died.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:4
verses.text: He reminds Julian of the trials of Job and recommends him to imitate the patience of the patriarch.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:5
verses.text: He also urges him to follow the example set by Pammachius and Paulinus, that is, to give up his riches and to become a monk for the sake of Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:6
verses.text: The date of the letter is 406 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:7
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:9
verses.text: At the very instant of his departure Ausonius, a son to me as he is a brother to you, gave me a late glimpse of himself but quickly hurried away again, saying good-morning and good-bye together.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:10
verses.text: Yet he thought that he would return empty-handed unless he could bring you some trifle from me however hastily written.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:11
verses.text: Clothed in scarlet as befitted his rank, he had already strapped on his sword-belt and sent down a requisition to have a stage-horse saddled.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:12
verses.text: Still he made me send for my secretary and dictate a letter to him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:13
verses.text: This I did with such rapidity that his nimble hand could hardly keep pace with my words or manage to put down my hurried sentences.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:14
verses.text: Thus hasty dictation has taken the place of careful writing; and, if I break my long silence, it is but to offer you an expression of good will.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:15
verses.text: This is an impromptu letter without logical order or charm of style.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:16
verses.text: You must look on me for once as a friend only; you will find, I assure you, nothing of the orator here.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:17
verses.text: Bear in mind that it has been dashed off on the spur of the moment and given as a provision for the way to one in a hurry to depart.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:18
verses.text: Holy scripture says: "a tale out of season is as musick in mourning".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:19
verses.text: Accordingly I have disdained the graces of rhetoric and those charms of eloquence which boys find so captivating, and have fallen back on the serious tone of the sacred writings.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:20
verses.text: For in these are to be found true medicines for wounds and sure remedies for sorrow.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:21
verses.text: In these a mother receives back her only son even on the bier.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:22
verses.text: In these a crowd of mourners hears the words: "the maid is not dead but sleepeth".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:23
verses.text: In these one that is four days dead comes forth bound at the call of the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:25
verses.text: I hear that in a short space of time you have suffered several bereavements, that you have buried in quick succession two young unmarried daughters, and that Faustina, most chaste and loyal of wives, your sister in the fervour of her faith and your one comfort in the loss of your children, has suddenly fallen asleep and been taken from you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:26
verses.text: You have been like a shipwrecked man, who has no sooner reached the shore than he falls into the hands of brigands, or in the eloquent language of the prophet like one "who did flee from a lion, and a bear met him; or went into the house, and leaned his hand on the wall, and a serpent bit him".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:27
verses.text: Pecuniary losses have followed your bereavements; the entire province has been overrun by a barbarian enemy, and in the general devastation your private property has been destroyed, your flocks and herds have been driven off, and your poor slaves either made prisoners or else slain.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:28
verses.text: To crown all, your only daughter, made all the more dear to you by the loss of the others, has for her husband a young nobleman who, to say nothing worse of him, has given you more occasion for sorrow than for rejoicing.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:29
verses.text: Such is the list of the trials that have been laid upon you; such is the conflict waged by the old enemy against Julian a raw recruit to Christ's standard.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:30
verses.text: If you look only to yourself your troubles are indeed great but if you look to the strong Warrior, they are but child's play and the conflict is only the semblance of one.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:31
verses.text: After untold trials a wicked wife was still left to the blessed Job, the devil hoping that he might learn from her to blaspheme God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:32
verses.text: You on the other hand have been deprived of an excellent one that you might learn to go without consolation in the hour of misfortune.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:33
verses.text: Yet it is far harder to put up with a wife whom you dislike than it is to mourn for one whom you dearly love.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:34
verses.text: Moreover when Job's children died they found a common tomb beneath the ruins of his house, and all he could do to shew his parental affection was to rend his garments, to fall upon the ground and to worship, saying: "Naked came I out of my mother's womb, and naked shall I return thither: the Lord gave and the Lord hath taken away: it has been as the Lord pleased: blessed be the name of the Lord".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:35
verses.text: But you, to put the matter briefly, have been allowed to perform the obsequies of your dear ones; and those obsequies have been attended by many respectful kinsmen and comforting friends.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:36
verses.text: Again Job lost all his wealth at once; and, as, one after another, the messengers of woe unfolded new calamities, he flinched as little as the sage of whom Horace writes:—  Shatter the world to atoms if you will.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:37
verses.text: Fearless will be the man on whom it falls.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:38
verses.text: But with you the case is different.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:39
verses.text: The greater part of your substance has been left to you, and your trials have not been greater than you can bear.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:40
verses.text: For you have not yet attained to such perfection that the devil has to marshal all his forces against you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:42
verses.text: Long ago this wealthy proprietor and still wealthier father was made by a sudden stroke destitute and bereaved.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:43
verses.text: But as, in spite of all that befel him, he had not sinned before God or spoken foolishly, the Lord—exulting in the victory of his servant and regarding Job's patience as His own triumph—said to the devil: "Hast thou considered my servant Job, that there is none like him in the earth, a perfect and an upright man, one that feareth God and escheweth evil? and still he holdeth fast his integrity?" He finely adds the last clause because it is difficult for innocence to refrain from murmuring when it is overborne by misfortune; and to avoid making a shipwreck of faith when it sees that its sufferings are unjustly inflicted.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:44
verses.text: The devil answered the Lord and said: "Skin for skin, yea, all that a man hath will he give for his life.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:45
verses.text: But put forth thine hand now, and touch his bone and his flesh, and he will curse thee to thy face".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:46
verses.text: See how crafty the adversary is, and how hardened in sin his evil days have made him! He knows the difference between things external and internal.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:47
verses.text: He knows that even the philosophers of the world call the former ἀδιάφορα, that is indifferent, and that the perfection of virtue does not consist in losing or disdaining them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:48
verses.text: It is the latter, those that are internal and objects of preference, the loss of which inevitably causes chagrin.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:49
verses.text: Wherefore he boldly contradicts what God has said and declares that Job deserves no praise at all; since he has yielded up no part of himself but only what is outside himself, since he has given for his own skin the skins of his children, and since he has but laid down his purse to secure the health of his body.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:50
verses.text: From this your sagacity may perceive that your trials have so far only reached the point at which you give hide for hide, skin for skin, and are ready to give all that you have for your life.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:51
verses.text: The Lord has not yet stretched forth His hand upon you, or touched your flesh, or broken your bones.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:52
verses.text: Yet it is when such afflictions as these are laid upon you that it is hard not to groan and not to 'bless' God to His face, that is to curse Him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:53
verses.text: The word 'bless' is used in the same way in the books of Kings where it is said of Naboth that he 'blessed' God and the king and was therefore stoned by the people.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:54
verses.text: But the Lord knew His champion and felt sure that this great hero would even in this last and severest conflict prove unconquerable.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:55
verses.text: Therefore He said: "Behold he is in thine hand; but save his life".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:56
verses.text: The holy man's flesh is placed at the devil's disposal, but his vital powers are withheld.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:57
verses.text: For if the devil had smitten that on which sensation and mental judgment depend, the guilt arising from a misuse of these faculties I would have lain at the door not of him who committed the sin but of him who had overthrown the balance of his mind.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:59
verses.text: Others may praise you if they will, and celebrate your victories over the devil.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:60
verses.text: They may eulogize you for the smiling face with which you bore the loss of your daughters, or for the resolution with which, forty days after they fell asleep, you exchanged your mourning for a white robe to attend the dedication of a martyr's bones; unconcerned for a bereavement which was the concern of the whole city, and anxious only to share in a martyr's triumph.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:61
verses.text: Nay, say they, when you bore your wife to burial, it was not as one dead but as one setting forth on a journey.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:62
verses.text: But I shall not deceive you with flattering words or take the ground from under your feet with slippery praises.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:63
verses.text: Rather will I say what it is good for you to hear: "My son, if thou come to serve the Lord, prepare thy soul for temptation," and "when thou shalt have done all those things which are commanded thee, say, I am an unprofitable servant; I have done that which was my duty to do".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:64
verses.text: Say to God: "the children that thou hast taken from me were Thine own gift.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:65
verses.text: The hand-maiden that Thou hast taken to Thyself Thou also didst lend to me for a season to be my solace.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:66
verses.text: I am not aggrieved that Thou hast taken her back, but thankful rather that Thou hast previously given her to me".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:67
verses.text: Once upon a time a rich young man boasted that he had fulfilled all the requirements of the law, but the Lord said to him (as we read in the gospel): "One thing thou lackest: if thou wilt be perfect, go thy way, sell whatsoever thou hast, and give to the poor; and come and follow me".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:68
verses.text: He who declared that he had done all things gave way at the first onset to the power of riches.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:69
verses.text: Wherefore they who are rich find it hard to enter the kingdom of heaven, a kingdom which desires for its citizens souls that soar aloft free from all ties and hindrances.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:70
verses.text: "Go thy way," the Lord says, "and sell" not a part of thy substance but "all that thou hast, and give to the poor;" not to thy friends or kinsfolk or relatives, not to thy wife or to thy children.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:71
verses.text: I will even go farther and say: keep back nothing for yourself because you fear to be some day poor, lest by so doing you share the condemnation of Ananias and Sapphira; but give everything to the poor and make to yourself friends of the mammon of unrighteousness that they may receive you into everlasting habitations.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:72
verses.text: Obey the Master's injunction "follow me," and take the Lord of the world for your possession; that you may be able to sing with the prophet, "The Lord is my portion," and like a true Levite may possess no earthly inheritance.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:73
verses.text: I cannot but advise you thus if you wish to be perfect, if you desire to attain the pinnacle of the apostles' glory, if you wish to take up your cross and to follow Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:74
verses.text: When once you have put your hand to the plough you must not look back; when once you stand on the housetop you must think no more of your clothes within; to escape your Egyptian mistress you must abandon the cloak that belongs to this world.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:75
verses.text: Even Elijah, in his quick translation to heaven could not take his mantle with him, but left in the world the garments of the world.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:76
verses.text: Such conduct, you will object, is for him who would emulate the apostles, for the man who aspires to be perfect.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:77
verses.text: But why should not you aspire to be perfect? Why should not you who hold a foremost place in the world hold a foremost place also in Christ's household? Is it because you have been married? Peter was married too, but when he forsook his ship and his nets he forsook his wife also.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:78
verses.text: The Lord who wills that all men shall be saved and prefers the repentance of a sinner to his death has, in His almighty providence, removed from you this excuse.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:79
verses.text: Your wife can no longer draw you earthwards, but you can follow her as she draws you heavenwards.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:80
verses.text: Provide good things for your children who have gone home before you to the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:81
verses.text: Do not let their portions go to swell their sister's fortune, but use them to ransom your own soul and to give sustenance to the needy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:82
verses.text: These are the necklaces your daughters expect from you; these are the jewels they wish to see sparkle on their foreheads.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:83
verses.text: The money which they would have wasted in buying silks may well be considered saved when it provides cheap clothing for the poor.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:84
verses.text: They ask you for their portions.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:85
verses.text: Now that they are united to their spouse they are loth to appear poor and undistinguished: they desire to have the ornaments that befit their rank.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:87
verses.text: Nor may you excuse yourself on the score of your noble station and the responsibilities of wealth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:88
verses.text: Look at Pammachius and at Paulinus that presbyter of glowing faith both of whom have offered to the Lord not only their riches but themselves.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:89
verses.text: In spite of the devil and his shuffling they have by no means given skin for skin, but have consecrated their own flesh and bones, yea and their very souls unto the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:90
verses.text: Surely these may lead you to higher things both by their example and by their preaching, that is, by their deeds and words.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:91
verses.text: You are of noble birth, so are they: but in Christ they are made nobler still.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:92
verses.text: You are rich and held in repute, so once were they: but now instead of being rich and held in repute they are poor and obscure, yet, because it is for Christ's sake, they are really richer and more famous than ever.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:93
verses.text: You too, it is true, shew yourself beneficent, you are said to minister to the wants of the saints, to entertain monks, and to present large sums of money to churches.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:94
verses.text: This however is only the a b c of your soldiership.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:95
verses.text: You despise money; the world's philosophers have done the same.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:96
verses.text: One of these—to say nothing of the rest—cast the price of many possessions into the sea, saying as he did so "To the bottom with you, ye provokers of evil lusts.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:97
verses.text: I shall drown you in the sea that you may never drown me in sin".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:98
verses.text: If then a philosopher—a creature of vanity whom popular applause can buy and sell—laid down all his burthen at once, how can you think that you have reached virtue's crowning height when you have yielded up but a portion of yours? It is you yourself that the Lord wishes for, "a living sacrifice…acceptable unto God".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:99
verses.text: Yourself, I say, and not what you have.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:100
verses.text: And therefore, as he trained Israel by subjecting it to many plagues and afflictions, so does He now admonish you by sending you trials of different kinds.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:101
verses.text: "For whom the Lord loveth he chasteneth, and scourgeth every son whom he receiveth".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:102
verses.text: The poor widow did but cast two mites into the treasury; yet because she cast in all that she had it is said of her that she surpassed all the rich in offering gifts to God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:103
verses.text: Such gifts are valued not by their weight but by the good-will with which they are made.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:104
verses.text: You may have spent your substance upon numbers of people, and a portion of your fellows may have reason to rejoice in your bounty; yet those who have received nothing at your hands are still more numerous.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:105
verses.text: Neither the wealth of Darius nor the riches of Croesus would suffice to satisfy the wants of the world's poor.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:106
verses.text: But if you once give yourself to the Lord and resolve to follow the Saviour in the perfection of apostolic virtue, then you will come to see what your place has hitherto been, and how you have lagged in the rear of Christ's army.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:107
verses.text: Hardly had you begun to mourn for your dead daughters when the fear of Christ dried the tears of paternal affection upon your cheeks.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:108
verses.text: It was a great triumph of faith, true.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:109
verses.text: But how much greater was that won by Abraham who was content to slay his only son, of whom he had been told that he was to inherit the world, yet did not cease to hope that after death Isaac would live again.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:110
verses.text: Jephthah too offered up his virgin daughter, and for this is placed by the apostle in the roll of the saints.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:111
verses.text: I would not therefore have you offer to the Lord only what a thief may steal from you or an enemy fall upon, or a proscription confiscate, what is liable to fluctuations in value now going up and now down, what belongs to a succession of masters who follow each other as fast as in the sea wave follows wave, and—to say everything in a word—what, whether you like it or not, you must leave behind you when you die.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:112
verses.text: Rather offer to God that which no enemy can carry off and no tyrant take from you, which will go down with you into the grave, nay on to the kingdom of heaven and the enchantments of paradise.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:113
verses.text: You already build monasteries and support in the various islands of Dalmatia a large number of holy men.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:114
verses.text: But you would do better still if you were to live among these holy men as a holy man yourself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:115
verses.text: "Be ye holy, saith the Lord, for I am holy".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:116
verses.text: The apostles boasted that they had left all things and had followed the Saviour.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:117
verses.text: We do not read that they left anything except their ship and their nets; yet they were crowned with the approval of Him who was to be their judge.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:118
verses.text: Why? Because in offering up themselves they had indeed left all that they had.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:120
verses.text: I say all this not in disparagement of your good works or because I wish to under-rate your generosity in almsgiving, but because I do not wish you to be a monk among men of the world and a man of the world among monks.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:121
verses.text: I shall require every sacrifice of you for I hear that your mind is devoted to the service of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:122
verses.text: If some friend, or follower, or kinsman tries to combat this counsel of mine and to recall you to the pleasures of a handsome table, be sure that he is thinking less of your soul than of his own belly, and remember that death in a moment terminates both elegant entertainments and all other pleasures provided by wealth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:123
verses.text: Within the short space of twenty days you have lost two daughters, the one eight years old and the other six; and do you suppose that one so old as you are yourself can live much longer? David tells you how long a time you can look for: "the days of our years are threescore years and ten; and if by reason of strength they be fourscore years, yet is their strength labour and sorrow".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:124
verses.text: Happy is he and to be held worthy of the highest bliss whom old age shall find a servant of Christ and whom the last day shall discover fighting for the Saviour's cause.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:125
verses.text: "He shall not be ashamed when he speaketh with his enemies in the gate".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:126
verses.text: On his entrance into paradise it shall be said to him: "thou in thy lifetime receivedst evil things but nowhere thou art comforted".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:127
verses.text: The Lord will not avenge the same sin twice.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:128
verses.text: Lazarus, formerly poor and full of ulcers, whose sores the dogs licked and who barely managed to live, poor wretch, on the crumbs that fell from the rich man's table, is now welcomed into Abraham's bosom and has the joy of finding a father in the great patriarch.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:129
verses.text: It is difficult nay impossible for a man to enjoy both the good things of the present and those of the future, to satisfy his belly here and his mind yonder, to pass from the pleasures of this life to the pleasures of that, to be first in both worlds, and to be held in honour both on earth and in heaven.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:131
verses.text: And if in your secret thoughts you are troubled because I who give you this advice am not myself what I desire you to be, and because you have seen some after beginning well fall midway on their journey; I shall briefly plead in reply that the words which I speak are not mine but those of the Lord and Saviour, and that I urge upon you not the standard which is possible to myself but the ideal which every true servant of Christ must wish for and realize.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:132
verses.text: Athletes as a rule are stronger than their backers; yet the weaker presses the stronger to put forth all his efforts.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:133
verses.text: Look not upon Judas denying his Lord but upon Paul confessing Him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:134
verses.text: Jacob's father was a man of great wealth; yet, when Jacob went to Mesopotamia, he went alone and destitute leaning upon his staff.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:135
verses.text: When he felt weary he had to lie down by the wayside and, delicately nurtured as he had been by his mother Rebekah, was forced to content himself with a stone for a pillow.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:136
verses.text: Yet it was then that he saw the ladder set up from earth to heaven, and the angels ascending and descending on it, and the Lord above it holding out a helping hand to such as fall and encouraging the climbers to fresh efforts by the vision of Himself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:137
verses.text: Therefore is the spot called Bethel or the house of God; for there day by day there is ascending and descending.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:138
verses.text: When they are careless, even holy men lose their footing; and sinners, if they wash away their stains with tears regain their place.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:139
verses.text: I say this not that those coming down may frighten you but that those going up may stimulate you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:140
verses.text: For evil can never supply a model and even in worldly affairs incentives to virtue come always from the brighter side.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:141
verses.text: But I have forgotten my purpose and the limits set to my letter.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:142
verses.text: I should have liked to say a great deal more.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:143
verses.text: Indeed all that I can say is inadequate alike to satisfy the seriousness of the subject and the claims of your rank.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:144
verses.text: But here is our Ausonius beginning to be impatient for the sheets, hurrying the secretaries, and in his impatience at the neighing of his horse, accusing my poor wits of slowness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:145
verses.text: Remember me, then, and prosper in Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:146
verses.text: And one thing more; follow the example set you at home by the holy Vera, who like a true follower of Christ does not fear to endure the hardships of pilgrimage.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 120:147
verses.text: Find in a woman your 'leader in this high emprise.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 123:23
verses.text: 3?  The date of the letter is 406 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 123:24
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:1
verses.text: Letter CXXII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:2
verses.text: To Rusticus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:3
verses.text: Rusticus and Artemia his wife having made a vow of continence broke it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:4
verses.text: Artemia proceeded to Palestine to do penance for her sin and Rusticus promised to follow her.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:5
verses.text: However he failed to do so, and Jerome was asked to write this letter in the hope that it might induce him to fulfil his promise.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:6
verses.text: The date is about 408 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:7
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:9
verses.text: I am induced to write to you, a stranger to a stranger, by the entreaties of that holy servant of Christ Hedibia and of my daughter in the faith Artemia, once your wife but now no longer your wife but your sister and fellow-servant.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:10
verses.text: Not content with assuring her own salvation she has sought yours also, in former days at home and now in the holy places.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:11
verses.text: She is anxious to emulate the thoughtfulness of the apostles Andrew and Philip; who after Christ had found them, desired in their turn to find, the one his brother Simon and the other his friend Nathanael.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:12
verses.text: To the former of these it was said "Thou art Simon, the son of Jona: thou shalt be called Cephas which is by interpretation a stone;" while the latter, whose name Nathanael means the gift of God, was comforted by Christ's witness to him: "behold an Israelite indeed in whom is no guile".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:13
verses.text: So of old Lot desired to rescue his wife as well as his two daughters, and refusing to leave blazing Sodom and Gomorrah until he was himself half-on-fire, tried to lead forth one who was tied and bound by her past sins.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:14
verses.text: But in her despair she lost her composure, and looking back became a monument of an unbelieving soul.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:15
verses.text: Yet, as if to make up for the loss of a single woman, Lot's glowing faith set free the whole city of Zoar.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:16
verses.text: In fact when he left the dark valleys in which Sodom lay and came to the mountains, the sun rose upon him as he entered Zoar or the little City; so-called because the little faith that Lot possessed, though unable to save greater places, was at least able to preserve smaller ones.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:17
verses.text: For one who had gone so far astray as to live in Gomorrah could not all at once reach the noonland where Abraham, the friend of God, entertained God and His angels.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:18
verses.text: (For it was in Egypt that Joseph fed his brothers, and when the bride speaks to the Bridegroom her cry is: "tell me where thou feedest, where thou makest thy flock to rest at noon".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:19
verses.text: ) Good men have always sorrowed for the sins of others.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:20
verses.text: Samuel of old lamented for Saul because he neglected to treat the ulcers of pride with the balm of penitence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:21
verses.text: And Paul wept for the Corinthians who refused to wash out with their tears the stains of fornication.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:22
verses.text: For the same reason Ezekiel swallowed the book where were written within and without song, and lamentation and woe; the song in praise of the righteous, the lamentation over the penitent, and the woe for those of whom it is written, "When the wicked man falleth into the depths of evil, then is he filled with scorn".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:23
verses.text: It is to these that Isaiah alludes when he says: "in that day did the Lord God of hosts call to weeping and to mourning and to baldness and to girding with sackcloth: and behold joy and gladness, slaying oxen; and killing sheep, eating flesh" and saying, "let us eat and drink, for tomorrow we die".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:24
verses.text: Yet of such persons Ezekiel is bidden to speak thus: "O thou son of man, speak unto the house of Israel; Thus ye speak, saying, If our transgressions and our sins be upon us, and we pine away in them, how should we then live? Say unto them, As I live, saith the Lord God, I have no pleasure in the death of the wicked; but that the wicked turn from his way and live," and again, "turn ye, turn ye from your evil ways; for why will ye die, O house of Israel?" Nothing makes God so angry as when men from despair of better things cleave to those which are worse; and indeed this despair in itself is a sign of unbelief.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:25
verses.text: One who despairs of salvation can have no expectation of a judgment to come.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:26
verses.text: For if he dreaded such, he would by doing good works prepare to meet his Judge.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:27
verses.text: Let us hear what God says through Jeremiah, "withhold thy foot from a rough way and thy throat from thirst" and again "shall they fall, and not arise? Shall he turn away, and not return?" Let us hear also what God says by Isaiah: "When thou shalt turn and bewail thyself, then shalt thou be saved, and then shalt thou know where thou hast hitherto been".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:28
verses.text: We do not realize the miseries of sickness till returning health reveals them to us.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:29
verses.text: So sins serve as a foil to the blessedness of virtue; and light shines more brightly when it is relieved against darkness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:30
verses.text: Ezekiel uses language like that of the other prophets because he is animated by a similar spirit.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:31
verses.text: "Repent," he cries, "and turn yourselves from all your transgressions; so iniquity shall not be your ruin.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:32
verses.text: Cast away from you all your transgressions whereby ye have transgressed; and make you a new heart and a new spirit: for why will ye die, O house of Israel? For I have no pleasure in the death of him that dieth, saith the Lord".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:33
verses.text: Wherefore in a subsequent passage he says: "As I live, saith the Lord God, I have no pleasure in the death of the wicked: but that the wicked turn from his way and live".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:34
verses.text: These words shew us that the mind must not through disbelief in the promised blessings give way to despair; and that the soul once marked out for perdition must not refuse to apply remedies on the ground that its wounds are past curing.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:35
verses.text: Ezekiel describes God as swearing, that if we refuse to believe His promise in regard to our salvation we may at least believe His oath.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:36
verses.text: It is with full confidence that the righteous man prays and says, "Turn us, O God of our salvation, and cause thine anger toward us to cease," and again, "Lord, by thy favour thou hast made my mountain to stand strong: thou didst hide thy face and I was troubled".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:37
verses.text: He means to say, "when I forsook the foulness of my faults for the beauty of virtue, God strengthened my weakness with His grace".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:38
verses.text: Lo, I hear His promise: "I will pursue mine enemies and overtake them: neither will I turn again till they are consumed," so that I who was once thine enemy and a fugitive from thee, shall be laid hold of by thine hand.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:39
verses.text: Cease not from pursuing me till my wickedness is consumed, and I return to my old husband who will give me my wool and my flax, my oil and my fine flour and will feed me with the richest foods.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:40
verses.text: He it was who hedged up and enclosed my evil ways that I might find Him the true way who says in the gospel, "I am the way, the truth, and the life".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:41
verses.text: Hear the words of the prophet: "they that sow in tears shall reap in joy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:42
verses.text: He that goeth forth and weepeth, bearing precious seed, shall doubtless come again with rejoicing, bringing his sheaves with him".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:43
verses.text: Say also with him: "All the night make I my bed to swim; I water my couch with my tears": and again, "As the hart panteth after the water brooks, so panteth my soul after thee, O God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:44
verses.text: My soul thirsteth for God, for the living God: when shall I come and appear before God? My tears have been my meat day and night," and in another place, "O God, thou art my God; early will I seek thee: my soul thirsteth for thee, my flesh longeth for thee in a dry and weary land where no water is.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:45
verses.text: So have I looked upon thee in the sanctuary".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:46
verses.text: For although my soul has thirsted after thee, yet much more have I sought thee by the labour of my flesh and have not been able to look upon thee in thy sanctuary; not at any rate till I have first dwelt in a land barren of sin, where the weary wayfarer is no more assailed by the adversary, and where there are no pools or rivers of lust.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:47
verses.text: The Saviour also wept over the city of Jerusalem because its inhabitants had not repented; and Peter washed out his triple denial with bitter tears, thus fulfilling the words of the prophet: "rivers of waters run down mine eyes".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:48
verses.text: Jeremiah too laments over his impenitent people, saying: "Oh that my head were waters and mine eyes a fountain of tears, that I might weep day and night for…my people!" And farther on he gives a reason for his lamentation: "weep ye not for the dead," he writes, "neither bemoan him: but weep sore for him that goeth away: for he shall return no more".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:49
verses.text: The Jew and the Gentile therefore are not to be bemoaned, for they have never been in the Church and have died once for all (it is of these that the Saviour says: "let the dead bury their dead"); weep rather for those who by reason of their crimes and sins go away from the Church, and who suffering condemnation for their faults shall no more return to it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:50
verses.text: It is in this sense that the prophet speaks to ministers of the Church, calling them its walls and towers, and saying to each in turn, "O wall, let tears run down".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:51
verses.text: In this way, it is prophetically implied, you will fulfil the apostolic precept: "rejoice with them that do rejoice and weep with them that weep," and by your tears you will melt the hard hearts of sinners till they too weep; whereas, if they persist in evil doing they will find these words applied to them, "I…planted thee a noble vine, wholly a right seed: how then art thou turned into the degenerate plant of a strange vine unto me?" and again "saying to a stock, Thou art my father; and to a stone, Thou hast brought me forth: for they have turned their back unto me, and not their face".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:52
verses.text: He means, they would not turn towards God in penitence; but in the hardness of their hearts turned their backs upon Him to insult Him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:53
verses.text: Wherefore also the Lord says to Jeremiah: "hast thou seen that which backsliding Israel hath done? She is gone up upon every high mountain and under every green tree, and there hath played the harlot.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:54
verses.text: And I said after she" had played the harlot and "had done all these things, Turn thou unto me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:55
verses.text: But she returned not".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:57
verses.text: How hard hearted we are and how merciful God is! who even after our many sins urges us to seek salvation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:58
verses.text: Yet not even so are we willing to turn to better things.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:59
verses.text: Hear the words of the Lord: "If a man put away his wife, and she go from him, and become another man's and shall afterwards desire to return to him, will he at all receive her? Will he not loathe her rather? But thou hast played the harlot with many lovers: yet return again to me, saith the Lord".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:60
verses.text: In place of the last clause the true Hebrew text (which is not preserved in the Greek and Latin versions) gives the following: "thou hast forsaken me, yet return, and I will receive thee, saith the Lord".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:61
verses.text: Isaiah also speaking in the same sense uses almost the same words: "Return," he cries, "O children of Israel, ye who think deep counsel and wicked.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:62
verses.text: Return thou unto me and I will redeem thee.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:63
verses.text: I am God, and there is no God else beside me; a just God and a Saviour; there is none beside me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:64
verses.text: Look unto me, and be ye saved, all the ends of the earth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:65
verses.text: Remember this and shew yourselves men: bring it again to mind, O ye transgressors.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:66
verses.text: Return in heart and remember the former things of old: for I am God and there is none else".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:67
verses.text: Joel also writes: "turn ye even to me with all your heart, and with fasting and with weeping and with mourning: and rend your heart and not your garments and turn unto the Lord your God; for he is gracious and merciful…and repenteth him of the evil".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:68
verses.text: How great His mercy is and how excessive—if I may so say—and unspeakable is His pitifulness, the prophet Hosea tells us when he speaks in the Lord's name: "how shall I give thee up, Ephraim? how shall I deliver thee, Israel? how shall I make thee as Admah? How shall I set thee as Zeboim? Mine heart is turned within me, my repentings are kindled together.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:69
verses.text: I will not execute the fierceness of mine anger".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:70
verses.text: David also says in a psalm: "in death there is no remembrance of thee; in the grave who shall give thee thanks?" and in another place: "I acknowledged my sin unto thee, and mine iniquity have I not hid.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:71
verses.text: I said, I will confess my transgressions unto the Lord; and thou forgavest the iniquity of my sin.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:72
verses.text: For this shall every one that is godly pray unto thee in a time when thou mayest be found: surely in the floods of great waters they shall not come nigh unto him".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:74
verses.text: Think how great that weeping must be which deserves to be compared to a flood of waters.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:75
verses.text: Whosoever so weeps and says with the prophet Jeremiah "let not the apple of mine eye cease" shall straightway find the words fulfilled of him: "mercy and truth are met together: righteousness and peace have kissed each other;" so that, if righteousness and truth terrify him, mercy and peace may encourage him to seek salvation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:76
verses.text: The whole repentance of a sinner is exhibited to us in the fifty-first psalm written by David after he had gone in unto Bathsheba the wife of Uriah the Hittite, and when, to the rebuke of the prophet Nathan he had replied, "I have sinned".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:77
verses.text: Immediately that he confessed his fault he was comforted by the words: "the Lord also hath put away thy sin".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:78
verses.text: He had added murder to adultery; yet bursting into tears he says: "Have mercy upon me, O God, according to thy loving kindness: according unto the multitude of thy tender mercies blot out my transgressions".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:79
verses.text: A sin so great needed to find great mercy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:80
verses.text: Accordingly he goes on to say: "Wash me thoroughly from mine iniquity, and cleanse me from my sin.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:81
verses.text: For I acknowledge my transgressions: and my sin is ever before me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:82
verses.text: Against thee, thee only have I sinned"—as a king he had no one to fear but God—"and done this evil in thy sight; that thou mightest be justified when thou speakest and be clear when thou judgest".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:83
verses.text: For "God hath concluded all in unbelief, that he might have mercy upon all".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:84
verses.text: And such was the progress that David made that he who had once been a sinner and a penitent afterwards became a master able to say: "I will teach transgressors thy ways; and sinners shall be converted unto thee".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:85
verses.text: For as "confession and beauty are before God," so a sinner who confesses his sins and says: "my wounds stink and are corrupt because of my foolishness" loses his foul wounds and is made whole and clean.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:86
verses.text: But "he that covereth his sins shall not prosper".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:87
verses.text: The ungodly king Ahab, who shed the blood of Naboth to gain his vineyard, was with Jezebel, the partner less of his bed than of his cruelty, severely rebuked by Elijah.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:88
verses.text: "Thus saith the Lord, hast thou killed and also taken possession?" and again, "in the place where dogs licked the blood of Naboth, shall dogs lick thy blood, even thine;" and "the dogs shall eat Jezebel by the wall of Jezreel".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:89
