verses.text: "And it came to pass"—the passage goes on—"when Ahab heard those words that he rent his clothes, and put sackcloth upon his flesh, and fasted, and lay in sackcloth…and the word of the Lord came to Elijah saying, Because Ahab humbleth himself before me, I will not bring the evil in his days".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:90
verses.text: Ahab's sin and Jezebel's were the same; yet because Ahab repented, his punishment was postponed so as to fall upon his sons, while Jezebel persisting in her wickedness met her doom then and there.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:91
verses.text: Moreover the Lord tells us in the gospel, "the men of Nineveh shall rise in judgment with this generation and shall condemn it: because they repented at the preaching of Jonas;" and again He says "I am not come to call the righteous but sinners to repentance".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:92
verses.text: The lost piece of silver is sought for until it is found in the mire.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:93
verses.text: So also the ninety and nine sheep are left in the wilderness, while the shepherd carries home on his shoulders the one sheep which has gone astray.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:94
verses.text: Wherefore also "there is joy in the presence of the angels over one sinner that repenteth".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:95
verses.text: What a blessed thought it is that heavenly beings rejoice in our salvation! For it is of us that the words are said: "Repent ye: for the kingdom of heaven is at hand".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:96
verses.text: Death and life are contrary the one to the other; there is no middle term.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:97
verses.text: Yet penitence can knit death to life.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:98
verses.text: The prodigal son, we are told, wasted all his substance, and in the far country away from his father "would fain have filled his belly with the husks that the swine did eat".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:99
verses.text: Yet, when he comes back to his father, the fatted calf is killed, a robe and a ring are given to him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:100
verses.text: That is to say, he receives again Christ's robe which he had before defiled, and hears to his comfort the injunction: "let thy garments be always white".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:101
verses.text: He receives the signet of God and cries to the Lord: "Father, I have sinned against heaven and before thee;" and receiving the kiss of reconciliation, he says to Him: "Now is the light of thy countenance sealed upon us, O Lord".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:102
verses.text: Hear the words of Ezekiel: "as for the wickedness of the wicked, he shall not fall thereby in the day that he turneth from his wickedness; neither shall the righteous be able to live for his righteousness in the day that he sinneth".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:103
verses.text: The Lord judges every man according as he finds him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:104
verses.text: It is not the past that He looks upon but the present.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:105
verses.text: Bygone sins there may be, but renewal and conversion remove them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:106
verses.text: "A just man," we read "falleth seven times and riseth up again".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:107
verses.text: If he falls, how is he just? and if he is just, how does he fall? The answer is that a sinner does not lose the name of just if he always repents of his sins and rises again.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:108
verses.text: If a sinner repents, his sins are forgiven him not only till seven times but till seventy times seven.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:109
verses.text: To whom much is forgiven, the same loveth much.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:110
verses.text: The harlot washed with her tears the Saviour's feet and wiped them with her hair; and to her, as a type of the Church gathered from the nations, was the declaration made: "Thy sins are forgiven".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:111
verses.text: The self-righteous Pharisee perished in his pride, while the humble publican was saved by his confession.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:112
verses.text: God makes asseveration by the mouth of the prophet Jeremiah: "At what instant I shall speak concerning a nation and concerning a kingdom, to pluck up, to pull down and to destroy it: if that nation, against whom I have pronounced, turn from their evil, I will repent of the evil that I thought to do unto them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:113
verses.text: And at what instant I shall speak concerning a nation, and concerning a kingdom to build and to plant it; if it do evil in my sight, that it obey not my voice, then I will repent of the good wherewith I said I would benefit them".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:114
verses.text: And immediately he adds: "Behold, I frame evil against you, and devise a device against you: return ye now every one from his evil way, and make your ways and your doings good.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:115
verses.text: And they said, there is no hope: but we will walk after our own devices, and we will every one do the imagination of his evil heart".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:116
verses.text: The righteous Simeon says in the gospel: "Behold, this child is set for the fall and rising again of many," for the fall, that is, of sinners and for the rising again of the penitent.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:117
verses.text: So the apostle writes to the Corinthians: "it is reported commonly that there is fornication among you, and such fornication as is not so much as named among the Gentiles, that one should have his father's wife.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:118
verses.text: And ye are puffed up and have not rather mourned that he that hath done this deed might be taken away from among you".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:119
verses.text: And in his second epistle to the same, "lest such a one should be swallowed up with overmuch sorrow," he calls him back, and begs them to confirm their love towards him, so that he who had been destroyed by incest might be saved by penitence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:120
verses.text: "There is no man clean from sin; even though he has lived but for one day".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:121
verses.text: And the years of man's life are many in number.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:122
verses.text: "The stars are not pure in his sight, and his angels he charged with folly".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:123
verses.text: If there is sin in heaven, how much more must there be sin on earth? If they are stained with guilt who have no bodily temptations, how much more must we be, enveloped as we are in frail flesh and forced to cry each one of us with the apostle: "O wretched man that I am! who shall deliver me from the body of this death? For in my flesh there dwelleth no good thing".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:124
verses.text: For we do not what we would but what we would not; the soul desires to do one thing, the flesh is compelled to do another.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:125
verses.text: If any persons are called righteous in scripture, and not only righteous but righteous in the sight of God, they are called righteous according to that righteousness mentioned in the passage I have quoted: "A just man falleth seven times and riseth up again," and on the principle laid down that the wickedness of the wicked shall not hurt him in the day that he turns to repentance.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:126
verses.text: In fact Zachariah the father of John who is described as a righteous man sinned in disbelieving the message sent to him and was at once punished with dumbness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:127
verses.text: Even Job, who at the outset of his history is spoken of as perfect and upright and uncomplaining, is afterwards proved to be a sinner both by God's words and by his own confession.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:128
verses.text: If Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, the prophets also and the apostles were by no means free from sin and if the finest wheat had chaff mixed with it, what can be said of us of whom it is written: "What is the chaff to the wheat, saith the Lord?" Yet the chaff is reserved for future burning; as also are the tares which at present are mingled with the growing corn.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:129
verses.text: For one shall come whose fan is in His hand, and shall purge His floor, and shall gather His wheat into the garner, and shall burn the chaff in the fire of hell.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:131
verses.text: Roaming thus through the fairest fields of scripture I have culled its loveliest flowers to weave for your brows a garland of penitence; for my aim is that, flying on the wings of a dove, you may find rest and make your peace with the Father of mercy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:132
verses.text: Your former wife, who is now your sister and fellow-servant, has told me that, acting on the apostolic precept, you and she lived apart by consent that you might give yourselves to prayer; but that after a time your feet sank beneath you as if resting on water and indeed—to speak plainly—gave way altogether.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:133
verses.text: For her part she heard the Lord saying to her as to Moses: "as for thee stand thou here by me;" and with the psalmist she said of Him: "He hath set my feet upon a rock".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:134
verses.text: But your house—she went on—having no sure foundation of faith fell before a whirlwind of the devil.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:135
verses.text: Hers however still stands in the Lord, and does not refuse its shelter to you; you can still be joined in spirit to her to whom you were once joined in body.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:136
verses.text: For, as the apostle says, "he that is joined unto the Lord is one spirit" with him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:137
verses.text: Moreover, when the fury of the barbarians and the risk of captivity separated you again, you promised with a solemn oath that, if she made her way to the holy places, you would follow her either immediately or later, and that you would try to save your soul now that by your carelessness you had seemed to lose it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:138
verses.text: Perform, now, the vow which you then made in the presence of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:139
verses.text: Human life is uncertain.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:140
verses.text: Therefore, lest you may be snatched away before you have fulfilled your promise, imitate her whose teacher you ought to have been.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:141
verses.text: For shame! the weaker vessel overcomes the world, and yet the stronger is overcome by it!  A woman leadeth in the high emprise;  and yet you will not follow her when her salvation leads you to the threshold of the faith! Perhaps, however, you desire to save the remnants of your property and to see the last of your friends and fellow-citizens and of their cities and villas.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:142
verses.text: If so, amid the horrors of captivity, in the presence of exulting foes, and in the shipwreck of the province, at least hold fast to the plank of penitence; and remember your fellow-servant who daily sighs for your salvation and never despairs of it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:143
verses.text: While you are wandering about your own country (though, indeed, you no longer have a country; that which you once had, you have lost) she is interceding for you in the venerable spots which witnessed the nativity, crucifixion and resurrection of our Lord and Saviour, and in the first of which He uttered His infant-cry.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:144
verses.text: She draws you to her by her prayers that you may be saved, if not by your own exertions, at any rate by her faith.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:145
verses.text: Of old one lay upon his bed sick of the palsy, so powerless in all his joints that he could neither move his feet to walk nor his hands to pray; yet when he was carried to our Lord by others, he was by Him so completely restored to health as to carry the bed which a little before had carried him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:146
verses.text: You too—absent in the body but present to her faith—your fellow-servant offers to her Lord and Saviour; and with the Canaanite woman she says of you: "my daughter is grievously vexed with a devil".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:147
verses.text: Souls are of no sex; therefore I may fairly call your soul the daughter of hers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:148
verses.text: For as a mother coaxes her unweaned child which is as yet unable to take solid food; so does she call you to the milk suitable for babes and offer to you the sustenance that a nursing mother gives.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 124:149
verses.text: Thus shall you be able to say with the prophet: "I have gone astray like a lost sheep; seek thy servant; for I do not forget thy commandments".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:1
verses.text: Letter CXXIII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:2
verses.text: To Ageruchia.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:3
verses.text: An appeal to the widow Ageruchia, highborn lady of Gaul, not to marry again.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:4
verses.text: It should be compared with the letters to Furia (LIV.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:5
verses.text: ) and to Salvina (LXXIX.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:6
verses.text: ) The allusion to Stilicho's treaty with Alaric fixes the date to 409 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:7
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:9
verses.text: I must look for a new track on the old road and devise a natural treatment, the same yet not the same, for a hackneyed and well-worn theme.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:10
verses.text: It is true that there is but one road; yet one can often reach one's goal by striking across country.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:11
verses.text: I have several times written letters to widows in which for their instruction I have sought out examples from scripture, weaving its varied flowers into a single garland of chastity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:12
verses.text: On the present occasion I address myself to Ageruchia; whose very name (allotted to her by the divine guidance) has proved a prophecy of her after-life.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:13
verses.text: Around her stand her grandmother, her mother, and her aunt; a noble band of tried Christian women.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:14
verses.text: Her grandmother, Metronia, now a widow for forty years, reminds us of Anna the daughter of Phanuel in the gospel.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:15
verses.text: Her mother, Benigna, now in the fourteenth year of her widowhood, is surrounded by virgins whose chastity bears fruit a hundredfold.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:16
verses.text: The sister of Celerinus, Ageruchia's father, has nursed her niece from infancy and indeed took her into her lap the moment that she was born.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:17
verses.text: Deprived of the solace of her husband she has for twenty years trained her brother's child, teaching her the lessons which she has learned from her own mother.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:19
verses.text: I make these brief remarks to shew my young friend that in resolving not to marry again she does but perform a duty to her family; and that, while she will deserve no praise for fulfilling it, she will be justly blamed if she fails to do so.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:20
verses.text: The more so that she has a posthumous son named after his father Simplicius and thus cannot plead loneliness or the want of an heir.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:21
verses.text: For the lust of many shelters itself under such excuses as though the promptings of incontinence were only a desire for offspring.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:22
verses.text: But why do I speak as to one who wavers when I hear that Ageruchia seeks the church's protection against the many suitors whom she meets in the palace? For the devil inflames men to vie with one another in proving the chastity of our beloved widow; and rank and beauty, youth and riches cause her to be sought after by all.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:23
verses.text: But the greater the assaults that are made upon her continence, the greater will be the rewards that will follow her victory.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:25
verses.text: But no sooner do I clear the harbour than I find my way to the sea barred by a rock.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:26
verses.text: I am confronted with the authority of the apostle Paul who in writing to Timothy thus speaks concerning widows: "I will therefore that the younger women marry, bear children, guide the house, give none occasion to the adversary to speak reproachfully.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:27
verses.text: For some are already turned aside after Satan".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:28
verses.text: I must accordingly begin by considering the meaning of this pronouncement and examining the context of the whole passage.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:29
verses.text: I must then plant my feet in the steps of the apostle and, as the saying goes, not deviate a hair's breadth from them either to this side or to that.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:30
verses.text: He had previously described his ideal widow as one who had been the wife of one man, who had brought up children, who was well reported of for good works, who had relieved the afflicted with her substance, whose trust had been in God, and who had continued in prayer day and night.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:31
verses.text: With her he contrasted her opposite, saying: "She that liveth in pleasure is dead while she liveth".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:32
verses.text: And that he might warn his disciple Timothy with all needful admonition, he immediately added these words: "the younger widows refuse: for when they have begun to wax wanton against Christ they will marry; having damnation because they have cast off their first faith".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:33
verses.text: It is then for these who have outraged Christ their Spouse by committing fornication against Him (for this is the sense of the Greek word καταστρηνιάσωσι )—it is for these that the apostle wishes a second marriage, thinking digamy preferable to fornication; but this second marriage is a concession and not a command.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:35
verses.text: We must also take the passage clause by clause.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:36
verses.text: "I will," he says, "that the younger women marry".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:37
verses.text: Why, pray? because I would not have young women commit fornication.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:38
verses.text: "That they bear children;" for what reason? That they may not be induced by fear of the consequences to kill children whom they have conceived in adultery.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:39
verses.text: "That they be the heads of households".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:40
verses.text: Wherefore, pray? Because it is much more tolerable that a woman should marry again than that she should be a prostitute, and better that she should have a second husband than several paramours.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:41
verses.text: The first alternative brings relief in a miserable plight, but the second involves a sin and its punishment.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:42
verses.text: He continues: "that they give none occasion to the adversary to speak reproachfully," a brief and comprehensive precept in which many admonitions are summed up.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:43
verses.text: As for instance these: that a woman must not bring discredit upon her profession of widowhood by too great attention to her dress, that she must not draw troops of young men after her by gay smiles or expressive glances, that she must not profess one thing by her words and another by her behaviour, that she must give no ground for the application to herself of the well known line:  She gave a meaning look and slyly smiled.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:44
verses.text: Lastly, that Paul may compress into a few words all the reasons for such marriages, he shews the motive of his command by saying: "for some are already turned aside after Satan".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:45
verses.text: Thus he allows to the incontinent a second marriage, or in case of need a third, simply that he may rescue them from Satan, preferring that a woman should be joined to the worst of husbands rather than to the devil.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:46
verses.text: To the Corinthians he uses somewhat similar language: "I say therefore to the unmarried and widows, It is good for them if they abide even as I.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:47
verses.text: But if they cannot contain, let them marry: for it is better to marry than to burn".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:48
verses.text: Why, O apostle, is it better to marry? He answers immediately: because it is worse to burn.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:50
verses.text: Apart from these considerations, that which is absolutely good and not merely relatively so is to be as the apostle, that is loose, not bound; free, not enslaved; caring for the things of God, not for the things of a wife.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:51
verses.text: Immediately afterwards he adds: "The wife is bound by the law to her husband as long as her husband liveth, but if her husband be fallen asleep, she is at liberty to be married to whom she will; only in the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:52
verses.text: But she is happier if she so abide, after my judgment: and I think also that I have the spirit of God".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:53
verses.text: This passage corresponds with the former in meaning, because the spirit of the two is the same.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:54
verses.text: For though the epistles are different, they are the work of one author.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:55
verses.text: While her husband lives the woman is bound, and when he is dead, she is loosed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:56
verses.text: Marriage then is a bond, and widowhood is the loosing of it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:57
verses.text: The wife is bound to the husband and the husband to the wife; and so close is the tie that they have no power over their own bodies, but each stands indebted to the other.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:58
verses.text: They who are under the yoke of wedlock have not the option of choosing continence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:59
verses.text: When the apostle adds the words "only in the Lord," he excludes heathen marriages of which he had spoken in another place thus: "be ye not unequally yoked together with unbelievers: for what fellowship hath righteousness with unrighteousness? and what communion hath light with darkness? and what concord hath Christ with Belial? or what part hath he that believeth with an infidel? and what agreement hath the temple of God with idols?" We must not plough with an ox and an ass together; nor weave our wedding garment of different colours.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:60
verses.text: He at once takes back the concession he made, and, as if repenting of his opinion, withdraws it by saying: "She is happier if she so abide," that is, unmarried; and declares that in his judgment this course is preferable.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:61
verses.text: And that this may not be made light of as a merely human utterance, he claims for it the authority of the Holy Spirit, so that we are listening not to a fellowman making concessions to the weakness of the flesh but to the Holy Spirit using the apostle for his mouthpiece.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:63
verses.text: Again, no widow of youthful age must quiet her qualms of conscience by the plea that he gives commandment that no widow is to be taken into the number under three-score years old.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:64
verses.text: He does not by this arrangement urge unmarried girls or youthful widows to marry, seeing that even of the married he says: "the time is short: it remaineth that they that have wives be as though they had none".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:65
verses.text: No, he is speaking of widows who have relations able to support them, who have sons and grandsons to be responsible for their maintenance.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:66
verses.text: The apostle commands these latter to shew piety at home, and to requite their parents and to relieve them adequately; that the church may not be charged, but may be free to relieve those that are widows indeed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:67
verses.text: "Honour widows," he writes, "that are widows indeed," that is, such as are desolate and have no relations to help them, who cannot labour with their hands, who are weakened by poverty and overcome by years, whose trust is in God and their only work prayer.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:68
verses.text: From which it is easy to infer that the younger widows, unless they are excused by ill health, are either left to their own exertions or else are consigned to the care of their children or relations.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:69
verses.text: The word 'honour' in this passage implies either alms or a gift, as also in the verse immediately following: "Let the elders…be counted worthy of double honour, especially they who labour in the word and doctrine".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:70
verses.text: So also in the gospel when the Lord discusses that commandment of the Law which says: "Honour thy father and thy mother," He declares that it is to be interpreted not of mere words which while offering an empty shew of regard may still leave a parent's wants unrelieved, but of the actual provision of the necessaries of life.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:71
verses.text: The Lord commanded that poor parents should be supported by their children and that these should pay them back when old those benefits which they had themselves received in their childhood.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:72
verses.text: The scribes and pharisees on the other hand taught the children to answer their parents by saying: "It is Corban, that is to say, a gift which I have promised to the altar and engaged to present to the temple: it will relieve you as much there, as if I were to give it you directly to buy food".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:73
verses.text: So it frequently happened that while father and mother were destitute their children were offering sacrifices for the priests and scribes to consume.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:74
verses.text: If then the apostle compels poor widows—yet only those who are young and not broken down by sickness—to labour with their hands that the church, not charged with their maintenance, may be able to support such widows as are old, what plea can be urged by one who has abundance of this world's goods, both for her own wants and those of others, and who can make to herself friends of the mammon of unrighteousness able to receive her into everlasting habitations?  Consider too that no one is to be elected a widow, except she has been the wife of one husband.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:75
verses.text: We sometimes fancy it to be the distinctive mark of the priesthood that none but monogamists shall be admitted to the altar.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:76
verses.text: But not only are the twice-married excluded from the priestly office, they are debarred from receiving the alms of the church.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:77
verses.text: A woman who has resorted to a second marriage is held unworthy to be supported by the faithful.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:78
verses.text: And even the layman is bound by the law of the priest, for his conduct must be such as to admit of his election to the priesthood.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:79
verses.text: If he has been twice married, he cannot be so elected.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:80
verses.text: Therefore, as priests are chosen from the ranks of laymen, the layman also is bound by the commandment, fulfilment of which is indispensable for the attainment of the priesthood.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:82
verses.text: We must distinguish between what the apostle himself desires and what he is compelled to acquiesce in.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:83
verses.text: If he allows me to marry again, this is due to my own incontinence and not to his wish.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:84
verses.text: For he wishes all men to be as he is, and to think the things of God, and when once they are loosed no more to seek to be bound.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:85
verses.text: But when he sees unstable men in danger through their incontinence of falling into the abyss of lust, he extends to them the offer of a second marriage; that, if they must wallow in the mire, it may be with one and not with many.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:86
verses.text: The husband of a second wife must not consider this a harsh saying or one that conflicts with the rule laid down by the apostle.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:87
verses.text: The apostle is of two minds: first, he proclaims a command, "I say therefore to the unmarried and widows, It is good for them if they abide even as I".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:88
verses.text: Next.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:89
verses.text: he makes a concession, "But if they cannot contain, let them marry: for it is better to marry than to burn".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:90
verses.text: He first shews what he himself desires, then that in which he is forced to acquiesce.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:91
verses.text: He wishes us—after one marriage—to abide even as he, that is, unmarried, and sets before us in his own apostolic example an instance of the blessedness of which he speaks.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:92
verses.text: If however he finds that we are unwilling to do as he wishes, he makes a concession to our incontinence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:93
verses.text: Which then of the two alternatives do we choose for ourselves? The one which he prefers and which is in itself good? Or the one which in comparison with evil is tolerable, yet as it is only a substitute for evil is not altogether good? Suppose that we choose that course which the apostle does not wish but to which he only consents against his will, allowing those who seek lower ends to have their own way; in this case we carry out not the apostle's wish but our own.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:94
verses.text: We read in the old testament that the daughters of the priests who have been married once and have become widows are to eat of the priests' food and that when they die they are to be buried with the same ceremonies as their father and mother.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:95
verses.text: If on the other hand they take other husbands they are to be kept apart both from their father and from the sacrifices and are to be counted as strangers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:97
verses.text: These restraints on marriage are observed even among the heathen; and it is our condemnation if the true faith cannot do for Christ what false ones do for the devil, who has substituted for the saving chastity of the gospel a damning chastity of his own.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:98
verses.text: The Athenian hierophant disowns his manhood and weakens his passions by a perpetual restraint.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:99
verses.text: The holy office of the flamen is limited to those who have been once married, and the attendants of the flamens' wives must also have had but one husband.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:100
verses.text: Only monogamists are allowed to share in the sacred rites connected with the Egyptian bull.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:101
verses.text: I need say nothing of the vestal virgins and those of Apollo, the Achivan Juno, Diana, and Minerva, all of whom waste away in the perpetual virginity required by their vocation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:102
verses.text: I will just glance at the queen of Carthage who was willing to burn herself rather than marry king Iarbas; at the wife of Hasdrubal who taking her two children one in each hand cast, herself into the flames beneath her rather than surrender her honour; and at Lucretia who having lost the prize of her chastity refused to survive the defilement of her soul.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:103
verses.text: I will not lengthen my letter by quoting the many instances of the like virtue which you can read to your profit in my first book against Jovinian.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:104
verses.text: I will merely relate one which took place in your own country and which will shew you that chastity is held in high honour even among wild and barbarous and cruel peoples.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:105
verses.text: Once the Teutons who came from the remote shores of the German Ocean overran all parts of Gaul, and it was only when they had cut to pieces several Roman armies that Marius at last defeated them in an encounter at Aquae Sextiae.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:106
verses.text: By the conditions of the surrender three hundred of their married women were to be handed over to the Romans.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:107
verses.text: When the Teuton matrons heard of this stipulation they first begged the consul that they might be set apart to minister in the temples of Ceres and Venus; and then when they failed to obtain their request and were removed by the lictors, they slew their little children and next morning were all found dead in each other's arms having strangled themselves in the night.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:109
verses.text: Shall then a highborn lady do what these barbarian women refused to do even as prisoners of war? After losing a first husband, good or bad as the case may be, shall she make trial of a second, and thus run counter to the judgment of God? And in case that she immediately loses this second, shall she take a third? And if he too is called to his rest, shall she go on to a fourth and a fifth, and by so doing identify herself with the harlots? No, a widow must take every precaution not to overstep by an inch the bounds of chastity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:110
verses.text: For if she once oversteps them and breaks through the modesty which becomes a matron, she will soon riot in every kind of excess; so much so that the prophet's words shall be true of her "Thou hast a whore's forehead, thou refusest to be ashamed".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:111
verses.text: What then? do I condemn second marriages? not at all; but I commend first ones.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:112
verses.text: Do I expel twice-married persons from the church? Far from it; but I urge those who have been once married to lives of continence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:113
verses.text: The Ark of Noah contained unclean animals as well as clean.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:114
verses.text: It contained both creeping things and human beings.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:115
verses.text: In a great house there are vessels of different kinds, some to honour and some to dishonour.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:116
verses.text: In the gospel parable the seed sown in the good ground brings forth fruit, some an hundredfold, some sixtyfold, some thirtyfold.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:117
verses.text: The hundredfold which comes first betokens the crown of virginity; the sixtyfold which comes next refers to the work of widows; while the thirtyfold—indicated by joining together the points of the thumb and forefinger—denotes the marriage-tie.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:118
verses.text: What room is left for double marriages? None.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:119
verses.text: They are not counted.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:120
verses.text: Such weeds do not grow in good ground but among briers and thorns, the favourite haunts of those foxes to whom the Lord compares the impious Herod.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:121
verses.text: A woman who marries more than once fancies herself worthy of praise because she is not so bad as the prostitutes, because she compares favourably with these victims of indiscriminate lust by surrendering herself to one alone and not to a number.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:123
verses.text: The story which I am about to relate is an incredible one; yet it is vouched for by many witnesses.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:124
verses.text: A great many years ago when I was helping Damasus bishop of Rome with his ecclesiastical correspondence, and writing his answers to the questions referred to him by the councils of the east and west, I saw a married couple, both of whom were sprung from the very dregs of the people.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:125
verses.text: The man had already buried twenty wives, and the woman had had twenty-two husbands.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:126
verses.text: Now they were united to each other as each believed for the last time.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:127
verses.text: The greatest curiosity prevailed both among men and women to see which of these two veterans would live to bury the other.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:128
verses.text: The husband triumphed and walked before the bier of his often-married wife, amid a great concourse of people from all quarters, with garland and palm-branch, scattering spelt as he went along among an approving crowd.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:129
verses.text: What shall we say to such a woman as that? Surely just what the Lord said to the woman of Samaria: "Thou hast had twenty-two husbands, and he by whom you are now buried is not your husband".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:131
verses.text: I beseech you therefore, my devout daughter in Christ, not to dwell on those passages which offer succour to the incontinent and the unhappy but rather to read those in which chastity is crowned.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:132
verses.text: It is enough for you that you have lost the first and highest kind, that of virginity, and that you have passed through the third to the second; that is to say, having formerly fulfilled the obligations of a wife, that you now live in continence as a widow.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:133
verses.text: Think not of the lowest grade, nay of that which does not count at all, I mean, second marriage; and do not seek for far fetched precedents to justify you in marrying again.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:134
verses.text: You cannot too closely imitate your grandmother, your mother, and your aunt; whose teaching and advice as to life will form for you a rule of virtue.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:135
verses.text: For if many wives in the lifetime of their husbands come to realize the truth of the apostle's words: "all things are lawful unto me but all things are not expedient," and make eunuchs of themselves for the kingdom of heaven's sake either by consent after their regeneration through the baptismal laver, or else in the ardour of their faith immediately after their marriage; why should not a widow, who by God's decree has ceased to have a husband, joyfully cry again and again with Job: "the Lord gave, and the Lord hath taken away," and seize the opportunity offered to her of having power over her own body instead of again becoming the servant of a man.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:136
verses.text: Assuredly it is much harder to abstain from enjoying what you have than it is to regret what you have lost.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:137
verses.text: Virginity is the easier because virgins know nothing of the promptings of the flesh, and widowhood is the harder because widows cannot help thinking of the license they have enjoyed in the past.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:138
verses.text: And it is harder still if they suppose their husbands to be lost and not gone before; for while the former alternative brings pain, the latter causes joy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:140
verses.text: The creation of the first man should teach us to reject more marriages than one.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:141
verses.text: There was but one Adam and but one Eve; in fact the woman was fashioned from a rib of Adam.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:142
verses.text: Thus divided they were subsequently joined together in marriage; in the words of scripture "the twain shall be one flesh," not two or three.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:143
verses.text: "Therefore shall a man leave his father and his mother, and shall cleave unto his wife".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:144
verses.text: Certainly it is not said "to his wives".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:145
verses.text: Paul in explaining the passage refers it to Christ and the church; making the first Adam a monogamist in the flesh and the second a monogamist in the spirit.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:146
verses.text: As there is one Eve who is "the mother of all living," so is there one church which is the parent of all Christians.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:147
verses.text: And as the accursed Lamech made of the first Eve two separate wives, so also the heretics sever the second into several churches which, according to the apocalypse of John, ought rather to be called synagogues of the devil than congregations of Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:148
verses.text: In the Book of Songs we read as follows:—"there are threescore queens, and fourscore concubines, and virgins without number.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:149
verses.text: My dove, my undefiled is but one; she is the only one of her mother, she is the choice one of her that bare her".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:150
verses.text: It is to this choice one that the same John addresses an epistle in these words, "the elder unto the elect lady and her children".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:151
verses.text: So too in the case of the ark which the apostle Peter interprets as a type of the church, Noah brings in for his three sons one wife apiece and not two.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:152
verses.text: Likewise of the unclean animals pairs only are taken, male and female, to shew that digamy has no place even among brutes, creeping things, crocodiles and lizards.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:153
verses.text: And if of the clean animals there are seven taken of each kind, that is, an uneven number; this points to the palm which awaits virginal chastity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:154
verses.text: For on leaving the ark Noah sacrificed victims to God not of course of the animals taken by twos for these were kept to multiply their species, but of those taken by sevens some of which had been set apart for sacrifice.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:156
verses.text: It is true that the patriarchs had each of them more wives than one and that they had numerous concubines besides.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:157
verses.text: And as if their example was not enough, David had many wives and Solomon a countless number.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:158
verses.text: Judah went in to Tamar thinking her to be a harlot; and according to the letter that killeth the prophet Hosea married not only a whore but an adulteress.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:159
verses.text: If these instances are to justify us let us neigh after every woman that we meet; like the people of Sodom and Gomorrah let us be found by the last day buying and selling, marrying and giving in marriage; and let us only end our marrying with the close of our lives.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:160
verses.text: And if both before and after the deluge the maxim held good: "be fruitful and multiply and replenish the earth:" what has that to do with us upon whom the ends of the ages are come, unto whom it is said, "the time is short," and "now the axe is laid unto the root of the trees;" that is to say, the forests of marriage and of the law must be cut down by the chastity of the gospel.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:161
verses.text: There is "a time to embrace, and a time to refrain from embracing".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:162
verses.text: Owing to the near approach of the captivity Jeremiah is forbidden to take a wife.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:163
verses.text: In Babylon Ezekiel says: "my wife is dead and my mouth is opened".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:164
verses.text: Neither he who wished to marry nor he who had married could in wedlock prophesy freely.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:165
verses.text: In days gone by men rejoiced to hear it said of them: "thy children shall be like olive plants round about thy table," and "thou shalt see thy children's children".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:166
verses.text: But now it is said of those who live in continence: "he that is joined unto the Lord is one spirit;" and "my soul followeth hard after thee: thy right hand upholdeth me".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:167
verses.text: Then it was said "an eye for an eye;" now the commandment is "whosoever shall smite thee on thy right cheek, turn to him the other also".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:168
verses.text: In those days men said to the warrior: "gird thy sword upon thy thigh, O most mighty;" now it is said to Peter: "put up again thy sword into his place: for all they that take the sword shall perish with the sword".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:169
verses.text: In speaking thus I do not mean to sever the law from the gospel, as Marcion falsely does.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:170
verses.text: No, I receive one and the same God in both who, as the time and the object vary, is both the Beginning and the End, who sows that He may reap, who plants that He may have somewhat to cut down, and who lays the foundation that in the fulness of time He may crown the edifice.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:171
verses.text: Besides, if we are to deal with symbols and types of things to come, we must judge of them not by our own opinions but in the light of the apostle's explanations.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:172
verses.text: Hagar and Sarah, or Sinai and Zion, are typical of the two testaments.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:173
verses.text: Leah who was tender-eyed and Rachel whom Jacob loved signify the synagogue and the church.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:174
verses.text: So likewise do Hannah and Peninnah of whom the former, at first barren, afterwards exceeded the latter in fruitfulness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:175
verses.text: In Isaac and Rebekah we see an early example of monogamy: it was only to Rebekah that the Lord revealed Himself in the hour of childbirth and she alone went of herself to enquire of the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:176
verses.text: What shall I say of Tamar who bore twin sons, Pharez and Zarah? At their birth was broken down that middle wall of partition which typified the division existing between the two peoples; while the binding of Zarah's hand with the scarlet thread even then marked the conscience of the Jews with the stain of Christ's blood.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:177
verses.text: And how shall I speak of the whore married by the prophet who is a figure either of the church as gathered in from the Gentiles or—an interpretation which better suits the passage—of the synagogue? First adopted from among the idolaters by Abraham and Moses, this has now denied the Saviour and proved unfaithful to Him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:178
verses.text: Therefore it has long been deprived of its altar, priests, and prophets and has to abide many days for its first husband.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:179
verses.text: For when the fulness of the Gentiles shall have come in, all Israel shall be saved.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:181
verses.text: I have tried to compress a great deal into a limited space as a draughtsman does when he delineates a large country in a small map.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:182
verses.text: For I wish to deal with other questions, the first of which I shall give in Anna's words to her sister Dido:  Why waste your youth alone in ceaseless grief  Unblest with offspring, sweetest gift of love?  Think you the buried dead require this?  To whom the sufferer thus briefly replies:  'Twas you, my sister, you, who were the first  To plunge my frenzied soul into this woe.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:183
verses.text: Why could I not have lived a virgin life  Like some wild creature innocent of care?  Alas! I pledged my soul unto the dead:  I vowed a vow and I have broken it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:184
verses.text: You set before me the joys of wedlock.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:185
verses.text: I for my part will remind you of Dido's sword and pyre and funeral flames.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:186
verses.text: In marriage there is not so much good to be hoped for as there is evil which may happen and must be feared.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:187
verses.text: Passion when indulged always brings repentance with it; it is never satisfied, and once quenched it is soon kindled anew.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:188
verses.text: Its growth or decay is a matter of habit; led like a captive by impulse it refuses to obey reason.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:189
verses.text: But you will argue, 'the management of wealth and property requires the superintendence of a husband.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:190
verses.text: ' Do you mean to say that the affairs of those who live single are ruined; and that, unless you make yourself as much a slave as your own servants, you will not be able to govern your household? Do not your grandmother, your mother and your aunt enjoy even more than their old influence and respect, looked up to as they are by the whole province and by the leaders of the churches? Do not soldiers and travellers manage their domestic affairs and give entertainments to one another with no wives to help them? Why can you not have grave and elderly servants or freed-men, such as those who have nursed you in your childhood, to preside over your house, to answer public calls, to pay taxes; men who will look up to you as a patroness, who will love you as a nursling, who will revere you as a saint? "Seek first the kingdom of God, and all these things shall be added unto you".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:191
verses.text: If you are careful for raiment the gospel bids you "consider the lilies;" and, if for food, to go back to the fowls which "sow not neither do they reap; yet your heavenly father feedeth them".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:192
verses.text: How many virgins and widows there are who have looked after their property for themselves without thereby incurring any stain of scandal!  15.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:193
verses.text: Do not associate with young women or cleave to them, for it is on account of such that the apostle makes his concession of second marriage, and so you may be shipwrecked in what appears to be calm water.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:194
verses.text: If Paul can say to Timothy, "the younger widows refuse," and again "love the elder women as mothers; the younger as sisters, with all purity," what plea can you urge for refusing to hear my admonitions? Avoid all persons to whom a suspicion of evil living may attach itself, and do not content yourself with the trite answer, 'my own conscience is enough for me; I do not care what people say of me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:195
verses.text: ' That was not the principle on which the apostle acted.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:196
verses.text: He provided things honest not only in the sight of God but in the sight of all men; that the name of God might not be blasphemed among the Gentiles.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:197
verses.text: Though he had power to lead about a sister, a wife, he would not do so, for he did not wish to be judged by an unbeliever's conscience.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:198
verses.text: And, though he might have lived by the gospel, he laboured day and night with his own hands, that he might not be burdensome to the believers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:199
verses.text: "If meat," he says, "make my brother to offend.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:200
verses.text: I will eat no flesh while the world standeth".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:201
verses.text: Let us then say, if a sister or a brother causes not one or two but the whole church to offend, 'I will not see that sister or that brother.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:202
verses.text: ' It is better to lose a portion of one's substance than to imperil the salvation of one's soul.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:203
verses.text: It is better to lose that which some day, whether we like it or not, must be lost to us and to give it up freely, than to lose that for which we should sacrifice all that we have.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:204
verses.text: Which of us can add—I will not say a cubit for that would be an immense addition—but the tenth part of a single inch to his stature? Why are we careful what we shall eat or what we shall drink? Let us "take no thought for the morrow: sufficient unto the day is the evil thereof".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:205
verses.text: Jacob in his flight from his brother left behind in his father's house great riches and made his way with nothing into Mesopotamia.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:206
verses.text: Moreover, to prove to us his powers of endurance, he took a stone for his pillow.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:207
verses.text: Yet as he lay there he beheld a ladder set up on the earth reaching to heaven and behold the Lord stood above it, and the angels ascended and descended on it; the lesson being thus taught that the sinner must not despair of salvation nor the righteous man rest secure in his virtue.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:208
verses.text: To pass over much of the story (for there is no time to explain all the points in the narrative) after twenty years he who before had passed over Jordan with his staff returned into his native land with three droves of cattle, rich in flocks and herds and richer still in children.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:209
verses.text: The apostles likewise travelled throughout the world without either money in their purses, or staves in their hands, or shoes on their feet; and yet they could speak of themselves as "having nothing and yet possessing all things".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:210
verses.text: "Silver and gold," say they, "have we none, but such as we have give we thee: in the name of Jesus Christ of Nazareth rise up and walk".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:211
verses.text: For they were not weighed down with the burthen of riches.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:212
verses.text: Therefore they could stand, as Elijah, in the crevice of the rock, they could pass through the needle's eye, and behold the back parts of the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:213
verses.text: But as for us we burn with covetousness and, even while we declaim against the love of money, we hold out our skirts to catch gold and never have enough.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:214
verses.text: There is a common saying about the Megarians which may rightly be applied to all who suffer from this passion: "They build as if they are to live forever; they live as if they are to die to-morrow".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:215
verses.text: We do the same, for we do not believe the Lord's words.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:216
verses.text: When we attain the age which all desire we forget the nearness of that death which as human beings we owe to nature and with futile hope promise to ourselves a long length of years.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:217
verses.text: No old man is so weak and decrepit as to suppose that he will not live for one year more.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:218
verses.text: A forgetfulness of his true condition gradually creeps upon him; so that—earthly creature that he is and close to dissolution as he stands—he is lifted up into pride, and in imagination seats himself in heaven.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:220
verses.text: But what am I doing? Whilst I talk about the cargo, the vessel itself founders.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:221
verses.text: He that letteth is taken out of the way, and yet we do not realize that Antichrist is near.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:222
verses.text: Yes, Antichrist is near whom the Lord Jesus Christ "shall consume with the spirit of his mouth".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:223
verses.text: "Woe unto them," he cries, "that are with child, and to them that give suck in those days".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:224
verses.text: Now these things are both the fruits of marriage.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:225
verses.text: I shall now say a few words of our present miseries.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:226
verses.text: A few of us have hitherto survived them, but this is due not to anything we have done ourselves but to the mercy of the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:227
verses.text: Savage tribes in countless numbers have overrun all parts of Gaul.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:228
verses.text: The whole country between the Alps and the Pyrenees, between the Rhine and the Ocean, has been laid waste by hordes of Quadi, Vandals, Sarmatians, Alans, Gepids, Herules, Saxons, Burgundians, Allemanni and—alas! for the commonweal!—even Pannonians.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:229
verses.text: For "Assur also is joined with them".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:230
verses.text: The once noble city of Moguntiacum has been captured and destroyed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:231
verses.text: In its church many thousands have been massacred.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:232
verses.text: The people of Vangium after standing a long siege have been extirpated.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:233
verses.text: The powerful city of Rheims, the Ambiani, the Altrebatae, the Belgians on the skirts of the world, Tournay, Spires, and Strasburg have fallen to Germany: while the provinces of Aquitaine and of the Nine Nations, of Lyons and of Narbonne are with the exception of a few cities one universal scene of desolation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:234
verses.text: And those which the sword spares without, famine ravages within.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:235
verses.text: I cannot speak without tears of Toulouse which has been kept from falling hitherto by the merits of its reverend bishop Exuperius.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:236
verses.text: Even the Spains are on the brink of ruin and tremble daily as they recall the invasion of the Cymry; and, while others suffer misfortunes once in actual fact, they suffer them continually in anticipation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:238
verses.text: I say nothing of other places that I may not seem to despair of God's mercy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:239
verses.text: All that is ours now from the Pontic Sea to the Julian Alps in days gone by once ceased to be ours.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:240
verses.text: For thirty years the barbarians burst the barrier of the Danube and fought in the heart of the Roman Empire.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:241
verses.text: Long use dried our tears.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:242
verses.text: For all but a few old people had been born either in captivity or during a blockade, and consequently they did not miss a liberty which they had never known.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:243
verses.text: Yet who will hereafter credit the fact or what histories will seriously discuss it, that Rome has to fight within her own borders not for glory but for bare life; and that she does not even fight but buys the right to exist by giving gold and sacrificing all her substance? This humiliation has been brought upon her not by the fault of her Emperors who are both most religious men, but by the crime of a half-barbarian traitor who with our money has armed our foes against us.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:244
verses.text: Of old the Roman Empire was branded with eternal shame because after ravaging the country and routing the Romans at the Allia, Brennus with his Gauls entered Rome itself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:245
verses.text: Nor could this ancient stain be wiped out until Gaul, the birth-place of the Gauls, and Gaulish Greece, wherein they had settled after triumphing over East and West, were subjugated to her sway.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:246
verses.text: Even Hannibal who swept like a devastating storm from Spain into Italy, although he came within sight of the city, did not dare to lay siege to it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:247
verses.text: Even Pyrrhus was so completely bound by the spell of the Roman name that destroying everything that came in his way, he yet withdrew from its vicinity and, victor though he was, did not presume to gaze upon what he had learned to be a city of kings.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:248
verses.text: Yet in return for such insults—not to say such haughty pride—as theirs which ended thus happily for Rome, one banished from all the world found death at last by poison in Bithynia; while the other returning to his native land was slain in his own dominions.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:249
verses.text: The countries of both became tributary to the Roman people.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:250
verses.text: But now, even if complete success attends our arms, we can wrest nothing from our vanquished foes but what we have already lost to them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:251
verses.text: The poet Lucan describing the power of the city in a glowing passage says:  If Rome be weak, where shall we look for strength?  we may vary his words and say:  If Rome be lost, where shall we look for help?  or quote the language of Virgil:  Had I a hundred tongues and throat of bronze  The woes of captives I could not relate  Or ev'n recount the names of all the slain.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:252
verses.text: Even what I have said is fraught with danger both to me who say it and to all who hear it; for we are no longer free even to lament our fate, and are unwilling, nay, I may even say, afraid to weep for our sufferings.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:253
verses.text: Dearest daughter in Christ, answer me this question: will you marry amid such scenes as these? Tell me, what kind of husband will you take? One that will run or one that will fight? In either case you know what the result will be.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:254
verses.text: Instead of the Fescennine song, the hoarse blare of the terrible trumpet will deafen your ears and your very brideswomen may be turned into mourners.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:255
verses.text: In what pleasures can you hope to revel now that you have lost the proceeds of all your possessions, now that you see your small retinue under close blockade and a prey to the inroads of pestilence and famine? But far be it from me to think so meanly of you or to harbour any suspicions of one who has dedicated her soul to the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:256
verses.text: Though nominally addressed to you my words are really meant for others such as are idle, inquisitive and given to gossip.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:257
verses.text: These wander from house to house and from one married lady to another, their god is their belly and their glory is in their shame, of the scriptures they know nothing except the texts which favour second marriages, but they love to quote the example of others to justify their own self-indulgence, and flatter themselves that they are no worse than their fellow-sinners.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:258
verses.text: When you have confounded the shameless proposals of such women by explaining the true drift of the apostle's meaning; then to show you by what mode of life you can best preserve your widowhood, you may read with advantage what I have written.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:259
verses.text: I mean my treatise on the preservation of virginity addressed to Eustochium and my two letters to Furia and Salvina.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:260
verses.text: Of these two latter you may like to know that the first is daughter-in-law to Probus some time consul, and the second daughter to Gildo formerly governour of Africa.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 125:261
verses.text: This tract on monogamy I shall call by your name.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:1
verses.text: Letter CXXIV.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:2
verses.text: To Avitus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:3
verses.text: Avitus to whom this letter is addressed is probably the same person who induced Jerome to write to Salvina (see Letter LXXIX.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:4
verses.text: , §I, ante).

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:5
verses.text: The occasion of writing is as follows.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:6
verses.text: Ten years previously (that is to say in a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:7
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:8
verses.text: 399 or 400) Pammachius had asked Jerome to supply him with a correct version of Origen's First Principles to enable him to detect the variations introduced by Rufinus into his rendering.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:9
verses.text: This Jerome willingly did (see Letters LXXXIII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:10
verses.text: and LXXXIV.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:11
verses.text: ) but when the work in its integrity was perused by Pammachius he thought it so erroneous in doctrine that he determined not to circulate it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:12
verses.text: However, "a certain brother" induced him to lend the ms.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:13
verses.text: to him for a short time; and then, when he had got it into his hands, had a hasty and incorrect transcript made, which he forthwith published much to the chagrin of Pammachius.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:14
verses.text: Falling into the hands of Avitus a copy of this much perplexed him and he seems to have appealed to Jerome for an explanation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:15
verses.text: This the latter now gives forwarding at the same time an authentic edition of his version of the First Principles.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:16
verses.text: The date of the letter is a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:17
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:20
verses.text: About ten years ago that saintly man Pammachius sent me a copy of a certain person's rendering, or rather misrendering, of Origen's First Principles; with a request that in a Latin version I should give the true sense of the Greek and should set down the writer's words for good or for evil without bias in either direction.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:21
verses.text: When I did as he wished and sent him the book, he was shocked to read it and locked it up in his desk lest being circulated it might wound the souls of many.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:22
verses.text: However, a certain brother, who had "a zeal for God but not according to knowledge," asked for a loan of the manuscript that he might read it; and, as he promised to return it without delay, Pammachius, thinking no harm could happen in so short a time, unsuspectingly consented.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:23
verses.text: Hereupon he who had borrowed the book to read, with the aid of scribes copied the whole of it and gave it back much sooner than he had promised.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:24
verses.text: Then with the same rashness or—to use a less severe term—thoughtlessness he made bad worse by confiding to others what he had thus stolen.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:25
verses.text: Moreover, since a bulky treatise on an abstruse subject is difficult to reproduce with accuracy, especially if it has to be taken down surreptitiously and in a hurry, order and sense were sacrificed in several passages.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:26
verses.text: Whence it comes, my dear Avitus, that you ask me to send you a copy of my version as made for Pammachius and not for the public, a garbled edition of which has been published by the aforesaid brother.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:28
verses.text: Take then what you have asked for; but know that there are countless things in the book to be abhorred, and that, as the Lord says, you will have to walk among scorpions and serpents.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:29
verses.text: It begins by saying that Christ was made God's son not born; that God the Father, as He is by nature invisible, is invisible even to the Son; that the Son, who is the likeness of the invisible Father, compared with the Father is not the truth but compared with us who cannot receive the truth of the almighty Father seems a figure of the truth so that we perceive the majesty and magnitude of the greater in the less, the Father's glory limited in the Son; that God the Father is a light incomprehensible and that Christ compared with him is but a minute brightness, although by reason of our incapacity to us he appears a great one.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:30
verses.text: The Father and the Son are compared to two statues, a larger one and a small; the first filling the world and being somehow invisible through its size, the second cognisable by the eyes of men.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:31
verses.text: God the Father omnipotent the writer terms good and of perfect goodness; but of the Son he says: "He is not good but an emanation and likeness of goodness; not good absolutely but only with a qualification, as 'the good shepherd' and the like".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:32
verses.text: The Holy Spirit he places after the Father and the Son as third in dignity and honour.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:33
verses.text: And while he declares that he does not know whether the Holy Spirit is created or uncreated, he has later on given his own opinion that except God the Father alone there is nothing uncreated.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:34
verses.text: "The Son," he states, "is inferior to the Father, inasmuch as He is second and the Father first; and the Holy Spirit which dwells in all the saints is inferior to the Son.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:35
verses.text: In the same way the power of the Father is greater than that of the Son and of the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:36
verses.text: Likewise the power of the Son is greater than that of the Holy Spirit, and as a consequence the Holy Spirit in its turn has greater virtue than other things called holy".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:38
verses.text: Then, when he comes to deal with rational creatures and to describe their lapse into earthly bodies as due to their own negligence, he goes on to say: "Surely it argues great negligence and sloth for a soul so far to empty itself as to fall into sin and allow itself to be tied to the material body of an unreasoning brute;" and in a subsequent passage: "These reasonings induce me to suppose that it is by their own free act that some are numbered with God's saints and servants, and that it was through their own fault that others fell from holiness into such negligence that they were changed into forces of an opposite kind".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:39
verses.text: He maintains that after every end a fresh beginning springs forth and an end from each beginning, and that wholesale variation is possible; so that one who is now a human being may in another world become a demon, while one who by reason of his negligence is now a demon may hereafter be placed in a more material body and thus become a human being.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:40
verses.text: So far does he carry this transforming process that on his theory an archangel may become the devil and the devil in turn be changed back into an archangel.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:41
verses.text: "Such as have wavered or faltered but have not altogether fallen shall be made subject, for rule and government and guidance, to better things—to principalities and powers, to thrones and dominations"; and of these perhaps another human race will be formed, when in the words of Isaiah there shall be "new heavens and a new earth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:42
verses.text: ' But such as have not deserved to return through humanity to their former estate shall become the devil and his angels, demons of the worst sort; and according to what they have done shall have special duties assigned to them in particular worlds".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:43
verses.text: Moreover, the very demons and rulers of darkness in any world or worlds, if they are willing to turn to better things, may become human beings and so come back to their first beginning.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:44
verses.text: That is to say, after they have borne the discipline of punishment and torture for a longer or a shorter time in human bodies, they may again reach the angelic pinnacles from which they have fallen.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:45
verses.text: Hence it may be shewn that we men may change into any other reasonable beings, and that not once only or on emergency but time after time; we and angels shall become demons if we neglect our duty; and demons, if they will take to themselves virtues, may attain to the rank of angels.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:47
verses.text: Bodily substances too are to pass away utterly or else at the end of all things will become highly rarified like the sky and aether and other subtle bodies.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:48
verses.text: It is clear that these principles must affect the writer's view of the resurrection.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:49
verses.text: The sun also and the moon and the rest of the constellations are alive.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:50
verses.text: Nay more; as we men by reason of our sins are enveloped in bodies material and sluggish; so the lights of heaven have for like reasons received bodies more or less luminous, and demons have been for more serious faults clothed with starry frames.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:51
verses.text: This, he argues, is the view of the apostle who writes:—"the creation has been subjected to vanity and shall be delivered for the revealing of the sons of God".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:52
verses.text: That it may not be supposed that I am imputing to him ideas of my own I shall give his actual words.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:53
verses.text: "At the end and consummation of the world," he writes, "when souls and beings endowed with reason shall be released from prison by the Lord, they will move slowly or fly quickly according as they have previously been slothful or energetic.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:54
verses.text: And as all of them have free will and are free to choose virtue or vice, those who choose the latter will be much worse off than they now are.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:55
verses.text: But those who choose the former will improve their condition.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:56
verses.text: Their movements and decisions in this direction or in that will determine their various futures; whether, that is, angels are to become men or demons, and whether demons are to become men or angels".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:57
verses.text: Then after adducing various arguments in support of his thesis and maintaining that while not incapable of virtue the devil has yet not chosen to be virtuous, he has finally reasoned with much diffuseness that an angel, a human soul, and a demon—all according to him of one nature but of different wills—may in punishment for great negligence or folly be transformed into brutes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:58
verses.text: Moreover, to avoid the agony of punishment and the burning flame the more sensitive may choose to become low organisms, to dwell in water, to assume the shape of this or that animal; so that we have reason to fear a metamorphosis not only into four-footed things but even into fishes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:59
verses.text: Then, lest he should be held guilty of maintaining with Pythagoras the transmigration of souls, he winds up the wicked reasoning with which he has wounded his reader by saying: "I must not be taken to make dogmas of these things; they are only thrown out as conjectures to shew that they are not altogether overlooked".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:61
verses.text: In his second book he maintains a plurality of worlds; not, however, as Epicurus taught, many like ones existing at once, but a new one beginning each time that the old comes to an end.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:62
verses.text: There was a world before this world of ours, and after it there will be first one and then another and so on in regular succession.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:63
verses.text: He is in doubt whether one world shall be so completely similar to another as to leave no room for any difference between them, or whether one world shall never wholly be indistinguishable from another.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:64
verses.text: And again a little farther on he writes: "if, as the course of the discussion makes necessary, all things can live without body, all bodily existence shall be swallowed up and that which once has been made out of nothing shall again be reduced to nothing.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:65
verses.text: And yet a time will come when its use will be once more necessary".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:66
verses.text: And in the same context: "but if, as reason and the authority of scripture shew, this corruptible shall put on incorruption and this mortal shall put on immortality, death shall be swallowed up in victory and corruption in incorruption.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:67
verses.text: And it may be that all bodily existence shall be removed, for it is only in this that death can operate".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:68
verses.text: And a little farther on: "if these things are not contrary to the faith, it may be that we shall some day live in a disembodied state.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:69
verses.text: Moreover, if only he is fully subject to Christ who is disembodied, and if all must be made subject to Him, we too shall lose our bodies when we become fully subject to Him".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:70
verses.text: And in the same passage: "if all are to be made subject to God, all shall lay aside their bodies; and then all bodily existence shall be brought to nought.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:71
