verses.text: But if through the fall of reasonable beings it is a second time required it will reappear.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:72
verses.text: For God has left souls to strive and struggle, to teach them that full and complete victory is to be attained not by their own efforts but by His grace.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:73
verses.text: And so to my mind worlds vary with the sins which cause them, and those are exploded theories which maintain that all worlds are alike".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:74
verses.text: And again: "three conjectures occur to me with regard to the end; it is for the reader to determine which is nearest to the truth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:75
verses.text: For either we shall be bodiless when being made subject to Christ we shall be made subject to God and He shall be all in all; or as things made subject to Christ shall be with Christ Himself made subject to God and brought under one law, so all substance shall be refined into its most perfect form and rarified into aether which is a pure and uncompounded essence; or else the sphere which I have called motionless and all that it contains will be dissolved into nothing, and the sphere in which the antizone itself is contained shall be called 'good ground,' and that other sphere which in its revolution surrounds the earth and goes by the name of heaven shall be reserved for the abode of the saints".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:77
verses.text: In speaking thus does he not most clearly follow the error of the heathen and foist upon the simple faith of Christians the ravings of philosophy? In the same book he writes: "it remains that God is invisible.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:78
verses.text: But if He is by nature invisible, He must be so even to the Saviour".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:79
verses.text: And lower down: "no soul which has descended into a human body has borne upon it so true an impress of its previous character as Christ's soul of which He says: 'no man taketh it from me, but I lay it down of myself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:80
verses.text: '" And in another place: "we must carefully consider whether souls, when they have won salvation and have attained to the blessed life, may not cease to be souls.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:81
verses.text: For as the Lord and Saviour came to seek and to save that which was lost that it might cease to be lost; so the lost soul which the Lord came to save, when saved, will cease to be a soul.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:82
verses.text: We must ask ourselves whether, as the lost was not lost once and again will not be, the soul likewise may have been and again may be not a soul".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:83
verses.text: And after a good many remarks upon the soul he brings in the following, "νοῦς or" intelligence by falling becomes a soul; and by acquiring virtue this will become intelligence again.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:84
verses.text: This at least is a fair inference from the case of Esau who for his old sins is condemned to lead a lower life.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:85
verses.text: And concerning the heavenly bodies we must make a similar acknowledgment.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:86
verses.text: The soul of the sun—or whatever else you like to call it—does not date its existence from the creation of the world; it already existed before it entered its shining and glowing body.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:87
verses.text: So also with the moon and stars.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:88
verses.text: From antecedent causes they have been made subject to vanity not willingly but for future reward, and are forced to do not their own will but the creator's who has assigned to them their several spheres".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:90
verses.text: Hellfire, moreover, and the torments with which holy scripture threatens sinners he explains not as external punishments but as the pangs of guilty consciences when by God's power the memory of our transgressions is set before our eyes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:91
verses.text: "The whole crop of our sins grows up afresh from seeds which remain in the soul, and all our dishonourable and undutiful acts are again pictured before our gaze.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:92
verses.text: Thus it is the fire of conscience and the stings of remorse which torture the mind as it looks back on former self-indulgence".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:93
verses.text: And again: "but perhaps this coarse and earthly body ought to be described as mist and darkness; for at the end of this world and when it becomes necessary to pass into another, the like darkness will lead to the like physical birth".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:94
verses.text: In speaking thus he clearly pleads for the transmigration of souls as taught by Pythagoras and Plato.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:95
verses.text: And at the end of the second book in dealing with our perfection he has said: "when we shall have made such progress as not only to cease to be flesh or body but perhaps also to cease to be souls our perfect intelligence and perception, undimmed with any mist of passion, will discern reasonable and intelligible substances face to face.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:97
verses.text: In the third book the following faulty statements are contained.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:98
verses.text: "If we once admit that, when one vessel is made to honour and another to dishonour, this is due to antecedent causes; why may we not revert to the mystery of the soul and allow that it is loved in one and hated in another because of its past actions, before in Jacob it becomes a supplanter and before in Esau it is supplanted?" And again: "the fact that souls are made some to honour and some to dishonour is to be explained by their previous history".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:99
verses.text: And in the same place: "on this hypothesis of mine a vessel made to honour which fails to fulfil its object will in another world become a vessel made to dishonour; and contrariwise a vessel which has from a previous fault been condemned to dishonour will, if it accepts correction in this present life, become in the new creation a vessel 'sanctified and meet for the Master's use and prepared unto every good work.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:100
verses.text: '" And he immediately goes on to say: "I believe that men who begin with small faults may become so hardened in wickedness that, if they do not repent and turn to better things, they must become inhuman energies; and contrariwise that hostile and demonic beings may in course of time so far heal their wounds and check the current of their former sins that they may attain to the abode of the perfect.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:101
verses.text: As I have often said, in those countless and unceasing worlds in which the soul lives and has its being some grow worse and worse until they reach the lowest depths of degradation; while others in those lowest depths grow better and better until they reach the perfection of virtue".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:102
verses.text: Thus he tries to shew that men, or rather their souls, may become demons; and that demons in turn may be restored to the rank of angels.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:103
verses.text: In the same book he writes: "this too must be considered; why the human soul is diversely acted upon now by influences of one kind and now by influences of another".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:104
verses.text: And he surmises that this is due to conduct which has preceded birth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:105
verses.text: It is for this, he argues, that John leaps in his mother's womb when at Mary's salutation Elizabeth declares herself unworthy of her notice.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:106
verses.text: And he immediately subjoins: "on the other hand infants that are hardly weaned are possessed with evil spirits and become diviners and soothsayers; indeed, some are indwelt from their earliest years with the spirit of a python.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:107
verses.text: Now as they have done nothing to bring upon themselves these visitations, one who holds that nothing happens without God's permission, and that all things are governed by His justice, cannot suppose that God's providence has abandoned them without good reason".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:109
verses.text: Again, of the world he writes thus: "The belief commends itself to me that there was a world before this world and that after it there will be another.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:110
verses.text: Do you wish to know that after the decay of this world there will be a new one? Hear the words of Isaiah: 'the new heavens and the new earth which I will make shall remain before me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:111
verses.text: ' Do you wish to know that before the making of this world there have previously been others? Listen to the Preacher who says: 'the thing which hath been, it is that which shall be; and that which is done is that which shall be done: and there is no new thing under the sun.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:112
verses.text: Is there anything whereof it may be said, See, this is new? it hath been already of old time, which was before us.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:113
verses.text: ' A passage which proves not only that other worlds have been but that other worlds shall be; not, however, simultaneously and side by side but one after another".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:114
verses.text: And he immediately adds: "I hold that heaven is the abode of the deity, the true place of rest; and that it was there that reasonable creatures enjoyed their ancient bliss, before coming down to a lower plane and exchanging the invisible for the visible, they fell to the earth and came to need material bodies.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:115
verses.text: Now that they have fallen, God the creator has made for them bodies suitable to their surroundings; and has fashioned this visible world, and has sent into it ministers to ensure the salvation and correction of the fallen.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:116
verses.text: Of these ministers some have held assigned positions and have been subject to the world's necessary laws; while others have intelligently performed duties laid upon them in times and seasons determined by God's plan.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:117
verses.text: To the former class belong the sun, moon, and stars called by the apostle 'the creation;' and these have had allotted to them the heights of heaven.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:118
verses.text: Now the creation is subjected to vanity because it is encased in material bodies and visible to the eye.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:119
verses.text: And yet it is 'made subject to vanity not willingly but by reason of him who hath subjected the same in hope.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:120
verses.text: ' Others again of the second class, at particular places and times known to their Maker only, we believe to be His angels sent to steer the world".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:121
verses.text: A little farther on he says: "the affairs of the world are so ordered by Providence that while some angels fall from heaven others freely glide down to earth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:122
verses.text: The former are hurled down against their will; the latter descend from choice alone.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:123
verses.text: The former are forced to continue in a distasteful service for a fixed period; the latter spontaneously embrace the task of lending a hand to those who fall".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:124
verses.text: Again he writes: "whence it follows that these different movements result in the creation of different worlds; and that this world of ours will be succeeded by one quite unlike it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:125
verses.text: Now, as regards this falling and rising, this rewarding of virtue and punishment of vice, whether they take place in the past, present, or future, God, the creator, can alone apportion desert and make all things converge to one end.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:126
verses.text: For He only knows why He allows some to follow their own inclination and to descend from the higher planes to the lowest; and why He visits others and giving them His hand draws them back to their former state and places them once more in heaven".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:128
verses.text: In discussing the end of the world he has made use of the following language.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:129
verses.text: "Since, as I have often said, a new beginning springs from the end, it may be asked whether bodies will then continue to exist, or whether, when they have been annihilated, we shall live without bodies and be incorporeal as we know God to be.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:130
verses.text: Now there can be no doubt but that, if bodies or, as the apostle calls them, visible things, belong only to our sensible world, the life of the disembodied will be incorporeal".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:131
verses.text: And a little farther on: "when the apostle writes, 'the creation shall be delivered from the bondage of corruption into the liberty of the glory of the children of God,' I explain his words thus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:132
verses.text: Reasonable and incorporeal beings are the highest of God's creatures, for not being clothed with bodies they are not the slaves of corruption.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:133
verses.text: Since where there are bodies, there corruption is sure to be found.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:134
verses.text: But hereafter 'the creation shall be delivered from the bondage of corruption,' and then men shall receive the glory of the children of God and God shall be all in all".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:135
verses.text: And in the same passage he writes: "that the final state will be an incorporeal one is rendered credible by the words of our Saviour's prayer: 'as thou, Father, art in me and I in thee, that they also may be one in us.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:136
verses.text: ' For we ought to realize what God is and what the Saviour will finally be, and how the likeness to the Father and the Son here promised to the Saints consists in this that as They are one in Themselves so we shall be one in Them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:137
verses.text: For if in the end the life of the Saints is to be assimilated to the life of God, we must either admit that the Lord of the universe is clothed with a body and that he is enveloped in matter as we are in flesh; or, if it is unbecoming to suppose this, especially in persons who have but small clues from which to infer God's majesty and to guess at the glory of His innate and transcendent nature, we are reduced to the following dilemma.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:138
verses.text: Either we shall always have bodies and in that case must despair of ever being like God; or, if the blessedness of the life of God is really promised to us, the conditions of His life must be the conditions of ours".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:140
verses.text: These passages prove what his view is regarding the resurrection.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:141
verses.text: For he evidently maintains that all bodies will perish and that we shall be incorporeal as according to him we were before we received our present bodies.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:142
verses.text: Again when he comes to argue for a variety of worlds and to maintain that angels will become demons, demons either angels or men, and men in their turn demons; in a word that everything will be turned into something else, he thus sums up his own opinion: "no doubt, after an interval matter will exist afresh and bodies will be formed and a different world will be created to meet the varying wills of reasonable beings who, having forfeited the perfect bliss which continues to the end, have gradually fallen into so great wickedness as to change their nature and refuse to keep their first estate of unalloyed blessedness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:143
verses.text: Many reasonable beings, it is right to say, keep it until a second, a third, and a fourth world, and give God no ground for changing their condition.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:144
verses.text: Others deteriorate so little that they seem to have lost hardly anything, and others again have to be hurled headlong into the abyss.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:145
verses.text: God who orders all things alone knows how to use each class according to its deserts in a suitable sphere; for He only understands opportunities and motives and the course in which the world must be steered.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:146
verses.text: Thus one who has borne away the palm for wickedness and has sunk into the lowest degradation will in the world which is hereafter to be fashioned be made a devil, a kind of first fruits of the Lord's handiwork, to be a laughing stock to the angels who have lost their first virtue".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:147
verses.text: What is this but to argue that the sinful men of this world may become a devil and demons in another; and contrariwise that those who are now demons may hereafter become either men or angels? And after a lengthy discussion in which he maintains that all corporeal creatures must exchange their material for subtle and spiritual bodies and that all substance must become one pure and inconceivably bright body, of which the human mind can at present form no conception, he winds up thus:—"'God shall be all in all;' that is to say, all bodily existence shall be made as perfect as possible; it shall be brought into the divine essence, than which there is none better".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:149
verses.text: In the fourth and last book of his work the following passages deserve the church's condemnation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:150
verses.text: "It may be that as, when men die in this world by the separation of soul and body, they are allotted different positions in hell according to the difference in their works; so when angels die, out of the system of the heavenly Jerusalem, they come down to this world as a hell and are placed on earth according to their deserts".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:151
verses.text: And again: "as we have compared the souls which pass from this world to hell with those which as they come from heaven to us are in a manner dead; so we must carefully inquire whether this is true of all souls without exception.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:152
verses.text: For in that case souls born on earth when they desire better things rise out of hell and assume human bodies or when they desire worse things come down to us from better worlds; and in the firmament above us likewise there are souls on their way from our world to higher ones, and others who, while they have fallen from heaven, have not sinned so grievously as to be thrust down to earth".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:153
verses.text: He thus tries to prove that the firmament, that is the sky, is hell compared with heaven; and that this earth is hell compared with the firmament; and again that our world is heaven to hell.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:154
verses.text: Or in other words what is hell to some is heaven to others.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:155
verses.text: And not content with saying this he goes on: "at the end of all things when we shall return to the heavenly Jerusalem the hostile powers shall declare war against the people of God to breathe and exercise their valour and strengthen their resolve.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:156
verses.text: For this they cannot have until they have faced and foiled their foes; of whom we read in the book of Numbers that they are overcome by reason, discipline, and tactical skill".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:158
verses.text: After saying that according to the apocalypse of John "the everlasting gospel" which shall be revealed in heaven as much surpasses our gospel as Christ's preaching does the sacraments of the ancient law, he has asserted what it is sacrilegious even to think; that Christ will once more suffer in the sky for the salvation of demons.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:159
verses.text: And although he has not expressly said it, it is yet implied in his words that as for men God became man to set men free, so for the salvation of demons when He comes to deliver them He will become a demon.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:160
verses.text: To shew that this is no gloss of mine, I must give his own words: "As Christ," he writes, "has fulfilled the shadow of the law by the shadow of the gospel, and as all law is a pattern and shadow of things done in heaven, we must inquire whether we are justified in supposing that even the heavenly law and the rites of the celestial worship are still incomplete and need the true gospel which in the apocalypse of John is called everlasting to distinguish it from ours which is only temporal, set forth in a world that shall pass away.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:161
verses.text: Now if we extend our inquiry to the passion of our Lord and Saviour, it may indeed be overbold to suppose that He will suffer in heaven; yet if there is spiritual wickedness in heavenly places and if we confess without a blush that the Lord has once been crucified to destroy those things which He has destroyed by His passion; why need we fear to imagine a like occurrence in the upper world in the fulness of time, so that the nations of all realms shall be saved by a passion of Christ?"  14.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:162
verses.text: Here is another blasphemy which he has spoken of the Son.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:163
verses.text: "Assuming that the Son knows the Father, it would seem that by this knowledge He can comprehend Him as much as a craftsman can comprehend the rules of his art.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:164
verses.text: And, doubtless, if the Father is in the Son, He is also comprehended by Him in whom He is.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:165
verses.text: But if we mean by comprehension not merely that the knower takes a thing in by perception and insight but that he contains it within himself by virtue of a special faculty; in this sense we cannot say that the Son comprehends the Father.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:166
verses.text: For the Father comprehends all things, and of these the Son is one; therefore, He comprehends the Son".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:167
verses.text: And to shew us reasons why, while the Father comprehends the Son, the Son cannot comprehend the Father, he adds: "the curious reader may inquire whether the Father knows Himself in the same way that the Son knows Him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:168
verses.text: But if he recalls the words: 'the Father who sent me is greater than I,' he will allow that they must be universally true and will admit that, in knowledge as in everything else, the Father is greater than the Son, and knows Himself more perfectly and immediately than the Son can do".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:170
verses.text: The following passage is a convincing proof that he holds the transmigration of souls and annihilation of bodies.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:171
verses.text: "If it can be shewn that an incorporeal and reasonable being has life in itself independently of the body and that it is worse off in the body than out of it; then beyond a doubt bodies are only of secondary importance and arise from time to time to meet the varying conditions of reasonable creatures.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:172
verses.text: Those who require bodies are clothed with them, and contrariwise, when fallen souls have lifted themselves up to better things, their bodies are once more annihilated.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:173
verses.text: They are thus ever vanishing and ever reappearing".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:174
verses.text: And to prevent us from minimizing the impiety of his previous utterances he ends his work by maintaining that all reasonable beings, that is, the Father, the Son, and the Holy Ghost, angels, powers, dominations, and virtues, and even man by right of his soul's dignity, are of one and the same essence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:175
verses.text: "God," he writes, "and His only-begotten Son and the Holy Spirit are conscious of an intellectual and reasonable nature.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:176
verses.text: But so also are the angels, the powers, and the virtues, as well as the inward man who is created in the image and after the likeness of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:177
verses.text: From which I conclude that God and they are in some sort of one essence".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:178
verses.text: He adds "in some sort" to escape the charge of blasphemy; and while in another place he will not allow the Son and the Holy Spirit to be of one substance with the Father lest by so doing he should appear to make the divine essence divisible, he here bestows the nature of God almighty upon angels and men.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:180
verses.text: This being the nature of Origen's book, is it anything short of madness to change a few blasphemous passages regarding the Son and the Holy Spirit and then to publish the rest unchanged with an unprincipled eulogy when the parts unaltered as well as the parts altered flow from the same fountain head of gross impiety? This is not the time to confute all the statements made in detail; and indeed those who have written against Arius, Eunomius, Manichaeus, and various other heretics must be supposed to have answered these blasphemies as well.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 126:181
verses.text: If anyone, therefore, wishes to read the work let him walk with his feet shod towards the land of promise; let him guard against the jaws of the serpent and the crooked jaws of the scorpion; let him read this treatise first and before he enters upon the path let him know the dangers which he will have to avoid.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:1
verses.text: Letter CXXV.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:2
verses.text: To Rusticus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:3
verses.text: Rusticus, a young monk of Toulouse, (to be carefully distinguished from the recipient of Letter CXXII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:4
verses.text: ) is advised by Jerome not to become an anchorite but to continue in a community.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:5
verses.text: Rules are suggested for the monastic life and a vivid picture is drawn of the difference between a good monk and a bad.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:6
verses.text: Incidentally Jerome indulges his spleen against his dead opponent Rufinus (§18).

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:7
verses.text: The date of the letter is 411 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:8
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:10
verses.text: No man is happier than the Christian, for to him is promised the kingdom of heaven.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:11
verses.text: No man struggles harder than he, for he goes daily in danger of his life.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:12
verses.text: No man is stronger, for he overcomes the Devil.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:13
verses.text: No man is weaker, for he is overcome by the flesh.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:14
verses.text: Both pairs of statements can be proved by many examples.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:15
verses.text: For instance, the robber believes upon the cross and immediately hears the assuring words: "verily I say unto thee, To-day shalt thou be with me in paradise:" while Judas falls from the pinnacle of the apostolate into the abyss of perdition.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:16
verses.text: Neither the close intercourse of the banquet nor the dipping of the sop nor the Lord's gracious kiss can save him from betraying as man Him whom he had known as the Son of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:17
verses.text: Could any one have been viler than the woman of Samaria? Yet not only did she herself believe, and after her six husbands find one Lord, not only did she recognize that Messiah by the well, whom the Jews failed to recognize in the temple; she brought salvation to many and, while the apostles were away buying food, refreshed the Saviour's hunger and relieved His weariness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:18
verses.text: Was ever man wiser than Solomon? Yet love for women made even him foolish.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:19
verses.text: Salt is good, and every offering must be sprinkled with it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:20
verses.text: Wherefore also the apostle has given commandment: "let your speech be alway with grace, seasoned with salt".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:21
verses.text: But "if the salt have lost his savour," it is cast out.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:22
verses.text: And so utterly does it lose its value that it is not even fit for the dunghill, whence believers fetch manure to enrich the barren soil of their souls.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:23
verses.text: I begin thus, Rusticus my son, to teach you the greatness of your enterprise and the loftiness of your ideal; and to shew you that only by trampling under foot youthful lusts can you hope to climb the heights of true maturity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:24
verses.text: For the path along which you walk is a slippery one and the glory of success is less than the shame of failure.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:26
verses.text: I need not now conduct the stream of my discourse through the meadows of virtue, nor exert myself to shew to you the beauty of its several flowers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:27
verses.text: I need not dilate on the purity of the lily, the modest blush of the rose, the royal purple of the violet, or the promise of glowing gems which their various colours hold out.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:28
verses.text: For through the mercy of God you have already put your hand to the plough; you have already gone up upon the housetop like the apostle Peter.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:29
verses.text: Who when he became hungry among the Jews had his hunger satisfied by the faith of Cornelius, and stilled the craving caused by their unbelief through the conversion of the centurion and other Gentiles.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:30
verses.text: By the vessel let down from heaven to earth, the four corners of which typified the four gospels, he was taught that all men can be saved.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:31
verses.text: Once more, this fair white sheet which in his vision was taken up again was a symbol of the church which carries believers from earth to heaven, an assurance that the Lord's promise should be fulfilled: "blessed are the pure in heart, for they shall see God".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:32
verses.text: All this means that I take you by the hand and do my best to impress certain facts upon your mind; that, like a skilled sailor who has been through many shipwrecks, I am anxious to caution an inexperienced passenger of the risks before him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:33
verses.text: For on one side is the Charybdis of covetousness, "the root of all evil;" and on the other lurks the Scylla of detraction girt with the railing hounds of which the apostle says: "if ye bite and devour one another, take heed that ye be not consumed one of another".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:34
verses.text: Sometimes, you must know, the quicksands of vice suck us down as we sail at ease through the calm water; and the desert of this world is not untenanted by venomous reptiles.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:36
verses.text: Those who navigate the Red Sea—where we must pray that the true Pharaoh may be drowned with all his host—have to encounter many difficulties and dangers before they reach the city of Auxuma.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:37
verses.text: Nomad savages and ferocious wild beasts haunt the shores on either side.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:38
verses.text: Thus travellers must be always armed and on the alert, and they must carry with them a whole year's provisions.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:39
verses.text: Moreover, so full are the waters of hidden reefs and impassable shoals that a look-out has constantly to be kept from the masthead to direct the helmsman how to shape his course.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:40
verses.text: They may count themselves fortunate if after six months they make the port of the above-mentioned city.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:41
verses.text: At this point the ocean begins, to cross which a whole year hardly suffices.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:42
verses.text: Then India is reached and the river Ganges—called in holy scripture Pison—"which compasseth the whole land of Havilah" and is said to carry down with it—from its source in paradise—various dyes and pigments.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:43
verses.text: Here are found rubies and emeralds, glowing pearls and gems of the first water, such as high born ladies passionately desire.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:44
verses.text: There are also mountains of gold which however men cannot approach by reason of the griffins, dragons, and huge monsters which haunt them; for such are the guardians which avarice needs for its treasures.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:46
verses.text: What, you ask, is the drift of all this? Surely it is clear enough.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:47
verses.text: For if the merchants of the world undergo such hardships to win a doubtful and passing gain, and if after seeking it through many dangers they only keep it at risk of their lives; what should Christ's merchant do who "selleth all that he hath" that he may acquire the "one pearl of great price;" who with his whole substance buys a field that he may find therein a treasure which neither thief can dig up nor robber carry away?  5.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:48
verses.text: I know that I must offend large numbers who will be angry with my criticisms as aimed at their own deficiencies.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:49
verses.text: Yet such anger does but shew an uneasy conscience and they will pass a far severer sentence on themselves than on me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:50
verses.text: For I shall not mention names; or copy the licence of the old comedy which criticized individuals.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:51
verses.text: Wise men and wise women will try to hide or rather to correct whatever they perceive to be amiss in them; they will be more angry with themselves than with me, and will not be disposed to heap curses upon the head of their monitor.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:52
verses.text: For he, although he is liable to the same charges, is certainly superior in this that he is discontented with his own faults.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:54
verses.text: I am told that your mother is a religious woman, a widow of many years' standing; and that when you were a child she reared and taught you herself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:55
verses.text: Afterwards when you had spent some time in the flourishing schools of Gaul she sent you to Rome, sparing no expense and consoling herself for your absence by the thought of the future that lay before you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:56
verses.text: She hoped to see the exuberance and glitter of your Gallic eloquence toned down by Roman sobriety, for she saw that you required the rein more than the spur.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:57
verses.text: So we are told of the greatest orators of Greece that they seasoned the bombast of Asia with the salt of Athens and pruned their vines when they grew too fast.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:58
verses.text: For they wished to fill the wine-press of eloquence not with the tendrils of mere words but with the rich grape-juice of good sense.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:59
verses.text: Your mother has done the same thing for you; you should, therefore, look up to her as a parent, love her as a tender nurse, and venerate her as a saint.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:60
verses.text: You must not imitate those who leave their own relations and pay court to strange women.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:61
verses.text: Their infamy is apparent to all, for what they aim at under the pretence of pure affection is simply illicit intercourse.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:62
verses.text: I know some women of riper years, indeed a good many, who, finding pleasure in their young freedmen, make them their spiritual children and thus, pretending to be mothers to them, gradually overcome their own sense of shame and allow themselves in the licence of marriage.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:63
verses.text: Other women desert their maiden sisters and unite themselves to strange widows.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:64
verses.text: There are some who hate their parents and have no affection for their kin.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:65
verses.text: Their state of mind is indicated by a restlessness which disdains excuses; they rend the veil of chastity and put it aside like a cobweb.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:66
verses.text: Such are the ways of women; not, indeed, that men are any better.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:67
verses.text: For there are persons to be seen who (for all their girded loins, sombre garb, and long beards) are inseparable from women, live under one roof with them, dine in their company, have young girls to wait upon them, and, save that they do not claim to be called husbands, are as good as married.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:68
verses.text: Still it is no fault of Christianity that a hypocrite falls into sin; rather, it is the confusion of the Gentiles that the churches condemn what is condemned by all good men.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:70
verses.text: But if for your part you desire to be a monk and not merely to seem one, be more careful of your soul than of your property; for in adopting a religious profession you have renounced this once for all.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:71
verses.text: Let your garments be squalid to shew that your mind is white; and your tunic coarse to prove that you despise the world.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:72
verses.text: But give not way to pride lest your dress and language be found at variance.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:73
verses.text: Baths stimulate the senses and must, therefore, be avoided; for to quench natural heat is the aim of chilling fasts.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:74
verses.text: Yet even these must be moderate, for, if they are carried to excess, they weaken the stomach and by making more food necessary to it promote indigestion, that fruitful parent of unclean desires.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:75
verses.text: A frugal and temperate diet is good for both body and soul.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:76
verses.text: See your mother as often as you please but not with other women, for their faces may dwell in your thoughts and so  A secret wound may fester in your breast.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:77
verses.text: The maidservants who attend upon her you must regard as so many snares laid to entrap you; for the lower their condition is the more easy is it for you to effect their ruin.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:78
verses.text: John the Baptist had a religious mother and his father was a priest.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:79
verses.text: Yet neither his mother's affection nor his father's wealth could induce him to live in his parents' house at the risk of his chastity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:80
verses.text: He lived in the desert, and seeking Christ with his eyes refused to look at anything else.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:81
verses.text: His rough garb, his girdle made of skins, his diet of locusts and wild honey were all alike designed to encourage virtue and continence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:82
verses.text: The sons of the prophets, who were the monks of the Old Testament, built for themselves huts by the waters of Jordan and forsaking the crowded cities lived in these on pottage and wild herbs.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:83
verses.text: As long as you are at home make your cell your paradise, gather there the varied fruits of scripture, let this be your favourite companion, and take its precepts to your heart.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:84
verses.text: If your eye offend you or your foot or your hand, cast them from you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:85
verses.text: To spare your soul spare nothing else.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:86
verses.text: The Lord says: "whosoever looketh on a woman to lust after her hath committed adultery with her already in his heart".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:87
verses.text: "Who can say," writes the wise man, "I have made my heart clean?" The stars are not pure in the Lord's sight; how much less men whose whole life is one long temptation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:88
verses.text: Woe be to us who commit fornication every time that we cherish lust.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:89
verses.text: "My sword," God says, "hath drunk its fill in heaven;" much more then upon the earth with its crop of thorns and thistles.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:90
verses.text: The chosen vessel who had Christ's name ever on his lips kept under his body and brought it into subjection.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:91
verses.text: Yet even he was hindered by carnal desire and had to do what he would not.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:92
verses.text: As one suffering violence he cries: "O wretched man that I am! who shall deliver me from the body of this death?" Is it likely then that you can pass without fall or wound, unless you keep your heart with all diligence, and say with the Saviour: "my mother and my brethren are these which hear the word of God and do it".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:93
verses.text: This may seem cruelty, but it is really affection.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:94
verses.text: What greater proof, indeed, can there be of affection than to guard for a holy mother a holy son? She too desired your eternal welfare and is content to forego seeing you for a time that she may see you for ever with Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:95
verses.text: She is like Hannah who brought forth Samuel not for her own solace but for the service of the tabernacle.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:96
verses.text: The sons of Jonadab, we are told, drank neither wine nor strong drink and dwelt in tents pitched wherever night overtook them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:97
verses.text: According to the psalter they were the first to undergo captivity; for, when the Chaldaeans began to ravage Judah they were compelled to take refuge in cities.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:99
verses.text: Others may think what they like and follow each his own bent.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:100
verses.text: But to me a town is a prison and solitude paradise.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:101
verses.text: Why do we long for the bustle of cities, we whose very name speaks of loneliness? To fit him for the leadership of the Jewish people Moses was trained for forty years in the wilderness; and it was not till after these that the shepherd of sheep became a shepherd of men.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:102
verses.text: The apostles were fishers on lake Gennesaret before they became "fishers of men".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:103
verses.text: But at the Lord's call they forsook all that they had, father, net, and ship, and bore their cross daily without so much as a rod in their hands.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:104
verses.text: I say these things that, in case you desire to enter the ranks of the clergy, you may learn what you must afterwards teach, that you may offer a reasonable sacrifice to Christ, that you may not think yourself a finished soldier while still a raw recruit, or suppose yourself a master while you are as yet only a learner.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:105
verses.text: It does not become one of my humble abilities to pass judgment upon the clergy or to speak to the discredit of those who are ministers in the churches.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:106
verses.text: They have their own rank and station and must keep it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:107
verses.text: If ever you become one of them my published letter to Nepotian will teach you the mode of life suitable to you in that vocation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:108
verses.text: At present I am dealing with the forming and training of a monk; of one too who has put the yoke of Christ upon his neck after receiving a liberal education in his younger days.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:110
verses.text: The first point to be considered is whether you ought to live by yourself or in a monastery with others.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:111
verses.text: For my part I should like you to have the society of holy men so as not to be thrown altogether on your resources.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:112
verses.text: For if you set out upon a road that is new to you without a guide, you are sure to turn aside immediately either to the right or to the left, to lay yourself open to the assaults of error, to go too far or else not far enough, to weary yourself with running too fast or to loiter by the way and to fall asleep.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:113
verses.text: In loneliness pride quickly creeps upon a man: if he has fasted for a little while and has seen no one, he fancies himself a person of some note; forgetting who he is, whence he comes, and whither he goes, he lets his thoughts riot within and outwardly indulges in rash speech.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:114
verses.text: Contrary to the apostle's wish he judges another man's servants, puts forth his hand to grasp whatever his appetite desires, sleeps as long he pleases, fears nobody, does what he likes, fancies everyone inferior to himself, spends more of his time in cities than in his cell, and, while with the brothers he affects to be retiring, rubs shoulders with the crowd in the streets.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:115
verses.text: What then, you will say? Do I condemn a solitary life? By no means: in fact I have often commended it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:116
verses.text: But I wish to see the monastic schools turn out soldiers who have no fear of the rough training of the desert, who have exhibited the spectacle of a holy life for a considerable time, who have made themselves last that they might be first, who have not been overcome by hunger or satiety, whose joy is in poverty, who teach virtue by their garb and mien, and who are too conscientious to invent—as some silly men do—monstrous stories of struggles with demons, designed to magnify their heroes in the eyes of the crowd and before all to extort money from it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:118
verses.text: Quite recently we have seen to our sorrow a fortune worthy of Croesus brought to light by a monk's death, and a city's alms, collected for the poor, left by will to his sons and successors.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:119
verses.text: After sinking to the bottom the iron has once more floated upon the surface, and men have again seen among the palm-trees the bitter waters of Marah.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:120
verses.text: In this there is, however, nothing strange, for the man had for his companion and teacher one who turned the hunger of the needy into a source of wealth for himself and kept back sums left to the miserable to his own subsequent misery.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:121
verses.text: Yet their cry came up to heaven and entering God's ears overcame His patience.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:122
verses.text: Wherefore, He sent an angel of woe to say to this new Carmelite, this second Nabal, "Thou fool, this night thy soul shall be required of thee: then whose shall those things be which thou hast provided?"  11.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:123
verses.text: If I wish you then not to live with your mother, it is for the reasons given above, and above all for the two following.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:124
verses.text: If she offers you delicacies to eat, you will grieve her by refusing them; and if you take them, you will add fuel to the flame that already burns within you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:125
verses.text: Again in a house where there are so many girls you will see in the daytime sights that will tempt you at night.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:126
verses.text: Never take your hand or your eyes off your book; learn the psalms word for word, pray without ceasing, be always on the alert, and let no vain thoughts lay hold upon you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:127
verses.text: Direct both body and mind to the Lord, overcome wrath by patience, love the knowledge of scripture, and you will no longer love the sins of the flesh.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:128
verses.text: Do not let your mind become a prey to excitement, for if this effects a lodgment in your breast it will have dominion over you and will lead you into the great transgression.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:129
verses.text: Always have some work on hand, that the devil may find you busy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:130
verses.text: If apostles who had the right to live of the Gospel laboured with their own hands that they might be chargeable to no man, and bestowed relief upon others whose carnal things they had a claim to reap as having sown unto them spiritual things; why do you not provide a supply to meet your needs? Make creels of reeds or weave baskets out of pliant osiers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:131
verses.text: Hoe your ground; mark out your garden into even plots; and when you have sown your cabbages or set your plants convey water to them in conduits; that you may see with your own eyes the lovely vision of the poet:  Art draws fresh water from the hilltop near  Till the stream plashing down among the rocks  Cools the parched meadows and allays their thirst.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:132
verses.text: Graft unfruitful stocks with buds and slips that you may shortly be rewarded for your toil by plucking sweet apples from them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:133
verses.text: Construct also hives for bees, for to these the proverbs of Solomon send you, and you may learn from the tiny creatures how to order a monastery and to discipline a kingdom.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:134
verses.text: Twist lines too for catching fish, and copy books; that your hand may earn your food and your mind may be satisfied with reading.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:135
verses.text: For "every one that is idle is a prey to vain desires".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:136
verses.text: In Egypt the monasteries make it a rule to receive none who are not willing to work; for they regard labour as necessary not only for the support of the body but also for the salvation of the soul.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:137
verses.text: Do not let your mind stray into harmful thoughts, or, like Jerusalem in her whoredoms, open its feet to every chance comer.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:139
verses.text: In my youth when the desert walled me in with its solitude I was still unable to endure the promptings of sin and the natural heat of my blood; and, although I tried by frequent fasts to break the force of both, my mind still surged with [evil] thoughts.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:140
verses.text: To subdue its turbulence I betook myself to a brother who before his conversion had been a Jew and asked him to teach me Hebrew.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:141
verses.text: Thus, after having familiarised myself with the pointedness of Quintilian, the fluency of Cicero, the seriousness of Fronto and the gentleness of Pliny, I began to learn my letters anew and to study to pronounce words both harsh and guttural.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:142
verses.text: What labour I spent upon this task, what difficulties I went through, how often I despaired, how often I gave over and then in my eagerness to learn commenced again, can be attested both by myself the subject of this misery and by those who then lived with me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:143
verses.text: But I thank the Lord that from this seed of learning sown in bitterness I now cull sweet fruits.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:145
verses.text: I will recount also another thing that I saw in Egypt.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:146
verses.text: There was in a community a young Greek the flame of whose desire neither continual fasting nor the severest labour could avail to quench.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:147
verses.text: He was in great danger of falling, when the father of the monastery saved him by the following device.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:148
verses.text: He gave orders to one of the older brothers to pursue him with objurgations and reproaches, and then after having thus wronged him to be beforehand with him in laying a complaint against him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:149
verses.text: When witnesses were called they spoke always on behalf of the aggressor.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:150
verses.text: On hearing such falsehoods he used to weep that no one gave credit to the truth; the father alone used cleverly to put in a word for him that he might not be "swallowed up with overmuch sorrow".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:151
verses.text: To make the story short, a year passed in this way and at the expiration of it the young man was asked concerning his former evil thoughts and whether they still troubled him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:152
verses.text: "Good gracious," he replied, "how can I find pleasure in fornication when I am not allowed so much as to live?" Had he been a solitary hermit, by whose aid could he have overcome the temptations that assailed him?  14.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:153
verses.text: The world's philosophers drive out an old passion by instilling a new one; they hammer out one nail by hammering in another.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:154
verses.text: It was on this principle that the seven princes of Persia acted towards king Ahasuerus, for they subdued his regret for queen Vashti by inducing him to love other maidens.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:155
verses.text: But whereas they cured one fault by another fault and one sin by another sin, we must overcome our faults by learning to love the opposite virtues.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:156
verses.text: "Depart from evil," says the psalmist, "and do good; seek peace and pursue it".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:157
verses.text: For if we do not hate evil we cannot love good.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:158
verses.text: Nay more, we must do good if we are to depart from evil.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:159
verses.text: We must seek peace if we are to avoid war.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:160
verses.text: And it is not enough merely to seek it; when we have found it and when it flees before us we must pursue it with all our energies.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:161
verses.text: For "it passeth all understanding;" it is the habitation of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:162
verses.text: As the psalmist says, "in peace also is his habitation".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:163
verses.text: The pursuing of peace is a fine metaphor and may be compared with the apostle's words, "pursuing hospitality".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:164
verses.text: It is not enough, he means, for us to invite guests with our lips; we should be as eager to detain them as though they were robbers carrying off our savings.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:166
verses.text: No art is ever learned without a master.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:167
verses.text: Even dumb animals and wild herds follow leaders of their own.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:168
verses.text: Bees have princes, and cranes fly after one of their number in the shape of a Y.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:169
verses.text: There is but one emperor and each province has but one judge.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:170
verses.text: Rome was founded by two brothers, but, as it could not have two kings at once, was inaugurated by an act of fratricide.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:171
verses.text: So too Esau and Jacob strove in Rebekah's womb.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:172
verses.text: Each church has a single bishop, a single archpresbyter, a single archdeacon; and every ecclesiastical order is subjected to its own rulers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:173
verses.text: A ship has but one pilot, a house but one master, and the largest army moves at the command of one man.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:174
verses.text: That I may not tire you by heaping up instances, my drift is simply this.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:175
verses.text: Do not rely on your own discretion, but live in a monastery.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:176
verses.text: For there, while you will be under the control of one father, you will have many companions; and these will teach you, one humility, another patience, a third silence, and a fourth meekness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:177
verses.text: You will do as others wish; you will eat what you are told to eat; you will wear what clothes are given you; you will perform the task allotted to you; you will obey one whom you do not like, you will come to bed tired out; you will go to sleep on your feet and you will be forced to rise before you have had sufficient rest.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:178
verses.text: When your turn comes, you will recite the psalms, a task which requires not a well modulated voice but genuine emotion.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:179
verses.text: The apostle says: "I will pray with the spirit and I will pray with the understanding also," and to the Ephesians, "make melody in your hearts to the Lord".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:180
verses.text: For he had read the precept of the psalmist: "Sing ye praises with understanding".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:181
verses.text: You will serve the brothers, you will wash the guests' feet; if you suffer wrong you will bear it in silence; the superior of the community you will fear as a master and love as a father.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:182
verses.text: Whatever he may order you to do you will believe to be wholesome for you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:183
verses.text: You will not pass judgment upon those who are placed over you, for your duty will be to obey them and to do what you are told, according to the words spoken by Moses: "keep silence and hearken, O Israel".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:184
verses.text: You will have so many tasks to occupy you that you will have no time for [evil] thoughts; and while you pass from one thing to another and fresh work follows work done, you will only be able to think of what you have it in charge at the moment to do.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:186
verses.text: But I myself have seen monks of quite a different stamp from this, men whose renunciation of the world has consisted in a change of clothes and a verbal profession, while their real life and their former habits have remained unchanged.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:187
verses.text: Their property has increased rather than diminished.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:188
verses.text: They still have the same servants and keep the same table.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:189
verses.text: Out of cheap glasses and common earthenware they swallow gold.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:190
verses.text: With servants about them in swarms they claim for themselves the name of hermits.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:191
verses.text: Others who though poor think themselves discerning, walk as solemnly as pageants through the streets and do nothing but snarl at every one whom they meet.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:192
verses.text: Others shrug their shoulders and croak out what is best known to themselves.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:193
verses.text: While they keep their eyes fixed upon the earth, they balance swelling words upon their tongues.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:194
verses.text: Only a crier is wanted to persuade you that it is his excellency the prefect who is coming along.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:195
verses.text: Some too there are who from the dampness of their cells and from the severity of their fasts, from their weariness of solitude and from excessive study have a singing in their ears day and night and turn melancholy mad so as to need the poultices of Hippocrates more than exhortations from me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:196
verses.text: Great numbers are unable to break free from the crafts and trades they have previously practised.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:197
verses.text: They no longer call themselves dealers but they carry on the same traffic as before; seeking for themselves not "food and raiment" as the apostle directs, but money-profits and these greater than are looked for by men of the world.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:198
verses.text: In former days the greed of sellers was kept within bounds by the action of the aediles or as the Greeks call them market-inspectors, and men could not then cheat with impunity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:199
verses.text: But now persons who profess religion are not ashamed to seek unjust profits and the good name of Christianity is more often a cloak for fraud than a victim to it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:200
verses.text: I am ashamed to say it, yet it must be said—we are at least bound to blush for our infamy—while in public we hold out our hands for alms we conceal gold beneath our rags; and to the amazement of every one after living as poor men we die rich and with our purses well-filled.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:201
verses.text: But you, since you will not be alone but one of a community, will have no temptation to act thus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:202
verses.text: Things at first compulsory will become habitual.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:203
verses.text: You will set to work unbidden and will find pleasure in your toil.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:204
verses.text: You will forget things which are behind and will reach forth to those which are before.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:205
verses.text: You will think less of the evil that others do than of the good you ought to do.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:207
verses.text: Be not led by the multitude of those who sin, neither let the host of those who perish tempt you to say secretly: "What? must all be lost who live in cities? Behold, they continue to enjoy their property, they serve churches, they frequent baths, they do not disdain cosmetics, and yet they are universally well-spoken of".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:208
verses.text: To this kind of remark I have before replied and now shortly reply again that the object of this little work is not to discuss the clergy but to lay down rules for a monk.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:209
verses.text: The clergy are holy men and their lives are always worthy of praise.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:210
verses.text: Rouse yourself then and so live in your monastery that you may deserve to be a clergyman, that you may preserve your youth from defilement, that you may go to Christ's altar as a virgin out of her chamber.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:211
verses.text: See that you are well-reported of without and that women are familiar with your reputation but not with your appearance.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:212
verses.text: When you come to mature years, if, that is, you live so long, and when you have been chosen into the ranks of the clergy either by the people of the city or by its bishop, act in a way that befits a clergyman, and choose for your models the best of your brothers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:213
verses.text: For in every rank and condition of life the bad are mingled with the good.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:215
verses.text: Do not be carried away by some mad caprice and rush into authorship.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:216
verses.text: Learn long and carefully what you propose to teach.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:217
verses.text: Do not credit all that flatterers say to you, or, I should rather say, do not lend too ready an ear to those who mean to mock you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:218
verses.text: They will fawn upon you with fulsome praise and do their best to blind your judgment; yet if you suddenly look behind you, you will find that they are making gestures of derision with their hands, either a stork's neck or the flapping ears of a donkey or a thirsty dog's protruding tongue.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:219
verses.text: Never speak evil of anyone or suppose that you make yourself better by assailing the reputations of others.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:220
verses.text: The charges we bring against them often come home to ourselves; we inveigh against faults which are as much ours as theirs; and so our eloquence ends by telling against ourselves.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:221
verses.text: It is as though dumb persons were to criticize orators.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:222
verses.text: When the grunter wished to speak he used to come forward at a snail's pace and to utter a word now and again with such long pauses between that he seemed less making a speech than gasping for breath.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:223
verses.text: Then, when he had placed his table and arranged on it his pile of books, he used to knit his brow, to draw in his nostrils, to wrinkle his forehead and to snap his fingers, signs meant to engage the attention of his pupils.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:224
verses.text: Then he would pour forth a torrent of nonsense and declaim so vehemently against every one that you would take him for a critic like Longinus or fancy him a second Cato the Censor passing judgment on Roman eloquence and excluding whom he pleased from the senate of the learned.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:225
verses.text: As he had plenty of money he made himself still more popular by giving entertainments.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:226
verses.text: Numbers of persons shared in his hospitality; and thus it was not surprising that when he went out he was surrounded always by a buzzing throng.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:227
verses.text: At home he was a monster like Nero, abroad a paragon like Cato.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:228
verses.text: Made up of different and opposing natures, as a whole he baffled description.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:229
verses.text: You would say that he was formed of jarring elements like that unnatural and unheard of monster of which the poet tells us that it was 'in front a lion, behind a dragon, in the middle the goat whose name it bears.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:231
verses.text: Men such as these you must never look at or associate with.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:232
verses.text: Nor must you turn aside your heart unto words of evil lest the psalmist say to you: "Thou sittest and speakest against thy brother; thou slanderest thine own mother's son," and lest you become as "the sons of men whose teeth are spears and arrows," and as the man whose "words were softer than oil yet were they drawn swords".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:233
verses.text: The Preacher expresses this more clearly still when he says: "Surely the serpent will bite where there is no enchantment, and the slanderer is no better".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:234
verses.text: But you will say, 'I am not given to detraction, but how can I check others who are?' If we put forward such a plea as this it can only be that we may "practise wicked works with men that work iniquity".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:235
verses.text: Yet Christ is not deceived by this device.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:236
verses.text: It is not I but an apostle who says: "Be not deceived; God is not mocked".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:237
verses.text: "Man looketh upon the outward appearance but the Lord looketh upon the heart".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:238
verses.text: And in the proverbs Solomon tells us that as "the north wind driveth away rain, so doth an angry countenance a backbiting tongue".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:239
verses.text: It sometimes happens that an arrow when it is aimed at a hard object rebounds upon the bowman, wounding the would-be wounder, and thus, the words are fulfilled, "they were turned aside like a deceitful bow," and in another passage: "whoso casteth a stone on high casteth it on his own head".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:240
verses.text: So when a slanderer sees anger in the countenance of his hearer who will not hear him but stops his ears that he may not hear of blood, he becomes silent on the moment, his face turns pale, his lips stick fast, his mouth becomes parched.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:241
verses.text: Wherefore the same wise man says: "meddle not with them that are given to detraction: for their calamity shall rise suddenly; and who knoweth the ruin of them both?" of him who speaks, that is, and of him who hears.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:242
verses.text: Truth does not love corners or seek whisperers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:243
verses.text: To Timothy it is said, "Against an elder receive not an accusation suddenly; but him that sinneth rebuke before all, that others also may fear".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:244
verses.text: When a man is advanced in years you must not be too ready to believe evil of him; his past life is itself a defence, and so also is his rank as an elder.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:245
verses.text: Still, since we are but human and sometimes in spite of the ripeness of our years fall into the sins of youth, if I do wrong and you wish to correct me, accuse me openly of my fault: do not backbite me secretly.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:246
verses.text: "Let the righteous smite me, it shall be a kindness, and let him reprove me; but let not the oil of the sinner enrich my head".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:247
verses.text: For what says the apostle? "Whom the Lord loveth, he chasteneth, and scourgeth every son whom he receiveth".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:248
verses.text: By the mouth of Isaiah the Lord speaks thus: "O my people, they who call you happy cause you to err and destroy the way of your paths".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:249
verses.text: How do you help me by telling my misdeeds to others? You may, without my knowing of it, wound some one else by the narration of my sins or rather of those which you slanderously attribute to me; and while you are eager to spread the news in all quarters, you may pretend to confide in each individual as though you had spoken to no one else.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:250
verses.text: Such a course has for its object not my correction but the indulgence of your own failing.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:251
verses.text: The Lord gives commandment that those who sin against us are to be arraigned privately or else in the presence of a witness, and that if they refuse to hear reason, the matter is to be laid before the church, and those who persist in their wickedness are to be regarded as heathen men and publicans.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:253
verses.text: I lay great emphasis on these points that I may deliver a young man who is dear to me from the itching both of the tongue and of the ears: that, since he has been born again in Christ, I may present him without spot or wrinkle as a chaste virgin, chaste in mind as well as in body; that the virginity of which he boasts may be more than nominal and that he may not be shut out by the bridegroom because being unprovided with the oil of good works his lamp has gone out.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:254
verses.text: In Proculus you have a reverend and most learned prelate, able by the sound of his voice to do more for you than I with my written sheets and sure to direct you on your path by daily homilies.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:255
verses.text: He will not suffer you to turn to the right hand or to the left or to leave the king's highway; for to this Israel pledges itself to keep in its hasty passage to the land of promise.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:256
verses.text: May God hear the voice of the church's supplication.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:257
verses.text: "Lord, ordain peace for us, for thou hast also wrought all our works for us".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:258
verses.text: May our renunciation of the world be made freely and not under compulsion! May we seek poverty gladly to win its glory and not suffer anguish because others lay it upon us! For the rest amid our present miseries with the sword making havoc around us, he is rich enough who has bread sufficient for his need, and he is abundantly powerful who is not reduced to be a slave.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:259
verses.text: Exuperius the reverend bishop of Toulouse, imitating the widow of Zarephath, feeds others though hungry himself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:260
verses.text: His face is pale with fasting, yet it is the cravings of others that torment him most.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:261
verses.text: In fact he has bestowed his whole substance to meet the needs of Christ's poor.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:262
verses.text: Yet none is richer than he, for his wicker basket contains the body of the Lord, and his plain glass-cup the precious blood.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:263
verses.text: Like his Master he has banished greed out of the temple; and without either scourge of cords or words of chiding he has overthrown the chairs of them that sell doves, that is, the gifts of the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:264
verses.text: He has upset the tables of Mammon and has scattered the money of the money-changers; zealous that the house of God may be called a house of prayer and not a den of robbers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:265
verses.text: In his steps follow closely and in those of others like him in virtue, whom the priesthood makes poor men and more than ever humble.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:266
verses.text: Or if you will be perfect, go out with Abraham from your country and from your kindred, and go whither you know not.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:267
verses.text: If you have substance, sell it and give to the poor.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:268
verses.text: If you have none, then are you free from a great burthen.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:269
verses.text: Destitute yourself, follow a destitute Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 127:270
verses.text: The task is a hard one, it is great and difficult; but the reward is also great.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 128:1
verses.text: Letter CXXVI.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 128:2
verses.text: To Marcellinus and Anapsychia.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 128:3
verses.text: Marcellinus, a Roman official of high rank, and Anapsychia his wife had written to Jerome from Africa to ask him his opinion on the vexed question of the origin of the soul.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 128:4
verses.text: Jerome in his reply briefly enumerates the several views that have been held on the subject.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 128:5
verses.text: For fuller information he refers his questioners to his treatise against Rufinus and also to their bishop Augustin who will, he says, explain the matter to them by word of mouth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 128:6
verses.text: Although it hardly appears in this letter Jerome is a decided creationist (see his Comm.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 128:7
verses.text: on Eccles.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 128:8
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 128:10
verses.text: But, though he vehemently condemns Rufinus (Ap.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 128:11
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 128:12
verses.text: 10) for professing ignorance on the subject, he assents (Letter CXXXIV.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 128:13
verses.text: ) to Augustin (Letter CXXXI.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 128:14
verses.text: ) who similarly professes ignorance but seems to lean to traducianism.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 128:15
verses.text: The date of writing is a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 128:16
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 128:18
verses.text: To his truly holy lord and lady, his children worthy of the highest respect and affection, Marcellinus and Anapsychia, Jerome sends greeting.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 128:20
verses.text: I have at last received from Africa your joint letter and no longer regret the effrontery which led me, in spite of your silence to ply you both with so many missives.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 128:21
verses.text: I hoped, indeed, by so doing to gain a reply and to learn of your welfare not indirectly from others but directly from yourselves.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 128:22
verses.text: I well remember your little problem about the nature of the soul; although I ought not to call it little, seeing that it is one of the greatest with which the church has to deal.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 128:23
verses.text: You ask whether it has fallen from heaven, as Pythagoras, all Platonists, and Origen suppose; or whether it is part of God's essence as the Stoics, Manes, and the Spanish Priscillianists hint.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 128:24
verses.text: Whether souls created long since are kept in God's storehouse as some ecclesiastical writers foolishly imagine; or whether they are formed by God and introduced into bodies day by day according to that saying in the Gospel: "my Father worketh hitherto and I work;" or whether, lastly, they are transmitted by propagation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 128:25
verses.text: This is the view of Tertullian, Apollinaris, and most western writers who hold that soul is derived from soul as body is from body and that the conditions of life are the same for men and brutes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 128:26
verses.text: I have given my opinion on the matter in my reply to the treatise which Rufinus presented to Anastasius, bishop of Rome, of holy memory.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 128:27
verses.text: He strives in this by an evasive and crafty but sufficiently foolish confession to play with the simplicity of his hearers, but only succeeds in playing with his own faith or rather want of it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 128:28
