verses.text: My book, which has been published a good while, contains an answer to the calumnies which in his various writings Rufinus has directed against me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 128:29
verses.text: Your reverend father Oceanus has, I think, a copy of it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 128:30
verses.text: But if you cannot procure it your bishop Augustine is both learned and holy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 128:31
verses.text: He will teach you by word of mouth and will give you his opinion, or rather mine, in his own words.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 128:33
verses.text: I have long wished to attack the prophecies of Ezekiel and to make good the promises which I have so often given to curious readers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 128:34
verses.text: When, however, I began to dictate I was so confounded by the havoc wrought in the West and above all by the sack of Rome that, as the common saying has it, I forgot even my own name.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 128:35
verses.text: Long did I remain silent knowing that it was a time to weep.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 128:36
verses.text: This year I began again and had written three books of commentary when a sudden incursion of those barbarians of whom your Virgil speaks as the "far-wandering men of Barce" (and to whom may be applied what holy scripture says of Ishmael: "he shall dwell over against all his brethren") overran the borders of Egypt, Palestine, Phenicia, and Syria, and like a raging torrent carried everything before them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 128:37
verses.text: It was with difficulty and only through Christ's mercy that we were able to escape from their hands.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 128:38
verses.text: But if, as the great orator says, "amid the clash of arms law ceases to be heard;" how much more truly may it be said that war puts an end to the study of holy scripture.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 128:39
verses.text: For this requires plenty of books and silence and careful copyists and above all freedom from alarm and a sense of security.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 128:40
verses.text: I have accordingly only been able to complete two books and these I have sent to my daughter, Fabiola, from whom you can if you like borrow them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 128:41
verses.text: For want of time I have not been able as yet to transcribe the rest.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 128:42
verses.text: But when you have read these you will have seen the ante-chamber and will easily form from this a notion of the whole edifice.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 128:43
verses.text: I trust in God's mercy and believe that, as he has helped me in the difficult opening chapters of the prophecy, so he will help me in the chapters towards the close.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 128:44
verses.text: These describe the wars of Gog and Magog, and set forth the mode of building, the plan, and the dimensions of the holy and mysterious temple.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 128:46
verses.text: Our reverend brother Oceanus to whom you desire an introduction is a great and good man and so learned in the law of the Lord that no words of mine are needed to make him able and willing to instruct you both and to explain to you in conformity with the rules which govern our common studies, my opinion and his on all questions arising out of the scriptures.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 128:47
verses.text: In conclusion, my truly holy lord and lady, may Christ our God by his almighty power have you in his safekeeping and cause you to live long and happily.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:1
verses.text: Letter CXXVII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:2
verses.text: To Principia.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:3
verses.text: This letter is really a memoir of Marcella (for whom see note on Letter XXIII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:4
verses.text: ) addressed to her greatest friend.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:5
verses.text: After describing her history, character, and favourite studies, Jerome goes on to recount her eminent services in the cause of orthodoxy at a time when, through the efforts of Rufinus, it seemed likely that Origenism would prevail at Rome (§§9, 10).

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:6
verses.text: He briefly relates the fall of the city and the horrors consequent upon it (§§12, 13) which appear to have been the immediate cause of Marcella's death (§14).

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:7
verses.text: The date of the letter is 412 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:8
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:10
verses.text: You have besought me often and earnestly, Principia, virgin of Christ, to dedicate a letter to the memory of that holy woman Marcella, and to set forth the goodness long enjoyed by us for others to know and to imitate.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:11
verses.text: I am so anxious myself to do justice to her merits that it grieves me that you should spur me on and fancy that your entreaties are needed when I do not yield even to you in love of her.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:12
verses.text: In putting upon record her signal virtues I shall receive far more benefit myself than I can possibly confer upon others.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:13
verses.text: If I have hitherto remained silent and have allowed two years to go over without making any sign, this has not been owing to a wish to ignore her as you wrongly suppose, but to an incredible sorrow which so overcame my mind that I judged it better to remain silent for a while than to praise her virtues in inadequate language.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:14
verses.text: Neither will I now follow the rules of rhetoric in eulogizing one so dear to both of us and to all the saints, Marcella the glory of her native Rome.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:15
verses.text: I will not set forth her illustrious family and lofty lineage, nor will I trace her pedigree through a line of consuls and praetorian prefects.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:16
verses.text: I will praise her for nothing but the virtue which is her own and which is the more noble, because forsaking both wealth and rank she has sought the true nobility of poverty and lowliness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:18
verses.text: Her father's death left her an orphan, and she had been married less than seven months when her husband was taken from her.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:19
verses.text: Then as she was young, and highborn, as well as distinguished for her beauty—always an attraction to men—and her self-control, an illustrious consular named Cerealis paid court to her with great assiduity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:20
verses.text: Being an old man he offered to make over to her his fortune so that she might consider herself less his wife than his daughter.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:21
verses.text: Her mother Albina went out of her way to secure for the young widow so exalted a protector.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:22
verses.text: But Marcella answered: "had I a wish to marry and not rather to dedicate myself to perpetual chastity, I should look for a husband and not for an inheritance;" and when her suitor argued that sometimes old men live long while young men die early, she cleverly retorted: "a young man may indeed die early, but an old man cannot live long".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:23
verses.text: This decided rejection of Cerealis convinced others that they had no hope of winning her hand.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:24
verses.text: In the gospel according to Luke we read the following passage: "there was one Anna, a prophetess, the daughter of Phanuel, of the tribe of Aser: she was of great age, and had lived with an husband seven years from her virginity; and she was a widow of about fourscore and four years, which departed not from the temple but served God with fastings and prayers night and day".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:25
verses.text: It was no marvel that she won the vision of the Saviour, whom she sought so earnestly.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:26
verses.text: Let us then compare her case with that of Marcella and we shall see that the latter has every way the advantage.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:27
verses.text: Anna lived with her husband seven years; Marcella seven months.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:28
verses.text: Anna only hoped for Christ; Marcella held Him fast.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:29
verses.text: Anna confessed him at His birth; Marcella believed in Him crucified.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:30
verses.text: Anna did not deny the Child; Marcella rejoiced in the Man as king.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:31
verses.text: I do not wish to draw distinctions between holy women on the score of their merits, as some persons have made it a custom to do as regards holy men and leaders of churches; the conclusion at which I aim is that, as both have one task, so both have one reward.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:33
verses.text: In a slander-loving community such as Rome, filled as it formerly was with people from all parts and bearing the palm for wickedness of all kinds, detraction assailed the upright and strove to defile even the pure and the clean.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:34
verses.text: In such an atmosphere it is hard to escape from the breath of calumny.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:35
verses.text: A stainless reputation is difficult nay almost impossible to attain; the prophet yearns for it but hardly hopes to win it: "Blessed," he says, "are the undefiled in the way who walk in the law of the Lord".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:36
verses.text: The undefiled in the way of this world are those whose fair fame no breath of scandal has ever sullied, and who have earned no reproach at the hands of their neighbours.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:37
verses.text: It is this which makes the Saviour say in the gospel: "agree with," or be complaisant to, "thine adversary whilst thou art in the way with him".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:38
verses.text: Who ever heard a slander of Marcella that deserved the least credit? Or who ever credited such without making himself guilty of malice and defamation? No; she put the Gentiles to confusion by shewing them the nature of that Christian widowhood which her conscience and mien alike set forth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:39
verses.text: For women of the world are wont to paint their faces with rouge and white-lead, to wear robes of shining silk, to adorn themselves with jewels, to put gold chains round their necks, to pierce their ears and hang in them the costliest pearls of the Red Sea, and to scent themselves with musk.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:40
verses.text: While they mourn for the husbands they have lost they rejoice at their own deliverance and freedom to choose fresh partners—not, as God wills, to obey these but to rule over them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:41
verses.text: With this object in view they select for their partners poor men who contented with the mere name of husbands are the more ready to put up with rivals as they know that, if they so much as murmur, they will be cast off at once.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:42
verses.text: Our widow's clothing was meant to keep out the cold and not to shew her figure.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:43
verses.text: Of gold she would not wear so much as a seal-ring, choosing to store her money in the stomachs of the poor rather than to keep it at her own disposal.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:44
verses.text: She went nowhere without her mother, and would never see without witnesses such monks and clergy as the needs of a large house required her to interview.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:45
verses.text: Her train was always composed of virgins and widows, and these women serious and staid; for, as she well knew, the levity of the maids speaks ill for the mistress and a woman's character is shewn by her choice of companions.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:47
verses.text: Her delight in the divine scriptures was incredible.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:48
verses.text: She was for ever singing, "Thy words have I hid in mine heart that I might not sin against thee," as well as the words which describe the perfect man, "his delight is in the law of the Lord; and in his law doth he meditate day and night".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:49
verses.text: This meditation in the law she understood not of a review of the written words as among the Jews the Pharisees think, but of action according to that saying of the apostle, "whether, therefore, ye eat or drink or what soever ye do, do all to the glory of God".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:50
verses.text: She remembered also the prophet's words, "through thy precepts I get understanding," and felt sure that only when she had fulfilled these would she be permitted to understand the scriptures.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:51
verses.text: In this sense we read elsewhere that "Jesus began both to do and teach".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:52
verses.text: For teaching is put to the blush when a man's conscience rebukes him; and it is in vain that his tongue preaches poverty or teaches alms-giving if he is rolling in the riches of Croesus and if, in spite of his threadbare cloak, he has silken robes at home to save from the moth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:53
verses.text: Marcella practised fasting, but in moderation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:54
verses.text: She abstained from eating flesh, and she knew rather the scent of wine than its taste; touching it only for her stomach's sake and for her often infirmities.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:55
verses.text: She seldom appeared in public and took care to avoid the houses of great ladies, that she might not be forced to look upon what she had once for all renounced.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:56
verses.text: She frequented the basilicas of apostles and martyrs that she might escape from the throng and give herself to private prayer.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:57
verses.text: So obedient was she to her mother that for her sake she did things of which she herself disapproved.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:58
verses.text: For example, when her mother, careless of her own offspring, was for transferring all her property from her children and grandchildren to her brother's family, Marcella wished the money to be given to the poor instead, and yet could not bring herself to thwart her parent.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:59
verses.text: Therefore she made over her ornaments and other effects to persons already rich, content to throw away her money rather than to sadden her mother's heart.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:61
verses.text: In those days no highborn lady at Rome had made profession of the monastic life, or had ventured—so strange and ignominious and degrading did it then seem—publicly to call herself a nun.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:62
verses.text: It was from some priests of Alexandria, and from pope Athanasius, and subsequently from Peter, who, to escape the persecution of the Arian heretics, had all fled for refuge to Rome as the safest haven in which they could find communion—it was from these that Marcella heard of the life of the blessed Antony, then still alive, and of the monasteries in the Thebaid founded by Pachomius, and of the discipline laid down for virgins and for widows.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:63
verses.text: Nor was she ashamed to profess a life which she had thus learned to be pleasing to Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:64
verses.text: Many years after her example was followed first by Sophronia and then by others, of whom it may be well said in the words of Ennius:  Would that ne'er in Pelion's woods  Had the axe these pinetrees felled.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:65
verses.text: My revered friend Paula was blessed with Marcella's friendship, and it was in Marcella's cell that Eustochium, that paragon of virgins, was gradually trained.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:66
verses.text: Thus it is easy to see of what type the mistress was who found such pupils.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:67
verses.text: The unbelieving reader may perhaps laugh at me for dwelling so long on the praises of mere women; yet if he will but remember how holy women followed our Lord and Saviour and ministered to Him of their substance, and how the three Marys stood before the cross and especially how Mary Magdalen—called the tower from the earnestness and glow of her faith—was privileged to see the rising Christ first of all before the very apostles, he will convict himself of pride sooner than me of folly.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:68
verses.text: For we judge of people's virtue not by their sex but by their character, and hold those to be worthy of the highest glory who have renounced both rank and wealth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:69
verses.text: It was for this reason that Jesus loved the evangelist John more than the other disciples.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:70
verses.text: For John was of noble birth and known to the high priest, yet was so little appalled by the plottings of the Jews that he introduced Peter into his court, and was the only one of the apostles bold enough to take his stand before the cross.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:71
verses.text: For it was he who took the Saviour's parent to his own home; it was the virgin son who received the virgin mother as a legacy from the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:73
verses.text: Marcella then lived the ascetic life for many years, and found herself old before she bethought herself that she had once been young.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:74
verses.text: She often quoted with approval Plato's saying that philosophy consists in meditating on death.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:75
verses.text: A truth which our own apostle indorses when he says: "for your salvation I die daily".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:76
verses.text: Indeed according to the old copies our Lord himself says: "whosoever doth not bear His cross daily and come after me cannot be my disciple".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:77
verses.text: Ages before, the Holy Spirit had said by the prophet: "for thy sake are we killed all the day long: we are counted as sheep for the slaughter".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:78
verses.text: Many generations afterwards the words were spoken: "remember the end and thou shalt never do amiss," as well as that precept of the eloquent satirist: "live with death in your mind; time flies; this say of mine is so much taken from it".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:79
verses.text: Well then, as I was saying, she passed her days and lived always in the thought that she must die.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:80
verses.text: Her very clothing was such as to remind her of the tomb, and she presented herself as a living sacrifice, reasonable and acceptable, unto God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:82
verses.text: When the needs of the Church at length brought me to Rome in company with the reverend pontiffs, Paulinus and Epiphanius—the first of whom ruled the church of the Syrian Antioch while the second presided over that of Salamis in Cyprus,—I in my modesty was for avoiding the eyes of highborn ladies, yet she pleaded so earnestly, "both in season and out of season" as the apostle says, that at last her perseverance overcame my reluctance.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:83
verses.text: And, as in those days my name was held in some renown as that of a student of the scriptures, she never came to see me that she did not ask me some question concerning them, nor would she at once acquiesce in my explanations but on the contrary would dispute them; not, however, for argument's sake but to learn the answers to those objections which might, as she saw, be made to my statements.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:84
verses.text: How much virtue and ability, how much holiness and purity I found in her I am afraid to say; both lest I may exceed the bounds of men's belief and lest I may increase your sorrow by reminding you of the blessings that you have lost.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:85
verses.text: This much only will I say, that whatever in me was the fruit of long study and as such made by constant meditation a part of my nature, this she tasted, this she learned and made her own.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:86
verses.text: Consequently after my departure from Rome, in case of a dispute arising as to the testimony of scripture on any subject, recourse was had to her to settle it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:87
verses.text: And so wise was she and so well did she understand what philosophers call τό πρέπον, that is, the becoming, in what she did, that when she answered questions she gave her own opinion not as her own but as from me or some one else, thus admitting that what she taught she had herself learned from others.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:88
verses.text: For she knew that the apostle had said: "I suffer not a woman to teach," and she would not seem to inflict a wrong upon the male sex many of whom (including sometimes priests) questioned her concerning obscure and doubtful points.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:90
verses.text: I am told that my place with her was immediately taken by you, that you attached yourself to her, and that, as the saying goes, you never let even a hair's-breadth come between her and you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:91
verses.text: You both lived in the same house and occupied the same room so that every one in the city knew for certain that you had found a mother in her and she a daughter in you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:92
verses.text: In the suburbs you found for yourselves a monastic seclusion, and chose the country instead of the town because of its loneliness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:93
verses.text: For a long time you lived together, and as many ladies shaped their conduct by your examples, I had the joy of seeing Rome transformed into another Jerusalem.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:94
verses.text: Monastic establishments for virgins became numerous, and of hermits there were countless numbers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:95
verses.text: In fact so many were the servants of God that monasticism which had before been a term of reproach became subsequently one of honour.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:96
verses.text: Meantime we consoled each other for our separation by words of mutual encouragement, and discharged in the spirit the debt which in the flesh we could not pay.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:97
verses.text: We always went to meet each other's letters, tried to outdo each other in attentions, and anticipated each other in courteous inquiries.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:98
verses.text: Not much was lost by a separation thus effectually bridged by a constant correspondence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:100
verses.text: While Marcella was thus serving the Lord in holy tranquillity, there arose in these provinces a tornado of heresy which threw everything into confusion; indeed so great was the fury into which it lashed itself that it spared neither itself nor anything that was good.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:101
verses.text: And as if it were too little to have disturbed everything here, it introduced a ship freighted with blasphemies into the port of Rome itself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:102
verses.text: The dish soon found itself a cover; and the muddy feet of heretics fouled the clear waters of the faith of Rome.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:103
verses.text: No wonder that in the streets and in the market places a soothsayer can strike fools on the back or, catching up his cudgel, shatter the teeth of such as carp at him; when such venomous and filthy teaching as this has found at Rome dupes whom it can lead astray.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:104
verses.text: Next came the scandalous version of Origen's book On First Principles, and that 'fortunate' disciple who would have been indeed fortunate had he never fallen in with such a master.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:105
verses.text: Next followed the confutation set forth by my supporters, which destroyed the case of the Pharisees and threw them into confusion.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:106
verses.text: It was then that the holy Marcella, who had long held back lest she should be thought to act from party motives, threw herself into the breach.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:107
verses.text: Conscious that the faith of Rome—once praised by an apostle—was now in danger, and that this new heresy was drawing to itself not only priests and monks but also many of the laity besides imposing on the bishop who fancied others as guileless as he was himself, she publicly withstood its teachers choosing to please God rather than men.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:109
verses.text: In the gospel the Saviour commends the unjust steward because, although he defrauded his master, he acted wisely for his own interests.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:110
verses.text: The heretics in this instance pursued the same course; for, seeing how great a matter a little fire had kindled, and that the flames applied by them to the foundations had by this time reached the housetops, and that the deception practised on many could no longer be hid, they asked for and obtained letters of commendation from the church, so that it might appear that till the day of their departure they had continued in full communion with it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:111
verses.text: Shortly afterwards the distinguished Anastasius succeeded to the pontificate; but he was soon taken away, for it was not fitting that the head of the world should be struck off during the episcopate of one so great.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:112
verses.text: He was removed, no doubt, that he might not seek to turn away by his prayers the sentence of God passed once for all.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:113
verses.text: For the words of the Lord to Jeremiah concerning Israel applied equally to Rome: "pray not for this people for their good.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:114
verses.text: When they fast I will not hear their cry; and when they offer burnt-offering and oblation, I will not accept them; but I will consume them by the sword and by the famine and by the pestilence".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:115
verses.text: You will say, what has this to do with the praises of Marcella? I reply, She it was who originated the condemnation of the heretics.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:116
verses.text: She it was who furnished witnesses first taught by them and then carried away by their heretical teaching.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:117
verses.text: She it was who showed how large a number they had deceived and who brought up against them the impious books On First Principles, books which were passing from hand to hand after being 'improved' by the hand of the scorpion.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:118
verses.text: She it was lastly who called on the heretics in letter after letter to appear in their own defence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:119
verses.text: They did not indeed venture to come, for they were so conscience-stricken that they let the case go against them by default rather than face their accusers and be convicted by them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:120
verses.text: This glorious victory originated with Marcella, she was the source and cause of this great blessing.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:121
verses.text: You who shared the honour with her know that I speak the truth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:122
verses.text: You know too that out of many incidents I only mention a few, not to tire out the reader by a wearisome recapitulation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:123
verses.text: Were I to say more, ill natured persons might fancy me, under pretext of commending a woman's virtues, to be giving vent to my own rancour.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:124
verses.text: I will pass now to the remainder of my story.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:126
verses.text: The whirlwind passed from the West into the East and threatened in its passage to shipwreck many a noble craft.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:127
verses.text: Then were the words of Jesus fulfilled: "when the son of man cometh, shall he find faith on the earth?" The love of many waxed cold.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:128
verses.text: Yet the few who still loved the true faith rallied to my side.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:129
verses.text: Men openly sought to take their lives and every expedient was employed against them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:130
verses.text: So hotly indeed did the persecution rage that "Barnabas also was carried away with their dissimulation;" nay more he committed murder, if not in actual violence at least in will.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:131
verses.text: Then behold God blew and the tempest passed away; so that the prediction of the prophet was fulfilled, "thou takest away their breath, they die, and return to their dust.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:132
verses.text: In that very day his thoughts perish," as also the gospel-saying, "Thou fool, this night thy soul shall be required of thee: then whose shall those things be, which thou hast provided?"  12.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:133
verses.text: Whilst these things were happening in Jebus a dreadful rumour came from the West.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:134
verses.text: Rome had been besieged and its citizens had been forced to buy their lives with gold.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:135
verses.text: Then thus despoiled they had been besieged again so as to lose not their substance only but their lives.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:136
verses.text: My voice sticks in my throat; and, as I dictate, sobs choke my utterance.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:137
verses.text: The City which had taken the whole world was itself taken; nay more famine was beforehand with the sword and but few citizens were left to be made captives.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:138
verses.text: In their frenzy the starving people had recourse to hideous food; and tore each other limb from limb that they might have flesh to eat.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:139
verses.text: Even the mother did not spare the babe at her breast.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:140
verses.text: In the night was Moab taken, in the night did her wall fall down.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:141
verses.text: "O God, the heathen have come into thine inheritance; thy holy temple have they defiled; they have made Jerusalem an orchard.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:142
verses.text: The dead bodies of thy servants have they given to be meat unto the fowls of the heaven, the flesh of thy saints unto the beasts of the earth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:143
verses.text: Their blood have they shed like water round about Jerusalem; and there was none to bury them".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:144
verses.text: Who can set forth the carnage of that night?  What tears are equal to its agony?  Of ancient date a sovran city falls;  And lifeless in its streets and houses lie  Unnumbered bodies of its citizens.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:145
verses.text: In many a ghastly shape doth death appear.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:147
verses.text: Meantime, as was natural in a scene of such confusion, one of the bloodstained victors found his way into Marcella's house.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:148
verses.text: Now be it mine to say what I have heard, to relate what holy men have seen; for there were some such present and they say that you too were with her in the hour of danger.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:149
verses.text: When the soldiers entered she is said to have received them without any look of alarm; and when they asked her for gold she pointed to her coarse dress to shew them that she had no buried treasure.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:150
verses.text: However they would not believe in her self-chosen poverty, but scourged her and beat her with cudgels.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:151
verses.text: She is said to have felt no pain but to have thrown herself at their feet and to have pleaded with tears for you, that you might not be taken from her, or owing to your youth have to endure what she as an old woman had no occasion to fear.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:152
verses.text: Christ softened their hard hearts and even among bloodstained swords natural affection asserted its rights.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:153
verses.text: The barbarians conveyed both you and her to the basilica of the apostle Paul, that you might find there either a place of safety or, if not that, at least a tomb.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:154
verses.text: Hereupon Marcella is said to have burst into great joy and to have thanked God for having kept you unharmed in answer to her prayer.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:155
verses.text: She said she was thankful too that the taking of the city had found her poor, not made her so, that she was now in want of daily bread, that Christ satisfied her needs so that she no longer felt hunger, that she was able to say in word and in deed: "naked came I out of my mother's womb, and naked shall I return thither: the Lord gave and the Lord hath taken away; blessed be the name of the Lord".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:157
verses.text: After a few days she fell asleep in the Lord; but to the last her powers remained unimpaired.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:158
verses.text: You she made the heir of her poverty, or rather the poor through you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:159
verses.text: When she closed her eyes, it was in your arms; when she breathed her last breath, your lips received it; you shed tears but she smiled conscious of having led a good life and hoping for her reward hereafter.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 129:160
verses.text: In one short night I have dictated this letter in honour of you, revered Marcella, and of you, my daughter Principia; not to shew off my own eloquence but to express my heartfelt gratitude to you both; my one desire has been to please both God and my readers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:1
verses.text: Letter CXXVIII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:2
verses.text: To Gaudentius.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:3
verses.text: Gaudentius had written from Rome to ask Jerome's advice as to the bringing up of his infant daughter; whom after the religious fashion of the day he had dedicated to a life of virginity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:4
verses.text: Jerome's reply may be compared with his advice to Laeta (Letter CVII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:5
verses.text: ) which it closely resembles.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:6
verses.text: It is noticeable also for the vivid account which it gives of the sack of Rome by Alaric in a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:7
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:9
verses.text: The date of the letter is a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:10
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:13
verses.text: It is hard to write to a little girl who cannot understand what you say, of whose mind you know nothing, and of whose inclinations it would be rash to prophesy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:14
verses.text: In the words of a famous orator "she is to be praised more for what she will be than for what she is".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:15
verses.text: For how can you speak of self-control to a child who is eager for cakes, who babbles on her mother's knee, and to whom honey is sweeter than any words? Will she hear the deep things of the apostle when all her delight is in nursery tales? Will she heed the dark sayings of the prophets when her nurse can frighten her by a frowning face? Or will she comprehend the majesty of the gospel, when its splendour dazzles the keenest intellect? Shall I urge her to obey her parents when with her chubby hand she beats her smiling mother? For such reasons as these my dear Pacatula must read some other time the letter that I send her now.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:16
verses.text: Meanwhile let her learn the alphabet, spelling, grammar, and syntax.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:17
verses.text: To induce her to repeat her lessons with her little shrill voice, hold out to her as rewards cakes and mead and sweetmeats.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:18
verses.text: She will make haste to perform her task if she hopes afterwards to get some bright bunch of flowers, some glittering bauble, some enchanting doll.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:19
verses.text: She must also learn to spin, shaping the yarn with her tender thumb; for, even if she constantly breaks the threads, a day will come when she will no longer break them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:20
verses.text: Then when she has finished her lessons she ought to have some recreation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:21
verses.text: At such times she may hang round her mother's neck, or snatch kisses from her relations.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:22
verses.text: Reward her for singing psalms that she may love what she has to learn.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:23
verses.text: Her task will then become a pleasure to her and no compulsion will be necessary.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:25
verses.text: Some mothers when they have vowed a daughter to virginity clothe her in sombre garments, wrap her up in a dark cloak, and let her have neither linen nor gold ornaments.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:26
verses.text: They wisely refuse to accustom her to what she will afterwards have to lay aside.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:27
verses.text: Others act on the opposite principle.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:28
verses.text: "What is the use," say they, "of keeping such things from her? Will she not see them with others? Women are fond of finery and many whose chastity is beyond question dress not for men but for themselves.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:29
verses.text: Give her what she asks for, but shew her that those are most praised who ask for nothing.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:30
verses.text: It is better that she should enjoy things to the full and so learn to despise them than that from not having them she should wish to have them".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:31
verses.text: "This," they continue, "was the plan which the Lord adopted with the children of Israel.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:32
verses.text: When they longed for the fleshpots of Egypt He sent them flights of quails and allowed them to gorge themselves until they were sick.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:33
verses.text: Those who have once lived worldly lives more readily forego the pleasures of sense than such as from their youth up have known nothing of desire".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:34
verses.text: For while the former—so they argue—trample on what they know, the latter are attracted by what is to them unknown.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:35
verses.text: While the former penitently shun the insidious advances which pleasure makes, the latter coquet with the allurements of sense and fancying them to be as sweet as honey find them to be deadly poison.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:36
verses.text: They quote the passage which says that "the lips of a strange woman drop as an honeycomb;" which is sweet indeed in the eater's mouth but is afterwards found more bitter than gall.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:37
verses.text: This they argue, is the reason that neither honey nor wax is offered in the sacrifices of the Lord, and that oil the product of the bitter olive is burned in His temple.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:38
verses.text: Moreover it is with bitter herbs that the passover is eaten, and "with the unleavened bread of sincerity and truth".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:39
verses.text: He that receives these shall suffer persecution in the world.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:40
verses.text: Wherefore the prophet symbolically sings: "I sat alone because I was filled with bitterness".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:42
verses.text: What then, I reply? Is youth to run riot that self-indulgence may afterwards be more resolutely rejected? Far from it, they rejoin: "let every man, wherein he is called, therein abide.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:43
verses.text: Is any called being circumcised,"—that is, as a virgin?—"let him not become uncircumcised"—that is, let him not seek the coat of marriage given to Adam on his expulsion from the paradise of virginity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:44
verses.text: "Is any called in uncircumcision,"—that is, having a wife and enveloped in the skin of matrimony? let him not seek the nakedness of virginity and of that eternal chastity which he has lost once for all.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:45
verses.text: No, let him "possess his vessel in sanctification and honour," let him drink of his own wells not out of the dissolute cisterns of the harlots which cannot hold within them the pure waters of chastity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:46
verses.text: The same Paul also in the same chapter, when discussing the subjects of virginity and marriage, calls those who are married slaves of the flesh, but those not under the yoke of wedlock freemen who serve the Lord in all freedom.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:47
verses.text: What I say I do not say as universally applicable; my treatment of the subject is only partial.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:48
verses.text: I speak of some only, not of all.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:49
verses.text: However my words are addressed to those of both sexes, and not only to "the weaker vessel".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:50
verses.text: Are you a virgin? Why then do you find pleasure in the society of a woman? Why do you commit to the high seas your frail patched boat, why do you so confidently face the great peril of a dangerous voyage? You know not what you desire, and yet you cling to her as though you had either desired her before or, to put it as leniently as possible, as though you would hereafter desire her.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:51
verses.text: Women, you will say, make better servants than men.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:52
verses.text: In that case choose a misshapen old woman, choose one whose continence is approved in the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:53
verses.text: Why should you find pleasure in a young girl, pretty, and voluptuous? You frequent the baths, walk abroad sleek and ruddy, eat flesh, abound in riches, and wear the most expensive clothes; and yet you fancy that you can sleep safely beside a death-dealing serpent.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:54
verses.text: You tell me perhaps that you do not live in the same house with her.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:55
verses.text: This is only true at night.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:56
verses.text: But you spend whole days in conversing with her.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:57
verses.text: Why do you sit alone with her? Why do you dispense with witnesses? By so doing if you do not actually sin you appear to do so, and (so important is your influence) you embolden unhappy men by your example to do what is wrong.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:58
verses.text: You too, whether virgin or widow, why do you allow a man to detain you in conversation so long? Why are you not afraid to be left alone with him? At least go out of doors to satisfy the wants of nature, and for this at any rate leave the man with whom you have given yourself more liberty than you would with your brother, and have behaved more immodestly than you would with your husband.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:59
verses.text: You have some question, you say, to ask concerning the holy scriptures.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:60
verses.text: If so, ask it publicly; let your maids and your attendants hear it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:61
verses.text: "Everything that is made manifest is light".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:62
verses.text: He who says only what he ought does not look for a corner to say it in; he is glad to have hearers for he likes to be praised.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:63
verses.text: He must be a fine teacher, on the other hand, who thinks little of men, does not care for the brothers, and labours in secret merely to instruct just one weak woman!  3a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:64
verses.text: I have wandered for a little from my immediate subject to discuss the procedure of others in such a case as yours; and while it is my object to train, nay rather to nurse, the infant Pacatula, I have in a moment drawn upon myself the hostility of many women who are by no means daughters of peace.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:65
verses.text: But I shall now return to my proper theme.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:66
verses.text: A girl should associate only with girls, she should know nothing of boys and should dread even playing with them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:67
verses.text: She should never hear an unclean word, and if amid the bustle of the household she should chance to hear one, she should not understand it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:68
verses.text: Her mother's nod should be to her as much a command as a spoken injunction.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:69
verses.text: She should love her as her parent, obey her as her mistress, and reverence her as her teacher.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:70
verses.text: She is now a child without teeth and without ideas, but, as soon as she is seven years old, a blushing girl knowing what she ought not to say and hesitating as to what she ought, she should until she is grown up commit to memory the psalter and the books of Solomon; the gospels, the apostles and the prophets should be the treasure of her heart.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:71
verses.text: She should not appear in public too freely or too frequently attend crowded churches.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:72
verses.text: All her pleasure should be in her chamber.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:73
verses.text: She must never look at young men or turn her eyes upon curled fops; and the wanton songs of sweet voiced girls which wound the soul through the ears must be kept from her.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:74
verses.text: The more freedom of access such persons possess, the harder is it to avoid them when they come; and what they have once learned themselves they will secretly teach her and will thus contaminate our secluded Danaë by the talk of the crowd.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:75
verses.text: Give her for guardian and companion a mistress and a governess, one not given to much wine or in the apostle's words idle and a tattler, but sober, grave, industrious in spinning wool and one whose words will form her childish mind to the practice of virtue.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:76
verses.text: For, as water follows a finger drawn through the sand, so one of soft and tender years is pliable for good or evil; she can be drawn in whatever direction you choose to guide her.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:77
verses.text: Moreover spruce and gay young men often seek access for themselves by paying court to nurses or dependants or even by bribing them, and when they have thus gently effected their approach they blow up the first spark of passion until it bursts into flame and little by little advance to the most shameless requests.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:78
verses.text: And it is quite impossible to check them then, for the verse is proved true in their case: "It is ill rebuking what you have once allowed to become ingrained".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:79
verses.text: I am ashamed to say it and yet I must; high born ladies who have rejected more high born suitors cohabit with men of the lowest grade and even with slaves.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:80
verses.text: Sometimes in the name of religion and under the cloak of a desire for celibacy they actually desert their husbands in favour of such paramours.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:81
verses.text: You may often see a Helen following her Paris without the smallest dread of Menelaus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:82
verses.text: Such persons we see and mourn for but we cannot punish, for the multitude of sinners procures tolerance for the sin.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:84
verses.text: The world sinks into ruin: yes! but shameful to say our sins still live and flourish.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:85
verses.text: The renowned city, the capital of the Roman Empire, is swallowed up in one tremendous fire; and there is no part of the earth where Romans are not in exile.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:86
verses.text: Churches once held sacred are now but heaps of dust and ashes; and yet we have our minds set on the desire of gain.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:87
verses.text: We live as though we are going to die tomorrow; yet we build as though we are going to live always in this world.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:88
verses.text: Our walls shine with gold, our ceilings also and the capitals of our pillars; yet Christ dies before our doors naked and hungry in the persons of His poor.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:89
verses.text: The pontiff Aaron, we read, faced the raging flames, and by putting fire in his censer checked the wrath of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:90
verses.text: The High Priest stood between the dead and the living, and the fire dared not pass his feet.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:91
verses.text: On another occasion God said to Moses, "Let me alone.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:92
verses.text: …that I may consume this people," shewing by the words "let me alone" that he can be withheld from doing what he threatens.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:93
verses.text: The prayers of His servant hindered His power.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:94
verses.text: Who, think you, is there now under heaven able to stay God's wrath, to face the flame of His judgment, and to say with the apostle, "I could wish that I myself were accursed for my brethren"? Flocks and shepherds perish together, because as it is with the people, so is it with the priest.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:95
verses.text: Of old it was not so.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:96
verses.text: Then Moses spoke in a passion of pity, "yet now if thou wilt forgive their sin—; and if not, blot me, I pray thee, out of thy book".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:97
verses.text: He is not satisfied to secure his own salvation, he desires to perish with those that perish.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:98
verses.text: And he is right, for "in the multitude of people is the king's honour".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:99
verses.text: Such are the times in which our little Pacatula is born.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:100
verses.text: Such are the swaddling clothes in which she draws her first breath; she is destined to know of tears before laughter and to feel sorrow sooner than joy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:101
verses.text: And hardly does she come upon the stage when she is called on to make her exit.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:102
verses.text: Let her then suppose that the world has always been what it is now.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:103
verses.text: Let her know nothing of the past, let her shun the present, and let her long for the future.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:104
verses.text: These thoughts of mine are but hastily mustered.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:105
verses.text: For my grief for lost friends has known no intermission and only recently have I recovered sufficient composure to write an old man's letter to a little child.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:106
verses.text: My affection for you, brother Gaudentius, has induced me to make the attempt and I have thought it better to say a few words than to say nothing at all.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 130:107
verses.text: The grief that paralyses my will will excuse my brevity; whereas, were I to say nothing, the sincerity of my friendship might well be doubted.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 131:1
verses.text: Letter CXXIX.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 131:2
verses.text: To Dardanus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 131:3
verses.text: In answer to a question put by Dardanus, prefect of Gaul, Jerome writes concerning the Promised Land which he identifies not with Canaan but with heaven.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 131:4
verses.text: He then points out that the present sufferings of the Jews are due altogether to the crime of which they have been guilty in the crucifixion of Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 131:5
verses.text: The date of the letter is 414 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 131:6
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:1
verses.text: Letter CXXX.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:2
verses.text: To Demetrias.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:3
verses.text: Jerome writes to Demetrias, a highborn lady of Rome who had recently embraced the vocation of a virgin.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:4
verses.text: After narrating her life's history first at Rome and then in Africa, he goes on to lay down rules and principles to guide her in her new life.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:5
verses.text: These which cover the whole field of ascetic practice and include the duties of study, of prayer, of fasting, of obedience, of giving up money for Christ, and of constant industry, are in substance similar to those which thirty years before Jerome had suggested to Eustochium (Letter XXII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:7
verses.text: The tone of the letter is however milder and less fanatical; the asceticism recommended is not so severe; there is less of rhapsody and more of common sense.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:8
verses.text: This letter should also be compared with the letter addressed to Demetrias by Pelagius, which is given in Vol.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:9
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:10
verses.text: of Jerome's works (Migne's Patr.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:11
verses.text: Lat.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:12
verses.text: xxx.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:13
verses.text: ed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:15
verses.text: The date is 414 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:16
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:18
verses.text: Of all the subjects that I have treated from my youth up until now, either with my own pen or that of my secretaries I have dealt with none more difficult than that which now occupies me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:19
verses.text: I am going to write to Demetrias a virgin of Christ and a lady whose birth and riches make her second to none in the Roman world.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:20
verses.text: If, therefore, I employ language adequate to describe her virtue, I shall be thought to flatter her; and if I suppress some details on the score that they might appear incredible, my reserve will not do justice to her undoubted merits.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:21
verses.text: What am I to do then? I am unequal to the task before me, yet I cannot venture to decline it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:22
verses.text: Her grandmother and her mother are both women of mark, and they have alike authority to command, faith to seek and perseverance to obtain that which they require.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:23
verses.text: It is not indeed anything very new or special that they ask of me; my wits have often been exercised upon similar themes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:24
verses.text: What they wish for is that I should raise my voice and bear witness as strongly as I can to the virtues of one who—in the words of the famous orator—is to be praised less for what she is than for what she gives promise of being.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:25
verses.text: Yet, girl though she is, she has a glowing faith beyond her years, and has started from a point at which others think it a mark of signal virtue to leave off.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:27
verses.text: Let detraction stand aloof and envy give way; let no charge of self seeking be brought against me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:28
verses.text: I write as a stranger to a stranger, at least so far as the personal appearance is concerned.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:29
verses.text: For the inner man finds itself well known by that knowledge whereby the apostle Paul knew the Colossians and many other believers whom he had never seen.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:30
verses.text: How high an esteem I entertain for this virgin, nay more what a miracle of virtue I think her, you may judge by the fact that being occupied in the explanation of Ezekiel's description of the temple—the hardest piece in the whole range of scripture—and finding myself in that part of the sacred edifice wherein is the Holy of Holies and the altar of incense, I have chosen by way of a brief rest to pass from that altar to this, that upon it I might consecrate to eternal chastity a living offering acceptable to God and free from all stain.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:31
verses.text: I am aware that the bishop has with words of prayer covered her holy head with the virgin's bridal-veil, reciting the while the solemn sentence of the apostle: "I wish to present you all as a chaste virgin to Christ".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:32
verses.text: She stood as a queen at his right hand, her clothing of wrought gold and her raiment of needlework.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:33
verses.text: Such was the coat of many colours, that is, formed of many different virtues, which Joseph wore; and similar ones were of old the ordinary dress of king's daughters.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:34
verses.text: Thereupon the bride herself rejoices and says: "the king hath brought me into his chambers," and the choir of her companions responds: "the king's daughter is all glorious within".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:35
verses.text: Thus she is a professed virgin.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:36
verses.text: Still these words of mine will not be without their use.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:37
verses.text: The speed of racehorses is quickened by the applause of spectators; prize fighters are urged to greater efforts by the cries of their backers; and when armies are drawn up for battle and swords are drawn, the general's speech does much to fire his soldiers' valour.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:38
verses.text: So also is it on the present occasion.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:39
verses.text: The grandmother and the mother have planted, but it is I that water and the Lord that giveth the increase.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:41
verses.text: It is the practice of the rhetoricians to exalt him who is the subject of their praises by referring to his forefathers and the past nobility of his race, so that a fertile root may make up for barren branches and that you may admire in the stem what you have not got in the fruit.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:42
verses.text: Thus I ought now to recall the distinguished names of the Probi and of the Olybrii, and that illustrious Anician house, the representatives of which have seldom or never been unworthy of the consulship.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:43
verses.text: Or I ought to bring forward Olybrius our virgin's father, whose untimely loss Rome has had to mourn.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:44
verses.text: I fear to say more of him, lest I should intensify the pain of your saintly mother, and lest the commemoration of his virtues should become a renewing of her grief.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:45
verses.text: He was a dutiful son, a loveable husband, a kind master, a popular citizen.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:46
verses.text: He was made consul while still a boy; but the goodness of his character made him more illustrious as a senator.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:47
verses.text: He was happy in his death for it saved him from seeing the ruin of his country; and happier still in his offspring, for the distinguished name of his great grandmother Demetrias has become yet more distinguished now that his daughter Demetrias has vowed herself to perpetual chastity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:49
verses.text: But what am I doing? Forgetful of my purpose and filled with admiration for this young man, I have spoken in terms of praise of mere worldly advantages; whereas I should rather have commended our virgin for having rejected all these, and for having determined to regard herself not as a wealthy or a high born lady, but simply as a woman like other women.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:50
verses.text: Her strength of mind almost passes belief.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:51
verses.text: Though she had silks and jewels freely at her disposal, and though she was surrounded by crowds of eunuchs and serving-women, a bustling household of flattering and attentive domestics, and though the daintiest feasts that the abundance of a large house could supply were daily set before her; she preferred to all these severe fasting, rough clothing, and frugal living.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:52
verses.text: For she had read the words of the Lord: "they that wear soft clothing are in kings' houses".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:53
verses.text: She was filled with admiration for the manner of life followed by Elijah and by John the Baptist; both of whom confined and mortified their loins with girdles of skin, while the second of them is said to have come in the spirit and power of Elijah as the forerunner of the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:54
verses.text: As such he prophesied while still in his mother's womb, and before the day of judgment won the commendation of the Judge.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:55
verses.text: She admired also the zeal of Anna the daughter of Phanuel, who continued even to extreme old age to serve the Lord in the temple with prayers and fastings.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:56
verses.text: When she thought of the four virgins who were the daughters of Philip, she longed to join their band and to be numbered with those who by their virginal purity have attained the grace of prophecy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:57
verses.text: With these and similar meditations she fed her mind, dreading nothing so much as to offend her grandmother and her mother.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:58
verses.text: Although she was encouraged by their example, she was discouraged by their expressed wish and desire; not indeed that they disapproved of her holy purpose, but that the prize was so great that they did not venture to hope for it, or to aspire to it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:59
verses.text: Thus this poor novice in Christ's service was sorely perplexed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:60
verses.text: She came to hate all her fine apparel and cried like Esther to the Lord: "Thou knowest that I abhor the sign of my high estate"—that is to say, the diadem which she wore as queen—"and that I abhor it as a menstruous rag".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:61
verses.text: Among the holy and highborn ladies who have seen and known her some have been driven by the tempest which has swept over Africa, from the shores of Gaul to a refuge in the holy places.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:62
verses.text: These tell me that secretly night after night, though no one knew of it but the virgins dedicated to God in her mother's and grandmother's retinue, Demetrias, refusing sheets of linen and beds of down, spread a rug of goat's hair upon the ground and watered her face with ceaseless tears.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:63
verses.text: Night after night she cast herself in thought at the Saviour's knees and implored him to accept her choice, to fulfil her aspiration, and to soften the hearts of her grandmother and of her mother.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:65
verses.text: Why do I still delay to relate the sequel? When her wedding day was now close at hand and when a marriage chamber was being got ready for the bride and bridegroom; secretly without any witnesses and with only the night to comfort her, she is said to have nerved herself with such considerations as these: "What ails you, Demetrias? Why are you so fearful of defending your chastity? What you need is freedom and courage.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:66
verses.text: If you are so panic-stricken in time of peace, what would you do if you were called on to undergo martyrdom? If you cannot bear so much as a frown from your own, how would you steel yourself to face the tribunals of persecutors? If men's examples leave you unmoved, at least gather courage and confidence from the blessed martyr Agnes who vanquished the temptations both of youth and of a despot and by her martyrdom hallowed the very name of chastity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:67
verses.text: Unhappy girl! you know not, you know not to whom your virginity is due.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:68
verses.text: It is not long since you have trembled in the hands of the barbarians and clung to your grandmother and your mother cowering under their cloaks for safety.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:69
verses.text: You have seen yourself a prisoner and your chastity not in your own power.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:70
verses.text: You have shuddered at the fierce looks of your enemies; you have seen with secret agony the virgins of God ravished.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:71
verses.text: Your city, once the capital of the world, is now the grave of the Roman people; and will you on the shores of Libya, yourself an exile, accept an exile for a husband? Where will you find a matron to be present at your bridal? Whom will you get to escort you home? No tongue but a harsh Punic one will sing for you the wanton Fescennine verses.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:72
verses.text: Away with all hesitations! 'Perfect love' of God 'casteth out fear.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:73
verses.text: ' Take to yourself the shield of faith, the breastplate of righteousness, the helmet of salvation, and sally forth to battle.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:74
verses.text: The preservation of your chastity involves a martyrdom of its own.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:75
verses.text: Why do you fear your grandmother? Why do you dread your mother? Perhaps they may themselves wish for you a course which they do not think you wish for yourself".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:76
verses.text: When by these and other arguments she had wrought herself to the necessary pitch of resolution, she cast from her as so many hindrances all her ornaments and worldly attire.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:77
verses.text: Her precious necklaces, costly pearls, and glowing gems she put back in their cases.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:78
verses.text: Then dressing herself in a coarse tunic and throwing over herself a still courser cloak she came in at an unlooked for moment, threw herself down suddenly at her grandmother's knees, and with tears and sobs shewed her what she really was.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:79
verses.text: That staid and holy woman was amazed when she beheld her granddaughter in so strange a dress.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:80
verses.text: Her mother was completely overcome for joy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:81
verses.text: Both women could hardly believe that true which they had longed to be true.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:82
verses.text: Their voices stuck in their throats, and, what with blushing and turning pale, with fright and with joy, they were a prey to many conflicting emotions.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:84
verses.text: I must needs give way here and not attempt to describe what defies description.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:85
verses.text: In the effort to explain the greatness of that joy past all belief, the flow of Tully's eloquence would run dry and the bolts poised and hurled by Demosthenes would become spent and fall short.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:86
verses.text: Whatever mind can conceive or speech can interpret of human gladness was seen then.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:87
verses.text: Mother and child, grandmother and granddaughter kissed each other again and again.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:88
verses.text: The two elder women wept copiously for joy, they raised the prostrate girl, they embraced her trembling form.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:89
verses.text: In her purpose they recognized their own mind, and congratulated each other that now a virgin was to make a noble house more noble still by her virginity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:90
verses.text: She had found they said, a way to benefit her family and to lessen the calamity of the ruin of Rome.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:91
verses.text: Good Jesus! What exultation there was all through the house! Many virgins sprouted out at once as shoots from a fruitful stem, and the example set by their patroness and lady was followed by a host both of clients and servants.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:92
verses.text: Virginity was warmly espoused in every house and although those who made profession of it were as regards the flesh of lower rank than Demetrias they sought one reward with her, the reward of chastity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:93
verses.text: My words are too weak.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:94
verses.text: Every church in Africa danced for joy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:95
verses.text: The news reached not only the cities, towns, and villages but even the scattered huts.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:96
verses.text: Every island between Africa and Italy was full of it, the glad tidings ran far and wide, disliked by none.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:97
verses.text: Then Italy put off her mourning and the ruined walls of Rome resumed in part their olden splendour; for they believed the full conversion of their fosterchild to be a sign of God's favour towards them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:98
verses.text: You would fancy that the Goths had been annihilated and that that concourse of deserters and slaves had fallen by a thunderbolt from the Lord on high.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:99
verses.text: There was less elation in Rome when Marcellus won his first success at Nola after thousands of Romans had fallen at the Trebia, Lake Thrasymenus, and Cannae.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:100
verses.text: There was less joy among the nobles cooped up in the capitol, on whom the future of Rome depended, when after buying their lives with gold they heard that the Gauls had at length been routed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:101
verses.text: The news penetrated to the coasts of the East, and this triumph of Christian glory was heard of in the remote cities of the interior.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:102
verses.text: What Christian virgin was not proud to have Demetrias as a companion? What mother did not call Juliana's womb blessed? Unbelievers may scoff at the doubtfulness of rewards to come.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:103
verses.text: Meantime, in becoming a virgin you have gained more than you have sacrificed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:104
verses.text: Had you become a man's bride but one province would have known of you; while as a Christian virgin you are known to the whole world.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:105
verses.text: Mothers who have but little faith in Christ are unhappily wont to dedicate to virginity only deformed and crippled daughters for whom they can find no suitable husbands.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:106
verses.text: Glass beads, as the saying goes, are thought equal to pearls.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:107
verses.text: Men who pride themselves on their religion give to their virgin daughters sums scarcely sufficient for their maintenance, and bestow the bulk of their property upon sons and daughters living in the world.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:108
verses.text: Quite recently in this city a rich presbyter left two of his daughters who were professed virgins with a mere pittance, while he provided his other children with ample means for self-indulgence and pleasure.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:109
verses.text: The same thing has been done, I am sorry to say, by many women who have adopted the ascetic life.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:110
verses.text: Would that such instances were rare, but unfortunately they are not.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:111
verses.text: Yet the more frequent they are the more blessed are those who refuse to follow an example which is set them by so many.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:113
verses.text: All Christians are loud in their praises of Christ's holy yokefellows, because they gave to Demetrias when she professed herself a virgin the money which had been set apart as a dowry for her marriage.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:114
verses.text: They would not wrong her heavenly bridegroom; in fact they wished her to come to Him with all her previous riches, that these might not be wasted on the things of the world, but might relieve the distress of God's servants.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:115
verses.text: Who would believe it? That Proba, who of all persons of high rank and birth in the Roman world bears the most illustrious name, whose holy life and universal charity have won for her esteem even among the barbarians, who has made nothing of the regular consulships enjoyed by her three sons, Probinus, Olybrius, and Probus,—that Proba, I say, now that Rome has been taken and its contents burned or carried off, is said to be selling what property she has and to be making for herself friends of the mammon of unrighteousness, that these may receive her into everlasting habitations! Well may the church's ministers, whatever their degree, and those monks who are only monks in name, blush for shame that they are buying estates, when this noble lady is selling them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:116
verses.text: Hardly had she escaped from the hands of the barbarians, hardly had she ceased weeping for the virgins whom they had torn from her arms, when she was overwhelmed by a sudden and unbearable bereavement, one too which she had had no cause to fear, the death of her loving son.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:117
verses.text: Yet as one who was to be grandmother to a Christian virgin, she bore up against this death-dealing stroke, strong in hope of the future and proving true of herself the words of the lyric:  "Should the round world in fragments burst, its fall  May strike the just, may slay, but not appal".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:118
verses.text: We read in the book of Job how, while the first messenger of evil was yet speaking, there came also another; and in the same book it is written: "is there not a temptation"—or as the Hebrew better gives it—"a warfare to man upon earth?" It is for this end that we labour, it is for this end that we risk our lives in the warfare of this world, that we may be crowned in the world to come.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:119
verses.text: That we should believe this to be true of men is nothing wonderful, for even the Lord Himself was tempted, and of Abraham the scripture bears witness that God tempted him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:120
verses.text: It is for this reason also that the apostle says: "we glory in tribulations.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:121
verses.text: …knowing that tribulation worketh patience; and patience experience; and experience hope; and hope maketh not ashamed;" and in another passage: "Who shall separate us from the love of Christ? Shall tribulation or distress or persecution or famine or nakedness or peril or sword? As it is written, For thy sake we are killed all the day long; we are accounted as sheep for the slaughter".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:122
verses.text: The prophet Isaiah comforts those in like case in these words: "ye that are weaned from the milk, ye that are drawn from the breasts, look for tribulation upon tribulation, but also for hope upon hope".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:123
verses.text: For, as the apostle puts it "the sufferings of this present time are not worthy to be compared with the glory which shall be revealed in us".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:124
verses.text: Why I have here brought together all these passages the sequel will make plain.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:125
verses.text: Proba who had seen from the sea the smoke of her native city and had committed her own safety and that of those dear to her to a fragile boat, found the shores of Africa even more cruel than those which she had left.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:126
verses.text: For one lay in wait for her of whom it would be hard to say whether he was more covetous or heartless, one who cared for nothing but wine and money, one who under pretence of serving the mildest of emperors stood forth as the most savage of all despots.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:127
verses.text: If I may be allowed to quote a fable of the poets, he was like Orcus in Tartarus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:128
verses.text: Like him too he had with him a Cerberus, not three headed but many headed, ready to seize and rend everything within his reach.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:129
verses.text: He tore betrothed daughters from their mothers' arms and sold high-born maidens in marriage to those greediest of men, the merchants of Syria.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:130
verses.text: No plea of poverty induced him to spare either ward or widow or virgin dedicated to Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:131
verses.text: Indeed he looked more at the hands than at the faces of those who appealed to him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:132
verses.text: Such was the dread Charybdis and such the hound-girt Scylla which this lady encountered in fleeing from the barbarians; monsters who neither spared the shipwrecked nor heeded the cry of those made captive.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:133
verses.text: Cruel wretch! at least imitate the enemy of the Roman Empire.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:134
verses.text: The Brennus of our day took only what he found, but you seek what you cannot find.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:135
verses.text: Virtue, indeed, is always exposed to envy, and cavillers may marvel at the secret agreement by which Proba purchased the chastity of her numerous companions.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:136
verses.text: They may allege that the count who could have taken all would not have been satisfied with a part; and that she could not have questioned his claim since in spite of her rank she was but a slave in his despotic hands.
