verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:137
verses.text: I perceive also that I am laying myself open to the attacks of enemies and that I may seem to be flattering a lady of the highest birth and distinction.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:138
verses.text: Yet these men will not be able to accuse me when they learn that hitherto I have said nothing about her.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:139
verses.text: I have never either in the lifetime of her husband or since his decease praised her for the antiquity of her family or for the extent of her wealth and power, subjects which others might perhaps have improved in mercenary speeches.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:140
verses.text: My purpose is to praise the grandmother of my virgin in a style befitting the church, and to thank her for having aided with her goodwill the desire which Demetrias has formed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:141
verses.text: For the rest my cell, my food and clothing, my advanced years, and my narrow circumstances sufficiently refute the charge of flattery.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:142
verses.text: In what remains of my letter I shall direct all my words to Demetrias herself, whose holiness ennobles her as much as her rank, and of whom it may be said that the higher she climbs the more terrible will be her fall.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:143
verses.text: For the rest  This one thing, child of God, I lay on thee;  Yea before all, and urge it many times:  Love to occupy your mind with the reading of scripture.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:144
verses.text: Do not in the good ground of your breast gather only a crop of darnel and wild oats.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:145
verses.text: Do not let an enemy sow tares among the wheat when the householder is asleep (that is when the mind which ever cleaves to God is off its guard); but say always with the bride in the song of songs: "By night I sought him whom my soul loveth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:146
verses.text: Tell me where thou feedest, where thou makest thy flock to rest at noon;" and with the psalmist: "my soul followeth hard after thee: thy right hand upholdeth me;" and with Jeremiah: "I have not found it hard.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:147
verses.text: …to follow thee," for "there is no grief in Jacob neither is there travail in Israel".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:148
verses.text: When you were in the world you loved the things of the world.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:149
verses.text: You rubbed your cheeks with rouge and used whitelead to improve your complexion.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:150
verses.text: You dressed your hair and built up a tower on your head with tresses not your own.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:151
verses.text: I shall say nothing of your costly earrings, your glistening pearls from the depths of the Red Sea, your bright green emeralds, your flashing onyxes, your liquid sapphires,—tones which turn the heads of matrons, and make them eager to possess the like.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:152
verses.text: For you have relinquished the world and besides your baptismal vow have taken a new one; you have entered into a compact with your adversary and have said: "I renounce thee, O devil, and thy world and thy pomp and thy works".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:153
verses.text: Observe, therefore, the treaty that you have made, and keep terms with your adversary while you are in the way of this world.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:154
verses.text: Otherwise he may some day deliver you to the judge and prove that you have taken what is his; and then the judge will deliver you to the officer—at once your foe and your avenger—and you will be cast into prison; into that outer darkness which surrounds us with the greater horror as it severs us from Christ the one true light.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:155
verses.text: And you shall by no means come out thence till you have paid the uttermost farthing, that is, till you have expiated your most trifling sins; for we shall give account of every idle word in the day of judgment.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:157
verses.text: In speaking thus I do not wish to utter an ill-omened prophecy against you but only to warn you as an apprehensive and prudent monitor who in your case fears even what is safe.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:158
verses.text: What says the scripture? "If the spirit of the ruler rise up against thee, leave not thy place".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:159
verses.text: We must always stand under arms and in battle array, ready to engage the foe.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:160
verses.text: When he tries to dislodge us from our position and to make us fall back, we must plant our feet firmly down, and say with the psalmist, "he hath set my feet upon a rock" and "the rocks are a refuge for the conies".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:161
verses.text: In this latter passage for 'conies' many read 'hedgehogs.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:162
verses.text: ' Now the hedgehog is a small animal, very shy, and covered over with thorny bristles.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:163
verses.text: When Jesus was crowned with thorns and bore our sins and suffered for us, it was to make the roses of virginity and the lilies of chastity grow for us out of the brambles and briers which have formed the lot of women since the day when it was said to Eve, "in sorrow thou shalt bring forth children; and thy desire shall be to thy husband and he shall rule over thee".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:164
verses.text: We are told that the bridegroom feeds among the lilies, that is, among those who have not defiled their garments, for they have remained virgins and have hearkened to the precept of the Preacher: "let thy garments be always white".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:165
verses.text: As the author and prince of virginity He says boldly of Himself: "I am the rose of Sharon and the lily of the valleys".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:166
verses.text: "The rocks" then "are a refuge for the conies" who when they are persecuted in one city flee into another and have no fear that the prophetic words "refuge failed me" will be fulfilled in their case.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:167
verses.text: "The high hills are a refuge for the wild goats," and their food are the serpents which a little child draws out of their holes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:168
verses.text: Meanwhile the leopard lies down with the kid and the lion eats straw like the ox; not of course that the ox may learn ferocity from the lion but that the lion may learn docility from the ox.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:169
verses.text: But let us turn back to the passage first quoted, "If the spirit of the ruler rise up against thee, leave not thy place," a sentence which is followed by these words: "for yielding pacifieth great offences".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:170
verses.text: The meaning is, that if the serpent finds his way into your thoughts you must "keep your heart with all diligence" and sing with David, "cleanse thou me from secret faults: keep back thy servant also from presumptuous sins," and come not to "the great transgression" which is sin in act.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:171
verses.text: Rather slay the allurements to vice while they are still only thoughts; and dash the little ones of the daughter of Babylon against the stones where the serpent can leave no trail.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:172
verses.text: Be wary and vow a vow unto the Lord: "let them not have dominion over me: then shall I be upright and I shall be innocent from the great transgression".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:173
verses.text: For elsewhere also the scripture testifies, "I will visit the iniquity of the fathers upon the children unto the third and fourth generation".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:174
verses.text: That is to say, God will not punish us at once for our thoughts and resolves but will send retribution upon their offspring, that is, upon the evil deeds and habits of sin which arise out of them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:175
verses.text: As He says by the mouth of Amos: "for three transgressions of such and such a city and for four I will not turn away the punishment thereof".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:177
verses.text: I cull these few flowers in passing from the fair field of the holy scriptures.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:178
verses.text: They will suffice to warn you that you must shut the door of your breast and fortify your brow by often making the sign of the cross.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:179
verses.text: Thus alone will the destroyer of Egypt find no place to attack you; thus alone will the first-born of your soul escape the fate of the first-born of the Egyptians; thus alone will you be able with the prophet to say: "my heart is fixed, O God, my heart is fixed; I will sing and give praise.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:180
verses.text: Awake up, my glory; awake, psaltery and harp".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:181
verses.text: For, sin stricken as she is, even Tyre is bidden to take up her harp and to do penance; like Peter she is told to wash away the stains of her former foulness with bitter tears.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:182
verses.text: Howbeit, let us know nothing of penitence, lest the thought of it lead us into sin.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:183
verses.text: It is a plank for those who have had the misfortune to be shipwrecked; but an inviolate virgin may hope to save the ship itself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:184
verses.text: For it is one thing to look for what you have cast away, and another to keep what you have never lost.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:185
verses.text: Even the apostle kept under his body and brought it into subjection, lest having preached to others he might himself become a castaway.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:186
verses.text: Heated with the violence of sensual passion he made himself the spokesman of the human race: "O wretched man that I am! who shall deliver me from the body of this death?" and again, "I know that in me, that is in my flesh, dwelleth no good thing: for to will is present with me; but how to perform that which is good, I find not.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:187
verses.text: For the good that I would, I do not: but the evil which I would not, that I do;" and once more: "they that are in the flesh cannot please God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:188
verses.text: But ye are not in the flesh, but in the spirit, if so be that the spirit of God dwell in you".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:190
verses.text: After you have paid the most careful attention to your thoughts, you must then put on the armour of fasting and sing with David: "I chastened my soul with fasting," and "I have eaten ashes like bread," and "as for me when they troubled me my clothing was sackcloth".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:191
verses.text: Eve was expelled from paradise because she had eaten of the forbidden fruit.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:192
verses.text: Elijah on the other hand after forty days of fasting was carried in a fiery chariot into heaven.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:193
verses.text: For forty days and forty nights Moses lived by the intimate converse which he had with God, thus proving in his own case the complete truth of the saying, "man doth not live by bread only but by every word that proceedeth out of the mouth of the Lord".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:194
verses.text: The Saviour of the world, who in His virtues and His mode of life has left us an example to follow, was, immediately after His baptism, taken up by the spirit that He might contend with the devil, and after crushing him and overthrowing him might deliver him to his disciples to trample under foot.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:195
verses.text: For what says the apostle? "God shall bruise Satan under your feet shortly".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:196
verses.text: And yet after the Saviour had fasted forty days, it was through food that the old enemy laid a snare for him, saying, "If thou be the Son of God, command that these stones be made bread".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:197
verses.text: Under the law, in the seventh month after the blowing of trumpets and on the tenth day of the month, a fast was proclaimed for the whole Jewish people, and that soul was cut off from among his people which on that day preferred self-indulgence to self-denial.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:198
verses.text: In Job it is written of behemoth that "his strength is in his loins, and his force is in the navel of his belly".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:199
verses.text: Our foe uses the heat of youthful passion to tempt young men and maidens and "sets on fire the wheel of our birth".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:200
verses.text: He thus fulfils the words of Hosea, "they are all adulterers, their heart is like an oven;" an oven which only God's mercy and severe fasting can extinguish.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:201
verses.text: These are "the fiery darts" with which the devil wounds men and sets them on fire, and it was these which the king of Babylon used against the three children.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:202
verses.text: But when he made his fire forty-nine cubits high he did but turn to his own ruin the seven weeks which the Lord had appointed for a time of salvation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:203
verses.text: And as then a fourth bearing a form like the son of God slackened the terrible heat and cooled the flames of the blazing fiery furnace, until, menacing as they looked, they became quite harmless, so is it now with the virgin soul.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:204
verses.text: The dew of heaven and severe fasting quench in a girl the flame of passion and enable her soul even in its earthly tenement to live the angelic life.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:205
verses.text: Therefore the chosen vessel declares that concerning virgins he has no commandment of the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:206
verses.text: For you must act against nature or rather above nature if you are to forswear your natural function, to cut off your own root, to cull no fruit but that of virginity, to abjure the marriage-bed, to shun intercourse with men, and while in the body to live as though out of it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:208
verses.text: I do not, however, lay on you as an obligation any extreme fasting or abnormal abstinence from food.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:209
verses.text: Such practices soon break down weak constitutions and cause bodily sickness before they lay the foundations of a holy life.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:210
verses.text: It is a maxim of the philosophers that virtues are means, and that all extremes are of the nature of vice; and it is in this sense that one of the seven wise men propounds the famous saw quoted in the comedy, "In nothing too much".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:211
verses.text: You must not go on fasting until your heart begins to throb and your breath to fail and you have to be supported or carried by others.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:212
verses.text: No; while curbing the desires of the flesh, you must keep sufficient strength to read scripture, to sing psalms, and to observe vigils.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:213
verses.text: For fasting is not a complete virtue in itself but only a foundation on which other virtues may be built.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:214
verses.text: The same may be said of sanctification and of that chastity without which no man shall see the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:215
verses.text: Each of these is a step on the upward way, yet none of them by itself will avail to win the virgin's crown.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:216
verses.text: The gospel teaches us this in the parable of the wise and foolish virgins; the former of whom enter into the bridechamber of the bridegroom, while the latter are shut out from it because not having the oil of good works they allow their lamps to fail.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:217
verses.text: This subject of fasting opens up a wide field in which I have often wandered myself, and many writers have devoted treatises to the subject.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:218
verses.text: I must refer you to these if you wish to learn the advantages of self-restraint and on the other hand the evils of over-feeding.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:220
verses.text: Follow the example of your Spouse: be subject to your grandmother and to your mother.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:221
verses.text: Never look upon a man, especially upon a young man, except in their company.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:222
verses.text: Never know a man whom they do not know.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:223
verses.text: It is a maxim of the world that the only sure friendship is one based on an identity of likes and dislikes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:224
verses.text: You have been taught by their example as well as instructed by the holy life of your home to aspire to virginity, to recognize the commandments of Christ, to know what is expedient for you and what course you ought to choose.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:225
verses.text: But do not regard what is your own as absolutely your own.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:226
verses.text: Remember that part of it belongs to those who have communicated their chastity to you and from whose honourable marriages and beds undefiled you have sprung up like a choice flower.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:227
verses.text: For you are destined to produce perfect fruit if only you will humble yourself under the mighty hand of God, always remembering that it is written: "God resisteth the proud and giveth grace to the humble".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:228
verses.text: Now where there is grace, this is not given in return for works but is the free gift of the giver, so that the apostles' words are fulfilled: "it is not of him that willeth nor of him that runneth, but of God that sheweth mercy".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:229
verses.text: And yet it is ours to will and not to will; and all the while the very liberty that is ours is only ours by the mercy of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:231
verses.text: Again in selecting for yourself eunuchs and maids and servingmen look rather to their characters than to their good looks; for, whatever their age or sex, and even if mutilation ensures in them a compulsory chastity, you must take account of their dispositions, for these cannot be operated on save by the fear of Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:232
verses.text: When you are present buffoonery and loose talk must find no place.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:233
verses.text: You should never hear an improper word; if you do hear one, you must not be carried away by it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:234
verses.text: Abandoned men often make use of a single light expression to try the gates of chastity.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:235
verses.text: Leave to worldlings the privileges of laughing and being laughed at.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:236
verses.text: One who is in your position ought to be serious.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:237
verses.text: Cato the Censor, in old time a leading man in your city, (the same who in his last days turned his attention to Greek literature without either blushing for himself as censor or despairing of success on account of his age) is said by Lucilius to have laughed only once in his life, and the same remark is made about Marcus Crassus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:238
verses.text: These men may have affected this austere mien to gain for themselves reputation and notoriety.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:239
verses.text: For so long as we dwell in the tabernacle of this body and are enveloped with this fragile flesh, we can but restrain and regulate our affections and passions; we cannot wholly extirpate them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:240
verses.text: Knowing this the psalmist says: "be ye angry and sin not;" which the apostle explains thus: "let not the sun go down upon your wrath".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:241
verses.text: For, if to be angry is human, to put an end to one's anger is Christian.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:243
verses.text: I think it unnecessary to warn you against covetousness since it is the way of your family both to have riches and to despise them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:244
verses.text: The apostle too tells us that covetousness is idolatry, and to one who asked the Lord the question: "Good Master what good thing shall I do that I may have eternal life?" He thus replied: "If thou wilt be perfect, go and sell that thou hast and give to the poor, and thou shalt have treasure in heaven; and come and follow me".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:245
verses.text: Such is the climax of complete and apostolic virtue—to sell all that one has and to distribute to the poor, and thus freed from all earthly encumbrance to fly up to the heavenly realms with Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:246
verses.text: To us, or I should rather say to you, a careful stewardship is entrusted, although in such matters full freedom of choice is left to every individual, whether old or young.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:247
verses.text: Christ's words are "if thou wilt be perfect".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:248
verses.text: I do not compel you, He seems to say, I do not command you, but I set the palm before you, I shew you the prize; it is for you to choose whether you will enter the arena and win the crown.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:249
verses.text: Let us consider how wisely Wisdom has spoken.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:250
verses.text: "Sell that thou hast".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:251
verses.text: To whom is the command given? Why, to him to whom it was said, "if thou wilt be perfect".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:252
verses.text: Sell not a part of thy goods but "all that thou hast".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:253
verses.text: And when you have sold them, what then? "Give to the poor".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:254
verses.text: Not to the rich, not to your kinsfolk, not to minister to self indulgence; but to relieve need.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:255
verses.text: It does not matter whether a man is a priest or a relation or a connexion, you must think of nothing but his poverty.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:256
verses.text: Let your praises come from the stomachs of the hungry and not from the rich banquets of the overfed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:257
verses.text: We read in the Acts of the Apostles how, while the blood of the Lord was still warm and believers were in the fervour of their first faith, they all sold their possessions and laid the price of them at the apostles' feet (to shew that money ought to be trampled underfoot) and "distribution was made unto every man according as he had need".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:258
verses.text: But Ananias and Sapphira proved timid stewards, and what is more, deceitful ones; therefore they brought on themselves condemnation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:259
verses.text: For having made a vow they offered their money to God as if it were their own and not His to whom they had vowed it; and keeping back for their own use a part of that which belonged to another, through fear of famine which true faith never fears, they drew down on themselves suddenly the avenging stroke, which was meant not in cruelty towards them but as a warning to others.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:260
verses.text: In fact the apostle Peter by no means called down death upon them as Porphyry foolishly says.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:261
verses.text: He merely announced God's judgment by the spirit of prophecy, that the doom of two persons might be a lesson to many.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:262
verses.text: From the time of your dedication to perpetual virginity your property is yours no longer; or rather is now first truly yours because it has come to be Christ's.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:263
verses.text: Yet while your grandmother and mother are living you must deal with it according to their wishes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:264
verses.text: If, however, they die and rest in the sleep of the saints (and I know that they desire that you should survive them); when your years are riper, and your will steadier, and your resolution stronger, you will do with your money what seems best to you, or rather what the Lord shall command, knowing as you will that hereafter you will have nothing save that which you have here spent on good works.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:265
verses.text: Others may build churches, may adorn their walls when built with marbles, may procure massive columns, may deck the unconscious capitals with gold and precious ornaments, may cover church doors with silver and adorn the altars with gold and gems.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:266
verses.text: I do not blame those who do these things; I do not repudiate them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:267
verses.text: Everyone must follow his own judgment.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:268
verses.text: And it is better to spend one's money thus than to hoard it up and brood over it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:269
verses.text: However your duty is of a different kind.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:270
verses.text: It is yours to clothe Christ in the poor, to visit Him in the sick, to feed Him in the hungry, to shelter Him in the homeless, particularly such as are of the household of faith, to support communities of virgins, to take care of God's servants, of those who are poor in spirit, who serve the same Lord as you day and night, who while they are on earth live the angelic life and speak only of the praises of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:271
verses.text: Having food and raiment they rejoice and count themselves rich.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:272
verses.text: They seek for nothing more, contented if only they can persevere in their design.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:273
verses.text: For as soon as they begin to seek more they are shewn to be undeserving even of those things that are needful.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:274
verses.text: The preceding counsels have been addressed to a virgin who is wealthy and a lady of rank.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:276
verses.text: But what I am now going to say will be addressed to the virgin alone.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:277
verses.text: I shall take into consideration, that is, not your circumstances but yourself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:278
verses.text: In addition to the rule of psalmody and prayer which you must always observe at the third, sixth, and ninth hours, at evening, at midnight, and at dawn, you should determine how much time you will bind yourself to give to the learning and reading of scripture, aiming to please and instruct the soul rather than to lay a burthen upon it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:279
verses.text: When you have spent your allotted time in these studies, often kneeling down to pray as care for your soul will impel you to do; have some wool always at hand, shape the threads into yarn with your thumb, attach them to the shuttle, and then throw this to weave a web, or roll up the yarn which others have spun or lay it out for the weavers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:280
verses.text: Examine their work when it is done, find fault with its defects, and arrange how much they are to do.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:281
verses.text: If you busy yourself with these numerous occupations, you will never find your days long; however late the summer sun may be in setting, a day will always seem too short on which something remains undone.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:282
verses.text: By observing such rules as these you will save yourself and others, you will set a good example as a mistress, and you will place to your credit the chastity of many.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:283
verses.text: For the scripture says: "the soul of every idler is filled with desires".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:284
verses.text: Nor may you excuse yourself from toil on the plea that God's bounty has left you in want of nothing.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:285
verses.text: No; you must labour with the rest, that being always busy you may think only of the service of the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:286
verses.text: I shall speak quite plainly.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:287
verses.text: Even supposing that you give all your property to the poor, Christ will value nothing more highly than what you have wrought with your own hands.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:288
verses.text: You may work for yourself or to set an example to your virgins; or you may make presents to your mother and grandmother to draw from them larger sums for the relief of the poor.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:290
verses.text: I have all but passed over the most important point of all.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:291
verses.text: While you were still quite small, bishop Anastasius of holy and blessed memory ruled the Roman church.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:292
verses.text: In his days a terrible storm of heresy came from the East and strove first to corrupt and then to undermine that simple faith which an apostle has praised.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:293
verses.text: However the bishop, rich in poverty and as careful of his flock as an apostle, at once smote the noxious thing on the head, and stayed the hydra's hissing.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:294
verses.text: Now I have reason to fear—in fact a report has reached me to this effect—that the poisonous germs of this heresy still live and sprout in the minds of some to this day.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:295
verses.text: I think, therefore, that I ought to warn you, in all kindness and affection, to hold fast the faith of the saintly Innocent, the spiritual son of Anastasius and his successor in the apostolic see; and not to receive any foreign doctrine, however wise and discerning you may take yourself to be.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:296
verses.text: Men of this type whisper in corners and pretend to inquire into the justice of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:297
verses.text: Why, they ask, was a particular soul born in a particular province? What is the reason that some are born of Christian parents, others among wild beasts and savage tribes who have no knowledge of God? Wherever they can strike the simple with their scorpion-sting and form an ulcer fitted to their purpose, there they diffuse their venom.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:298
verses.text: "Is it for nothing, think you,"—thus they argue—"that a little child scarcely able to recognize its mother by a laugh or a look of joy, which has done nothing either good or evil, is seized by a devil or overwhelmed with jaundice or doomed to bear afflictions which godless men escape, while God's servants have to bear them?" Now if God's judgments, they say, are "true and righteous altogether," and if "there is no unrighteousness in Him," we are compelled by reason to believe that our souls have pre-existed in heaven, that they are condemned to and, if I may so say, buried in human bodies because of some ancient sins, and that we are punished in this valley of weeping for old misdeeds.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:299
verses.text: This according to them is the prophet's reason for saying: "Before I was afflicted I went astray," and again, "Bring my soul out of prison".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:300
verses.text: They explain in the same way the question of the disciples in the gospel: "Who did sin, this man or his parents, that he was born blind?" and other similar passages.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:301
verses.text: This godless and wicked teaching was formerly ripe in Egypt and the East; and now it lurks secretly like a viper in its hole among many persons in those parts, defiling the purity of the faith and gradually creeping on like an inherited disease till it assails a large number.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:302
verses.text: But I am sure that if you hear it you will not accept it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:303
verses.text: For you have preceptresses under God whose faith is a rule of sound doctrine.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:304
verses.text: You will understand what I mean, for God will give you understanding in all things.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:305
verses.text: You must not ask me on the spot to give you a refutation of this dreadful heresy and of others worse still; for were I to do so I should "criticize where I ought to forbid," and my present object is not to refute heretics but to instruct a virgin.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:306
verses.text: However, I have defeated their wiles and counterworked their efforts to undermine the truth in a treatise which by God's help I have written; and if you desire to have this, I shall send it to you promptly and with pleasure.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:307
verses.text: I say, if you desire to have it, for as the proverb says, wares proffered unasked are little esteemed, and a plentiful supply brings down prices, which are always highest where scarcity prevails.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:309
verses.text: Men often discuss the comparative merits of life in solitude and life in a community; and the preference is usually given to the first over the second.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:310
verses.text: Still even for men there is always the risk that, being withdrawn from the society of their fellows, they may become exposed to unclean and godless imaginations, and in the fulness of their arrogance and disdain may look down upon everyone but themselves, and may arm their tongues to detract from the clergy or from those who like themselves are bound by the vows of a solitary life.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:311
verses.text: Of such it is well said by the psalmist, "as for the children of men their teeth are spears and arrows and their tongue a sharp sword".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:312
verses.text: Now if all this is true of men, how much more does it apply to women whose fickle and vacillating minds, if left to their own devices, soon degenerate.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:313
verses.text: I am myself acquainted with anchorites of both sexes who by excessive fasting have so impaired their faculties that they do not know what to do or where to turn, when to speak or when to be silent.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:314
verses.text: Most frequently those who have been so affected have lived in solitary cells, cold and damp.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:315
verses.text: Moreover if persons untrained in secular learning read the works of able church writers, they only acquire from them a wordy fluency and not, as they might do, a fuller knowledge of the scriptures.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:316
verses.text: The old saying is found true of them, although they have not the wit to speak, they cannot remain silent.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:317
verses.text: They teach to others the scriptures that they do not understand themselves; and if they are fortunate enough to convince them, they take upon themselves airs as men of learning.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:318
verses.text: In fact, they set up as instructors of the ignorant before they have gone to school themselves.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:319
verses.text: It is a good thing therefore to defer to one's betters, to obey those set over one, to learn not only from the scriptures but from the example of others how one ought to order one's life, and not to follow that worst of teachers, one's own self-confidence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:320
verses.text: Of women who are thus presumptuous the apostle says that they "are carried about with every wind of doctrine, ever learning and never able to come to the knowledge of the truth".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:322
verses.text: Avoid the company of married women who are devoted to their husbands and to the world, that your mind may not become unsettled by hearing what a husband says to his wife, or a wife to her husband.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:323
verses.text: Such conversations are filled with deadly venom.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:324
verses.text: To express his condemnation of them the apostle has taken a verse of a profane writer and has pressed it into the service of the church.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:325
verses.text: It may be literally rendered at the expense of the metre: "evil communications corrupt good manners".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:326
verses.text: No; you should choose for your companions staid and serious women, particularly widows and virgins, persons of approved conversation, of few words, and of a holy modesty.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:327
verses.text: Shun gay and thoughtless girls, who deck their heads and wear their hair in fringes, who use cosmetics to improve their skins and affect tight sleeves, dresses without a crease, and dainty buskins; and by pretending to be virgins more easily sell themselves into destruction.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:328
verses.text: Moreover, the character and tastes of a mistress are often inferred from the behaviour of her attendants.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:329
verses.text: Regard as fair and lovable and a fitting companion one who is unconscious of her good looks and careless of her appearance; who does not expose her breast out of doors or throw back her cloak to reveal her neck; who veils all of her face except her eyes, and only uses these to find her way.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:331
verses.text: I hesitate about what I am going to say but, as often happens, whether I like it or not, it must be said; not that I have reason to fear anything of the kind in your case, for probably you know nothing of such things and have never even heard of them, but that in advising you I may warn others.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:332
verses.text: A virgin should avoid as so many plagues and banes of chastity all ringletted youths who curl their hair and scent themselves with musk; to whom may well be applied the words of Petronius Arbiter, "too much perfume makes an ill perfume".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:333
verses.text: I need not speak of those who by their pertinacious visits to virgins bring discredit both on themselves and on these; for, even if nothing wrong is done by them, no wrong can be imagined greater than to find oneself exposed to the calumnies and attacks of the heathen.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:334
verses.text: I do not here speak of all, but only of those whom the church itself rebukes, whom sometimes it expels, and against whom the censure of bishops and presbyters is not seldom directed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:335
verses.text: For, as it is, it is almost more dangerous for giddy girls to shew themselves in the abodes of religion than even to walk abroad.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:336
verses.text: Virgins who live in communities and of whom large numbers are assembled together, should never go out by themselves or unaccompanied by their mother.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:337
verses.text: A hawk often singles out one of a flight of doves, pounces on it and tears it open till it is gorged with its flesh and blood.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:338
verses.text: Sick sheep stray from the flock and fall into the jaws of wolves.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:339
verses.text: I know some saintly virgins who on holy days keep at home to avoid the crowds and refuse to go out when they must either take a strong escort, or altogether avoid all public places.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:340
verses.text: It is about thirty years since I published a treatise on the preservation of virginity,in which I felt constrained to oppose certain vices and to lay bare the wiles of the devil for the instruction of the virgin to whom it was addressed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:341
verses.text: My language then gave offence to a great many, for everyone applied what I said to himself and instead of welcoming my admonitions turned away from me as an accuser of his deeds.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:342
verses.text: Was it any use, do you ask, thus to arm a host of remonstrants and to show by my complaints the wounds which my conscience received? Yes, I answer, for, while they have passed away, my book still remains.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:343
verses.text: I have also written short exhortations to several virgins and widows, and in these smaller works I have gathered together all that there is to be said on the subject.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:344
verses.text: So that I am reduced to the alternative of repeating exhortations which seem superfluous or of omitting them to the serious injury of this treatise.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:345
verses.text: The blessed Cyprian has left a noble work on virginity; and many other writers, both Greek and Latin, have done the same.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:346
verses.text: Indeed the virginal life has been praised both with tongue and pen among all nations and particularly among the churches.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:347
verses.text: Most, however, of those who have written on the subject have addressed themselves to such as have not yet chosen virginity, and who need help to enable them to choose aright.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:348
verses.text: But I and those to whom I write have made our choice; and our one object is to remain constant to it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:349
verses.text: Therefore, as our way lies among scorpions and adders, among snares and banes, let us go forward staff in hand, our loins girded and our feet shod; that so we may come to the sweet waters of the true Jordan, and enter the land of promise and go up to the house of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:350
verses.text: Then shall we sing with the prophet: "Lord, I have loved the habitation of thy house and the place where thine honour dwelleth;" and again: "one thing have I desired of the Lord, that will I seek after; that I may dwell in the house of the Lord all the days of my life".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:351
verses.text: Happy is the soul, happy is the virgin in whose heart there is room for no other love than the love of Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:352
verses.text: For in Himself He is wisdom and chastity, patience and justice and every other virtue.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:353
verses.text: Happy too is she who can recall a man's face without the least sigh of regret, and who has no desire to set eyes on one whom, after she has seen him, she may find herself unwilling to give up.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:354
verses.text: Some there are, however, who by their ill-behaviour bring discredit on the holy profession of virginity and upon the glory of the heavenly and angelic company who have made it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:355
verses.text: These must be frankly told either to marry if they cannot contain, or to contain if they will not marry.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:356
verses.text: It is also a matter for laughter or rather for tears, that when mistresses walk abroad they are preceded by maids better dressed than themselves; indeed so usual has this become that, if of two women you see one less neat than the other, you take her for the mistress as a matter of course.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:357
verses.text: And yet these maids are professed virgins.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:358
verses.text: Again not a few virgins choose sequestered dwellings where they will not be under the eyes of others, in order that they may live more freely than they otherwise could do.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:359
verses.text: They take baths, do what they please, and try as much as they can to escape notice.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:360
verses.text: We see these things and yet we put up with them; in fact, if we catch sight of the glitter of gold, we are ready to account of them as good works.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:362
verses.text: I end as I began, not content to have given you but a single warning.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:363
verses.text: Love the holy scriptures, and wisdom will love you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:364
verses.text: Love wisdom, and it will keep you safe.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:365
verses.text: Honour wisdom, and it will embrace you round about.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:366
verses.text: Let the jewels on your breast and in your ears be the gems of wisdom.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:367
verses.text: Let your tongue know no theme but Christ, let no sound pass your lips that is not holy, and let your words always reproduce that sweetness of which your grandmother and your mother set you the example.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 132:368
verses.text: Imitate them, for they are models of virtue.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 133:1
verses.text: Letter CXXXI.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 133:2
verses.text: From Augustine.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 133:3
verses.text: At the suggestion of Jerome, Marcellinus (for whom see Letter CXXVI.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 133:4
verses.text: ) had consulted Augustine on the difficult question of the origin of the soul but had failed to get any definite opinion from this latter.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 133:5
verses.text: Augustine now writes to Jerome confessing his inability to decide the question and asking for advice upon it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 133:6
verses.text: He begins by reciting—and justifying—his own belief that the soul is immortal and incorporeal and that its fall into sin is due not to God but to its own free choice.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 133:7
verses.text: He then goes on to say that he is quite ready to accept creationism as a solution of the difficulty if Jerome will shew him how this theory is reconcilable with the church's condemnation of Pelagius and its assertion of the doctrine of original sin.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 133:8
verses.text: The damnation of unbaptized infants is assumed throughout.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 133:9
verses.text: The date of the letter is 415 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 133:10
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 133:11
verses.text: Its number in the Letters of Augustine is CLXVI.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 134:1
verses.text: Letter CXXXII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 134:2
verses.text: From Augustine.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 134:3
verses.text: In this letter Augustine deals with the statement of James ii.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 134:4
verses.text: 10 ("whosoever shall keep the whole law and yet offend in one point, he is guilty of all") and explains it by saying that every breach of the law is a breach of love.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 134:5
verses.text: He also takes occasion to criticise two doctrines of the schools then prevalent, (1) that all sins are equal and (2) that he who has one virtue has all and that all virtues are wanting to him who lacks one.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 134:6
verses.text: The date of the letter is 415 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 134:7
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 134:8
verses.text: Its number in the Letters of Augustine is CLXVII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:1
verses.text: Letter CXXXIII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:2
verses.text: To Ctesiphon.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:3
verses.text: Ctesiphon had written to Jerome for his opinion on two points in the teaching of Pelagius, (1) his quietism and (2) his denial of original sin.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:4
verses.text: Jerome now refutes these two doctrines and points out that Pelagius has drawn them partly from the philosophers and partly from the heretics.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:5
verses.text: He censures Rufinus, who had died 5 years before, for attributing to Sixtus bishop of Rome a book which is really the work of Xystus a Pythagorean, and for passing off as the composition of the martyr Pamphilus a panegyric of Origen really due to his friend Eusebius.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:6
verses.text: In both these assertions, however, Jerome is more wrong than right.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:7
verses.text: (See Prolegomena to the works of Rufinus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:8
verses.text: ) The letter concludes with a promise to deal more fully with the heresy of Pelagius at some future time, a promise afterwards redeemed by the publication of a 'dialogue against the Pelagians.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:9
verses.text: ' The date of the letter is 415 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:10
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:12
verses.text: In acquainting me with the new controversy which has taken the place of the old you are wrong in thinking that you have acted rashly, for your conduct has been prompted by zeal and friendship.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:13
verses.text: Already before the arrival of your letter many in the East have been deceived into a pride which apes humility and have said with the devil: "I will ascend into heaven, I will exalt my throne above the stars of God; I will be like the Most High".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:14
verses.text: Can there be greater presumption than to claim not likeness to God but equality with Him, and so to compress into a few words the poisonous doctrines of all the heretics which in their turn flow from the statements of the philosophers, particularly of Pythagoras and Zeno the founder of the Stoic school? For those states of feeling which the Greeks call πάθη and which we may describe as "passions," relating to the present or the future such as vexation and gladness, hope and fear,—these, they tell us, it is possible to root out of our minds; in fact all vice may be destroyed root and branch in man by meditation on virtue and constant practice of it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:15
verses.text: The position which they thus take up is vehemently assailed by the Peripatetics who trace themselves to Aristotle, and by the new Academics of whom Cicero is a disciple; and these overthrow not the facts of their opponents—for they have no facts—but the shadows and wishes which do duty for them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:16
verses.text: To maintain such a doctrine is to take man's nature from him, to forget that he is constituted of body as well as soul, to substitute mere wishes for sound teaching.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:17
verses.text: For the apostle says:—"O wretched man that I am! who shall deliver me from the body of this death?" But as I cannot say all that I wish in a short letter I will briefly touch on the points that you must avoid.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:18
verses.text: Virgil writes:—  Thus mortals fear and hope, rejoice and grieve,  And shut in darkness have no sight of heaven.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:19
verses.text: For who can escape these feelings? Must we not all clap our hands when we are joyful, and shrink at the approach of sorrow? Must not hope always animate us and fear put us in terror? So in one of his Satires the poet Horace, whose words are so weighty, writes:  From faults no mortal is completely free;  He that has fewest is the perfect man.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:21
verses.text: Well does one of our own writers say: "the philosophers are the patriarchs of the heretics".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:22
verses.text: It is they who have stained with their perverse doctrine the spotlessness of the Church, not knowing that of human weakness it is said: "Why is earth and ashes proud?" So likewise the apostle: "I see another law in my members warring against the law of my mind and bringing me into captivity"; and again, "The good that I would I do not: but the evil which I would not that I do".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:23
verses.text: Now if Paul does what he wills not, what becomes of the assertion that a man may be without sin if he will? Given the will, how is it to have its way when the apostle tells us that he has no power to do what he wishes? Moreover if we ask them who the persons are whom they regard as sinless they seek to veil the truth by a new subterfuge.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:24
verses.text: They do not, they say, profess that men are or have been without sin; all that they maintain is that it is possible for them to be so.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:25
verses.text: Remarkable teachers truly, who maintain that a thing may be which on their own shewing, never has been; whereas the scripture says:—"The thing which shall be, it is that which hath been already of old time".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:26
verses.text: I need not go through the lives of the saints or call attention to the moles and spots which mark the fairest skins.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:27
verses.text: Many of our writers, it is true, unwisely, take this course; however, a few sentences of scripture will dispose alike of the heretics and the philosophers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:28
verses.text: What says the chosen vessel? "God had concluded all in unbelief that he might have mercy upon all;" and in another place, "all have sinned and come short of the glory of God".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:29
verses.text: The preacher also who is the mouthpiece of the Divine Wisdom freely protests and says: "there is not a just man upon earth, that doeth good and sinneth not:" and again, "if thy people sin against thee, for there is no man that sinneth not:" and "who can say, I have made my heart clean?" and "none is clean from stain, not even if his life on earth has been but for one day".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:30
verses.text: David insists on the same thing when he says: "Behold, I was shapen in iniquity and in sin did my mother conceive me;" and in another psalm, "in thy sight shall no man living be justified".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:31
verses.text: This last passage they try to explain away from motives of reverence, arguing that the meaning is that no man is perfect in comparison with God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:32
verses.text: Yet the scripture does not say: "in comparison with thee shall no man living be justified" but "in thy sight shall no man living be justified".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:33
verses.text: And when it says "in thy sight" it means that those who seem holy to men to God in his fuller knowledge are by no means holy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:34
verses.text: For "man looketh on the outward appearance, but the Lord looketh on the heart".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:35
verses.text: But if in the sight of God who sees all things and to whom the secrets of the heart lie open no man is just; then these heretics instead of adding to man's dignity, clearly take away from God's power.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:36
verses.text: I might bring together many other passages of scripture of the same import; but were I to do so, I should exceed the limits I will not say of a letter but of a volume.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:38
verses.text: It is with no new doctrines that in their self-applauding perfidy they deceive the simple and untaught.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:39
verses.text: They cannot, however, deceive theologians who meditate in the law of the Lord day and night.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:40
verses.text: Let those blush then for their leaders and companions who say that a man may be "without sin" if he will, or, as the Greeks term it αναμάρτητος , "sinless".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:41
verses.text: As such a statement sounds intolerable to the Eastern churches, they profess indeed only to say that a man may be "without sin" and do not presume to allege that he may be "sinless" as well.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:42
verses.text: As if, forsooth, "sinless" and "without sin" had different meanings; whereas the only difference between them is that Latin requires two words to express what Greek gives in one.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:43
verses.text: If you adopt "without sin" and reject "sinless," then condemn the preachers of sinlessness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:44
verses.text: But this you cannot do.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:45
verses.text: You know very well what it is that you teach your pupils in private; and that while you say one thing with your lips you engrave another on your heart.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:46
verses.text: To us, ignorant outsiders you speak in parables; but to your own followers you avow your secret meaning.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:47
verses.text: And for this you claim the authority of scripture which says: "to the multitudes Jesus spake in parables;" but to his own disciples He said: "it is given unto you to know the mysteries of the kingdom of heaven, but to them it is not given".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:48
verses.text: But to return; I will shortly set forth the names of your leaders and companions to shew you who those are of whose fellowship you make your boast.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:49
verses.text: Manichaeus says of his elect—whom he places among Plato's orbits in heaven—that they are free from all sin, and cannot sin even if they will.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:50
verses.text: To so great heights have they attained in virtue that they laugh at the works of the flesh.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:51
verses.text: Then there is Priscillian in Spain whose infamy makes him as bad as Manichaeus, and whose disciples profess a high esteem for you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:52
verses.text: These are rash enough to claim for themselves the twofold credit of perfection and wisdom.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:53
verses.text: Yet they shut themselves up alone with women and justify their sinful embraces by quoting the lines:  The almighty father takes the earth to wife;  Pouring upon her fertilizing rain,  That from her womb new harvest he may reap.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:54
verses.text: These heretics have affinities with Gnosticism which may be traced to the impious teaching of Basilides.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:55
verses.text: It is from him that you derive the assertion that without knowledge of the law it is impossible to avoid sin.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:56
verses.text: But why do I speak of Priscillian who has been condemned by the whole world and put to death by the secular sword? Evagrius of Ibera in Pontus who sends letters to virgins and monks and among others to her whose name bears witness to the blackness of her perfidy, has published a book of maxims on apathy, or, as we should say, impassivity or imperturbability; a state in which the mind ceases to be agitated and—to speak simply—becomes either a stone or a God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:57
verses.text: His work is widely read, in the East in Greek and in the West in a Latin translation made by his disciple Rufinus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:58
verses.text: He has also written a book which professes to be about monks and includes in it many not monks at all whom he declares to have been Origenists, and who have certainly been condemned by the bishops.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:59
verses.text: I mean Ammonius, Eusebius, Euthymius, Evagrius himself, Horus, Isidorus, and many others whom it would be tedious to enumerate.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:60
verses.text: He is careful, however, to do as the physicians, of whom Lucretius says:  To children bitter wormwood still they give  In cups with juice of sweetest honey smeared.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:61
verses.text: That is to say, he has set in the forefront of his book John, an undoubted Catholic and saint, by his means to introduce to the church the heretics mentioned farther on.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:62
verses.text: But who can adequately characterize the rashness or madness which has led him to ascribe a book of the Pythagorean philosopher Xystus, a heathen who knew nothing of Christ, to Sixtus a martyr and bishop of the Roman church? In this work the subject of perfection is discussed at length in the light of the Pythagorean doctrine which makes man equal with God and of one substance with Him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:63
verses.text: Thus many not knowing that its author was a philosopher and supposing that they are reading the words of a martyr, drink of the golden cup of Babylon.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:64
verses.text: Moreover in its pages there is no mention of prophets, patriarchs, apostles, or of Christ; so that according to Rufinus there has been a bishop and a martyr who had nothing to do with Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:65
verses.text: Such is the book from which you and your followers quote passages against the church.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:66
verses.text: In the same way he played fast and loose with the name of the holy martyr Pamphilus ascribing to him the first of the six books in defence of Origen written by Eusebius of Caesarea who is admitted by every body to have been an Arian.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:67
verses.text: His object in doing so was of course to commend to Latin ears Origen's four wonderful books about First Principles.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:68
verses.text: Would you have me name another of your masters in heresy? Much of your teaching is traceable to Origen.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:69
verses.text: For, to give one instance only, when he comments on the psalmist's words: "My reins also instruct me in the night season," he maintains that when a holy man like yourself has reached perfection, he is free even at night from human infirmity and is not tempted by evil thoughts.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:70
verses.text: You need not blush to avow yourself a follower of these men; it is of no use to disclaim their names when you adopt their blasphemies.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:71
verses.text: Moreover, your teaching corresponds to Jovinian's second position.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:72
verses.text: You must, therefore, take the answer which I have given to him as equally applicable to yourself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:73
verses.text: Where men's opinions are the same their destinies can hardly be different.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:75
verses.text: Such being the state of the case, what object is served by "silly women laden with sins, carried about with every wind of doctrine, ever learning and never able to come to the knowledge of the truth?" Or how is the cause helped by the men who dance attendance upon these, men with itching ears who know neither how to hear nor how to speak? They confound old mire with new cement and, as Ezekiel says, daub a wall with untempered mortar; so that, when the truth comes in a shower, they are brought to nought.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:76
verses.text: It was with the help of the harlot Helena that Simon Magus founded his sect.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:77
verses.text: Bands of women accompanied Nicolas of Antioch that deviser of all uncleanness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:78
verses.text: Marcion sent a woman before him to Rome to prepare men's minds to fall into his snares.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:79
verses.text: Apelles possessed in Philumena an associate in his false doctrines.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:80
verses.text: Montanus, that mouthpiece of an unclean spirit, used two rich and high born ladies Prisca and Maximilla first to bribe and then to pervert many churches.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:81
verses.text: Leaving ancient history I will pass to times nearer to our own.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:82
verses.text: Arius intent on leading the world astray began by misleading the Emperor's sister.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:83
verses.text: The resources of Lucilla helped Donatus to defile with his polluting baptism many unhappy persons throughout Africa.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:84
verses.text: In Spain the blind woman Agape led the blind man Elpidius into the ditch.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:85
verses.text: He was followed by Priscillian, an enthusiastic votary of Zoroaster and a magian before he became a bishop.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:86
verses.text: A woman named Galla seconded his efforts and left a gadabout sister to perpetuate a second heresy of a kindred form.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:87
verses.text: Now also the mystery of iniquity is working.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:88
verses.text: Men and women in turn lay snares for each other till we cannot but recall the prophet's words: "the partridge hath cried aloud, she hath gathered young which she hath not brought forth, she getteth riches and not by right; in the midst of her days she shall leave them, and at her end she shall be a fool".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:90
verses.text: The better to deceive men they have added to the maxim given above the saving clause "but not without the grace of God;" and this may at the first blush take in some readers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:91
verses.text: However, when it is carefully sifted and considered, it can deceive nobody.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:92
verses.text: For while they acknowledge the grace of God, they tell us that our acts do not depend upon His help.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:93
verses.text: Rather, they understand by the grace of God free will and the commandments of the Law.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:94
verses.text: They quote Isaiah's words: "God hath given the law to aid men," and say that we ought to thank Him for having created us such that of our own free will we can choose the good and avoid the evil.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:95
verses.text: Nor do they see that in alleging this the devil uses their lips to hiss out an intolerable blasphemy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:96
verses.text: For if God's grace is limited to this that He has formed us with wills of our own, and if we are to rest content with free will, not seeking the divine aid lest this should be impaired, we should cease to pray; for we cannot entreat God's mercy to give us daily what is already in our hands having been given to us once for all.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:97
verses.text: Those who think thus make prayer impossible and boast that free will makes them not merely controllers of themselves but as powerful as God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:98
verses.text: For they need no external help.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:99
verses.text: Away with fasting, away with every form of self-restraint! For why need I strive to win by toil what has once for all been placed within my reach? The argument that I am using is not mine; it is that put forward by a disciple of Pelagius, or rather one who is the teacher and commander of his whole army.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:100
verses.text: This man, who is the opposite of Paul for he is a vessel of perdition, roams through thickets—not, as his partisans say, of syllogisms, but of solecisms, and theorizes thus: "If I do nothing without the help of God and if all that I do is His act, I cease to labour and the crown that I shall win will belong not to me but to the grace of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:101
verses.text: It is idle for Him to have given me the power of choice if I cannot use it without His constant help.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:102
verses.text: For will that requires external support ceases to be will.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:103
verses.text: God has given me freedom of choice, but what becomes of this if I cannot do as I wish?" Accordingly he propounds the following dilemma: "Either once for all I use the power which is given to me, and so preserve the freedom of my will; or I need the help of another, in which case the freedom of my will is wholly abrogated".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:105
verses.text: Surely the man who says this is no ordinary blasphemer; the poison of his heresy is no common poison.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:106
verses.text: Since our wills are free, they argue, we are no longer dependent upon God; and they forget the Apostle's words "what hast thou that thou didst not receive? Now if thou didst receive it why dost thou glory as if thou hadst not received it?" A nice return, truly, does a man make to God when to assert the freedom of his will he rebels against Him! For our parts we gladly embrace this freedom, but we never forget to thank the Giver; knowing that we are powerless unless He continually preserves in us His own gift.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:107
verses.text: As the apostle says, "it is not of him that willeth, nor of him that runneth, but of God that sheweth mercy".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:108
verses.text: To will and to run are mine, but they will cease to be mine unless God brings me His continual aid.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:109
verses.text: For the same apostle says "it is God which worketh in you both to will and to do".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:110
verses.text: And in the Gospel the Saviour says: "my Father worketh hitherto and I work".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:111
verses.text: He is always a giver, always a bestower.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:112
verses.text: It is not enough for me that he has given me grace once; He must give it me always.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:113
verses.text: I seek that I may obtain, and when I have obtained I seek again.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:114
verses.text: I am covetous of God's bounty; and as He is never slack in giving, so I am never weary in receiving.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:115
verses.text: The more I drink, the more I thirst.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:116
verses.text: For I have read the song of the psalmist: "O taste and see that the Lord is good".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:117
verses.text: Every good thing that we have is a tasting of the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:118
verses.text: When I fancy myself to have finished the book of virtue, I shall then only be at the beginning.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:119
verses.text: For "the fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom," and this fear is in its turn cast out by love.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:120
verses.text: Men are only perfect so far as they know themselves to be imperfect.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:121
verses.text: "So likewise ye," Christ says, "when ye shall have done all those things which are commanded you, say, We are unprofitable servants: we have done that which was our duty to do".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:122
verses.text: If he is unprofitable who has done all, what must we say of him who has failed to do so? This is why the Apostle declares that he has attained in part and apprehended in part, that he is not yet perfect, and that forgetting those things which are behind he reaches forth unto those things which are before.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:123
verses.text: Now he who always forgets the past and longs for the future shews that he is not content with the present.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:124
verses.text: They are for ever objecting to us that we destroy free will.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:125
verses.text: Nay, we reply, it is you who destroy it; for you use it amiss and disown the bounty of its Giver.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:126
verses.text: Which really destroys freedom? the man who thanks God always and traces back his own tiny rill to its source in Him? or the man who says: "come not near to me, for I am holy; I have no need of Thee.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:127
verses.text: Thou hast given me once for all freedom of choice to do as I wish.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:128
verses.text: Why then dost Thou interfere again to prevent me from doing anything unless Thou Thyself first makest Thy gifts effective in me?" To such an one I would say: "your profession of belief in God's grace is insincere.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:129
verses.text: For you explain this of the state in which man has been created and you do not look for God to help him in his actions.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:130
verses.text: To do this, you argue, would be to surrender human freedom.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:131
verses.text: Thus disdaining the aid of God you have to look to men for help".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:133
verses.text: Listen, only listen, to the blasphemer.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:134
verses.text: "Suppose," he avers, "that I want to bend my finger or to move my hand, to sit, to stand, to walk, to run to and fro, to spit or to blow my nose, to perform the offices of nature; must the help of God be always indispensable to me?" Thankless, nay blasphemous wretch, hear the apostle's declaration: "whether therefore ye eat or drink, or whatsoever ye do, do all to the glory of God".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:135
verses.text: Hear also the words of James: "go to now, ye that say, To-day or to-morrow we will go into such a city and continue there a year, and buy, and sell, and get gain.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:136
verses.text: Whereas ye know not what shall be on the morrow: for what is your life? It is even a vapour that appeareth for a little time, and then vanisheth away.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:137
verses.text: For that ye ought to say, If the Lord will, we shall live, and do this or that.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:138
verses.text: But now ye rejoice in your boastings; all such rejoicing is evil".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:139
verses.text: You fancy that a wrong is inflicted on you and your freedom of choice is destroyed if you are forced to fall back on God as the moving cause of all your actions, if you are made dependent on His Will, and if you have to echo the psalmist's words: "mine eyes are ever toward the Lord: for it is he that shall pluck my feet out of the net".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:140
verses.text: And so you presume rashly to maintain that each individual is governed by his own choice.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:141
verses.text: But if he is governed by his own choice, what becomes of God's help? If he does not need Christ to rule him, why does Jeremiah write: "the way of man is not in himself" and "the Lord directeth his steps".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:142
verses.text: You say that the commandments of God are easy, and yet you cannot produce any one who has fulfilled them all.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:143
verses.text: Answer me this: are they easy or are they difficult? If they are easy, then produce some one who has fulfilled them all.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:144
verses.text: Explain also the words of the psalmist: "thou dost cause toil by thy law," and "because of the words of thy lips I have kept hard ways".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:145
verses.text: And make plain our Lord's sayings in the gospel: "enter ye in at the strait gate;" and "love your enemies;" and "pray for them which persecute you".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:146
verses.text: If on the other hand the commandments are difficult and if no man has kept them all, how have you presumed to say that they are easy? Do not you see that you contradict yourself? For either they are easy and countless numbers have kept them; or they are difficult and you have been too hasty in calling them easy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:148
verses.text: It is a common argument with your party to say that God's commandments are either possible or impossible.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:149
verses.text: So far as they are the former you admit that they are rightly laid upon us; but so far as they are the latter you allege that blame attaches not to us who have received them but to God who has imposed them on us.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:150
verses.text: What! has God commanded me to be what He is, to put no difference between myself and my creator, to be greater than the greatest of the angels, to have a power which no angels possess? Sinlessness is made a characteristic of Christ, "who did no sin neither was guile found in his mouth".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:151
verses.text: But if I am sinless as well as He, how is sinlessness any longer His distinguishing mark? for if this distinction exists, your theory becomes fatal to itself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:152
verses.text: You assert that a man may be without sin if he will; and then, as though awakening from a deep sleep, you try to deceive the unwary by adding the saving clause "yet not without the grace of God".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:153
verses.text: For if by his own efforts a man can keep himself without sin, what need has he of God's grace? If on the other hand he can do nothing without this, what is the use of saying that he can do what he cannot do? It is argued that a man may be without sin and perfect if he only wills it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:154
verses.text: What Christian is there who does not wish to be sinless or who would reject perfection if, as you say, it is to be had for the wishing, and if the will is sure to be followed by the power? There is no Christian who does not wish to be sinless; wishing to be so, therefore, they all will be so.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:155
verses.text: Whether you like it or not you will be caught in this dilemma, that you can produce nobody or hardly anybody who is without sin, yet have to admit that everybody may be sinless if he likes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:156
verses.text: God's commandments, it is argued, are possible to keep.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:157
verses.text: Who denies it? But how this truth is to be understood the chosen vessel thus most clearly explains: "what the law could not do in that it was weak through the flesh, God, sending his own Son in the likeness of sinful flesh and for sin, condemned sin in the flesh;" and again: "by the deeds of the law there shall no flesh be justified".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:158
verses.text: And to shew that it is not only the law of Moses that is meant or all those precepts which collectively are termed the law, the same apostle writes: "I delight in the law of God after the inward man.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:159
verses.text: But I see another law in my members, warring against the law of my mind, and bringing me into captivity to the law of sin which is in my members.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:160
