verses.text: O wretched man that I am: who shall deliver me from the body of this death? The grace of God through Jesus Christ our Lord".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:161
verses.text: Other words of his further explain his meaning: "we know that the law is spiritual: but I am carnal, sold under sin.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:162
verses.text: For that which I do I know not: for what I would that do I not, but what I hate that do I.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:163
verses.text: If then I do that which I would not, I consent unto the law that it is good.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:164
verses.text: Now then it is no more I that do it: but sin that dwelleth in me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:165
verses.text: For I know that in me (that is, in my flesh) dwelleth no good thing.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:166
verses.text: For to will is present with me: but how to perform that which is good I find not.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:167
verses.text: For the good that I would, I do not: but the evil which I would not, that I do.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:168
verses.text: Now if I do that I would not, it is no more I that do it, but sin that dwelleth in me".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:170
verses.text: But you will demur to this and say that I follow the teaching of the Manichaeans and others who make war against the church's doctrine in the interest of their belief that there are two natures diverse from one another and that there is an evil nature which can in no wise be changed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:171
verses.text: But it is not against me that you must make this imputation but against the apostle who knows well that God is one thing and man another, that the flesh is weak and the spirit strong.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:172
verses.text: "The flesh lusteth against the spirit and the spirit against the flesh: and these are contrary the one to the other: so that ye cannot do the things that ye would".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:173
verses.text: But from me you will never hear that any nature is essentially evil.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:174
verses.text: Let us learn then from him who tells us so in what sense the flesh is weak.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:175
verses.text: Ask him why he has said: "the good that I would, I do not; the evil which I would not, that I do".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:176
verses.text: What necessity fetters his will? What compulsion commands him to do what he dislikes? And why must he do not what he wishes but what he dislikes and does not wish? He will answer you thus: "nay, but, O man, who art thou that repliest against God? Shall the thing formed say unto him that formed it, Why hast thou made me thus? Hath not the potter power over the clay, of the same lump to make one vessel unto honour and another unto dishonour?" Bring a yet graver charge against God and ask Him why, when Esau and Jacob were still in the womb, He said: "Jacob have I loved, but Esau have I hated".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:177
verses.text: Accuse Him of injustice because, when Achan the son of Carmi stole part of the spoil of Jericho, He butchered so many thousands for the fault of one.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:178
verses.text: Ask Him why for the sin of the sons of Eli the people were well-nigh annihilated and the ark captured.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:179
verses.text: And why, when David sinned by numbering the people, so many thousands lost their lives.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:180
verses.text: Or lastly make your own the favorite cavil of your associate Porphyry, and ask how God can be described as pitiful and of great mercy when from Adam to Moses and from Moses to the coming of Christ He has suffered all nations to die in ignorance of the Law and of His commandments.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:181
verses.text: For Britain, that province so fertile in despots, the Scottish tribes, and all the barbarians round about as far as the ocean were alike without knowledge of Moses and the prophets.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:182
verses.text: Why should Christ's coming have been delayed to the last times? Why should He not have come before so vast a number had perished? Of this last question the blessed apostle in writing to the Romans most wisely disposes by admitting that he does not know and that only God does.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:183
verses.text: Do you too, then, condescend to remain ignorant of that into which you inquire.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:184
verses.text: Leave to God His power over what is His own; He does not need you to justify His actions.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:185
verses.text: I am the hapless being against whom you ought to direct your insults, I who am for ever reading the words: "by grace ye are saved," and "blessed is he whose transgression is forgiven, whose sin is covered".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:186
verses.text: Yet, to lay bare my own weakness, I know that I wish to do many things which I ought to do and yet cannot.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:187
verses.text: For while my spirit is strong and leads me to life my flesh is weak and draws me to death.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:188
verses.text: And I have the warning of the Lord in my ears: "watch and pray that ye enter not into temptation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:189
verses.text: The spirit indeed is willing, but the flesh is weak".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:191
verses.text: It is in vain that you misrepresent me and try to convince the ignorant that I condemn free will.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:192
verses.text: Let him who condemns it be himself condemned.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:193
verses.text: We have been created endowed with free will; still it is not this which distinguishes us from the brutes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:194
verses.text: For human free will, as I have said before, depends upon the help of God and needs His aid moment by moment, a thing which you and yours do not choose to admit.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:195
verses.text: Your position is that, if a man once has free will, he no longer needs the help of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:196
verses.text: It is true that freedom of the will brings with it freedom of decision.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:197
verses.text: Still man does not act immediately on his free will, but requires God's aid who Himself needs no aid.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:198
verses.text: You yourself boast that a man's righteousness may be perfect and equal to God's; yet you confess that you are a sinner.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:199
verses.text: Answer me this, then; do you or do you not wish to be free from sin? If you do, why on your principle do you not carry out your desire? And if you do not, do you not prove yourself a despiser of God's commandments? If you are a despiser, then you are a sinner.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:200
verses.text: And if you are a sinner, then the scripture says: "unto the wicked God saith, what hast thou to do to declare my statutes, or that thou shouldest take my covenant in thy mouth? seeing thou hatest instruction and castest my words behind thee".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:201
verses.text: So long as you are unwilling to do what God commands, so long do you cast His words behind you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:202
verses.text: And yet like a new apostle you lay down for the world what to do and what not to do.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:203
verses.text: However, your words and your thoughts by no means correspond.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:204
verses.text: For when you say that you are a sinner—yet that a man may be without sin if he will, you wish it to be understood that you are a saint and free from all sin.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:205
verses.text: It is only out of humility that you call yourself a sinner; to give you a chance of praising others while you depreciate yourself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:207
verses.text: Another of your arguments is also intolerable, one which runs thus: "To be sinless is one thing, to be able to be so is another.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:208
verses.text: The first is not in our power, the second generally is.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:209
verses.text: For though none ever has been sinless, yet, if a man wills to be so, he can be so".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:210
verses.text: What sort of reasoning, I ask, is this? that a man can be what a man never has been! that a thing is possible which according to your own admission, no man has yet achieved! You are predicating of man a quality which, for aught you know, he may never possess! and you are assigning to any chance person a grace which you cannot shew to have marked patriarchs, prophets, or apostles.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:211
verses.text: Listen to the Church's words, plain as they may seem to you or crude or ignorant.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:212
verses.text: And speak what you think; preach publicly what secretly you tell your disciples.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:213
verses.text: You profess to have freedom of choice; why do you not speak your thoughts freely? Your secret chambers hear one doctrine, the crowd around the platform hear another.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:214
verses.text: The uneducated throng, I suppose, is not able to digest your esoteric teaching.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:215
verses.text: Satisfied with the milk-diet of an infant it cannot take solid food.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:216
verses.text: I have written nothing yet, and still you menace me with the thunders of a reply; hoping, I suppose, that I may be scared by your terrors and may not venture to open my mouth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:217
verses.text: You fail to see that my purpose in writing is to force you to answer and to commit yourself plainly to doctrines which at present you maintain or ignore, as time, place, and person require.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:218
verses.text: One kind of freedom I must deny to you, the freedom to deny what you have once written.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:219
verses.text: An open avowal on your part of the opinions that you hold will be a victory for the church.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:220
verses.text: For either the language of your reply will correspond to mine, in which case I shall count you no longer as opponents but as friends; or else you will gainsay my doctrine, in which case the making known of your opinion to all the churches will be a triumph for me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:221
verses.text: To have brought your tenets to light is to have overcome them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:222
verses.text: Blasphemy is written on the face of them, and a doctrine, which in its very statement is blasphemous, needs no refutation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:223
verses.text: You threaten me with a reply, but this nobody can escape except the man who does not write at all.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:224
verses.text: How do you know what I am going to say that you talk of a reply? Perhaps I shall take your view and then you will have sharpened your wits to no purpose.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:225
verses.text: Eunomians, Arians, Macedonians—all these, unlike in name, alike in impiety, give me no trouble.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:226
verses.text: For they say what they think.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:227
verses.text: Yours is the only heresy which blushes openly to maintain what secretly it does not fear to teach.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:228
verses.text: But the frenzy of the disciples exposes the silence of the masters; for what they have heard from them in the closet they preach upon the housetop.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:229
verses.text: If their auditors like what they say, their masters get the credit; and if they dislike it, only the disciples are blamed, the masters go free.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:230
verses.text: In this way your heresy has grown and you have deceived many; especially those who cleave to women and are assured that they cannot sin.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:231
verses.text: You are always teaching, you are always denying; you deserve to have the prophet's words applied to you: "give to them glory, O Lord, when they are in travail and in the throes of labour.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:232
verses.text: Give them, O Lord; what wilt thou give? Give them a miscarrying womb and dry breasts".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:233
verses.text: My temper rises and I cannot check my words.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:234
verses.text: The limits of a letter do not admit of a lengthy discussion.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:235
verses.text: I assail nobody by name here.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:236
verses.text: It is only against the teacher of perverse doctrine that I have spoken.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:237
verses.text: If resentment shall induce him to reply, he will but betray himself like a mouse which always leaves traces of its presence; and, when it comes to blows in earnest, will receive more serious wounds.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:239
verses.text: From my youth up until now I have spent many years in writing various works and have always tried to teach my hearers the doctrine that I have been taught publicly in church.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:240
verses.text: I have not followed the philosophers in their discussions but have preferred to acquiesce in the plain words of the apostles.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:241
verses.text: For I have known that it is written: "I will destroy the wisdom of the wise, and will bring to nothing the understanding of the prudent," and "the foolishness of God is wiser than men".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:242
verses.text: This being the case, I challenge my opponents thoroughly to sift all my past writings and, if they can find anything that is faulty in them, to bring it to light.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:243
verses.text: One of two things must happen.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:244
verses.text: Either my works will be found edifying and I shall confute the false charges brought against me; or they will be found blameworthy and I shall confess my error.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:245
verses.text: For I would sooner correct an error than persevere in an opinion proved to be wrong.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:246
verses.text: And as for you, illustrious doctor, go you and do likewise: either defend the statements that you have made, and support your clever theories with corresponding eloquence, and do not when the whim takes you disown your own words; or if, as a man may do, you have made a mistake, confess it frankly and restore harmony where there has been disagreement.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:247
verses.text: Recall to mind how even the soldiers did not rend the coat of the Saviour.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:248
verses.text: When you see brothers at strife you laugh; and are glad that some are called by your name and others by that of Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:249
verses.text: Better would it be to imitate Jonah and say: "If it is for my sake that this great tempest is upon you, take me up and cast me forth into the sea".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:250
verses.text: He in his humility was thrown into the deep that he might rise again in glory to be a type of the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:251
verses.text: But you are lifted up in your pride to the stars, only that of you too Jesus may say: "I beheld Satan as lightning fall from heaven".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:253
verses.text: It is true that in the holy scriptures many are called righteous, as Zacharias and Elizabeth, Job, Jehosaphat, Josiah, and many others who are mentioned in the sacred writings.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:254
verses.text: Of this fact I shall, if God gives me grace, give a full explanation in the work which I have promised; in this letter it must suffice to say that they are called righteous, not because they are faultless but because their faults are eclipsed by their virtues.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:255
verses.text: In fact Zacharias is punished with dumbness, Job is condemned out of his own mouth, and Jehoshaphat and Josiah who are beyond a doubt described as righteous are narrated to have done things displeasing to the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:256
verses.text: The first leagued himself with the ungodly Ahab and brought upon himself the rebuke of Micaiah; and the second—though forbidden by the word of the Lord spoken by Jeremiah—went against Pharaoh-Nechoh, king of Egypt, and was slain by him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:257
verses.text: Yet they are both called righteous.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:258
verses.text: Of the rest this is not the time to write; for you have asked me not for a treatise but for a letter.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:259
verses.text: For a complete refutation I require leisure and then I hope to destroy all their cavils by the help of Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:260
verses.text: For this purpose I shall rely on the holy scriptures in which God every day speaks to those who believe.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:261
verses.text: And this is the warning which I would give through you to all who are assembled within your holy and illustrious house, that they should not allow one or at the most three mannikins to taint them with the dregs of so many heresies and with the infamy—to say the least—attaching to them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:262
verses.text: A place once famous for virtue and holiness must not be defiled by the presumption of the devil and by unclean associations.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:263
verses.text: And let those who supply money to such men know that they are adding to the ranks of the heretics, raising up enemies to Christ and fostering his avowed opponents.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 135:264
verses.text: It is idle for them to profess one thing with their lips when by their actions they are proved to think another.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 136:1
verses.text: Letter CXXXIV.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 136:2
verses.text: To Augustine.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 136:3
verses.text: Jerome acknowledges the receipt of Letters CXXXI.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 136:4
verses.text: and CXXXII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 136:5
verses.text: and excuses himself from answering the questions raised in them on the twofold ground (1) that the times are evil and (2) that it is inexpedient that he should be supposed to differ from Augustine.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 136:6
verses.text: He prays for the speedy extinction of Pelagianism, regrets that he cannot send Augustine a critical Latin text of the O.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 136:7
verses.text: T.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 136:8
verses.text: , and concludes with a number of salutations from himself and those with him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 136:9
verses.text: The date of the letter is 416 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 136:10
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 136:11
verses.text: Its number in Augustine's Letters is CLXXII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 137:1
verses.text: Letter CXXXV.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 137:2
verses.text: From Pope Innocent to Aurelius.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 137:3
verses.text: Shortly after the synod of Diospolis the Pelagians exulting in their success made an attack upon Jerome's monasteries at Bethlehem which they pillaged and partially burned.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 137:4
verses.text: This gained for him the sympathy of Innocent who now (a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 137:5
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 137:6
verses.text: 417) asks Aurelius to transmit to him the letter which follows this.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 137:7
verses.text: Innocent to his most esteemed friend and brother Aurelius.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 137:8
verses.text: Our fellow-presbyter Jerome has informed us of your most dutiful desire to come to see us.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 137:9
verses.text: We suffer with him as with a member of our own flock.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 137:10
verses.text: We have been swift also to take such measures as have appeared to us expedient and practicable.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 137:11
verses.text: As you count yourself one of us, most dear brother, make haste to transmit the following letter to the aforesaid Jerome.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 138:1
verses.text: Letter CXXXVI.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 138:2
verses.text: From Pope Innocent to Jerome.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 138:3
verses.text: Innocent expresses his sympathy with Jerome and promises to take strong measures to punish his opponents if he will bring specific charges against them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 138:4
verses.text: The date of the letter is a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 138:5
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 138:7
verses.text: Innocent to his most esteemed son, the presbyter Jerome.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 138:8
verses.text: The apostle bears witness that contention has never done good in the church; and for this reason he gives direction that heretics should be admonished once or twice in the beginning of their heresy and not subjected to a long series of rebukes.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 138:9
verses.text: Where this rule is negligently observed, the evil to be guarded against so far from being evaded is rather intensified.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 138:10
verses.text: Your grief and lamentation have so affected us that we can neither act nor advise.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 138:11
verses.text: To begin however, we commend you for the constancy of your faith.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 138:12
verses.text: To quote your own words spoken many times in the ears of many, a man will gladly face misrepresentation or even personal danger on behalf of the truth; if he is looking for the blessedness that is to come.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 138:13
verses.text: We remind you of what you have yourself preached although we are sure that you need no reminder.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 138:14
verses.text: The spectacle of these terrible evils has so thoroughly roused us that we have hastened to put forth the authority of the apostolic see to repress the plague in all its manifestations; but as your letters name no individuals and bring no specific charges, there is no one at present against whom we can proceed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 138:15
verses.text: But we do all that we can; we sympathize deeply with you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 138:16
verses.text: And if you will lay a clear and unambiguous accusation against any persons in particular we will appoint suitable judges to try their cases; or if you, our highly esteemed son, think that it is needful for us to take yet graver and more urgent action, we shall not be slow to do so.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 138:17
verses.text: Meantime we have written to our brother bishop John advising him to act more considerately, so that nothing may occur in the church committed to him which it is his duty to foresee and to prevent, and that nothing may happen which may subsequently prove a source of trouble to him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 139:1
verses.text: Letter CXXXVII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 139:2
verses.text: From Pope Innocent to John, Bishop of Jerusalem.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 139:3
verses.text: Innocent censures John for having allowed the Pelagians to effuse the disturbance at Bethlehem mentioned in the two preceding letters and exhorts him to be more watchful over his diocese in future.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 139:4
verses.text: The date of the letter is a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 139:5
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 139:7
verses.text: This was the year of the death of both John and Innocent, and it is probable that John never received the letter.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 139:8
verses.text: Innocent to his most highly esteemed brother John.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 139:9
verses.text: The holy virgins Eustochium and Paula have deplored to me the ravages, murders, fires and outrages of all kinds, which they say that the devil has perpetrated in the district belonging to their church; for with wonderful clemency and generosity they have left untold the name and motive of his human agent.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 139:10
verses.text: Now although there can be no doubt as to who is the guilty person; yet you, my brother, ought to have taken precautions and to have been more careful of your flock so that no disturbance of the kind might arise; for others suffer by your negligence, and you encourage men by it to make havoc of the Lord's flock till His tender lambs, fleeced and weakened by fire, sword and persecution, their relations murdered and dead, are, as we are informed, themselves scarce alive.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 139:11
verses.text: Does it not touch your sacred responsibility as a priest that the devil has shewn himself so powerful against you and yours? Against you, I say; for surely it speaks ill of your capacity as a priest that a crime so terrible should have been committed in the pale of your church.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 139:12
verses.text: Where were your precautions? Where, after the blow had been struck, were your attempts at relief? Where too were your words of comfort? These ladies tell me that up to the present they have been in a state of too great apprehension to complain of what they have already suffered.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 139:13
verses.text: I should judge more gravely of the matter had they spoken to me concerning it more freely than they have.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 139:14
verses.text: Beware then, brother, of the wiles of the old enemy, and in the spirit of a good ruler be vigilant either to correct or to repress such evils.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 139:15
verses.text: For they have reached my ears in the shape of rumours rather than as specific accusations.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 139:16
verses.text: If nothing is done, the law of the Church on the subject of injuries may compel the person who has failed to defend his flock to shew cause for his negligence.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 140:1
verses.text: Letter CXXXVIII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 140:2
verses.text: To Riparius.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 140:3
verses.text: Jerome praises Riparius for his zeal on behalf of the Catholic faith and for his efforts to put down the Pelagians.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 140:4
verses.text: He then describes the attack made by these heretics upon the monasteries of Bethlehem.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 140:5
verses.text: Now, he is glad to say, they have at last been driven from Palestine.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 140:6
verses.text: Most of them, that is, for some still linger at Joppa including one of their chief leaders.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 140:7
verses.text: The date is a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 140:8
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 140:10
verses.text: That you fight Christ's battles against the enemies of the Catholic Faith your own letters have informed me as well as the reports of many persons, but I am told that you find the winds contrary and that those who ought to have been the world's champions have backed the cause of perdition to each other's ruin.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 140:11
verses.text: You are to know that in this part of the world, without any human help and merely by the decree of Christ, Catiline has been driven not only from the capital but from the borders of Palestine.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 140:12
verses.text: Lentulus, however, and many of his fellow-conspirators still linger to our sorrow in Joppa.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 140:13
verses.text: I myself have thought it better to change my abode than to surrender the true faith; and have chosen to leave my pleasant home rather than to suffer contamination from heresy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 140:14
verses.text: For I could not communicate with men who would either have insisted on my instant submission or would else have summoned me to support my opinions by the sword.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 140:15
verses.text: A good many, I dare say, have told you the story of my sufferings and of the vengeance which Christ's uplifted hand has on my behalf taken upon my enemies.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 140:16
verses.text: I would beg of you, therefore, to complete the task which you have taken up and not, while you are in it, to leave Christ's church without a defender.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 140:17
verses.text: Every one knows the weapons that must be used in this warfare; and you, I feel sure will ask for no others.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 140:18
verses.text: You must contend with all your might against the foe; but it must be not with physical force but with that spiritual charity which is never overcome.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 140:19
verses.text: The reverend brothers who are with me, unworthy as I am, salute you warmly.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 140:20
verses.text: The reverend brother, the deacon Alentius, is sure to give you, my worshipful friend, a faithful narrative of all the facts.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 140:21
verses.text: May Christ our Lord, of His almighty power, keep you safe and mindful of me, truly reverend sir and esteemed brother.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 141:1
verses.text: Letter CXXXIX.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 141:2
verses.text: To Apronius.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 141:3
verses.text: Of Apronius nothing is known; but from the mention of Innocent (for whom see Letter CXLIII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 141:4
verses.text: ) it seems a fair inference that he lived in the West.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 141:5
verses.text: Jerome here congratulates him on his steadfastness in the faith and exhorts him to come to Bethlehem.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 141:6
verses.text: He then touches on the mischief done by Pelagius and complains that his own monastery has been destroyed by him or by his partisans.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 141:7
verses.text: The date of the letter is a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 141:8
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 141:10
verses.text: I know not by what wiles of the devil it has come to pass that all your toil and the efforts of the reverend presbyter Innocent and my own prayers and wishes seem for the moment to produce no effect.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 141:11
verses.text: God be thanked that you are well and that the fire of faith glows in you even when you are in the midst of the devil's wiles.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 141:12
verses.text: My greatest joy is to hear that my spiritual sons are fighting in the cause of Christ; and assuredly He in whom we believe will so quicken this zeal of ours that we shall be glad freely to shed our blood in defence of His faith.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 141:13
verses.text: I grieve to hear that a noble family has been subverted, for what reason I cannot learn; for the bearer of the letter could give me no information.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 141:14
verses.text: We may well grieve over the loss of our common friends and ask Christ the only potentate and Lord to have mercy upon them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 141:15
verses.text: At the same time we have deserved to receive punishment at God's hand for we have harboured the enemies of the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 141:16
verses.text: The best course you can take is to leave everything and to come to the East, before all to the holy places; for everything is now quiet here.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 141:17
verses.text: The heretics have not, it is true, purged the venom from their breasts, but they do not venture to open their impious mouths.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 141:18
verses.text: They are "like the deaf adder that stoppeth her ear".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 141:19
verses.text: Salute your reverend brothers on my behalf.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 141:20
verses.text: As for our house, so far as fleshly wealth is concerned, it has been completely destroyed by the onslaughts of the heretics; but by the mercy of Christ it is still filled with spiritual riches.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 141:21
verses.text: To live on bread is better than to lose the faith.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 142:1
verses.text: Letter CXL.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 142:2
verses.text: To Cyprian the Presbyter.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 142:3
verses.text: Cyprian had visited Jerome at Bethlehem and had asked him to write an exposition of Psalm XC.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 142:4
verses.text: in simple language such as might be readily understood.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 142:5
verses.text: With this request Jerome now complies, giving a very full account of the psalm, verse by verse, and bringing the treasures of his learning and especially his knowledge of Hebrew to bear upon it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 142:6
verses.text: He asserts its Mosaic authorship but is careful to add that "the man of God" may have spoken not for himself but in the name of the Jewish people.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 142:7
verses.text: He speaks of the five books into which the psalter is divisible and says that it is a mistake to ascribe all the psalms to David.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 142:8
verses.text: An allusion to the doctrine of Pelagius shows that the letter must belong to Jerome's last years, and Vallarsi is probably right in assigning it to a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 142:9
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 143:1
verses.text: Letter CXLI.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 143:2
verses.text: To Augustine  A short note in which Jerome praises Augustine for the determined stand which he has made against heresy and speaks of him as "the restorer of the ancient faith".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 143:3
verses.text: The allusion seems to be to his action in the Pelagian controversy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 143:4
verses.text: If so, the date is probably 418 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 143:5
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 143:6
verses.text: This letter is among those of Augustine, number 195.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 144:1
verses.text: Letter CXLII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 144:2
verses.text: To Augustine.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 144:3
verses.text: There is good ground for supposing this to form part of the previous letter.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 144:4
verses.text: If so, Jerome speaks in a figure of the success gained by Pelagianism in Palestine.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 144:5
verses.text: "Jerusalem," he says, "is in the hands of Nebuchadnezzar and will not heed the voice of Jeremiah," that is, as the context shews, Jerome himself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 144:6
verses.text: This letter is among those of Augustine, number 123.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 145:1
verses.text: Letter CXLIII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 145:2
verses.text: To Alypius and Augustine.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 145:3
verses.text: In this letter Jerome congratulates Alypius and Augustine on their success in strangling the heresy of Caelestius, the co-adjutor of Pelagius, and states that, if he can find time and secretaries, he hopes to write a refutation of the absurd errors of the Pelagian pseudodeacon Annianus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 145:4
verses.text: The date is 419 a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 145:5
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 145:6
verses.text: This letter is among those of Augustine, number 202.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 146:1
verses.text: Letter CXLIV.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 146:2
verses.text: From Augustine to Optatus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:1
verses.text: Augustine writes to Optatus, bishop of Milevis, to say that he cannot send him a copy of his letter to Jerome on the origin of the soul (Letter CXXXI.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:2
verses.text: ) as it is incomplete without Jerome's reply which he has not yet received.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:3
verses.text: He then criticises the arguments with which Optatus combats traducianism and points out that his reasoning is inconclusive.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:4
verses.text: The date of the letter is a.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:5
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:7
verses.text: The letter has been somewhat compressed in translation: the involved sentences of the original have been simplified and its redundancies curtailed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:8
verses.text: To the blessed lord and brother, sincerely loved and longed-for, his fellow-bishop Optatus, Augustine [sends] greeting in the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:10
verses.text: By the hand of the reverend presbyter Saturninus I have received a letter from you, venerable sir, in which you earnestly ask me for what I have not yet got.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:11
verses.text: You thus shew clearly your belief that I have already had a reply to my question on the subject.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:12
verses.text: Would that I had! Knowing the eagerness of your expectation, I should never have dreamed of keeping back from you your share in the gift; but if you will believe me, dear brother, it is not so.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:13
verses.text: Although five years have elapsed since I despatched to the East my letter (which was one of inquiry, not of assertion), I have so far received no reply, and am consequently unable to untie the knot as you wish me to do.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:14
verses.text: Had I had both letters, I should gladly have sent you both; but I think it better not to circulate mine by itself lest he to whom it is addressed and who may still answer me as I desire should prove displeased.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:15
verses.text: If I were to publish so elaborate a treatise as mine without his reply to it, he might be justly indignant, and suppose me more intent on displaying my talents than on promoting some useful end.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:16
verses.text: It would look as if I were bent on starting problems too hard for him to solve.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:17
verses.text: It is better to wait for the answer which he probably means to send.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:18
verses.text: For I am well aware that he has other subjects to occupy him which are more serious and urgent than this question of mine.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:19
verses.text: Your holiness will readily understand this if you read what he wrote to me a year later when my messenger was returning.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:20
verses.text: The following is an extract from his letter:  "A most trying time has come upon us in which I have found it better to hold my peace than to speak.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:21
verses.text: Consequently my studies have ceased, that I may not give occasion to what Appius calls 'the eloquence of dogs.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:22
verses.text: ' For this reason I have not been able to send any answer to your two learned and brilliant letters.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:23
verses.text: Not, indeed, that I think anything in them needs correction, but that I recall the Apostle's words: 'One judges in this way, another in that; let every man give full expression to his own opinion.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:24
verses.text: ' All that a lofty intellect can draw from the well of holy scripture has been drawn by you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:25
verses.text: So much your reverence must allow me to say in praise of your ability.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:26
verses.text: But though in any discussion between us our joint object is the advancement of learning, our rivals and especially the heretics will ascribe any difference of opinion between us to mutual jealousy.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:27
verses.text: For my part, however, I am resolved to love you, to look up to you, to reverence and admire you, and to defend your opinions as my own.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:28
verses.text: I have also in a dialogue which I have recently brought out made allusion to your holiness in suitable terms.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:29
verses.text: Let us, rather, then, strain every nerve to banish from the churches that most pernicious heresy, which feigns repentance that it may have liberty to teach in our churches.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:30
verses.text: For were it to come out into the light of day, it would be expelled and die".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:32
verses.text: You can see, worshipful brother, from this reply that my friend does not refuse to answer my inquiry; he postpones it because he is condemned to give his time to more urgent matters.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:33
verses.text: Moreover, that he is well disposed towards me is clear from his friendly warning that a controversy between us begun in all charity and in the interests of learning may be misconstrued by jealous and heretical persons as due to mutual illfeeling.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:34
verses.text: No; it will be better for the public to have both together, his explanation as well as my inquiry.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:35
verses.text: For, as I shall have to thank him for instructing me if he is able to explain the matter, the discussion will be of no small advantage when it comes to the knowledge of the world.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:36
verses.text: Those who come after us will not only know what view they ought to take of a subject thus fully argued but will also learn how under the divine mercy brothers in affection may dispute a difficult question and yet preserve each other's esteem.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:38
verses.text: On the other hand, if I were to publish the letter in which I raise this obscure point without the reply in which it may be set at rest, it might circulate widely and reach men who "comparing themselves," as the Apostle says, "with themselves," would misconstrue a motive which they could not understand, and would explain my feeling towards one whom I love and esteem for his immense services not as it would appear to them (for it would be invisible to them) but as their own fancy and malice would dictate.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:39
verses.text: Now this is a danger which, so far as in me lies, I am bound to guard against.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:40
verses.text: But if a document which I am unwilling to publish is published without my consent and placed in hands from which I would withhold it, then I shall have to resign myself to the will of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:41
verses.text: Indeed, had I wished to keep my words permanently undivulged I should never have sent them to any one.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:42
verses.text: For if (though I hope it may not be so) chance or necessity shall prevent any reply being ever given me, my letter of inquiry is still bound sooner or later to come to light.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:43
verses.text: Nor will it be useless to those who read it; for, although they will nor find what they seek, they will learn how much better it is, when one is uninformed, to put questions than to make assertions; and in the meantime those whom they consult will work out the points raised by me, laying aside contention and in the interests of learning and charity trying to obtain sound opinions about them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:44
verses.text: Thus they will either arrive at the solutions they desire, or their faculties will be quickened and they will learn from the investigation that farther inquiry is useless.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:45
verses.text: At present, however, as I have no reason to despair of an answer from my friend I have decided not to publish the letter I have sent him, and I trust, my dear comrade, that this decision may commend itself to you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:46
verses.text: It should do so, for you have not asked for my letter so much as for the answer to it; and this I would gladly send you if I had it to send.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:47
verses.text: It is true that in your epistle you speak of "the lucid demonstration of my wisdom which in virtue of my life the Giver of light has bestowed upon me"; and if by this you mean not the way in which I have stated the problem but a solution which I have obtained of the point in question, I should like to gratify your wish.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:48
verses.text: But I must admit that I have so far failed to discover how the soul can derive its sin from Adam (a truth which it is unlawful to question) and yet not itself be derived from Adam.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:49
verses.text: At present I think it better to sift the matter farther than to dogmatize rashly.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:51
verses.text: Your letter speaks of "many old men and persons educated by learned priests whom you have failed to recall to your modest way of thinking, and to a statement of the case which is truth itself".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:52
verses.text: You do not, however, explain what this mode of expression is.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:53
verses.text: If your old men hold fast what they have received from learned priests, how comes it that you are troubled by a boorish mob of unlettered clerics? On the other hand, if the old men and the unlettered clerics have wickedly departed from the priests' teachings, surely these latter are the persons to correct them and restrain them from controversial excesses.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:54
verses.text: Again when you say that "you as a new-fledged and inexperienced teacher have been afraid to tamper with the doctrines handed down by great and famous bishops, and that you have been loth to draw men into a better path lest you should cast discredit on the dead," do you not imply that in refusing to agree with you the objects of your solicitude are but preferring the tradition of great and famous bishops to the views of a new-fledged and inexperienced teacher? Of their conduct in the matter I say nothing, but I am most anxious to learn that "mode of expression which is truth itself," not the thing expressed, but the mode of expression.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:56
verses.text: For you have made it sufficiently plain to me that you disapprove of those who assert that men's souls are derived from that of the protoplast and propagated from one generation to another; but as your letter does not inform me, I have no means of knowing on what grounds and from what passages of scripture you have shewn this view to be false.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:57
verses.text: What does commend itself to you is not clear either from your letter to the brothers at Caesarea or from that which you have lately addressed to me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:58
verses.text: Only I see that you believe and write that "God has been, is, and will be the maker of men, and that there is nothing either in heaven or on earth which does not owe its existence wholly to Him".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:59
verses.text: This is of course a truism which nobody can call in question.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:60
verses.text: But as you affirm that souls are not propagated, you ought to explain out of what God makes them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:61
verses.text: Is it out of some pre-existing material, or is it out of nothing? For it is impossible that you should hold the opinion of Origen, Priscillian, and other heretics that it is for deeds done in a former life that souls are confined in earthly and mortal bodies.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:62
verses.text: This opinion is, indeed, flatly contradicted by the apostle who says of Jacob and Esau that before they were born they had done neither good nor evil.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:63
verses.text: Your view of the matter, then, is known to me though only partially, but of your reasons for supposing it to be true I know nothing.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:64
verses.text: This was why in a former letter I asked you to send me your confession of faith, the one which you were vexed to find that one of your presbyters had signed dishonestly.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:65
verses.text: I now again ask you for this, as well as for any passages of scripture which you have brought to bear on the question.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:66
verses.text: For you say in your letter to the brothers at Caesarea that you "have resolved to have all definitions of dogma reviewed by lay judges, sitting by general invitation, and investigating all points touching the faith".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:67
verses.text: And you continue: "the divine mercy has made it possible for them to put forward their views in a positive and definite form, which your modest ability has reinforced with a great weight of evidence".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:68
verses.text: Now it is this "great weight of evidence" which I am so anxious to obtain.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:69
verses.text: For, so far as I can see, your one aim has been to refute your opponents when they deny that our souls are the handiwork of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:70
verses.text: If they hold such a view, you are right in thinking that it should be condemned.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:71
verses.text: Were they to say the same thing of our bodies, they would be forced to retract it, or else be held up to execration.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:72
verses.text: For what Christian can deny that every single human body is the work of God? Yet when we admit that they are of divine origin we do not mean to deny that they are humanly engendered.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:73
verses.text: When therefore it is asserted that our souls are procreated from a kind of immaterial seed, and that they, like our bodies, come to us from our parents, yet are made souls by the working of God, it is not by human guesses that the assertion is to be refuted, but by the witness of divine scripture.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:74
verses.text: Numbers of passages may indeed be quoted from the sacred books which have canonical authority, to prove that our souls are God's handiwork.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:75
verses.text: But such passages only refute those who deny that each several human soul is made by God; not at all those who while they admit this contend that, like our bodies, they are formed by divine agency through the instrumentality of parents.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:76
verses.text: To refute these you must look for unmistakable texts; or, if you have already discovered such, shew your affection by communicating them to me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:77
verses.text: For though I seek them most diligently I fail to find them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:78
verses.text: As stated shortly by yourself (at the end of your letter to the brothers at Caesarea) your dilemma is as follows: "inasmuch as I am your son and disciple and have but recently by God's help come to consider these mysteries, I beg you with your priestly wisdom to teach me which of two opposite views I ought to hold.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:79
verses.text: Am I to maintain that souls are transmitted by generation, and that they are derived in some mysterious way from Adam our first-formed father? Or am I with your brothers and the priests who are here to hold that God has been, is, and will be the author and maker of all things and all men?"  6.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:80
verses.text: Of the two alternatives which you thus put forward you wish to be urged to choose one or other; and this would be the course of wisdom if your alternatives were so contrary that the choice of one would involve the rejection of the other.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:81
verses.text: But as it is, instead of selecting one of them a man may say that they are both true.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:82
verses.text: He may maintain that the souls of all mankind are derived from Adam our first-formed father, and yet believe and assert that God has been, is, and will be the author and maker of all things and all men.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:83
verses.text: How on your principles is such a man to be confuted? Shall we say: "If they are transmitted by generation God is not their author, for He does not make them?" In that case he will reply: "Bodies too are engendered and not made by God; on your shewing, then He is not their author".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:84
verses.text: Will any one maintain that God is the maker of no bodies but Adam's which He made out of the dust and Eve's which He formed out of Adam's side; and that other bodies are not made by Him because they are engendered by human parents?  7.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:85
verses.text: If your opponents go so far in maintaining the derivation of souls as to deny that they are made and formed by God, you may use this argument as a weapon to confute them so far as God's help enables you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:86
verses.text: But if, while they assert that the soul's beginnings come from Adam first and then from a man's parents, they at the same time hold that the soul in every man is created and formed by God the author of all things, they can only be confuted out of scripture.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:87
verses.text: Search therefore till you find a passage that is neither obscure nor capable of a double meaning; or if you have already found one, hand it on to me as I have begged you to do.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:88
verses.text: But if, like myself, you have so far failed to discover any such passage, you must still strain every nerve to confute those who say that souls are in no sense God's handiwork.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:89
verses.text: This seems to be your opponents position, for in your first letter you write that "they have secretly whispered scandalous doctrines and have forsaken your communion and the obedience of the church on account of this foolish, nay impious opinion".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:90
verses.text: Against such men defend and uphold by every possible expedient the doctrine you have laid down in the same letter, that God has been, is, and will be the maker of souls; and that everything in heaven and on earth owes its existence wholly to Him.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:91
verses.text: For this is true of every creature; and as such is to be believed, asserted, defended, and proved.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:92
verses.text: God has been, is, and will be the author and maker of all things and all men as you have told your fellow-bishops of the province of Caesarea, exhorting them to adopt the doctrine by the example of your brothers and fellow-priests.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:93
verses.text: But there are two quite distinct dilemmas: (1) Is God the author and maker of all souls and bodies (the true view), or is there something in nature which He has not made (a view which is wholly erroneous)? (2) If souls are undoubtedly God's handiwork, does He make them directly, or indirectly by propagation? It is in dealing with this second dilemma that I would have you to be sober and vigilant.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:94
verses.text: Else in refuting the propagation-theory you may fall incautiously into the heresy of Pelagius.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:95
verses.text: Everybody knows that human bodies are propagated by generation; yet if we are right in saying that all human souls—and not only those of Adam and Eve—are created by God, it is clear that to assert their transmission by generation is not to deny their divine origin.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:96
verses.text: For in this view God makes the soul as He makes the body, indirectly by a process of generation.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:97
verses.text: If the truth condemns this as an error, some fresh argument must be sought to confute it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:98
verses.text: No persons could better advise you on the point (if only they were within reach) than those dead worthies whom you feared to discredit by drawing men away from them into a better path.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:99
verses.text: They were, you said, great and famous bishops while you were a new-fledged and inexperienced teacher; thus you were loth to tamper with their doctrines.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:100
verses.text: Would that I could know on what passages these great men rested their opinion that souls are transmitted! For in your letter to the brothers at Caesarea, you speak of their view with a total disregard of their authority, as a new invention, an unheard-of doctrine; though we all know that, error as it may be, it is no novelty but old and of ancient date.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:102
verses.text: Now when we have reason to be doubtful about a point, we need not doubt that we are right in doubting.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:103
verses.text: There is no doubt but that we ought to doubt things that are doubtful.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:104
verses.text: For instance, the Apostle has no doubt about doubting whether he was in the body or out of the body when he was carried up into the third heaven.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:105
verses.text: Whether it was thus or thus, he says, I know not; God knows.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:106
verses.text: Why may not I, then, so long as I have no light, doubt whether my soul comes to me by generation or unengendered? Why may I not be doubtful about this, so long as I do not doubt that in either case it is the work of God most high? Why may I not say; "I know that my soul owes its existence to God and is altogether His handiwork; but whether it comes by generation, as the body does, or unengendered, as was Adam's soul, I know not; God knows".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:107
verses.text: You wish me to assert positively one view or the other.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:108
verses.text: I might do so if I knew which was right.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:109
verses.text: You may have some light on the point, and if so you will find me keener to learn what I know not than to teach what I know.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:110
verses.text: But if, like myself, you are in the dark, you should pray, as I do, that either through one of His servants, or with His own lips, He would teach us who said to His disciples: "Be not ye called masters; for one is your master, even Christ".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:111
verses.text: Yet such knowledge is only expedient for us when He knows it to be expedient who knows both what He has to teach and what we ought to learn.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:112
verses.text: Nevertheless, to you, my dear friend, I confess my eagerness.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:113
verses.text: Still much as I desire to know this after which you seek, I would sooner know when the desire of all nations shall come and when the kingdom of the saints will be set up, than how my soul has come to its earthly abode.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:114
verses.text: But when His disciples (who are our apostles) put this question to the all-knowing Christ, they were told: "It is not yours to know the times or the seasons which the Father hath put in His own power".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:115
verses.text: What if Christ, who knows what is expedient for us, knows this knowledge not to be expedient? Through Him I know that it is not ours to know the times which God has placed in His own power; but concerning the origin of souls, I am ignorant whether it is or is not ours to know.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:116
verses.text: If I could be sure that such knowledge is not for us, I should cease not only to dogmatize, but even to inquire.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:117
verses.text: As it is, though the subject is so deep and dark that my fear of becoming a rash teacher is almost greater than my eagerness to learn the truth, I still wish to know it if I can do so.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:118
verses.text: It may be that the knowledge for which the psalmist prays: "Lord, make me to know mine end," is much more necessary; yet I would that my beginning also might be revealed to me.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:120
verses.text: But even as touching this I must not be ungrateful to my Master.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:121
verses.text: I know that the human soul is spiritual not corporeal, that it is endowed with reason and intelligence, and that it is not of God's essence but a thing created.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:122
verses.text: It is both mortal and immortal: the first because it is subject to corruption and separable from the life of God in which it is alone blessed, the second because its consciousness must ever continue and form the source of its happiness or woe.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:123
verses.text: It does not, it is true, owe its immersion in the flesh to acts done before the flesh; yet in man it is never without sin, not even when "its life has been but for one day".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:124
verses.text: Of those engendered of the seed of Adam no man is born without sin, and it is necessary even for babes to be born anew in Christ by the grace of regeneration.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:125
verses.text: All this I know concerning the soul, and it is much; the greater part of it, indeed, is not only knowledge but matter of faith as well.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:126
verses.text: I rejoice to have learned it all and I can truly say that I know it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:127
verses.text: If there are things of which I am still ignorant (as whether God creates souls by generation or apart from it—for that He does create them I have no doubt) I would sooner know the truth than be ignorant of it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:128
verses.text: But so long as I cannot know it I had rather suspend my judgment than assert what is plainly contrary to an indisputable truth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:130
verses.text: You, my brother, ask me to decide for you whether men's souls as made by the Creator come like their bodies by generation from Adam, or whether like his soul they are made without generation and separately for each individual.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:131
verses.text: For in one way or the other we both admit that they are God's handiwork.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:132
verses.text: Suffer me then in turn to ask you a question.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:133
verses.text: Can a soul derive original sin from a source from which it is not itself derived? For unless we are to fall into the detestable heresy of Pelagius, we must both of us allow that all souls do derive original sin from Adam.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:134
verses.text: And if you cannot answer my question, pray give me leave to confess my ignorance alike of your question and of my own.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:135
verses.text: But if you already know what I ask, teach me and then I will teach you what you wish to know.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:136
verses.text: Pray do not be displeased with me for taking this line, for though I have given you no positive answer to your question, I have shewn you how you ought to put it.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:137
verses.text: When once you are clear about that, you may be quite positive where you have been doubtful.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:138
verses.text: This much I have thought it right to write to your holiness seeing that you are so sure that the transmission of souls is a doctrine to be rejected.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:139
verses.text: Had I been writing to maintainers of the doctrine I might perhaps have shewn how ignorant they are of what they fancy they know and how cautious they should be not to make rash assertions.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:140
verses.text: It may perhaps perplex you that in my friend's answer as I have quoted it in this letter he mentions two letters of mine to which he has no time to reply.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:141
verses.text: Only one of these deals with the problem of the soul; in the other I have asked light on another difficulty.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:142
verses.text: Again when he urges me to take more pains for the removal from the church of a most pernicious heresy, he alludes to the error of the Pelagians which I earnestly beg you, my brother, at all hazards to avoid.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:143
verses.text: In speculating or arguing on the origin of the soul you must never give place to this heresy with its insidious suggestions.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:144
verses.text: For there is no soul, save that of the one Mediator, which does not derive original sin from Adam.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 147:145
verses.text: Original sin is that which is fastened on the soul at its birth and from which it can only be freed by being born again.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 148:1
verses.text: Letter CXLV.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 148:2
verses.text: To Exuperantius.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 148:3
verses.text: Jerome advises Exuperantius, a Roman soldier, to come to Bethlehem and with his brother Quintilian to become a monk.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 148:4
verses.text: According to Palladius (H.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 148:5
verses.text: L.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 148:6
verses.text: c.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 148:7
verses.text: lxxx.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 148:8
verses.text: ) Exuperantius came to Jerome but went away again 'unable to endure his violence and ill-will.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 148:9
verses.text: ' The date of the letter is unknown.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 148:10
verses.text: Among all the favours that my friendship with the reverend brother Quintilian has conferred upon me the greatest is this that he has introduced me in the spirit to you whom I do not know personally.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 148:11
verses.text: Who can fail to love a man who, while he wears the cloak and uniform of a soldier does the work of a prophet, and while his outer man gives promise of quite a different character, overcomes this by the inner man which is formed after the image of the creator.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 148:12
verses.text: I come forward therefore to challenge you to an interchange of letters and beg that you will often give me occasion to reply to you that I may for the future feel less constraint in writing.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 148:13
verses.text: For the present I will content myself by suggesting to your discretion that you should bear in mind the apostle's words: "Art thou bound unto a wife? Seek not to be loosed.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 148:14
verses.text: Art thou loosed from a wife? Seek not a wife;" that is, seek not that binding which is contrary to loosing.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 148:15
verses.text: He who has contracted the obligations of marriage, is bound, and he who is bound is a slave; on the other hand he who is loosed is free.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 148:16
verses.text: Since therefore you rejoice in the freedom of Christ, since your life is better than your profession, since you are all but on the housetop of which the Saviour speaks; you ought not to come down to take your clothes, you ought not to look behind you, you ought not having put your hand to the plough, then to let it go.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 148:17
verses.text: Rather, if you can, imitate Joseph and leave your garment in the hand of your Egyptian mistress, that naked you may follow your Lord and Saviour.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 148:18
verses.text: For in the gospel He says: "Whosoever doth not leave all that he hath and bear his cross and come after me cannot be my disciple".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 148:19
verses.text: Cast from you the burthen of the things of this world, and seek not those riches which in the gospel are compared to the humps of camels.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 148:20
verses.text: Naked and unencumbered fly up to heaven; masses of gold will but impede the wings of your virtue.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 148:21
verses.text: I do not speak thus because I know you to be covetous, but because I have a notion that your object in remaining so long in the army is to fill that purse which the Lord has commanded you to empty.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 148:22
verses.text: For they who have possessions and riches are bidden to sell all that they have and to give to the poor and then to follow the Saviour.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 148:23
verses.text: Thus if your worship is rich already you ought to fulfil the command and sell your riches; or if you are still poor you ought not to amass what you will have to pay away.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 148:24
verses.text: Christ accepts the sacrifices made for him according as he who makes them has a willing mind.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 148:25
verses.text: Never were any men poorer than the apostles; yet never any left more for the Lord than they.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 148:26
verses.text: The poor widow in the gospel who cast but two mites into the treasury was set before all the men of wealth because she gave all that she had.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 148:27
verses.text: So it should be with you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 148:28
verses.text: Seek not for wealth which you will have to pay away; but rather give up that which you have already acquired that Christ may know his new recruit to be brave and resolute, and then when you are a great way off His Father will run with joy to meet you.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 148:29
verses.text: He will give you a robe, will put a ring upon your finger, and will kill for you the fatted calf.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 148:30
verses.text: Then when you are freed from all encumbrances God will soon make a way for you to cross the sea to me with your reverend brother Quintilian.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 148:31
verses.text: I have now knocked at the door of friendship: if you open it to me you will find me a frequent visitor.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 149:1
verses.text: Letter CXLVI.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 149:2
verses.text: To Evangelus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 149:3
verses.text: Jerome refutes the opinion of those who make deacons equal to presbyters, but in doing so himself makes presbyters equal to bishops.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 149:4
verses.text: The date of the letter is unknown.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 149:6
verses.text: We read in Isaiah the words, "the fool will speak folly," and I am told that some one has been mad enough to put deacons before presbyters, that is, before bishops.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 149:7
verses.text: For when the apostle clearly teaches that presbyters are the same as bishops, must not a mere server of tables and of widows be insane to set himself up arrogantly over men through whose prayers the body and blood of Christ are produced? Do you ask for proof of what I say? Listen to this passage: "Paul and Timotheus, the servants of Jesus Christ, to all the saints in Christ Jesus which are at Philippi with the bishops and deacons".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 149:8
verses.text: Do you wish for another instance? In the Acts of the Apostles Paul thus speaks to the priests of a single church: "Take heed unto yourselves and to all the flock, in the which the Holy Ghost hath made you bishops, to feed the church of God which He purchased with His own blood".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 149:9
verses.text: And lest any should in a spirit of contention argue that there must then have been more bishops than one in a single church, there is the following passage which clearly proves a bishop and a presbyter to be the same.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 149:10
verses.text: Writing to Titus the apostle says: "For this cause left I thee in Crete, that thou shouldest set in order the things that are wanting, and ordain presbyters in every city, as I had appointed thee: if any be blameless, the husband of one wife, having faithful children not accused of riot or unruly.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 149:11
verses.text: For a bishop must be blameless as the steward of God".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 149:12
verses.text: And to Timothy he says: "Neglect not the gift that is in thee, which was given thee by prophecy, with the laying on of the hands of the presbytery".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 149:13
verses.text: Peter also says in his first epistle: "The presbyters which are among you I exhort, who am your fellow-presbyter and a witness of the sufferings of Christ and also a partaker of the glory that shall be revealed: feed the flock of Christ…taking the oversight thereof not by constraint but willingly, according unto God".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 149:14
verses.text: In the Greek the meaning is still plainer, for the word used is επισκοποῦντες , that is to say, overseeing, and this is the origin of the name overseer or bishop.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 149:15
verses.text: But perhaps the testimony of these great men seems to you insufficient.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 149:16
verses.text: If so, then listen to the blast of the gospel trumpet, that son of thunder, the disciple whom Jesus loved and who reclining on the Saviour's breast drank in the waters of sound doctrine.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 149:17
verses.text: One of his letters begins thus: "The presbyter unto the elect lady and her children whom I love in the truth;" and another thus: "The presbyter unto the well-beloved Gaius whom I love in the truth".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 149:18
verses.text: When subsequently one presbyter was chosen to preside over the rest, this was done to remedy schism and to prevent each individual from rending the church of Christ by drawing it to himself.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 149:19
verses.text: For even at Alexandria from the time of Mark the Evangelist until the episcopates of Heraclas and Dionysius the presbyters always named as bishop one of their own number chosen by themselves and set in a more exalted position, just as an army elects a general, or as deacons appoint one of themselves whom they know to be diligent and call him archdeacon.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 149:20
verses.text: For what function, excepting ordination, belongs to a bishop that does not also belong to a presbyter? It is not the case that there is one church at Rome and another in all the world beside.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 149:21
verses.text: Gaul and Britain, Africa and Persia, India and the East worship one Christ and observe one rule of truth.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 149:22
verses.text: If you ask for authority, the world outweighs its capital.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 149:23
verses.text: Wherever there is a bishop, whether it be at Rome or at Engubium, whether it be at Constantinople or at Rhegium, whether it be at Alexandria or at Zoan, his dignity is one and his priesthood is one.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 149:24
verses.text: Neither the command of wealth nor the lowliness of poverty makes him more a bishop or less a bishop.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 149:25
verses.text: All alike are successors of the apostles.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 149:27
verses.text: But you will say, how comes it then that at Rome a presbyter is only ordained on the recommendation of a deacon? To which I reply as follows.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 149:28
verses.text: Why do you bring forward a custom which exists in one city only? Why do you oppose to the laws of the Church a paltry exception which has given rise to arrogance and pride? The rarer anything is the more it is sought after.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 149:29
verses.text: In India pennyroyal is more costly than pepper.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 149:30
verses.text: Their fewness makes deacons persons of consequence while presbyters are less thought of owing to their great numbers.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 149:31
verses.text: But even in the church of Rome the deacons stand while the presbyters seat themselves, although bad habits have by degrees so far crept in that I have seen a deacon, in the absence of the bishop, seat himself among the presbyters and at social gatherings give his blessing to them.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 149:32
verses.text: Those who act thus must learn that they are wrong and must give heed to the apostles words: "it is not reason that we should leave the word of God and serve tables".

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 149:33
verses.text: They must consider the reasons which led to the appointment of deacons at the beginning.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 149:34
verses.text: They must read the Acts of the Apostles and bear in mind their true position.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 149:35
verses.text: Of the names presbyter and bishop the first denotes age, the second rank.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 149:36
verses.text: In writing both to Titus and to Timothy the apostle speaks of the ordination of bishops and of deacons, but says not a word of the ordination of presbyters; for the fact is that the word bishops includes presbyters also.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 149:37
verses.text: Again when a man is promoted it is from a lower place to a higher.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 149:38
verses.text: Either then a presbyter should be ordained a deacon, from the lesser office, that is, to the more important, to prove that a presbyter is inferior to a deacon; or if on the other hand it is the deacon that is ordained presbyter, this latter should recognize that, although he may be less highly paid than a deacon, he is superior to him in virtue of his priesthood.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 149:39
verses.text: In fact as if to tell us that the traditions handed down by the apostles were taken by them from the old testament, bishops, presbyters and deacons occupy in the church the same positions as those which were occupied by Aaron, his sons, and the Levites in the temple.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 150:1
verses.text: Letter CXLVII.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 150:2
verses.text: To Sabinianus.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 150:3
verses.text: Jerome writes in severe but moderate language to Sabinianus, a deacon, calling on him to repent of his sins.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 150:4
verses.text: Of these he recounts at length the two most serious, an act of adultery at Rome and an attempt to seduce a nun at Bethlehem.

verses.name: Jerome: Letters 150:5
verses.text: The date of the letter is uncertain.
